column2: Many pastors will preach today on the European arms situation and will urge a "hands-off" policy for the United States. Some clergymen will discuss the recent archaeological discoveries in Palestine throwing light on Bible narratives.

Columbia and St. John's baseball supporters had a preview of their teams yesterday at Baker Field and the Lions won, 3 -- 2. Considering the early stage of the season, the practice game was a well-played affair and Blue and White supporters were impressed by their team's defensive ability. St. John's flashed a
As the vast army of New York trout anglers impatiently awaits the opening of the season next Saturday, the question uppermost in all minds is, "Where can I go fishing?"

The new code of contract bridge rules goes into effect throughout the world today, under the agreement reached by the three legislating bodies, the Whist Club of New York, the Portland Club of London and the Commission Francais du Bridge.

Revised regulations of the State Department of Education, effective Jan. 1, 1938, are expected to reduce the "high mortality" of candidates for the title of certified public accountant and place examination results on a basis comparable with those of other professions.

CHICAGO, March 30. -- A slight expansion of loans and a slower rise in deposits in banks in this city in the first two months of the year were disclosed today in responses to calls for statements as of March 4 by the Controller of the Currency and the State Auditor. Idle cash remained almost stationary.

DUBLIN, March 29. -- Developments that have taken place in the Irish Free State this week will materially affect the future of ordered government in this country. With unexpected decision Eamon de Valera's administration has moved against subversive radical elements that have become worrisome.

PHILADELPHIA, March 30. -- The premiere for this country of Erwin Piscator's "An American Tragedy," another adaptation of Theodore Dreiser's novel, will be presented by the Hedgerow Theatre Players of Moylan-Rose Valley on April 20.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 30. -- Princeton University will introduce a new program of upper class study in the architectural section of its Department of Art and Archeology next year, continuing the series of curricular changes which have been adopted in the last two years, according to an announcement today by Professor Sherley W. Morgan director of the School of Architecture.

THE figures of the 1934-5 season of the Metropolitan Opera Association are published at the end of this article. They are not of a spectacular character, if only for the fact that this season Mr. Gatti was compelled to curtail expenses beyond the point at which he might have liked to conclude his last season as director.

The little Wisconsin village of Sac Prairie is the scene of this, as of the other stories about Judge Peck, who is Mr. Derleth's pet sleuth. The judge and his friend, Dr. Considine, have just returned from a fishing trip. They learn that during their absence two persons have died and a third is at the point of death.

CHICAGO, March 30. -- Approximately an hour will be clipped from the present schedule of the Broadway Limited, crack train of the Pennsylvania Railroad between Chicago and New York, with the advent of the daylight saving time April 28.

The City College baseball team opened its 1935 season by defeating an alumni nine, 9 to 7, yesterday at Lewisohn Stadium in a game cut to eight innings by agreement. Three varsity pitchers held the graduates to five hits, but one was a home run by Halsey Josephson, former Lavender mound ace, with one on base in the first inning.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., March 30. -- At the opening this afternoon of the Larchmont Yacht Club's Saturday sailing dinghy program the experiment was tried of racing all the boats in one class instead of separating them, and there were some surprising results.

BERLIN, March 30. -- A sentence of death by beheading was imposed upon Frau Charlotte Juenemann, 24-year-old mother, today, ending one of the most remarkable cases with which the Berlin criminal court has dealt in years. The court decided that she had deliberately starved to death her three small children.

IT is a question whether this new volume in the Appleton Biographies Series is not more romance than biography. Its sources are, patently, more in imagination than in fact. But the author seems to think that in many conjoined imaginations truth may be found.

PALM BEACH. -- In line with the movement to come a month earlier, stay a month longer, launched last Spring by a group of colonists, April's exodus this year will be unusually small. Half the homes are remaining open until mid-May and many until June.

POPULATION maps of New Mexico are almost entirely white and yellow. The white indicates less than two inhabitants per square mile; the yellow from two to six. The Mescalero Apache Reservation is white on population maps, purple on economic maps.

WHETHER the Blue Eagle has been brought finally to earth, "viewing its own feather on the fatal dart," or whether it is merely gathering strength for a new and less spectacular flight, General Johnson has written an account of it which is as enthusiastic, as impulsive and as colorful as his administration of NRA.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- John D. Rockefeller Jr. owns 5,093,870 shares of the Socony Vacuum Oil Company, or 15.7 per cent of the total shares of that company, which is seeking permanent registration on the New York Stock Exchange. This was shown in his listing today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Felix M. Warburg, national chairman of the United Jewish Appeal, announced yesterday that Jews in New York City and Westchester, Nassau and Suffolk Counties would be asked to contribute $1,250,000 in the forthcoming Greater New York Campaign. The national quota is $3,250,000.
BASLE. -- How far the barter and clearing arrangements have gone in Europe is indicated by these facts in reports reaching the World Bank:

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- "The Parthians," wrote the old Greek chronicler, "made as if to flee after a discharge of arrows, and then, wheeling about, launched another volley at the oncoming foe, deceived in thinking them in retreat."

MONTREAL, March 30. -- Their defense unyielding under the brunt of some of the hardest charges they have been called on to face this season, the Montreal Maroons held the New York Rangers to a tie, 3 to 3, tonight in the second game of their play-off series, and earned the right to oppose the Toronto Maple Leafs for the Stanley Cup and the world's hockey championship.

PARIS, March 30. -- France's crack reserve troops today started three months of manoeuvres on the eastern frontier. The war training period, it was learned, was started earlier than last year partly because of the situation created by German rearmament.

Children will enjoy this volume chiefly for its maps. In small but clear and delightful fashion the animals are placed in their native habitats, from the mountain lion and bison of the United States to the three-toed sloth of Central America and the platypus of Australia.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- Many Germans are fleeing the Reich to get away from Nazi rule, according to immigration figures, which show that the number of Germans who entered this country last year was more than double the number entering in 1933.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP). -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt tonight had two beautiful new Easter gowns she didn't even know about yesterday -- a good-will gift from the Philippines.

Two boys at the end of their senior year in high school take a 2,250-mile canoe trip from Minneapolis to Hudson Bay, the first time that an all-water trip had ever been made from Minnesota to the North Atlantic Ocean. They financed themselves by writing regular articles for The Minnesota Star.

ST. LOUIS, March 29. -- Special sales by department stores in the Eighth Federal Reserve District have increased the turnover materially, but withal the retail situation is not up to the level of previous weeks and is generally reported to be about 8 per cent ahead of that of a year ago.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 30. -- The Dodgers may need an extra hurler or two to back up their "Big Four" of Mungo, Benge, Leonard and Babich, but there is no question that the team is well fixed in infield material when a pair of bright prospects like Johnny McCarthy and Glenn Chapman can be dropped without affecting a line-up that appears ready for the opening of the season.
The appointment of William A. Boring as Dean Emeritus of the Faculty of Architecture in Columbia University was announced yesterday by Frank D. Fackenthal, secretary of the university.

WITH Stravinsky and John McCormack among its guest artists and a "first performance" of works by Bartok, Malipiero and Werner Janssen, the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Foundation has announced five programs in three days for the Festival of Chamber Music to be held at the Library of Congress in Washington. The programs follow:

PARIS, March 29. -- Seldom has there been in France such a complete disarray of opinion as has developed since Germany declared herself liberated from the armaments restrictions of the Treaty of Versailles.

BUDAPEST, March 30. -- Hungary will elect 183 Members of Parliament tomorrow in an open ballot, mostly in the agricultural districts. A week hence the remainder of Parliament will be elected in a secret ballot.

TO provide an autogiro with folding wings and arrange a clutch so that it can be driven along the road, as proposed by the Bureau of Air Commerce, is a constructive step. Further experimentation on the part of Harold F. Pitcairn here and of Juan de la Cierva abroad with an autogiro capable of taking off without forward run, and, indeed, with chocks under the wheels, will be watched with deep interest.

SIGMUND SPAETH, who has auditioned several aspiring amateurs at WEVD, reports he is convinced plenty of good talent is available if some one will take the trouble to develop it properly. He finds lack of microphone experience generally evident, but points out this can be remedied.

THE appearance this week of first published report of survey committee of New York City public schools is the step in what it is hoped will be one of the most far-reaching studies of education ever made in this country.

There appeared in a recent issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES an editorial entitled "Helping the Railroads," which in effect urged Federal regulation of highway transport comparable to that now exercised over the railroads.
TOKYO, March 30. -- "There is no Locarno in the Far East," said a Foreign Office spokesman tonight.

Announcement was made here yesterday of the appointment of Stephen J. Pigott as managing director of the engineering and ship-building works of John Brown Co., Ltd., of Clydebank, Scotland. Mr. Pigott has been with the company nearly twenty-five years and he is credited jointly with the chief engineer of the Cunard Line with having designed the entire machinery plant of the liner Queen Mary, now under construction at the Clydebank yard.

IT is not a light task to dig out the essential nature of "Blind Men Crossing a Bridge." Described the book can be, and easily, for it fits well into the romantic pigeonhole. If Wordsworth had written novels, "Blind Men" might have been his.

MIKELL HARE was one of those fiction heroines who had been brought up to be extremely decorative and mistress of all the social graces. At 21 her butterfly was rudely smashed. Her pretty, frivolous mother married a millionaire and shunted Mikell off to her father.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- With the FERA down to its last $4,000,000, Senate and House leaders predicted today that only direct intervention by President Roosevelt, who is fishing in West Indian waters, would prevent enactment of the $4,880,000,000 Relief Bill in the form agreed by the conference committee yesterday.

SPRING is enhancing reception of the foreign short-wave programs. The louder the reception from abroad, however, the more noticeable is the interference with transmitters on this side of the Atlantic. One of the worst "spots" below 200 meters is between 6,150 to 6,000 kilocycles, in which three of the most reliable of the foreign broadcasters are located, namely, 2RO, Rome; GSA, London, and DJC, Berlin.

BERLIN, March 30. -- The new campaign against Jews is spreading steadily and increasing in virulence. Today the major Nazi organ of Western Germany, the West Deutsche Beobachter, issued a special number devoted to violent attacks on Jews as citizens, as business and professional men and as just plain human beings.

The curse of the Pharaohs has nothing whatever to do with the death of Professor Larkin, the Egyptologist, even though he did dig up the mummy of Teslev I and carry off a lot of treasure from the tomb, but the murderer may have had some hope that such an explanation would be accepted.
CHICAGO, March 30 (AP). -- The railroads will give notice soon after May 1 that they will seek a reduction from the 1929 wage levels which become effective again next Monday.

Employment in a group of key industrial corporations in the United States, selected at random, showed an increase last year of 21 per cent over 1933. The number of employes of these seven corporations was about 556,000 in 1934, against approximately 456,000 in 1933.

The south and west winds have been heavy today with more yellow Panhandle dust. The sun does not shine through, and both inside and outside the atmosphere is murky to look at and irritating to breathe. It is dry and sifts through the window glass to lie like Pittsburgh cinders over everything.

ATLANTA, March 30 (AP). -- A veteran of fairway warfare, a rising young star and a Southern player who has yet to win national notice cracked par today to steal the honors in the opening round of the fifty-four-hole metropolitan open tournament.

CHICAGO, March 29. -- Retail trade this week with the larger department stores here held about even with last year, which, in the opinion of merchandise managers, was rather remarkable because Easter in 1934 fell on April 1. At wholesale, the dollar turnover was somewhat below last year's mark, the amount varying with the house.

Just where the national outboard motorboat championships will be held this year is in doubt. Tulsa, Okla., bid for them, and Oct. 5 and 6 were assigned as the dates. Then Tulsa decided that October was too late in the season.

KANSAS CITY, March 30 (AP). -- As midwestern farmers and government agencies laid plans today to combat the menace of dust storms, the weather changed its tactics and also produced snow, rain and freezing temperatures in a wide area. Four States were hit by the renewed dust storms.

The Institute of Women's Professional Relations, closing a three-day conference on career opportunities at the Hotel Astor yesterday, heard prominent speakers express sharply divergent views on whether political preferment was more important than merit in obtaining a place in public service.

VIENNA, March 29. -- Germany's military conscription decree and subsequent defiant attitude on the question of a Danubian pact have brought a chain of fresh complications to the Schuschnigg government.

Paintings, tapestries, and French, English and Italian period furniture from the collection of the late Mrs. Cooper Hewitt (Lucy Work Hewitt), removed from her residence at 1,115 Fifth Avenue and her country estate, Woodburn Hall, New Windsor, N.Y., will be offered at auction at the American Art Association-Auderson Galleries. Inc., next Wednesday, Thursday, Friday and Saturday afternoons.
THE question whether States can tax radio stations is a major question now facing commercial broadcasters.

OVER Colorado, Texas, Oklahoma, Kansas, Nebraska Missouri and parts of Iowa golden-gray dust streams down from on high. As they gaze up at a metallic sun, distracted farmers talk of the "dust blizzard." But there is no howling gale. The dust settles down gently and smothers the young wheat, the budding leaves on the trees and the blades of grass that constitute the principal sustenance of cattle.

THE raciest melodrama of the new year, you may be surprised to learn, is a product of those British studios which hitherto have been at their best in the leisurely pastures of historical romance. "The Man Who Knew Too Much" slipped quietly into the Mayfair last week while most of us were focusing the spotlight on "Naughty Marietta" and "The Little Colonel."
LONDON, March 30. -- For the second year in succession the British Government proudly announced tonight it had ended its financial year with a handsome budget surplus.

MOSCOW, March 30. -- Soviet Russia's officially inspired press be-spoke United States cooperation in helping keep Europe's peace today as Anglo-Russian security discussions ended with results termed "practical" and "highly satisfactory" by both sides.
SYACUSE, N.Y., March 30 (AP). -- Tivoli Brewing of Detroit went into first place in the American Bowling Congress with a 3,024 team total tonight before a capacity crowd of 2,500.

The Roosevelt International Mercantile Marine Company announced yesterday that George W. Cook had been retired as controller of the company after forty-six years of service and that Solfest Tomasson, his assistant, had been named his successor. The change will become effective immediately.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., March 30. -- Eastern High School of Washington, champion of the District of Columbia, won the Eastern States basketball tournament honors tonight, defeating Brown Prep of Philadelphia by 43 to 29 in the final.

The oldest college sporting rivalry in the world faces its eighty-seventh renewal Saturday when the eight-oared crews of Oxford and Cambridge meet in the University Boat Race on the Thames of England.

HERE is the account of an enterprise undertaken in 1930 by an enthusiastic young Frenchman and carried out at the cost of tremendous effort, suffering danger and finally death itself. It appears from the introduction by Jean Vieuchange that the author, Michel Vieuchange, became obsessed with the idea of going to Smara, a dead and deserted town in South Morocco in the midst of a fearful desert infested with wild and warring tribes.

The appointment of 108 New York University students to leading positions in fifty-one undergraduate clubs, publications and societies at the University Heights centre was announced yesterday by Harold O. Voorhis, university secretary.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- Agitation in Congress for inflation of the currency is at a lower ebb today than probably at any other time since Franklin Delano Roosevelt took over the reins of government on March 4, 1933.
Europe's calendar reads 1935; yet the whole Continent breathes the air of 1912-14.

ROME, March 30. -- Italy does not consider that there has been an open rupture in negotiations with Ethiopia, a government spokesman said tonight in commenting on a dispatch from Addis Ababa that negotiations had broken down.

THE 250th anniversary of Handel's birth could not be allowed to pass unnoticed in the country which has taken him as the pattern of all that composers should be. It is a fact that even Purcell has had to make way for his too successful competitor.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., March 30. -- More than 30 per cent of Smith College's 2,000 students will be housed in the quadrangle unit when the two new buildings, which were announced recently and on which construction will begin this Summer, are completed.

Prison-made goods are still "flooding the retail markets of the country, and although an NRA compact and regulation in some States have checked to a degree the quantities of this merchandise reaching distributers, these goods remain a threat to labor and employment in private industries," the National Retail Dry Goods Association charged yesterday in a statement.
AIKEN, S.C. -- Aiken Winter residents will join with the local citizens this week in celebrating the town's 100th anniversary, a varied program having been planned for Thursday, Friday and Saturday.
PHILADELPHIA, March 30. -- Democracy will be weighed against socialism and fascism by speakers at the annual meeting of the American Academy of Political and Social Science here Friday and Saturday.

Harlem is quiet again after the sudden riots which broke out on the night of March 19 and the early morning of March 20. As quiet is restored, it becomes clear that very serious economic and social distress has existed in Harlem and has created the tension that made the riots possible.

Meetings held recently by committee members for the Jungle Ball, which is to take place on April 12 at the Plaza, have resulted in plans for an elaborate decorative scheme and a fanciful pageant as features of the ball. The entertainment will benefit Briarcliff Holiday House, a home for orphaned children at Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.

TORONTO, March 30. -- Regis (Pep) Kelly, 20-year-old former St. Mivhael's College junior, who quit school to play professional hockey, climaxed his first season as a pro tonight by leading Toronto to the National League championship with a 2-1 overtime victory over the Boston Bruins.
GONE from the world these sixty-five years, enshrined in Westminster Abbey, Charles Dickens declines to rest in peace. His exuberance still irrepressible, he takes his walks abroad.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 30. -- The new Pierce-Arrow Motor Corporation began business today a few hours after Federal Judge John Knight had approved plans for the reorganization of the old Pierce-Arrow Motor Car Company. The court's decree provided a new capital structure and upheld the constitutionality of Section 77b of the amended bankruptcy act, which had been challenged by a creditor of the old company.

In a life span of fifty years the average person puts more than fifty tons of "alleged" food into his body, Dr. Ralph P. Baker of the Pennsylvania Board of Osteopathic Examiners declared yesterday. He spoke to 600 osteopaths at the opening of the annual convention of the Eastern Osteopathic Association, at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

FEW Americans know who made the Washington Monument, that slender finger of stone that rises into the blue from beside the Potomac and dominates Washington. And yet one of our most eminent architects has pronounced it "the noblest architectural structure in America," and it is also probably the best known and the best loved.

NANKING. -- The unexpected collapse of the organized Communist-bandit threat to the important trade centres of Central Szechuan has resulted in an acceleration of Nanking's efforts to extend the central government's political, military and economic influence into this largest and most populous province of China proper.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- All except three of the principal divisions of the Patent Office have shown gains in activities during the first eight months of the current fiscal year, as compared with the same period of 1934, according to Conway P. Coe, Commissioner of Patents.

THE land of the Pharaohs, home of one of the world's most ancient civilizations, is manifesting the modern spirit in buying new automobiles and in initiating the construction of modern through highways," writes Hamilton M. Wright from Cairo, where he is gathering material to use here as a representative of the Egyptian Government.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., March 30. -- The Illinois Recvery Act was held unconstitutional today by Judge Homer W. Hall of the McLean County Court. He also declared inoperative the National Automobile Code as applied to Illinois.

DOWN on lower Broadway in a building that once flaunted the two-headed eagle of imperial Germany the Blue Eagle of the NRA is now supreme. Through red, white and black marble balls that years ago echoed the footsteps of prospective visitors to the Fatherland tread representatives of labor and industry.

A NEW educational field that in recent years has been opened and much cultivated, known in general as orientation, is based, in its narrower application, on the ancient admonition to "Know Thy-self." Mr. Bennett is one of its experts and as Director of Orientation in the Pasadena Junior College he has had much experience in its practical application in the education of young people.

With the best outlook for business they have had since 1929, machine tool builders yesterday completed plans for speeding up second quarter production in order to handle increased business for the government, private industry and foreign sources.

Inspector John J. De Martino, in charge of the uniformed police in Harlem, testified yesterday at the first public hearing of the Mayor's committee investigating the rioting of March 19 that, in the future, if wild rumors that might lead to rioting began to circulate among the Negroes he would use broadcasting stations and every other agency to spread the truth and dispel the rumors.

TOPEKA, March 29. -- Republican leaders of the Middle West who have been working diligently but quietly since last January to start a movement to try to revive party interest in this section were greatly disturbed this week by Governor Landon of Kansas.

LOS ANGELES, March 29. NOW we are having something remotely like a little season again. Outstanding at the moment, and as a matter of fact outstanding in the annals of the local theatre, is the success of "Tobacco Road," with Henry Hull in his original role and Mary Servoss winning many plaudits in the part created by Margaret Wycherly.

HARALD KREUTZBERG'S recent pair of recitals after an absence of something over two years helps to make certain facts increasingly clear. One of them is that he is possessed of a superb talent and the other is that the dance is developing at a phenomenal rate of speed in America.

FOR centuries Germany has prided herself on being "the land of poets and philosophers.'' Whatever shortcomings her "Kultur" may have had in the eyes of other nations, there was no doubt about her rich intellectual life, and her science enjoyed an almost uncanny reputation.

Despite predictions of lower March volume, reports indicate that the month closes with many stores coming nearer to "making" their figures than general sentiment had forecast, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

NO THROUGH ROAD" is a sort of ghost story without the ghosts. Six people in a motor car, returning to Oxford after the races, took the wrong turning, had a breakdown, got completely lost, and drove down a dead-end road that wound up in the farmyard of a dreary old manor house.

The life of Robert E. Lee has all the elements to appeal to young readers Mr. Horn has written with understanding and appreciation of this gallant gentleman and brave soldier, who was as inspiring a figure when he surrendered to General Grant as he was when directing a victorious Confederate campaign.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 29. -- Several industrial companies in the Twelfth Federal Reserve District have reported increases in earnings in the last week, but the Western Pacific and the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railroads showed smaller returns and the Southern Pacific's carloadings decreased in the week ended on March 23.
ROME, March 30. -- The possession of gas masks by employes in Italy's strategic industries was made obligatory today by the Cabinet at a meeting presided over by Premier Mussolini.

HOLLYWOOD. THE industry is contemplating Ernst Lubitsch and his endeavors with speculative eye. His assumption of the Paramount throne is, frankly, an experiment, and Hollywood has ever been just a little shy of experiments.

LONDON, March 30. -- A sudden fall in sterling puzzled the foreign exchange market today since the Belgian clash is regarded as by no means over. All the gold currencies and the dollar turned against the pound. The dollar rate crossed $4.79 1/4, compared with $4.81 3/4 yesterday. French francs closed at 72 25-32, compared with 73 3-16 yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, March 30. -- Appearing to be considerably refreshed after their twenty-four-hour respite, the Giants and Indians once more went to work on each other in the fourth game of their series today, but only the Clevelanders came up with a result to indicate they had benefited any from the rest.

RICHMOND, Va., March 29. -- February trade and industry in the Fifth Federal Reserve District were fully up to seasonal levels in nearly all lines, the Richmond Bank says in its monthly review. Leaders reported were retail trade, coal production and cigarette manufacturing.

MEDFORD, N.J., March 30. -- Excellently handled by her owner, George H. Rogers of Mount Holly, the veteran liver and white pointer, Juliana, added another victory to her long string as she romped off with first prize in the Members Amateur Shooting Dog Stake at the ninth annual competition of the South Jersey Field Trial Club today.

Presidents of the sixteen locals of the Greater New York Council of the Building Service Employes International Union met secretly yesterday afternoon to discuss plans for a strike of elevator operators, building superintendents, janitors, porters and other service employes against approximately half the building owners of Manhattan.

HERE is a tale that sets out deliberately to be that bone of contemporary literary contention -- the proletarian novel. It goes a step further. It sets out deliberately to be an American proletarian novel. It aims to speak the American language.

Bank loans of the thirty-one principal public utility holding and operating companies in the United States at the close of 1934 amounted to $124,027,000, having been reduced $37,528,000, or 23.23 per cent, in the year. They were virtually only one-fourth as large as at the end of 1930, when their sum was $489,409,000, the highest point attained.

THE Actors Equity Association, habitually stern about security for its members, has looked at the Group Theatre for a long time and decided that it is a safe bet. The result is that the Group has received Equity's red badge of economic integrity, not to say courage, and henceforth will not be required to post a bond guaranteeing the salaries of its regular actors.

A COMPLETELY free evening art school, where all the teachers give their services and where all who wish to study may attend, has recently been opened at 149 East Thirty-fourth Street in New York City. Known as the Leonardo da Vinci Art School, it is a reorganization of the same name founded in 1923 by the sculptor Onorio Ruotolo.
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., March 30. -- The NRA Retail Coal Dealers Code was declared unconstitutional today in its application to a Michigan case.

In calling, as he did yesterday, for a statement of the condition of national banks on March 4 last, the Controller of the Currency has again invited the most striking comparison possible to illustrate the gains made in two years by the banking system.

LET'S get down to the business of party frocks and furbelows. Holiday time is here. Girls are home from college, if only for a short and early Easter vacation. Those who don't go away to school are also in a playful mood. "I will dance," is in the air.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., March 30 (AP). -- Pennsylvania's Attorney General, Charles J. Margiotti, emerged from a round of conference tonight with an expression of confidence that a solution of the anthracite mine controversy in this area will be reached.

MOSCOW, March 30. -- The conversations between Anthony Eden, British Lord Privy Seal, and Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Foreign Commissar, ended today in an atmosphere of undisguised optimism, especially on the side of the Russians.
ALUMI, students and professors have long had their intercollegiate conferences. This Spring, for the first time, one is being provided for the forgotten trustee.
MERCERSBURG, Pa., March 30. -- Forest Park High School of Baltimore, defeated Mercersburg Academy, 11 -- 5, today as the local school opened its baseball season.

RYE, N.Y., March 30. -- The opening Spring dinner dance of the Westchester Country Club was held here tonight. An amateur entertainment by residents of Westchester County was a feature of the event, which was attended by 250 persons.

WARRENTON, Va., March 30. -- More than fifty workmen are constructing the permanent courses for the Virginia Gold Cup Race on Broad View, the estate of Alexander Hagner. There will be two courses, one of brush and one of timber, built on the plan of the English courses at Aintree.

THE blossoming of Japanese cherry trees in Washington, an event that draws thousands of visitors to the capital each year, is now at hand. It will be the signal for garden devotees all over the country to sally forth in quest of new bloom worlds to conquer.

The nation learned on Friday, in circumstances that were extraordinary, what kind of National Industrial Recovery Act President Roosevelt wishes Congress to adopt in preparation for the expiration of the present NIRA June 16.
BERLIN, March 30 (AP). -- Germany's military regeneration gained momentum today as the Cabinet empowered the army to obtain land for manoeuvres, garrisons and other military purposes.

What a pleasant job detecting would be could one use the methods employed by George Congreve in this story of murder in the wine room of a chateau in France! Congreve is an epicure and a connoisseur of wines, and his theory is based on the old saying "in vino veritas."
There is only one exhibit in the eighth annual show of the New York Physicians Art Club, which opened last night at the New York Academy of Medicine, that has a medical subject.

All expectations that the shipment of scrap iron to foreign countries this year will break the 1934 record have faded, dealers declared yesterday, following the sharp cessation of buying by Japan and Italy, the two principal takers of American scrap.

In unusually active dealings for a Saturday, the foreign exchange market attempted yesterday to adjust itself to the new situation in Belgium. The belga fell to a new low price of 18.44 cents and closed at 18.80 cents, off 55 points net. At these prices it was still well above the level of 17.66 cents which represents the new parity as a result of the 25 per cent devaluation.

Russian exports to the United States this year will be double those of 1934, chiefly because of the addition of gold-bearing materials to the list of approximately 125 items which the Soviet now ships here, it was learned from authoritative sources yesterday.

WITH his accustomed brilliancy and forthrightness Professor Soddy in his latest book continues to lecture the academic and professional economists on what to him seems to be their great error, namely, that they have turned orthodox economics into the "class economics of the owners of debt."

Relief, in the last few months, has become a basic factor in the social structure of New York City. The events of the past weeks and the attacks upon the administrative organization, with counter-charges, have brought this fact sharply into focus.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 30. -- Miss Marion Short, '36, of Hillside was elected today to head the editorial staff of Campus News, undergraduate newspaper at the New Jersey College for Women, according to an announcement made by Miss Frances Williams, '35, of Westfield, whom Miss Short will succeed.

S.L.A. Marshall's series on the development of unrest in Mexico is to be commended as forthright, informative and sympathetic. As a reader, I wish to express appreciation. My own view, based upon academic and direct contacts with the Mexican situation, differs in some respects from that of Mr. Marshall; however, the paradoxes and complexities of the present Mexican situation are such as to give ample room for valid differences of opinion.
LEXINGTON, Ky., March 30. -- Senator Nye asserted in an address here tonight that President Roosevelt "has voiced a determination to keep America out of another war at all costs."
A three-story clubhouse, equipped by S. Klein, Union Square merchant, for his employes, was presented to them last night at a dedication ceremony in the building, 109-111 East Fifteenth Street.
LONDON, March 30 (AP). -- The Duke of Manchester, who has an income of about $17,000 a year, was released on bail today to await a jury trial of charges that he pawned jewelry not his.

THE moral lesson conjured in this story of depression-blighted New Yorkers is that loss of an accustomed income may turn a normally honest person into a sneak, a coward, a parasite and a beat. That deterioration overtook Niles Renshaw, the prospering co-partner in a firm of architects, when the boom era collapsed.

BERLIN. -- Marie Adelheid, Princess of Lippe, speaking at a meeting of the Nordic Faith Movement in a government office building, said children should be forbidden to read the Old Testament and asserted that there was not much sense in reading the New Testament.

THE Frankenstein of Universal City has just finished his biggest job to date and is well advanced on his next assignment of turning men into monsters. This practitioner of occult rites, before whom strong actors tremble, is Jack Pierce, half man, half plasterer.

Unique features are being planned for the Lace Ball in behalf of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association which will be held on May 3 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The motif will be lace, in varying forms and simulations, which will transform the ballroom into a magical wonderland of transparent, floating gossamer.

A threat of a series of special sessions of the Legislature in an attempt to force Tammany Assemblymen into line seemed yesterday to be almost the only hope of passing the Democratic legislative reapportionment bill, which Tammany does not want, and against which at least eight Tammany Assemblymen are understood to be ready to vote when it comes up again.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 30. -- Slack airs turned the first race today in the series between the Bermuda one-design yachts and the Long Island Sound Interclub boats into a drifting match, moving the judges to call a halt when the yachts had completed a triangular run and it was apparent that they could not finish in the allotted time.

The measurements of Drs. Stetson and Loomis, checking time between stations, one on the western, the other on the eastern, continent, have established the fact that the distance between them varies with the relative position of the moon and the earth.

A SHARP upturn in retail trade was the report for the week from most centres. Local stores ran close to last year's figures and from other cities came the information that sales were running much better than was expected as the month came to a close.

AN exhibition of contemporary Mexican art, assembled as a traveling show by the College Art Association, is being held, until April 6, in the galleries of the Squibb Building. One of its virtues is the inclusion of work by several Mexican artists not previously known here; another is the variety of mediums illustrated, for the show is made up of oils, watercolors, drawings, prints and sculpture.

The other day I received such a forcible and yet pitiful lesson in political economy that I thought it well worth while to set it down just as I saw it. I was walking along the street and before me beheld a little pushcart piled with small tables of unpainted wood.

THIS twentieth volume of the Year Book series is of special interest and importance because of the compendium it offers of the social, political and economic events of a year that will go down in American history as an epochal period of bold experiments and many changes.
The celebration of the 800th anniversary of the birth of Moses Maimonides, Jewish philosopher, began internationally yesterday. The scholar and sage was born on March 30, 1135, in Cordova, Spain.

ALONG the sandy soil of the Mexican border political rumors spread like cactus, and for some reason the rumors are always of revolution and upheaval to come. They take color from the perpetual comings and goings, the meetings and low-voiced conversations in the cafes of Nuevo Laredo, in the tamale-houses of Eagle Pass.

THIS fantasy, which Mr. Bacon calls a "fantastic epic," is really made up of three stories. We follow the epigraph on the book's jacket in calling them stories, but they are nearer to parables. And if not parables in the exact meaning of the word, the narrations are so studded with symbols as quite to carry them out of any natural realm.

PHILADELPHIA, March 29. -- Retailers have capitalized the lateness of Easter by a prolonged period of advertising. Early announcements have brought good results and retail distribution continues to hold up remarkably well. Sales are reported running per cent above last year in some lines, with indications of a favorable demand continuing in April.

THOMAS MOTT OSBORNE presents the phenomenon, not rare among men of genius and high talent, where the work of the man surpasses the individual. To no one person is the modern world of prison reform and the whole broad subject of penology so much in debt as to him.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP). -- Elimination of radio "blood-and-thunder programs" for children was urged tonight by Chairman Prall of the Communications Commission.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- When for the second successive year -- and also for the second time in recorded history -- great dust storms sweep the Western plains, one of America's great land problems is luridly dramatized.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 30 (AP). -- Raymond Hamilton, Texas gunman, eluded capture today as practically every Federal and police officer in the South sought him in the government's latest "shoot-to-kill" manhunt.
BOGOTA. -- There are too many lawyers and too few teachers in Colombia, according to the review, Education, published in this city.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 30. -- Simultaneous movement of tanker ships at various Pacific ports, including San Francisco, with non-union crews today broke the strike blockade which had stalled those ships since March 9. Although crowds of pickets were within range of the moving ships or the piers at which they were loaded, special deputies prevented any violent incident.

RETAIL sales of new passenger cars in the New York area in January of this year were 24 1/2 per cent above those of January, 1934, and in February, 1935, they were 64 1-3 per cent above the sales in February of last year, according to Sherlock and Arnold, analysts.

CHICAGO, March 29. -- It is not like the old days in Chicago when Capone and his gangsters were driving around town in armored cars with shatterproof glass. The major league gangsters are in the penitentiary or lying low. Every now and again one is picked up by the police, just on general principles.

SO effectively does Lloyd Goodrich epitomize the points of contrast illustrated in the Whitney Museum's admirable current exhibition of American genre (March 26-April 29) that one cannot do better than offer certain cogent passages in the catalogue foreword -- which is really a valuable feature of the show.

MANY banks throughout the country are holding large sums of money unclaimed by the rightful owners. The owners are difficult to find. In spite of the depression, many individuals, organizations and heirs have not withdrawn money which is theirs.

HEWLET, L.I., March 30. -- Shown in splendid black coat, Animated Inkspot, owned and exhibited by Miss Maud W. Van Rensselaer, went to the top in the first competition held by the newly organized South Shore Spaniel Club of Long Island today.

AUGUSTA, Ga. -- The annual Augusta women's invitation tournament, completed Friday, which saw some of the outstanding women golfers of the United States competing, has served only to whet the appetites of fans here for the second annual Augusta national invitation tournament, to be played over the Ideal course of Bobby Jones here this week.

PARIS, March 30. -- The week ended with the Bourse nervous and agitated, a prey to many wild rumors, but nevertheless nothing drastic occurred. Heavy arbitrage sales by Belgians of Bank of Paris shares here caused that stock to open 38 francs down and influenced the whole market.

ROSITA FORBES returned to England from South America with a study entitled "Eight Republics in Search of a Future," and from Uruguay she brought the setting of her most recent novel. "The Extraordinary House" concerns five people who leave a cruise rather than remain on shipboard during the entire voyage.

ELMER DAVIS'S latest collection of longish short stories belong together in a single volume. They are all "little novels" of American middle-class life caught in the vortex of the Wall Street panic and sucked into the depths of the depression.
WASHINGTON, March 30. -- The executive order of Donald R. Richberg, acting chairman of the NIRB, extending wages and hours provisions of the Bituminous Coal Code to June 16 follows:
Receipts from the first of the four instalments of the city's 2 per cent sales tax up to 6 o'clock last night totaled $6,914,986.91 -- far below the expected payment of $12,000,000 to $14,000,000.

BERLIN, March 31. -- A foreign news agency dispatch reaching Berlin from abroad purporting to reveal in advance details of the forthcoming regulations for conscription aroused ire tonight in official quarters, which branded the alleged revelations as "April fool nonsense."

MINEOLA, L.I., March 31. -- A grand jury investigation has been started to determine the whereabouts of 7,000 pounds of veal, several thousand burlap bags, four tons of coal and two barrels of pork, which are missing from the TERA distributing plant at Glen Cove.
NEW ORLEANS, March 31. -- The cotton market here gradually quieted down last week and trading near the close recalled the inactivity that prevailed prior to the recent slump in values.

JACKSON, Miss., March 31 (AP). -- Mississippi counted four known dead tonight, at least eight injured and unestimated property damage in the wake of a freakish tornado that swept out of the southwest today, striking with intermittent fury in a half-dozen counties in South and Central Mississippi.

The Montclair Art Museum, in honor of George Inness, is to hold a one-day exhibition of his paintings with a program of music in the evening on May 1, the 110th anniversary of the artist's birth. It has been requested that any one wishing to cooperate and knowing of paintings by Inness, owned in the vicinity of Montclair, where the artist had his home, communicate with Mrs. Mary Cooke Swartwout, director of the museum.

CHICAGO, March 31. -- The Omnibus Corporation, a Chicago transportation holding company, reported today a consolidated net profit of $489,171 for 1934. This was less than half the profit of $1,151,212 in 1933.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., March 31. -- One of America's own dogs -- a Chesapeake Bay -- attained a signal victory today when Skipper Bob was awarded first money, the blue ribbon and a popular unrecorded vote of being the best dog in the first non-slip retriever trials of the Long Island Retriever Club, concluded on the estates of Wilton Lloyd-Smith and Willis D. Wood.

A bank teller who started thirty-one years ago as an office boy faced charges of grand larceny and forgery yesterday because, he explained in a cell at headquarters, "my living expenses exceeded my salary."
Samuel Untermyer, who has been wintering at Palm Springs, Calif., will arrive today on the Panama Pacific liner Pennsylvania from the Coast via the Canal.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Official Washington tonight was awaiting word from President Roosevelt as to whether he would accede to the solicitations of some administrative aides and Congressional leaders and throw his personal weight against the legislative jam that has held his program practically at a standstill since the middle of January.

Women headed by Mrs. Henry Hollister Pease are active in behalf of a drive for funds for Vacation House, the Summer home maintained in Stockbridge, Mass., by the New York Exchange for Woman's Work, so that needy women may have vacations in the country.
CHICAGO, March 31. -- New York and Chicago shared honors in the fourth annual intercity Catholic school basketball games in the Loyola University gymnasium today.
Work on the detailed plans and drawings for the Sixth Avenue subway will be started today by eighty engineers and draftsmen of the Board of Transportation.
DETROIT, March 31 (AP). -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, in what was regarded as an inferential reply to Hugh S. Johnson, defended today the methods used to finance his Union for Social Justice.

DUBLIN, March 31. -- The government announced tonight that the Free State had closed the financial year last night with a deficit of 2,432,811 [the pound is worth about $4.80]. The expenditures for the year were 31,203,499, while the revenue from all sources totaled 28,770,688.
Churchgoing is not optional but is required for members of the Episcopal Church, the Rev. Milo H. Gates, dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, said yesterday morning in his sermon there.
The Mayor's committee investigating conditions in Harlem expects that its inquiry will last more than two months. Dr. Charles H. Roberts of 233 West 139th Street, its chairman, said yesterday.

MEXICO, D.F., March 31. -- After hitting the canvas nine times in six rounds, Frankie Wallace was saved from further punishment by the local featherweight idol, Baby Arizmendi, today when his manager threw a towel into the ring before 20,000 spectators.

Local merchandise markets were quite active last week, as the approach of Easter brought in a large volume of mail and wire orders. Dresses were outstanding in demand, with emphasis on afternoon types with lace trimming. A wide variety of cotton styles started to sell more freely, volume business developing from the South particularly.

Federal bureaus concerned with the local supervision or regulation of merchant shipping will be concentrated at 45 Broadway within the next few weeks. Directors of the several activities have been notified to collect records and other physical properties for removal to the nine-story building that houses offices of the NRA, the Shipping Board and other Federal arms.

BUDAPEST, March 31. -- The results of the first day of the Hungarian general elections -- the remaining voting will take place next Thursday and Sunday -- point to a triumph for Premier Julius Goemboes. Eighty-four per cent of the seats in Parliament were filled today and he secures a greater majority of them than even former Premier Count Stephen Bethlen ever knew.

With eleven artists participating, a musical program of wide variety was presented at the Menorah concert given in the Town Hall last night and devoted to "the Hebraic and Biblical Image in World Music." The concert was under the auspices of the Menorah Writers' and Artists' Committee and was for the benefit of the educational work of the Menorah Association.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 31 (AP). -- Two Canton, Ohio, teams gained places among the American Bowling Congress leaders tonight.

On Friday our Government notified Mr. STRACHEY that the proceedings against him had been dropped and that he was free to sail for England a he had planned. This is the end of a case which leaves our authorities looking pretty shamefaced, for they had arrested Mr. STRACHEY on charges of which they could give no shadow of proof.
Brighter tones colored the relief picture as nine States yesterday disclosed a downward trend in the cost of caring for the needy or in the total of those aided, says The Associated Press.

PARIS, March 29. -- It is thought here that the British equalization fund bought gold in the London open market, with the effect of raising the price of gold, thus allowing arbitragists to take gold from the Bank of France for sale in London with a slight profit.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, March 31 (AP). -- A violently worded anti-Semitic manifesto was issued today by eleven former Cabinet Ministers of Rumania advocating the introduction of racial correction measures in all forms of Rumanian activity.

New securities offered to the public here in March were all bonds and amounted to $237,282,000 for thirty-nine issues, the largest amount of bonds marketed since July. The offerings compared with a total of $70,075,000 in February, when thirty-eight bond issues aggregated $69,206,000, with one stock issue of $869,000.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $7,745,265,280. They consist of Treasury bonds, consols, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

Thirty-four pieces of jewelry valued at from $50,000 to $75,000 were stolen two weeks ago from the home of J. Couper Lord, insurance broker, at 177 East Seventy-ninth Street while Mr. Lord was spending a week-end in the country with his wife and daughter, the police revealed yesterday.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., March 31. -- After forty years of police work in Nassau County, Chief of Police Phineas A. Seaman of the Hempstead Village Police Department was retired at midnight by the village Board of Trustees. He said he planned to enter the building contracting business.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- An official monthly summary of reports of ownership and of transactions in equity securities by officers and directors and principal stockholders of corporations as required by Section 16 (a) of the Securities Exchange Act, will be made available to the public by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Thirty-five members of the Police Department received honorable mention and 388 others were cited for meritorious conduct "in the line of duty" in orders issued yesterday by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine.

Letters to THE TIMES objecting to fingerprinting express an old, mistaken idea of American liberty. Lack of identification of the individual is just what is most desired by a long list of persons resident in the United States: racketeers in general, crooks of all kinds, persons who for various reasons desire to change their names.

Pointing to more than 260,000 retarded pupils in the city's public schools, the survey committee appointed by Mayor La Guardia and Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, in the second instalment of its preliminary report today, recommends a comprehensive study as soon as possible to discover the basic causes of pupil failure.

The Old Guard of the Intercollegiate Fencing Association, limited to only twelve of twenty-one championships in the past three seasons after long years of complete dominance, is ready to form a select group of its own. This was the most startling aftermath of the forty-second annual title tournament of the association that ended on Saturday with one of the newcomers, N.Y.U., once more taking a major share of the awards.
Two hold-ups staged by bandits in motion picture theatres just before last midnight netted $2,107 in receipts. One of the hold-ups was in Brooklyn and the other was in Queens.

The modern world is hastening toward destruction under a system of civilization that is "the release of the three concupiscences which God said would ruin the world," according to Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen of the Catholic University of America at Washington, D.C.
For the first time since 1926 two Canadian teams will fight it out for the Stanley Cup, emblematic of the world's professional hockey championship.

The proportions of the government's borrowing and distributing are too vast to be easily comprehended by the people. They do not generally understand that the government has no assets to distribute, except the power to impose taxes, and that the bill for the distributions must be handed to the people for settlement.

The assets of life insurance companies authorized in New York State rose $853,479,241 in 1934 to $19,099,883,583, the State Insurance Department reported yesterday in an advance summary of a report to be issued soon. This gain compared with one of $311,057,971 in 1938.

ROME, March 31 (AP). -- A distinct cooling of the British attitude toward Italy's activities in East Africa, growing out of the Ethiopian controversy, was causing heated discussion in government circles today. A treaty signed in 1906 by England, Italy and France guarantees the independence of Ethiopia as the only remaining African kingdom.

German schools and universities have become elements in the Nazi propaganda machine, and all the forces of education are directed toward fostering a militaristic spirit among Nazi youth, according to a special report prepared by Dr. Isaac L. Kandel, Professor of Education at Teachers College, for the eleventh annual yearbook of the college's International Institute.

MONTREAL, March 31. -- Disappointed at not having reached the final round of the Stanley Cup playoffs for the world's hockey championship, but at the same time pleased with their stirring fight against the Montreal Maroons, the New York Rangers left tonight for New York City.

Realty transactions reported in Manhattan over the week-end indicated a continuance of the demand for housing properties that has been a feature of trading for several months. Investors were active in the purchase of multi-family buildings, banks figuring as the sellers in some of the deals.
Sales of New Jersey farm properties to New Yorkers were announced over the week-end.

Charter membership in the new 3-cents-a-day plan for hospital care has thus far been accepted by fifty-two hospitals in New York City and the adjacent area, it was said yesterday by Karl Eilers, president of the Associated Hospital Service, at 122 East Twenty-second Street.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 31. -- One of the important social events here today was the tea with which Hugh Dillman entertained at Sandy Loam Farm.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 31. -- An eight-hit attack crackled about the ears of Larry Benton, cast-off Giant pitcher, today as the Yankees took another game from the Braves at Waterfront Park, to insure them the honors of the inter-league series. The score was 7 to 3.
Sloosh is contented now, but he still arches his back and puffs his tail when he hears a motor starting. He hates motors, fan belts and motor oil with all the bitterness that an adult cat can muster.
The New York League of Locality Mayors will induct its first honorary member on Thursday, it became known yesterday. He is the Right Hon. Alderman Alfred Byrne, Lord Mayor of Dublin.

BOSTON, March 31 (AP). -- Death stalked Massachusetts highways last week, killing twenty-five persons and injuring 1,200, Frank A. Goodwin, registrar of motor vehicles, said tonight, appealing to police and the courts to curb the increasing toll from automobile accidents.
BERLIN, March 31 (AP). -- Whether an expectant mother's head shall be placed upon the Nazi chopping block was a question today which Chancellor Adolf Hitler must decide.

Despite the gloom surrounding some of the financial markets, current news of American business continues on the whole to be favorable. Bank clearings, widely regarded as a significant index of business activity, were reported yesterday to have reached a new high mark for 1935, at approximately 13 per cent above the level of a year ago.

The statement of the I.C.C., accompanying its freight rate decision, is not a very cheerful document, but it is an eminently sensible and realistic one. What is most reassuring in it is not what it says directly, but the evidence it gives that the commission is fully aware of the plight of the railroads and deeply concerned to relieve that plight to the extent of its power.

As he was leaving the First Presbyterian Church of Cedar Manor, Queens, of which he is pastor, after conducting services there, the Rev. Roland T. Morris of 159-12 Eighty-ninth Avenue, Jamaica, was arrested yesterday on a charge of secreting mortgaged property.

EAST NEWARK, March 31. -- The Pawtucket Rangers vanquished the Scots-Americans, 2 to 0, today, in their return match in the Eastern finals of the annual cup competition of the United States Football Association.

Another evidence of the heated undercover strife in the New York Stock Exchange election campaign has come to light with the announcement by the special committee on commissions that it would recommend to the board of governors that no change be made in the floor brokerage commission rate.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- About 3,429,000 school children, representing about one-eighth of all those enrolled in the nation, will receive three months less education this year than in normal times, the Federal Office of Education reported today, in holding that the emergency was as serious this year as it was last.

LONDON, March 30. -- The Economist's fortnightly index of commodity prices in Great Britain, based on 1927 as 100, stood on March 27 at 66.1, against 65.7 a fortnight before, 66.4 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, when the gold standard was abandoned.

Edward R. Hewitt drove up to the Catskills one day last week to inspect his camp on the Neversink, and after a careful survey of stream conditions ventured the prediction that the early trout fishing this year would be the best in many seasons.

The Outlet Company in its annual report for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31 shows a net profit of $464,105 after charges and reserves. This is equivalent, after preferred dividend requirements, to $3.88 a share available for common stock, and compares with a net profit of $514,690 in the preceding year.

With an exuberance that contrasted with the dignity of his years, Benjamin Kotolowitz celebrated his 110th birthday yesterday in the Bialystoker Home for the Aged, 230 East Broadway. Joining in the fete were 400 relatives and friends who believe him to be the oldest person of the Jewish faith in New York.
A couple of crowded houses enthusiastically welcomed the return of Commendatore Giuseppe Sterni's "Il Conte di Monte Cristo" yesterday afternoon and evening at Longacre Theatre.

March was, on the whole, a disappointing month for business, says the National City Bank in its Spring bulletin, published today. It had been hoped, the bank says, that the upswing in industrial activity which began last Fall would continue into the second quarter of this year, and that it might broaden in scope to include the backward industries whose improvement is indispensable to recovery.
The official who promises 100 per cent efficiency in work relief is "taking the public for a ride," Park Commissioner Robert Moses declared yesterday.

Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange in March was smaller than in any corresponding month since 1922. Sales for the month, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, totaled 15,849,017 shares, compared with 14,404,225 shares in February and with 29,915,969 in March, a year ago.

The Metropolitan Opera Association, aided and abetted by a number of Puckish minds from theatre and radio, put on its annual "surprise party" at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. It was the fourth edition of a jamboree that has one consecutive performance a year -- for many good reasons.
MOSCOW, March 31. -- The text of the joint communique, issued jointly on behalf of Great Britain and Soviet Russia, follows:
One Metropolitan A.A.U. senior women's swimming championship changed hands at the Women's Swimming Association yesterday, while another remained with the defending titleholder.

CHICAGO, March 31. -- Farmers are reported to be complaining in that their livestock operations are the most discouraging in their experience as the result of the governments' activities in reducing surplus supplies of cattle and hogs and the operation of the processing tax.
A spirit of rivalry appeared yesterday in the policy and vice investigation.

BERLIN, March 29. -- The negative outcome of Foreign Minister Sir John Simon's Berlin mission and uncertainty as to Belgian currency had an unsettling effect on business, and prices on the Boerse ruled irregular this week with declines in armament stocks early in the period.

The nervousness that had characterized the cotton market here in the previous fortnight was noticeably absent last week. Considerable buying was reported for foreign account. The domestic mills bought fairly freely on recessions. In some quarters the strengthening was believed to be partly attributable to the firmer spot basis in the South.

A new departure in crime prevention will be instituted this week among children in the University Settlement, 184 Eldridge Street, according to an announcement yesterday by Leon J. Rubenstein, the director.

Liquor dealers must obey the regulations of the State Liquor Authority if they expect to continue in business in this State, Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the State Liquor Authority, said last night. He addressed the members of the Greater New York Licensed Liquor Stores Association at their second annual dinner in the Hotel New Yorker.
WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP). -- Two of the most controversial measures of the New Deal, the railroad pension act and the Frazier Lemke farm moratorium, will be before the Supreme Court tomorrow.

Suspension of the gold standard by Belgium, and devaluation of the belga by 25 to 30 per cent, exerted a depressing influence on the foreign exchange market last week. There had been some anticipation of the plan in banking quarters, but until the official announcement came on Saturday all rates were subjected to wide fluctuations.
Leslie Howard, the actor, has no more desire to play in the commercial theatre, he said yesterday at the Conference on Acting being held in the Beekman Tower at 3 Mitchell Place.

The pessimism of those who believe that the destruction of our civilization by another World War is impending was challenged yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. William P. Merrill in his sermon at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street.

DOYLESTOWN, Pa., March 31. -- A warning against dictatorship and an appeal to the youth of America to help "maintain America as the world's greatest democracy" were voiced by Dr. Luther Harr, State Secretary of Banking, in an address today to the thirty-one graduates of the National Farm School.
WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP). -- A tacit decision not to press a $405, 000,000 army modernization program, despite the crisis in Europe, has been reached by the House Military Committee.

One man was killed and two persons, a man and a woman, were injured at 12:40 A.M. this morning when the automobile in which they were riding on Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, crashed through a guard rail of the Long Island Railroad cut at that point and dropped about twenty feet to the tracks.
