CLEMONTON, N.J., April 13. -- The Pine Valley Golf Club, never negotiated in competition in less than its par 70, will be the scene of next year's Walker Cup matches between amateur teams of Great Britain and the United States.

The president and members of the board of directors of the Woman's Roosevelt Memorial Association will give a reception for Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt, widow of President Roosevelt, the afternoon of April 29 at the Roosevelt House, 28 East Twentieth Street.

HAMBURG, April 13. -- In a speech before the Ibero-American Institute, Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics, declared today the international debt problem was the key to the world economic crisis and that "without a solution of that problem neither commercial barriers nor currency chaos can be eliminated."
PARIS, April 13. -- President Roosevelt's silver policy was the alleged cause on the Bourse today of a fall of the dollar to 15.11 francs from 15.14. Sterling also dropped slightly to 73.23 francs.
The relief issue made headlines again last week in New York. These things happened:

STARTING out to spend a month's vacation with his old friend. Judge Macklin, Ellery Queen arrives at Spanish Cape just in time to be in on a murder mystery. A handsome but unscrupulous person named John Marco has been found dead, sitting in a chair on a terrace overlooking the sea.

THE bright-colored maps by Santoyo in this guide practically steal the show. They're the best we've seen. By looking at them you not only know where you're going but what's there or what's happened there. Along every road the pictures tell the story.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 13. -- Mrs. Max J.H. Rossbach of Thirlsmere, North Street, this place, will open her home on Tuesday for a meeting of the Garden Day Committee of the Westchester County Children's Association, of which she is chairman.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld. -- Setting about a drastic reorganization of Newfoundland's educational system, the Commission of Government has taken the first step in cutting away most of the props of the existing religious denominational control, and setting up machinery to bring the whole system under government management.
LONDON, April 13. -- The most encouraging foreign trade figures in many months were issued by the Board of Trade today, showing that Great Britain's industrial revival is net over by any means.

FOR at least forty years the absurdities and futilities of the once vaunted "elective system" have been under an increasingly destructive fire. Rich and varied as were the courses offered, their very multiplicity and narrowness of scope made a systematic and balanced grouping impossible.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 13. -- Chester Phillips of Temple and the Navy athletes were outstanding in the Eastern intercollegiate individual gymnastic championships after six hours of competition at the Walker Memorial Gym of M.I.T. today.

The Stresa meeting has brought mixed results. The gains are temporary and spring from expediency. The loss is on the side of principle and the longer good. The immediate peace outlook is better because HITLER is willing to pledge non-aggression within the framework of an Eastern Locarno.

In Legare's career we see many reflections of the interesting intellectual and political life of Charleston in the decades just after 1800.

WHEELING, W. Va., April 13. -- Former President Herbert Hoover, accompanied by Mark Sullivan, the political writer, en route by automobile from New York to California, paused here for an hour this afternoon and met several prominent Republicans of West Virginia.

TWO years ago next August a military revolt in Cuba overthrew the dictatorial Machado regime. Now, in the person of Colonel Fulgencio Batista, former sergeant. Chief of Staff since September, 1933. Cuba has another virtual dictator.

The metropolitan racing season, which will be ushered in at Jamaica Saturday, approaches with the promise of being the best New York has experienced since the enactment of the Anti-Betting Laws in 1909, and which operated to hold back the sport in this State for nearly a quarter of a century.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 13. -- With the Kentucky Derby only three weeks away, there is more uncertainty than in many years as to the probable starters.

Delegates to the Student Model Assembly of the League of Nations, Middle Atlantic States division, meeting yesterday for their concluding session of a three-day conference at New York University, voted for the establishment of a permanent disarmament commission.
PARIS, April 12. -- Little illusion is now left France, if any was ever entertained, that the Stresa conference will frighten Germany.

THIS unostentatious little book will make a sure appeal to a small but appreciative audience. Though much slighter and intended for younger readers, in its sureness of touch and understanding of children it suggests Eiluned Lewis's "Dew on the Grass."

WARSAW, April 13. -- The Eastern pact is dead, triumphantly announce Warsaw's newspaper headlines over the Stresa dispatches with the information that Germany is ready to enter a collective non-aggression pact without a mutual-assistance clause.

Plans for the establishment of a Nassau County branch of New York University at Hempstead, L.I., were disclosed yesterday with the purchase by the university of the sixteen-acre estate of the late William S. Hofstra in that community.

The Barnard College gymnasium was transformed into a Grecian amphitheatre yesterday afternoon for the annual Greek games festival, in which 250 members of the freshman and sophomore classes engaged in contests of skill in dance, song, verse and athletics.

BERLIN. GERTRUD BAUMER is one of the most vital representatives of that now disappearing generation the women of which suddenly awoke, took their fate into their own hands and roused thousands of their sisters to vigorous activity for their sex a well as to cooperation in the work of the State and the community.

ALL up and down Atlantic City's famous Boardwalk the most conspicuous sight today is fresh paint. There and throughout the city, as in other well-known resort towns along the Jersey coast, a refurbishing is taking place, and it is leaving no nook or cranny untouched.

Following Friday's halt, the upward movement in prices on the Cotton Exchange was resumed yesterday, and gains of 15 to 18 points carried July to 11 3/4 cents a pound and several new-crop positions to 11 1/2 cents.
WASHINGTON, April 13. -- The volume of business in the first week in April was about the same level as in March, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly review of the domestic situation.

For a half-cent of 1796 in uncirculated condition, $410 was paid yesterday at a coin sale conducted by the Elder Coin and Curio Corporation at 8 West Thirty-seventh Street, with O.R. Gilbert acting as auctioneer. It was the highest price paid for a half-cent at a public offering in this city for a long time.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 13. -- Unemployment insurance was attacked by Dr. Sydney Roslow, psychologist, of New York University, before the New York branch of the American Psychological Association, which held its sixth annual Spring meeting here today.

Forecasts of the chances of their teams were made yesterday for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the managers of the local major league clubs. The statements of Bill Terry of the Giants, Joe McCarthy of the Yankees and Casey Stengel of the Dodgers follow:

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Stronger efforts to stamp out bootlegging or the lowering of taxes on liquor were asked of Secrtary Morgenthau today, in a letter sent to him by Ammon McClellan, executive director of the League of Distilled Spirits Rectifiers and Rectifiers Code Authority.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., April 13. -- A gift of $75,000 to be used toward the erection of a new wing of the Bryn Mawr College library was announced today in connection with the Alumnae Association's nationwide campaign to raise $1,000,000.

ONLY two years ago college faculties were complaining that students took little interest in State and national affairs. A few, through International Relations Clubs and model Leagues of Nations, were posted on foreign policies.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP). -- Contending that the first three and a half months of the present Congressional session have seen only one really major measure enacted, Senate Republican leaders asserted today that, unless the administration program is sharply curtailed, Congress will be here all Summer.

Three moves by the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed last week were described in Wall Street as affording safeguards to investors in railroads and railroad holding companies which until now they have been without. The most radical of these moves was the promulgation by the commission of a form for the use of railroads, telephone and telegraph companies and other carriers which may seek permanent registration of their securities on Stock Exchanges.

ALBANY, April 13. -- The lash of two powerful Democratic leaders from New York City cracked over the backs of party Senators today and the Twomey resolution for a constitutional amendment to permit pari-mutuels at the New York race tracks went down to defeat by a vote of 16 to 31.

AT the turn from the nineteenth into the twentieth century all intellectual Dublin was obsessed with the Irish peasant. Douglas Hyde was sitting before peat fires in smoky Connacht cabins collecting his songs. Lady Gregory had for several years been searching out and taking down his folklore.

A preview of a loan exhibition of fifteenth-century portraits will be held tomorrow at the Knoedler Galleries, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street, for the benefit of the recreation department of the New York Association for the Blind. The exhibition will be under the auspices of the junior committee of the organization, headed by Mrs. Stephen Koshland.

TOKYO, April 13. -- If Japan's exports to Latin America are restricted, said a Foreign Office statement handed the local press today, "it will affect our purchasing power, especially with reference to United States cotton, and will consequently react unfavorably upon America's export trade to Japan."

With a new course laid out for them on Lake Quinsigamond, the college and school outboard drivers are looking to some record breaking when they gather at Worcester, Mass., on June 29 and 30 for their annual championships. They even are talking about lowering some world marks.

The Joint Distribution Committee appropriated $1,290,000 for relief work abroad during 1934, it was reported last night at the annual meeting of its national council at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street.

ISTANBUL, April 13. -- At the invitation of the women of Turkey some 300 delegates and visitors from thirty-five countries are assembling in Istanbul for the twelfth Congress of the International Woman Suffrage Alliance to be held next week.
CHICAGO, April 13 (AP). -- The White Sox defeated their city rivals, the Cubs, in their first home meeting of the exhibition season today, 5 to 2, before 8,000 shivering fans at Comiskey Park.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- President Roosevelt took an actual part in a skit at the annual Spring dinner of the Gridiron Club here tonight. The dinner, marking the fiftieth anniversary of the club, was the first one in which a President actually took part in the club's burlesques.

Significant facts concerning the state of American economy are sometimes to be deduced from simple diagrams. That is true of the two accompanying charts, which reveal the change in total national income status between 1929 and 1934. For 1929, figures of the National Industrial Conference Board have been used. "

The rather excellent interpretation of the forces motivating the current undergraduate drive against war by Dean Gauss, published in THE TIMES, contained two or three sentences which conveyed an inaccurate impression.

EVER since some bewildered cave man went out into the moonlight and demanded of earth and sky, "What are you? And what am I?" man has been asking the same question -- and frequently believing he was spinning the answer out of his own brain.

PHILADELPHIA, April 13. -- Jimmy Foxx hit two home runs and another by pitcher Sugar Cain helped the Athletics to rout the Phillies today by a score of 16 to 2, before a crowd of 2,000 shivering fans. It was the Athletics' first triumph of the series. The clubs play their final game tomorrow.

The Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club lacrosse team, with several former college stars in its line-up, opened its season yesterday with an overwhelming 15-4 triumph over the Savage School on the winner's field in Bay Ridge.

BERLIN, March 27, 1935. THE time has come, the Walrus said, to talk of Bach and Handel; and if the scene happens to be Germany, to make a few deferential mops and mows in the direction of their grave and reverend antecedent, Heinrich Schuetz, born most considerately an exact century earlier and ranking, therefore, among the major birthday children of this year of grace 1935.

WHEN Miss Hahn writes she usually is sure of her ground, whether the soil be Africa or Manhattan. This air of versimilitude is one of the good things about "Affair," as is also the simplicity of structure and the economical style.

Proposed new partnerships announced yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange included that of C.E. Welles Co., which will be formed on Tuesday by William J. Butler, Frank D. Lackey Jr. and Henry S. Brown, with offices at. 25 Broadway.

Spring, to all appearances, has adopted the British way of doing things. It will proclaim no hard-and-fast policy. It will give no pledges and assume no commitments. If it feels like snowing on the opening day of the baseball season it retains a free hand to do so.

WITHIN the ranks of the hobby movement -- a growing one, judging from the many clubs, exhibitions and books devoted to it -- collecting antiques is a favorite enthusiasm. In this field the stamp specialist is akin to the lover of early American glass or pine furniture.

BENNINGTON, Vt., April 13. -- The majority stock of the G.S. Stoddard Chemical Company of New York is bequeathed either to the corporation itself or to five managing employes by the will of its late president, Mrs. Elizabeth Cooper Kelley, filed today in Bennington Probate Court.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- The adverse ruling in Louisville on the tobacco processing tax today came on the first court test on the tobacco crop control plan and will be read with especial interest by AAA officials, who are expected to file prompt appeal.

PARIS, April 13. -- Most American and British correspondents at Stresa featured in their dispatches printed today Germany's agreement to be a party to an Eastern pact of non-aggression, even if other parties to such a pact concluded pacts of mutual assistance. The French correspondents and their editorial writers, however, for the most part dismissed the matter as "a clumsy manoeuvre."

HAVOC to hedges has been dealt by Jack Frost in the Eastern States in the last two years, especially in New York and in New England territory. Most of these blasted barriers were of privet. Their casualties were not altogether unexpected, for privet is a favorite fence plant in this region, more being used there than all similar growths combined.

Directors of the Protestant Big Sisters have taken over a preview performance for the night of April 22 at the Booth Theatre of "Kind Lady," a new play by Edward Chodorov, adapted from a story by Hugh Walpole, with Grace George in the leading role. Already there has been a large sale of seats for the performance.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Action on a complaint against foreign competition in pig iron has been dropped by the National Industrial Recovery Board at the direction of the President. The complaint was filed by a tariff committee representing the Eastern group of merchant pig iron producers by authority of their Iron and Steel Institute.

THE founding of a new quarterly, to be known as The Southern Review, is announced by Louisiana State University. Its program will, however, not be sectional, nor will its tone be academic. The review will deal with vital contemporary activity in creative literature, criticism and social thought.

THE new Susan Ertz novel is the lively story of two people who fall in love at first sight. Their earliest conversations practically accept marriage as a foregone conclusion, with only the details of life together to be worked out. In a few weeks the pair are rashly married and madly in love.

Retail trade suffered a severe setback from weather conditions last week, and with one more week of Easter buying remaining, retailers throughout the country were hoping for warm, sunny days, and for an end of the severe dust storms in the West.

The American Council of the World Alliance for International Peace Through the Churches invited the thirty-three national branches of the organization yesterday to cooperate in a program emphasizing "the indispensable need of world disarmament for the preservation of international peace."

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Reform is to hold the boards for the remainder of this session of Congress. How much of the reform legislation will be passed and how long its consideration will require are questions that still remain in the realm of doubt.

STOCKHOLM, April 12. -- A united front by Scandinavia against increased armaments is being urged by various peace organizations in the northern kingdoms prior to the meeting of the Council of the League of Nations in Geneva Monday.

Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute took first place in the sixth annual Metropolitan invitation rifle meet sponsored by St. John's University at the School of Firearms and Gallery yesterday. The Poly marksmen scored 677 points out of a possible 750 to annex the team prize.

Vladimir Horowitz gave a piano recital yesterday afternoon, a recital not only successful from all practical points of view, but indicative of Mr. Horowitz's development as an interpreter. He could easily have been content, after the sensational successes of his first tour of America, with the reputation of a heaven-storming virtuoso.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 13. -- Cornell and Princeton divided an Eastern League double-header today, the Ithacans taking the first game, 10 to 8, and the Tiger nine winning the second, 2 to 1, Both contests were limited to seven innings.
PHILADELPHIA, April 13. -- Dartmouth made the most of its four hits and, aided by Penn's erratic infield work, won the Eastern Intercollegiate League game on Franklin Field today, 5 to 3.

BERLIN, April 13. -- In a communique made public tonight the Reich Government formally reiterates its position on the Eastern pact or any other interstate agreement involving the assumption of mutual aid of a military nature. This official statement, it was announced, was made necessary to prevent misinterpretations abroad of Germany's "contribution" to the Stress conference.

PARIS. THE dull times which the economic crisis has brought to France have been enlivened for the American companies here by the most determined and vicious attack to which they have yet been subjected.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Former President Hoover's activity in conferring with Republican leaders, after issuing several statements aimed to guide the party's thought, is accepted by observers here as indicating that he probably means to enter the contest for the Presidential nomination next year.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- The creation of a permanent national planning agency to chart a continuing public works program was reported authoritatively today to be envisaged by President Roosevelt in shaping his $4,000,000,000 relief work plan.

The present sweeping movement to refund callable corporate bonds at considerable savings to the borrowers has reached the largest proportions since the boom days of 1928 and early in 1929. The methods used, however, are generally different from the practices employed six years ago.
PALM BEACH. -- Although Garden Club members will soon close their villas until next season, plans made recently by the organization for the beautification of the island will move forward.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP). -- Receiving little encouragement by the White House thus far, representatives of New England and Southern textile interests today nevertheless sought, another meeting with the President to attempt to persuade him to change his attitude.

BERLIN, April 13. -- The Boerse was inactive again today, although with signs of firmness. Heavy industrials were quiet. Machines were slightly stronger, Berlin Karlsruhe gaining 1 3/8 points. Electricals showed improvement ranging from 1/4 to 1/2 point. Chemicals were mixed and unsteady.

In granting the release on a writ of habeas corpus of two men, with records as pickpockets, Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo, in a decision submitted yesterday, emphasized the need for actual participation in a crime as a basis for conviction, rather than the reference to their previous records for such a violation.

That Thrift House, the permanent rummage shop at 9 West Fifty-seventh Street, an affiliate of the Federated Jewish Philanthropic Societies and of which Mrs. Julius Ochs Adler is chairman, has its "lighter" side there is no doubt.

PUPPET shows are being used as a means of discovering what ails misbehaved children. At Bellevue Psycopathic Hospital experiments are being conducted under the supervision of Dr. Lauretta Bender, senior psychiatrist of the children's department.

In a recent issue of THE TIMES I observed that a worthy movement has been started by Robert Seelav, president of the Spanish-American Society, with a view of donating a bronze plaque to La Rabida Convent at Palos, Spain, in commemoration of Columbus's sojourn.

After having been pegged at 1 per cent for more than sixteen months, the call-money market is to be allowed tomorrow to revert to a natural condition wherein supply and demand will determine the rate. It is expected that, under the new conditions, a rate of one-half of 1 per cent will be posted at the money desk of the New York Stock Exchange.

BOWIE, Md., April 13. -- Evergold and Bright Light, color-bearers of the Chicago-owned Shandon Farm, swept both stakes as the Bowie meeting came to a successful conclusion with 12,000 in attendance today. Evergold was piloted to a length-and-a-half victory by Silvio Coucci in the $5,000 added Southern Maryland Handicap, while Bright Light was first in the $2,000 added Kindergarten Stakes with Johnny Gilbert up.

BERRY FLEMING, in what his publishers describe as "his first serious novel of contemporary life," makes use of a method which is becoming increasingly popular in American fiction. He takes a handful of characters -- a dozen or so unrelated persons from all walks of life -- and stirs their various stories together into a more or less integrated pattern.

SHANGHAI. -- The village of Maotin, about thirty miles from Shanghai, is deserted, and the authorities are dragging a small lake near by for the bodies of fifty-five starving peasants who were the victims of a brutal massacre.

CHICAGO, April 13. -- All deliveries of wheat sold above $1 today as a result of general buying that swept the July and September to new high marks for the season with public participation in the market broader than at any time recently.

WITH both an evening and an afternoon of "Parsifal," in which Kirsten Flagstad will sing Kundry, the coming week's music will include Lily Pons's concert for the Judson Health Centre, a farewell visit of the Philadelphia Orchestra, led by Iturbi, and the beginning of Toscanini's farewell fortnight with the Philharmonic-Symphony.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- The American Society of International Law will devote its annual meeting hers, April 25-27, to a discussion of neutrality, in view of the attempts being made in administration and Congressional circles to define a policy in that regard for application by the government in event of war.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 13. -- Current events are reflected in current styles of women's dress, and many of the gowns for this Spring show the effect of England's silver jubilee of King George.

STRESA, Italy, April 12. -- It is the custom of diplomats to hold conferences in the world's pleasant places. Perhaps such a setting is needed as a foil to the bickerings and hairsplittings of the conferences themselves, calming ruffled spirits, disappointment and chagrin that come from refuted arguments and controverted viewpoints.

Now that President Roosevelt has signed the $4,880,000,000 Work Relief Act, Wall Street's analysts and statisticians are determining which industries will be stimulated most quickly by the expenditure of this vast fund. The-act is designed primarily to increase employment by providing useful projects, but it also will supply private industry with orders for merchandise and materials running into hundreds of millions of dollars.

A book of practical garden experience and advice comes from the pen of the versatile Max Schling, florist and seedsman. Without furbelows or confusing scientific terms, it tells in quaint but simple language just what the Amateur should know of gardening, of flowers and of the care of country or suburban grounds, together with the rudiments of effective landscaping.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- As the House entered its third day of debate on the Social Security Bill, a charge that Townsend plan followers throughout the country were being deluded into believing that the proposal calls for old-age pensions of $200 a month, when, in fact, the revised proposal embodied in the McGroarty bill would provide only $50 a month, was made by Representative Buck of California.

THE anti-war demonstrations of the past week in the colleges again direct attention dramatically to the extraordinary change that has come over the undergraduate -- and the campus -- in the years since the armistice. It is a change in viewpoint and in climate that deserves both notice and explanation.

Two wires which led from a garage at 424 West Fifteenth Street to an electric bell in the basement of 428 West Fifteenth Street, where a large still was found Friday night, resulted in the arrest yesterday of Harry Cashin and James Cashin, brothers, of 426 West Nineteenth Street.
BRONXVILLE, NY., April 13. -- Gus, the only member of the fire company here who does twenty-four-hour duty, had better not get his alarm signals mixed if his case comes up in court.

ST. GEORGE'S, Bermuda. -- Days when Bermuda was a great military and naval post and the islands were known as "the Gibraltar of the West," will be recalled on April 23 at the annual celebration by St. George's, the ancient capital, of its patron saint.

Mayor La Guardia has rejected flatly the offer of State Senate Leader John J. Dunnigan to drop the proposed legislative investigation of relief in the State in return for a pledge by the Mayor to provide additional funds for carrying on the current relief inquiry being conducted by the Aldermanic committee.

SEEDLINGS started early, in the house or in a hotbed, are now being transplanted or thinned out so that they will produce strong, stocky plants. Sometimes it takes the beginner several seasons to learn from experience that a dozen such plants will give him more and better blooms than half a hundred crowded spindling seedlings that, even if they do not perish, require weeks or months to overcome the disadvantages of early mistreatment.

Lester Borden, captain of the Fordham football team, was voted in a poll of the senior class as the student who had done most for the college, it was announced yesterday. Borden was named as one of the foremost ends in the country last Fall, and represented Fordham in the East-West game on the Coast last Jan. 1.

French attempts at the Stresa conference to prevent the unilateral denunciation of clauses of the Treaty of Versailles by strengthening the League of Nations focuses attention once again on the provisions of that document. What were its original stipulations and what remains of them today?

GERALD DU MAURIER was a versatile and competent actor, an actor-manager of the days of the prosperous theatre and the usually trifling play. He had talent; his daughter thinks, "a spark of genius." The fame of a popular actor is evanescent.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 13. -- Federal Judge Charles I. Dawson today held unconstitutional the Kerr-Smith Act regulating tobacco production.

Frayed nerves and psychological phenomena were probably responsible for the lower plane to which the hearings on the Rayburn bill in the House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce descended last week.

The "casual note, outstanding in Summer sports fashions, finds its best expression in cottons," according to the special report prepared for THE TIMES by Tobe, fashion authority and consultant to more than 100 leading stores throughout the country.

MADRID, April 13. -- The rest of Europe may be deeply concerned over international questions and the foreign policies of neighboring powers, but Spain is completely absorbed just now with party politics at home and with controversies over strictly local affairs.
The plan inaugurated nearly six months ago to provide public school camps for "experiential learning" during the Summer in near-by State parks appeared last week in material form.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 13. -- President Dennett of Williams College and Gardner Jackson, former administrative assistant to the Consumers Council of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration, spoke this afternoon before students from more than thirty New England colleges gathered at Harvard in a conference on careers in government and assailed the bureaucracy of the national government as the cultivator not only of incompetency but also of graft.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 13. -- Shipping agents are adapting themselves to the changes in the business centres of San Francisco which will be brought about by the completion of the bay bridges.

ST. LOUIS, April 12. -- Depressing weather, dust storms and Lent all conspired to slow down business and industry in the Eighth Federal Reserve District in the last week. Running the gamut from retail sales to carloading, the picture is not satisfactory. In the former, however, there is a slight activity due to Easter buying, although that has not been up to expectations.

GENEVA, April 13. -- France will ask the League of Nations Council at its session Monday merely to "regret" instead of condemning Germany's denunciation of the Versailles treaty's ban on compulsory military service, according to a source usually accurately informed. From that source comes the following information:

PHILADELPHIA, April 13. -- Development of an improved economy for Cuba and its people was offered today by Sumner Welles, Assistant Secretary of State, as evidence that the Roosevelt administration's "good neighbor" policy toward Latin America would react to the benefit of the entire Western Hemisphere.
Industry will display its wares to the public in an exhibition, bearing the subtitle "A Preview of Prosperity," which will open tomorrow night at the Rockefeller Center Forum.

An encouraging sale of boxes and seats has been reported for the recital by Mme. Lily Pons of the Metropolitan Opera which will take place on Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Judson Health Centre. Debutantes, as well as students of the Finch School, will sell programs at the recital.

PHILADELPHIA, April 11. -- In one respect, the investigation of Philadelphia's twenty-eight magistrates' courts, started a year after New York's magisterial system had undergone a purging, is a natural outgrowth of the Bar Association's recent action against criminal lawyers suspected of collusion with racketeers.

Cast in the role of a relief hurler in his first college baseball game, Harry Dahl held the opposition to five hits and no runs in six innings as Wagner College defeated St. Peter's College of Jersey City, 9 to 3, yesterday at Wagner Field, Grymes Hill, S.I.

The author of this novel has achieved the almost impossible feat of writing a crime thriller in which there is no murder and very little mystery. There is no lack of excitement, however, for murder seems imminent at any moment, and the chief villain is perfectly capable of that or any other crime, although his specialty is something less risky and far more lucrative.

GUYMON, Okla., April 13. -- Governor Marland has asked $500,000 in Federal funds for employment of 137 engineers and aides to institute a program of deep plowing in seven Northwestern Oklahoma and Panhandle counties to prevent more blowing of dust.

At the rate we are going now it won't be long until every second farmer in the United States will be a tenant. Nearly 45 per cent of our farmers were tenants in 1930, and the number is growing all the time.

There is a great deal of mystery connected with the life and death of Julian Marks, and by no means all of it is cleared up before Mr. Gilbert's story is ended. Marks is a man of great wealth and the owner of an enormously valuable diamond which he insists upon carrying on his person during a visit to Paris and Monte Carlo.

While in recent months several valuable paintings from American collections have been bought for European collections, another important canvas, formerly in an English private collection, has entered an American art gallery.

TWO days more and the crack of the bat and the multitude's roar will be heard in the land. Peanuts will crunch in grand stands and bleachers, the plaintive bark of the hot dog will sweeten the air and the sap will flow free in the rooter's veins.

LONDON, April 13. -- The status of the former German colonies now under British mandate sooner or later will be a live question once more. It will have its turn in the long series of controversies logically growing out of the admission of Germany's status of equality as a sovereign State.

SINGULARLY appropriate to the temper of public thought in America today is Ordway Tead's "The Art of Leadership,". presenting a modern philosophy of management. The author affirms the practicability of the democratic ideal in the conduct of modern American enterprises.
The loss of a $50,000 pearl and diamond necklace, the property of Mrs. William F. Kenny, wife of a close friend of former Governor Alfred E. Smith, was revealed last night.

MONTREAL, April 13. -- Leading newsprint manufacturers of the Province are considerably disturbed over some aspects of the Newsprint Bill which has just been presented to the Legislature. They appear as one in apprehending some potential dangers as contained in the measure, with their chief fear based on the reaction of consumers.

Camp Greycourt, the 326-acre city-owned tract in Orange County that has been turned into a farm for the rehabilitation of homeless and jobless men, opened its second season yesterday. Eight hundred men from the city streets and lodging houses were taken to the farm.

WITH 1934 a banner year in national park travel, plans are being made to welcome even greater numbers in 1935. These plans are not based so much on the phenomenal increase in visitors last year as on the present pre-season statistics.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- An assertion that Republican chances for the Presidency in 1936 were improving, but varying views as to how they should be capitalized, today emerged from brief and informal political parleys here between Colonel Frank Knox, Chicago publisher, and Republican Senators.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 13. -- Maclean Williamson's dash across the Yale goal line during the last thirty seconds of play gave the New York Rugby Club a 3-0 victory over Yale today. Williamson, a brilliant all-round athlete when he was at Yale, made his try from formation five yards from the Yale goal line.

WASHINGTON, April 12. -- The consumer's food dollar is being studied by government analysts. Its buying power is being measured; its distribution among food producers and distributers ascertained. Government statistics reveal that this dollar has shrunk 26 per cent in purchasing power the last two years; that farmers are getting more of it and processors and distributers less of it now than in the Spring of 1933.

IN this little book, an attractive example of typography, Mr. Griffith has gathered the choristers who have sung the praises of Bermuda. Though Shakespeare called the Bermoothes "still-vex'd" and the adventurers of his day believed them to be the abode of evil spirits, later poets have found in Bermuda only beauty and tranquillity.
PARIS, April 13. -- After more than four months of exhaustive studies and delicate negotiations carried on in silence, France's imperial conference came to a successful conclusion today.

HAVING nothing much to do, the wireless from London says most of it by reporting a quiet Holy Week ahead with nothing in the way of an opening after tomorrow night. The chief events will not take place in London at all.

Miss Nellie Broderick, 74 years old. who had been bedridden for about a year, and her sister, Mrs. Catherine L. McNenomy, 75, widow of an insurance company official, were trapped and killed early yesterday by a fire that ruined the upper half of their two-and-one-half-story frame dwelling at 109 Prospect Street, Stapleton, S.I. The property damage was estimated at about $3,500.

AT a moment when the new Germany appears to be repeating history by reversion to the old tactics of force, or threat of force, it is interesting to read an exhaustive analysis of the warrior who, to most Americans, typifies the Prussian character of the past two decades.

IN the exhibition room at the New York Public Library, where color prints of the past fifty years are being shown, a number of people have been asking questions of each other and receiving ambiguous replies. It is rather a straightforward art, yet in a collection as large as this one there are so many variations of appearance, so many differences of method and style, that one cannot feel much surprise at the interrogatory attitude.

Swimmers representing Public School 89 of Brooklyn tallied fourteen points to capture the honors in the seventh and eighth year divisions of the annual city P.S.A.L. elementary schools championship meet in the City College pool yesterday.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 13 (AP). -Affidavits were filed in Criminal Court here today against three former officials of closed banks in Indianapolis, nearly five years from the time the alleged offenses were committed.

WHETHER he is writing in his pleasant, comic vein, or whether he is turning out swift and melodramatic romance, Dornford Yates is uniformly reliable as to results. Of the two, perhaps, his romance runs second best to his comedy.

ALBANY, April 13. -- The Feld bill, which would restore to 36,000 New York City teachers some $6,000,000 to $8,000,000 in salary cuts which were imposed on them in 1932, was passed by the Assembly today and sent to Governor Lehman.

GENEVA, April 13. -- A strong plea to the International Labor Office's governing body to hasten the consideration of shorter hours for textile workers was made by David Dubinsky, the American worker delegate, before it adjourned today until May 31.

PORTLAND, Ore., April 11. -- Washington's new law placing a 2 per cent tax on all purchases totaling more than $20 made outside the State and then brought within its boundaries is stirring up opposition. In Washington this opposition is urging a referendum; in Oregon merchants propose legal action against the act as unconstitutional.
The Stevens Tech lacrosse team triumphed over Lafayette, 6 to 3, yesterday at Castle Point Field, Hoboken, N.J. It was the third straight victory for Stevens.

Consumers in the city saved millions of dollars on their food bill last year as a result of the activities of the Department of Public Markets, Commissioner William Fellowes Morgan Jr. reported yesterday in making public his annual report.

The collection of furniture, decorations, paintings and Oriental rugs of the late Alfred H. Mulliken, together with property consigned by his widow, Mrs. A.H. Mulliken, and his son, John H. Mulliken, realized $97,280 when it was auctioned on Friday and yesterday at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries.

ROME, April 13 (AP). -- Mobilization of two additional divisions of Italy's armed forces was authorized in a decree tonight by King Victor Emanuel. At the same time a government spokesman said Italy had informed the League of Nations of her willingness to deal with Ethiopia through the establishment of a conciliation commission.

While the inflationary possibilities contained in the government's increase in its buying price for silver, raised commodity quotations sharply last week, buyers were doubtful that the domestic trend could continue to go against that of world prices on a gold basis.

PHILADELPHIA, April 13. -- An award of $60,000 in cash and $6,000 a year for life, provided she does not remarry, has been made to Mrs. Mildred Santry Fell, second of three wives of John R. Fell, in settlement of her claim against his estate.

BALTIMORE, April 13. -- Sportswomen from New York came into their own today in the twenty-seventh annual running of My Lady's Manor point-to-point race when Mrs. Francis P. Garvan's Arundel won by two lengths over the same owner's Sporting Print. Hotspur 2d, the property of Mrs. W. Austin Wadsworth, was third.

IN the land of intelligence tests, "Ask Me Another" games and other forms of curiosity about many things, encyclopedic volumes have generally had a large and steady market. Whether such a widespread market existed in the case of collections of musical information was open to question.
In more ways than one, the circus was an attraction at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

AN assortment of old familiars, such as the comradely father, the self-sacrificial daughter, and the lady adventuress from France, play their prescribed roles in this latest novel by the prolific Miss Hine. The keynote of the book is the bond of deep affection between Hugh Pirnie, a widower, and his charming young daughter, Phillida.

After ten years of warfare on the various fistic battlefronts, James J. Braddock yesterday approached a step nearer to his goal, the heavyweight championship of the world, when he signed a contract to meet Max Baer in a title bout here next Summer.

NO nation in the world except Spain has accorded the first place in its literature to an author whose work is permeated with humor. Cervantes, that master of irony, revered Spain and its traditions, rebelled against those very same traditions, ridiculed the customs of his contemporaries and loved them for their customs.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- Palm Sunday finds a large colony gathered at the Greenbrier, where a wide variety of entertainment, has been planned for this most festive of weeks at White Sulphur.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP). -- Cotton consumed during March was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 481,135 bales of lint and 66,754 bales of linters, compared with 478,291 of lint and 62,850 of linters for February this year and 544,870 of lint and 73,483 of linters for March last year.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- The five millionth copy of the Boy Scout Handbook for Boys was presented to President Roosevelt today by a delegation of scout leaders who visited the White House, accompanied by a group of Eagle Scouts, boys who have won the highest honors of the order.

THREE more diverse exhibitions could hardly be put on at once than the Delphic Studios have currently undertaken. The fresh, vigorous and direct paintings of scenes and types of the Balearic Isles by Mary Hoover have for neighbors portraits, oil and tempera paintings and clever little wood carvings from cypress knees by Alida Conover and the somewhat maundering cosmic surrealism of M. Rodriguez Orgaz.

THAT Rachmaninoff in his Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini developed, for piano and orchestra, the passage used by Brahms as the basis of his fourth set of variations for the piano does not necessarily imply any relationship between the two derived compositions.

For the first time in their history voluntary chains and cooperative groups in the grocery industry equaled the annual business volume of the corporate chain organizations last year, according to a nation-wide survey completed last week by the American Institute of Food Distribution, Inc.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 13. -- Adrian Iselin 2d's Ace, from the Western Long Island Sound fleet, again displayed superiority over her rivals today to capture the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club Trophy. Ace won both the second and third races of this Star Class series, open to all entries.

THE mind of a director of an opera house is likely to be buzzing with problems, but radio is not one of them any longer, according to Herbert Witherspoon, the new general director of the Metropolitan Opera. There was a time when broadcasters, persistent upon edging the microphone into the wings of the opera, irked the impresarios, who threw up their hands and shooed the electrical devices away.

That "wholesale" discrimination against employment of Negroes was prevalent in Harlem and throughout the city was charged yesterday by witnesses before a subcommittee of the Mayor's commission on conditions in Harlem.

A Spring atmosphere will pervade the Ballroom Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria at the Lace Ball to be given on 3 for the benefit of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association. The attractiveness of the lace curtains and streamers which are to be the dominating motif in the decorations will be enhanced by masses of cherry and apple blossoms in many rooms of the suite.

BERKELEY, Calif., April 13. -- In a meet marred by an injury suffered by Neree Alix, Michigan two-mile runner, the University of California defeated the Wolverines on track and field today by the score of 76 1/2 to 54 1/2.

Nellie, black and white mongreldog mascot of the newspaper men who covered the trial of Bruno Richard Hauptmann at Flemington, N.J., took the centre of the stage yesterday at an Animal Hero Day celebration in the Astor Hotel. The event was under the sponsorship of the New York Anti-Vivi-section Society as a part of Be Kind to Animals Week.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., April 13. -- Four weeks of intensive Spring football drills were brought to a close at Lehigh today when the Brown and White conquered St. Joseph's College of Philadelphia, 20 to 14, in a practice game.

EASTOH, Pa., April 13. -- Dick (Lefty) Baldwin, making his debut as a varsity hurler for Lafayette, made an impressive showing as the Maroon nine defeated Haverford on Fisher Field today, 5 to 0. It was the third straight victory for Lafayette.

TOKYO, April 13. -- "Machinations of United States business interests in Central and South American countries against Japanese trade" are the subject of a warning published in all this morning's papers as a statement of the Foreign Office's views.

THERE is no dearth of automotive experience behind Guy W. Vaughan, newly elected president of Curtis-Wright. Upon completing high school at New Rochelle, N.Y., in 1898, he started to work for the Desberon Motor Company and later joined the Standard Automobile Company, of which he became vice president and chief engineer.

ALBANY, April 13. -- Split wide open by internal strife, the Democrats in control of the Legislature at the last minute tonight scrapped plans to bring the 1935 session to an end by midnight and voted to extend the session into next week.

Miss Ardelle Kloss of the Skating Club of New York and Bruce Mapes of the Brooklyn Skating Club yesterday won the titles undefended by last year's winners, Miss Valerie Jones and Robin Lee, national champion, as they placed first in the senior singles events of the annual Middle Atlantic skating championships held at the Ice Club.

A large luncheon and Spring fashion show will be given on Tuesday at the Central Park Casino for the benefit of the Generosity Thrift Shop at 1,257 Third Avenue. The net proceeds will be turned over to six philanthropic organizations which habitually benefit from sales made at the shop.

The Pennsylvania Company reported yesterday for 1934 a net income of $5,094,730 after taxes and charges but exclusive of $15,641 net profit on sales of securities, which was credited to the profit and loss account. This compared with a net income of $5,363,114, excluding $36,272 net loss on sales of securities in 1933.

The social security program of President Roosevelt was criticized and defended yesterday at a luncheon meeting under the sponsorship of the Bronx Free Fellowship at Rosoff's restaurant, 147 West Forty-third Street.

Events of varied character have been planned for the Bryn Mawr fete to be held Tuesday at Rockefeller Center to celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of Bryn Mawr College. One of the events of the fete will be a bridge tournament, of 150 tables, which will take place during the afternoon in the Cloisters on the sixty-seventh floor of the RCA Building.

Four student organizations at New York University honored 135 undergraduates yesterday. Ninety students were appointed to The Violet, student yearbook, University's School of Commerce; twenty-six were elected for Phi Beta Kappa.

WITH casts chiefly of artists from the Metropolitan Opera, three performances are announced by the Detroit Civic Opera Company, of which Thaddeus Wronski is general director, to take place during the second week of May. Sung in English as "The Swallow," Puccini's "La Rondine" will begin the series on Tuesday, May 7. Gounod's "Faust" will be the second opera.

DURING the season when the 1935 consignment of resolutions was being prepared as macadam for the path of good intentions, this amiable department decided, in addition to loving Terry Ramsaye and cutting down on cigarettes, to plot the bestten photoplay list from month to month as the season whisked along.

CHICAGO, April 13. -- Robert Hutchins, president of the University of Chicago, rejected today the request of Charles R. Walgreen, head of a national drug store chain, for an open meeting of the board of trustees to thresh out charges that the university is a centre of radical teaching and subversive propaganda.

A collection of Chinese art objects, in which K'ang-hsi and Ch'ien-iung pieces predominate, will be offered at auction at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Wednesday afternoon.
The storm over the Virgin Islands is whistling today around the portico of the Capitol and threatens to leave in its wake blasted political careers and hopes.

Marked by secrecy unusual in civic surveys of its kind, a study of the problems of the Port of New York has been undertaken by a group of men headed by Dock Commissioner John McKenzie with a view to drafting a program of port protection and development.

WASHINGTON, April 12. -- In raising funds to meet the appropriation of $4,800,000,000 voted by Congress for relief work, as these may be necessary, the Treasury will use the machinery of the Public Debt Service, headed by Commissioner William S. Broughton, which issues all public debt obligations of the United States and conducts transactions in these obligations after issue.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 13. -- In an address tonight before the Jefferson Union, Secretary Wallace held up "Thomas Jefferson: Practical Idealist" as a guide in the present-day "struggle for economic democracy."

ATLANTA, April 13. -- Secretary Wallace warned processors and handlers of farm commodities today that they might face "something more extreme" if they succeed in destroying the Agricultural Adjustment program.

George G. Goodwin, assistant curator of mammals at the American Museum of Natural History, is at his desk again with a wind-browned face and 400 pounds of buffalo skin as mementos of a two-week hunt in northern Alberta.

VIRTUE and sterling character may be hopelessly crushed to earth, but they are bound to rise again in a Warwick Deeping story. Young Constance Brent is the downtrodden heroine of his latest romance. She was pretty, fragile and sensitive, and keen for the joy of living.

CORLISS LAMONT has been wrestling with the problem of immortality for some time. He began as a believer. Gradually his investigations undermined his earlier assurances. "The Issues of Immortality," his first book on the subject, cleared the way for further investigations.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., April 13. -- The two-day State speech tournament of the National Forensic League was concluded tonight at the Peekskill High School. Ilion High School, with 30 points, won first place. Albany High School finished second with 27 points.

Forty-eight men many of whom bore placards protesting conditions which brought about a strike on the Independent subway construction project, were arrested shortly after 3 P.M. yesterday by police of the Fort Hamilton station when they refused to leave the street and sidewalk in front of the home of Controller Frank J. Taylor, at 35 Seventy-eighth Street, Brooklyn.

REGIONAL novels, wherein some particular bit of the United States is more or less minutely described, have become fairly numerous of late. And this is a very good thing, since it extends our acquaintance with our own country. For John Gill's novel the Eastern Shore of Maryland provides something more than a mere setting.

Nothing has so Deeply stirred scientists as the proposal, oft repeated of late, that a research moratorium be declared so that the world may be given time to adjust itself to a rapidly changing environment. Here we behold defeatism at its worst, an abject confession that the world lacks vision and social leadership.

WOODMERE, L.I., April 13. -- The Singers and Players Club of the South Shore will give a program on May 4 at the John Hessel Memorial Hall in this village. The program will be in two parts, one a concert by the choral club and the other "An Italian Fantasy," in song and pantomime, to be produced in six scenes.

Enrolment of 6,555 new members for the fifth period of the Civilian Conservation Corps will be started at army recruiting offices in New York, New Jersey and Delaware tomorrow, in accordance with orders issued by Major Gen. Dennis E. Nolan, commanding the Second Corps Area on Governors Island.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Sixteen high school girls arrived here today on the first "Good Citizenship Pilgrimage" to be conducted under the auspices of the Daughters of the American Revolution. They will be the society's guests over the week-end.

PHILADELPHIA, April 13. -- Temple suffered its first defeat of the season today, the Penn A.C. nine winning by a score of 8 to 5. The game was decided in the ninth, when the Penn A.C. tallied three runs on a pass, a sacrifice by French and singles by Carlston, McGill, Harwi and McKenna.

STRESA, Italy, April 13. -- The discussions at the Stresa conference were completed this evening after a hard day in which the delegates talked for almost seven hours. As to the conclusions reached there will be no announcement until tomorrow, at the request of the British.

Louis Mastriani is quite correct when he says that the average American wage-earner is not opposed to organization. The average American wage-earner is simply indifferent. An excellent example is the labor situation in Ohio, a State which is certainly as "representative" as any in the Union.

New York premieres of five contemporary musical works will be given at the concluding concert of the League of Composers' twelfth season, scheduled for the French Institute tomorrow night. Among the novelties will be Paul Hindemith's "Die Serenaden," described as light and frankly melodious, for voice, oboe, viola and 'cello.

DALLAS, Texas, April 12. -- Faith among Texas Democrats in New Deal agricultural policies, which has wavered perceptibly on more than one occasion lately as statistics continue to reveal a decline in cotton consumption at home and abroad, came nearer to toppling this week when Texas ginners threatened defiance of the Bankhead law.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 13. -- The North and South women's golf championship went South today for the first time in its thirty-five-year history when Miss Estelle Lawson, 26-year-old Chapel Hill (N.C.) girl, defeated Miss Charlotte Glutting of East Orange, N.J., the medalist and defending champion, 1 up, in the eighteen-hole final.
MARK TWAIN'S version of the French duel -- an affair in which the greatest danger is in taking cold -- does not describe the modern combat on the field of honor here.

FRANKLY, Mr. van Druten's new play is disappointing. "Flowers of the Forest," which Katharine Cornell has just produced for American audiences, strikes out at the glory and nobility of war. At a time when every one is facing the possibility of a renewal of war between nervous nations and another reckless destruction of human life by gunfire Mr. van Druten finds audiences eager to hear anything he can say.

MIDDLEBURG, Va., April. 13. -- Indigo, favored gray gelding from the Northwood Stables, was well ridden by W.B. Cocks to an easy victory in the fifteenth annual Middleburg Hunt Cup race at the Glenwood course on the D.C. Sands estate today.

THE scene -- village of Belltown, in Southern New Hampshire -- and certain of the people are the same here as in Miss Marshall's "None but the Brave," her present story carrying on the wholesome cheeriness and adulation of rustic

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- "New Dealers" today had their first opportunity to see themselves as Reuben Nakian of New York, sculptor, sees them, and as they will be presented to posterity in clay or bronze.

More than 10,000 of the 15,000 dressmakers involved in the stoppage of work begun last Tuesday in protest against piece rates that failed to yield the minimum wages guaranteed by the union agreement will return to work tomorrow, it was announced last night by Julius Hochman, general manager of the joint board of the Dressmakers' Union.

A fear of kidnappers, caused by the kidnapping and murder of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr. three years ago, caused Clarence D. Chamberlin, transatlantic flier, and his wife, Mrs. Wilda Chamberlin, to keep secret from all but relatives and close friends the birth of a daughter in Paris Aug. 22, 1933.
My favorite prediction for the past two months has been that 1935 will prove to be a great year for baseball.

PARIS. THREE years ago I received the visit of a young collegian who brought me a manuscript. Too often the first lines of such writings suffice to discourage the reader, but, in this case, on the contrary, a few words sufficed to reveal to me a born writer.

Five leading New York banks and the General Electric Company will begin on Tuesday at 10:30 A.M. to defend themselves against evidence introduced in the last six weeks in the Federal court. They are charged with having disregarded the rights of 23,000 Insull debenture holders, who now claim restitution of $30,000,000.

GIVE us again roses with the old-fashioned rose fragrance." That is the demand which, during recent years, has been repeated more and more frequently. It is a demand which merits attention, and already rose breeders have turned their efforts in this dirction.

George J. Schaefer of New Rochelle, who has hunted for big game fish in the waters off Catalina, Montauk and Key West, experienced some new thrills when he made his first trip to Bimini recently. He found the fishing at the Bahaman resort all that had been claimed for it.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 13. -- Jack Doon, sprightly brown gelding, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Untermyer of Greenwich and shown by Miss Frances Thord-Gray, captured the hunter championship as the eighth annual Spring horse show held by the Round Hill Club in its riding hall came to a close tonight. Dr. Edgar, 6-year-old chestnut, belonging to C.W. Howard was placed in reserve.
PORTLAND, Me., April 13. -- A special convocation of Colby College on May 18, to be devoted to the subject of the freedom of the press, was authorized by the Colby Board of Trustees today.

AMERICAN readers wishing to learn something of Maimonides, the great Jewish physician and philosopher whose eight hundredth anniversary is being commemorated this year, have heretofore found rather slim pickings in their native tongue.

VIENNA, April 12. -- The Austrian Government has not been fortunate in the impression created by three recent big political trials, the last of which, the trial of Major Eiller and twenty other former leaders of the Republican Defense Corps, is just drawing to a close.

News was received yesterday from Belfast that the two Union Castle 25,000-ton passenger liners under construction at the Harland Wolff shipyard for the South African trade will be equipped with an electrical time system, a departure from the present practice.

SEATTLE, April 11. -- Although the Federal Constitution prohibits the several States from levying duties on imports or exports except with the consent of Congress, Washington's new Retail Sales Tax Law puts a penalty of 2 per cent on goods bought elsewhere.

Rumors that a half-dozen nations shortly will be operating centralized buying and selling agencies modeled on Soviet Russia's Amtorg Trading Corporation, here, caused widespread concern among exporters yesterday. Countries where plans for such commercial representation are under serious discussion are reported to be Italy, Czechoslovakia, Rumania, Hungary, Spain and Chile. In all except Italy, plans are understood to be still in the discussion stage.

RICHMOND, Va., April 12. -- Although seventy years have passed since Grant and Lee met at Appomattox, and the North and the South have fought two wars side by side since that time, serious obstacles are in the way of a proposed joint reunion in Washington next year between the surviving Union and Confederate veterans.

Nearly 2,000 members of Manhattan troops of the Boy Scouts of America took part last night in their annual rally, held this year in the armory of the 102d Regiment of Engineers at 168th Street and Fort Washington Avenue.

DETROIT, April 13. -- The 'Automobile Labor Board, of which Dr. Leo Wolman is chairman, announced today a "constitution" for guidance of the bargaining agencies elected by about 19,000 employee of the automobile industry.

ONE thing, at any rate, the nineteenth annual exhibition of the Society of Independent Artists at the Grand Central Palace reports with unmistakable emphasis: These are troubled times, politically and sociologically considered.

Lynn Hunt of the North Jersey Gun Club led a field of seventy-five gunners in the registered shoot of the Amateur Trapshooting Association over the traps of the New York A.C. at Travers Island yesterday. Competing in Class A, Hunt won the High-Over-All Cup by breaking 98 out of 100 targets.

IT has been an unpleasant week for the cinema. Eating words has never been enjoyable; and eating harsh words, a prospect confronting the industry, is bitter even to contemplate. From indications, it would seem that all the wild conversation about quitting California if a picture tax is imposed has fallen on alien ears.

RECENTLY the inventor of the autogiro, Juan de la Cierva, spoke before the Royal Aeronautical Society on the new developments of his rotating-wing aircraft. His remarks as to the possibilities inherent in this type with "direct take-off," as he calls it, hold out interesting hopes both for the private flier and the commercial application of the larger autogiro.

The Spring vacation period for all public schools in the city win begin Thursday, the first day of the Jewish Passover, instead of Good Friday, as usually is the custom. Schools will close after classes Wednesday and will reopen April 29. This is in accordance with a resolution presented by James Marshall, member of the Board of Education, and adopted by the board at its meeting last week.

SHEILA MACDONALD has every reason to congratulate herself upon her latest novel, which marks a notable advance, both in matter and style, on her previous work. The present reviewer, who knows South Africa and who found "The Outsider" disappointing because of its apparently ingrained romanticism, was agreeably surprised to discover that "Mr. Crusoe's Young Woman" was stiffened by substantial chunks of realism and rendered palatable by occasional tartness.

Very little note was taken of a move made a month ago by Secretary Swanson of the Navy. That move, it has been held, may be the most important single step taken in a long time for the continuation and further development of the airship program of the United States.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 13. -- The senior class at Vassar College gave its annual promenade tonight in Students Building. The program started this afternoon with a concert by the college sextet. The receiving line formed shortly after 5 o'clock.

WINCHESTER, Va., April 13. -- Mlle. Nella Veverka, 20-year-old daughter of the Czechoslovak Minister at Washington, today was named to reign over the twelfth Shenandoah Apple Blossom Festival as Queen Shenandoah XII. The festival will be held May 2 and 3.

A MEMBER of the teaching staff of Mercersburg Academy and, he says, a teacher of boys for thirty years, Mr. Rutledge has extensive stores of knowledge upon which to draw for this little book about boys, schools, teachers and the atmosphere that dominates the institutions.

THE FORDS: Almost half a century ago a young chap named Henry Ford made a distinctly favorable impression on Miss Clara Bryant by showing her a watch he had made which was equipped with extra hands, thus making it possible to determine the hour in either "sun" or "standard" time.

For months past there have been evidences of a strong feeling against a "planned economy" under our Government. Many who were blithely for the new system two years ago and a year ago are now eager to get rid of large parts of it. Hence the National Recovery Act in the way of being "revised" out of all recognition.

PITTSBURGH, April 13 (AP). -- Records from the A.W. Mellon income-tax hearing disclose that the financier lists his public gifts for educational and charitable purposes for the five years ending in 1934 at $23,612,031.32.

THE clerk at the Hotel Chatham stopped sorting envelopes and raised his head. "Charles Laughton, please," said the visitor. "Sorry," murmured the clerk, "Mr. Laughton left word he was not to be awakened until 10:30."
Magistrate Louis B. Brodsky in Yorkville court yesterday freed two fathers accused of stealing a case of milk and gave one of them $5 to help feed six children who the father said were starving.

Adverse weather conditions took toll of retail trade in the New York metropolitan area last week. The sales volume of department and other stores ran well under expectations for a period so close to Easter. Estimates indicated that department-store sales ranged from 5 to 8 per cent above last year to declines of similar amounts.

A homeless man about 55 years old was burned to death, three persons were carried down ladders from blazing apartments and twelve children were carried to safety across fire escapee last night when fire swept a five-story tenement at 345 West Forty-third Street, near Ninth Avenue.

NICE, France, April 13 (AP). -- Renewed warnings of the "German peril" and gratification that "Russia's military forces" were on the French side were voiced today before the Republican Federation Congress.

Peace negotiations started recently by Argentina and Chile to end war in the Chaco between Bolivia and Paraguay have excellent chances to succeed, according to Senator Oscar Valenzuela, president of the Committee on Foreign Affairs for the Senate of Chile, who made this statement yesterday in an interview at the Hotel St. Moritz.

By ridiculing a few projects whose immediate practical value was not obvious to them, opponents of work relief have been casting doubt upon a large amount of valuable work conducted under the so-called white-collar projects. These misunderstandings tend to jeopardize a program which means the difference between self-respect and collapse of morale for tens of thousands of people who are performing useful public tasks in a period of great personal stress.

There has been a large subscription for the concert arranged by Albert Morris Bagby in behalf of the investment fund of the Music Lovers' Foundation Inc., which will take place Tuesday afternoon in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Artists who have donated their services are Miss Lucrezia Bori, Mme. Elisabeth Rethberg, Richard Bonelli, Giovanni Martinelli, Ezio Pinza and Emanuel List, all of the Metropolitan Opera; Miss Galli-Campi, and Albert Spalding, violinist.

If it should ever become necessary to classify this novel for textbook purposes, it would have to be put down under the heading of "stories of local color." Any injustice involved in this classification would be at worst no more than superficial.
OKLAHOMA CITY, April 13 (AP). -- Winning five titles and amassing 32 points during the championship round, the Oklahoma A. and M. College team tonight clinched the national A.A.U. wrestling crown.

Locked with a golden key, the Florentine folio holds a secret in the life of Ophelia Clifford, a secret which, according to the terms of Miss Clifford's will, was to be buried with her. But when, after the sudden death of Miss Clifford, it is discovered that the will has been destroyed and that the key is missing.

STRESA, Italy, April 13. -- Officials said late tonight that seven declarations would be published tomorrow, each containing a separate point upon which an agreement had been reached either in full or in principle by the tripartite conference. They stated that the declarations would discuss the following subjects:

MILAN, March 27, 1935. FIORDISOLE" (Sun Daughter), "choregraphic fantasy" in six scenes by Gino Cornali, music by Franco Vittadini, scored a definite success over a few protests on its recent premiere at La Scala, as the sole terpsichorean novelty of the Milanese season.

GENEVA, April 13. -- The committee that for eight weeks has been discussing the United States draft arms traffic treaty finished the first reading of it today and adjourned. There was enough agreement for several delegates to express the hope that the treaty could be concluded on the second reading, but so much disagreement that no one even suggested fixing the date of the second reading.

THOSE who drive to Atlantic City and the other resorts on the New Jersey coast for the Easter week-end have a choice of various routes, all in good condition. They are indicated on the accompanying map.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 13. -- Taking part in its first game of lacrosse indoors, the Army ten opened the Spring sport schedule here by defeating Springfield College, 12 to 2, today in a well played game.

AINTREE, England (By Mall). -- There were four in the party that took a race train out of Exchange Station in Liverpool at precisely 10 o'clock of a fine sunny morning. The Grand National was scheduled for 3:15 in the afternoon but only the Prince of Wales could arrive late and hope for a good seat.

The last effort in attaining physical perfection having been made, the sixteen clubs of the two major circuits will embark upon another championship baseball campaign on Tuesday with the National League launching its sixtieth pennant race and the American loop setting out on its thirty-sixth.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 13. -- By breaking 46 out of 50 targets, R. Kohler won the scratch prize in the regular 16-yard event at the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. The handicap trophy went to J.F. Simonson, who had a card of 44 -- 5 -- 49.

" SAP'S RUNNING," they say in New England, is the first infallible sign of Spring. The steady drip of the sap from the sugar maple is a harbinger more to be depended upon than even the wild geese honking north to Hudson Bay, and for weeks past the sap buckets have been brimming from the Berkshires to Vermont.
DETROIT, April 13. -- New steel mills, apartment houses, factory additions, theatres and religious institutions are major items in Greater Detroit's $64,000,000 building program for 1935.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 13. -- Resolutions favoring social insurance, the Copeland bill for eliminating false advertising, administration housing efforts, the AAA plan of production control by marketing and acreage provisions, the Child Labor Amendment, and government control of certain distressed industries, were adopted at the final plenary session of the Whig-Clio conference on business and government which closed today.

The board of directors of the American Palestine Campaign, fund-raising agency in the United States of the Central Bureau for the Settlement of German Jews in Palestine and the Jewish Agency for Palestine, has been increased from forty-two to seventy-five members at its annual meeting, it was announced yesterday.

The last concert of the season, and certainly the best of the three which have been given publicly by the New York Woman's Symphony Orchestra, took place yesterday evening in Town Hall. The program was fortunately arranged, especially in the first part, because this offered scores that sound well in a small hall, and in one instance a work rarely heard, which deserved to be better known.

WASHINGTON, April 12. -- A new plan of strategy by which Senator Long hopes to prevent President Roosevelt's re-election in 1936 caused much discussion this week among politicians of both major parties.
PARIS, April 2. -- The forthcoming exposition of Italian art, which opens on May 14 at the Petit Palais, will be a feature of what promises to be a busy social season.

NEW LONDON, Conn., April 13. -- In an after-breath of the Northeast storm that has lashed the coast since last Sunday night, the North American Dinghy Association's first national regatta was initiated tonight on the Thames River.

HARTFORD, April 13. -- Much historic interest attaches to many of the garments and accessories of the Costume Exhibition which the Connecticut Society of the Colonial Dames of America will conduct at the Morgan Memorial here, starting on Tuesday of this week.

ONCE there was a car barn on Seventh Avenue. Old-timer still remember plunging, with bated breath, through the drab no man's land of that region between Broadway and the comparatively settled territory of Sixth.

THE author of the successful "Beth: A Sheep Dog" here turns biographer of a horse. A generation raised on "Black Beauty" measure some of the distance traversed since that sentimental and tearful volume appeared by comparing this story told in the first person (or animal) by Revenge, race horse, steeplechaser and hunter.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 13. -- For the first time in Ohio history, a Governor of the State has asked charity for the funding of operations of his office. Governor Martin L. Davey made the request today when he said he saw no chance to get the Ohio Senate to vote him funds.

OAKLAND, Calif., April 13. -- The University of Washington's varsity oarsmen drove their gleaming shell to a thrilling victory over California today in a three-mile race so close it was first announced California had won the classic.

VERBANK, N.Y., April 13. -- After the dogs had run eight hours under difficult conditions, the judges tonight awarded the three prizes in the Open All-Age Stake of the Orange County Field Trial Club's annual Spring meeting as follows:

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- The Irving Trust Company, as trustee for the United Cigar Stores Company of America, has violated Section 7a of the Recovery Act, in discharging two clerks employed in Chicago stores of the bankrupt company, according to a decision made public today by the National labor Relations Board.

The extent to which banks have become dependent upon United States Government securities for the investment of their funds has been illustrated with renewed force in the reports for the first quarter of the year that have appeared in the last two weeks.

WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., April 13 (AP). -- The Wilmerding (Pa.) five tonight won the national Y.M.C.A. basketball tournament by defeating the team of the 135th Street branch of New York, 50 to 28, in the final.

Endorsement of Parents Day, which will be celebrated on the Central Park Mall May 12 by school children, was contained in a letter from Governor Lehman to Uncle Robert, children's radio entertainer and co-sponsod with the Board of Education of the celebration.

Flatbush fans took their first look at the 1935 Dodgers at Ebbets Field yesterday and all 5,000 of them went away in the drizzling rain with nothing to feel elated about. For Joe McCarthy's pennant-aspiring Yankees won the first engagement of the exhibition season wind-up by the score of 8 to 4.

BOSTON, April 12. -- Over all New England tension prevails because of the perils that threaten the cotton textile industry. Mills in five States are reducing hours or shutting down. At a hearing this week on Beacon Hill labor for the first time in years joined capital in presenting a common cause.
PHOENIX, Ariz., April 13. -Southern California was menaced today by a dust storm which swirled westward across Arizona and New Mexico from its source in the Texas Panhandle.

Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, refused yesterday to accept the resignation of Miss Dorothy Kenyon as public representative on the new Hotel and Restaurant Wage Board that will fix wages and working conditions of 60,000 hotel and restaurant workers.

SPRING skiing on the high slopes of the White Mountains will reach its climax on April 19, and the holiday will find many an expert, among them a group from the Amateur Ski Club of New York, climbing to Tuckerman's Ravine on Mount Washington for a last fling at the steep grades.

FROM a distance no longer so great as it once seemed to be, the United States looks warily at the hazardous course of events in Europe. We have no commitments in this conflict of national purposes which statesmen are seeking to avert. But we know from experience how close-knit is the world and how rare is the role of the outsider.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- An agreement intended to avert a strike affecting 35,000 employes of three principal rubber companies in Akron was signed today by union leaders and officers and counsel of the companies. It will be submitted to the unions in Akron tomorrow for ratification and the union leaders expressed hope that it would be approved.

Music of Soviet composers was played, sung and danced to, in Mecca Temple last night at the first of two concerts devoted to compositions of contemporary Russians. The second has been announced for next Saturday. Participating in last night's event were the Orchestral League of New York, Charles Lichter, conductor; the Choral Art Guild, Alexan Saron, conductor, and Lillian Shapero and her dance group.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 13. -- "Navy Juniors," supervised by Spike Webb, coach of Naval Academy and Olympic boxing teams, engaged in their sixteenth annual tournament today. Many of the contestants, who squared off and pummeled one another enthusiastically, were related to former Navy athletes and are on the way to the same academy.
WASHINGTON, April 12. -- Are the "House Mavericks" getting ready to stampede this Spring, or are they slowly coming within range of the administration and partisan branding irons?
