There has been a search in the correspondence columns of The London Times for the author of the "accidental" stanza, delightful by contrast with its severe subject, which reads thus in HOYT'S "Encyclopedia of Practical Quotations" and in STEVENSON'S "Home Book of Quotations":

Strong rallying tendencies were in evidence on the Stock Exchange yesterday and the volume of business held up well in spite of the restrictive influences which normally are at work in advance of a holiday. Trading was quiet, however, in the commodity markets, where price movements were irregular.

GRAND CANYON, Ariz., April 18 (AP). -- Fiorello H. La Guardia, who gave an address on "The Office Seeker's Platform" at high school graduation exercises at Prescott, near here, in 1898, returned to the country of his boyhood today.

So great has the agitation become regarding the supposed menace of importation of cotton goods from Japan, that the President has finally felt obliged to turn the question over to the Tariff Commission for "investigation." It would be certain to injure us in the long run if we were to lose our sense of proportion in this matter and end by taking discriminatory action against Japanese goods.

Government in business, as a policy, was frowned upon in a forum held last night in the Women's National Republican Club at 3 West Fifty-first Street, under joint auspices with the National Republican Club. Colonel Theodore Roosevelt, president of the men's organization, presided.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Mrs. William A. Becker of New Jersey was elected today to succeed Mrs. Russell William Magna as president-general of the Daughters of the American Revolution. The vote was 1,436 for Mrs. Becker and 619 for Mrs. Flora Myers Gillentine, her opponent in the most hotly contested election in years.

Business activity declined in March chiefly because of decreases in the daily averages for cotton consumption, steel ingot production and pig iron output, according to The Annalist. Next in importance were declines in the daily average power production and freight-car loadings.

BERLIN, April 18. -- Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler left his Bavarian mountain retreat and went to Munich today to confer with party leaders and close advisers over the form his answer to the League of Nations Council's indictment of Germany shall take.

VIENNA, April 18. -- In a silence broken only by sobbing women, twenty-one officers of the Socialist Republican Defense Corps stood at attention in court here this morning while the judge read out their sentences, totaling 129 1/2 years of rigorous imprisonment.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- If Herbert Hoover's friends here are well informed and he intends to write a series of articles in the course of which he will attempt to show that the emergency steps taken by President Roosevelt in the banking crisis were almost in toto those formulated by the Hoover administration, he will have no difficulty in making his point.

Joseph Testa, 11 years old, of Fort Lee, N.J., was crushed to death there yesterday afternoon by a half-ton boulder which fell on him while he and two other children were climbing on a cliff of the Palisades.

Donald R. Richberg, chairman of the National Industrial Recovery Board, asserted last night that "a vast majority" of trade and industry wanted an extension of the NRA, and urged those in favor to voice their support with greater force.

Will the enemies of the profit motive kindly think back over the weather of the last fortnight? The forces that control the solar system are supposed to operate for use and not for profit. But what conceivable use is there in this perfectly wretched Spring we have been having?

LONDON, April 18. -- On his return from Geneva this morning Sir John Simon, British Foreign Secretary, learned that the German Government had delivered an oral protest against Great Britain's action at Stresa and at Geneva in supporting the League of Nations Council resolution censuring the Reich.
BUENOS AIRES, April 18. -- Argentina's new tax on imports is vigorously assailed as unconstitutional in a two-column editorial published by the newspaper Prensa today.

HARRISBURG, Pa., April 18. -Governor Earle today accepted the stop-gap relief plan of the Republican-controlled State Senate and, in consequence, Pennsylvania was assured $20,000,000 for unemployment needs until May 15.

Acting Mayor Bernard S. Deutsch chided Park Commissioner Robert Moses yesterday for his "obstreperous" tactics in the aldermanic relief investigation, but decided to withhold formal action on complaints against Mr. Moses until Mayor La Guardia returns next week.

The trend of commodity prices in the first quarter of 1935 was generally upward, despite the drop in March with the break in cotton, The Annalist says, and that publication's index of wholesale commodity prices rose to 126.6 on last Tuesday from 121.9 on Jan. 15.

THE HAGUE, April 18. -- Of 3,320,000 votes cast in ten of the eleven Netherland provinces in Provincial Council elections yesterday, the results of which were announced today, the National Socialists, presenting candidates for the first time in the Netherlands history, obtained 264,000 ballots, or slightly less than 8 per cent.

TOKYO, April 18. -- A Japanese economic mission to the United States is being considered by the Foreign Office, which the newspaper Asahi reports is consulting the Japanese Economic Federation and the Japanese-American Trade Council.

Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey declared yesterday afternoon that more active participation by citizens in government, decentralization of governmental functions and development of interstate compacts were necessary for a progressive administration of the nation's affairs in the future.
WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Arthur Krock's dispatch in THE TIMES of April 17 on the Costigan-Wagner Anti-Lynching Bill contains grave misstatements, which I ask THE TIMES to correct.

Our esteemed neighbor The Sun printed Wednesday an interesting, if too brief, summary of the bills, mostly unsuccessful, introduced into State Legislatures this year, rudely classified as "freak" legislation or attempts at it. It is too early yet to get a comprehensive view of this subject.

ALBANY, April 18. -- Sharp cleavages in the Democratic and Republican parties foreshadowing trends in the Presidential campaigns next year were brought out by the session of the Legislature just closed.

Headed by Tommy Miyamoto, who made a host of friends wherever he appeared when he was here before, a team of six Japanese golf stars is now nearing Seattle for the first official golf invasion the Nipponese have made.

The city is again preparing to take the 5-cent fare issue to the United States Supreme Court, it was ascertained yesterday. This time it will go there in an effort to prevent Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver for the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, from disaffirming the company's 999-year lease of its elevated lines.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., April 18. -- Collecting eleven hits off two twirlers, Long Island University's nine won from Virginia today, 5 to 2, in a clean-fielding game.
WASHINGTON, April 18. -- The Omnibus Banking Bill of 1935 was completed today by the House Banking and Currency Committee in almost precisely the form the administration desires.

Organization of a company to engage in the remodeling of old residential and commercial buildings on a national scale was revealed yesterday with the announcement of plans of the Interstate Reconstruction Corporation to buy for its headquarters the former State Title and Mortgage Company Building at 340 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Although Jimmy Foxx made his second home run in as many days, the Philadelphia Athletics could not match Washington's early spurt and lost again to the Senators, 6 to 5, today.

John Farrar reports that "Don't Ever Leave Me," by Katherine Brush, which will be published by Farrar Rinehardt on April 22, has had the largest advance sale of any novel published by them this season.

SYRACUSE, April 18. -- When Miss Marguerite Scholl, Bronx stenographer, stepped from the witness stand in Federal court here this afternoon, Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer gave proof that his nerves were a bit overtaxed.

A jury which was unable to arrive at a verdict after deliberating almost two full days, was discharged yesterday afternoon by Federal Judge John C. Knox, who told the twelve men that "the jury system has failed to operate as it should."

BRUNSWICK, Me., April 18. -Fascism, communism or collective "planning" by the State, which can be none other than socialism, might possibly be made to function in America, but only on a much lower level of productivity and a consequently greatly reduced standard of living, Ogden L. Mills, former Secretary of the Treasury, declared in an address tonight before the Institute of Politics at Bowdoin College in which he denounced the policies of the Roosevelt administration.
OTTAWA, Ont., April 18 (Canadian Press). -- A substantial increase in both deposits and investments was shown today in the weekly statement of the Bank of Canada.

DERBY, Conn., April 18. -- John Sherman of Chicago, Yale law student and member of a prominent Ohio family, narrowly escaped being killed by electricity, burned to death in an airplane, killed by crashing to earth and finally drowning, in a quick succession of adventures within five minutes this afternoon as he flew a small plane into a mass of high tension wires over the Housatonic River, in front of the Robert J. Cook boathouse.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- The Code Authority for the live poultry industry of the New York metropolitan area asked NRA approval today of proposed code budgets for the periods May 1 to June 16 and June 17 to April 30, 1936. The amounts are $13,327.50 and $91,792.50, respectively.

Six innings elapsed before the Yankees got their batting artillery functioning correctly at the Stadium yesterday, but once the lucky seventh had rolled around, the McCarthymen began to bunch hits and then proceeded to blank the Red Sox, 4 to 0.

Retail package deliveries made for stores in the metropolitan area during the week ended April 13 showed a decrease of 2 per cent under the same week a year ago, according to the report issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service.

In one of the largest Fifth Avenue realty deals in recent years, Bergdorf-Goodman has purchased the building at the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street, which it has occupied under lease for seven years.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 18. -Twenty-eight grants totalling $34,681 for research in the social sciences by members of the faculty of Harvard University in the departments of sociology, psychology, history, government and economics, were revealed today by the Harvard University Committee on Research in the Social Sciences, operating under a grant from the Rockefeller Foundation.

ST. PAUL, April 18 (AP). -- The death-threatening ransom notes which demanded payment of as much as twice the $200,000 finally yielded for his release were introduced today in the trial of ten alleged conspirators in the Edward G. Bremer abduction.

The report of the Alleghany Corporation for 1934, issued yesterday, shows a net loss of $983,042 after charges, interest and general expenses. For 1933, the company had reported a net loss of $1,336,806. The profit from the sale of securities in 1934, which was not included in the income account, was $689.

Bank clearings were lower in the week ended on Wednesday, their second consecutive decrease. The total for twenty-two leading cities, as reported by Dun Bradstreet Inc., was $5,321,203,000, against $6,021,939,000 in the corresponding week of last year, a loss of 11.6 per cent.
ITHACA, N.Y., April 18. -- Cornell's traditional junior smoker in honor of the winners of the varsity "C" during the past year was held tonight with 179 awards made in twelve sports.

Many new leases for office, showroom and loft space in Manhattan were closed yesterday with firms dealing in men's and boys' clothing, furs, dresses and kindred apparel lines. The leasing, most of which was done in the midtown area, included contracts for a number of retail stores.

Member banks of the Federal Reserve System recovered an additional $214,000,000 of reserves in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the report of the System, published yesterday. The gain followed one of $94,000,000 last week, making a total rise of $308,000,000 in the two weeks.
BUFFALO, April 18. -- Opposition to the reorganization plan for the Terminal and Transportation Company of America was presented in Federal court today before Judge John Knight.

If the offer of a rate cut by the Consolidated Gas Company is as favorable to New York City as it is to the United States Treasury "the latter will sign the contract," Secretary Morgenthau declared yesterday in Washington.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- The administration compromise bonus plan was described tonight in a radio speech by its author, Senator Harrison, as the only bill of this character which can be enacted at this session of Congress.

Chaos in international trade and finance will be an inevitable result of international competition in currency inflation, Dr. E.W. Kemmerer of Princeton, internationally known authority on monetary matters, said here yesterday in a speech before the fourteenth annual meeting of the National Council of American Importers and Traders, Inc., in the Hotel Astor.

Mrs. William A. Duncan gave a luncheon yesterday in the roof garden of the St. Regis for Mrs. William A. Pond Phipps, Mrs. Clinton S. Lutkins and Mrs. Lawrence Swift. The luncheon guests there of Miss Mabelle Lane were Mrs. Edward Kendall, Mrs. Acosta Nichols, Mrs. Edgar Miller and Mrs. F. Hallett Lovell.

The problems confronting Jews in various parts of the world were discussed yesterday morning in sermons at Passover services in synagogues. The services commemorated deliverance of the Jews from Egyptian bondage.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, first department, handed down yesterday a decision in a policy case that is expected to compel the police to change their methods. Assistant District Attorney James J. Wilson said the police would have to confine arrests to "big shots" and not the "poor one and two-cent players."

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Another firm protest to Japan against the Manchukuoan oil monopoly is being made by the State Department as a result of the unsatisfactory reply last week to the first protest.

The various Republican forays in preparation for the great conflict of 1936 are causing some old Republican campaigners and strategists to utter words of caution. Let not the public suppose that these agitations and committees and conferences are in favor of any one man.

Eastern seaboard ports from Boston to Norfolk asked the Eastern railroads yesterday to cooperate in an effort to prevent the diversion to Gulf ports of traffic from the Middle West which should move to the Eastern seaboard. The railroads were asked to cancel their concurrence with Southern lines in joint import or export or proportional rates between Central Freight Association or Middle Western territory and Gulf and Southern ports.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended April 17, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,476,000,000, an increase of $15,000,000 compared with the preceding week and a decrease of $28,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1934.

Trading on the commodity futures markets here yesterday was light except in sugar and hides, which were strong. On the cash markets, corn and cotton advanced, and wheat, rye, lard, tin, silk and rubber declined.
BOSTON, April 18. -- The Giants pulled stakes today and headed for Philadelphia, where they hope for conditions that will come nearer the popular conception of baseball weather.

PARIS. April 18. -- Foreign Minister Pierre Laval returned to Paris from Geneva this evening bringing with him the text of the Franco-Russian agreement negotiated with Foreign Commissar Maxim Litvinoff, which he will submit to the Cabinet tomorrow. If it is approved it will probably be initialed at once and signed when M. Lavai goes to Moscow, probpbly about the middie of May.

BOSTON, April 18. -- Frank D. Comerford, president of the Edison Electric Illuminating Company of Boston, has called special meeting of stockholders for April 30 to consider the refinancing of short indebtedness of the company. The management and directors have under consideration several plans, he said tonight.

Opening at the Capitol and Loew's Metropolitan in Brooklyn this morning is Jean Harlow's new picture, "Reckless," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer offering, in which she is co-starred with William Powell. Other members of the cast are Franchot Tone, May Robson and Ted Healy.

Yesterday's statement for the twelve reserve banks showed the largest gold holdings on record, and a ratio of reserve to deposits and circulation the highest of the present year, and the highest since Sept. 23, 1931. No other high or low records were touched for the year.

CHICAGO, April 18. -- Brother Paul Dean, handsomely assisted by Joe Medwick, conquered the Chicago Cubs today, 1 to 0, for the first of the forty victories this season promised by the speaking member of the Dean clan, brother Dizzy.

Rallying tendencies, although not very pronounced, characterized trading in bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday. United States Government bonds, which were lethargic most of the day, stiffened at the close and finished generally higher, up 4-32 to off 2-32 point.

WELLESLEY, Mass., April 18. -An eight-stall Texas horse van, which, until it was barred from Wellesley College last week, was the home of a new Wellesley "sorority," "Forty and Eight" (40 femmes, 8 chevaux), seems likely to have a place in the sun in the college town after all.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, on returning from his second Antarctic expedition, will make his official landing here on May 10, and he will be welcomed home by President Roosevelt. This announcement, made by the White House, was the first disclosure that Admiral Byrd would not make his first landing in New York, as he did on his return from his first Antarctic expedition.

Foreign liquidation and commission house profit-taking carried prices off 15 points at one time yesterday on the Cotton Exchange at which stage an improvement in the stock market stimulated active buying. A recovery of 30 points wiped out the early loss, leaving the list with gains of 10 to 12 points on the day.

Herbert Witherspoon, the new general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Association, will announce a tentative repertory for next season and the names of some of the artists who have been reengaged next week, he said yesterday.

ARLINGTON, Texas, April 18 (AP). -- Jockey Paul Keester tied Wayne Wright as America's leading rider of winning horses today when he piloted Ima Count to victory in the Cowpuncher Purse over the Waggoner Course at Arlington Downs.

Charles Pinnell, head of Fred Butterfield Co., was re-elected president of the Textile Color Card Association at the annual meeting of the organization held yesterday at its headquarters, 200 Madison Avenue. Twelve directors were elected for the coming year, an increase of three over the previous number.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- The political future of Herbert Hoover is so completely in the lap of the gods that the former President can do nothing about it himself, William Allen White of Emporia told the American Society of Newspaper Editors today.
BOSTON, April 18. -- Marathon runners are ready to compete tomorrow in the thirty-eighth running of the Boston A. A.'s famous race from Hopkinton to its Back Bay clubhouse.

Your account of my address to the Barnard students yesterday inadvertently misrepresents me by making me appear a very languid worker in the cause of world peace, a cause for which, as it happens, I have labored zealously for many years.

A six-story apartment house to be built on the east side of Jerome Avenue, 17 feet north of Minerva Place, will cost $200,000, according to plans filed with the Bronx Department of Buildings. William I. Hohauser, architect, designed the structure for the Dornhage Realty Corporation of 1,896 First Avenue.
DETROIT, April 18. -- The Detroit Tigers defeated the Chicago White Sox, 5 to 4, today and drove the first nail into what they hope will be their ladder to the 1935 American League championship.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- The Century Ribbon Mills, Inc., paid its president, Herman Levy, compensation of $55,140 during 1934, a registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission revealed today. Irving Levy, vice president, got $39,660.

Merchant ship construction, which in the last two years reached new low post-war levels, appears due for greater activity, according to H. Gerrish Smith, president of the National Council of American Shipbuilders. He discussed the domestic situation yesterday in a report submitted to the annual meeting of the council at the Whitehall Club.

NEWARK, N.J., April 18. -- The Rochester Red Wings turned the cables on the Newark Bears today in the second game of their inaugural series at Ruppert Stadium, winning decisively, 12 to 7, to erase the sting of their defeat by 16 -- 3 the day before.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- While Governor Talmadge was attacking President Roosevelt in Georgia, Secretary Ickes made it clear today that he would make no further public works loans to Georgia and also made some new caustic remarks about Senator Long.

The Securities Acts of 1933 and 1934 do not create new types of liability for false and misleading statements but merely extend preexisting liability to cover new situations, Charles H. Meyer, an authority on Stock Exchange law, said yesterday in his second and final address at the Stock Exchange Institute.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Gordon gave a dinner last night at their home, 149 East Seventy-third Street, to celebrate the anniversary of their marriage, later taking their guests to a theatre and then to the Rainbow Room, Rockefeller Center, for supper and dancing.

After describing roulette as "a sucker's game" in a speech for the newsreels yesterday, Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine tried his luck at a wheel and won. His performance preceded the destruction of $100,000 worth of gambling equipment in a lot in front of the police property clerk's storehouse at the foot of Thirty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, shortly before noon.

CHICAGO, April 18. -- Receipts of hogs here today were small and the demand was not aggressive. Reports of a decline in the price of fresh pork loins of 1 to 2 cents a pound in the East in the last few days tended to check buying. Early sales of hogs were generally about steady, but later some business was put through at declines of 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight.

BOSTON, April 18. -- Secretary Wallace's remarks at Brunswick last evening concerning the "whining" of New England mill owners served to unite the industrial and political leaders of the section more solidly than ever today in their fight for repeal of the cotton processing tax.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended April 13 totaled 324,289,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines, Department of the Interior.

Negotiations for the resale of a plot in the Pelham Parkway section of the Bronx for improvement with the two six-story elevator apartment houses were announced yesterday by the Standard National Corporation, which has just bought sixteen lots on the west side of Bolton Street, 300 feet south of Pelham Parkway.

TOPEKA, Kan., April 18. -- No one can give any idea of the conditions existing in parts of five States by description. You must experience it personally to have any understanding of the situation, and you cannot generalize on this appalling catastrophe.

The need for currency stablization as part of any national program for prosperity was stressed by Benjamin M. Anderson Jr. economist of the Chase National Bank, in an address yesterday afternoon at a luncheon of the association of Foreign Press Correspondents at the Fifth Avenue Hotel.
LONDON, April 18 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

BROCKTON, Mass., April 18. -Ignoring a machine gun and three pistols a 68-year-old bank guard, single-handed, opened fire on four bandits and put them to flight without loot today when they attempted to hold up the Campello branch of the Brockton National Bank.
Columbia's varsity crew was on the Harlem River yesterday for a long workout, its final intensive drill for its season's debut against Navy tomorrow.

Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens submitted yesterday to Mayor La Guardia a list of public works projects in the borough for inclusion in the city's request for PWA funds. The borough projects call for an expenditure of $53,538,300 to provide employment for 30,000 men.

An exhibition made up of the graphic and literary work of Joseph Pennell, widely known American artist, and his wife, Elizabeth Robbins Pennell, author and critic, was opened last evening at the Grolier Club, 47 East Sixtieth Street, the occasion being the club's monthly meeting.

The High School of Commerce nine triumphed over the New York University freshmen by 10 to 2 at Ohio Field yesterday, clouting three Violet pitchers for nine hits. Zuppe limited the losers to two safeties and struck out fourteen.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18. -Seven home runs were delivered by four first-string Phillies and three leading Dodger sluggers today, but these gentlemen were only cardboard heroes compared to Mickey Haslin, one of Manager Jimmy Wilson's bench-warmers.

The question of lower interest rates and fixed maturity dates for the $62,900,000 of demand loans of the New York Central Railroad that are held by eleven banks were discussed informally yesterday by Jesse Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, and Harold Vanderbilt, a director and member of the executive committee of the New York Central.

BERLIN, April 18. -- The days of Frederick the Great's famous Foot Grenadiers are gone. The physical-fitness regulations for universal military service issued today by the Ministry of War rate any soldier as first class in the matter of height if he measures 5 feet 2 inches.

PARIS, April 18 (By Wireless). -- Robert Gordon Switz was found today in a little hotel on the edge of the Latin Quarter, where he had been taken by his father-in-law, Albert S. Bard of New York, after he had been freed by judicial authorities, who had held him on charges of espionage.

POUGHKEEPSIE, April 18. -Vassar College took steps today to end picketing by students in a strike at a Beacon garment factory. President MacCracken called a special assembly to express disapproval of the strike activity.

Jimmy and Johnny Woods, the twins who for the first two of their three years were the subjects of scientific experiment at the Normal Child Development Clinic of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Centre, saw their first circus yesterday afternoon as part of the celebration of their third birthday.

Henry P. Fletcher, Republican national chairman, presided here yesterday at a conference of Republican leaders from five of the largest industrial States in the country. The conference was held to further a drive for funds to keep the party machinery functioning until March, 1936.
TOKYO, April 18. -- The arrival in Tokyo yesterday of thirteen Mongolian lamas marks an unobtrusive but significant step in Japan's policy of winning over the Mongols.
WASHINGTON, April 18. -- President Roosevelt conferred with Secretary Hull and members of the Senate Munitions Committee.

The Art Directors Club's fourteenth annual exhibition of advertising art was opened privately yesterday afternoon on the fifth floor of R.H. Macy Co., where it will be on view to the public daily, beginning today, through May 11.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18. -- A universe doomed to death through the inevitable burning up of all its matter as fuel, rising once more out of its primeval ashes into the splendors of countless billions of living suns and stars, was pictured here tonight before the annual meeting of the American Philosophical Society.

PITTSBURGH, April 18 (AP). -- Big Jim Weaver's debut as a Pirate hurler was marred today by the hustling Reds, who chased him to the showers in less than two frames and continued their cannonade against his four successors to defeat Pittsburgh, 9 to 4.

Several large apartment properties in Manhattan were offered for bidding at auctioneers' stands yesterday when twelve buildings were sold under the hammer. The foreclosures involved two business buildings and a hospital building in addition to the multi-family structures.

The New York Stock and Curb Exchanges and other major security and commodity markets throughout the nation will be closed today in observance of Good Friday. Members of the New York Security Dealers Association also will suspend business for the day.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 18. -- The student bodies of Greenbrier Woman's College and Greenbrier Military Academy were guests tonight at the last of a series of concerts given by the International Marimba Symphony Orchestra which was broadcast from the Greenbrier ballroom over a nation-wide hook-up.

It would be a difficult task to find a spot in any branch of intercollegiate sport where there is a more perfect example of the man fitting the job than in Yale rowing. And, conversely, the thing is true the other way; the job perfectly fits Ed Leader.
Tony Esposito defeated Mike De Falco in an exciting 135-pound class bout which featured the annual boxing matches of the Boys Club at the Jefferson Park Building last night.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- An investigation of the case of the four former bombing planes of Tampa-New Orleans-Tampico Air Lines, Inc., which were grounded in Lima, Peru, late last month has been launched by Martin Conboy, United States Attorney at New York City, with the aid of Gordon Dean of the Department of Justice, Attorney General Homer S. Cummings announced today.

SOFIA, April 18. -- The long latent political crisis in Bulgaria broke out today with the internment of two former Premiers, Alexander Tsankoff and Kimon Gueorgieff, and the subsequent resignation of the Zlateff Government.

The inland "Jones Beach" which the Long Island State Park Commission is developing at Bethpage State Park, Farmingdale, L.I., was inspected yesterday by Park Commissioner Robert Moses, officials of city and State park organizations and a group of newspaper men and photographers.
Good Friday will be observed widely today in the city's churches.

ALBANY, April 18. -- The State Automobile Association, in a statement today, characterized the Gillen Auto License Plate Bill, passed during the closing hours of the legislative session, as "probably the worst piece of legislation" ever enacted.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Senator Borah today introduced a joint resolution to prohibit public or private loans to foreign governments outside the American Continent, and Senator Lewis demanded from the floor that European nations pay their debts to the United States before they censure Germany for repudiating the Versailles treaty.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 19. -- Commonwealth, the Bostonian gelding owned by Mrs. Walter M. Jeffords, which is the second choice in the future hooks for the Kentucky Derby, will be tested here tomorrow in the $7,500 added Chesapeake Stakes.
The Most Rev. James DeWolf Perry, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, who is also Bishop of Rhode Island, issued the following Easter message to his communion yesterday:
Premier Richard B. Bennett of Canada and Lily Pons. Feodor Chaliapin and Emanuel List, opera singers, are among the persons sailing today for Europe on the French liner Paris.

Sister Johanna of the Order of St. Dominic, who was under treatment for a mental disorder resulting from a nervous breakdown in Mary Immaculate Hospital, Jamaica, committed suicide by hanging herself in her private room there, it became known yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 19 (AP). -- The California Supreme Court upheld a State law today authorizing execution of kidnappers who harm their victims. It affirmed the death sentences of William E. Tanner and Harry C. Brooks, convicted of the abduction of Henry C. Bodkin, Los Angeles attorney, and Mrs. Bodkin late in 1933.

Interviewed in his suite at the Hotel Madison yesterday afternoon a few hours before sailing for England aboard the Cunard-White Star liner Berengaria, Frederick J. Perry, English and American tennis champion, refused to commit himself on the question of turning professional.

SHANGHAI, April 20. -- Akira Ariyoshi, Japanese Minister to China, left today for Tokyo, where he is expected to present a brief for continued peaceful negotiations with China to obtain Japanese aims here and to report on the Chinese situation to Foreign Minister Koki Hirota and others.
WASHINGTON, April 19. -- Foes of the Costigan-Wagner Anti-Lynching Bill mapped their campaign today to prevent the measure from being taken up for consideration in the Senate.

PRINCETON. N.J., April 19. -- A masterful exhibition of pitching by Bill Lincoln, who let Princeton down with two hits, gave Harvard a 2-0 victory over the Tigers in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game today. A crowd of about 1,200 saw the contest.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 19. -- Paul Revere was in too much of a hurry -- if he had taken things easier on his gallop to Lexington, just 160 years ago last night, the Revolution might have started off with a greater bang than it did.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP). -- Feeling that the Presidential restriction against the move had ended, the Senate munitions committee announced today that it would ask Donald R. Richberg, NRA chief, to explain asserted delay in "cracking down" on the Colt Firearms Company for refusal to negotiate with a labor union.

A nurse died, a 3-year-old child and several adults were rescued and several other tenants suffered burns in a fire that swept a four-story brick apartment house at 86 Perry Street, Greenwich Village, at 5 o'clock yesterday morning.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 19. -- Easter services in churches throughout Westchester County will be marked by special music and floral decorations and the churches expect record attendances.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- THE NEW YORK TIMES printed a dispatch yesterday from its Washington bureau regarding an application on Form 10 to the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Real Silk Hosiery Mills, which included the following statements:
NEWARK, N.J., April 19. -- Dick Porter's single in the tenth inning today gave the Bears a 3-to-2 victory and the lead in the series with the Rochester Red Wings.

Both the Federal and city Governments appear to be on the eve of signing contracts with the Consolidated Gas Company. The terms have not yet been officially announced, but they are said to represent a reduction of 25 or 35 per cent in the present charges for electric current for lighting streets and public buildings.

TOKYO, April 19. -- Criticisms implying that the coming American naval manoeuvres in the North Pacific are offensive in character as compared with Japan's "defensive" exercises carried out in the South Pacific last year appear in two Tokyo newspapers.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 19 (AP). -- Although sorry that her disappearance while she was grieving over the death of a pet dog "kicked up a rumpus" in New York City, Miss Billidean Curtis, 25-year-old Brooklyn stenographer, laughed about the matter today at her "second home" with Mrs. William Bibby here.

SMITHLAND, Ky., April 19 (AP). -- William T. De Boe Jr. of Paducah, 23 years old and white, was hanged at dawn today, in the presence of the woman he is alleged to have attacked. He delivered from the gallows a forty-five-minute tirade, in which he called her a "cold-blooded murderer" and dared the crowd to shoot him.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- The government today took over the administration of all Federal relief in Georgia, the Governor of which yesterday attacked President Roosevelt and predicted the development of a third party for the 1936 election.

Widely diversified new issues of State and municipal bonds will come up for award next week and will amount to $31,081,006. This sum compares with this week's revised total of $15,830,988, and with the weekly average of $20,727,152 for the year thus far.

Judge Grover M. Moscowitz in the United States District Court in Brooklyn yesterday reserved decision on an application of counsel for the trustees in reorganization proceedings of Prudence Company, Inc., for permission to continue to guarantee the payment of principal and interest of a $4,600,000 issue of bonds of the Prudence Bonds Corporation known as the fifteenth series.
Churches and cathedrals were crowded yesterday at Good Friday services commemorating the crucifixion.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- Seven "basic defects" in the National Recovery Act and its administration are pictured by the Brookings Institute in an exhaustive analysis to be published in book form soon. It adds that any attempt to remove these "defects" would result in a widespread collapse of the present code system.
BOSTON, April 19 (AP). The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow:
PHILADELPHIA, April 19. -- The Giants caught up with the Sun and the Phillies simultaneously today at Baker Bowl and the consequences were terrible from a New York standpoint.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 19 (AP). -- Debt-ridden taxing units of Florida saw a two-year breathing spell in a modified moratorium on defaulted public indebtedness which gained legislative approval today.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- Besides the billions of new taxes levied under the Social Security Bill passed by the House today for old-age annuity benefits and unemployment compensation, the measure would appropriate nearly $100,000,000 for Federal grants in aid to States for old-age relief, maternal and child care, vocational rehabilitation of incapacitated workers and public health.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- Senator Reynolds was appointed today a subcommittee of one to go to the Virgin Islands to investigate conditions and inquire into the charges filed against Governor Paul Pearson before the Senate Insular Affairs Committee.
A.H. Shaw, general passenger agent of the Long Island Railroad, announced yesterday the plans for operating the low-fare fishing excursion trains to Montauk and Greenport.

ROME, April 19. -- A meeting lasting more than an hour was held at the Palazzo Venezia today between Premier Mussolini and Prince Ernst von Starhemberg, Vice Chancellor of Austria, who arrived from Vienna by air without previous newspaper announcement.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- President Roosevelt appointed a Cabinet committee to investigate the cotton textile situation, and conferred with O. Max Gardner, former Governor of North Carolina, and Charles A. Cannon, textile mill operator.

Widespread Republican resentment against the New Deal of the Roosevelt administration and the ripper legislation of the Democratic-controlled Legislature exists up-State, Chase Mellen Jr. declared yesterday.

MEMPHIS, April 18. -- A large number of share-croppers who had been told by organizers for the Southern Tenant Farmers' Union that the government would protect them from eviction found themselves legally dispossessed or forcibly "run off the place" by the large plantation owners of Northeastern Arkansas last Winter.

Three more men were arrested late last night, on charges of blackmail and attempted extortion in connection with an attempt to force Mrs. George U. Harris, wife of a member of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange, to pay them $5,000.
Realty trading, somewhat curtailed because of observance of Good Friday, was featured yesterday by deals in the Bronx, where announcements were made of plans for improving three sites.

Warily refusing to place too much stock in the report that Columbia was weak this year, the Naval Academy crews took to the Harlem River yesterday and finished preliminary work for today's regatta, their first of the year and the first of the local rowing season.

The plan for reorganization of Fox Metropolitan Playhouses, Inc., proposed by Milton C. Weisman, receiver in equity for the Fox Theatres Corporation, was endorsed yesterday by several moving-picture theatre operators testifying before Federal Judge Julian W. Mack at a hearing in the County Lawyers Association Building, 14 Vesey Street.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 19. -- The annual five-college conference began this afternoon at Vassar with a tea at which Dean C. Mildred Thompson was hostess. Meetings continued at dinner tonight and discussions of common educational problems will be held tomorrow.

Deposits in savings accounts of thrifty pupils in more than 500 banks in the city have increased from $6,000,000 in 1926, when the school banking system was reorganized, to about $20,000,000 and only an infinitesimal amount, comparatively, now lies in dormant accounts, Miss Helen A. McKeon, in charge of the "school banks," disclosed yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19. -- A "Hollywood revue," to be given by junior Republican women of Pennsylvania, will interpret personal appearances of favorite cinema stars at a benefit bridge to be given by the organization at the Bellevue on April 30.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- Protests of two Republican Senators against phases of the bill aimed at curbing public utility holding companies were met today by a wagon-load of statistical information poured into the Interstate Commerce Committee hearing by Dozier A. de Vane, solicitor of the Federal Power Commission.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- Presidential appointment of the special committee to survey the cotton textile industry, while far from the immediate exercise of Executive powers desired by textile advocates in Congress, caused gratification on Capitol Hill.

The J.G. White Engineering Corporation, which has been in 42 Exchange Place for thirty-two years, has leased 6,000 square feet on the twenty-third floor of the Maritime Exchange Building, 80 Broad Street. The Washburn-Crosby Milling Company and the Ore and Chemical Corporation each leased a floor in the building.

Fifty-four schools have filed more than 700 entries for the twenty-seventh New York University interscholastic track and field meet, which will open the metropolitan schoolboy outdoor track campaign this afternoon at Ohio Field, starting at 2 o'clock.

Earle H. Balch, vice president of G.P. Putnam's Sons, has returned from Europe with several foreign manuscripts and the news that he has contracted for five novels by the French writer, Georges Duhamel, which he plans to publish in one volume under the title "Salavin," some time in the Fall of 1936.

BOSTON, April 19. -- Patriots' Day was a Dodger holiday so far as nearly 30,000 Hub fans were able to determine from the progress of affairs on Braves Field today. Winning both the morning and afternoon games by identical scores of 4 to 2, Casey Stengel's rollicking athletes left the Bostonians practically aghast.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- Payment in 1934 of $85,139 compensation to Lessing J. Rosenwald, chairman, by Sears, Roebuck Co., and of $81,818 to Robert E. Wood, the company's president, was revealed today in a securities registration statement filed with the SEC.

In your editorial "Higher Pay Unwarranted'' you say: "A recent survey conducted by the Citizens Budget Commission revealed that average salaries of city employes increased 83 per cent between 1918 and 1932." Again, "Is it too much to ask of them that they continue to accept a 75 per cent increase over the level set in wartime, when the cost of living was higher than it is today?"

A resolution petitioning Governor Lehman to veto the Feld-Crawford trade-mark and copyright bill. passed by the Legislature before its final adjournment, was adopted by 600 delegates of the Central Trades and Labor Council at a meeting held Thursday night in Beethoven Hall, 210 East Fifth Street.

BOSTON, April 19. -- Although he gorged himself with the equivalent of fifteen hearty meals as he ran, Johnny Kelley, 27-year-old Irish athlete from Arlington, finished a quarter-mile ahead of his most dangerous rival, Pat Dengis of Baltimore, today to win the thirty-eighth renewal of the famous Boston A.A. marathon.

Aiding employment in the building trades and giving impetus to the durable goods industries, hundreds of retail stores throughout the country, are modernizing their buildings by embellishing their exteriors and installing equipment of the latest type for the convenience of customers, the National Retail Dry Goods Association reported yesterday in announcing a study of the apparently rapid expansion of the store-modernization movement.

BERLIN, April 19. -- Tributes to Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler as the common soldier who is leading Germany back to her high place as a world military power were paid by army leaders and others tonight, on the eve of the leader's forty-sixth birthday.

Regional Republican rebirth is planned and prophesied to occur according to a time schedule. HENRY ALLEN and WILLIAM ALLEN WHITE are in active circulation, the most suave men midwives that ever were. From all around, reports flow in to Chairman FLETCHER, convincing him that the "prospects of the party are improving rapidly and very satisfactorily.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- In one of the most striking victories yet registered by the administration on controverted legislation, the House voted today by 372 to 33 to pass and send to the Senate the Social Security Bill, levying taxes on industrial employers and workers to support a broad plan of old-age annuities and unemployment compensation.

A move by banks to put on a five-year basis the $62,900,000 loans that they made to the New York Central Railroad might prove to be acceptable to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, Jesse Jones, chairman, said yesterday. Previously, Mr. Jones had proposed a ten-year term for the debt, which now consists of demand loans.
To the roster of shows departing tonight "Potash and Perlmutter," at the Park, was added yesterday, according to a representative of the management.
CHICAGO, April 19 (AP). -- The Reds turned in their third straight victory today, shutting out the Cubs, 4 to 0, in the opening game of the series.

Before a hushed audience, such as for more than a generation past has annually greeted Richard Wagner's "consecrational festival play" on Good Friday, this season's remarkable group of artists repeated "Parsifal" yesterday for the fourth time in recent weeks at the Metropolitan.

BUENOS AIRES, April 19. -- In nothing more than in today's observance of Good Friday has Buenos Aires shown the rapidity with which it has grown from a large provincial town to a sophisticated world capital.

It was a favorite observation of HERBERT SPENCER that governments almost never started to legislate against an evil until the evil had already begun to cure itself. Senator BORAH'S new resolution is an ideal illustration of the point. At a time when practically nobody would dream of making a loan to Europe he wants a law prohibiting public or private loans to foreign Governments outside the American continent.

PARIS, April 19. -- Expectations that the Franco-Soviet pact of mutual assistance would be initialed this week-end have been disappointed and Maxim Litvinoff, the Russian Foreign Commissar, instead of coming to Paris for a triumphal reception at the Quai d'Orsay tomorrow, has gone on from Geneva to Moscow for new consultations with his government.

There is probably no holiday season more inviting to the night-club brand of whimsey than Easter -- with its customary bunnies, baby chicks and deceptive hard-boiled eggs. Given a chorus line and a pert little singer or twain, the average floor show producer won't have to tax his imagination for a holiday "special" next week.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 19. -- Carol Tareauanu, in charge of the Rumanian Consulate in New York, and Madame Tarcauanu, arrived today to open up their Hot Springs home, the Chimneys, for the season. J. Rosenthal, the Rumanian press attache, is their house guest, and Mr. and Mrs. Woodson Houghton of Washington will arrive to spend the Easter vacation with them.

VIENNA, April 19. -- At last some one has been inspired after two years to make a permanent record of the often brilliantly clever satirical jokes against the regime which, in dictatorial countries like Germany, spread like wildfire.

HUDSON, N.Y., April 19. -- A warrant for the arrest of M. William Herbs, treasurer of this city, remains unserved in his hands, Chief of Police Thomas L. Conners said today, with the whereabouts of Mr. Herbs still a mystery.

John M. Morehead, former United States Minister to Sweden, and Mrs. Morehead gave a dinner last night at the Ritz-Carlton for Countess Folke Bernadotte of Sweden, who is visiting relatives in this country. The other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Axel Wenner-Gren, Mr. and Mrs. Rufus L. Patterson and Mr. and Mrs. H. Edward Manville.

The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company announced yesterday it was considering the operation of a so-called "Hiking Train" during the Summer months which would allow New Yorkers to spend a day or week-end of recreation in New England and still be back in the city in time for work Monday morning.

Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, announced yesterday that the Henry Hudson Parkway Authority had delivered its bonds to the banking group which is financing its express highway project and that the proceeds, amounting to almost $3,000,000, had been deposited with the Controller.

The New York racing season will start today at the Jamaica track of the Metropolitan Jockey Club with the $5,000-added Paumonok Handicap, which traditionally ushers in the sport here, down for decision as the feature of the opening card.

John A. Kingsbury, Commissioner of Charities under the administration of the late Mayor John Purroy Mitchel, has severed his connection with the Milbank Memorial Fund as the result of "differences of opinion as to policy," it was announced yesterday by the directors of the fund.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- Provision for several New York projects was contained in allotments totaling $28,404,850 made by the War Department today for maintenance of river and harbor projects. Included were $165,000 for New York Harbor, $150,000 for Bay Ridge and Red Hook Channels and $114,000 for the Hudson River Channel.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., April 19 (AP). -- Four-fifths of the world's press today knows how cruelly the powers of the censor may be applied, said Lee A. White, member of the editorial board of The Detroit News, in an address here tonight.
Four supposed girl students of Brooklyn College who were found guilty of picketing a cafeteria were denounced yesterday in the Gates Avenue Court, Brooklyn, by Magistrate Jacob Eilperin.

ALBANY, April 19. -- A drive to Win an agreement from Tammany, through pressure and promises of political rewards, which would permit passage of reapportionment at a special session has been started by a group of Democratic leaders, it was said here today.

A meeting scheduled for yesterday in the Federal court in Brooklyn to afford an opportunity to creditors of the Allied Owners Corporation to pass final judgment on a plan of reorganization for the corporation was adjourned by Judge Inch until May 3. The delay was to enable Oscar Lewis, special master, to make a complete check on the acceptances of the plan of reorganization sent to him by creditors.
According to THE TIMES, Chief City Magistrate James E. McDonald has put a stop to the practice of making the night court a kind of free-for-all circus for morbid curiosity seekers.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 19. -- Mrs. Graham Fair Vanderbilt of New York City arrived at the Greenbrier this morning in her private car with friends to spend the Easter holidays here. Those in her party are Mrs. Vanderbilt Smith, Mr. and Mrs. Julius W. Noyes, Roger Davis, Charles H. Towne and T. Markoe Robertson of New York City and F.H. Rediker of Calais, Me.

PITTSBURGH, April 19. -- Rookie Darrel (Cy) Blanton subdued the St. Louis Cardinals with a masterful one-hit pitching achievement today and led the Pittsburgh Pirates to a brilliant 3-to-0 triumph over the world champions.
WASHINGTON, April 19. -- A "code" for the Easter Monday egg rolling on the White House lawn was issued today.

A move to take laissez-faire out of the Glorious Fourth has been made by the Pyrotechnic Code Authority and approved by the Recovery Board at Washington. An amendment effective next July 6 establishes for firecrackers and "salutes'' a maximum of four inches in length and five-eighths of an inch in diameter.
BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y., April 19. -- Two stakes were completed today in the covers of the Lewis estate under ideal conditions, and with the largest first-day gallery of the Spring season in attendance.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- A slight revival of wholesale prices in the early part of April in Germany, following a recession of the index from February to March because of a drop in foodstuffs was reported today by the Commerce Department in its weekly survey of business abroad.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- An important change in naval policy under which the light cruiser Omaha will relieve a heavy cruiser as flagship of the Asiatic fleet next Fall was revealed today by the Navy Department.

BURBANK, Calif., April 19 (AP). -- Amelia Earhart hopped off from the Union Air Terminal at 9:55 P.M. (12:55 A.M. Saturday New York time) in what she described as a non-stop good-will flight to Mexico, D.F.

SOFIA, April 19. -- King Boris today entrusted the former Bulgarian diplomat Andrew Tocheff with the task of forming a Cabinet to succeed that of General Petko Zlateff, who resigned yesterday. M. Tocheff consulted political leaders all day in the hope of being able to present a definite list tomorrow.

Charging "scandalous mismanagement'' of the Cotton Garment Code Authority, Leon Kellman, assistant secretary of the National Work Shirt Manufacturers Association, in a letter yesterday to Senator Carter Glass, urged that the Senate Finance Committee make a thorough investigation of the financial management of code authorities.
WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP). -- American editors heard high praise for their Berlin correspondents today from Dorothy Thompson, special writer who recently was ordered out of Germany.
GRAND CANYON, Ariz., April 19 (AP). -- Mayor LaGuardia of New York visited the home of the Navajo Indians on the Painted Desert today and posed en route for a picture with two Hopi maidens.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- A protest over discrimination against Americans and violation of contract has been made to the German Government by the United States because of Germany's failure last Monday to provide currency for servicing coupons of the Dawes loan held by Americans.

Crop indications are favorable to the Great Northern Railway, W.P. Kenney, president, said in the report of the company for 1934, which was issued yesterday. He estimated that the freight surcharges recently authorized by the Interstate Commerce Commission should, in the last eight months of 1935, add $800,000 to the company's revenues, principally from the movement of coal, ore, petroleum products and miscellaneous manufactures.

Winging its way from its Winter quarters in the South to a Summer nesting in the Adirondacks, a friendly, brown-eyed woodcock, making the first known visit of a bird of its species to the city since 1927, met with an accident here yesterday which disrupted the itinerary of its journey.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP). -- Cash bonus leaders in the Senate served notice today that the compromise bill offered by Chairman Harrison of the Senate Finance Committee was not satisfactory and that they would fight for a more liberal measure.

Influenced by motives of vengeance and self-esteem, society has created a criminal law which today is antiquated and outworn, in which hypothetical men and not real ones are tried and convicted of crimes, Dr. William Alanson White, superintendent of St. Elizabeth's Hospital in Washington, declared last night.

BALTIMORE, April 19. -- Howard Bruce, Maryland sportsman and owner of the famous jumper Billy Barton, which finished second in England's classic steeplechase at Aintree some years ago, will attempt to win the Grand National point-to-point tomorrow with Avalon, a former flat runner, and thereby take permanent possession of the Gold Challenge Cup put into competition in 1925 by Dr. and Mrs. Walter Wickes.

BLOOMFIELD, Conn., April 19 (AP). -- A dawn-to-darkness search today for Mrs. Ann Booth Gordon, missing Farmington society matron, by a posse of 300 police, National Guardsmen, society friends of the family and others, went unrewarded.

BOGOTA, Colombia, April 19. -- Mexico's only woman diplomat, Senorita Palma Guillen, recently accredited to Colombia, has raised a storm of protest by a statement to the local press that there is no religious persecution in Mexico.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- All banks in the United States should be required to support the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, Chairman Leo T. Crowley declared today before a Senate Banking and Currency subcommittee in urging enactment of legislation giving the corporation greater power to protect not only the solvency of the banks but the money of their depositors.

BERLIN, April 19. -- While Europe tensely awaited Adolf Hitler's reaction to the League of Nation's condemnation of Germany's rearmament, the Reich tonight made ready to celebrate the leader's forty-sixth birthday tomorrow with typical Nazi fervor.

Three theatrical unions temporarily enjoined yesterday from demonstrating within a half-mile radius of the Oxford Theatre, 552 State Street, Brooklyn, will defy the court order this evening with a mass demonstration in front of the theatre. More than 1,000 union members will participate, their leaders announced yesterday.

Six cases of fatal pneumonia, caused by mineral oils and animal fats drawn into the lungs of infants and adults in small quantities, were reported yesterday by Dr. Irving Graef, pathologist at Bellevue Hospital.
WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP). -- The Roosevelt administration's power program, now spread out among a half dozen or more branches of government, may be coordinated under one head or agency.

BALTIMORE, April 19 (AP). -- In a game featured by twenty-eight hits, ten of them home runs, the Montreal Royals defeated Baltimore today, 7 to 6, to take a 2-1 lead in the series. Both the hits and the homers were equally divided between the clubs.
The Easter parade on Fifth Avenue will have fair weather. The weather man said late last night that today and tomorrow would be fair, without much change in temperature.

SAN PEDRO, Calif., April 19. -- Lonely areas of the North Pacific soon will hum with the activity of many naval airplanes which are expected to link widely separated American outposts in spectacular operations.
WASHINGTON, April 19. -- The House vote on final passage of the administration's Social Security Bill was as follows:

Aided greatly by two home runs, one by Wally Moses and the other by Bob Johnson, the Philadelphia Athletics downed the Yankees, 6 to 5, at the Stadium yesterday, thereby registering their first triumph and simultaneously climbing out of the American League cellar.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- In a great calm succeeding their storm of electioneering, the Daughters of the American Revolution held memorial services today for deceased members and later made their annual pilgrimages to Arlington National Cemetery and to Mount Vernon.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 19 (AP). -- Austin Tierney of Cambridge, Mass., was discovered in an empty truck today with his hands bound and a noose around his neck. and told police that five men had looted the vehicle of 259 cases of shoes, valued at $10,000, after hijacking it between North Haven and Hamden.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):

BALDWIN MILLS, Que., April 19 (Canadian Press) . -- Provincial police and a posse of citizens were scouring the countryside today for a person wearing spike-studded rubber shoes who is believed to have killed W.K. Baldwin, former Liberal member of Parliament for Standstead.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19. -- How some of the basic instincts and psychological behavior of an animal may be changed from a natural desire to kill to an attitude of tender solicitude by the injection of organic chemicals was demonstrated here today in motion pictures before the meeting of the American Philosophical Society.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- Individual and corporation income tax collections in March totaled $321,907, 863, a rise of $93,382,252 from last year, the Treasury reported today. This was a gain of nearly 41 per cent. The increase for the nine months of the fiscal year through March was also substantial.

There will be several outdoor Easter dawn services tomorrow and they will be attended by those of all Christian faiths. Many who will not go to an open-air service will assemble in their own churches for sunrise worship to commemorate the resurrection of Christ.

JERUSALEM, April 19 (AP). -- The Holy City was thronged again tonight -- as it was more than 1,900 years ago for the Passover festival to which Jesus Christ came to preach -- with crowds come to do adoration at Eastertide.

While automobile associations made known their opposition to a legislative bill providing for illuminated automobile plates yesterday, Assemblyman Michael J. Gillen, Brooklyn Democrat, sponsor of the bill, declared that he would ask Governor Lehman to sign it because it was "a real public necessity."

Residential building contracts last month in the thirty-seven States east of the Rocky Mountains totaled $32,207,400, which was almost double the February aggregate, the F.W. Dodge Corporation reported yesterday. Last month's total exceeded the March, 1934, figure by almost 15 per cent and was the highest recorded since March, 1932, when the total was only $1,000,000 greater than last month's volume.

One of the rewarding solo shows this week is that of Charles Ellis at the Montross Gallery, where his work will remain on view until April 27. Mr. Ellis -- after studying, long ago, at the Art Students League under Henri, Bellows and Sloan -- laid aside his brushes and went on the stage.

Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. of New York accused radio broadcasting station WHN yesterday of suppressing an address he had been scheduled to make at 6:15 P.M. Accepting the challenge as a "direct blow at free speech," Mr. Fish announced that he would register his charge in the Congressional Record and before the Federal Radio Commission.

Michael Balcon, production head of the Gaumont-British film studios, sailed last night on the Berengaria after a six weeks' sojourn here and in Hollywood arranging for the appearance of some of this country's well-known motion picture players in English-made productions.

Declaring that $30,000,000 must be added to the city budget next year unless Governor Lehman vetoes the salary restoration bills affecting city employes, the Citizens Budget Commission asked the public last night to support its demand for the veto.

All the important domestic and foreign markets were closed yesterday in accordance with the Good Friday custom. The New York Stock Exchange as well as other security markets will reopen this morning, but trading in commodities, with some unimportant exceptions, will not be resumed until Monday.

Even before the mathematical physicists disturbed us with the conception of an atom composed not of matter but of events, the second law of thermodynamics was questioned. It is a law which tells us that heat flows from hot to cold bodies, that tea-kettles are not likely to freeze on glowing coals, and that the universe must eventually run down for lack of energy and become once more a stagnant chaos.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- Several amendments to the Code for the Paper and Pulp Industry, aiming to clarify overlappings in jurisdiction and to change minimum wage and maximum hour provisions for some classes of employes, will be discussed at a public hearing here May 10, the NRA announced today. They were submitted by the Code Authority.
Vital statistics at the Central Park Zoo fluctuated rapidly yesterday. By nightfall Headkeeper Robert Hurton and his aides were feeling the effects of two days of much coming and going.

President Roosevelt asked the continued cooperation of the newspapers of the country "until there is a real national recovery on all fronts" in a message made public yesterday by the weekly magazine Editor and Publisher. The message was sent in advance of the annual meetings of The Associated Press and The American Newspaper Publishers Association, to be held here next week.

American Scouting was born in New York City. Her citizens should have a special pride in the record of the twenty-five years and a special interest in its enlarged plans for the next quarter century. It has enrolled more than 6,500,000 boys in this period under the leadership of 1,300,000 men volunteers.

DETROIT, April 19 f2).--lq, ookie John Whitehead and a scrappy assortment of White Sex registered a 3oto-2 victory over the ]Setroit Tigers today, sending the American League champions down to defeat l in their first series of the season. The Sox took two of the three: games played.

Already rebuffed by Park Commissioner Robert Moses, the aldermanic committee investigating relief got another setback yesterday when Harry M. Prince, Deputy Tenement House Commissioner, walked out of a hearing because he failed to get a copy of his testimony.

DETROIT, April 19 (AP). -- The row over management of the Hupp Motor Car Company moved a step nearer settlement today as attorneys for the rival factions tentatively agreed upon a proposed new directorate.

BATON ROUGE, La., April 19 (AP). -- Despite the threat of Secretary Ickes to withhold Public Works Administration funds from Louisiana, Senator Huey P. Long's Legislature today put all but the finishing touches on bills to give him control of Federal monies spent in the State in the future.

ROME, April 19 (AP). -- The confusion of nature at the death of Christ was commemorated in hundreds of ceremonies in Rome's many basilicas and churches tonight as the great majority of Italians celebrated Good Friday.

LONDON, April 19. -- More than 500,000 soccer enthusiasts saw the Good Friday fixtures in England today. The matches resulted in few surprises in the various divisions of the league. The leaders in the two senior branches of the sport recorded victories to improve their championship chances.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- Mr. Hopkins, in announcing today that he had taken over control of Federal relief in Georgia, said that several Georgia cities were making relief contributions and indicated that, cities would receive funds independent of the State.

In canceling some work-loan projects in Georgia, Secretary ICKES seems to have a good case against Governor TALMADGE. That official had just vetoed a bill, having connection with highway construction in Georgia, which he had promised to support and which Mr. ICKES regarded as part of the bargain.

A relief worker who turned into a bandit was shot dead last night when he and two companions attempted to hold up a cafe and candy store at 206 Forsyth Street. Two customers who were playing cards with the proprietor were wounded, presumably by bullets fired by the fleeing robbers.

SEVILLE, Spain, April 19. -- When Seville was awakened yesterday morning by the pealing bells of the Giralda, the city's ancient Moorish prayer tower, it beheld foreigners pouring into the city for the conclusion of its annual Easter pageant in numbers far surpassing all expectations.
U. S. Department of A-rieuiture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

PINEHURST, N.C., April 19. -- Mrs. Penelope Anderson McBride of Short Hills, N.J., who is ranked fifteenth nationally, upset Miss Jane Sharp, Pasadena, Calif., ranked sixth, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, today to win the women's title in the North and South tennis tournament.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP). -- Although touched for nine hits in the six innings he pitched, Robert Moses (Lefty) Grove had some success today in his first pitching appearance this year when Boston unloosed a late attack to defeat Washington, 10 to 4.
CHICAGO, April 19. -- Illinois State finance officers were virtually dismissed today from control of the Federal funds which comprise three-fourths of all relief expenditures in the State.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- A Cabinet committee to conduct two parallel inquiries into the cotton textile situation, with special emphasis on obsolescence of mill equipment, was appointed by President Roosevelt today.

Marked improvement featured trade in the metropolitan area toward the close of the week as mild weather favored the close of the pre-Easter buying period. Sales volume in apparel lines is expected to be large today. Results for the pre-Easter period, however, have been much below expectations.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 19 (AP). -- The Toronto Maple Leafs scored a 3-to-2 victory over the Syracuse Chiefs to even their series at one-all today, with Hilcher holding Syracuse to five hits in six innings, while Coleman, who relieved him, didn't allow a blow.
WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP). -- The Senate ratified a reciprocal copyright treaty today only to find it had moved so fast that it will be asked Monday to retrace its steps.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP). -- A broad plan for early expansion of the Republican National Committee's activities in preparation for the 1936 Presidential campaign was tentatively drafted today at party headquarters.

BERLIN, April 19 (AP). -- A friendly but firm refusal to alter Germany's decision was expected to be the Foreign Office's reply to the American protest against paying holders of Dawes loan coupons in reichsmarks.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 19 (AP). -- Amid a tempest of charges and counter-charges, Preston E. Thomas won momentary reinstatement today as warden of Ohio penitentiary.

With new bond issues aggregating $19,590,000 offered to the public this week, the market experienced a comparative lull in new financing following last week's total flotations of $263,310,000, the largest of any week in exactly four years. This week a year ago, the total was $81,472,500.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in the State, now offered by dealers:

BERLIN, April 19. -- A frank confession that the average German gets his news now through gossip and has lost faith in the strictly censored German newspapers is contained in the most recent number of the German Press, a journalistic trade organ published by Propaganda Minister Paul Joseph Goebbels's Reich Press League.

A three-year moratorium on tax increases on improvements to buildings in the city as a means of stimulating employment and at the same time raising the actual value of real estate in New York was suggested to Mayor La Guardia in a report from the Board of Taxes and Assessments made public yesterday.

BERLIN, April 19. -- The Amerika Institut, German correspondent of the Smithsonian Institution, the American University Union and the Institute of International Education, will celebrate its twenty-fifth anniversary in conjunction with the sixtieth birthday of its director, Dr. Karl Bertling, on Easter Sunday.

SYRACUSE, April 19. -- "Dutch" Schultz's round face was wreathed in continual amusement in the Federal court this afternoon as a dozen Bronx detectives paraded to the stand to testify that they tapped his telephone lines in 1929-30, talked with him in his Third Avenue speakeasy, and heard him boast of controlling the window cleaners' racket in his territory, north of Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- An increase of 74.5 per cent in the value of building permits issued in March, as compared with a year ago, and of 53.5 per cent as compared with February, was reported today by Commissioner Lubin of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The increase between February and March was the greatest recorded in that period since 1929.
ALBANY, N.Y., April 19 (AP). -- The Buffalo Bisons made it two straight over the Albany Senators today, winning, 3 to 2, in ten innings.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 20. -- Fifteen undergraduates of Rutgers University have been elected to membership in Tau Kappa Alpha, national honorary forensic society, after one of the most extensive debate schedules in the history of the university, it was announced today by Professor Richard C. Reager, coach of debating.

I wonder how many musicians who did not know Edwin Arlington Robinson, who died in New York, realized his devotion to music. Whether because he had learned to play the clarinet in his youth or because it came to him naturally, the great poet's love for music was only second to his love for poetry.

ARLINGTON, Texas, April 20. -- Sachsenmaier and Reuter's Roman Soldier, 3-year-old colt eligible for the Kentucky Derby, came from behind in the stretch today to take the lead from Whiskolo and capture the third renewal of the $15,000-added Texas Derby at Arlington Downs.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 20. -- Yale will open up a new field of advanced study in the Fall with the establishment of a special division in the Graduate School centering upon general work apart from research and putting degrees secondary.
BERLIN, April 20. -- Catholic theological students have been freed of Storm Troop and labor service, which is compulsory for every German candidate for a university degree in Germany.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP). -- Government and private agencies moved to supply relief to dust-plagued farmers in the dry West today as the Agriculture Department foresaw, with the aid of favorable conditions, a Spring wheat crop ample for domestic needs.

A CATALOGUE which is animated with a liberal supply of bold-face type and mass reproductions has just burst out of its envelope in time to warn us of another big auction event. Conscious of the great gifts which it bears, it struts importantly in describing and picturing the 354 manuscripts and books which will be offered at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries Wednesday and Thursday evenings, the 24th and 25th of this month.

PEOPLE who devote their time to efforts to make the world a better place to live in often seem nowadays to be the most humorless and joyless of mortals. This generalization is intended to apply to Fascists as well as Communists and to most of the intervening categories.

IN scarlet stamped with gold the famous Temple Shakespeare has been completely reborn. Forty years after the original issue M.R. Ridley, Fellow of Balliol, has brought the editing down to date once more. The paper is good, the type clear, the pages not too crowded, the decorations by Eric Gill excellent.

LONDON (By Mail). -- There used to be some slight difficulty in remembering whether Oxford or Cambridge over here was the Dark Blue or Light Blue or vice versa, but after watching The Boat Race on the Thames there will be no further mistake for a while. It is Oxford that is the Dark Blue, and with very good reason.

CHICAGO, April 19. -- Pre-Easter shopping volume improved sharply the latter part of this week, but the unseasonably cold weather of the last three weeks kept the merchandise turnover lower than expected. However, stores showed gains in sales over the like period of last year, ranging from 5 to 10 per cent in dollar totals.

White-robed singers of Washington's A Cappella Choir came over by late afternoon train yesterday, had a short hour's rehearsal in the Town Hall, gave an evening concert there as their debut in New York and were off again at midnight for the nation's capital.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 20. -- For the first time in many years shiploads of pioneers will sail from here for Alaska soon. Their quest will not be gold.

The Needlework Guild of America, founded by the late Mrs. John Wood Stewart of New York and reputed to be the largest woman's charitable organization in the world, will observe its fiftieth anniversary in Philadelphia May 2, 3 and 4, according to an announcement of the program yesterday.
Le Roy Barber, 7 years old, was returned to his home at 527 Ocean Avenue, Jersey City, last night after he had been missing seven hours, had caught, he said, seven fish, and had walked seven miles.

TO the wealth of almost priceless original Wagner documents now in America has been added the autograph manuscript score of "Die Hochzeit," Wagner's first opera, composed before he had turned twenty. Its whereabouts have been something of a mystery.

LONDON. FOR the first time in twenty-five years, or since the coronation of King George, the 200-year-old state coach of the Speaker of the House of Commons will be used by the Speaker when he rides in the jubilee procession on May 6.

About eighty volunteers communicated with New York Hospital yesterday in response to the appeal broadcast for blood donors for Harold Pfleger, 14 years old, who has already received sixty-five blood transfusions in his fight against osteomyelitis and staphylococcus septicemia.

IT is very far from Broadway to Mexicantown in San Antonio, much further than a mere two thousand miles of air or railway travel would indicate. The distance which you must travel spans a century or more in time. Abruptly you are asked to descend from the height of twentieth century sophistication to the crude and rather touching naivete of Indian villagers, hardly a generation removed from their native Mexican mountains.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- More than 600 visitors are at White Sulphur for Easter, and their interest during the week will be centred on the annual Mason and Dixon tennis championship. This will open tomorrow on the clay courts of the Greenbrier Golf and Tennis Club.
PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., April 20. -- The third annual Pleasantville Music Festival will be held on Tuesday evening and Wednesday afternoon and evening in the auditorium of the high school.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., April 20. -- Although making only one hit off Marquardt and Johnson, Lawrenceville hurlers, the Poly Prep nine won a loosely-played game today, 4 to 1. Marquardt held the visiting team hitless for six frames, but Poly Prep rushed across four tallies in the sixth without a safety.

A COMMERCIAL airliner built to carry passengers, express and mail arose last Tuesday afternoon from the waters of San Francisco Bay, climbed over the city and, still climbing, sped out through the Golden Gate bound for Honolulu, 2,400 miles away.
