Sugar now stands out, according to opinions in trade circles, as probably the only major commodity with respect to which legislation, quotas, duties and processing taxes have worked out for the benefit of both producers and consumers, without, at the same time, having had any ill effects on foreign interests in the field.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 20. -- Detectives of the undercover squad who tapped Dutch Schultz's telephone lines when he was top man in the beer business and other enterprises in the Bronx in 1929-30 gave sensational testimony today at his trial before Federal Judge Frederick H. Bryant on charges of income tax evasion.

Working out of the uncertainty which hampered operations in March, business in the East and Midwest moved back to February levels of activity this month, according to the report made public yesterday by the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.
POTTSTOWN, Pa., April 20. -- The Hill School trackmen, in their initial meet of the season, vanquished the Princeton freshmen today, 67 1/4 to 58 3/4.

IN "Strange Holiness" Robert P. Tristram Coffin again presents a collection of finely chiseled verses. In an age when form in poetry is less zealously cherished than once it was, Mr. Coffin's carefully wrought lines and perfectly attuned rhyming values unite for artistry.

AT the meeting of the American Societies for Experimental Biology held early last week in Detroit the representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES sat himself down in a room of the Henry Ford Hospital and had himself tested by an "electroencephalogram," which the press, by common consent, picturesquely but misleadingly shortened to "thought recorder."

THE state of mind which we call "bourgeois" has been increasingly the subject of attack by creative writers, and more recently by Marxians. No one indeed has a good word to say for time bourgeoisie. The bourgeoisie themselves, if taunted to their faces with the opprobrious term, would doubtless shrug and point to a neighbor: "You mean him!" The Communist doesn't mind being called a Communist, but no one likes being called a bourgeois.

MUCH of the Western World thinks of Jerusalem on Easter Sunday; a larger proportion, in fact, than we commonly suppose. Christians widely identify it with their particular religion, but it is also the Holy City of the Jews, and to the Mohammedans it ranks very closely in importance to Mecca.

MAYOR FIORELLO H. LA GUARDIA and his aviation aide, Deputy Commissioner F. William Zelcer, by no means have given up the fight to have the Eastern terminal of the air mail transferred from the Newark Metropolitan Airport to Floyd Bennett Field.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- The climax of the Bermuda social season will be reached on Wednesday when the annual subscription ball for the Lady Cubitt Compassionate Fund is held at the Princess Hotel. This entertainment, the proceeds of which are distributed to charities throughout the year, is given under the patronage of Sir Thomas Astley Cubitt, Governor of the Colony, and Lady Cubitt.

A substantial reduction in the cost of relief in New York City next month, bringing relief expenditures for the month below $19,000,000, was announced yesterday by Oswald W. Knauth, city Relief Director.

ANDOVER, Mass., April 20. -- Scoring eight runs in the eighth inning, Andover came from behind to beat Thayer Academy, 12 to 11, today. The visitors tied the count in the ninth, but Viens hit to left with two out to score Reiter with the winning run.
HAMILTON, N.Y., April 20. -- Colgate opened its baseball season today by routing the Oswego Teachers' nine, 20 to 5. Colgate batters collected 22 safeties.
CHENGTU, Szechwan, China, April 20 (AP). -- Government authorities made feverish preparations today to defend Chengtu against Communists as Chinese and foreign residents by the hundreds moved out.

MOSCOW, April 19. -- When a woman is chosen to the bench in the United States it is usually on the theory -- not always realized -- that she will temper rigid justice with feminine mercy and understanding and give that sympathetic, human touch which man-ruled courts are supposed to lack.

About 100 persons, suffering from smoke, shock or hysteria, and often a combination of all three, were treated at the entrances to the Wall Street station of the West Side I.R.T. subway yesterday after smoke sucked in from the Furman Street fire in Brooklyn had filled the tunnel under the East River.

The New York City Housing Authority's plan for renovating a group of tenement houses at Avenue A and Third Street was termed "ill-advised, impractical and unsound financially," by the New York chapter of the Architectural Guild of America in urging the abandonment of the remodeling plan and the erection of new buildings instead.

HOWARD BARLOW, conductor, who has a record of more than 2,500 hours on the air, directs the music of two WABC programs, recently awarded badges of distinction, namely, "The Concert Hall" and "The March of Time."
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):

LONDON, April 20. -- Although it has not been officially announced, it is understood the British, French and Italian Governments today transmitted to the Lithuanian Government a joint representation regarding Memel.

The American Civil Liberties Union joined yesterday with Representative Hamilton Fish Jr., one of its severest critics, in protesting the suppression of the speech he had been scheduled to deliver over radio broadcasting Station WHN on Friday evening.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- Demands that the Republican party openly and definitely attack the "fallacies of the New Deal" in a series of regional meetings and adopt a platform based on constructive ideas in 1936 which is in keeping with changed economic conditions were made by party leaders today at a luncheon given for William Allen White.
EXETER, N.H., April 20. -- The Harvard freshmen, behind the masterful pitching of Eddie Ingalls, subdued Exeter, 6 to 2, today. Ingalls allowed only three hits, all singles.
PITTSBURGH, April 20. -- The champion Cardinals today won what may prove to be a costly victory from the Pirates, 4 to 1, behind the steady hurling of Lefty Bill Walker.

Denmark's Foreign Minister and representative on the League of Nations Council at Geneva, Dr. Peter Munch, refused last Wednesday to join his colleagues in signing the resolution condemning Germany for violating its Versailles treaty obligations. Did the reason for this refusal go deeper than the claim that the resolution passed by the Council would hamper a continuance of the current disarmament negotiations and an eventual return of Germany to the League of Nations?
ALBANY, April 20 (AP). -- Albany pounded four Buffalo pitchers for 20 hits today and gained its first victory of the season, 13 to 4.

THE capital this Spring is having to take the measure of subtlety of a new kind. Although this subtlety concerns a woman, it is not of the strictly feminine variety with which Washington had a fairly close acquaintance even before women started coming to Congress.

The French liner Paris, which sailed yesterday for Havre, had a number of musicians on her first-class passenger list. Prominent among them was Miss Lily Pons, French soprano of the Metropolitan Opera Association, on her way to London to sing at Covent Garden for the King's Silver Jubilee on May 6.

Robert Weiner, 31 years old, who spent thirteen months in the Sing Sing death house before the Court of Appeals reversed his conviction for murder in connection with the Tombs jailbreak in 1926, which cost five lives, landed in the prison ward at Bellevue Hospital early yesterday.

VIRGINIA GARDEN WEEK is now, as the racing people say, a fixture in the calendar of national events. When April is ripening toward May Springtime fancy seeks for fragrant memories of budding and blooming things -- to every man his cherished bit of earth, blessed by association with the quick senses of youth, whence the call of Spring comes clearest.

The Associated Press reached the highest membership in its history last year, according to the annual report of the board of directors for 1934, to be made to the members at their annual meeting tomorrow. The report to the membership follows:

WE have already seen this gifted granddaughter of Queen Victoria and Czar Alexander II of Russia as she played and prattled and sometimes studied through childhood and adolescence at one royal residence or another, and then beheld her in more sedate, but still alert, demeanor as the wife of the Crown Prince of Rumania.

On the assumption, probably, that Vernon Gomez is indeed a very brilliant pitcher and therefore does not need any support of the fence-smashing variety, the Yankees again hit the ball very gingerly as the distinguished Castilian southpaw made his second start of the season at the Stadium yesterday.

THE colorful atmosphere of the Orient has been captured with marked success in some of the sets erected for one of the more blood-curdling adventure yarns of the season, "China Seas," which at the moment is engrossing M-G-M.

Heavy buying of stocks, with resultant gains of from 1 to 3 points for many of the dividend-paying common and preferred issues, gave the Stock Exchange its busiest Saturday yesterday in nearly a year. Total transactions during the two-hour trading period reached 880,000 shares for the first time for such a short period since May 12, 1934.

Disorder and numerous charges of police brutality to Negroes over a period of several years marked the hearing yesterday of a subcommittee of the Mayor's Commission to Investigate Conditions in Harlem.
ITHACA, N.Y., April 20. -- Dartmouth crushed Cornell in an Eastern Intercollegiate League baseball game today by 11 to 2.

IT is significant that monetary economics recruits its scholars from among those with a mathematical bent of mind. Thus Professor Soddy came to his preoccupation with monetary problems from mathematical chemistry. Professor Fisher, the author of the present book, came to devote himself to the study of economics from mathematical physics.

Water-colors by Willard Nash are being exhibited, until April 27, at the Marie Harriman Gallery. They seem rather slight and, though not oppressively, appear related to Cezanne; somewhat also, perhaps, to the subsequent cubist theories. One of the best of these papers is "Side of Engine," which neatly turns a bit of close-up realism into an abstract pattern.

Tammany seemingly has warded off for this year a legislative re-apportionment that would mean the loss of three Senate and seven Assembly seats in Manhattan. But it has done so at the cost of a break with the national administration of President Roosevelt, the State administration of Governor Lehman and the Democratic national and State organizations headed by Postmaster General James A. Farley.

Last week's headlines told about reductions in the British income taxes, and doubtless many Americans, still smarting from March 15, concluded that it was about time something of the sort happened in Washington. Those who read more than the headlines quickly ceased to grumble; we are not in such a bad spot after all. Consider these comparisons:

The annual Butterfly Ball, for years an event of Easter week, will be held on Tuesday night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. It will be the fifteenth annual ball for the benefit of the House of Rest at Sprain Ridge, near Yonkers, and for the second consecutive year it will be conducted as a dinner dance.

NEW ORLEANS, April 19. -- With millions of Federal funds and thousands of jobs at stake, interest of all classes of Louisianians is centred on the outcome of the political game being played by Senator Huey P. Long and the Secretary of the Interior, Harold L. Ickes.

THE hobby-interests of the adolescent today are definitely inspired and colored by the school curriculum. This fact will be demonstrated by exhibits of the New York public schools at the hobby round-up in the Port Authority Building from May 1 to 11.

Having organized for the season of 1935, the New York and Metropolitan District Cricket Association will have teams representing six clubs in its championship competition when the annual series opens on June 1, according to the official schedule issued by F. Fitzmaurice Kelly, secretary.

Referring specifically to bulletins issued by the United State Department of Labor, Major Benjamin H. Namm, president of The Namm Store, Brooklyn, in a communication to the Business Section of THE TIMES, scored Federal stimulation of the organization of consumer cooperatives.

Easter will be observed today in the churches with sermons on the theme of life immortal, oratorios, cantatas, carols and other music on the Resurrection and pageants and religious dramas presented by the young people. The sanctuaries will be bedecked with Spring blooms and special collections will be taken for the spread of Christianity. It is expected the churches will be crowded.

After nearly two years of Federal intervention the cotton problem of the United States is today involved in as much controversy and apparently as far from being solved as it has been at any time since Eli Whitney invented the cotton gin.

WHAT has become of the salt-bank fisheries of the United States? What has become of that old-time Georges fisherman who stood at the rail of a tossing schooner, hauling in by a hand-line fat and sturdy fish?

ON the theory that half a loaf is better than none, Dr. Chu Chia-hua, now Minister of Communications in the Nanking government, favors cutting the school day in half and taking on extra classes in the afternoons. Dr. Chu was formerly Minister of Education for China and is an expert on school problems.

Medical attention was refused to a girl student of Abraham Lincoln High School in Brooklyn because she was wearing a tag advertising the student peace strike April 12, it was said last night at a meeting of teachers and students in the Union Methodist Episcopal Church, 229 West Forty-eighth Street.

Perhaps the happiest boy in New York yesterday was Paul Ringling. He is a grandnephew of the Ringling brothers who founded the famous circus of that name. Yesterday was his fifteenth birthday and he came down from the New York Military Academy at Cornwall, N.Y., to celebrate it with his mother, Mrs. Richard Ringling. She took him to Madison Square Garden.

IN America the essay has become the vehicle for information. Very few American writers continue the personal essay. In England, however, this literary form remains the medium for expressing an author's personality. And Desmond MacCarthy, a well-known English critic, is one of the better English essayists.

Navy's varsity crew, taking command in the first full minute of rowing, steamed away from Columbia on the Harlem River yesterday to round out a day of victory for the Midshipmen by leaving the Lion varsity four and a half lengths behind.

THE large audiences which were captured by "Young Man of Manhattan" and "Redheaded Woman" will not be disappointed in Miss Brush's new novel. Most men will not get past its first page; most women will not pause until they have finished the last page.

LAWRENCE, Kan., April 20. -- Glenn Cunningham yielded to the finishing "kick" of his usually consistent victim -- Glen Dawson of Skiatook, Okla. -- today in the greatest upset of the thirteenth annual Kansas relay carnival.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that the following companies had reported to it changes in the amount of treasury stock held by them:

EASTER trade closed with a rush, but was quite generally described as "disappointing" by retailers. Adverse weather conditions in many parts of the country held down volume. The closing days of the shopping period last week, however, brought a sharp rise in business, which was marked especially in the children's and juniors' wear lines and in adult apparel.

TOKYO, April 20. -- A group of 217 American missionaries in Japan today issued an appeal to their fellow-Christians in this country to apply the principles of their creed to their government and avoid giving offense by naval manoeuvres on the borders of friendly powers.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 18. -- Although money has been allocated by the Federal Government to pay for "listing" large acreages in the Plains States to stop soil erosion and meetings are being held between government representatives and landowners in the dust area, no general program has been undertaken to stop the dust storms.
DENVER, April 20. -- "Send-a-Dime" chain letters are pouring into the postoffice here in a new scheme which has sprung up virtually overnight.

BOMBAY. -- Speculation has begun as to who will succeed Lord Willingdon as Viceroy of India when his term of office expires in April, 1936. The belief is freely expressed in India that the present appointee has only the remotest chance of continuing after that time. Private advices received here from London indicate that Whitehall has already been examining the chances of various candidates to take his place.

Construction of the super-liners Normandie and Queen Mary by the French and Cunard White Star lines, respectively, has tended to divert attention from the building programs of other lines in smaller units of tonnage for services other than the transatlantic express service.

FEW people are more unfortunate than those who are born out of their own time, whether they belong of right to the future or to the past. In the nineteenth century Lucy Benton, the heroine of Marjorie Worthington's delicate and sensitive novel, would have been a "grande amoureuse"; in the twentieth, she was a joke to those who weren't attached to her and a nuisance to those who were.

FOR twenty years after her death, Queen Victoria was remembered by her name frequently appearing on the map, by her countenance still visible on coins and stamps, by numberless statues and portraits and by the receding mirage of the glorious era which history has dedicated to her sway.
ALTHOUGH Mexico has of late years made many changes in religious ceremonies, there are ancient customs which endure, particularly in the smaller places.
PRESCOTT, Ariz., April 20 (AP). --Fiorello H. La Guardia, smiling and jovially reminiscent, came "back home" to Prescott today, after an absence of thirty-seven years.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 20. -- Deputy Chief Inspector Henry Bruckman, a witness at the trial of Dutch Schultz, had left here today before word came that Commissioner Valentine might inquire into the conduct of New York police who testified against the racketeer in Federal court here.

CHICAGO, April 20. -- The $100,000 verdict awarded by a jury in the Federal District Court to Mrs. Helen Bedford-Jones on April 4 for the lost love of her former husband, Henry Bedford-Jones, wealthy writer for "pulp magazines," was set aside today by Judge William H. Holly, the trial judge.

Seldom has legislation of such outstanding importance as the Administration's "social security" bill been put through the House of Representatives by so great a majority. The Democratic members voted for it, twenty-two to one. The Republicans, who were its chief critics during the debate, wound up by voting for it, four to one.

Newspaper publishers, editors, business managers and other executives will gather in New York this week for the annual meetings of The Associated Press and the American Newspaper Publishers Association. Both conventions will be held at the Waldorf-Astoria.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., April 20. -- Though intercollegiate forensic encounters under the banner of the Eastern Debate League are over for the season, Mount Holyoke debaters, both upper classmen and freshmen, are out for Spring manoeuvres and non-competitive debating skirmishes the coming week.

THE transportation lines of the British Isles will make the silver jubilee of the accession of King George the occasion of an ambitious travel program so that visitors may view the exercises in various parts of the kingdom. Cruising trains will be operated to the ninety zones into which the islands have been divided and will connect with a motor-coach service at convenient terminal points.

" When you're in the country you have to find things for yourself," said Araminta's grandmother, and so Araminta, the little colored girl, who knew all about city life, learned how different things are in the country. Water didn't come out of a faucet in the kitchen, so when Araminta wanted a drink she had to search until she found the well.

Miss Frances Coleman and a committee have arranged a bazaar and card party for May 2 at the home of Mrs. Albert L. Hoffman, 58 East Seventy-ninth Street, for the benefit of Save-a-Life Farm in Nyack, N.Y. Miss Coleman's associates are Mrs. Hoffman, Mrs. L. Carbury Ritchie, Mrs. William F. Cogswell, Mrs. Francis X. Sadlier, Miss Virginia Alexandre and Mrs. Richard L. Farrelly.

THE next cycle in the movies may be, for all we know, comedy in the grand, or romantic, style. Whimsy, with urbane acting and the Continental flavor, the sort that recalls W.J. Locke's novels, films like "The Grand Duchess and the Waiter" and the acting of which Leo Dietrichstein was an exponent and which Tullio Carminati has brought to Hollywood.

One thousand miniature boats -- steam, sail, electric and spring motor -- cut through the tiny swells of the Conservatory Lake at Central Park yesterday in keen competition for prizes in the semi-annual model boat regatta of which R.H. Macy Co. and the New York City park Department are sponsors.

THIS novel of the Old South is written without a touch of Southern moonlight and roses, flirtatious curls and crinolines, pretty speeches and high-flown gallantry. The author is State historian of Virginia, and knows his facts about the Old South.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP). -- Behind Boston's timely hitting, right-hander Johnny Welch limited the Senators to four hits today as the Red Sox won their second straight game from Washington, 4 to 0.

BERLIN, April 20. -- The German Labor Front announced today as a "birthday gift" to Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler that in its nation-wide confidential shop council elections last week, 84.5 per cent of the total vote was cast for the official lists put up by the Labor Front in conjunction with shop leaders or managers.

Contrary to all expectations, the share market came to life yesterday in the two-hour market sandwiched between Good Friday and Easter Sunday. Trading on the Stock Exchange was the most active for a Saturday in nearly a year, or since May 12, 1934.

In The Saturday Review of Literature the well-known publisher, GEORGE H. DORAN, describes three striking experiences of his own with literary plagiarism. One had to do with an unnamed woman author, described as "a "very prominent, popular and highly "successful novelist."

FROM abysmal depths of ignorance concerning the scientific and mechanical side of photography, I am venturing to write of it as an art for the one reason that an often expressed preference for etchings, lithographs, engravings, all the forms of graphic art in which the interpretation of the design is the direct work of the hand, probably has given the impression of indifference to the claims of photography as an art.

RENO, Nev., April 20 (AP). -- Mrs. Norma Jones Edwards, formerly of White Plains, N.Y., and Howard Clayton of Brooklyn and Yokohama, Japan, were married here today shortly after Mrs. Edwards divorced William Hanford (Big Bill) Edwards, former Princeton football star and one-time Collector of the Port of New York.
PINEHURST, N.C., April 20. -- Wilmer Allison of Austin, Texas, top-ranking American tennis player, enjoyed a most successful day on the courts of the Pinehurst Country Club today.

MARTIN BRAITHWAITE, successful playwright, had a theory that "exploding popular fallacies is always sure-fire." While he was finishing a play at the Summer-resort home of friends, he had a chance to take a pot-shot at one such "fallacy" in real life.

Chauncey Brewster Tinker and George Henry Nettleton and other sapient scholars looked over his shoulder helpfully from time to time while he was at work. But Mr. Purdy alone deserves the honors for this distinguished study of Sheridan's comedy as it was first -- and rather disastrously for the time being -- acted at the Theatre Royal in Covent Garden.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 20 (AP). -- Loosing a barrage off twenty-one hits, Toronto today downed Syrauce, 15 to 6, to earn a 2-to-1 edge in their brief series.

APPARENTLY, Elly Beinhorn is to Germany something like what Amelia Earhart is to the United States. At any rate, she is a courageous airwoman who doesn't pay much attention to the chances she takes and is always happy when she is going somewhere in her plane.
The 371st anniversary of the birth of Shakespeare will be celebrated Tuesday with two assemblies at the Shakespeare statue in Central Park; one at 11 A.M. and the second at 2 P.M.

IT is a good idea for a writer to keep a dictionary within arm's reach. Words in common usage have a capricious way of turning up in gay costumes when they are tracked down in the dictionary. I was about to accuse "Ceiling Zero" of being hokum at heart -- a contemptible thing to say about any play.

Two detectives, one a Scotland Yard man and the other an amateur, cooperate most amicably on the murder problem presented in this book. They investigate separately, but they meet frequently to compare notes, and they very rarely hold out on each other.

Eighty-six New York University girls have been pledged to fourteen sororities this semester, Mrs. Dorothy McSparran Arnold, dean of women at the university's Washington Square College and faculty adviser to the Pan-Hellenic Congress, announced yesterday.

With this book Mrs. Haskell adds another volume to her popular "Katrinka" series. Although complete in itself, it continues the history of Peter, brother of Katrinka, whose youth in Soviet Russia was described in an earlier volume. This story begins with the marriage of Peter to Peggy Likorenko, gay young daughter of a Russian father and American mother.

Two brilliant performances by Ted Ellison, versatile DeWitt Clinton High School athlete, featured the wholesale assault on meet records as the twenty-seventh New York University interscholastic games at Ohio Field yesterday opened the 1935 schoolboy outdoor track and field campaign.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 20. -- For the first time since the introduction of the house plan in Harvard College, officials believe that the undergraduates have put the stamp of approval on the project, made possible by a gift of Edward S. Harkness.

This year's Spring showing of General Motors products opened at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Astor. Exhibits of automobiles, frigidaire coolers and conditioners, accessories of the United Motor Service, Delco appliances and Fisher bodies occupied the grand ball room and surrounding space on the main floor.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- Declaring that the American citizen's great problem today is to protect himself "against the encroachment upon his own rights and liberty by his own government," Senator Borah called on the Society of American Editors in an address tonight to battle for the maintenance of constitutional forms of government.

The hoard of gold coins having an intrinsic value of more than $11,000, unearthed in the basement of an old house in Baltimore last August by the two 16-year-old boys, Theodore Jones and Henry Grob, will be sold at auction in the Lord Baltimore Hotel, Baltimore, on Thursday afternoon, May 2.

In each of the six stories in this volume, Reggie Fortune objects to the obvious conclusions drawn by the detectives of Scotland Yard from the evidence placed before them, and in each case he is able to demonstrate that he is right and they are wrong.
DUBLIN, April 19. -- "Ireland never is but always is to be a republic," Professor Michael Tierney, one of the clearest of our political thinkers, writes in the current number of The Irish Review.
LONDON, April 20. -- Prices for seats from which to view the royal procession to St. Paul's Cathedral on May 6, Accession Day, soared today as eager promoters grasped for the utmost farthing.

PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT'S announced plan to allot about $200,000,000 in Federal funds for grade-crossing elimination is viewed as the biggest concerted effort to attack a problem that has cost thousands of lives in the last few years.

PALM BEACH. -- Colonists are now following the line of least resistance, devoting daytime hours to fishing, swimming or cruising, and evenings to informal dinners followed by dancing, contract bridge or attendance at wrestling and boxing bouts.

IN one of his recent prefaces H.G. Wells makes an observation which ought to stand as a motto for every novelist who feels tempted to take liberties with the common interpretation of the laws of nature. Mr. Wells says:

Running away from his opposition in the last burning eighth of a mile, C.H. Knebelkamp's King Saxon yesterday lowered the ten-year-old six-furlong track record as he swept through the stretch and on to victory in the Paumonok Handicap at Jamaica to the cheers of 15,000 persons.

CLEVELAND, April 19. -- Revolution in public-school financing has struck Ohio, and its outcome is due within the two or three weeks remaining before recess of the Ohio Legislature. The House has passed a long-debated "foundation" bill to allot $48,000,000 a year to carrying weak town and country schools.

Fifteen classes, all but one of them arranged for the Junior contestants, will be judged tomorrow, the opening day of the annual New York Spring Horse Show in the arena of the Riding Club, 7 West Sixty-sixth Street. The exhibition, with matinee and evening sessions each day, will continue through Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- The Roosevelt administration made its anticipated move this week to "compromise" the troublesome bonus issue and thereby meet the defiant demands in Congress for immediate cash or "fiat" payment of the World War adjusted service certificates, which are not due before 1945.

BOSTON, April 20 (AP). -- William G. Gavin, city editor of The Boston Traveler, who declined to disclose the source of a news story, was threatened by Governor Curley tonight with jail over Easter but won postponement of action on contempt proceedings until Monday.
MEXICO, D.F., April 20. -- A bug in her eye today spoiled Amelia Earhart's projected non-stop flight from Burbank, Calif., to this city.
Warfare, with PWA and FERA cash as the ammunition, was declared last week by the Democratic national administration against two States of the Solid South -- Louisiana and Georgia.

ONE of the most talked-about men in Britain is Leslie Hore-Belisha, Minister of Transport. The silence order at night which he has imposed on motorists and the black-and-white posts with orange globes on them which he has installed at street corners to indicate pedestrians' crossing -- the famous Belisha beacons -- have caused him to be ridiculed, criticized and applauded on every road in Britain.

MR. CURRY'S keen interest in education is largely because he considers its fundamentals to be of prime importance to civilization and feels sure that upon them will depend the kind of world the future will bring. "I believe," he says, "that the most important problem which educators must face is that of the fundamental social attitudes produced by education."

THE suggestion that safety slogans be used in the cancellation of postage stamps has been made to Postmaster General Farley by Urban F. Emme, chief clerk of the Traffic Department of the Municipal Court of Los Angeles. In a letter to the Postmaster General, Mr. Emme said:

The main hope of the cotton-textile industry lies in the number of capable young men who are rapidly coming to the fore both in mill management and selling, according to one of the leading executives in the industry yesterday. He enumerated offhand about twenty-five of the younger executives who eventually will be the heads of their various organizations and who will be the controlling factors in the industry.

Renewing complaints against the "unnecessarily severe" interpretations placed on customs regulations by local customs officials, importers last week appealed to the Treasury Department to release sample cases of merchandise being held at the Appraiser's Stores until disputes over marking of the shipments are settled.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- The downward movement in steel production was halted this week, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly survey of domestic business. For the week the scheduled output was 4 per cent of capacity, a slight increase.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -A lesson in Irish history was given today by Representative John J. O'Connor of New York to a namesake in Cleveland, the occasion being a criticism of Mr. O'Connor's opposition to the Townsend Plan.

A COLD-BLOODED murder in a Pennsylvania coal town in 1929 and an accidental meeting between a jurist and an actor were the events preceding the screen play of "Black Fury" which, after a siege of censor trouble, has arrived at the Strand.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., April 20. -- The mobilization of the New York National Guard units at Pine Camp between Aug. 17 and 31 has necessitated changes in the previously arranged schedule.

Professor Albert Einstein at a Passover celebration last night in the Manhattan Opera House, Eighth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, warned against supporting the activities of any Jewish political group whose acts were preventing friendly cooperation of Jews and Arabs in Palestine.

ABOARD S.S. NORTH HAVEN, April 20 (By Wireless). -- The second post of the long air relay between two hemispheres, America and Asia, was rapidly taking form today as heavily loaded barges lurched drunkenly in rolling seas and dumped tons of cargo for construction of the Pan American Airways base at Midway Island on the white sands of the island.

Columbia University's "100-year-project," a dictionary of Latin inscriptions, of which several hundred thousand are extant, gained new impetus yesterday with the publishing of the first section of Volume II, which brings the dictionary up to the word "audio."

A 25-year-old pilot and two youthful friends who were making their first airplane trip were killed and their bodies burned beyond recognition yesterday afternoon when their airplane fell from an altitude of about 150 feet into the marshy land of Jamaica Creek and burst into flames.

STARTED as an adventure in philanthropy, Thrift House has just celebrated its second birthday and embarked on a program of expansion. All is grist that comes to Thrift House; its stock in trade are things discarded by householders, and its volunteer workers find a market for every item, however battered.

LONDON, April 20. -- Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler's note challenging the right of other powers to judge Germany was received by the British Foreign Office early this afternoon without any ceremony of circumstance. It was carried there by a messenger from the German Embassy and its receipt merely acknowledged by the subordinate official to whom it was handed.

THREE fairly recent theatrical productions have all turned to the history of the past for their characters and their background, and each has incidentally tried to restore the reputation of a historical person. The place and the period alike are, however, widely different in each case, and the spirit of the treatment more different still.

The Homeric and the Berengaria of the Cunard White Star Line will be in the reviewing line at Spithead, England, when King George reviews the British Fleet July 16 in conjunction with the Silver Jubilee of his accession. The Homeric originally had been assigned to carry persons desiring to witness the spectacle, but accommodations were exhausted and the Berengaria was assigned to accommodate the overflow.

LONDON, April 20. -- When as cautious a Chancellor of the Exchequer as Neville Chamberlain announces that Great Britain has regained 80 per cent of her prosperity, there must be some truth in what he says.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 20. -A hot single off Cadet Welhnig's bat following Durbin's double and $annarone's sacrifice gave the Army plebes a twelfth-inning vietory over the Islip High School nine today, 4 to 3.

The furniture and decorations of Ophir Hall at Purchase, N.Y., the estate of the late Mrs. Whitelaw Reid, will be sold at auction next month under the auspices of the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc. The dates of the sale and the preceding exhibition have not been set yet.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 20. -- Showing his heels to a half dozen other Kentucky Derby nominees, Plat Eye, 3-year-old brown colt of Mrs. Payne Whitney's Greentree Stable, won the $7,500 added mile and a sixteenth Chesapeake Stakes today in a driving finish.

Senator Fearon, the Republican leader, shook hands with Senator Dunnigan, staggered to his chair, dropped his chin on his breast and sobbed. There were tears in the eyes of other sleepless and overwrought Senators and Assemblymen as the Legislature, on Wednesday afternoon, after twenty-nine hours of continuous argument, came to the end of one of the most remarkable closing sessions in New York history.

In 1928 it was charged in Congress that postoffices were being sold in certain Southern States like bales of cotton in the open market. Investigations were made, but public indignation, usually as fickle as public favor, quickly evaporated and the matter was soon forgotten.

With increasing frequency have been heard statements that at last we have done with foreign nations forever. We have washed our hands of them. We will have nothing more to do with them. Their problems and difficulties have no relation to ours, and we shall hereafter prevent the two from getting mixed up.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19. -- Now that the Philadelphia Bar Association's investigation of reported collusion between its members and the underworld has led to the permanent disbarment of six criminal lawyers, subject to confirmatory action of the State Supreme Court, certain questions are bound to be posed.

Here is an 8-year-old's informal preface to marine biology, for in this book the author of "Holiday Hill" and other nature studies for children has collaborated with Dr. Fenton in describing some of the myriad forms of animal life in shallow waters along the seashore.

The rapidity with which industry and trade have rallied to the support of the NRA, when the tide appeared going against it, is illustrated by the fact that within three weeks some 250,000 business units have expressed their desire for a continuance of the law to the Industry and Business Committee for NRA Extension, Ward Cheney, president of Cheney Brothers, and chairman of the committee, pointed out here yesterday.

Robert Moses, who has the reputation of enjoying a good fight, was at war on two fronts last week. One battle concerned the Triborough Bridge; the other was about the cost of the recently rebuilt Central Park Zoo.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP). -- The Bureau of Agricultural Economics reports that better prices for the farmer's products are reflected in higher wages for the farmhand. Farm wages started downward in 1929 and joined in the collapse in crop and livestock prices.

IT needs only slight acquaintance with the book world of today to know that Mr. Wingfield-Stratford is at work in a field already fairly well populated, although he seems to think that he is its discoverer. Nevertheless, he has written a readable book that is often highly entertaining, and has put into it much sound common sense and a considerable knowledge of the scientific principles involved in bodily and mental development.

FEW of America's great stories of exploration are more stirring than that of the Lewis and Clark expedition. When the United States negotiated the Louisiana Purchase, in 1803, neither party to the transaction had much notion of what had changed hands.

PHILADELPHIA, April 20. -- The Giants finally broke into the National League's victory column today in their third start of the season. It required eleven innings of baseball, a blasting blow from the bat of Manager Bill Terry and an exhibition of reliable pitching by Carl Hubbell in a crisis to accomplish the feat.

MEMPHIS, April 18. -- Despite evidence of widespread unemployment and extreme poverty among the cotton sharecroppers, the planters and landlords of the rich delta lands of Northeastern Arkansas argue with striking unanimity that the Agricultural Adjustment Act has helped rather than hurt the tenant farmer.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., April 20 (AP). -- Five former State prison camp officials were indicted today on charges arising from two Negro prisoners developing gangrenous feet necessitating amputation of the members.

MANILA. -- Reaction in the Philippines to various proposals made in the United States for modification of the Tydings-McDuffie Law, or possibly even changing the entire basis of the relationship, are very largely what might have been expected.

NOW again comes the summons to Africa. This time (with shows already in progress at the Museum of Modern Art and at the Pierre Matisse Gallery) it is the collection assembled by Louis Carre of Paris, which has been placed on view at the Valentine (April 15-27).

BERLIN, April 20. -- The war guilt lie had become mildewed through supercultivation in Geneva's political hothouse, a new alibi was needed to perpetuate the defamation of Germany, and then German conscription, illegally reintroduced, came to the rescue and provided a pretext once more to pillory the Reich as the world's perennial villain -- that about sums up the popular German interpretation of the rebuke by the Council of the League of Nations.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- A balloon flight to nearly five miles above the earth to test instruments for a stratosphere expedition in June by the National Geographic Society and the Army Air Corps will be made tomorrow from Scott Field, near Belleville, Ill., the society's headquarters announced tonight.

SAN JUAN, P.R., April 18. -- Sea and psychology separating Washington and San Juan have multiplied New Deal difficulties in Puerto Rico. Add the factors of experimentation and uncertainty which have featured the present administration and a basis is found for at least a part of the insular reaction to programs set forth at Washington.

The recent action of a local radio station in barring the address of Commissioner of Accounts Blanshard on the grounds that the management of the station was responsible in case of libel, presents an interesting question that bids fair to undermine the entire system of American broadcasting.

Chairmen of trade groups in the United Jewish Appeal's campaign to raise $1,250,000 as New York City's share of the national quota of $3,250,000, sought for the aid of Jews in Germany and other lands and for their settlement in Palestine, were announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- Opening a campaign to put the Omnibus Banking Bill through the Senate, Chairman Fletcher of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee struck out today against a "flood of letters and telegrams" attacking the measure, which he said had been sent to Congress members.

Although buying of Fall merchandise by dry-goods wholesalers is proceeding slowly, they said yesterday that they were planning to expand their budgets 10 to 15 per cent on these lines over last year. Their main belief that Fall business will expand to this extent is based on the works relief program, which is expected to be under way by the time Summer ends.
LONDON, April 20. -Anthony Eden, the Lord Privy Seal, has replied to Liberals in his Warwick constituency who recently sent him a letter protesting the White Paper on British armament estimates.

THIS writer has been privileged to see manuscript pages of Parts I and II of "The New Green Mountain Songster," containing "traditional folksongs of Vermont, collected, transcribed and edited by Helen Hartness Flanders, Elizabeth Flanders, George Brown and Phillips Barry."
WASHINGTON, April 19. -- Resolved that the United States Capitol Building should strive for artistic perfection.

BERLIN, April 20. -- The German Government for the first time today took formal cognizance of the resolution adopted by the Council of the League of Nations last Wednesday, on the initiative of the Stresa conferees, declaring that Germany "has failed in the duty incumbent on all members of the international community to respect their contractual obligations" and condemning any such unilateral repudiation.

THE astonishing increase in the interest in daffodils during the last few years is typical of the inexplicable way in which some groups of flowers go on for years without attracting particular attention and then suddenly become the vogue in the garden world.

MARK TWAIN'S century will reach its close in November of this year. It is still undeniably his, and his fame goes marching on into a new one, though he died twenty-five years ago on this day of April in 1910 -- long enough ago for an average president or a fairly good king to have been forgotten.
LONDON, April 14. -- The crucial issue in Europe now is: What is to be done to meet the still rising tide of German armaments?

INDUSTRIAL design -- the modern term expressing the artist's role in the making of equipment for everyday living -- has given a new dignity of appearance to household fittings and other articles of convenience long left unimproved.

GLOUCESTER, Mass.., April 20 (AP). -- There has been no substantial improvement in the methods of rigging sailing ships for more than 200 years, and John Hays Hammond Jr., the inventor, decided today to see if modern methods of research would not make windjammers more efficient and give them a new lease on a fast-ebbing life.

PITTSBURGH, April 20 (AP). -- Dr. Vilhjalmur Stefansson, the Arctic explorer, explained today his theory that America was discovered by the Irish nearly seven centuries before Columbus's voyage in 1492.

DESPITE the unseasonable weather that has been keeping impatient gardeners champing at the bit for the last fortnight Spring has been coming on apace. Magnolias, many early flowering shrubs and early hardy plants have paid little attention to shrill winds and occasional sleet and snow storms.

WARSAW, April 20. -- Last Sunday's anti-German riots near Gdynia in Wejherow and Maliczack in the Polish Corridor drew public attention to the fact that the problem of German minorities has changed altogether since the Polish and German Governments signed their non-aggression declaration and became good friends.

AFTER twelve years, when radio seemed stabilized, a double revolution is brewing. The first, caused by the promise of high definition television operated by the government, has shaken the industry so that in the confusion the second revolution has almost escaped notice.

Despite the protestations of weavers and converters that current rayon fabric prices have discounted the reduction in yarn, buyers were certain last week that some further revisions would be made before the market settled down. Manufacturers would have a better chance of getting current prices if any substantial demand existed at this time, buyers said, but with the current lack of interest only very low quotations can bring in orders.

PARIS, April 20 (AP). -- Veils will be the banner of chic on Easter bonnets that make their debut tomorrow at church services or the races at Auteuil. Three-quarters of the new hats delivered to fashionable Parisians are ornamented with veils used in a great variety of ways.

FOR nearly a quarter of a century (1909-1933) A. Lawrence Lowell was president of Harvard. What the university is today, though perhaps not what it will be tomorrow, is largely the result of his efforts, added to those of his illustrious predecessor, Charles W. Eliot.
BOGOTA, Colombia. -- The General Labor Office has published the form of a model employment contract which will be obligatory for all private employes above the grade of laborer under Law 10 of 1934.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- Although the new British budget, submitted last week by Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, sharply reduces income taxes in the lower brackets, they remain so far above those of the United States as to seem almost unbearable here.

ALBANY, April 20. -- Governor Lehman will face a record task in acting on accumulated legislation when he returns from his brief vacation, a check-up today showed. The Governor will have to deal with 943 "thirty-day" bills, said to be the largest number in history.

Many tables have been reserved for the "Five-To-Fifty-Year-Old Fashion Show" in aid of Everybody's Thrift Shop to be held Thursday afternoon at Sherry's. Women of society will act as manikins in the fashion showing of the latest costumes for Spring wear for persons from 5 to 50 years of age. Later in the afternoon tea will be served.

ON cold December night many years ago, the thin and boyish frame of George White was hurled through the doors of a Bowery saloon by a burly bartender. The stunned lad slowly picked himself up, brushed the snow from the seat of his messenger-boy pants and decided he had taken his last bump.
The names of the 112 students who were pledged to 28 sororities at Hunter College were made public yesterday by Miss Pauline Kreisberg, president of the Pan-Hellenic Association.

ROME, April 19. -- Perhaps the comment about the Stresa conference that came nearest to hitting the mark was that made by a British journalist who said Stresa made European peace as secure as mere words can make it. The obvious corollary is that if something more than words is needed to avert war then the prospect is not equally rosy.

Two hundred and twenty sterling silver trophies, valued at nearly $5,000, are offered to exhibitors in the ninth annual all-breed dog show of the Morris and Essex Kennel Club, according to the elaborate premium list just sent to exhibitors all over the United States and Canada.

Functioning of what is the most comprehensive undertaking ever launched in the field of distribution, designed to impress upon Washington and the State capitols that distribution, the third largest industry in the country, must be heard upon questions of national and economic import, will begin tomorrow when Colonel Clarence O. Sherrill assumes his post as active head of the American Retail Federation.

DALLAS, Texas, April 19. -- With favorable weather in the week preceding Easter, retail merchants in the Eleventh Federal Reserve District report heavy increase in volume of sales. The prevalence of dust storms acted as a deterrent on pre-Easter buying and retail sales failed to measure up to expectations until the last week, but in the last week sales exceeded expectations even in aggregate volume for the entire pre-Easter season.

MADRID, March 27, 1935. THE first Spanish novelty presented this season by Bartolome Perez Casas and his Orquesta Filarmonica was a symphonic poem, "Por la Flor del Lirio Azul" (For the Blue Fleur-de-Lis), by the young Valencian, Joaquin Rodrigo.

Apropos of recent Jefferson Day orations and especially that of Secretary Wallace at Atlanta, in which he said "Jefferson, if living now, would be in the forefront fighting the battle against such organizations as the present-day Liberty League," might it not be fair to that justly esteemed statesman to let him state his own political principles?

Economic isolation is a policy impossible of successful fulfillment in the United States, one that will involve dire consequences, Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of General Motors Corporation, and Gerard Swope, president of General Electric Company, said last night in radio addresses on "World Trade and Economic Recovery."

While the dwindling "gold bloc" of nations fights desperately, the downfall of the old gold standard is almost complete. Only France, Switzerland and the Netherlands remain anchored to gold and the action of their currencies in the foreign exchange market shows that the ties which bind them to gold are rapidly fraying.

FOR a touch of originality, Mrs. La Farge begins her romance with a wedding, devoting her story to the years conventionally covered by the phrase "and they lived happily ever after." It is easy to guess that Rosamond and Tom are not going to follow that monotonously rosy pattern.

LONDON, March 29. A VERY full week, which has offered to devoted playgoers a choice of thirteen first-nights, has yielded to me several plays of varying commercial value and one, a translation by Allan Wade of Jean Cocteau's "La Machine Infernale," of more lasting interest.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- Three thousand Daughters of the American Revolution, all differences for the moment forgotten, assembled at the White House today in an atmosphere replete with harmony and sweet with Easter lilies and exchanged greetings with Mrs. Roosevelt.

With but four concerts remaining in the Philharmonic-Symphony's 1934-35 season, Arturo Toscanini concluded the Saturday Students Series in Carnegie Hall last night before a capacity audience that recalled him to the platform many times after each of the two symphonies of his program.

A new Fordham hurling star, sophomore George Robinson, shut out Temple University, 1 to 0, yesterday on Fordham Field before a crowd of 2,000. Two singles were all that young Robinson allowed, and with Ken Berry, the invading hurler, almost keeping pace, the teams set a new record for the field, completing the engagement in 1 hour and 25 minutes.
LITTLE things are "going big" in this Spring's daytime styles. You cannot afford to overlook them and you can afford to have them.

CHICAGO, April 20. -- The markets for wheat and corn on the Board of Trade acted today in a manner that led some operators to believe a bull movement was under way. No material pressure developed, while persistent commission-house and local buying lifted wheat nearly 2 cents a bushel above Thursday's final prices.

TWO grade crossings of the Erie Railroad on Routes 6 and 23 at Singac, Passaic County, N.J., will be eliminated under a contract for which bids have been received by Highway Commissioners Arthur F. Foran and James Baker.

Politicians seeking an issue and sincere but impractical admirers of European nostrums are responsible for the present agitation against the privately owned electric power utilities, declares Wendell L. Willkie, president of the Commonweath and Southern Corporation, in a statement of the case for the power industry in May Current History.
DIXON, Ill., April 20 (AP). -- Charles Skinner, the deaf and eccentric poet of Amboy, was convicted and sentenced to life imprisonment today for the "love murder" of 17-year-old Olive Derwent.

IN spite of our considering ourselves, and in many respects rightly, as a new people and nation, we have already for nearly a generation been celebrating the tercentenaries of the founding of various States in the Union. This year it is the turn of Connecticut.

THE professed scope of this Goethe study is to present the great German poet as a challenge to and an indictment of, the cruelty and oppression practiced today by Hitler and his followers against the Jews. In his preface Dr. Waldman assures us that Goethe would not be welcome in Hitlerland and would in all probability have landed in a concentration camp or in exile.

Progress of The Associated Press in the gathering and distribution of news during 1934 is described in the annual report of Kent Cooper, general manager. The report, addressed to the board of directors, and dated Jan. 1, 1935, follows:

PARIS, April 20. -- France's Easter is not going to be spoiled by Germany's vehement protest against the League of Nations Council's condemnation. Unofficially it is characterized as sharp, undiplomatic, specious and baseless, while its picture of Germany as an innocent victim is treated with scorn.
Because of the dust storms out West, land and wheat are news gain. City people are asking: Is the Great Plains region becoming a desert? Will there be enough bread to go 'round this coming year?

In contrast with the large volume of bond retirements in recent weeks, calls issued last week for bonds for payment before their dates of maturity were fewer. Most of them were for small amounts of municipal bonds to be redeemed next month.

There are some truly delightful characters in this book, and there are others who are utterly undelightful. The worst of the lot is old Arabella, Lady Engleton, who has evolved a beautifully simple plan for restoring the fortunes of the House of de Birkett, of which she is the unquestioned head, although her 20-year-old grandson Henry is the present Lord Engleton.

CHATTANOOGA will be host at the second National Folk Festival, May 12-18, when the ballad lore of Tennessee will be brought to the attention of visitors, together with primitive music of various types from other regions. Preliminary festivals are now being held in Tennessee counties, providing try-outs for harp singers, fiddlers, dancers and others representative of America's rediscovered folk-art.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 20. -- Joe McGinn accounted for eight points as Harvard's rugby team opened its home season with an 11-to-5 victory over Long Island University today.

MARY BOLAND granted an interview last week. Promptly at the appointed hour a group of six or seven persons of inquiring minds reported to the Boland suite. Miss Boland, blond and much slimmer and younger than the pictures make her, pretended for a moment to be baffled, flustered and befuddled.

FREEPORT, L.I., April 20. -- Princeton achieved the distinction of scoring the first points made this season against the New York Rugby Club at the Freeport Stadium today, but like the five other opponents of the blue-shirted fifteen the Tigers could not approach the scoring total of the clubmen, who triumphed, 18 to 3.

OVER the land a recruiting campaign is in progress. Unemployed boys are signing up with the government to build forest trails, blast out roadbeds, reclaim swamps and carry on a hundred other outdoor jobs. Soon these boys will be in camp, ready for work.

Pleas for international amity were made yesterday by five prelates of the Roman Catholic Church in a far-flung broadcast that linked the United States and four European nations. The addresses, which came from Armagh, Ireland; Paris, Naples, Vienna and Boston, were correlated by wires and an international radio hook-up through London and rebroadcast here over the nation-wide network of WABC.

PARIS, April 18 -- Chanel is showing separate sailor collars instead of evening capelets with many new gowns. They are very wide-shouldered and shallow and are fastened either in front or in back forming a square bib effect.
WORCESTER, Mass., April 20. -- Holy Cross opened its regular season today with a 10-to-8 victory over Brown.
WORCESTER, Mass., April 20. -- Three Yale crews brought their shells to victory in their opening races of the season against Massachusetts Institute of Technology on Lake Quinsigamond today.

LOUISVILLE, April 19. -- If Judge Charles I. Dawson is sustained in his invalidation of the Kerr-Smith Act, the result, it is feared here, will be a complete breakdown of the tobacco production control plans of the AAA in ten Southern or border States.

Edwin C. Johnson states in a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES that "nothing in the Morrill Act obligates land-grant colleges to maintain military courses upon a compulsory basis," and then quotes in support an opinion of the attorney General of the United States and the decision of the Supreme Court in the California case of Hamilton v. Regents.

The Agricultural Adjustment Administration, around which the whole policy of "national planning" appears to have been built, is facing its first real test with cotton. In view of recent protests against the processing tax, mainly from the textile industry, President Roosevelt late last week appointed a committee four members of the Cabinet to survey the textile situation.

The Nahem brothers, Sam and Joe, starred as the Brooklyn College nine defeated St. Peter's College of Jersey City, 4 to 1, yesterday at Manhattan Beach. It was the Maroon and Gold's third straight triumph of this week.

WHEN a bootlegger is caught transporting liquor in an automobile, the car is seized by the government. If the bootlegger has bought the car on the instalment plan, as he usually has, and has not finished paying for it, as he usually hasn't, the dealer who sold him the vehicle losses whatever money remains unpaid.

More than 10,000 chemists and industrialists will celebrate the 300th anniversary of the founding of the chemical industries in America at a series of meetings of the American Chemical Society in New York this week. It will be the eighty-ninth gathering of the society and probably will be the largest scientific convention ever held.

PHILADELPHIA, April 20. -- Pennsylvania, after losing three straight Eastern Intercollegiate League games, came through with a victory over Yale today, 4 to 3, when Bob Freeman's triple scored Shorty O'Donnell with two men out in the eighth inning. It was the Eli's first start in league competition.

FOR many years known to large audiences as playwright, poet, speaker, Mr. Anspacher can be assured of a wide interest in this volume of essays that puts into print the same voice to which they have listened from radio and lecture platform.

The movement to establish pension plans for officers and employes of banks received added impetus last week when the executive council of the American Bankers Association, meeting in Augusta, Ga., received a report of the association's committee on pension and retirement plans strongly endorsing them as "workable, economical and sound."

INCREASINGLY the nation is confronted with the question: "What are we to do about the large amount of leisure that lies ahead?" One phase of the problem arises, of course, out of the depression. But the issue is far deeper than that, for workdays have been shortened and are likely to be shortened still more in the future.

LONDON, April 20. -- A group of eighteen statues by Jacob Epstein, which helped start the American-born sculptor on the road to fame by the sensation they created in 1908, were offered for sale today. They are seven-foot nude figures he produced for the outside decorative scheme of the British Medical Association building in the Strand.

ONE of the large water-color groups is having its innings now -- the New York Water-Color Club, whose forty-sixth annual exhibition will continue, in the galleries of the American Fine Arts Building, until April 28.

The latest monthly report of FERA clearly indicates that relief costs throughout the country have risen primarily because of a larger per capita expenditure rather than because of a sudden expansion of the relief rolls themselves. It is true that between February, 1934, and February, 1935, the number of families on relief rose from 2,600,000 to 4,485,000, an increase of 72 per cent.

SALISBURY, Md., April 20. -- Three girls, seniors in the Delmar High School, and three young men were killed at Howellville, nine miles from here, early this morning when a sedan in which they were riding crashed into a parked motor truck.

Current real estate taxes collected to date total $59,115,988.32, as compared with $52,963,445.46 paid into the city treasury at the same date last year, Controller Frank J. Taylor announced yesterday. A total of $11,488,583.84 was collected last week.

" Probably the most far-reaching piece of legislation ever considered by the American Congress" (the description is by Chairman Doughton of the Ways and Means Committee) was passed by the House on Friday.
The Bank of Montreal rugby team, on a two-day visit to the metropolitan area, started successfully yesterday by overwhelming the Pilgrims at Innisfail Park, 26 to 0.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 20. -- A squeeze play with one out in the tenth inning gave Rutgers an 8-to-7 victory over the C.C.N.Y. nine today. Roy Lins, who relieved Cuno Bender in the fourth inning after going the full route against New York University Thursday, won his own game by scoring Palumbo on a well-placed bunt down the third-base line.

OUT Allentown way they are tightening the strings of the ancestral bow zither and dusting off the dulcimer. In Kentucky, Virginia and the Carolinas, the mountainfolk are tuning up grandpappy's fiddle, and limbering up kneecaps and larynx.

THE impact of golf on the American culture has been viewed apprehensively from several angles. To begin with, there was a disruptive effect in domestic life. Males were indifferent to meal hours; the female was resentful till "mother joined the country club" and asserted herself.

AND he found them intensely interesting. When he left the asylum in which they were confined after six years on its medical staff they had, all of them, individually and collectively, not only his pity but his sympathetic affection. And the reader who follows his portrayal in this book of the life of the 3,000 will better understand them and their condition and will know a great deal more about insanity than before.

BROWNSVILLE, Texas, April 20. -- Raymond Sylvester Bengson, 27-year-old American geologist employed by a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, was robbed and murdered on a lonely road southwest of Matamoros, Mexico, some time late yesterday.

H.R.H.: Ananda Mahidol, Siam's 9-year-old King, who has said that he would rather play with toy trains than sit upon a throne, learned last week that at least one royal prerogative is pleasant. At his school at Lausanne, Switzerland, he was promoted without being required to take the usual examination.

Garden tours to penthouse terraces and backyard gardens in the city as well as to the larger displays to be found at well-known estates on Long Island have been arranged in behalf of the School Nature League. The first of these tours will take place May 15 and will include visits to city gardens.

The ability of Dr. Fell to solve mysteries, and incidentally to mystify any other detectives who happen to be working with him, has been amply demonstrated in Mr. Carr's other stories about this obese criminologist. It is no surprise, therefore, to find him, in this new story, actually a part of the Scotland Yard organization.

PRAGUE. -- Interesting details of the latest restrictions placed by Dr. Goebbels on the German press are published in the Neue Vorwaerts, the German Socialist newspaper published here. The following are printed as extracts from the regular instructions issued from time to time by the Propaganda Ministry to the press in Germany:

The "University in Exile" will open its first Summer session in July to supply the vacation graduate work which students and professors of this country found in German universities until these were subjected to Nazi restrictions.

The banking system of the country, having lately escaped with the aid of government-supplied capital from a period of unprecedented losses, finds itself in the midst of an era of profitless business. Stimulated by last week's renewed fall in money rates to low records, bankers have begun to consider what may be the consequences of a prolonged period of unemployed bank funds and unremunerative returns on such funds as can find employment.

PANAMA, R.P. -- The threat of Japan to invade the Panama hat industry has alarmed jobbers and retail dealers here, the exporters in Colombia and Ecuador and the native Indians of the latter two countries, who weave the famous hats that are not made in the country from which they take their name.

BATON ROUGE, La., April 20. -- A pledge that he will use his control of the election machinery in Louisiana to bring about honest elections was made by Senator Huey P. Long today as the Legislature finally passed the bill which gives to local boards of election supervisors power to name all election commissioners, alternate commissioners and watchers of election.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- Narrowing their "must" legislative list to six big bills, Democratic leaders in Congress today planned a drive for speed, which they hoped would let them end the session before August.

MOST of the writing about shooting is worse than merely bad. Many of the so-called classics of the field are turgid compositions whose artificiality is not in keeping with nature and the sport they describe. These sketches and stories by Nash Buckingham are refreshingly different.

BERLIN, April 20. -- Reliable quarters today asserted intense military air activity "is rapidly placing the German Army beyond dreamed-of dimensions" since the announcement of conscription a month ago.

Last week's incident of the hungry journalists en route to Geneva will probably not have any serious international consequences. It was natural that the British Prime Minister, after his arduous labors at Stresa, should desire a little peace and quiet with his evening meal on the train.

BERLIN, April 20. -- Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler's forty-sixth birthday was celebrated today in a military atmosphere that put the emphasis squarely on the leader's functions as commander-in-chief of Germany's armed forces.

Twice as many accidental deaths were reported in homes last year as in industrial establishments, it was asserted yesterday by R.F. Cavanaugh, superintendent of the engineering department of the Fidelity and Casualty Company of New York, who said that thousands of lives might have been saved and hundreds of thousands of injuries avoided if hazards that would not be tolerated in any well-supervised factory were removed from homes.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 19. -- Led by San Francisco doctors, the California Medical Association is in open revolt against the leadership of the American Medical Association on the issue of compulsory State health insurance.

CHICAGO, April 19. -- A brew of jittery rumors and gossip concerning seditious teaching in the educational institutions of Illinois was brought to the boiling point when Charles R. Walgreen, pharmaceutical magnate, withdrew his niece, Miss Lucille Norton, from her classes at the University of Chicago.

THE rather narrow, formal curriculum of the American high school has of late years been the subject of severe criticism. Today thirty representative public and private secondary schools, with the cooperation of 250 colleges and universities, are engaged in an eight-year experiment to transform it to meet the needs of the changed world.

SUPPLEMENTING broadcast reception, the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel has added equipment to supply 2,000 rooms with short-wave programs from foreign lands. Western Electric engineers making the installation point to the aerial as a unique feature.
A new series of lectures are being given in the Department of Education at the Art Institute. Several new subjects in the series of popular lectures for laymen are offered.

CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas, April 20. -- Business establishments of this city were closed from noon until 3 P.M. yesterday under a proclamation issued by Mayor Giles at the recommendation of Joe Simon, Commissioner of Streets and Parks, who is a Jew. Mr. Simon urged this action to permit the city's Christians to meditate upon the death on the Cross.

General upward revision of the tariff law, renewed attacks on the reciprocal trade policy and enactment of embargo provisions in the revised NIRA are ultimate objectives in protectionists' fight against Japanese competition, exporters and importers charged here yesterday.

THE historic windmill in Arles Provence, France, which inspired Alphonse Daudet to write his "Lettres de mon Moulin," has been rescued from ruin and decay and will be dedicated as a Daudet Museum in June. Edouard Herriot, former Prime Minister and an authority on the French author, will be the principal speaker.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- The Administration Social Security Bill, despite its triumphant passage in the House yesterday, will have to wait its turn in the Senate, according to indications today. The measure will be sent to the Senate Monday and will be referred to the Finance Committee.
ZION, Ill., April 20 (AP). -- Bands played, orators declaimed and the people gathered in the streets today, for the prophet Voliva had ended his twenty-eight-year "reign."
Last week Adolf Hitler and his Third Reich were forced from the offensive to the defensive on the diplomatic battlefield of Europe.

THESE readings were prepared as an Introduction for boys and girls to the romantic history of exploration and the magnificent struggles of men to unravel the geographical secrets of the world. As befits its subject, the book is constructed on a geographical rather than a chronological pattern. The first section deals with the attempts to reach the Far East by water, and begins with a picturesque account of Marco Polo's travels.

TROUBLE is indicated from the very beginning of this story, but what the nature of that trouble is to be does not appear until near the end. The "most beautiful lady" from whom the book takes its title is the wife of Victor Pechot, a Frenchman by birth and an American by adoption, who has settled down in Florence Italy, to enjoy a fortune accumulated in America.

AMONG the newly opened exhibitions, several may be counted upon to attract a good bit of public attention. There is the big Industrial Arts show (on until April 28) at the RCA Building, Rockefeller Center, about which Mr. Storey writes in today's Magazine Section.

SOFIA, April 11. -- American charitable and religious organizations are bringing a heartening measure of order out of squalor in Bulgaria and a new spirit and outlook to the youth of cities and remote villages. Children are learning the meaning of cleanliness and sportsmanship, and their elders the lessons of trades and industries.

ABROAD program of development to assist the scheduled airlines of the United States further to improve the safety and reliability of air transportation is now being drafted by the Bureau of Air Commerce, Eugene L. Vidal, director, said last week.

SHANGHAI. -- The experiment of appointing a health worker for every tiny hamlet in rural China is being tested by the National Health Administration, under the directorship of Dr. J. Heng Liu, and already remarkably encouraging results are being achieved, according to official reports.

A city-wide strike of 17,000 cleaners and dyers, affecting 20,000 tailor shops, has been set for Tuesday morning despite last-minute efforts by the city to avert the walkout, which is expected to throw additional thousands on relief rolls.
I was very much interested in the article by Louis La Coss published in THE TIMES last Sunday referring to the opening of traffic in the Missouri River.

WITH that exactness of performance as scheduled which characterizes so many of its undertakings and bears witness to thoroughness of organization to the last detail, Pan American sent its big Sikorsky clipper last week over the California-Hawaii leg of the 8,500-mile air route which it is preparing to the Orient.

The Abercrombie Fitch Company reported yesterday that the net profit of itself and subsidiaries in the year ended on Jan. 31 was $148,123 after allowances for Federal taxes and other charges had been made. This was equal, after annual dividend requirements on the 7 per cent preference stock on which there are accumulated unpaid dividends, to 31 cents a share on 71,800 no-par common shares.

WILDWOOD, N.J., April 20. -- Clarence (Spike) Fisher, Wildwood champion, and James Fraser of Seaview held two of the semi-final brackets in the Eastern States Easter golf championship at the Wildwood Golf Club today. The other two places were filled by Philadelphians, Lorman Kelley of Paxon Hollow and James J. Jennings of McCall Field.

In his recent speech before the American Academy of Political and Social Science, Professor Salvemini warned us not to confuse political liberty with economic liberty; that it was fallacious to call any intervention in economic life dictatorship or fascism, and hence that it would be wrong to speak of the policies of the present government here as a type of fascism.
ISTANBUL, April 20. -- After two days of discussion the International Women's Nationality and Equal Moral Standard Congress today passed resolutions demanding:

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- At the banquet of the American Society of Newspaper Editors tonight Frank H. Simonds, writer on international affairs, said that while a new war in Europe had not become inevitable, "no system of organized peace is possible under present economic conditions, and war still constitutes the sole means of escape for upward of two hundred millions of people dwelling in three great powers. "

On March 4, 1935, President Roosevelt transmitted a message to the Congress presenting the question squarely as to whether the United States should have an adequate merchant marine. This question, he stated, should be answered in the affirmative for three excellent reasons, as follows:

On last Wednesday the Council of the League of Nations adopted a resolution condemning the German action of March 16 in establishing conscription in preparation for the building of a larger army in defiance of the Treaty of Versailles and set up a Committee of Thirteen to decide on economic and financial measures which might be taken in the future against any nation which might "endanger peace by unilateral repudiation of its international obligations."

Unique among the forthcoming events for the benefit of philanthropy is the radio broadcast in behalf of the Society for the Relief of Destitute Children of Seamen on Thursday morning at 9:45 o'clock over Station WINS.

THIS is a true Farnol romance. You can place it neither historically, geographically nor chronologically, and the human fauna, while bearing the outward semblance of homo sapiens -- exaggeratedly glorious or repulsive, according to the allotted role -- is a creation proceeding directly from the author's undiluted fancy.

Eight members of the Gulino family of South Barre, Mass., arriving here for an Easter visit, were taken to Fordham Hospital, the Bronx, yesterday after their automobile and a taxicab had crashed at East Tremont and Third Avenues at 6:05 A.M.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- With 300,000 trees already removed in the Dutch elm disease area of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut and an equal number marked for early removal, government officials are waiting for the remaining elm trees to bear leaves to start a more determined drive.

DALLAS, April 19. -- "Hot oil," persistent foe of economic stability in Texas for years, came to the front among political issues in the Southwest this week when both Austin and Washington moved for a show-down on the all-important question of whether the oil industry shall operate under State or Federal supervision.

MOSCOW, April 20. -- The international situation is developing so favorably from the Soviet point of view that today the government organ, Izvestia, issued a warning to Germany against continuing to challenge the public opinion of the world.
