A definite business upturn in late Summer, following recessions extending into August, was predicted here yesterday by Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, in his monthly review of busines sent to the organization's 20,000 members throughout the country.

BERLIN, April 20. -- The administrative and judicial heads of the Province of Hanover, President Eggers and Judge Haasemann, have issued an appeal to parents, teachers and pastors to do something to check "moral laxity" among the youth in the district. The appeal declares that this moral laxity is greatest in the rural districts, where "a complete lack of control seems to have appeared."

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- The National Industrial Recovery Board today announced approval of the method of value determination and rules and regulations covering trade-in allowances for used and second-hand machinery for the printing equipment industry and trade.

BOSTON, April 20. -- Every Brave has his day, including George Herman Ruth, as Casey Stengel's ambitious Dodgers discovered to their sorrow today. The great man didn't hit a home run but his mighty bat delivered a single off Van Lingle Mungo that aided in breaking a 1-1 deadlock and the Braves went on to win later, 7 to 1.

Under the regional reorganization plan of the American Power Boat Association, by which it is hoped to coordinate the loose ends of boating under that official body, the recommendation has been made that the United States and Canada be divided into nine regions. They would be as follows:

DARRYL ZANUCK, dynamic production head of Twentieth Century Pictures, flew in from the West Coast last week to help celebrate the second anniversary of the film corporation and to attend the openings of two of its latest productions, "Les Miserables" at the Rivoli and "Cardinal Richelieu" at the Music Hall.

BERKELEY, Calif., April 20. -- The University of California's Bears revived the track and field glories of a dozen years ago with a smashing 77 1/2 to 53 1/2 victory today over Stanford's Indians, 1934 collegiate champions, as 15,000 fans cheered.
PHILADELPHIA, April 20. -- A glimpse of the earth as it would appear to a man on Mars was pictured today before the closing session of the annual meeting of the American Philosophical Society.

The follies of the New Dealers and their bloodless revolution were analyzed most happily in 1790 by Edmund Burke, in his "Reflections on the Revolution in France." These were the words of the great eighteenth century liberal:

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP). -- If conditions in the Spring wheat belt continue favorable, the Agriculture Department said today, the United States will have a wheat crop this year ample to take care of domestic needs. Moisture in that area was reported to have averaged "better than normal," in contrast to the dry, wind-swept Winter wheat section in Kansas.

A seven-alarm fire in a Brooklyn Heights waterfront warehouse although confined to a relatively small area, wrought havoc yesterday afternoon when acrid billows of smoke swept through an I.R.T. subway ventilating system and hundreds of passengers had to be carried or helped to the street in Manhattan and treated by ambulance doctors. The burning warehouse was at the foot of Clark Street, just below Columbia Heights.

THERE is so much that is real and beautiful in this book that it seems rather a pity to have it spoiled by a plot that is outworn. Mr. Hudson knows his Gascony and his Gascons, but Mr. Hudson has lost touch with the American mind.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 20. -- Yale routed the Brown lacrosse team, 20 to 9, today, Jack Warner starring on the attack with eight goals.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP). -- The directors of emergency conservation work announced today there would be sixty-eight Civilian Conservation Corps camps in New York for the fifth enlistment period which started April 1.

CHICAGO, April 20 (AP). -- The New York metropolitan area has the largest acreage of public parks and playgrounds in America, but Chicago leads the nation in park acres per capita, with Cleveland it close second.

PARIS. THERE "Comite des Saisons de Paris" (which may be freely but correctly translated "the Society for the Promotion of Paris Elegance") renders a signal service to the fashion observer by organizing the social calendar so that one knows just where to lay one's finger -- or rather, one's eye -- on the Famous Forty, at any given moment.

TURNING aside from his better known lithographs and oils, Eugene Fitsch has gone back stage at the Radio City Music Hall and recorded in pastel and drawings the color, the swift changes, the light and shadow, the shifting action and the swiftly changing scenic effects of that kaleidoscopic life.
VILLANOVA, Pa., April 20. -Providenee College continued its winning streak by [aking a free-hitting garne from the Nillanova nine today, 10 [o 3.

Rome, April 20. -- Germany's protest against the Geneva resolution was handed in writing this morning by German Ambassador von Hassell to Baron Pompeo Aloisi in the absence of Premier Mussolini and Fulvio Suvich, Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs, who are not in Rome today.

LONDON. THE Governor General of the Dominion of Canada holds one of the most distinguished posts in the British Empire, and many famous names appear on the roll of its former occupants. The appointment of John Buchan to fill the approaching vacancy, though coming as a surprise, has been acclaimed on all sides as one of the best selections that could possibly have been made.

NEW YORKERS, already familiar with the work of that distinguished Iowan, Grant Wood, are now provided with an opportunity to obtain a more rounded impression of his art. Mr. Wood's first local one-man show has been on through the week at the Ferargil Galleries, where it will remain current until May 5.

MR. LEACOCK is enormously conscientious about explaining jokes. His thoughful blue-prints should convince the most lemony curmudgeon that funny things are funny. Few surviving practitioners know as much as he does about the theory and technique of humor.

BERLIN April 20. -- The growing German demand for colonies, voiced by Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler in his conference with Sir John Simon. British Foreign Secretary, as part of his program for restoring Germany's complete equality, is beginning to focus renewed attention on the National Socialist racial doctrine in its implications for inhabitants of such colonies.

LONDON, April 20 (Canadian Press). -- Arsenal has increased its lead over Sunderland in the race for the championship of the English Soccer League to four points and only a remarkable collapse of the London club can bring about a reversal of the positions of the hard-battling teams.

PITTSBURGH, April 20. -Former Senator David A. Reed came home from Europe today with a modest coat of healthy tan and an unqualified prediction that his friend Herbert Hoover will not be a candidate for the Presidency next year.

LAST Fall, when Mr. Pratt's first book appeared, there was a distinct unusualness about his quality which suggested that perhaps he had added himself to American letters. It might, however, he only another of the buds which fail to flower, another single swallow too precipitately foretelling Summer; rash to pronounce snap judgments; wait and see.

DETROIT, April 20 (AP). -- The Indians, rated as the most dangerous pennant contenders in the American League, went fourteen innings today to turn back the Tigers, 2 to 1, in a brilliant pitchers' battle. Successive singles By Hughes, Vosmik and Averill in the fourteenth produced the winning run.

A HIGHLY ingenious idea for a brief dance season has been conceived by the magazine New Theatre, and is scheduled to be carried out under its auspices and for its benefit on May 3, 4 and 5 at the Park Theatre when three performances will be given exclusively by men.

Charges that the American Federation of Labor was hampering recovery to force enactment of the Wagner Labor Disputes Bill and other measures have been made in a statement issued by directors of the National Association of Manufacturers.
I have just run across a bit of information which, with the help of your readers, may lead to the solution of one of the world's oldest mysteries as to a racial origin.

Both the distance and the doubles championships of the New York Athletic Club were decided at the Travers Island traps of the Winged Foot organization yesterday. In the former event, the title was taken by F.A. Cauchois. Standing on the 22-yard line, he broke 95 out of 100 targets.

THAT is, means Mr. Brangwyn, the Paris of everybody who wants to see, to understand, to appreciate the whole of Paris, the Paris of the French. That is the Paris he tries to portray. But this is not, alas, the Paris of most travelers.
WASHINGTON, April 20. -- A business plan for "overcoming obstacles still standing in the way of recovery" will be formulated at the annual meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

THE experience of the Stage Relief Fund in "presenting" sixty benefits, mostly on Sunday nights, during the past three seasons probably is worthy of a Sunday morning reckoning. (The Stage Relief Fund does not, of course, actually present benefits.

SAN PEDRO, Calif., April 20. -- As part of the exercises of the combined arms of the American Navy to be conducted over 5,000,000 square miles of the Pacific Ocean this Spring, the Navy air force will conduct a massed circumnavigation of the Eastern Pacific by air.

Modernization of Argentina's banking system under laws recently adopted after an exhausive study of international systems revolves mainly around the establishment of a central bank controlled jointly by the government and private member banks.

TRENTON, N.J., April 20. -- Egbert Rosecrans of Blairstown, as associate counsel for Bruno Richard Hauptmann, filed appeal papers today with the Secretary of State and the clerk of the Court of Errors and Appeals. They contained 143 citations of alleged errors on which the defense asks a reversal of Hauptmann's conviction by a jury at Flemington and his sentence to death in the electric chair for the murder of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr.

The semi-annual commercial examinations of the State Chamber of Commerce for scholarships for the academic year 1935-36 in approved schools of business of collegiate grade will be held from May 6 to 17. The examinations lead to senior and junior credentials and the scholarships will be awarded to candidates whose preparation best fits them for a course of regular instruction but who lack the necessary financial means.

The Easter parade had a rehearsal yesterday. A warm Spring sun and mild weather crowded Fifth Avenue as well as other streets with promenaders, but the pomp and display were reserved for today's exhibition on Fifth and Park Avenues.
In 1895 Penn and Princeton gave something new to the sporting world -- a relay race. They liked it and tried it again the following year. And in 1895 the Penn Relay Carnival came into being.

Quite generally retailers reported a satisfactory increase in business during the last week of pre-Easter promotions, with stocks apparently quite ample to take care of consumer needs, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by the McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.

BALTIMORE, April 20. -- Chatterplay, Paul Mellon's 8-year-old chestnut gelding, thundered into the ranks of the great steeplechasers today by winning the thirty-sixth annual Grand National Point-to-Point, a three-mile race over timber, in the sensational time of 5 minutes 45 1-5 seconds.

TORONTO, Ont., April 20. -- Ontario's gold mines produced gold bullion to the value of $5,801,989 in March, an increase of $465,620 over the $5,336,369 reported for February. Ore milled was 567,816 tons, against 513,439 in February.

The most complete season of exploration in the Antarctic since the days of Scott was described yesterday by Harold June, who was the chief pilot and in charge of transportation for the last expedition of Admiral Richard E. Byrd. June has just returned to the United States from New Zealand to take part in winding up the affairs of the expedition.
WHILE thousands of other would-be teachers knock vainly at the public school doors, qualified teachers of commercial subjects are slipping easily in. So reports from several States indicate.

The committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange has received applications for permanent registration under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 from the following listed companies: Framerican Industrial Development Corporation, Zenith Radio Corporation, Schulte Retail Stores Corporation, Kresge Department Stores, Inc., Detroit Edison Company, A.G. Spalding Bros., Industrial Rayon Corporation, Metropolitan Edison Company and Electric Boat Company.

ROME, April 20. -- What aviation officials said was the "biggest annual recruiting of aviators ever held in the world" began today as a flood of applications poured into the Air Ministry for 1,300 pilots' posts and 4,750 jobs for specialist mechanics.
BEDFORD, N.Y., April 20. -- Two stakes were completed today in the eighth annual Spring meeting of the Southern New York Field Trial Club on the Lewis estate.

Textile High School, defending city P.S.A.L. baseball champion, won its first game of the season in the Lower Manhattan-Richmond Division yesterday, defeating Port Richmond, 17-1, at Sisco Park, Port Richmond, S.I. Ray Romersa, Textile right-hander, limited the losers to four hits.

LONDON, says the cable, is expecting one of the busiest of Easter weeks, all the managements hoping for friendliness from the hordes of jubilee visitors. Her theatrical schedule runs something like this:

PRINCETON, N.J., April 20. -- Adoption of the preferential system of balloting for the election of alumni trustees of Princeton University was announced today by Laurence G. Payson, '16, of New York City, chairman of the Graduate Council, the executive body of Princeton Alumni.

The reports of increases in sales and of greater production in many parts of the country, and of higher income tax returns based on larger profits, all seem paradoxical when taken with the distressing reports of increased applications for home and work relief. If sales and production increase, why more unemployment?
IN April the flood of berries sets toward New York. To the city dealer "berry" does not mean raspberry or blueberry or currant -- it means "strawberry."

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- Contracts involving a large part of the $37,000,000 lent and granted Louisiana for public works will be considered automatically canceled by the government if the twenty-seven bills passed by the Louisiana Legislature this week contain the provisions Public Works Administration officials understand they do.
Favored by mild weather toward the close of the week, pre-Easter shopping in the metropolitan area ended in a burst of activity.

A group of South Americans and Spanish-Americans residing in New York have organized the Hispanic Art Centre, a social and cultural organization, in which North Americans will be invited to membership. The organization plans eventually to erect a building that will house a theatre, ballroom, library, a Spanish restaurant and a bureau of information.

IN the death of Edwin Arlington Robinson a major poet is lost to the world. Although not a really prolific writer. Mr. Robinson nevertheless produced in a little over three decades a sufficient body of verse to be collected in 1929 into a volume of 1,000 pages.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 20. -- The Naval Academy nine bowed to William and Mary, 9 to 8, today. Hitting was plentiful and each team used three pitchers.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- March factory sales of automobiles manufactured in the United States amounted to 429,830 vehicles, the largest monthly output since April, 1930, when 444,024 units were constructed, the Department of Commerce monthly survey said today.

ATLANTA, April 19. -- Governor Talmadge's charge that President Roosevelt is "a radical in extreme form" and his intimation that because of the President's physical condition he is unable to keep in touch with the changing mood of the people created a reaction in Georgia which was mirrored in resolutions passed today by the Georgia Federation of Labor, in Augusta.
AMHERST, Mass., April 20. -- Williams upset Massachusetts State, 3 to 1, in a well-played game on Alumni Field today as both teams opened their regular schedules.
GLASGOW, April 20 (Canadian Press). -- Supreme in Scottish soccer, the Glasgow Rangers again are holders of the Scottish Cup and champions of the league.
GENEVA, April 20. -- In post-war Europe, conference has followed conference, and all that each results in is still another conference.

WITH the national pathway toward normal expansion of motor car usage cleared of depression obstacles, the world market and the future possibilities of it again are occupying the attention of the minds that map the course ahead.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- Donald R. Richberg today accused the Brookings Institution of playing politics in causing the publication of advance excerpts from its study of the NRA, which is severely criticized and alleged to have retarded recovery.

The placid waters of the Harlem Ship Canal were violently disturbed twice yesterday as Bill Nash and Al Barabas rifled home-run balls over the Baker Field fence, the opening and closing shots in a drive that gave Columbia a 10 -- 7 Eastern Intercollegiate League victory over the Harvard nine.

Lights are burning until late hours again in Wall Street, as lawyers, accountants and investment banking firms struggle with the mounting tide of new bond financing. The pressure on some of the firms that are active in this field has been so great that increases in staffs appear unavoidable if the movement continues to grow.

AS thoroughly English as a novel well could be, Miss Cambridge's new book is a not very eventful story of two girls who were brought up together in the same Cotswold village. Susan's father was a gentleman recluse; Joanna was the vicar's daughter.

The listed bond market fluctuated yesterday within narrow limits, with the general trend toward slightly higher levels. Trading was quiet despite the holiday the day before, amounting to $6,177,700, compared with $6,249,200 on the previous Saturday.

UNDER Arturo Toscanini, the Philharmonic-Symphony will give a post-season concert on April 29 at the Metropolitan Theatre in Providence, R.I. The program will consist of Rossini's overture to "L'Italiana in Algeri," Brahms's Fourth symphony, the Preludes to Acts I and III of Wagner's "Lohengrin," Strauss's "Don Juan" and the overture to Verdi's "I Vespri Siciliani."

SCROLLS recently awarded by the Women's National Radio Committee singled out four programs as the best in their class on the air. Showmen who missed citations naturally wonder why. Some of them have been winning popularity polls for many weeks; some have topped the nation-wide surveys.

MEMBERS of the foreign colony of Bangkok, Siam, are the leading characters in this novel of mystery, intrigue and marital troubles, but the focal centre of the story is the so-called Emerald Buddha which stands in one of the city's great temples.

PURSUING the same general plan adopted in their previous volume on Matisse, these authors provide a comprehensive, detailed analysis of the paintings by another famous Frenchman, Renoir. One section of this book deals with the development of Renoir's form, beginning with the earliest work, in the Sixties, and continuing through to the end.

Scrapping of the interdepartmental agreement under which foreign trade service for American exporters and importers has been carried on by the Departments of State and Commerce since July, 1933, is urged in a special report offered for approval this week by eighty-two foreign trade groups affiliated with the National Federation of Foreign Trade Associations.

OMAHA, April 19. -- Notwithstanding the continuance of drought over the wheat lands, confirmed by the dust storms and the April 1 crop report, the corn belt section of the Middle West is not alarmed about its own weather prospects. For it the drought was broken by the Fall and Spring rains, well distributed over most of the corn-growing territory and from 90 per cent of normal to well above the average for the season.

Mrs. Theodore Griggs and Miss Mary Griggs entertained with a dinner in the roof garden of the St. Regis last night for Miss Mary Moncrieffe Livingston and Spencer Eddy Jr., who will be married on April 30. The other guests included:

Once again daylight-saving time approaches, the Merchants Association of New York announced yesterday. It will go generally into effect next Sunday at 2 A.M., when clocks will be advanced one hour. The hour of lost sleep will be recovered Sept. 29.

PHILADELPHIA, April 20. -- Dr. Albert Einstein and Sir John Ambrose Fleming have been selected by the Franklin Institute as this year's recipients of the Franklin Medal, the highest scientific honor bestowed by a Philadelphia organization.

IN an open letter to Thomas Coward of Coward-McCann, Julius King publicity director of Chautauqua Institution, complains that Thomas Duncan's novel, "O, Chautauqua," is "causing a confusion in the public mind and in the minds of the various literary critics who are reviewing it." Mr. King then gives the following facts about Chautauqua:

The Dramatic Society of City College will present "Spin the Bottle," an original musical review, as its varsity show this Thursday, Friday and Saturday evenings in the auditorium of the School of Business, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue.
CHICAGO, April 20 (AP). -- The Cubs sent over a run in the tenth inning today to defeat Cincinnati, 4 to 3, and even the current series.

GOLD had been found along Halfaday Creek, away up in the Canadian Yukon, only three or four miles from the Alaska boundary, and because it was so far away from civilization and so inaccessible it provided an ideal retreat for men "wanted" on either side of the line. And so the outlaws came drifting in.

PARIS, April 19. -- As so often happens in France, where things are done in easy-going fashion until an emergency comes, there has been fairly steady neglect of the air force and of air defense for many years, and now there is a sudden outburst of effort in the hope, by the end of this year, to have an air force "equal to any other."

BERLIN, April 20. -- Adolf Hitler, celebrating his forty-sixth birthday, today told thirteen nations represented on the League of Nations Council that they had no right to "set themselves up as judges of Germany."

SHANGHAI. -- Since 1912 the number of pupils in the grade schools of China has increased from a meager 2,793,633 to a total of 11,667,888, according to a statement made at Nanking by the chancellor of the National Central University, Dr. Lo Chia-lun.

The newly formed Citizens Committee for Survey and Planning has issued a general invitation to the musical public to attend a meeting for formal organization in the first week of May at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.

Now that the national senior fencing championship has been decided once more and the talented Miss Helene Mayer has returned to the West Coast with the title safely hers for the second successive time, the next important event on the fencing calendar is the seventh annual championship of the Intercollegiate Women's Fencing Association.

ST. LOUIS, April 20 (AP). -- Celebrating their return to activity after three days of enforced idleness, the Browns hit George Earnshaw for four runs in the sixth today, then went on to take a 9-to-4 victory from the White Sox.
DUBLIN, April 20 (AP). -- As much as they would like to see some Irishman get the credit, authorities here declared today that Columbus's claim to fame by discovering America still stood.

Of all books on Mexico, Terry's illustrious and incomparable guide best deserves to be called indispensable. Other guides come and other guides go; Terry -- secure in its impregnability as the greatest of all compilations of guide-book material about Mexico in English -- goes on triumphantly forever.

STRANGE, fragile and eerie, "Forever" wakens dim echoes of Maeterlinck and "The Brushwood Boy." It Is Mildred Cram's fancy that a soul about to be born wanders the earth beforehand, preparing itself for a known destiny.

On page 46 of "The Conquest of the North Pole," by J. Gordon Hayes, we read that the three authorities which prove that Peary did not reach the North Pole are, in order of worth: The Congressional Record; Peary's book "The North Pole"; and Dr. Cook's book "My Attainment of the Pole."

TODAY the political structure of Europe is more than ever dependent on the foreign policy of Nazi Germany. Whatever follows the tense and anxious series of negotiations now in progress, from the beginning they have signified just one thing: Europe has outlived and outgrown the elaborate compartments marked off by the architects of Versailles.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- The President moved vigorously this week against his political enemies, a dawdling Congress and critics of his policy. Gone -- at least temporarily -- was the laissez faire attitude of the past two months, and, whatever the Republicans say at their regional meetings, their shafts will be launched at an advancing foe, not at walls behind which it has retreated.

In the opinion of Frederick C. Lincoln, naturalist of the United States Bureau of Biological Survey, makers of new "homes" for migratory waterfowl do not give sufficient consideration to the birds' own idea of where home is.

With generally better weather in most sections of the country last week, retail merchants in many of the twelve Federal Reserve districts reported an improvement in sales. The unseasonably cold weather, however, in the last three weeks kept the pre-Easter turnover lower than expected, and in most areas April sales are said to be running below those in the corresponding period last year.

Visibly indignant, Police Commissioner Valentine stated yesterday that he had ordered a departmental investigation into newspaper reports that some of the twenty-six New York City policemen testifying at the trial of Dutch Schultz in Syracuse had appeared to be on friendly terms with the former beer runner.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19. -- Among numerous reports which in dicate the continued upward trend of business in the Third Federal Reserve District is a marked improvement in life insurance, not only in the larger number of new policies written but also in the declines in lapses and surrenders of policies.

THE Easter parade is the bouquet of Spring fashion. In cities and hamlets women don their newest and prettiest to join in it. As each one walks down the Avenue, Fifth or Michigan, or just Main Street, she has an inner conviction that she is looking her best, that in the gayety of her attire she is reflecting the mode -- in other words, Paris as translated in terms of New York.

The cotton-textile industry is looking forward to the promotion of National Cotton Week, starting on May 7, to recapture a portion of the business lost in the dismal months since the start of the year, according to comment by executives here yesterday.
Professor SWANN of the Bartol Research Foundations aligns himself with the small minority of scientists who hold that the universe may after all turn out to be a durable industry, so to speak.

MIAMI. -- More than 1,000 delegates, representing many sections of the United States, Canada and Mexico, are expected to visit Miami for the convention on June 16, 17 and 18 of the Civitan International Club, largest of the group gatherings to feature the Spring and Summer seasons here.

Despite an Easter selling period that has been substantially under expectations, retailers look forward with considerable confidence to a brisk Summer season to be launched during the first week in May.

NEWARK, N.J., April 20. -- Kemp Wicker, youthful Newark southpaw, weakened after pitching shut-out ball for six innings today and the Bears lost the final game of their series with the Rochester Red Wings, 4 to 2. Each team won two games of the series.

Emotions are governed largely by time and place. The great wave of anti-war sentiment which is sweeping our nation is a mass movement of individual emotion. Speakers who dwell at length on the horrors and cost and futility of war captivate their audiences. The flag is furled as a symbol of benevolence.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 20. -- The Manhattan varsity and junior varsity crews gave Harvard's junior and third varsity eights very little competition in informal races on the Charles River today.

BALTIMORE, April 20 (AP). -- In a game marked by a free-for-all fight in the ninth, Montreal made it three out of four in the series with Baltimore today, defeating the Orioles, 7 to 4. The Oriole runs came on pairs of homers by both Barton and Puccinelli.

THERE is a growing sentiment -- it is still too inchoate to be termed a movement -- among certain members of Congress with advanced social views and a willingness to break with tradition, in favor of drastic change in our form of government to facilitate nation-wide reforms frequently blocked by the very nature of our confederation.

All admirers of the immortal Rabelais -- scholars and laymen -- will want to have this new edition of W.F. Smith's monumental work. Called "the greatest English Rabelaisian scholar of his day," he saw the first publication of his work in 1892 and then continued to "annotate and expand."

CONGRESS plans to do something about the great American game of traffic-ticket fixing, it is reported by William Ullman, automobile correspondent. Because politics and politicians occupy so large a place in the Washington scene, the settling of traffic violation cases out of court -- in favor of the defendants -- is especially rampant in the capital.

ONEIDA, Wis. -- Leaderless for the first time in 600 years, the Turtle Clan of the Oneida Indians faces an unguided future, since the sons of the last chief, Frank Cornelius, who died recently, have white blood. Cornelius was a grandson of Daniel Bread, who as head chief of the tribe, led the Oneidas from New York State to Wisconsin a century ago.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- Amid balmy weather that ended weeks of rain and cold, the capital prepared today for an Eastertide that would see dignitaries, from the President down, attending church services.

Prominent educators, social work executives, members of the Big Brother and Big Sister organizations and others interested in juvenile delinquency problems are expected to attend the annual meeting of the Jewish Board of Guardians on Thursday, May 2, in the home of Adolph Lewisohn, 881 Fifth Avenue, it was announced yesterday.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 21 (AP). -- A six-run burst in the third inning enabled Buffalo to score a 10-to-5 victory over Syracuse in their series opener today.

Two more swordsmen from the intercollegiate ranks, which have produced this country's leading fencers, are ready to bid for national recognition as a result of their performances yesterday in the semi-finals of the national individual foils championship on the strips of the New York Athletic Club.

Chuck Tabor, driving a Tabor Special, annexed the twenty-lap trophy event which featured the indoor midget auto races at the New York Coliseum yesterday. Tabor went ahead on the fourteenth lap to lead Pete Canfield across the finish line. Ed Zimmerman placed third.

BERLIN, April 21 (London Times Dispatch) -- This year for the first time in many centuries thousands of Germans have kept the Eastertide as a pagan festival. The word "Ostermond" (Easter month) was used significantly in place of April in the congratulatory address accompanying the Storm Troopers' birthday gift of fighting planes to Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler.

Veronica Mascheroni, an investor, bought the three-story dwelling on a lot 15 by 99 feet at 627 West 142d Street for all cash from the estate of Henry F. Tiernan for remodeling into small apartments. Charles Weiburg was the broker, the buyer being represented by Samuel R. Kurzman, attorney.

Having nothing really better to do locally, the eyes of the theatre may just as well turn this evening to the banks of the Monongahela and Allegheny Rivers. That's Pittsburgh, and that is where Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne will start their careers in "The Taming of the Shrew."

PITTSBURGH, April 21. -- Production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 47 per cent of capacity, unchanged from the two preceding weeks, and no indications were seen that the rate would be lower this week.
WASHINGTON, April 21. -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress last week are give in the following tabulation:

CHICAGO, April 21. -- Inflation of currencies, uncertainty as to the size of this year's wheat crop in the United States and disposition of Western Canada's surplus from the 1934 crop are among the most important factors confronting the wheat trade in this country and Canada.
MOSCOW, April 21. -- The halt in the Franco-Soviet negotiations for a mutual assistance pact is based on two major points, according to informed circles here tonight.

Business leasing contracts announced over the week-end included one for 15,000 square feet in the Sixty Wall Tower Building at 70 Pine Street to Joseph D. Massoletti, restaurateur. The lessee will spend $50,000 equipping the place, which will have a cafe and bar.

The largest issue of securities thus far registered under the Securities Act of 1933 will be placed on the market today with the offering of $73,000,000 of Southern California Edison Company, Ltd., 3 3/4 per cent refunding mortgage bonds due in 1960 by a nation-wide banking syndicate headed by the First Boston Corporation.

In a request program that repeated outstanding numbers from a benefit concert given earlier in the season, the Workmen's Circle Chorus, Lazar Weiner, conductor, earned the hearty applause of a large audience in the Town Hall yesterday afternoon.

LONDON, April 20. -- The sharp fall in money rates in New York was noted with interest here, although internationally this pronounced easing-up is of little consequence. The fall in rates, while it may be due merely to an excessive supply of funds, also could be connected with the Treasury's huge debt refunding, which lies ahead, according to observers here.

NEW ORLEANS, April 21. -- Trading in the cotton contract market here was rather more moderate than usual last week. Uncertainty as to future moves in Washington and the impending long Easter holidays slackened business and induced evening-up and liquidation of commitments.

At last progress has barricaded Pier 45, at the foot of Tenth Street. For two leisurely years the long concrete floor protruding into the North River has been accessible to the neighborhood idlers, either through a hole in the fence or through gates that finally succumbed to persistent knocking.
CLEVELAND, April 21 (AP). -- Fifteen passengers on a Cleveland railway bus turned on an armed robber early today, beat him up and then put him and a companion in the hands of the police.

CHICAGO, April 21. -- Business in all lines in this territory was large last week, although more spotted than usual. Unfavorable weather restricted Easter buying, but in the aggregate trade was reported to be not more than a shade less than it was a year ago in women's and men's apparel, including hosiery, shoes and hats.
WASHINGTON, April 21. -- The text of the Treasury's announcement for refunding First Liberty bonds follows:

ATLANTA, Ga., April 21 (AP). -- Senator Huey P. Long threatened today "another Boston tea party" if Louisiana is deprived of Federal relief funds. He paused briefly on his way back to Washington, where, he has announced, he will denounce Secretary Ickes on the Senate floor tomorrow.

College professors as experts in their special fields are destined to become increasingly important in national, and professional life, but like other experts, they must be kept in their place, according to the annual review of legal education made public yesterday by the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching.
Cardinal Hayes was the celebrant of Pontifical Easter Mass yesterday morning in St. Patrick Cathedral, and at its conclusion he imparted the papal benediction upon a congregation of about 7,000.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 21 -- A leader of the Progressive Miners Union was slain and eight other men were wounded late today in a clash between rival mine factions in the heart of Springfield.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 21. -- Easter dawn services marked the special observances today in several sections of Westchester County.
ST. LOUIS, April 21 (AP). -- The White Sox evened their series with the Browns today, winning in ten innings, 6 to 5, before an Easter crowd of 9,000.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 21. -- "I shouldn't think women would want to resemble men," said Lady Astor, addressing a meeting of the International Alliance of Women for Suffrage and Equal Citizenship here tonight, "for the more we look at men the less we want to look like them.

NANKING, China, April 21. -- An estimated 12,000,000 persons are suffering from drought-induced famine conditions in eight provinces of China and hundreds of thousands have been reduced to eating the bark of trees, roots and even clay, relief workers disclosed today.

Hailing Jesus as a "Jew immortal," the Rev. Dr. Stephen S. Wise, at the service of the Free Synagogue in Carnegie Hall yesterday morning, accused the Christian world of having ignored His teachings, thereby "crucifying the Jewish people for 1,900 years."

With Pope Pius XI singing the Pater Noster, the first pontifical solemn high mass ever to be broadcast in this country from St. Peter's Basilica, in Rome, was heard clearly here yesterday over the networks of the Columbia System and the National Broadcasting Company.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP). -- Stringent action to prevent employes of the Securities Commission from making money through the special information they get officially has been taken by Chairman Joseph P. Kennedy.

Formal offering will be made of a new issue of $1,000,000 city of Providence (R.I.) 1 3/4 per cent emergency unemployment-relief bonds by a syndicate composed of Lazard Freres Co., Inc.; the First Michigan Corporation, Hornblower Weeks, Starkweather Co., Inc., and Lobdell Co.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., April 21. -- Egbert Moxham Jr., in Stingaree II, captured Class B dinghy sailing honors on Manhasset Bay today, beating Ted Clark's Eskimo III by a single point.

NEW HAVEN, April 19. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices this week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 81.5, which compares with 81.7 the week before, 81 two weeks before, 80.6 three weeks before and 81 four weeks before.

The division of economics and history of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace will hold a general conference on the economic, industrial, political and social relations between the United States and Canada in the week of June 17-22 at St. Lawrence University, Canton, N.Y.

CHICAGO, April 21 (AP). -- Stemming a Chicago rally with the season's first triple play in the eleventh, after the Cubs had sent the game into extra innings by scoring two runs in the ninth, the hustling Reds batted across four runs in the twelfth today to win, 8 to 4.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21. -- The Giants wasted what appeared to be a commanding lead early in their skirmish with the Philies at Baker Bowl today, dropped a decision to the umpires on a disputed strike of vital import, lost a race against time and the Pennsylvania Sabbath law, and wound up with a tie.

SEVILLE, April 21. -- Seville concluded her Holy Week processions today with a high mass attended by as many Americans and other foreign visitors as could crowd into the vast cathedral that contains the tomb of Columbus and also is distinguished architecturally by its belfry.

The New York Spring Horse Show will open the season this afternoon at the Riding Club with 500 entries ready for the three-day exhibition. The opening session will be devoted almost exclusively to children's classes, with the adults commanding the ring for the remaining two days.

CHICAGO, April 21. -- Oats were on sale last week on the Board of Trade on all bulges, enabling shorts to get in on their contracts and giving processors an opportunity to obtain supplies at a reasonable figure. Speculative trade as a whole is inclined to go slow, because every bulge brings pressure of Argentine oats.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, April 21 (AP). -- Severe fighting between the Paraguayan and Bolivian armies north of Villa Montes, which raged during Holy Week, was climaxed on Easter Sunday with one of the worst engagements of the war, severe engagements taking place at six sectors along a 120-mile front.

" COIN" HARVEY, I believe, has built himself a pyramid with a copy of the book explaining his singular monetary theory buried in it. One can visualize the astonishment of the violators of tombs in the year 3000 A.D., when they come upon pictures of men riding bicycles with one strong wheel labeled "gold" and one weak, wabbly wheel labeled "silver."

BERLIN, April 20. -- The export surplus for March was 12,000,000 marks, which, in part, is attributable to seasonal influences, the principal factor being a large increase in exports, such as occurred in March, 1933. There were appreciable gains in exports of steel, textiles and chemicals and considerable increases in exports of machines, paper and electrical equipment.

LONDON (By Mail). -- There was an amiable Anglo-American discussion on sports and much was said on both sides. One of the English speakers said that, population considered, more fellows played more games over here than Americans did in America on the American plan.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 21. -- Easter was marked by an unusual amount off entertaining, both at the Homestead and throughout the valley.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- An emergency conference of representatives of all labor unions to consider legislative strategy in behalf of the Wagner-Connery Labor Disputes Bill was called today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, to meet here on April 29.

VATICAN CITY, April 21. -- The Roman Catholic world made St. Peter's Basilica the focal point of all symbolic religious interest today as Pope Pius appeared before his Roman flock to impart a solemn Easter Sunday benediction.

The supreme crime against life "is when a man by sensual living destroys or allows to decay that element out of which the universe is seeking to develop lasting beauty," the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, pastor of the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue at Twenty-ninth Street, said in his sermon yesterday morning.

VATICAN CITY, April 21. -- Easter celebrations, which are a festive tradition of Roman life, assumed particular luster this year through the resumption by the Pope of the custom of blessing the people crowded in St. Peter's Square as he sat in the sedia gestatoria in a balcony of the basilica.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- With the announcement of an offering of 20-25-year 2 7/8 per cent bonds and of 5-year 1 5/8 per cent notes in exchange for $1,933,000,000 in outstanding First Liberty Bonds, Secretary Morgenthau took the next to the last step today in the retirement of securities issued during the World War.

Railroads, rapid transit lines, ferry services and other transportation agencies linking the city with outside communities carried 274,020,847 travelers in 1934, surpassing by 408,706 the total of 273,612,141 attained in 1933, according to a compilation made public yesterday by the Transit Commission.

A variety of exhibitions numbering well in excess of a score will open in local galleries this week or have opened during the week-end. Sculpture, paintings in oil and water-color, pastels, prints and photography are included. Swiss, French, Irish and American artists are represented.

A mystery romance that is the work of three well-known authors is announced for publication on May 10 by Bobbs-Merrill. The novel is titled "The Alleged Great Aunt." Henry Mitchell Webster planned the story and began it, and Margaret Ayer Barnes, Pulitzer Prize winner, and her sister, Janet Ayer Fairbank, collaborated in completing it.

The Electric Bond and Share Company reports net income of $9,224,857 for the twelve months ended on March 31, equal, after preferred dividends, to 15 cents a share on 5,267,147 common shares, compared with $10,507,025, or 39 cents a share, for the preceding twelve months.

TAIHOIKU, Formosa, Monday, April 22. -- Long rows of injured persons lying on mats along the roadside crying in pain for medical attention were seen today by a Rengo (Japanese) News Agency reporter who entered the centre of Formosa's earthquake zone.

MOSCOW, April 21. -- A new system has been introduced in many Soviet plants to counteract the worst faults of Russian industry, the poor and uneven quality of the products and the spoilage of material, it was announced today by the Commissariat for Heavy Industry.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $7,558,538,480. They consist of Treasury bonds, consols, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

I have just returned from an eight-month sojourn in the United States, my third visit to that country. During this stay, as in previous visits, I have experienced everywhere the dismay caused by the lack of information concerning South America, its civilzation and its culture.

CHICAGO, April 21. -- The top price for choice steers here last week was $15.50 a hundredweight, the highest since March, 1930, and as high as it has been in fifteen years. The best price for a full carload for the week was $4,235, comparded with $2,185 a year ago.

MOSCOW, April 21. -- The Communist parties of ten European countries joined today in an appeal to the working classes for demonstrations against the German Nazis and for a pledge of aid to the Soviet Union in case it should be attacked.
STOCKHOLM, April 21. -- The Swedish Government appears far from pleased with Denmark's decision not to vote on the Geneva resolution censuring Germany last week.

BOSTON, April 21. -- George Herman Ruth hit a home run in the first inning today and gave 20,000 fans the big thrill they came to get. With that detail happily taken care of, Casey Stengel's Dodgers went about the business of winning the contest from the Braves, 8 to 1, without hitting any homers.

DETROIT, April 21 (AP). -- Marvin Owen's sizzling grounder to short- scoring Charley Gehringer from third, ended a thirteen-inning game between the Tigers and Indians today, with Detroit on the long end of a 3 to 2 score.

HOLLYWOOD, April 21 (AP). -- Mae West tonight disposed of the story of her reported marriage, twenty-four years ago, to a Brooklyn actor named Frank Wallace, with the typically terse and unequivocal statement:

Former Supreme Court Justice Jeremiah T. Mahoney made formal announcement yesterday of his candidacy for the Tammany leadership of the Fifteenth Assembly District against former Park Commissioner John E. Sheehy, the present leader.

The cotton market here last week was subjected to conflicting influences which held prices within narrow limits. The controversy over certain phases of the AAA program, especially the processing tax, made for uncertainty regarding prices.
Major earthquakes of the twentieth century include the following:

CHICAGO, April 21. -- Easier markets for grains and cottenseed oil and lower prices for hogs depressed lard futures at times last week on the Board of Trade, but good buying developed on the breaks, bringing fair rallies. Packers were credited with hedging sales against their output of lard, while warehouse interests were good buyers of cash and futures of lard on declines.

Modern education was assailed as producing a "dishonest" people yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Ralph C. Hutchison, president of Washington and Jefferson College, Washington, Pa. He preached in the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street.

THOMAS JESSE JONES, the educational director of the Phelps Stokes Fund, who has spent years in social, educational and religious work in America, Africa and Asia, says that the "missionary" is increasingly devoting his services to the "basic realities of in " dividual, community and spiritual "life."

Steel works operations rose another point to 46 per cent last week, according to the magazine Steel. The gain was attributed to an increase in moderate-sized miscellaneous orders with no bulge in any particular consumer classification.

PITTSBURGH, April 21 (AP). -- An Easter crowd of 28,000 saw the world's champion St. Louis Cardinals defeat the Pirates today, 6 to 1. The triumph gave the Cards two victories in the three-game series and thrilled the biggest crowd at a game here since 1929.

PARIS, April 21. -- Germany's hinted desire to talk things over, which is being read into yesterday's note of protest against the League of Nations Council's reproof for having acted without talking, and Russia's refusal after much talk to accept the French view now, when their proposed mutual assistance pact should function, have created a situation that may mark the turning point in the complicated European situation.

Several associations will pay tribute to Shakespeare tomorrow on the occasion of his birthday. The largest memorial will be held in the afternoon, beginning at 2 o'clock, at the Central Park statue of the poet and will be under the auspices of the Roerich Shakespeare Association and the National Shakespeare Federation.

" There are judges in Berlin" was said years ago. Today it would seem as if the German Government would tolerate none elsewhere. It refuses to be judged, declaring to the member nations of the League Council that none of them have any power to pass upon the actions or policies of the Reich.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- Voicing opposition to Congressional approval of proposed amendments to the Agricultural Adjustment Administration Act, the American Liberty League said today that agriculture, industry and the consuming population have already suffered from too much "regimentation."

Ten women and twenty-one men-were arrested by the police in raids at 1 A.M. yesterday on three apartments in the building at 124 West Seventy-second Street. Assistant District Attorney William Goldman, in charge of District Attorney William C. Dodge's vice inquiry, who participated in the raids, said the men were arrested on vagrancy charges in line with a new policy in vice cases and would be prosecuted.

With most stores well-stocked with merchandise for pre-Easter sales activities, the volume of orders received last week in the wholesale markets here was comparatively light. There was some buying by retailers completing preparations for post-Easter sales events and cotton wearing apparel was in fair demand for promotions later in the season.

TOKYO, April 21 (AP). -- Roads to the city of Taichu were blocked today by processions of improvised stretchers and crude litters bearing the injured in Formosa's earthquake to places where medical attention would be available.

PRESCOTT, Ariz., April 21. -- In an address before a large Easter audience assembled this afternoon outside Yavapai County's Court House, Mayor La Guardia declared it was his hope to improve tenement conditions in New York City.

Firmer prices were the rule in last week's four-day trading in commodity futures, and the volume of business was moderately large for the period. Sugar futures advanced into the highest ground for the year and broke records of seven years' standing.

BERLIN, April 20. -- Business optimism was maintained this week by a flood of increases in corporation dividends, the favorable report of the Dresdner Bank and the prospects of armament orders. The continued delay in issuing the budget, however, caused concern.

In the appendix of the Carnegie Foundation's Annual Review of Legal Education, published today, are tables giving the numbers of lawyers and inhabitants of the United States since 1850 and the lawyers by population and State since 1910. Many readers will scan these figures with interest.

Along the coast from Atlantic City to Jones Beach State Park the popular waterfront resorts attracted almost 1,000,000 persons to their traditional Easter Sunday parades yesterday. Men, women and children, displaying or observing what the well-dressed person should wear, promenaded the walks.

At a meeting of the Administrative Committee of the Zionist Organization of America yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Astor representatives of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist organization, voted to join with the men's organization in presenting a united slate of candidates to be elected as delegates to the Zionist Congress to be held in Europe next August.

DETROIT, April 21 (AP). -- Bishop Michael J. Gallagher of Detroit threw the full authority of his jurisdiction today behind the radio addresses of Father Coughlin. The Bishop spoke in Father Coughlin's regular Sunday afternoon broadcast, the last of his regular Winter program.

New York City will have a new repertory theatre next Fall if plans being arranged by Elmer Rice and others go through. The scheme will at least reach the incorporation stage today, when papers will be filed in Albany on behalf of the Theatre Alliance, a cooperative organization with temporary headquarters at the Belasco Theatre.

Easter sunrise services were attended by large groups of worshipers at several places in the city yesterday. A crowd of 2,000 men and women attended a service on the Columbia University campus, while nearly 2,000 men, most of them unemployed, joined in a service in front of the Salvation Army's lodge at 40 Corlears Street.

Quiet conditions prevailed in the foreign exchange market last week. Business was in small volume and the daily range of rates limited to narrow lines. The dullness was ascribed to the absence of pressure from Europe's political and financial problems which had hitherto provoked erratic changes and volume turnover, also to the observance of Holy Week in the foreign capitals.

Maternity care is among the service offered by the recent New York plan for hospitalization on the basis of advance payments of 3 cents a day, David H. McAlpin Pyle, president of the United Hospital Fund, made known last night in a symposium broadcast from radio station WOR.

FREEPORT, L.I., April 21. -- Its high-powered passing attack checked by a heavier, although less organized combination, the Bank of Montreal Rugby football team dropped a 5-3 decision to an all-star fifteen, composed of metropolitan players, at the Freeport Municipal Stadium today.

ALBANY, April 21 (AP). -- The status of more than 1,000 New York State civil service employes whose titles have been changed illegally since 1932 puzzled the State Civil Service Commission tonight as it called a meeting for Thursday in New York City to discuss the situation.

I was very glad to read in the day's papers the remarks of Mr. Knauth with regard to work-relief; that he is going to look into the recreational projects and relief work as a whole, and do some changing and reorganizing where it seems necessary to him.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., April 21 (AP). -- No clue to the fate of the schooner Alsatian came from the Atlantic tonight and fears grew that the long-overdue Newfoundland Banks craft had gone to the bottom with her twenty-five seamen.

MEXICO, D.F., April 21 (AP). -- Amelia Earhart, who was balked by a bug that flew into her eye in an attempted non-stop flight from Burbank, Calif., here yesterday, said tonight she might attempt a non-stop hop to New York within ten days.

In so far as the stock market's course indicates the state of things, Wall Street is recovering emphatically from its recent extreme mental depression. At all events, the "stock averages" have risen somewhat again. Last week they reached the highest figure since Feb. 19, making the gain 6 3/4 points since the end of March and 9 3/4 from the low average of the year, and coming within less than 2 points of February's highest.

CHICAGO, April 21. -- E.B. McKinney; negro vice president of the Southern Tenant Farmers Union whose failure to reach Chicago for a Socialist party organizers' conference gave rise to fears that he had been kidnapped, arrived here late last night after having escaped from a carload of armed vigilantes in Tennessee.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP). -- A Republican leader had a good word to say tonight for some of the experiments of the New Deal.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, April 21. -- After a day of prolonged consultations a Cabinet was formed this evening by Premier Andrew Tocheff. Among the members is General Rachko Atasanoff, who is a member, though not a prominent one, of the Officers League and a former Assistant Chief of the General Staff.

The octocentennial anniversary of the birth of Moses Maimonides was observed last night at the second annual Passover rally under the auspices of the Metropolitan Conference of Temple Brotherhoods in thin Temple Sholem, 7 West Eighty-third Street.

Business conditions showed further improvement in March and the first half of April, according to the regular survey issued yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board. The continued expansion of the automobile industry and the sharp rise in building were responsible for the increase in industrial activity, the report states.

Yesterday at noon I left my office on Forty-second Street for a stroll up Broadway. I went into a theatre. It was crowded -- standing room only -- but there was no show on the stage, not even a picture screen, only a male chorus and a few preachers singing hymns, speaking and praying -- but that was the theatre district of Broadway.

LONDON, April 20. -- To all outward appearances, comparative stability and tranquility have been restored to the foreign exchanges in the last week. Guilders and Swiss francs, which became the storm centre after the devaluation of the belga, have been brought more or less under control, and this has been fairly easy recently because of the normal contraction of activity which occurs before the lengthy Easter holiday.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- Investigation by the Twentieth Century Fund does not bear out the contention that "government intervention through Section 7a and the various labor boards has intensified both industrial unrest and the number of strikes," according to a report by the section on strikes after a study of the role of the government in labor relations.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- The argument that the Republican party "is progressive because it has been conservative" was offered by Henry P. Fletcher, chairman of the Republican National Committee, in an article written for The Associated Collegiate Press, made public today.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 21. -- Chance Sun, favorite to win the Kentucky Derby, turned in the fastest trial among the Derby hopefuls in brisk workouts at Churchill Downs today.

FARRAR, Mo., April 21 (AP). -- An army balloon piloted by Captain Orville Anderson and Captain R.P. Williams of Dayton, Ohio, landed here tonight at 6:48 o'clock after a successful flight into the substratosphere region, which began at Scott Field, Belleville, Ill., at 3:12 o'clock this afternoon.

The Easter service at 11 o'clock yesterday morning in St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street, was attended by a throng of 4,000 worshipers. Some 1,200 persons who arrived late were unable to enter. Some of those attending sat in an adjoining chapel and auditorium to which the service was carried by amplifiers.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21 (AP) -- The board of directors of the Philadelphia Chamber of Commerce has recommended that Congress invite reconsideration of the Public Utility Bill directed at holding companies by giving a small group representing government and well-managed holding companies a month in which to agree on a revised bill for passage at the present session.

BERLIN, April 21. -- No one crossing Germany by train these Spring days can fail to be impressed by its super-orderliness, its thorough cultivation, the trimness and spruceness of its settlements, the absence everywhere of anything pertaining to the litter of waste and the pervading presence everywhere of a new spirit of improvement.

Taking the lead at the half-way mark, Franco Georgetti, Italian ace who holds the American all-around title, outdistanced four rivals to capture the 30-mile professional motor paced race, feature of the opening program at the Coney Island Velodrome yesterday.

A few weeks ago HARRY L. HOPKINS, the Federal Emergency Relief Administrator, replying to criticisms of "boon doggling" and other relief activities, denounced the critics as "too damned "dumb to appreciate the finer things of "life." Last week Secretary WALLACE launched a similar attack on the cotton textile manufacturers and the New England Governors who complained that the cotton processing tax was gravely hurting the textile business.

The Goldman Band, which probably has played to larger audiences and to more people than any other musical organization, will again entertain thousands in a series of free concerts this Summer in the city parks and at New York University.

Joseph Salvanni, 71 years old, of 535 Washington Street, Hoboken, died yesterday in the Jersey City Medical Center from injuries received Friday night when he was accidentally struck on Ocean Avenue by a truck operated, according to the police, by George Lewis of 94 Mercer Street, Jersey City.

The one hope for this world "is the way that Jesus shows us" and there is no other, Bishop William T. Manning said yesterday morning in his sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. More than 3,000 persons attended the service.

The Ellin Prince Speyer Hospital for Animals will be the beneficiary of a recital to be given by Mme. Kirsten Flagstad of the Metropolitan Opera tomorrow afternoon at the home of James Speyer, 1,058 Fifth Avenue, under the auspices of the New York Women's League for Animals.

Newspaper publishers and executives arriving yesterday from all parts of the country to attend the annual meeting of The Associated Press today and the American Newspaper Publishers Association tomorrow at the Waldorf-Astoria report that business is gradually picking up and that the outlook is improving.

With two of the roads serving the Northwest confronted with grave financial problems, general attention should be centred at last on the railroad situation. Even without this latest occurrence, the attention of every thinking American should long since have been directed toward a possible solution of the problem.

CHICAGO, April 21. -- A natural squeeze is on in May corn for delivery next month. The market has been heavily oversold of late, while consumers, particularly processors, who accumulated May corn some time ago are making it uneasy for those who are short, and forced a covering movement here last week, which carried prices up sharply.

A mass written especially for the Most Rev. Stephen J. Donahue, Auxiliary Bishop of New York, and dedicated to him by its composer, Alvin McDermott, organist of the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Name, Amsterdam Avenue and Ninety-sixth Street, was sung in that church yesterday for the first time.
Josephus Daniels, United States Ambassador to Mexico and former Secretary of the Navy, arrived yesterday from Vera Cruz on the Orizaba of the Ward Line accompanied by Mrs. Daniels.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- The condition of the share-croppers of the Cotton Belt has not escaped the attention of the planners in President Roosevelt's administration. Steps are being taken now to bring immediate relief to this distressed class of tenant farmer and eventually to eliminate a system of farming that has existed in the South since slavery was abolished.

With Rockefeller Center fast earning new distinction as a capital of the art world, a new Gallery for French Art was announced yesterday, to occupy the entire seventh floor and roof garden of the Maison Francaise. It will open on May 1 with the first of a series of exhibitions depicting the arts and industries of France.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 21 (AP). -- Mae West, star of the stage and screen, said not long ago that she had "never found a man I liked well enough to marry."

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- Presidential approval was claimed today for a new move toward a "planned economy" in which money and credit could be deflected from industries already producing surpluses and used instead to develop fields where demand exceeds domestic supply.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- Leaping food prices which may cause the army to spend an extra $5,000,000 next year have set worried military officers to figuring in advance what may be used for meat if the cost mounts too high.

The Merchants Association of New York made public yesterday a plan it has submitted to Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. for the revision of the income tax laws as they affect nonresident aliens.

Not only is the United States ruled by economic fascism, but it is beginning to experience "terroristic, political fascism," in the opinion of the Rev. Dr. Harry F. Ward of the Union Theological Seminary.

LONDON, April 20. -- What probably would have been a dull and uninteresting week for the stock markets was converted into cheerful, if inactive, period by the budget news. There was nothing exciting or exhilarating in it, but Chancellor of the Exchequer Neville Chamberlain succeeded in making a little money appear to go a long way.

LAMAR, Col., April 21 (AP). -- Dust-hoarsened voices mingled Easter paeans with prayers for resurrecting rains today in churches throughout the diminishing drought-blighted area of the high Southwest plains.
BOSTON, April 21 (AP). -- Mass meetings were held in Salem and Fall River today at which demands were made for relief for the New England textile industry, the ills of which were diagnosed.

ST. LOUIS, April 21 (AP). -- Encouraged by prospects of increased passenger and freight traffic, three Southwest railroads with headquarters here listed 1935 budget allotments today totaling $5,205,896 for repair and reconstruction projects.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- All proposals for bonus payments before 1945 were denounced by Henry H. Curran, director of the National Economy League, in a letter to all Senators, which was made public today.
ALBANY, N.Y., April 21 (AP). -- Six thousand fans saw Toronto win from Albany, 7 to 2, today, Earl Cook holding the Senators to seven scattered hits.

Although the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League race is still in its early stages, a competition equally as close as that of last year is promised as a result of the games played during the past week.

Belief in the theory of evolution, once considered a form of "intellectual anarchy," is today the best friend of religion because it speaks of the ages of God, the Rev. Dr. Malcolm James MacLeod said in a sermon yesterday morning at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue at Forty-eighth Street.

A very large audience listened yesterday afternoon to a Wagner Program given by Arturo Toscanini and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall. It listened engrossed to the stupendous music; it applauded and cheered and did all that an audience could to show the gratitude it felt to the composer and the master interpreter.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., April 21. -- Due to the size of the field, the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club was forced to end the first Long Island skeet team championship after 75 birds had been trapped for each gunner today. Originally it was planned to have a shoot at 100 targets.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 21. -- Frank Campbell, with Miss Myrtle Whittelsey crewing, made a runaway of the competition in the open Class B dinghy sailing today at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

FALL RIVER, Mass., April 21. -- More than 1,000 members of the Doffers and Spinners Union of the United Textile Workers of America, some in their old clothes and some in Easter finery, this afternoon gathered in the Casino to draft a joint letter to the President.

Though flames and smoke still rose last night from the five-story brick warehouse of the New York Dock Company at Furman and Clark Streets, on the Brooklyn waterfront, firemen had the spectacular blaze well in hand after a desperate struggle that began shortly after noon on Saturday.

Harry Bannister, actor, purchased from Ira Budd his seventy-six-acre property in the town of Greenwich, Warren County, improved with a sixteen-room house. Improvements planned by the new owner, including an artificial lake, will cost $40,000, according to Edward L. Dugan of Newark, attorney for Mr. Bannister.

The Bureau of Business Research of the College of the City of New York announced yesterday that it had completed an economic survey of business establishments in Manhattan and the Bronx. The research data, with special emphasis on neighborhod stores, are expected to prove useful to housing authorities, city planners, real estate men and retail store locaters.

A musicale and reception will be held at the Cosmopolitan Club on the afternoon of May 6 for the benefit of the hospital music committee of the New York City Visiting Committee. The artists will be Mildred Dilling, harpist; Frances Blaisdell, flutist; Arpad Sandor, pianist, and Rose Dirman, soprano.
NEWARK, N.J., April 21. -- The Newark Bears fought off Montreal's ninth inning rally today to defeat the Royals, 4 to 3, in the first game of their series before 7,000.

The S. W. Stores, Inc., leased the four-story business building at 440 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, adjoining the department store of Abraham Straus, from Mrs. Rose Abraham, widow of the founder of the department store. The lessees will take possession about Aug. 15, according to Riker Co., brokers in the deal.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1935, as well as last prices, for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:
Continuation of the balmy weather that prevailed over the week-end undoubtedly would bring the hoped-for improvement in trout fishing conditions in Southern New York waters.

The Charity Organization Society will open a drive for new members in an effort to increase interest and participation in its social welfare work here, it was announced yesterday by Walter S. Gifford, its president. Bayard F. Pope will be general chairman of the campaign and Lindsay Bradford the vice chairman.

A single legislative body to serve in place of the Board of Aldermen and the Board of Estimate and life tenure of office for the Police Commissioner of New York City are among recommendations in a memorandum on charter revision made public yesterday by the Society for the Prevention of Crime.

BERLIN, April 21. -- Germany's two prominent Communist leaders, Ernst Torgler and Ernst Thaelmann, often reported in recurring rumors as dead or facing the Nazi axeman, were learned on excellent authority today to be confined still in separate Berlin prisons.

TOKYO, Monday, April 22. -- The most severe earthquake that the Japanese island of Formosa has known in modern times devastated two provinces yesterday, and this morning the Overseas Department received a report that the dead numbered 2,471.
A word-picture of the future was drawn by a man of science last night in terms that made the usual dreamer's prophecies of rich happenings look pale and wan.

ALBANY, April 21. -- A shake-up in the Cabinet of Governor Lehman is impending, and it was indicated tonight that the scheduled changes may be disclosed soon after the Executive returns here tomorrow night from his vacation trip.

For seven and one-third innings at the Yankee Stadium yesterday, Bill Dietrich, a bespectacled pitcher with a hard high one and a curve that sort of corkscrewed all over the arena, envisioned a niche for himself in baseball's Hall of Fame.

The island of Formosa, which is one of the most important parts of the Japanese Empire, lies about ninety miles off the east coast of China, opposite the Province of Fukien. It is separated from the mainland of China by a relatively shallow strait and lies between the South and East China Seas.

MOSCOW, April 21. -- Soviet authorities, who recently launched campaigns against faulty educational methods and parental neglect that contribute to hoodlumism and juvenile crime, have started a new drive to reduce the appalling toll of children's accidents on Moscow streets.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- Sectional bitterness over the subject of lynching, dormant in Congress for nearly thirteen years, appeared tonight as a formidable threat to immediate progress on President Roosevelt's legislative program.

PARIS, April 20. -- The florin is staying close to the gold-export point, and the pressure of bear sellers has greatly relaxed. The exodus of gold from the Bank of Holland was only 12,000,000 florins last week, compared with 105,000,000 florins the week before.

The ecstatic followers of Major J. Divine coursed through Harlem 10,000 strong yesterday afternoon in a four-hour Easter parade that seemed to convince countless watchers that Father Divine indeed has "the world in a jug, and the stopper in his hand."

Almost the earliest existing pictorial version of one of the world's great myths and certainly the earliest that has ever come to this country has been acquired by the Metropolitan Museum of Art and has been placed on exhibition in its room of recent accessions.

DUBLIN, April 21. -- The de Valera administration staged today the first official ceremony held to commemorate the Easter week rebellion in 1916. President Eamon de Valera in the presence of a large gathering unveiled a memorial in the General Postoffice in Dublin.
BERLIN, April 21. -- The holy week of Easter has been a period of foreboding for the Christian confessions in Germany. The government's program is known and its intentions are becoming clear.
WASHINGTON, April 21. -- Official and unofficial Washington and the strangers, 100,000 strong within the gates of the capital on the Potomac, went to church today.

Providence College scored one run in the eighth inning without making a hit to tie the St. John's University nine, 4 to 4, before 2,500 persons at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, yesterday. The game was called after nine innings to permit a semi-pro game to start.

BEDFORD, N.Y., April 21. -- As the eighth annual Spring field trials of the Southern New York Field Trial Club ended today, the Judges awarded the highest honors in the open all-age stake, leading event of the three-day meeting, to Arcady Farm Tex, white and liver pointer dog owned by Mr. and Mrs. George W. Cole of Bridgewater, Conn.
Paul Friesel, national junior titleholder, equaled the American record of 0:29 in annexing the 50-yard breast-stroke final at the A.A.U. swimming meet in the Park Central Hotel pool yesterday.
CHICAGO, April 21. -- Statistics of operations on the Board of Trade here last week were as follows, in bushels:

Shipping men estimate that 10,000 United States seamen would obtain employment on American flag vessels if the administration shipping bill, introduced last week by Senator Copeland and Representative Bland, is successful. Hearings on the bill will start today in Washington.

The president and members of the board of directors of Union Settlement on behalf of that organization will give a dinner on May 1 at the Park Lane. The occasion will mark the fortieth anniversary of the founding of the settlement. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of the Union Settlement Association, will preside.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21 (AP). -- If the luck of the draw counts for anything at the forty-first annual Penn relays this week-end, Pittsburgh's well-balanced set of baton-passers can be giving themselves a slap on the back for congratulation today.

Federated Department Stores, Inc., reported in the annual statement for the year ended on Jan. 31 a net profit of $2,308,447, after deducting all costs and expenses, depreciation, interest and taxes. From this is deducted dividends of $995,784 on the preferred stock of subsidiary companies and $164,315 representing the part of the net profit applicable to minority interests in common stocks of subsidiaries.

PARIS, April 20. -- The exodus of gold from the Bank of France, amounting to 1,000,000,000 francs for the last fortnight, naturally has reduced the market's resources by as much. Call money, however, is at 2 per cent and thirty-day loans remain at 2 1/2 per cent.

Since Saturday evening is a neglected holiday in the Village no one need feel bitter about "Jackson White," which was put on at the Provincetown as an Easter prelude. In the program it is described as David Arnold Balch's "folk play of elemental passion."

The Massachusetts Investors Trust reports net assets of $34,651,401 as of March 31 last, compared with $30,809,648 at the end of the previous quarter. Shares outstanding numbered 1,917,473, compared with 1,638,460, and net assets for each share were $18.07 against $18.80.

Your editorial "Higher Pay Unwarranted" was posted on one of our bulletin boards in an elevator lobby on our floor. Your using "the salary level in wartime" as a basis of comparison has provoked the following reminder by several employes:

For two years I have been endeavoring to obtain a grasp of the essentials of the new economy as embodied in the New Deal, and although there have been literally tons of material sent out from Washington intended to explain this new philosophy of government, I must confess that to me it was all very confusing.

A nation-wide census of the unemployed, such as the Federal Relief Administration contemplates, will be worth the dozen-odd millions which it is expected to cost if the job is treated as something more than a piece of made work.

Federated Department Stores, Inc., reported in the annual statement for the year ended on Jan. 31 a net profit of $2,308,447, after deducting all costs and expenses, depreciation, interest and taxes. From this is deducted dividends of $995,784 on the preferred stock of subsidiary companies and $164,315 representing the part of the net profit applicable to minority interests in common stocks of subsidiaries.

PARIS, April 20. -- The exodus of gold from the Bank of France, amounting to 1,000,000,000 francs for the last fortnight, naturally has reduced the market's resources by as much. Call money, however, is at 2 per cent and thirty-day loans remain at 2 1/2 per cent.

Since Saturday evening is a neglected holiday in the Village no one need feel bitter about "Jackson White," which was put on at the Provincetown as an Easter prelude. In the program it is described as David Arnold Balch's "folk play of elemental passion."

The Massachusetts Investors Trust reports net assets of $34,651,401 as of March 31 last, compared with $30,809,648 at the end of the previous quarter. Shares outstanding numbered 1,917,473, compared with 1,638,460, and net assets for each share were $18.07 against $18.80.
