ST. LOUIS, April 25. -- Heavyweight champion Max Baer today peered with his one good eye at the simple life and solemnly announced that he would quit this "too tough fight racket" after three more titular appearances.
ALBANY, April 25. -- A permanent State system of unemployment insurance was formally created today when Governor Lehman signed the Byrne-Killgrew bill, establishing the new program.

CLEVELAND, April 25 (AP). -- The Indians moved into first place in the American League today by defeating the Browns, 7 to 6, in a free-hitting contest. Hal Trosky's first home run of the season in the seventh inning with Earl Averill on base brought in the winning tally.

LONDON, April 25. -- Prime Minister J. Ramsay MacDonald has written a severe attack on Germany which is to be published Saturday in the fortnightly News Letter, the organ of the Prime Minister's personal following of thirteen members of the House of Commons.

With 683 known cases of food poisoning resulting from cream puffs and eclairs sold Tuesday from a White Plains bakery plant, the possibility arose yesterday of Federal prosecution of a national distributor.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 25. -- After deliberating nearly five hours, a jury in Superior Court tonight returned a verdict of $5,000 in favor of Mrs. Luard T. Wells of New York in her $50,000 alienation suit against Zetta Robart Wells of Weston, present wife of her divorced husband, Carveth Wells, the explorer.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

Forest fires burned over wide areas near Deer Park and Setauket in Suffolk County yesterday, destroying hundreds of acres of stunted pine and scrub oak, killing rabbits and other small game, razing buildings and delaying traffic with heavy smoke.

FLINT, Mich., April 25. -- Circuit Judge Paul V. Gadola today dismissed charges against Herbert R. Wilkin and James L. Walsh of Detroit, growing out of the collapse of the Guardian Detroit Union Group, Inc., on the grounds that the State courts have no jurisdiction in any case where the bank is a member of the Federal Reserve System.
NEWARK, N.J., April 25. -- Scoring fifteen runs in the first three innings, Buffalo today handed the Bears their most decisive defeat of the season by 16 to 2 to even the series.
PARIS, April 25 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation reported yesterday a net loss of $607,298 for the quarter ended on March 31 after interest, depreciation and other charges, compared with a net loss of $902,044 in the first quarter of last year and a net profit of $411,099 in the fourth quarter of last year, when special year-end adjustments made possible a better showing.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- New York, Detroit and Chicago banks and investment houses were listed as large owners of Kelsey-Hayes Wheel Company stock in a statement filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission, which revealed that George W. Kennedy received $35,000 compensation as president and J.A. Sweeney $18,000 as vice president, while a payment of $40,000 was made to an unnamed consulting engineer.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- Pending before Congress in one form or another since shortly after the World War, a proposal has been reintroduced in the House by Representative Lanham of Texas to pay a claim of $150,000 to Edwin Fairfax Naulty and Leslie Fairfax Naulty of New York for 144 airplane devices and designs allegedly used by the War Department and other Federal agencies.

The most sweeping effort of its kind undertaken in Wall Street was put under way yesterday in an endeavor to remove an impasse between conflicting interests in the settlement of trades in "when-issued" securities of the Alleghany Corporation.

Among the efforts of chemists in the last year to make life more comfortable, the American Chemical Society, in session here, learned yesterday of a grave defect which has been remedied in transparent cellulose wrappers, commonly identified as cellophane.

ST. LOUIS, April 25 (AP). -- Paul Dean, serving in a relief role, sustained his first defeat of the season today as the Cubs landed on the offerings of three Cardinal pitchers to defeat the world champions, 7 to 5, in the odd game of their series.

Virtually duplicating Hal Schumacher's fine performance of Wednesday, Roy Parmelee limited the Braves to three hits yesterday at the Polo Grounds and the Giants conquered the Bostonians, 2 to 1, to sweep the three-game series.

Mild breezes and sunny skies beckon the angler out of doors these days, and barring a repetition of the pranks that have been played thus far by a capricious Spring, the coming week-end should see the first mass outpouring to fresh and salt water haunts.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 25. -- Commutation of the terms of Tom Mooney and Warren K. Billings "to time served" was recommended to Governor Merriam by the Assembly today in a resolution passed by a vote of 51 to 28.

MARGATE, England, April 25. -- With the completion of two rounds of the international masters tournament at the Easter Congress of the Kent County Chess Association, now in progress at the Grand Hotel, four of the ten competitors are tied for the lead, each having scored 1 1/2 points.

PARIS, April 25. -- Eight Ministers, 172 Senators and 313 Deputies are seeking re-election as Mayors or Councilors in the municipal elections that will take place throughout France on Sunday, May 5. In the 38,000 communes into which the country is divided, 450,000 municipal Councilors will be elected by 11,500,000 electors.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25 (AP). -- With Rookie Vernon Wilshere pitching no-hit hall for six innings and letting the opposition down finally with only a pair of singles, the Athletics found their collective batting eye today and hammered the Washington Senators into a 10 to 0 defeat.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25. -- Adoption by Congress of legislation which would help "make America first in the arts" was urged today at a legislative session of the nineteenth biennial convention of the National Federation of Music Clubs.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- With tiny beams of light serving as measuring rods and scales at the same time, scientists have been able to determine the height in miles and the weight in tons of the chief component of the atmospheres of the four giant planets in our solar system -- Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus and Neptune.
Seven Bronx properties were bought in by plaintiffs at auction sales yesterday.

Silver dealers here and abroad yesterday marked up their prices at once, virtually to the 77.57 cent level at which the Treasury announced on Wednesday night that it would buy newly mined metal in this country. The volume of trading was small, however, except in London.

BERLIN, April 25. -- A new revolution in the German newspaper publishing field, designed to make the National Socialist press supreme and annihilate even the "coordinated" bourgeois, professional and confessional newspapers still surviving, has been initiated by three orders issued by Max Amann, president of the Reich Press Chamber, who simultaneously has appointed himself Germany's supreme press dictator.

Leon Cohen, technical adviser to the securities and trading division of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has transferred his membership in the New York Stock Exchange to Wilfred H. Fritts, who, if elected, will become a partner in E. Lowltz Co., of which film Mr. Cohen was a member.

James F. Fogarty, president of the North American Company, told stockholders at their annual meeting here yesterday that electric output of the company's system for January and February had broken all records for these months in the history of the present subsidiaries, while March also was the best on record with the exception of March, 1930.

Two men accused of operating a beauty parlor to cover up their real occupation as distributers of Irish Sweepstakes tickets were held in bail of $2,000 each yesterday by Garrett W. Cotter, United States Commissioner, on a charge of sending lottery tickets through the mails.
BERLIN, April 25 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of April 23 shows the following changes in reichsmark:
WARSAW, April 25. -- Ten German members of the German Union have been arrested in Kepno, near the German border, charged with anti-Polish propaganda, bribery and corruption.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP). -- A challenge to look at the record tonight marked the stormy debate over whether companionate marriages are fostered by the law preventing both husband and wife from working for the government.

Joseph Clendenin gave a dinner last night in the Rainbow Room, Rockefeller Center, for his daughter, Mrs. Stanley O. Bailey, the former Miss Florence Clendenin, who is sailing tonight on the Aquitania for her home in England. The other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Morss, Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Thorne Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Robert Minshall, Miss Cordie Williams, Miss Margaret MacGowan, Harold Ten Eyck and Shirley Peck.
CINCINNATI, April 25 (AP). -- Beaten by the Pirates three times, the Reds crushed Pittsburgh, 6 to 0, today to end the series.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- Organization of a works allotment division under the chairmanship of Secretary Ickes, to advise President Roosevelt on final allocation of funds for approved works relief projects from the $4,000,000,000 appropriation, was announced today by the White House.

CHICAGO, April 25 (AP). -- The rampaging White Sox blasted Schoolboy Rowe out of action with a seven-run drive in the fourth inning and checked a ninth-inning Tiger rally today to win, 9 to 8, and sweep the three-game series with the American League champions.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- Ordinary expenditures for advertising need not be reported under the requirement for disclosure of payments of more than $20,000 to persons other than officers and directors of registering corporation, the Securities and Exchange Commission ruled today.

MEXICO, D.F., April 25. -- For the first time in practically three years the dollar today registered a sharp decrease in the local exchange market, as a result of the silver action in Washington. The Bank of Mexico. which for a long time has maintained an official rate of exchange at 3.60 pesos to the dollar, today sold the dollar at 3.50. Other banks sold as low as 3.45.

While the protests of midtown retailers increased and the Police Department made plans to cancel all leaves and to provide special guards for public buildings, churches, railroad stations and private residences, Communists and Socialists completed preparations yesterday for May Day parades next Wednesday.
RIVERSIDE, Mass., April 25. -- Boston University opened its baseball season with a defeat, being turned back, 14 to 8, by Harvard at Nickerson Field today.

Mrs. Chester C. Michael of Kansas City, Mo., who has brought on a string of eight horses for the Spring circuit, made her Eastern show debut last night at the forty-second annual Brooklyn Horse Show. The exhibition, which opened at the Riding and Driving Club, in Prospect Park Plaza, will continue through tomorrow night.

The Copeland-Bland Ship Subsidy Bill was called for by President Roosevelt to take the place of the Jones-White act. If the new act is to prove of any value it must rigorously avoid the mistakes of its predecessor.

LONDON, April 25. -- The stock markets here were generally firm today, although business remained small because of the approaching end of the account. British funds again strengthened. Foreign bonds were cheerful, German and Brazilian issues gaining. Outstanding in the stock list were industrials rayons, Imperial Tobacco, motors, Cables and Wireless, Unilever and breweries. Oils were inactive and reacted. Rubbers were steady except Rubber Trust.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 25. -- Rosemont, racing in the silks of the Foxcatcher Farm, owned by the du Ponts of Delaware, made his 3-year-old debut today at Havre de Grace. In a splendidly run race, he turned in his first victory of the season when he took the measure of the Howe Stable's Nautch and A.G. Vanderbilt's Bachelor Dinner.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):

The first two-way telephone conversation around the world took place yesterday morning when two officials of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, using telephones only fifty feet apart, talked over a 23,000-mile telephone and radio circuit.

The Diamond Match Company yesterday declared extra dividends of 20 cents a share each on its preferred and common stocks and the regular quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock, all payable on June 1 to stock of record of May 15.
ALBANY, N.Y., April 25 (AP). -- The Montreal Royals of the International League hit two Albany Senator pitchers, Shoffner and Mulcahy, freely and aided by misplays won easily today, 12 to 6.

More than 450 members and guests of the Friends of the Princeton Library, attending the annual dinner of the society last night at the Hotel Plaza, heard Ellen Glasgow, author, assail the "aimless violence" of present-day American novelists.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ending April 24 as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks was $2,477,000,000, an increase of $1,000,000, compared with the preceding week and a decrease of $27,000,000, compared with the corresponding week in 1934.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., April 25. -- One hundred and fifty Mount Holyoke juniors with their escorts from twenty-nine different college and university campuses and from home towns, far and near, will take part this week-end in the two-day festivities which mark Junior Prom at the college.

Your recent article relative to a $1 fee by doctors was an agreeable piece of news. For twenty-five years I have been preaching that the medical set-up was all wrong and that the profession was being exploited by society. But to an ultra-conservative profession my ideas were rank heresy.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 25. -- A hard-hitting Syracuse University team defeated Rochester today, 15 -- 0, to open the season for both clubs. The Orangemen collected sixteen hits and drove Brinker to the showers in the fourth. Sanford and Johnson of Syracuse made home runs and Simonitis collected three safeties.

ATLANTA, April 25. -- Clark Howell Sr., editor and publisher of The Atlanta Constitution, came to the defense of the national administration tonight with a sharp attack on Governor Talmadge's recent assaults on President Roosevelt and his policies.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- The rapid market rise today in silver to within a fraction of a cent of the official American price, following the increase last night in the government's price for newly mined domestic silver to 77.57 cents an ounce, failed to bring another advance today in what the Treasury will pay.

CHICAGO, April 25. -- Liquidation of the Rosenbaum Grain Corporation's holdings of grain and provisions through the clearing house of the Board of Trade was accomplished today in a most orderly manner and was completed within a few minutes after the opening.

Furniture retailers are assured of a sharp pick-up in volume in the Fall, David M. Lenz, president of the National Retail Furniture Association, said yesterday in opening a two-day advertising conference sponsored by the trade group at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

PARIS, April 25 (AP). -- The general terms of a convention to preserve Austria's independence have been accepted by six of the nine interested powers, it was learned today as France and Italy prepared to issue invitations to the Danubian conference to be held in Rome in June.

The Joint strike committee of the Cleaners, Dyers and Pressers' Union and the Cleaning and Dye House Drivers' Union, through their chairman, Jacob Effrat, rejected yesterday Aldermanic President Bernard S. Deutsch's proposal for a two-weeks' truce in the strike of 8,000 workers in the wholesale dyeing and cleaning plants throughout the city.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 25. -- Two major upsets were recorded in the Mason-Dixon tennis tournament today when Miss Kay Winthrop of Boston defeated Miss Jane Sharp of Pasadena, Calif., and Miss Eunice Dean, San Antonio, Texas, defeated Mrs. Frederick A. McBride, Short Hills, N.J.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 25. -- Sharp attacks on Secretary Wallace and the processing tax on cotton were made by speakers at the annual convention of the American Cotton Manufacturers Association here today.
Money market remained quiet in the matter of business, while quotations were unchanged for all classifications.

The rise in silver increased activity on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and the May advanced 35 points to 11 3/4 cents a pound, the highest since the collapse last month. Strength of the stock market attracted commission house interest, while a steady demand from mill sources disclosed a comparatively limited supply of contracts.

PITTSBURGH, April 25 (AP). -- Attorneys for Andrew W. Mellon dug into records fifteen years old today in an attempt to refute charges that he evaded taxes in disposing of his 30 per cent interest in McClintic-Marshall Corporation to Bethlehem Steel.

Everybody's Thrift Shop, which furthers various charitable organizations in the city, was the beneficiary of a novel fashion showing entitled "Five-to-Fifty-Year-Old Fashion Show," held yesterday afternoon at Sherry's. Fashions designed to suit all ages were shown by young matrons and debutantes of this and recent seasons.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- The Harrison compromise bonus bill, liberalized to permit veterans to receive cash or bonds for present value of their adjusted compensation certificates, was rushed to the Senate today as a means of displacing the anti-lynching issue which apparently had involved that body in a hopeless filibuster.

Interest was concentrated to a large extent yesterday in those markets that responded to the inflationary implications of the latest advance in the government's buying price for newly mined silver. An abnormal situation in grain, resulting from the liquidation of accounts of a large house recently embarrassed, made it impossible to judge the effect of the silver price change upon that market.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- Administration leaders in the House said tonight they thought it inevitable that the body would deliver a personal rebuke to Secretary Ickes by voting to delete from the Interior Department Appropriation Bill any provision for an Under-Secretary of the department, when the conference report on the measure is brought up for action next week.

Stocks responded yesterday to the increase in the Treasury's price of silver in much the same way as they acted just a fortnight ago following the increase in the official price to 71.11 cents an ounce. On that occasion, silver stocks were strong, but the rest of the market did nothing.
Business leases reported yesterday included several contracts for retail stores. Brokers also announced deals for some entire floors in business buildings.
Mrs. Dorothy Payne Whitney Elmhirst, the former Mrs. Willard Straight, renounced her United States citizenship yesterday in an affidavit filed with Federal Judge William Bondy.

Members of the graduating class of Columbia College are imbued with far greater optimism than last year's class, according to the senior poll conducted by the Columbian Year Book. By 1940 the average Columbia senior expects to have an annual income of $5,102, compared with the $3,600 estimate of last year's class.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., reports in its statement for 1934, to be given out today, a consolidated net income of $24,121,297, including dividends received from companies not consolidated. This is equivalent to 76 cents a share on 31,708,454 1/2 shares of capital stock outstanding at the end of the year.
LONDON, April 25 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

A special stockholders' meeting has been called by the Consolidated Oil Corporation for June 4, at which authorization will be asked for a new bond issue of not less than $50,000,000, to be used in retiring $48,781,700 of gold bonds and probably $12,324,800 of 8 per cent preferred stock, it was announced yesterday by Harry F. Sinclair, chairman of the executive committee.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- Reservation of a bequest to the United States by Oliver Wendell Holmes for disposition in a manner which would make a suitable memorial to the eminent jurist was recommended to Congress in a message by President Roosevelt today.

The radio broadcasting of news will continue for another year with a somewhat liberalized policy through the Press-Radio Bureaus established in New York and on the Pacific Coast by cooperation of press associations and broadcasting chains, as a result of action taken yesterday at the annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.
Lucrezia Bori will sing at White Plains tonight, closing the fifth season of concerts at the Westchester County Centre.

Last night Mr. Toscanini conducted the last Thursday night concert of the present Philharmonic-Symphony season at Carnegie Hall with a performance of the passionate and mystical music of Beethoven's Missa Solemnis. A worthier conclusion of a master's labors of a season could not have been contrived.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- The United States must maintain naval tonnage ratios prescribed by the Washington and London naval treaties "notwithstanding any agreement or lack of agreement," Chairman Vinson of the House Naval Affairs Committee declared today during House debate on the Navy Department Appropriation Bill.

Omaha, William Woodward's son of Gallant Fox, is the new future-book favorite for the Kentucky Derby, displacing Chance Sun, according to an announcement last night from Frank Shannon, well-known commissioner.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 25. -- The Trimmingham Brothers' six-meter sloop, Viking, justified those who predict victory for her in the international contests for the Prince of Wales cup by winning the second race today with more than a three-minute lead.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- Back of the late Presidential announcement last evening, raising the government price for new domestic silver, lies one of those mysteries which go with public administrative affairs. When it is truthfully set down that seasoned Treasury reporters were taken by surprise, the fact at least suggests that perhaps Treasury officials were surprised as well.

NEWARK, N.J., April 25. -- The Public Service Electric and Gas Company will be ordered to cut its electric rates a total of $5,176,566 a year, the New Jersey Board of Public Utility Commissioners announced today. The three commissioners, Harry Bacharach, Thomas L. Hanson and Frank J. Reardon, reached their decision in the two-year rate case after three days of conferences, the last of which ended early this morning.

Irked by charges that two East River seaplane ramps had been built at almost $160,000 more than their original estimated cost, Mayor La Guardia took a hand yesterday in the aldermanic investigation of relief by denouncing the witnesses who testified to waste and mismanagement on the project.
ALBANY, April 25. -- Following is the text of the Unemployment Insurance Bill as signed today by Governor Lehman:

Yesterday's statement for the twelve reserve banks again raised the system's gold holdings above all previous records. Ratio of reserve to deposits and circulation reached the highest of 1935 to date and the highest since Sept. 23, 1931. Reserve ratio at the New York bank also reached the highest since 1931.
Marvyn (Red) Dutton, for several years a leading defense man in the National Hockey League, yesterday signed as manager of the New York American sextet for the next two seasons.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- The low level reached in authorizations and commitments by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation continued in March, the total being only $40,339,664.57. Of this $10,000,000 was for the purchase of capital stock in the new RFC Mortgage Company.

Thomas D. Thacher, president of the Bar Association of the City of New York and former Solicitor General of the United States, suggested yesterday that New York State adopt the English barrister-solicitor legal system and limit court appearances to lawyers specializing in trial work.

Colonel Robert R. McCormick, editor and publisher of The Chicago Tribune, said yesterday afternoon that the American newspaper publishers in their code negotiations with the Federal Government preserved the freedom of the press "not only for newspaper publishing but for the entire people of the nation."
" George White's 1935 Scandals," a Fox musical production featuring Alice Faye, James Dunn, Ned Sparks and Lyda Roberti, opens this morning at the Roxy.

HANNIBAL, Mo., April 25 (AP). -- The boyhood antics and adult whimsies of Samuel L. Clemens were recalled tonight by visitors who thronged his boyhood home here for the dedication of a "Mark Twain Centennial Museum" as part of Hannibal's year-long centennial celebration in honor of its famous son.
Another plan for reorganization of Fox Metropolitan Playhouses, Inc., was outlined yesterday before Federal Judge Julian W. Mack in the County Lawyers Association Building, 14 Vesey Street.

Prices were mixed on the local commodity futures markets yesterday. Trading was quite heavy. Rubber, silk and hide futures recovered from their weakness of the previous day; sugar was erratic and coffee futures were sharply lower. On the cash markets wheat, corn, rye, flour, cocoa, lard, silk and hides declined, while oats, cotton, rubber and dairy products were higher.

Mrs. Payne Whitney's Galsac, which scored in his first race last Monday, came back with another sparkling effort at Jamaica yesterday to capture the Locust Purse. The event, a five-furlong dash for 2-year-olds, featured the day's racing.

The Long Island University nine scored its sixth consecutive victory by defeating St. Peter's College, 9 -- 3, on Manhattan College Field yesterday. The Long Islanders collected ten hits while holding the opposition to five.
WASHINGTON, April 25. -- Charles Edison, son of Thomas A. Edison was appointed by President Roosevelt today to temporary membership on the National Industrial Recovery Board.

Declaring "the American Retail Federation does not fear examination by a Congressional committee," Louis E. Kirstein of William Filene's Sons Company and chairman of the executive committee of the federation, said yesterday that the program of organizing the super-trade body to speak for the entire retail field will continue unchecked.

A well-founded report yesterday had it that Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer would back the production schedules next season of Sam H. Harris and Max Gordon. It is understood the film company will be financially interested in musical shows as well as plays, with the exception of the musical piece now being prepared by Cole Porter and Moss Hart for Mr. Harris.

AUSTIN, Texas, April 25. -- After more than nine hours of questioning, Howard Pierson, 20 years old, confessed today that he killed his parents, Associate Justice William A. Pierson of the Texas Supreme Court and Mrs. Pierson, for "revenge" and to obtain his father's insurance.

Heavy disbursements by the Treasury, compined with large gold imports and a decline in money in circulation lifted the reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System $218,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to a new high record of $4,719,000,000, according to the weekly report of the system, published yesterday.

LOURDES, France, April 25. -- At 4 o'clock this afternoon, in this place of world pilgrimage, there began a three-day Roman Catholic ceremony in conclusion of the jubilee celebration of the nineteenth centenary of Christ's death.

CHICAGO, April 25. -- Warmer weather and a sluggish demand for fresh meats caused a break of 5 to 25 cents a hundredweight in prices of hogs here today. Whereas the early top of $9.20 was only 5 cents below yesterday's, it would have been nard to get more than $9.10 at the close.
Banks figured as principals in the selling and leasing of real estate in the city yesterday. Financial institutions also played a prominent part as bidders at sales conducted by auctioneers.

Properties in Manhattan having a variety of improvments were offered at auctioneers' stands yesterday. The list included a loft building, a garage, a home for aged couples and several dwellings and tenement houses.

WITH the help of its power of invention, its air-conditioned rooms, its synthetic foods, its streamlined trains, its myriad labor-saving gadgets, the human race may some day become all intellect -- light, big-brained creatures of an H.G. Wells Utopian fantasy. But until that far time, the human body will probably retain the hundred unused and undeveloped muscles and aptitudes that cry out for daily exercise amid our megalopolitan towers and our sedentary occupations.

Colonel Frank Knox, publisher of The Chicago Daily News, asserted yesterday that President Roosevelt should be held directly responsible for the attempts of his subordinates to limit freedom of the press.

Mrs. Henry C. Caraway was elected president of the Women's National Republican Club at the annual meeting of members yesterday at their headquarters, 3 West Fifty-first Street. She succeeded Mrs. George A. Wyeth, who attacked the Roosevelt administration in her retiring address, declaring that "on every hand law-abiding men are under attack by one bureaucracy or another, each seeming to be ruled by no law save its own appetite."

A big, jovial man, seemingly without a care in the world, sits behind a desk in the Twenty-third Street Y.M.C.A. and paints bright word pictures of the future for destitute job applicants. Sometimes when he senses that the stabs of unlucky days have gone too deep, he makes quick sketches of a quaint old man with a bunny to give the applicant.

Reduced bank clearings for the nation in the week ended on Wednesday were attributed to the declines in New York, Boston and Philadelphia. All other centres reported gains. The total for the twenty-two leading cities as given by Dun Bradstreet, Inc., was $4,658,605,000, against $4,989,798,000 in the corresponding week last year.

The further this administration travels along the road that administrations like this one follow when they are going places -- if you know what I mean -- the plainer it becomes that Washington regards the profit motive as the crippled stepchild of economics.

LONDON, April 25. -- Speculation in silver was fanned afresh by the action of tile United States yesterday in raising the domestic buying price to 77.57 cents, an equivalent of about 35d in the London market. The immediate result was that the price rose 2 1-16d an ounce, to 34 7/8d, the highest since October, 1924.

Although John Clare, Northamptonshire peasant-poet, died in 1864, a complete edition of his works is just being issued. About 300 poems have been taken from manuscripts and added to the 500 previously published poems to make up this new two-volume edition. Dutton will publish the collection on May 30.
HANOVER, N.H., April 25. -- Dartmouth Hall, three-story white Colonial building and a reproduction of the first hall of Dartmouth College, built in 1784, was badly damaged by fire early this morning.
BERLIN, April 25. -- The Boerse was weaker today and generally inactive. Heavy industrials declined, Rheinstahl losing 1 point. Electricals were weaker, Siemens losing 1 1/2 points.

GENEVA, April 25. -- The Child Welfare Committee of the League of Nations began today its eleventh session. For the first time its American member was sitting as a full voting member and its Japanese member was sitting in the advisory capacity in which the delegate of the United States Department of Labor formerly sat.

With a view to giving ultimate consumers an opportunity to take a hand in writing standards for "over-the-counter" goods, the Standards Council of the American Standards Association, at a meeting at the Edison Electrical Institute, 420 Lexington Avenue, yesterday, voted to reorganize sections of its structure.
Patricia Anne Thompson is just old enough to be losing her baby teeth. Nevertheless, she is going to have a "retrospective" exhibition of her drawings at the Grand Central Art Galleries.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- President Roosevelt will go on the air Sunday night in a resumption of his fireside radio talks to the nation to discuss the new works relief program. He will speak for half an hour beginning at 10 P.M., Eastern standard time.
BOSTON, April 25. -- With an east wind smack on her nose, the America's Cup yacht Yankee left today for England, taking her departure from Boston Lightship at 1 P.M.

MADISON, Wis., April 25. -- Allegations that Mrs. Meta Berger, widow of Victor L. Berger, sought to dominate the faculty and the policies of the University of Wisconsin's Milwaukee branch were made by Dean Chester D. Snell, formerly head of the university's extension division, before a State Senate committee here tonight.

Reorders on women's apparel lines in the market here continue to await consumer response to current retail promotions. Reports here yesterday indicated that for the most part this response was good and that the way will be paved for more active purchasing of Summer lines.

The series of musical programs in public parks last Summer under the direction of the Concert Division of the Emergency Relief Bureau will be resumed early in June. This year's schedule calls for 370 concerts, it was announced yesterday by the Works Division.

The American Chemical Society, now in session here, announced yesterday that its highest honor, the Priestley Medal, awarded every three years "for distinguished service to chemistry." would be presented to William Albert Noyes, emeritus director of the laboratories of the University of Illinois.
ALBANY, April 25. -- Governor Lehman today signed the Breitbart bill providing that not more than three persons may ride in the front seat of an automobile.

Edwin Markham, the poet, who reached 83 on Tuesday, attended a reception in his honor at the McMillin Theatre, Columbia University. About 500 of his friends and admirers interrupted him frequently with applause as he read examples of his own and other poet's works in a loud, powerful voice which carried easily to the furthermost corners of the theatre.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

New bond financing was resumed on an active scale this week with new public offerings amounting to $112,310,000, compared with $19,590,000 last week. Two weeks ago, however, the total was $263,310,000, the greatest in four years. This week a year ago new bonds in the amount of $16,083,000 were placed on the market.

Mayor La Guardia clashed with the Aldermanic Committee Investigating Relief yesterday when he upheld the refusal of Park Commissioner Robert Moses to permit his staff to testify in private hearings unless they received copies of their testimony.
ROME, April 26. -- The Italian press continues to lay great emphasis on the insecure state of that part of Ethiopia lying beyond the Eritrean frontier, on account of brigandage.

Thousands of volunteers continued yesterday to fight forest fires in Long Island and New Jersey. The fires were concentrated for the most part in Suffolk County and the central and lower part of New Jersey. Two houses and a barn were burned on Long Island.

MEXICO, D.F., April 26. -- Eighteen thousand laborers are at work daily in the construction of roads throughout the republic, according to Jose Gonzalez, chief of the Department of National Highways. In a broadcast he announced that the Department of Communications was stimulating road building to the utmost.

QUEBEC, April 26. -- Quebec's newsprint bill, providing the government with absolute control over the newsprint industry in the Province, and also providing for prohibitive stumpage dues, comes up in the Legislature next week for first and second readings and debate, Premier Taschereau said tonight.

MARGATE, England. April 26. -- Jose R. Capablanca of Havana, former world chess champion, assumed the lead today in the international tournament at the Easter Congress of the Kent County Chess Association in progress at the Grand Hotel.

The Criterion and New York Theatres and eight five-story buildings adjoining were bought in at foreclosure auction yesterday by the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, as plaintiff, on a bid of $4,000,000. The buildings occupy the blockfront on the east side of Broadway, from Forty-fourth to Forty-fifth Street, in Times Square, fronting 203 feet on Broadway, 185 feet on Forty-fourth Street and 256 feet on Forty-fifth Street.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 26. -- Returning to the metropolitan area after a fifteen-week professional tennis tour, Ellsworth Vines of Pasadena, Calif., defeated Hans Nusslein of Germany in the New York State Naval Militia Armory tonight.

Founded in 1926 by Mr. and Mrs. Elie Nadelman, the Museum of Folk Arts at Riverdale-on-Hudson will be opened to the public with a formal reception this afternoon from 3 to 6 o'clock. Through a grant from the Carnegie Corporation and with the cooperation of the School Art League of New York, it has become possible this Spring to conduct the museum's activities on a considerably larger scale.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- A proposal to extend the present National Industrial Recovery Act for ten months to permit leisurely and methodical study of proposed changes before a revised act is introduced will be laid before President Roosevelt by Chairman Harrison of the Senate Finance Committee, which has the matter in charge.

Sailing on the Rex today for his fifty-second Atlantic crossing, Giulio Gatti-Casazza, the retiring general manager of New York's Metropolitan Opera, will be accompanied by Giulio Setti, the opera chorus master, who came here with Mr. Gatti in 1908 and who made it known yesterday that he also is retiring with his chief.

The noted Class J yacht Yankee, on her way abroad to race the large English sloops, was 155 miles out at noon yesterday, according to a radio received via the Catham, Mass., station. She had made that distance in 23 hours, and was south of Georges Bank.

The declaration yesterday by the highest court of this State that the Schackno act is unconstitutional raises again the question of intrastate enforcement of national industrial codes. This law, adopted at a special session of the Legislature held in 1933, was intended to make effective in intrastate commerce the general purposes of NIRA.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., April 26 (AP). -- Miss Mary McElroy pleaded with Governor Guy B. Park today to spare the life of Walter H. McGee, leader of the gang that kidnapped her for $30,000 ransom nearly two years ago.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 26. -- Brown defeated Dartmouth, 4 to 3, today. Three errors by Bill Clark, Dartmouth catcher coupled with two hits and a balk, gave Brown a three-run lead in the first inning. The Bruins increased that to four runs when Joe Jayne walked four men in the fourth, forcing in Murray.

MEXICO, D.F., April 26. -- With the peso rising sharply against the dollar today as the world silver market advanced, President Cardenas acted promptly to prevent the exportation or melting down of the currency, and in a decree ordered the present silver money in circulation exchanged for paper notes backed by the reserves of the Bank of Mexico.

" Justice -- social, economic, legal, international -- is the cry of the hour while we witness the most terrifying warlike preparations of all history by rulers and nations who pay no attention to the mandate of the Prince of Peace, 'Love thy neighbor as thyself,'" asserted Cardinal Hayes in a pastoral issued yesterday.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that on next Tuesday the firms of J.C. Dann Co. and W.A. Gardner Co. would be dissolved and on Wednesday the firm of J.C. Dann, Wickwire Co. would be formed by Ward A. Wickwire, Charles L. Gurney Jr., Alexander P. Dann, Jesse C. Dann Jr., E. Carl Warner and Llewellyn Powell, with offices at Charles D. Barney Co.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- President Roosevelt announced the appointment of Harry L. Hopkins as head of the Progress Division, charged with the progress of projects under the $4,000,000,000 work-relief program.

The National Association of Mutual Savings Banks will hold its annual convention here on May 8 to 10 inclusive. A large part of the program will be devoted to an examination of governmental influence upon business and upon the affairs of the average saver.

The United Gas Improvement Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on March 31 a consolidated net income of $31,088,150, equal after preferred dividends to $1.17 a share on the common stock outstanding, comparing with $32,294,924, or $1.22 a share, for the preceding year.

ALBANY, April 26. -- By a four-to-three decision the Court of Appeals ruled today that the Schackno State NRA Act was unconstitutional, but Governor Lehman immediately signed the Joseph bill, designed to meet anticipated objections of the highest State court.

PARIS, April 26. -- After a week's interruption, the negotiations between France and Russia for a mutual assistance pact were resumed this evening when Foreign Minister Pierre Laval and Vladimir Potemkin, Soviet Ambassador, held a long conference.

ALBANY, April 26. -- Following is the text of the Joseph bill, which the Governor signed today, designed to meet Court of Appeals objections to the Schackno Act. The italics comprise amendments of the previous act:

HOLLYWOOD, April 26 (AP). -- A network of strange circumstances was exposed tonight by officers investigating the slaying of Paul Ivar, 27, dress designer for film actresses, whose death last night was followed by the probably fatal shooting of a law professor and the suicide of the stylist's chauffeur.

Two Connecticut exhibitors achieved the greatest success last night during the second session of the three-day forty-second annual Brooklyn Horse Show at the Riding and Driving Club, Prospect Park Plaza. They were Mrs. John J. Farrell of Darien and Louis Kaiser of Bethel, each accounting for two blue ribbons.

Veto of the Feld bill granting manufacturers of trade-marked merchandise the right to fix the resale price of their goods has been urged in a letter to Governor Lehman by Benjamin H. Nature, head of the Namm store, Brooklyn.

The active commodity futures lost ground in the trading here yesterday, although copper and hides were moderately firmer in light trading. Sugar and coffee were the principal staples affected by the selling. On the cash markets, advances were scored by all the grains, cotton, lard and eggs.

Final decision by the police on the question of permits for the separate parades to be held by Communists and Socialists on May Day, Wednesday, will be made today with the expected return from Washington of Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine, it was said at police headquarters yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26. -- Columbia won one championship in spite of imperfect baton-passing and lost another because of it today as the forty-first annual Penn Relay Carnival opened on sun-flooded Franklin Field. The Lions, racing on the lightning-fast cinders, had the speed to win twice, but they lacked the manual dexterity to accomplish the feat.

ST. LOUIS, April 26 (AP). -- A Cardinal rookie, Ed Heusser, today held the Pittsburgh Pirates to three hits in six and one-third innings and finally got credit for a 3-to-2 victory in the eleventh inning. Heusser succeeded Bill Walker in the fifth.

CHICAGO, April 26 (AP). -- The hustling Chicago White Sox battered four St. Louis pitchers for five home runs and eleven other hits today to trounce the Browns, 11 to 4, in the series opener and take possession of second place in the American League.
BUENOS AIRES, April 26. -- The present fighting between the Bolivians and Paraguayans is the most violent of the Chaco war, now in progress in most three years.

One of the largest Sixth Avenue deals in the midtown area to be closed in some time was announced yesterday by Benjamin Winter, operator, who disposed of the southwest corner of Sixth Avenue and Forty-seventh Street. The property was said to have brought about $1,000,000.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26. -- Temple defeated Villanova today by 14 to 9 in a free-hitting game. The Owls found three Villanova pitchers for fifteen hits. Ken Berry, Temple southpaw, settled down after a shaky start. He struck out fourteen.

The Mexican peso soared 2.50 cents in dollar value to a new high for more than two years at 31.20 cents yesterday in response to the continued advance in silver. It closed here at 30.60 cents, up 1.90 cents net and about 2.70 cents over the quotation maintained for about two years prior to last Thursday.

Race followers who go to Jamaica today will see what amounts almost to a preview of the Kentucky Derby in the tenth running of the $10,000 added Wood Memorial Stakes for 3-year-olds at a mile and seventy yards.

LONDON, April 26. -- The Pilgrim Trust founded by Edward S. Harkness in 1930 has announced three gifts in honor of the King's silver jubilee. First is 5,000 to King George's Jubilee Trust, which the Prince of Wales is organizing to provide healthy recreation for the youth of the country.
PHILADELPHIA, April 26. -- A friendly sun shone with great kindliness upon the efforts of the Yankees today.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- NRA officials said tonight that the Spielman motor case, regarded as one of the crucial tests of the recovery program, would have to be dropped by New York State along with all other lawsuits brought under the Schackno Act now declared unconstitutional by the New York Court of Appeals.

Having only fifteen cents in his pocket, Leo Metlick, 50 years old, a janitor of the tenement house at 1,365 First Avenue, where he lives, was permitted yesterday to work out a $1 fine by sweeping the street in front of his house to escape the alternative of a one-day term in jail.
More than 1,000 persons, including high-ranking army officers, attended the tenth annual military ball of the New York University chapter of Scabbard and Blade at the Waldorf-Astoria last night.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 26. -- A big and powerful Cornell varsity and three other Big Red crews will open the local rowing season against the Navy tomorrow. Races will be for the varsities, junior varsities, plebe-freshmen and 150-pounders.

Net profit of the Schenley Distillers Corporation and subsidiaries for the quarter ended on March 31 was reported yesterday as $1,587,622 after interest, depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges. This was equivalent to $1.51 a share on 1,050,000 shares of $5 par capital stock.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP). -- Collectors and the Postoffice Department, which recently differed over the Farley ungummed "gift sheets" that brought about the March 15 "special printing," are combining efforts to make the fif tieth annual meeting of the American Philatelic Society here next August outstanding.

A "Soiree Francaise" will be held on Monday night in the concert hall of the Barbizon-Plaza as the initial step toward the founding in New York of a French school of secondary education to be located at the French Institute, 22 East Sixtieth Street, of which Dr. A. Hamilton Rice is president.

BERLIN, April 26. -- The Boerse again was weak today. Heavy industrials showed relatively large losses, Hoesch dropping 2 points, Klockner 1 3/4, Dubian 2 and Rhenish Brown Coal 3. Machines were only slightly weaker, dropping on an average 3/4 to 1 point.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- Thomas W. Lamont, a director, held 26,967 common shares of the International Agricultural Corporation as of April 1, and Albert H. Wiggin owned 9,124 prior preference, the company's registration statement to the Securities and Exchange Commission revealed today.
The first twenty railways to report showed declines in both gross revenue and net operating income in March, compared with March, 1934. The totals were above those for the short month of February.

CHICAGO, April 26. -- The directors of Montgomery Ward Co. wiped out arrears on the Class A stock today, following the annual stockholders' meeting. Payment of $5.25 a share on the A stock will be made on July 1 to shareholders of record June 20. It includes the last $3.50 on arrears and covers the current quarter ended on June 30.

Approximately 250 additional companies whose securities are listed on the New York Stock Exchange have notified the Exchange that they will file applications for permanent registration under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 before May 15.

LOURDES, France, April 26 (AP). -- Bishop James Edward Kearney of Salt Lake City lifted his voice in prayers for peace as he celebrated high mass at 9 A.M. today before a great assemblage of pilgrims at the famous shrine of Lourdes, where Catholics from the world over are praying for peace during three days and nights.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- The machinery for the $4,000,000,000 spending program designed to provide a job for every employable person on relief rolls was completed by President Roosevelt today with the designation of Harry L. Hopkins as Administrator of the Works Progress Division.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- Carrying out the policy of House leadership for wide open procedure, even on important administration bills, the Rules Committee today denied a request by the Banking and Currency Committee for a "gag" rule on the Omnibus Banking Bill and ordered that every opportunity be provided to debate or amend the measure.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- The largest naval appropriation bill since 1920 calling for expenditure of $457,805,261 during the next fiscal year, the construction of twenty-four new ships and 555 airplanes, and the addition of 11,677 officers and men was approved by the House today without a record vote.

C. Bascom Slemp, former secretary to President Coolidge and former Republican National Committeeman from Virginia, filed suit in Supreme Court here yesterday against Claudius H. Huston, former Republican National Chairman. Mr. Slemp wants to collect from Mr. Huston $10,000 spent in the Virginia campaign in 1929.

The members of the American Newspaper Publishers Association at their annual convention at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday adopted the following memorial necrology, presented in resolution form by Hilton U. Brown of The Indianapolis News:

TOKYO, April 26. -- Breaking the silence that the leading newspapers hitherto have observed, the Nichi Nichi today attacks the United States fleet manoeuvres and American naval air policy in the Pacific as showing that "the American Navy is doing all it can to maintain world supremacy and carry out trans-Pacific naval operations" by coming within 500 to 600 miles of Japan's outposts.

The traditional "last Tuesday in the month" will bring out the United States Steel Corporation's first-quarter report after the close of the markets that day. Wall Street is in considerable doubt as to what the statement will reveal. Usually well-informed sources suggest that the corporation will report the second largest profit from operations since the second quarter of 1931.

LONDON, April 26. -- The stock markets here were more active today, particularly industrials, which strengthened as the result of many good dividends and reports recently published. British funds continued in demand with confidence regarding cheap money, although profit-taking reduced early gains.

LONDON, April 26. -- The diplomatic correspondent of the Laborite Daily Herald reports that the German Government has placed orders in German shipyards for the construction of a number of submarines, which are expressly forbidden by Article 181 of the Treaty of Versailles.

Two couples stepped off the Welfare Island ferry at the foot of East Eighty-sixth Street at 2:10 o'clock yesterday afternoon and walked up the hill alongside Carl Schurz Park. They were wrangling and one of the women was crying, but they attracted no attention from the 250 children playing behind the iron fence.

Tonight's outward-bound attractions, as already announced, are "Revenge With Music" and "The Green Pastures." The first leaves after 158 performances at the New Amsterdam and disappears into history; the second, having had a return engagement of seventy-one showings at the Forty-fourth Street, will only pause until Labor Day, when it takes to the familiar road again.

It is difficult to say in which country Prime Minister MACDONALD'S violent attack upon the Hitler regime caused more surprise -- Germany or England. Germany was both surprised and offended. She had long been accustomed to think of Mr. MACDONALD as her best friend among European statesmen.

During the early days of the NRA it was said by at least one man in high position that business was being given one last chance, and it was implied that if the chance were not availed of dire happenings would follow.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26. -- Confidence in the future of American railroads, modified by a warning that government ownership would be "disastrous," was voiced today, by Martin W. Clement in his first interview since he became president of the Pennsylvania Railroad on Wednesday, succeeding General W. W. Atterbury.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 26. -- Before a large, enthusiastic gallery and under a clear, warm sky, J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange, N.J., defeated Marcel Rainville of Montreal today and earned the right to meet Wilmer Allison in the men's final of the Mason-Dixon tennis championship tomorrow.

A further dislocation in silver, resuiting largely from the widespread impression that the United States Treasury would soon order another advance in the government's buying price for newly mined domestic metal, obscured developments in other markets yesterday.

Adolf Gobel, Inc., yesterday filed a petition in the Federal court in Brooklyn for reorganization under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act, according to V. D. Skipworth, president of the company. The directors, he said, had decided to take this action at their monthly meeting on Thursday, which followed the stockholders' meeting.

The decline and fall of WILBUR GLENN VOLIVA should be of interest to planned economists and collectivizers. In Zion, Ill., formerly Zion City, he held absolute rule over 6,000 people for a period of twenty-eight years. Back in 1906 he wrested the sceptre from the enfeebled hands of Zion City's founder, J. ALEXANDER DOWIE.
It may be of interest to point the connection between THE TIMES editorial "No Escape" and a news item headed "Japanese Go After Panama Hat Trade."
NANKING, China, April 26. -- Economic warfare between China and Siam is imminent and China is considering imposition of a ban on imports of Siamese rice.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):

Shoulder to shoulder, 150 cadet members of the Knickerbocker Greys marched in soldierly stride yesterday afternoon before Major Gen. William N. Haskell and other army officers at the fifty-fourth annual Spring review of the Greys at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

The constitutionality of the Securities Act of 1933 and of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 was challenged yesterday in Federal Court in an answer filed by attorneys for J. Edward Jones to a suit brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission to bar him and five associates from dealing in oil royalties.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 26. -- Demonstration, racing for Mrs. Silas B. Mason, won the feature on the semi-final program of the Havre de Grace meeting today. In a driving finish and under capable handling of Jockey Charley Kurtsinger he defeated four other 3-year-olds in the Griffwood Purse, fourth event on the card.

Through thirteen innings, which lasted almost three and one-half hours, until darkness descended, the Giants and Phillies played to a 5-to-5 tie yesterday at the Polo Grounds in the opening contest of a three-game series.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, April 26. -- Toivo Antikainen, high Soviet army officer who was arrested in November as a spy, was convicted today of having ordered a young Finnish volunteer, Antti Marjoniemi, to be burned at the stake during the fighting in East Carelia in January, 1922, between Russian troops and the Finnish volunteer corps.
HARTFORD, Conn., April 26. -- Governor Cross, in his speech at the Bushnell Memorial at noon today to open the State's tercentenary celebration, said in part:

BOSTON, April 26 (AP). -- Joe Cronin, the $250,000 player-manager, set something of an altitude record today when the Boston infield blew sky-high behind Bob (Lefty) Grove and enabled the Senators to score their first victory in four starts against the Red Sox, 10 -- 5.
Howard Laramy, baritone, will assist the Amphion Chorus at the Town Hall this afternoon following a morning broadcast by the visitors from the West.

MEXICO, D.F., April 26. -- The Mexican Government, forced by the rise in the price of silver to take steps to prevent the exportation of currency, issued a decree tonight ordering the exchange of the present silver currency for paper notes of the Bank of Mexico.

Mrs. John Aspegren and her daughter, Miss Amy Aspegren, gave a dinner last night in the roof garden of the St. Regis for Miss Mary Moncrieffe Livingston and Spencer Eddy Jr., who will be married Tuesday. The other guests included:

CINCINNATI, April 26 (AP). -- The Reds fell before the Cubs, 3 to 2, today. Tex Carleton, Chicago pitcher, fanned eight and the outfield retired nine more, while Cavarretta at first base had almost a holiday, with one putout to his credit.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., April 26. -- The jury in the Dutch Schultz (Arthur Flegenheimer) income-tax evasion case went out at 11:50 o'clock this morning and, still trying to reach a verdict, was locked up for the night at 11:15 P. M. by order of Federal Judge Frederick H. Bryant.

NEWARK, N.J., April 26. -- Cliff Melton, elongated left-hander, came within an inning of pitching a no-hit game today as the Bears defeated the Buffalo Bisons, 4 to 2, in the third game of their series.

Jerome D. Barnum, publisher of The Syracuse (N.Y.) Post-Standard, was elected president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association yesterday at the annual meeting of members at the Waldorf-Astoria, closing the forty-ninth annual convention of the association, which opened on Tuesday.

Mr. and Mrs. Seaman Schepps gave a supper dance last night in the Rainbow Room, Rockefeller Center, for their daughter, Miss Virginia Jane Schepps, and Kenneth Price Dillon, whose engagement was announced recently. The other guests were:

In 1609 Hendrik Hudson explored the noble river which bears his name in the hope of finding a passage to the Pacific. In 1932 Ben Marden located a spot on the Jersey heights, hard by the George Washington Bridge, which he hoped -- and discovered -- to be ideal for a Summer night club with a breathtaking view of Manhattan and the calm, majestic stream which flows by it.

Election of thirty Columbia College juniors into two rival senior honorary societies, the Nacoms and the Sachems, was announced yesterday. The Society of Nacoms was founded in 1898 and the Society of Sachems in 1915. The Blue Key Society, honorary junior society, selected twenty sophomores for membership in its group, it was announced.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses and Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan engaged in a lively dispute before the Board of Estimate yesterday on the question of which of them should supervise further development of the West Side highway.

Howard Davis, business manager of The New York Herald Tribune, received a bound volume of tributes from numerous members of the American Newspaper Publishers Association at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday on retiring from the presidency after serving three successive terms.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, wife of the President, was the special guest of honor at the Front Page Ball, 1935 edition, given last night by the New York Newspaper Women's Club at the Hotel Astor. She was accompanied by her son, James Roosevelt.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 26. -- Harvard's competitive rowing season will open formally tomorrow with three races on the Charles River Basin.

HERE'S a real horse race. The regulars of the turf will turn up disdainful noses at it because there are jumps in it, and if there's anything a railbird hates worse than a jumping race it's two jumping races. But the Maryland Hunt Cup Race is held in high favor in this corner for a few reasons that will be stated.
GEORGETOWN, Del., April 26 (AP). -- For their crime more than seven years ago, a 52-year-old mother and her oldest son must pay with their lives.

BERLIN, April 26. -- The Propaganda Ministry late today admitted that Friedrich E. Husemann, internationally famous mine workers' leader, had been "shot when attempting to escape." Herr Husemann was reported in Prague to have been killed April 15 during transfer from Bochum to a concentration camp.
LONDON, April 26. -- Ticket speculators are beginning to fear they will lose heavily on their attempt to profiteer out of the King's jubilee.

NEW ORLEANS, April 26. -- State Representative Joseph Fisher, the first of Huey P. Long's Louisiana political lieutenants indicted for alleged Income Tax Law violations to be tried, was convicted by a Federal jury late today on two of seven counts.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- Plans of the Democratic leadership to sidetrack the anti-lynching issue were balked today when the Senate refused by a margin of one vote to adjourn until Monday, an action which would have vacated the pending motion to take up the Costigan-Wagner bill.

A single into short right field by Gus Masel sent Harry Miller scurrying home with the winning run to give Long Island University a ninth-inning 7-to-6 triumph over the Manhattan College baseball team yesterday at Manhattan Field.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations, including processing tax, on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:
An extensive Spring planting program, believed by Park Department officials to be the most ambitious ever undertaken in one city, is being started in the New York park system.
Nothing happened in the credit market to distinguish it from preceding sessions. Turnover was small and quotations unchanged for all classifications.

In the manly, easy and resourceful singing of Keith Falkner at his second recital of the season in the Town Hall last night were compensations for a program slender in its musical substance. To the circumstance that this was a "request" recital may be attributed the choice of songs, which, if in no instance so inferior as to be disturbing, fell rather persistently short of distinction.

New Yorkers pay $57,000,000 every month to support their municipal government, the Citizens Budget Commission said yesterday in the fourth of its series of pamphlets showing the man in the street how much he is taxed.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26. -- Two residents of New York were among the three winners of $1,000 prizes in the national finals of the young artists' contest held here tonight in connection with the biennial convention of the National Federation of Music Clubs.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 26. -- The new Gubernatorial election in the State of Para, ordered by the Superior Electoral Tribunal, will be held within forty-eight hours. It is expected that Jose Malcher, a compromise candidate with the approval of President Getulio Vargas, will be named Governor.

BERLIN, April 26. -- More than 15,000 anti-Christians, many of them in Storm Troop uniform, filled the Sportpalast here to over-flowing tonight for the first great public assembly organized by the Nordic Pagans.
" The People's Enemy," a Select production released through RKO Radio, opens this morning at the Globe. In the cast are Preston Foster, Melvyn Douglas and Lila Lee.

WORCESTER, Mass., April 26. -- Holy Cross tucked away its third victory of the season today, defeating Princeton, 9 to 1. Dale Rice, Princeton's starting pitcher, got off to a bad start, the Crusaders scoring seven runs in the first inning on four walks, a sacrifice and four hits, including a home run by Specs Kelley.

Taking as his anchor stones a little of the "Symphony Pathetique" and a passage from Gibran's "The Prophet," Charles March has endeavored to bridge the distance between them with a drama, "Symphony," which was put on at the Cort last evening.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 26. -- There was a large attendance yesterday at the last of a series of bridge parties held at the Siwanoy Country Club, Mount Vernon. Mrs. Clinton T. Miller of Pelham, soprano, gave a program. There also was a fashion show.

Although fifty-one communities throughout the country will ask bids on new bond issues next week, the total will be for only $25,915,900, compared with this week's revised amount of $36,941,000. The weekly average for the year thus far stands at $21,504,435.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- Outlines of Secretary Morgenthau's inheritance and gift tax program which he said would be necessary to finance any pre-payment of the veterans' bonus were made public today. He estimated that such a system would yield $300,000,000 additional revenue for the fiscal year 1936, and possibly $600,000,000 annually thereafter.

Real estate investors during the four months ended last March 31 bought from the Home Title Guaranty Company almost two and one-half times as much as during the same period a year ago, Donald Carr, sales manager, reported yesterday. The respective totals were $514,000 and $207,287.

Little Mary Tine, 3 years old, of 517 East Thirteenth Street, won a dress and a gold (paper) crown yesterday when she was chosen as Queen of the little sister beauty contest at the Tompkins Square clubhouse of the Boys Club of New York, Tenth Street and Avenue A.

Those two perennial rivals, the Illinois A.C. and the New York A.C. aggregations, will battle once more for the national indoor A.A. U. hard-ball water polo championship tonight as a result of their respective triumphs last night in the Winged Foot pool.

The cargo steamers Montauk and Montana, which for many months past have been a familiar if forlorn sight laid up at Hoboken near the Lackawanna Ferry docks, were sold yesterday to an Italian shipbreaking firm. The two vessels, it is understood, will leave soon for an Italian port.

The failure of public utility officials to understand the economics of their industry has adversely affected investors as well as consumers, Basil Manly, vice chairman of the Federal Power Commission, asserted yesterday in addressing a group of college deans on the need of training for public service.

Four clergymen of different faiths who saw active service in the World War will speak Thursday evening at the Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive, at the "Service of the Covenant of Peace" held under the auspices of twenty-nine rabbis and Christian ministers to protest against the United States Navy manoeuvres to be held in the North Pacific beginning the next day.

The economic theory of one of the Federal Reserve Board's technical advisers was attacked last night by Benjamin M. Anderson Jr., economist for the Chase National Bank, at a dinner of the American Statistical Society in the Roger Smith restaurant, 40 East Forty-first Street.
New Jersey's leading skeet shooters will gather today at the Roseland Community Gun Club in Roseland to compete in the seventh annual State championships. The program will be concluded tomorrow.
DES MOINES, Iowa, April 26. -- Jesse Owens of Ohio State drove through space today to establish a new American broad-jump record, missing the world mark by three-eighths of an inch.
The "Big Top" now has a rival in town. It is a children's circus, staged by children for children and with payment for children's trips to camp this Summer as its objective.

When the ancient philosopher argued the wisdom of profiting by the folly of others he can hardly have had in mind the Bronx Terminal Market. Nevertheless, his saying points the moral of what Commissioner MORGAN is trying to do with that $17,000,000 speculation from which Mayor HYLAN expected so much and realized so little.
There is gold in every ash can, according to one of the reports read here yesterday at the closing session of the eighty-ninth meeting of the American Chemical Society.

Warning that the taxpayers of the city already have been "taxed to the limit of their capacity," representatives of fourteen civic and commercial organizations, meeting yesterday afternoon at the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, 65 Liberty Street, called upon Governor Lehman to veto the salary restoration bills for city employes, passed by the Legislature at its closing sessions.

Two men and the wife of one of them received thirty-day terms in the workhouse and were fined $250 each in Special Sessions yesterday for defrauding the city of $753 in home relief, between 1932 and 1934.

The Museum of the City of New York was visited by 171,281 persons last year, an increase bf 2,111 over 1933, according to the annual report made public yesterday. Forty-two free concerts there during the year, under the auspices of the Department of Public Welfare and the Neighborhood School, drew 9,100.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- Donald R. Richberg, acting chairman of the National Industrial Recovery Board, testifying before the Senate Munitions Committee today, took a stand sharply at odds with the decision of the National Labor Relations Board, which had held that the Colt Patent Firearms Company had refused to bargain collectively with three trade unions.

BALTIMORE, April 26. -- Everything was in readiness tonight for tomorrow's renewal of the Maryland Hunt Cup, generally regarded as the most sought after prize in amateur steeplechasing. Ten of the best timber racers in training will start in the forty-second running over the stiff four-mile course in the Worthington Valley.

Frederick Brown, who recently purchased the plot at the southeast corner of the Grand Concourse and 182d Street, added to his Bronx holdings yesterday by acquiring from the Grandside Realty Corporation the southwest corner of the Concourse and Burnside Avenue.

Word has come from Texas through the Cornell University-Carnegie Institute ornithological expedition that despite the dust storms in the West the birds have not ceased from nesting and singing. One might assume that the birds were instinctively celebrating Audubon Week, for AUDUBON'S birthday was the 26th of April in 1785.

Your editorial regarding the 300th anniversary of the founding of the Boston Public Latin School and the announcement that the anniversary is to be commemorated by the dedication of a bronze tablet with the inscription "From the seed planted here the whole American system of free education grew" is well worthy of note.

Despite the proof displayed by distributive totals that the spurt in pre-Easter buying was more than a flash, the encouraging recovery of wholesale markets, and the maintenance of industrial operations in most divisions at previous levels, sentiment in business continues to trail actual trade improvement, according to the weekly survey of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The most obvious way of finding out how anything is constructed is to break it into pieces. Smaller and smaller the pieces became until at last hammer and crushers could do no more. Then the atom was created, once supposed to be the smallest indivisible chemical unit of matter. More hammering, now by particles shot forth either by radium or by electrical guns, reduces the atom to electrons, protons, neutrons and positrons.

Plans for a new six-story apartment house to be erected immediately at the southeast corner of Lexington Avenue and Fifty-second Street were announced yesterday by the Sharp Nassoit Management Corporation, which will have general supervision of the project for the Callahan estate, the owners.

Another rise of 3 cents an ounce in the price of silver and a 2-cent advance in wheat stimulated buying on the Cotton Exchange again yesterday, and prices moved into new high ground for the week, to close with gains of 12 to 17 points.

So that thousands of New Yorkers will not be deprived again of an outing in Palisades Interstate Park this week-end, the Park Commissioners will establish an emergency ferry service from Dyckman Street, Manhattan, if New York City does not reverse its stand today on the operation of the Dyckman Street Ferry.

The death of Sophie K. Levy on Oct. 28, 1934, makes available $534,924.61 for distribution to the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies under the terms of the will of her brother, William B. Kaufman, who died on Dec. 3, 1925.

After having been in preparation for more than two years, "Eyes of the World," a photographic record of history in the making, edited by M. Lincoln Schuster, has finally gone to press, Simon Schuster announce. This book will chronicle, through the medium of photographs and other facsimile documentation, high points of world history during the last eighteen months. It is scheduled for June publication.

Fire virtually destroyed St. Francis de Sales Roman Catholic Church, a two-story frame building, at Rockaway Beach Boulevard and Beach 129th Street, Belle Harbor, Queens, late yesterday afternoon, causing damage estimated by the pastor, the Rev. John J. Patterson, at $150,000.

Construction of the Sixth Avenue subway line will be started soon, regardless of whether or not the city obtains from the PWA a loan of $57,000,000 required to finance the work, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday after he had conferred with John H. Delaney, chairman of the Board of Transportation, and City Chamberlain A. A. Berle Jr.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., April 26. -- The Springfield College baseball team turned in its eighth straight victory of the season in beating Pratt Institute of Brooklyn today, 18-2.
HARTFORD, Conn., April 26 (AP). -- Homage to the men who laid the foundation of Connecticut's government was paid here today as the State formally opened its tercentenary celebration.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 26. -- Syracuse University's hard-hitting nine defeated Hamilton College, I7-0, today for its second shutout victory in two days.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- A statement that neutrality offers no certain road for keeping out of war was made by Henry L. Stimson, former Secretary of State, before the American Society of International Law tonight. The only certain way to achieve that object, he said, is, through collective action of nations, to prevent war from taking place.

International speculation in silver yesterday brought further sharp advances on the world's market, and foreign silver in New York rose to 81 cents, or 4 cents above the 77 cents quoted for domestic mined silver .999 fine, which is virtually the equivalent of the Treasury price of 77.57 cents an ounce for silver 1.000 fine.

BERLIN, April 26. -- Leaders of the rapidly growing Germanic Pagan Faith Movement boldly rejected Christianity tonight at a Nazi-sanctioned rally and said God had "revealed himself to us" through Adolf Hitler.

SHANGHAI, April 26. -- In a speech giving the keynote of the Chinese reaction to the visit of the American trade mission headed by W. Cameron Forbes, Chang Kai-n Gau, veteran banker, tonight expressed regret "that the United States Congress is so completely ignorant of China's position regarding silver and so ill-informed on the economic situation in China" as to persist in the silver-buying policy.

More than 1,000 pupils, students and teachers of the grades of the Ethical Culture Schools, ranging from kindergarten to normal school, assembled yesterday morning in the institution's building, 2 West Sixty-fourth Street, to pay tribute to the memory of Felix Adler, the educator who founded the schools fifty-seven years ago.

Charges of fraud and misappropriation of funds were brought against Samuel Levy, Borough President of Manhattan, in a suit filed yesterday in Federal court by Ferdinanda Backer, mother and guardian of three grandchildren of the late George Backer, at one time one of the city's wealthiest builders.

Suspension of two American Legion posts in Manhattan on the ground that members have picketed a Brooklyn burlesque and movie theatre while wearing American Legion insignia and uniforms has been asked by Irving M. Saunders, Kings County Legion commander, it was learned yesterday.

Twenty-one boys, 12 to 15 years old, who visited Yorkville Court yesterday got an insight into the workings of crime and punishment and heard a debate on the higher and lower forms of literary criticism applied to Gustave Flaubert's "November" by Morris Ernst and John S. Sumner, New York's vice crusader.

NEWPORT, R.I., April 26. -- A dinner for a company of fifty was given this evening by Mrs. E. Maitland Armstrong at her home, Kingscote, for Miss Marion M. Wilson, daughter of Mrs. Richard T. Wilson, and Lieutenant William A. M. Morin, U.S.A., who are to be married at noon tomorrow at Shady Lawn, the Wilson villa, and the members of the prospective wedding party.

ALBANY, April 26. -- The Quinn bill, writing into State law the provisions of the Norris-La Guardia Federal Act prescribing methods for issuance of injunctions in labor disputes, was signed by Governor Lehman today.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 26. -- In well-informed circles it was said this evening that it was unlikely that the government would modify in any sense the existing legislation covering partial resumption of the foreign debt obligations in accordance with the proposal put before foreign bondholders in New York and London by the official commissions sent abroad for that purpose.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- An amendment to the code for the electrical manufacturing industry prohibiting members from selling below current net price lists, was approved today by the National Industrial Recovery Board effective May 10.

Boston came to Brooklyn yesterday, but Babe Ruth stayed at home. Thirteen thousand fans who turned out to welcome the mighty man to Ebbets Field forgot their disappointment, however, as the Dodgers humbled the Braves, 5 -- 4, for their fifth consecutive victory of the current campaign and continued to lead the league.

The following monthly shareholding reports were filed yesterday with the New York Stock Exchange by officers, directors and principal stockholders of listed companies in compliance with the Securities Act of 1934:

In enacting a plan of unemployment insurance New York becomes one of the pioneer States in taking a step which enlightened opinion now recognizes to be necessary. While such insurance is not the panacea or unqualified blessing that some of its advocates believe it to be, it is better than either of the alternatives to it -- callous public neglect of the plight of the jobless or unsystematic doles.
