Eleven men and four women, all members of the Office Workers Union, were arrested yesterday at noon during mass picketing at the Curb Exchange, 86 Trinity Place. Several thousand persons witnessed the demonstration, which was dispersed by more than two dozen policemen.
ALBANY, April 26. -- Following is the text of the prevailing opinion in the Court of Appeals decision on the Schackno law and vital sections of the dissenting opinion:

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- Further gains in employment and payrolls during March were reported today by the Federal Reserve Board's monthly business survey, although industrial output fell to 88 per cent of the 1923-25 average, compared with 89 per cent in February and 90 per cent in January.

SOFIA, April 26. -- Private couriers from Athens bring news, suppressed by the Greek military censor, that the executions of the Venizelist Generals Papoulas, 79 years old, and Kimissis, 60, were carried out Wednesday, despite strong verbal representations by the French and British Ministers.

CLEVELAND, April 26 (AP). -- The Cleveland Indians scored an easy victory over the Detroit Tigers today, 11 to 3. Two successive home runs in the third inning, one by Hale with two men on bases and one by Campbell, accounted for four of the Indians' runs.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in the State, now offered by dealers:
Your editorial on literary plagiarism leads me to wonder if many people are aware of the deadly possibilities inherent in unconscious plagiarism.

Polly Adler withdrew in Special Sessions yesterday her previous plea of guilty to having obscene motion pictures in her apartment last March 5 when the police raided it. Justices Gresser, Walling and Caldwell thereupon set her trial for May 6 on this charge and another that she conducted an objectionable resort in the apartment house.

LONDON, April 26. -- Asserting that all the driving power for which President Franklin D. Roosevelt is famous will be needed if the grandiose program of work relief is to produce results, The Times editorially says the whole future of the New Deal depends on its success.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 26. -- Miss Elizabeth Hovey's helmsmanship brought the six-meter yacht Jill to victory again today in the international races for the Prince of Wales Cup, putting the Boston sloop in the lead in the series by one-quarter of a point.

Retail trade was rather spotty during the week, with the average of consumer response to current clearances ranging from fair to good. In some cases, stocks of coats and suits have been a little more difficult to move than was anticipated, although the expectation is that clearances will be successfully completed during the coming week.

The plan for reorganization of the Fox Metropolitan Playhouses, Inc., sponsored by Simon H. Fabian, moving-picture theatre operator, which promises the noteholders 20 per cent in cash and 80 per cent in debentures, was attacked yesterday at the hearing before Federal Judge Julian W. Mack in the County Lawyers Association Building, 14 Vesey Street.

Dr. Samuel T. Orton of New York, former president of the American Psychiatric Association and the Association for Research in Nervous and Mental Diseases, has been selected for the 1936 Salmon Memorial Award, it was announced last night by Dr. C.C. Burlingame at a meeting in the New York Academy of Medicine.

The third Eastern regional conference of the National Association of Bank Auditors and Controllers began a two-day session yesterday in the Hotel Montclair with addresses by a dozen banking executives on various auditing problems. About 300 bank officials are attending the conference, of which E.T. Ward of the New York Agency, Bank of Montreal, is general chairman.

BELGRADE, April 26. -- On Sunday, May 5, in Yugoslavia the first European dictatorship to risk a popular verdict will face the electors. For the first time the government has not forbidden all except its supporters as candidates.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- As a result of excited speculative activities in the world markets, and the protests of other nations, the Treasury today halted temporarily its program of raising the price at which it will buy newly mined silver every time the world price exceeded the fixed quotation.

CHICAGO, April 26. -- Few hogs were for sale today in the local market after those sent direct to packers had been deducted. Reports indicated easiness in Eastern fresh pork markets, but there was little change in prices of hogs, the top being 5 cents a hundredweight below the $9.20 paid early yesterday and the day's average being unchanged to $8.90.

The resignations of two directors of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad on the eve of its reorganization were disclosed in the report of the company for 1934, issued yesterday. One of the directors was Michael J. Cleary, president of the Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company.

We have public health laws in this city which require that all persons, particularly children, who have communicable diseases such as diphtheria, measles, scarlet fever, and so on, shall be confined to their homes or elsewhere until such time as all danger of contagion has passed. The exception to this rule is whooping cough, which is best treated by fresh air and continuation of normal outdoor activities.

NASSAU, Bahamas, April 26. -- After the jury trying him had been out for only ten minutes, Victor Humphrey, a British youth charged with the brutal murder last January of Fred Kamler, German manager of a swimming pool here, was acquitted.

The Brooklyn Union Gas Company reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on March 31 a net income of $2,533,501, excluding revenues of $1,024,127 held in suspense and interest accrued on them. The net income was equivalent to $3.40 a share on the average of 744,200 no-par shares of capital stock outstanding, during the year.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- The dollar value of stocks and bonds traded in on the national securities Exchanges of the country in March aggregated $973,845,485, compared with $824,489,314 in the previous month and $1,202,822,707 in January, a compilation by the Securities and Exchange Commission showed today.

BERLIN, April 26. -- The International Film Congress, meeting here under the patronage of Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, Propaganda Minister, began its sessions yesterday in the Kroll Opera House, the temporary Reichstag building. Forty nations, with about 2,000 representatives, are participating, according to an official announcement.

A shipment of animals and unusual birds arrived yesterday from Germany on the Hamburg-American liner Albert Ballin, marking the beginning of the Spring season in transporting animals here for zoos and parks.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- The release of atomic energy 200,000,000 times greater than the amount of energy applied was reported here today by physicists of Columbia University before the American Physical Society. The development was hailed as the greatest advance so far toward the practical utilization of the inconceivably large quantities of energy known to be locked in the heart of atoms.

IN the perennial conflict between city and country dwellers Mrs. Carroll has clearly chosen sides. Her second novel, like her first, defends and glorifies the rural way of life, admits that it is arduous, but insists on its rewards. "A Few Foolish Ones" is another glowing Maine chronicle -- wider in scope than "As the Earth Turns," but equally appreciative of the traditional New England virtues.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 26. -- California's State University at Berkeley, with its 13,000 students and a faculty that has been rated as second only to Harvard's in scholarly achievement, has been dragged into the centre of the storm raging around anti-Red bills pending before the Legislature at Sacramento.

Edmund Sousso of Egypt clinched first place in the nineteenth annual Poggenburg Memorial Cup 18.2 balkline tournament by defeating Lester Fisher, 300-55, at the Lawler Brothers' Manhattan Academy last night. With runs of 163 and 105 unfinished Soussa triumphed in seven innings.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- The government's silver-buying program, which has ruled the world's trading for nearly a year, was abruptly advanced this week for the second time in a fortnight when the price of newly mined domestic metal was raised to 77.57 an ounce.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Outstanding points of the administration's legislative program were sorted today by President Roosevelt for inclusion in another "fireside chat" which he plans to deliver over the nation-wide radio circuits at 10 o'clock (Eastern standard time) tomorrow night.

MAIRLBURY is one of those quiet and lovely English villages. Denchester is one of those big manufacturing cities which at the time of the novel, sometime in the near future, is wallowing in industrial doldrums. The great hunger march of 30,O00 workers is moving from various parts of England converging toward London.

CINCINNATI, April 27 (AP). -- Pitcher Paul Derringer won his own game today as the Reds defeated the Cubs, 2 to 1. He held the Cubs helpless, fanning the last four men to face him, and he bunted in a squeeze play in the fourth inning to score Goodman with what proved to be the winning run.

The Chinese Government took occasion last week to renew its protest against our silver purchase policy. To the leader of the "silver bloc" in Congress. Senator PITTMAN of Nevada, this will doubtless constitute fresh proof that the Chinese really do not know what is good for them. Only a few days ago Mr. PITTMAN told the Senate that it is "perfectly absurd" to think that our policy is ruining China.

CHICAGO. -- The Chicago City Council is in a tight fix. The Mayor has gone to Honolulu for a month's vacation and the Supreme Court of Illinois has decreed that the Council must pay back $800,000 to the judges, clerks and bailiffs of the municipal court, representing economy deductions from their salaries.

IN the new railroad time-tables, which go into effect today with daylight saving, two New York-Chicago trains, the Twentieth Century Limited and the Broadway Limited, are scheduled to make the run between the two cities in seventeen hours.

DEMAND for copies of the first edition of "World Short-Wave Radiophone Transmitters'' compiled by Lawrence D. Batson, of the Electrical Division of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce, Washington, D.C., has resulted in a new and more complete book.

PASADENA, Calif., April 27 (AP). -- New secrets of the heavens are disclosed by a nine-year job of cataloguing all the brighter stars, together with a few faint ones of peculiar color or motion, completed tonight at Mount Wilson Observatory.

Opening the outdoor bench show season in the New York area, the thirty-second annual exhibition of the Ladies' Kennel Association of America will be given on the fair grounds at Mineola, L.I., on Saturday, May 18. Entries are due to close Saturday.

FORMS never shaped before, sounds contained in no instrument, materials, textures, colors called into being by man -- these are some of the things cast up on the doorstep of art by science and its offspring, mass industry.

THE Pacific Coast will bid for American tourist travel this Summer, with the California International Exposition scheduled to open on May 29 at Balboa Park in San Diego. Three thousand workmen are engaged in the task of transforming the 1,400-acre park into a show ground where the progress of the world in a variety of fields will be displayed for the next seven months.

LONDON, April 27. -- Visitors to London for the King's jubilee will see a city looking fresher than for centuries past. After years of work and an expenditure running into hundreds of thousands of pounds, several of the most famous public buildings, including the Houses of Parliament and Westminster Abbey, have been so restored that they now appear much the same as they did when they were first built.

WHATEVER else may be said of Professor McLaughlin's constitutional history, it is indubitably the product of an independent and keenly analytic mind. On controversial details innumerable it cuts to the quick and lays bare the source of error.

Plans for the promotion of "a loyalty campaign" to further Americanism and to combat "the sinister forces which are stirring up class dissensions" were announced yesterday by executive members of America's Good-Will Union, a patriotic organization which has sponsored activities along these lines during the last twelve years.
ALL out of breath, an agitated matron rushed into a book store in a New York railway terminal one morning some years ago. "I want 'Holt on Feeding of Children.'" she said. "I must have it at once."

ISTANBUL, April 26. -- Despite optimistic declarations by the statesmen who took part in the Stresa conference, it covered so wide a range of conflicting interests that many countries are now wondering what will be the final outcome.

MOSCOW, April 26. -- There is only one subject of conversation in Moscow these days -- the new subway. Young people and old are trying to wangle passes for the free rides which are preceding the opening of the route to regular commercial traffic,

THE SEXES: Lady Astor addressed the International Alliance of Women for Suffrage and Equal Citizenship at Istanbul last week, saying: "I shouldn't think women would want to resemble men, for the more we look at men the less we want to look like them. We women seek to raise the moral standing of mankind and teach our children to live, not die, for their country."

MILAN, Italy, April 27 (AP). -- Cotton was king in this Italian textile centre tonight as delegates from most of the great countries of the world gathered here for preliminary session of the seventeenth International Cotton Congress tomorrow.
GENEVA, April 27. -- Elsewhere it may seem only a week since the Council of the League of Nations condemned Germany, but in Geneva it seems months.

THE published works of George Gibbs total nearly forty volumes of miscellaneous fiction -- mystery, adventure, historical and problem novels. His latest is an adventure story. Two jail-mates escape from a Portuguese prison in Angola, the elder, Dutch Brand, having been jogged six years for self-defensively killing a man.

Completion Tuesday of the Pacific Clipper's round-trip flight to Honolulu caused a stir in foreign trade circles here last week, where the possibilities of a transpacific airline carrying mail, express and passengers are regarded as of prime importance to the promotion of trade between this country, its Pacific outposts and China.

ISTANBUL, April 27. -- Thirty delegates to the International Womens Congress for Suffrage and Equal Citizenship visited Angora yesterday, and in the evening they were received by President Mustafa Kemal. They talked with him for two hours.
CHICAGO, April 27. -- A number of Western public enemies, dust particles, were captured by a scientific detective squad today after a 100-mile-an-hour chase across the skies.

THERE is a rumor going around that the clubs of London are dying. It is perhaps not the newest of rumors, for it was certainly going the rounds as far back as the Boer War and it may have been far from new even then If it is a true rumor, the clubs of London seem to be taking a long time in dying.

Don Ruddy took a pass from Adolph Winkler with just a bit more than a minute to go and jammed the ball past Fred Lauer, husky goal keeper, to give the New York Athletic Club a 4 to 3 triumph over the Illinois A.C. and possession of the National Senior A.A.U. hard ball water polo championship last night in the Winged Foot pool.

MANY years ago Henri Bergson's "Creative Evolution" was one of the most widely discussed philosophical books in this country. The fame of the author spread from philosophical circles to the larger public, and he acquired something of the vogue enjoyed in more recent years by Professor Einstein.

George Herman Ruth went hitless, the Braves halted Casey Stengel's Dodgers, 4 to 2, and tumbled them into second place, so 21,000 Flatbush fans who yesterday paid to see the fun at Ebbets Field didn't care much for what they witnessed.

The first of two "Gala Swedish Nights" was held in Carnegie Hall last night, with a musical program of orchestral, choral and solo numbers followed by folk dances and the showing of a film, "Sweden, Land of the Vikings." Participating were the Northern Orchestral Society, Josef Tort, conductor, Jacob M. Velt, guest conductor; the Swedish Glee Club, Erik Leidzen, conductor; Alma Michelini, soprano, Samuel Youngquist, tenor, and the Kungsholm Folk Dancers.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Tremendous quantities of steel, lumber, cement, clay products, electrical equipment and piping will be needed for the new Federal works projects. The extent of the participation of various industries is indicated roughly by figures in the United States census of construction for 1929.

The country's interest in chain letters in their varied manifestations was shown last week when the Denver postoffice was flooded by a "Send-a-Dime" scheme. While this perpetual-motion plan was devised, it seems, only to gain quick unearned wealth for its participants, chain letters generally are designed to sell goods, from fountain pens to silk hose, to arouse interest in a movement, man or issue, or to stir up religious or patriotic feeling.

In one of the most turbulent sessions of the Mayor's Commission on Conditions in Harlem, Edward Corsi, director of the Home Relief Bureau, asserted yesterday that his department did not discriminate against Negroes. He was the main witness at a hearing of a subcommittee on relief agencies at the Seventh District Municipal Court, 447 West 151st Street.

PARIS, April 25. -- The forthcoming Paris exhibition of Italian primitives casts its shadow before, inspiring Agnes's millinery mode. She is influenced by the halos of medieval saints, using them for high, upturned brims; rakishly, she slants them diagonally from one temple to the other, placing them on a skull cap which is lengthened into a bandeau on the wide section of the forehead.

Of the many fascinating aspects of deep-sea fishing, possibly the most alluring is the prospect of encountering the unusual. When the angler goes to sea in a boat, he never knows what will happen next. A recent incident in Florida waters is typical.

We are the advertising agents for the Mexican Government, with reference to the broadcasts of the "Mexican Musical Tours" over NBC network stations. Therefore, we are intimately concerned with the attack made upon our March 21 radio program, sponsored by our client.

The captain of the new French liner Normandie and the officers of his staff will be guests of honor at the Lace Ball to be held on Friday in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria, according to an announcement just made by the committee for the ball.

PHILADELPHIA, April 27. -- Pouncing on the one-mile relay championship with a desperation that sprang from the virtual forfeit of its two distance titles, Manhattan raced the eight furlongs in the clinking time of 3:16.3 today, the second fastest in the forty-one-year history of the Penn Relay Carnival.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- While silver broke in the world market, the Treasury maintained today its silence of the last two days concerning its future buying-price policy, and officially extended that silence over the week-end.

Major and minor insignia were granted this year by the City College student council to eleven seniors for their service to the college in extracurricular activities, it was announced yesterday. The names of the recipients will be listed in gold (major) or silver lettering on the council roll of honor in the principal corridor of the main building.

PARIS, April 27 (AP) -- Reports that Germany was building submarines were seen in French naval circles tonight as offering the opportunity to force "a showdown" on the whole status of the German Navy, including her demands for 35 per cent of the British tonnage.

TRAVEL from America to Europe promises to be much larger this year than last. The current of visitors from across the Atlantic will flow through new continental channels as well as the old ones. One stream will move toward England, where the King's Jubilee opens a Summer of festival; another will be diverted toward Soviet Russia, scene of a social experiment that puzzles and yet attracts.

Wherever yacht clubs and boat yards dot the shores of harbors, coves and rivers along those thousands of miles of metropolitan waterways that are spanned between Greenport or Sag Harbor and the towns upstream on the Hudson a good many thousands of New Yorkers today will take a new lease on life.

PITTSBURGH, April 26. -- The Mellon tax suit is transforming a name into an individual. For nearly all of his long business life in Pittsburgh, A.W. Mellon was a mysterious figure except to a comparatively small group of intimates.

FOR any one desirous of increasing his stock of sea lore without plunging into the technical works necessary to the actual practice of seamanship and navigation, no better book could be found than "Sea Lanes." The material of its three-hundred-odd pages has been contributed mainly by Captain Jonas Pendlebury, whose richly stored lockers of memory hold the wisdom and experience of forty sailoring years.

LONDON, April 18. -- "The joint effort of Italy and France, together with the cooperation achieved between France and Russia, has had the result of making war improbable in Europe this year," said the military expert. "The reply to Germany's rearmament, has been so powerful that for the moment the best Berlin can do is to keep quiet."

Market quotations for silver reacted sharply yesterday after two days of silence in the Treasury Department, whose previous statements of policy had been accepted as indicating that the price for domestic newly mined metal would be maintained above the world level.

IN the nineteenth century an editor of a newspaper in Pennsylvania faked a letter which he attributed to a great sixteenth-century preacher, Cotton Mather. The spurious document told of a plan to sell a shipload of Quakers into slavery for rum and sugar, to benefit Puritan ministers, and it was signed, "Yours in ye bowells of Christ, Cotton Mather."

This story has previously been published in Mystery Magazine under the title "Murder Madness," a more revealing title than the one chosen by the present publishers. Dinsmore, situated somewhere in the North Woods, is the home of the Dinsmore family, consisting of Deborah Dinsmore and her two brothers, Stephen and Jim.

LONDON, April 17, 1935. NOVELTIES have been plentiful recently, so plentiful that on one night it became necessary to choose between two equally important events. A hitherto unfamiliar Schubert symphony, left unfinished at the composer's death and completed by Weingartner, was being performed at the Queen's Hall, while the London Museum concerts offered a rival attraction in two unknown works of Beethoven.

Assured of an active market for merchandise this Fall, manufacturers of furniture will raise prices on all types of goods 5 to 10 per cent, according to opinions expressed here last week by producers and retailers who attended the advertising conference held at the Hotel Pennsylvania by the National Retail Furniture Association.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- It did not require any expert political weather man to predict the storm that broke in the Senate this week over the attempt of Senators Costigan and Wagner to force consideration of their anti-lynching bill.

BROADLY speaking. Michelangelo's life (1475-1564) spans what is perhaps the most exuberantly creative, brilliant, and certainly the most dangerous period to individual life and property in modern history -- the High Renaissance.

Captain Alexander Collie, master of the Anchor liner Caledonia, said yesterday before sailing for Glasgow that, while no official statement had been given out by the company, he had every reason to believe that the fleet had been sold to W. Runciman Co. of Newcastle-on-Tyne, who operate a fleet of twenty-one ships known as the Moor Line.
EL PASO, Texas, April 27. -- Near McPherson, Kan., the hoofs of cattle kick up dry whorls of dust. There the transcontinental traveler enters the gateway of the dust area.

DETROIT, April 26. -- The organization of the Michigan chapter of the National Union for Social Justice here this week opened a new phase of activity for the Rev. Father Charles E. Coughlin. For three years Father Coughlin has been planning the creation of a national political instrument, for five months he has been talking about it on the air.

BERLIN, April 27. -- Twice in this past week Nordic paganism has flaunted proudly in the face of Christian Germany its public recognition by the government and its position as a possible ally of the Nazi party in the State's struggle with Christian confessions.

NEW BRUNSWICK. N.J., April 27. -- Rutgers University's annual Summer session will open on July 1 and continue until Aug. 9, with an anticipated enrolment of 1,000 students, most of whom will be New Jersey school teachers, Dean Clarence E. Partch of the School of Education announced today.

FRANK BUCK is a careful hero who is determined not to become a bore. The Sultan of Johore's friendly name for him is "Mr. American Bluff." "Meaning," as Mr. Buck puts it, "what he means." Bluff or not, Mr. Buck knows listener-psychology.

On its first visit to the East the Amphion Male Chorus, composed of 106 business and professional men of Fargo, N.D., and Moorhead, Minn., gave a concert in the Town Hall yesterday afternoon that was characterized by enthusiasm and a praiseworthy degree of finish.

THE constant stream of new books about composers of past generations who have supposedly been amply treated by original investigators, may in many cases, perhaps not all be attributed to the finding of new material, new facts, new explanations of old ones Sometimes something of it may be attributed to a felt need of new presentation.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 27. -- Yale today evened its annual series with the University of Pennsylvania and won its first Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League victory, 7 to 6, tallying the deciding marker in the ninth.

A nation-wide movement to eliminate unfair trade practices, particularly predatory price-cutting, in the drug industry, will be launched on Wednesday when representatives of a portion of the 30,000 retail members of the Drug Institute of America, Inc., convene here, it was announced yesterday by the institute.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 27. -- A stylish Princeton varsity that commanded attention by its defeat of the Penn A.C. eight, national eight-oar champions, in its opening race of the current season, continued its success on the Charles River today.

EVER since, in 1867, the sons of Guillot accidentally produced the first rose of recurrent-blooming type, which later came to be known as They gain in strength from year to year, and if thoughtfully pruned and reasonably fertilized are as permanent as a lilac, a spirea or a deutzia.

PHILADELPHIA, April 27. -- The Penn A.C. nine defeated Drexel today by a score of 8 to 1. Sam Potter got a single off Powhida in the fourth and Harry Fox hit a home run in the eighth for Drexel's only safeties.
DETROIT, April 27 (AP). -- The Rev. Father Charles E. Coughlin withheld comment today on the potential role of his National Union for Social Justice in the third party movement.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 27 (AP). -- A tunnel excavated by the Persians in 256 A.D. beneath one corner of the thirty-foot wall about the ancient city of Dura, on the Euphrates River, in Syria, was disclosed today by Yale University as probably one of the most important discoveries in military history.

DEW IN APRIL" is a good historical romance, well above the average of such excursions into the past. Its period is the early thirteenth century, the scene Provence. Gathering power as it progresses, the tale sweeps one back into a world when knights were bold, when even little novices were susceptible, and when chivalry furnished about the only golden thread in a harsh fabric.

The strong, sharp burst of speed which C.V. Whitney's Today turned on at the top of the Jamaica stretch yesterday not only won him the $14,850 Wood Memorial but drove him into favoritism for the Kentucky Derby to be run next Saturday at Churchill Downs.

PARIS. MOLYNEUX'S new collection of midsummer models specially designed for his private impression of a sun-drenched flower garden. 'Pale rose-pinks and daffodil-yellows are prominent, and separately or combined in flower -- printed chiffons.
ITHACA, N.Y., April 27. -- The establishment of two memorials is holding the attention of students and alumni of Cornell.

WINCHESTER, Va., April 27. -- Orchards big and little, on the hillsides and in the valley throughout the fruit belt known as the Shenandoah-Cumberland-Potomac district, are bursting into bloom this weekend, on the eve of the twelfth annual Shenandoah Apple Blossom Festival, to be held here Thursday and Friday.

The controversy over transactions in when-issued securities of the Alleghany Corporation would adversely affect all "when-issued" trading if it reached the courts, Frank R. Hope, president of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms, said in a letter sent yesterday to all Wall Street houses interested in the Alleghany trading.

The annual Pamphratia Ball was held under the auspices of the Association of Fraternities of Columbia College last night in John Jay Hall on the campus, climaxing a week of tea dances and other entertainments at the fraternity houses.

A PRIZE contest, restricted to native and naturalized citizens of the United States, has been announced by Ginn Co., educational publishers, with the object of bringing out songs by outstanding American composers suitable for use by American youth of school age.

THREE exhibitions at once, including a wide variety of work by five distinct exhibitors, are quartered at the Delphic Studios this week. The first and largest brings together paintings and sculpture by three Negro artists under the sponsorship of the Harmon Foundation -- the late Malvin Gray Johnson, Richmond Barthe and Sargent Johnson.

LONDON, April 7. RODNEY ACKLAND'S "The Old Ladies," produced by Mr. John Gielgud at the New Theatre, is an adaptation from Mr. Hugh Walpole's novel. In the novel there were admirable descriptions of a cathedral town which the dramatist has had to omit, and one of the old ladles had, I think, a dog of some importance which has, fortunately, been allowed to rejoin its ancestors before the curtain rises.

BERLIN, April 27 (AP). -- Wholesale arrests of Catholics allegedly violating German foreign exchange regulations were disclosed today even as opposition churchmen asserted that Nazi repression ultimately might force the worship of God underground.

Post-Easter sales thus far have not developed the anticipated volume, with the result that retail requests for goods were fewer, as the stores depended upon clearances of merchandise from their own stocks, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 27. -- Powerful inflationary forces which probably will result in at least doubling the present cost of living have been set in operation in this country, Edwin Walter Kemmerer, Professor of International Finance at Princeton University, said today to bankers of Group One of the New York State Bankers Association at their annual Spring meeting in the Statler Hotel here.

IN this book Dr. Sidney L. Gulick, writer on Far Eastern subjects, who has known the Japanese for many years, surveys Japan's problems in the light of her recent policy and procedures, and examines American policy toward Japan.

In the face of a lagging market for domestic corporation bonds, notably public utility and railroad issues, United States Government loans rallied briskly on the Stock Exchange yesterday. With one or two exceptions, government issues were bid up 1-32 to 5-32 points.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 27. -- A Summer dramatic company of University of Rochester students will make its debut soon after the closing of the college year if present plans carry through.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 27. -- Harvard beat Princeton, 6 to 4, today, making it two straight victories in the Eastern Intercollegiate League series.

An appeal is being made throughout this week by members of the New York City committee for the fourteenth annual Book Collection Week of the American Merchant Marine Library Association for books to be distributed later to men of the American merchant marine, the United States Coast Guard, lighthouse keepers and lightship crews.
KANSAS CITY, April 27. -- Mrs. Grace Sloan Overton on New York complained today that the nation's best potential maker of love matches was balking at the role.

Huey P. Long -- attired in a light tan silk poplin suit, mottled rose and green tie, lavender checked shirt and brown-and-white shoes -- strode into the Senate chamber and tossed his straw hat to a page. He gained recognition from the chair -- and promptly sailed into a violent attack on the administration.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 27. -- Nellie Flag raced to victory in the Cherokee Park Purse and Beaver Dam, an outsider, captured the Clark Handicap at Churchill Downs today, inaugurating the Spring race meeting.

Estimating that some 10,000,000 women throughout the country are lending their leisure hours to knitting, crocheting or needlepoint, the merchandising division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association yesterday reported a marked growth in the "back-to-the-knitting needle" movement.
WASHINGTON, April 27. -- James A. Moffett today accepted from President Roosevelt a furlough until August from his duties as Federal Housing Administrator, in lieu of resigning that post.

MANY strange clients have come to Perry Mason, but none stranger than Pete Brunold, who complains that some one has stolen his artificial eye and left a counterfeit in its place. Brunold is fussy about his artificial eyes.

ALTHOUGH there was no definite confirmation of the reports of revolution in Albania, the gravity of the situation was proved by the fact that it was impossible to get into telephonic communication with Tirana last night," was the solemn pronouncement recently of a news agency which ought to have known better.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 27. -- After twenty-seven hours and ten minutes of deliberation on the income-tax case of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, the trial of which started here on April 16, the jury at 3 o'clock this afternoon reported a hopeless disagreement and was discharged by Federal Judge Frederick H. Bryant at the request of John H. McEvers, chief of prosecution.

FROM aircraft engineers have come new criticisms of current automobile structure. At a meeting of the Society of Automotive Engineers held here last week William B. Stout, national president of the S.A.E., and designer of the rear-engined Scarab car, came forward with pointed comment.

ST. LOUIS, April 27 (AP). -- Jim Collins, Cardinal first baseman, hit his second and third home runs of the season today, but the Pittsburgh Pirates took the second game of their series with the world champions, 8 to 5, before a crowd of 10,000.
Commodity futures were weak or irregular yesterday in the local markets, with trading on a small scale. In the cash markets, declines appeared in wheat, rye, oats, lard and rubber.

Production of dresses wholesaling at $4.75 is virtually at a standstill, it was reported yesterday by Mortimer Lanzit, executive director of the National Dress Manufacturers Association, Inc. Estimating that current output was scarcely 20 per cent of its normal level, he said that the costs of production, which were increased between 25 and 35 per cent by the recent strike, had rendered it practically impossible for firms in that division to operate.

The most-kissed person among the 1,000 passengers who sailed for Italy yesterday on the Italian liner Rex was undoubtedly Giullo Gatti-Casazza, who has retired as general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Association after twenty-seven years in that post.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 27 (AP). -- Baltimore's Orioles launched a 16-hit attack today to defeat the Toronto Leafs, 15 to 7, and even the series at 2-all. Vince Barton led the Baltimore attack with two homers and a pair of doubles to drive home eight runs.
NEWARK, N.J., April 27. -- The Newark Bears celebrated pennant-raising day yesterday by beating Buffalo, 4 to 3, to take the lead in the International League race.

Louis N. Hammerling, 61 years old, organizer and former president of the American Association of Foreign Language Newspapers. Inc., fell to his death from his apartment on the nineteenth floor at 5 Prospect Place at 7:15 o'clock yesterday morning.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 27. -- Westchester's first annual Beaux Arts ball will be held on Friday at the County Centre here. It will be sponsored by the Artists and Writers Dinner Club of New York, the National Association of Women Painters and Sculptors and the Westchester Arts and Craft Guild of the county's Recreation Commission.
BOSTON, April 27. -- "Just let Plymouth show a sardine like this!" said 5-year-old Milton Morgan of Provincetown, leaning negligently against a frozen three-foot fish.

THE first day of May brings to England one of her most beautiful yet simple ceremonies -- May Morning at Magdalen Tower. To attend it Londoners leave their homes at 2 A.M., arrive at Tim's Boat House, Oxford, at 4:30 and take a punt and pole up the waters of the Cherwell to Magdalen Bridge.

MARGATE, England, April 27. -- Jose R. Capablanca of Havana and Samuel Reshevsky of New York met today in the fourth round of the international tournament at the Congress of the Kent County Chess Association at the Grand Hotel, but failed to reach a decision after thirty-five moves, when adjournment took place.

In The Quarterly Review Mr. E. BERESFORD CHANCELLOR deals in a few pages with a subject on which five fat volumes could be written, "London Under the Five Georges." The growth of that enormous "wen," as WILLIAM COBBETT would say, the changes in architecture, manners, dress, the distribution of political power and so on, have been too enormous to be completely summarized.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP). -- Robert Fechner, director of emergency conservation work, announced today the number of Civilian Conservation Corps camps in New Jersey will be expanded from twenty-six to forty-eight under the new program made possible by the work-relief appropriation.
In his letter to THE TIMES Donald B. Davison gives quite an interesting account of the woodcock, especially to those unfamiliar with this bird and its song, if one cares to consider it as such.

PETER CLAVER was a Spanish priest, a Jesuit. who chose the mission of coming to the New World to devote himself utterly to the Negro slaves as they were landed from the African slave ships. The Caribbean port. Cartagena, was then the centre of the South American slave trade and ten thousand or more were brought there every year.

Mindful that the Olympic Games are only one track and field season away, officials and contestants in all participating countries are entering a serious campaign to discover new talent and improve the abilities of competitors.

OMAHA, April 26. -- Nebraska's last bicameral Legislature approaches adjournment with virtually no public regret at having decided to abolish the system and substitute for it a less numerous one-chamber body. Seldom has a session produced such a degree of confusion or provoked such a volume of criticism.
WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Business activity in the domestic field maintained a "fairly steady pace" in the week ended on April 20, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly survey.
While President Roosevelt proceeded last week with his national job-making program for the future, New York officials wrangled over the city's past experiences in caring for the needy.

SOMEWHERE In China a dozen American corporation executives and an economist or two are today eating their way through a forty-course Chinese feast, struggling with chopsticks in the cause of American business. They are members of an American trade mission of which Cameron W. Forbes, once Governor of the Philippine Islands, is the head.

Members of the Hospital Music Committee of the New York City Visiting Committee have arranged a musicale and tea in behalf of the work of that organization on the afternoon of May 6 at the Cosmopolitan Club. Proceeds will be devoted to furthering the work of the Hospital Music Committee, which provides recreation for patients in the city hospitals as well as for inmates of homes for the blind and the aged.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 27. -- Harvard's undefeated ten rolled up a record score as it vanquished Brown, 21 to 1, today. Tom Edrounds and Captain Jonathan England scored 17 points between them.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, April 27. -- Solemnly and with adequate emphasis upon the civic and historical facts of the matter, Mayor C.K. Quin let it be known today that there are plenty of bathtubs and countless gallons of water to accommodate delegates to the Kiwanis International Convention, which opens here May 19.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 27. -- The Princeton University Camera Club will hold its third annual photographic salon here in the exhibition rooms of McCormick Hall from Monday until May 8, it was announced today by the exhibition committee of the club.

WHOLLY irrespective of the merits of this little story -- and it is far from being without merit -- the discovery of a novel by Thomas Hardy, supposedly lost something like three-quarters of a century ago, is a literary event of no small interest.

LONDON. THE richest sheik in the world -- who is also the pearl king -- two of India's richest princes several princesses are among the more than 100 notables from the East who will be in London for King George's silver jubilee.

HISTORIC Santo Domingo, long out of the main stream of travel, is becoming more accessible with the reopening of the Caribbean by cruise ships and new airplane routes. This principal city of the little republic of Santo Domingo in Central America was founded, historians say, by Bartolome Colon, a brother of Christopher Columbus, on Aug. 4, 1496, and is the oldest city in the New World.

Forums held by parent associations in public school buildings may face censorship unless the programs conform to the requirements of a State law and rulings of the Commissioner of Education relating to certain subjects of discussion.
HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 27. -- Edward F. Seagram, Canadian breeder, furnished the winner of the $7,500 Philadelphia Handicap on the getaway program at Havre de Grace today.
BERLIN, April 27. -- An interview and editorial in the Voelkischer Beobachter throw a dim light on the purpose of the press decrees just issued by Max Amann, head of the Reich Press Chamber.

EVIDENCE is at hand from many sources that Europe is fully awake to American leadership in the air and does not intend to neglect solid effort to overcome that leadership. Faster planes, larger engines and more closely articulated transport systems are making their appearances in many countries.

President Roosevelt completed last week the machinery by which $4,000,000,000 is to be spent to put 3,500,000 in jobs. In four easy lessons he explained his plans to newspaper men, for the benefit of the nation.

ON many small places one of the most important of Spring jobs is the planting of a new hedge. When the location for the hedge has been settled, a trench amply deep is dug and the plants set eighteen to twenty-four inches apart and filled around with good soil, which is firmed well and then watered thoroughly.

Every one who thinks at all about public affairs must be disturbed by the spectacle which Congress now presents. The country sees legislation about to be enacted under duress. Powerful lobbies are trying, not to persuade Representatives and Senators, but to intimidate them. This is especially the case with the proposed soldiers' bonus.
LOURDES, France, April 27 (AP). -- A German Benedictine, the Rev. Dr. Hermann Bouvier, led thousands of pilgrims in prayers for peace today as the Catholic Church's great today neared its end.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., April 27. -- Five home runs, two of them by the winning pitcher, featured Ursinus's 16-to-2 victory over Lehigh University in the annual house party baseball contest before a large crowd today at Taylor Stadium.
KIMBERLEY, Union of South Africa, April 27. -- A shooting accident today cost the life of Lord Hyde, 29-year-old son and heir of the Earl of Clarendon, Governor General of South Africa.

MR. HARRY IRVING, co-author of "Black Fury," in replying to my charge that "Black Fury" was anti-labor propaganda, said "We were not trying in any way to generalize conditions by our portrayal of a slice of a miner's life."

CHICAGO, April 27. -- Uneasiness created by the sharp reaction in silver prices and evening-up by longs for President Roosevelt's speech to be broadcast tomorrow night resulted today in the grain markets developing an easy undertone.

FOR four or five years, now, Bayard Veiller has been a Broadway absentee. For a former stalwart of this sector, that is too much time to devote to the cinema. Or so it seemed to a historian who, shuffling idly through the records, observed that the eminent author of "The Trial of Mary Dugan" had not been represented on a local stage since 1930 and "That's the Woman."

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- A protest to President Roosevelt over the testimony given by Donald R. Richberg, chairman of the National Industrial Recovery Board, before the Senate munitions committee was made public today by a representative of the striking union leaders at the Colt Patent Firearms plant.
ALBANY, N.Y., April 27 (AP). -- Montreal reached a trio of Albany pitchers for thirteen hits today and won, 11 to 5. It was Montreal's third victory in four starts against the Senators.

IF Holinshed's dark and Gothic chronicles supplied material for the greatest dramas in the English tongue or the annals of the house of Atreus for those Greek tragedies that have survived two and a half millenniums, there is surely no reason why the biblical narrative of the Patriarchs should not form the substance of present-day novels.

The Columbia varsity crew, displaying improvement over the form it showed against Navy last week, defeated Manhattan by two and one-half lengths yesterday on the Harlem. It was an informal race, part of a three-event program between the Jaspers and the Lions, and marked the first varsity crew meeting ever held between the institutions.

MOSCOW, April 27. -- The whole Soviet Union has suddenly begun to blaze with red in preparation for the May Day celebration Wednesday. In Moscow, where the greatest demonstration of all will take place in Red Square in the presence of Joseph Stalin and other leaders of the Soviet State, acres of red bunting are being fixed to building fronts.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., April 27. -- A criminal court jury today decided that 68-year-old John Nardo will spend probably the last years of his life in the penitentiary for the "mechanical murder" of John Cavin, a former county road foreman.

IN the Summer of 1928 the schooner yacht Chance left New Bedford, manned by five recent Yale graduates. They set their course down the coast, through the Canal, across the Pacific, to Sydney, Australia. The story of their voyage, which filled almost a year, was engagingly told by one of the five, Edward H. Dodd Jr., in "Great Dipper to Southern Cro6s."
The Trinity College nine conquered Stevens Tech. 11 -- 8, on Castle Point Field in Hoboken yesterday.

THE Klondike rush was a generation ago. Looking back through all that has happened since, it might have been a century, so far away does it seem. But this book makes it startlingly vivid and alive. For it tells the story of a newspaper, the first newspaper to gather the daily news of Dawson City and the gold camps and put it all, throbbing with energy, as it happened, into black and white.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Frank C. Walker, director of "clearing house" activities under the $4,000,000,000 work-relief program, requested Secretary Ickes today to start taking applications for loans and grants immediately in the administration drive to put 3,500,000 unemployed on useful jobs within the shortest time.

OTTAWA, April 26. -- Harry Stevens, who originated Canada's new deal, but was dropped from Prime Minister Bennett's Cabinet before he was able to patent it, is not to be taken back into the fold while Mr. Bennett has his health and strength.

THIS, in spite of its American authorship, has all the earmarks of a Soviet proletarian novel. It is, in the first place, about proletarians, with a few boorjooys, Russian and American, thrown in for contrast, which rather brings to mind some old paintings by the Primitives on the Last Judgment, arraying on one side the just men and on the other the sinners.

THE completion early this year of a $1,000,000 air base at Nanchang, stronghold of General Chiang Kai-shek, will constitute material evidence of the ascendancy gained by Italian over American influence in shaping the course of military aviation in China.

THE silver jubilee in England, which will open with glittering pageantry on Nay 6 and continue through the Summer, has a world significance deeper than the ringing clarions of celebration and the splendid and diverse parade and spectacle.

WELLESLEY, Mass, April 27. -- Circolo Italiano, the Italian club of Wellesley College, is preparing to receive the Italian Ambassador to the United States, Signor Augusto Rosso, Tuesday afternoon, when he will come to Wellesley to present to the Circolo 300 volumes of the Italian classics and modern writers, the gift of the Italian Government.
PARIS, April 27. -- Tax receipts covering the first quarter of 1935, issued yesterday, show a serious decline, both as regards the same period last year and the budgetary estimates.

Plans are going forward rapidly for the annual Rainbow Ball for the benefit of the Association for the Aid of Crippled Children, which will take place Tuesday night in the private ballroom on the sixty-seventh floor of the RCA Building in Rockefeller Center.

TO many readers the thought of Roger W. Babson, famous as statistician and economist, writing a book about God and working out a religion by which he believes it would be possible to rescue civilization and save the world, both spiritually and economically, may seem incongruous.

DOUBTLESS the most sacred institution within the American theatre during the past five years has been the venerable production of "The Green Pastures," which concluded its sixth theatrical season and its second New York engagement concurrently last evening at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre.
The Giants turned that celebrated corner yesterday at the Polo Grounds when they downed Jimmy Wilson's Phillies, 5 to 4, and slid gracefully into the leadership of the National League.
BOSTON, April 27 (AP). -- Washington cast off the spell of Pitcher Johnny Welch today, laced out at total of seventeen hits and set down the Red Sox, 8 -- 3.

PARIS, April 17. -- King Gustaf of Sweden is making a ten-day stay here and has received much attention from Americans. At the Longchamp races last Sunday he was the guest of honor in a box party given by the American turfman A. K. Macomber, who acquired the late W.K. Vanderbilt's stable in France some years ago.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Political control of money and credit, explained as control by a government body responsible to the public, is the only alternative to control of these functions by irresponsible private interests, Chairman Steagall of the House Banking and Currency Committee said today as plans were laid to start debate Monday on the administration omnibus Banking Bill.
Extending its winning streak to eight in a row, the Long Island University nine overpowered Brooklyn College, 8 to 4, before 3,000 fans at Manhattan Beach yesterday.

After several years of inactivity in new boat construction during and just following the change in ownership of the Dawn Cruisers, Inc., work of producing three new yachts to meet the demand is being handled along with the pressure of fitting out more than forty motor cruisers which have been under Winter cover there.

Mayor La Guardia, in a fiery speech at ceremonies opening the Bronx Terminal Market yesterday, declared war on racketeers who might invade the market, bitterly condemned court justices in the case of a Brooklyn "boss" and called on police, merchants and the District Attorney to cooperate in obtaining convictions.

SYRACUSE, April 26. -- When the genial young members of the Bergen Social Club went to dances in the Hub district of the Bronx about fifteen years ago they packed lengths of rubber hose or iron pipe in their trousers to sock neighborhood lads who did not belong to the fraternity.

SOUND AND HEALTHY: The world's most famous country doctor was vindicated last week. As the result of an appeal by Oliva Dionne, father of the quintuplets, who said that his daughters were seriously ill and not merely suffering from a slight cold, a Toronto child specialist examined the babies.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 27. -- The appointment of the Right Rev. Mgr. Cornelius F. Crowley as president of the College of New Rochelle was announced today by the institution. The appointment was made by Patrick Cardinal Hayes, Archbishop of New York diocese of the Roman Catholic Church.

The first "Dean's Award," to be given periodically to the most outstanding and active student in Cooper Union, will go this year to William P. Reuss of Weehawken, N.J., a senior in the night School of Engineering, it was announced yesterday by Dean George F. Bateman. Reuss is president of the Student Council.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- It is as safe to indict the whole human race on the basis of one example as it is to describe or prescribe for areas suffering from wind erosion on the basis of conditions found in single areas, or the dust-storm of a single day, or the drift of a single year.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., April 27 (AP). -- Georgia Democrats were asked today by three organizations of this small town, often visited by the President, to "repudiate" the stand taken by Governor Eugene Talmadge in criticizing the national administration and the Chief Executive.

NOW we know! The Easter parade told the story of what women have selected from the many offerings displayed by the shops in the past weeks. So beautiful was the weather on Easter morning in New York that every one who had a Sunday best donned it and sauntered forth to view the other fellow's best.

THE Prince of Wales will be 41 in June. His playboy days -- a decade-full of magazine articles have assured us -- are over. He will probably assume the most important throne the modern world has known. His qualities have made him the most popular man of his time, the temper of the age notwithstanding.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., April 27. -- An important exhibition of paintings from the Lillie P. Bliss collection of the Museum of Modern Art in New York was opened at the Smith College Museum of Art on Wednesday, to be on view through May 19.

EUROPE'S travel facilities have been improved for the American tourists who will visit Europe this Summer. Aviation lines have been extended and plane service speeded up, with new comforts and conveniences for the air riders.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 27. -- A unique program designed to correlate romantic art, music and literature will be presented at Vassar College next week. Departments representing these fields are cooperating in a series of lectures, concerts and art exhibitions on a wider scale than ever before undertaken in an interdepartmental program at the college.

German claims of air parity with Great Britain are strongly discounted by Edward P. Warner, former Assistant Secretary of the Navy for Air, vice chairman of the recently disbanded Federal Aviation Commission and editor of the magazine Aviation, in the annual statistical number of that publication, which will be published this week.
EXCELSIOR SPRINGS, Mo., April 27 (AP). -- Midwestern Republican leaders struggled behind closed doors today with plans to rejuvenate the party, but reached open agreement on only two points:

NOT only one of the great magicians of the time but also accounted a thorough student of magic and one of the most learned authorities on its history, Mr. Mulholland appears in all three phases in this attractively made book.

DENVER, April 27 (AP) -- Letters from foreign countries appeared today in the "send-a-dime" mail avalanche, and Denver postal officials, who said postoffice facilities were "strained to the breaking point," were told by the chain letter fans to "put on more employes."

Tracy H. Lewis won the trapshooting championship of the New York Athletic Club at the Travers Island traps of the organization yesterday. He took the title in a field of fifty gunners by returning a card of 99 in the first and 96 in his second string of 100 targets. It gave him a grand total of 195 out of a possible 200.

To any one who still conceives the chemist as an experimenter who boils, precipitates and otherwise manipulates strange solutions in misshapen glass vessels, the voluminous press reports of the huge meeting held in New York by the American Chemical Society must have been a liberal education.

HONOLULU. A PROGRAM of flood control and slum elimination has emerged from the wreckage which followed in the wake of Honolulu's worst cloudburst in five years. The storm, which occurred recently, took nine lives and caused damage estimated at $2,000,000.

Captain Elbridge Colby's reply to my letter in THE TIMES offers no serious contradiction to my chief contention that nothing in the Morrill act of 1862 obligates land-grant colleges to maintain military courses upon a compulsory basis, but it does raise two or three points which deserve further consideration.

PROVIDENCE, April 27. -- With victory in his grasp, Fred Collins weakened in the eighth inning and permitted Dartmouth to score a 5-2 victory over the Providence College nine today. Two singles and four passes put four Indian runs over the plate in the eighth.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Against the advice of some of his most devoted friends, in whose judgment he has the greatest confidence, the President has assumed specific and personal responsibility for every dollar spent of the four billions that are available for work relief. In his radio speech tomorrow night he is expected once more to emphasize his personal accountability.

THE title sounds as if this should be a mystery story. Primarily It Is a romance of the Nineties with settings In New England and Paris. But there is also a mystery, with a villain at the bottom of it, which is finally unfolded in the charming old house in St. Cloud.

CHICAGO, April 27 (AP). -- The second place Chicago White Sox turned loose another loud hitting bombardment today to crush the St. Louis Browns, 16 to 4, and rack up their fifth straight victory before a crowd of 10,000.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- Passage of a compromise bill will bring to an end, it is hoped by the administration in Washington, the bitter controversy that has raged for more than ten years over the veterans' bonus. But many other problems in connection with payments to veterans and their dependents will remain.

SOME of the newer annuals are very important additions to the cutting garden; in fact many of them are primarily suited to add to the list of desirable and easily grown annuals that make the best of cut flowers. Ideas of flower arrangement have changed considerably of late.

CHICAGO, April 26. -- The fusillade of gunfire that crashed through the peace of Easter Monday in the State capital, killing one man and wounding seven others, was a sharp flare-up of a long and bloody feud between rival miners' unions in Illinois.

REPUBLICAN chieftains, like Prometheus, will seek the divine spark in Kansas City next month, but whether the resultant fire will race across the drought-stricken prairie, devouring Democrats as it goes, or whether it will flicker and die, with the fire-bringers impaled on the rock of their own aspiration, none of them can now say.

LOS ANGELES, April 27 (AP). -- Shreds of mystery still hanging about the bizarre slaying of Paul Ivar, eccentric Hollywood dress designer, were partially cleared away today when N.C. McDermitt, a sailor, only survivor of the dinner party preceding the tragedy was found and questioned aboard the battleship Pennsylvania here.

It is a tale of the cruelty of nature and of man, of love and of lust, of heroism and disease, of foulness and misery, and great beauty; it is the tale of rubber in the raw.

From two members of the administration, Congress heard last week that, if immediate payment of the veterans' bonus is authorized by any of the methods now under consideration, it will be up to Congress to scramble around and find methods of raising money by new taxes.

Fresh uncertainty as to the future silver policy of the government developed yesterday with a consequent chilling effect upon all speculative markets. Operations for the advance were halted everywhere as it became evident that the Treasury was weighing the silver situation cautiously, apparently with some concern over the disturbances caused in other countries.

ALBANY, April 27. -- Persons employing four or more domestic servants will be required to contribute for unemployment insurance for them, according to interpretations made here today of the Bryne-Killgrew Unemployment Insurance Law, just approved by Governor Lehman.

Commenting on an article published in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday from its Belgrade correspondent to the effect that the dictatorship of Yugoslavia fears the result of the May 5 election and has arrested fifty opposition candidates, Radoye Yankovitch, Yugoslav Consul General here, denied there is any dictatorship.
DES MOINES, April 27. -- Jesse Owens of Ohio took rank today alongside other great Negro sprinters of other years -- Eddie Tolan, Ralph Metcalfe and Howard Drew.

RETAIL trade in the week continued to run above a year ago, but by less than was expected. Sales results were spotty, not only by sections of the country but also by individual establishments in the same area. Apparel clearances drew fair response and homefurnishings seemed to attract demand above the usual amount for this particular period.

SHANGHAI. -- With flood menacing 10,000,000 persons in the Yellow River region of the north and famine facing 12,000,000 in the Yangtse River Basin, the Chinese National Government has two unhappy disasters to cope with and no adequate scheme of relief.

Coveted certificates which proclaim that they are careful and competent small boat pilots and navigators and the permission thenceforth to fly the curious U.S.P.S. ensign will be received tomorrow night by ninety-seven men and five women.

BRUSSELS, April 27. -- King Leopold in opening today the Brussels International Exhibition once more showed he was faithful to the policy of free trade which has always been followed by Belgium. He said:

LONDON, April 27. -- Parliament, resuming Monday after its Easter holiday, will, in the first week of its session, have another full-dress debate on the European situation and its bearing on questions of British defense.

Asserting that the United States, since Franklin D. Roosevelt became President, had traveled far on the road to recovery, Postmaster General James A. Farley predicted last night that the appropriation by Congress of $4,880,000,000 for a public works relief program to be administered by the President would prove to be the "knockout blow" of the depression.

ROME, April 27. -- With a brilliant military ceremony witnessed by the whole diplomatic corps and many thousands of citizens who took the fifteen-mile trip from Rome. Premier Mussolini today inaugurated the new experimental centre for the Royal Italian Air Force.

THE issue of academic freedom, debated of late in teachers' conventions all over the country, is having a formal legislative inquiry all its own in Pittsburgh. On successive week-ends five members of the State Legislature are sitting in the City Council chamber to determine whether teachers' rights are being abridged at the University of Pittsburgh.

The new policy of the National Industrial Recovery Board on price filing, emphasizing particularly the advisability of an impartial agency to administer such provisions, was regarded in business circles yesterday as a step in the direction of improved administration.

ATHENS, April 27. -- The valuable statue of the Diadoumenos, a Greek athlete binding up his brow after victory in a race, now in the Metropolitan Museum of New York, is asserted by Apostoloe Arvanitopoulos, Athens university professor and member of the governmental department of archaeology, to have been smuggled out of Greece.

CHICAGO. -- The department of anthropology of the University of Chicago approves the suggestion made recently by Dr. I. Zollschan of Carlsbad that the League of Nations call an international conference of scientists to enlighten the world on the question of race.

EUROPE goes on parade about this time each year. All through the Summer historic pageants, musical and other festivals, expositions, carnivals and celebrations of many kinds take place in large towns and small, in well-known countries and remote.

WARSAW. AIRPLANES completely equipped as ambulances are now serving outlying country districts of Poland from ten central metropolitan bases in an effort to make modern hospital facilities available to the peasants, who constitute 70 per cent of the Polish population.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Debits to individual accounts, as reported to the Federal Reserve Board by banks in leading cities for the week ended April 24, which included five business days in some of the reporting cities, aggregated $6,991,000,000, or 12 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week, and 5 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.

BERLIN, April 26. -- Superficially a great peace overspreads Germany at this writing, such a peace as caries one's mind back to the placid days early in June last year when a prospective vacation for the Storm Troops and the daring of Franz von Papen, who had ventured to suggest a little more freedom of public expression, were the most burning topics of the day.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 27. -- Relief from the processing tax on cotton was asked in resolutions adopted by the American Cotton Manufacturers Association in convention here today, but the association lined up solidly behind the growers by not asking for elimination of the tax until a suitable substitute has been perfected.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 27. -- The Yale Rugby team scored a decisive 27 -- 3 victory over the Long Island University team today. Not until the last two minutes of play were the New Yorkers able to score. Bant then crossing the goal line for the only try.

Sebastino Lupica, who has earned his living for years playing his accordion in the city streets, only to be informed this year by the License Department that he no longer could have a license, called at City Hall yesterday morning to see if Mayor La Guardia could help him.

Creation of a retail rehabilitation corporation to aid retailers in a manner similar to the work being done in other lines by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation has been suggested to Donald Richberg, chairman of the National Industrial Recovery Board, and to Louis E. Kirstein, chairman of the executive committee of the newly organized American Federation of Retailing, by Joseph T. Blatt, retail counselor of this city.

THE enigmatic title of Mr. Merwin's new book is taken from an old Scotch border ballad in which a certain Sir Andrew Barton encouraged his men to keep on fighting, telling them "I am hurt but I am not slaine; I'll lie me down and bleed awhile, And then I'll rise and fight againe."

Marking a new step in American education, six European philosophers and writers will give courses at the University of Notre Dame next Fall and Winter in an attempt to bring medieval philosophies to bear on present social, economic and political problems in the United States and to devise programs to meet those problems.
DERBY, Conn., April 27. -- In the annual regatta between the Yale freshman and the Kent School first and second crews on the Housatonic today, the Elis won both races.

With reference to the question of foreign debts, it is rather significant that the British Chancellor of the Exchequer, Neville Chamberlain, in presenting the budget, saw fit to disregard the British debt to the United States. It is of further significance that members of Parliament brought this matter to the floor of the House of Commons in fairly positive and comprehensive language.

The diplomatic stillness in Europe last week was broken by a shot aimed at Herr Hitler from an unexpected quarter. It came from the pen of James Ramsay MacDonald, Great Britain's enigmatic Prime Minister.

The Ringling Brothers-Barnum Bailey Circus made its twenty-ninth annual pilgrimage to Bellevue Hospital yesterday to cheer the shut-ins. A crowd of more than 4,000 children and grownups in wheel chairs, on foot and standing on hospital balconies viewed the show, called by Bellevue officials the "best we ever had."

THE sweet smell of budding trees and shrubs is in the air; the song el birds is heard in increasing volume; the call to the country grows. Golf clubs and tennis rackets need looking over, and the urge for new country togs must be satisfied.

BERLIN, April 27. -- German citizenship will become in the near future no longer a right acquired by birth, but a privilege granted by the National Socialist regime for service to the party and acceptance of its dogmas, Minister of the Interior Wilhelm Frick announced today.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., April 27. -- Frank Smith's clever twirling and the heavy hitting of Captain Bill McKechnie earned Penn State's baseball team a 5-3 victory over Juniata today.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 27. -- Brazil's Constituent Assembly passed out of existence today after an active life of two years.

Student life at New York University when Utopia is attained was depicted last night in the varsity show of the University's Washington Square College, entitled "New York Utopia," which was given at the Hotel Lismore before more than 1,000 students, faculty members and others.

DETROIT, April 26. -- With the arrival of the seasonal peak of the automobile industry, which occurs in May, the usual questionings as to the immediate future course of this industry, conceded to be so important in the recovery program of the nation, inevitably arise.

In its hunt for new sources of revenue the La Guardia administration is considering a tax, in the form of a licensing fee on all trade and professional schools conducted privately for profit and on all individual teachers charging a fee for instruction in any art, trade, vocation, calling or occupation, it was learned yesterday.

Still another trophy for some fortunate entrant in the Albany-to-New York motor boat marathon on Sunday, May 12, has been added to the list, according to yesterday's announcement by Commodore Charles F. Chapman of New York, race committee chairman.

WHAT are we going to do with the new kind of civilization that science and technocracy and the New Deal are on the point of giving us? This new civilization with its cheap electric power, its larger leisure, Its material gifts? Are we going to try to fit it upon our old culture, our old ways of thinking, our old ideals and visions?

The net operating income of the first forty-one railroads reporting for March amounted to $19,603,000, compared with $27,855,000 in March of last year, a decline of 29.6 per cent. In February, the net operating income of these carriers amounted to $13,967,000, a drop of 18.1 per cent from the $17,045,000 in February, 1934.

IF there were any way of knowing why men are devoted to birds the life of Jean Jacques Fougere Audubon ought to supply the evidence. Born on April 26 150 years ago, he fell in love with birds almost as soon as he was old enough to develop personal interests: and his life was diffuse and meaningless until, at the age of 35, he abandoned everything for ornithology.

With depreciation reserves wiped out in the last five years and with the cost of financing production nearly doubled since midsummer, 1933, the impossibility of a broadscale movement to rehabilitate and modernize the cotton-textile industry was pointed out here yesterday by textile engineers.

LONDON. THOUGH it is doubtful whether Hollywood will ever be transferred en bloc to England, as has been suggested recently, it is certainly true that the film business in Britain is becoming more and more internationalized.

Forty members of The Fossils, an organization of amateur journalists who were active in the last half of the nineteenth century, attended the thirty-second annual dinner and reunion at the Hotel Astor last night. The gathering was devoted to reminiscences of the days when The Fossils were publishing their little papers, setting their own type and running off their editions on hand presses.

DODGE CITY, Kan., April 26. -- The high plains region is on the rebound in spite of dust storms, drought and outlook for slim crops. Rains and snows in some sections of the dry area explain the improved condition, but what is a better portent, moisture in large amount has fallen on every side of the drought region.
ROME, April 27. -- The government's new commercial policy of "balanced exchanges" has led, not altogether surprisingly, to an increase in internal retail prices.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 27. -- The crews of the Naval Academy continued their string of victories today by taking the honors in all four races against Cornell.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- The fifth annual Old Dominion golf championship will get under way at Hot Springs tomorrow with the qualifying round of eighteen holes of medal play. The first and second rounds of match play will be played on Tuesday and Wednesday, respectively; the semi-final on Thursday and the finals on Friday.

WITH completion of the world's largest bridge tentatively set for Dec. 1, 1936, traffic engineers are now putting final touches to their plans for speeding the motorist over the double-deck span that will reach out in broad concrete avenues eight miles long, from San Francisco to Oakland.

BOSTON, April 26. -- Secretary of Agriculture Wallace has recognized the bitter resentment in New England over the disparaging remarks he permitted himself to make on his visit last week to Maine. The Cabinet officer who appears as the chief exponent of the administration's agricultural policy denounced the textile interests for their protests against the processing tax.

WHAT we remember after the first stunning impact of "Les Miserables," when we stumble drunkenly into the sunlight, are many clamorous, fierce and beautiful emotions. Javert and Valjean. The gloom and horror of the galleys.

TOLEDO, Ohio, April 27. -- T.J. Williams, conciliator of the Federal Department of Labor, was told today by William S. Knudsen, executive vice president of the General Motors Corporation, that the company "cannot resume negotiations with the strikers while the strike is on."

As an ex-dramatic critic (Brooklyn Eagle pre-Pollock) I rarely have occasion to quarrel with a Death Watch to which I once belonged. The box score during my term of service was nine bad plays to one good. Has it improved, I wonder?

While fire wardens in New York and New Jersey were making a survey yesterday of the thousands of acres of woodland laid waste by forest fires in the last few days and indications pointed to virtual control in both States, flames swept the parched timberland north of Toms River, N.J., and cut a path through the town of Silverton.

A goodly part of the Federal funds soon to be available for public works in the metropolitan area could safely and wisely be spent on water, coming and going: on water supply, drainage and the prevention of pollution. Mayor LA GUARDIA announced last week that he intended to push forward immediately with the city's plans for tapping the Delaware River watershed in order to add to the local supply.
BERLIN, April 27 (AP). -- Germany today officially admitted submarines were being "considered" in connection with plans to rebuild the navy.

An out-of-door motor-boat show, afloat, will be New York's novel way of ushering in the 1935 yachting season, according to the plan of a newly formed committee which was divulged yesterday by Albert Hickman, chairman and head of the Hickman Sea Sled Company.

DENVER. -- With the shearing season now under way on Western ranges sheepmen are expressing concern for the immediate future of their industry. Price, quality and quantity are expected to be below those of last year.

OUT beyond the lazy little town of Sleepy Cat. bordering on the Very Bad Lands of the arid Southwest, the great Gunlock Ranch was owned by old Gus Van Tambel, and old Gus was a tough hombre in every sense of the adjective Pretty much everybody in the region hated him for his greed and the misdeeds inspired by it.

The status of Constance Starr Brock, 10-year-old daughter of Mrs. Helen Josephson of 975 Park Avenue, whose custody was awarded last January to her maternal grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Starr of Mamaroneck, remained unsettled yesterday after a hearing for a writ of habeas corpus, brought on behalf of her mother before Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo in the Supreme Court here.

Retailers in close touch with the formation of the American Retail Federation said yesterday they "welcome" the Congressional inquiry and see in it a "splendid opportunity" to make clear the objectives of the body, which is designed to speak for the entire field of distribution.
Retail trade last week in most sections of the country was at a higher level than had been expected for the week after Easter.

Cardinal Hayes formally presented yesterday afternoon to Miss Teresa R. O'Donohue, president of the Ladies of Catholic Charity, the medal "Pro Ecclesia et Pontifice" (for church and Pope). The decoration recently was bestowed by Pope Pius XI.

About 200 "white-collar" workers paraded in front of the office of the Emergency Relief Bureau at 902 Broadway yesterday to protest the proposed investigation of 11,000 "white-collar" employes on the relief rolls to weed out those not entitled to assistance.

PANAMA, R.P. -- The recent decision of the leaders of the Conservative party in Colombia to abstain from participation in the May election may complicate rather than simplify the political situation there.

TWO experimental camps for New York City school children have been proposed to the Board of Education for establishment this Summer in State parks. After six months of deliberation this is the recommendation of the special committee appointed by Dr. George J. Ryan, president of the board, to study the practicability of such a project.
