Criticism that corporations in hard times have been paying out a disproportionate amount of their precious cash in the form of executive salaries is heard again. The angriest remonstrance comes from interests which have little if any financial stake in the corporations concerned but which profess to be concerned over the anti-social aspects of this type of corporate generosity.

THROUGHOUT the world men are striving to meet nature's challenge. The level of culture of any community is determined, in part at least, by the degree to which it can benefit from the advantages that nature offers and surmount the difficulties that she places in the way of progress.

The collection of American furniture and decorations formed by Mrs. Stanley H. Lowndes and the late Mr. Lowndes of Northport. L.I., will be offered at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., each afternoon this week beginning tomorrow and continuing through Saturday.

THE Punch and Judy of childhood's happy hour have entered business and economic life. Puppets are now being used by advertisers in behalf of their products, by strikers seeking to win sympathy for their cause and by large stores, particularly during the holiday seasons, in entertaining their child and adult patrons.

Prominent members of society and leading artists of the musical world are completing last-minute preparations for the third Opera Ball, which will be held on Thursday night in a setting of great beauty at the Metropolitan Opera House.

Soaring prices for silver, which carried quotations here to 81 cents an ounce Friday, brought deep concern to foreign traders doing business with the Far East and forced stetting silverware manufacturers to appeal to Washington for relief.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 27. -- Teaching, social service, journalism, secretarial work, government, the theatre, medicine, publishing, interior decoration, and advertising are the ten most popular vocations, in the order of their preference, of the undergraduates at Radcliffe College.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Excessive stock payment for services was given by the Securities and Exchange Commission today as the principal reason for suspending the securities registration statement of the Brandywine Brewing Company of Washington.

It is indeed comforting to learn that interstellar travel is at least a century off. One shudders to think of the unanswerable questions that might be put to us by curious tourists fresh from Venus and Mars, notebooks in hand, and eager to understand the whys and wherefores of our civilization.
CLEVELAND, April 27 (AP). -- The Indians scored their sixth consecutive victory today by defeating the Tigers in a one-sided contest, 9 to 2.

DESPITE all that has been written concerning home landscaping, many American houses are still woefully lacking in the seclusion and privacy which make of a man's house -- large or small -- his "castle." Hedges alone fail to achieve this result.

Six delegates to the Pan-American Commercial Conference, which begins in Buenos Aires on May 26 to continue work started in 1933 under Secretary Hull, sailed yesterday on the Munson liner American Legion. In December, 1933, at Montevideo the American delegation under Mr. Hull laid groundwork for extensive improvements of commercial relations between the United States and Latin-American countries.

ST. LOUIS, April 27 (AP). -- The New Deal moved slowly but relentlessly into the hills country today and 45,000 Missouri Ozarkians were "on the drive" -- bewildered principals in a gigantic "resettlement" program.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- President Roosevelt was the guest of honor tonight at the annual dinner of the White House Correspondents Association. His hosts were more than 300 Washington newspaper men who are members of the association. Mr. Roosevelt is honorary president.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- Although the dramatic aspects of organized labor's struggle for recognition are visible to the man in the street who reads the headlines describing the Toledo automobile workers' strike and similar disturbances, labor is preparing to devote perhaps its most intensive efforts to the legislative field.

SYDNEY, N.S.W. -- White man's laws and tribal customs were in conflict in a murder trial in the Northern Territory Supreme Court when Judge Wells deferred passing sentence on two aborigines, Numberlin and Nangee, convicted of killing another native.

A CARNIVAL spirit will be added to the classic traditions of the Kentucky Derby this year. Heretofore the thought never occurred to Kentuckians that anything more was needed to invite the great and small from near and far than "the best horse race in the world."

WHEN a New York congregation recently faced the question of repairs on an old and valued pipe organ, its inquiries were met with an offer to install, at fractional cost, a new American device of instantaneous tone production based on electric sources of sound as developed in modern telephone and radio.

WE almost could assume that a man's opinion of his own work was impossible to know with certainty, and, it is tempting to think, the more impossible if any statement of his own is followed. It is a common jest that to an artist the latest thing he has done is better than any other, however far it may fall below his accepted standard, but the jest is founded on fact often observed.
The role of research in solving Jewish problems was discussed by educators yesterday at a luncheon of the Conference on Jewish Relations at the Hotel Commodore. About 150 persons attended.

Upon the petition of the Silk Textile Code Authority, the National Industrial Recovery Board has granted a public hearing on the proposal to change the labor provisions of the Silk Code so that they will be identical with those in the Cotton Code, it was announced yesterday by Peter Van Horn, chairman of the Silk Code Authority.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., April 27. -- The recent announcement by President Fox that Union College will conduct a program of practical courses in government, which will be coupled with Summer internships in the State administrative departments in Albany, has resulted in the integration of the student groups on the campus interested in social welfare, including such questions as world peace.

CLEVERLY devised and interestingly worked out is this contribution to the economic literature inspired by the depression. It will appeal to the swarming victims of the general smash because of its understanding of their experiences and its endeavor to voice the reactions to the conditions that have resulted and its sanity.

SEVERAL group shows have augmented the week's variety. One of these is to be classified as a "permanent"; it marks the opening, to the public, of the Museum of Folk Arts at Riverdale-on-Hudson, which was founded in 1926 by Mr. and Mrs. Elie Nadelman.

LONDON, April 27. -- In a driving finish to the most thrilling final in recent years, the Sheffield Wednesday soccer team today won the English Cup for the third time, defeating West Bromwich Albion, 4 -- 2. Each scored one goal in the first half.

WHILE a goodly number of stellar attractions will fade from the microphone during the Summer, this season's exodus from the studios is not nearly, as heavy as in other years. An impressive array of headline performers will continue broadcasting during the vacation days.

TO celebrate the founding of the chemical industries in America 300 years ago by John Winthrop Jr., first Colonial Governor of Connecticut, some 10,000 chemists, all members of the American Chemical Society, gathered in New York last week and in 1,000 papers and addresses reviewed the mighty progress they had made.

A sudden halt in the rise of the price of silver unsettled early trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, but reactions were confined to limits of about 10 points, and a closing recovery left near months unchanged to a loss of 10 points in distant deliveries.

THE interest in the dance which is being manifested these days by the Board of Aldermen is little short of astounding. No sooner has the laughter died down over the absurdity that unemployed dancers should feel entitled to share in the relief program than another inspiration appears which, if it were not equally grim in its implications, would be even more hilarious.

Today marks the opening of National Youth Week and many pastors will preach sermons dealing with young people and their religious problems. Because the United States naval manoeuvres will begin Friday in the North Pacific many pastors will preach about peace, war and preparedness.

LONDON, April 27. -- The British Government was angered today to learn officially that Germany not only intended to build twelve new submarines but had ordered them six months ago and was already assembling them.

The illness of hundreds of people in Westchester County due to infected food has interested New Yorkers in the protection of their food supply. Such wholesale group illnesses have occurred in the city, but they have become increasingly rare because of the careful supervision of food supplies.

Some of the most extensive manoeuvres in the history of the United States Navy will start in the North Pacific this week, when more than 160 ships and about 450 planes, divided into two "enemy" forces, will join the gage of battle in the navy's annual mimic war.

Cornell's baseball team provided an upset in the Eastern Intercollegiate League by defeating Columbia's defending champions in both games of a doubleheader yesterday before 2,000 spectators at Baker Field. In nearly five hours of competition, all kinds of playing was furnished and the scores of both contests indicate the extremes to which the teams resorted.

ALBANY, April 27. -- Governor Lehman signed today the Killgrew bill, submitting to the people in the Fall election a proposed $55,000,000 bond issue for continuing the State unemployment relief program.

NENANA, Alaska, April 7. -- Alaska sourdoughs are all set for the big annual guessing contest, and a pool of $60,000 will go to the lucky one who hits the exact or closest time of the Tanana River ice breakup.

THIS short novel, if novel it can be called, is really a sort of elementary treatise on Central African anthropology cast in fictional form. For the greater part of thirty years Captain Rattray has served the British Government in Central Africa, rising to the post of District Commissioner.

THE word "Observations" which Miss Moore used for the book of poems from which this selection was made exactly describes their function. Miss Moore observes minutely and intently with the eye, and with the mind precisely and pragmatically sets down her observations.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 27. -- Senator Huey P. Long of Louisiana denounced the Democratic administration, and especially its agricultural program, before a crowd of 10,000 farmers at the State Fair Grounds here today. Followers of Milo Reno, erstwhile leader of the "farm strike," and others assembled in the third annual convention of the National Farmers Holiday Association, shouted and stamped their approval and cried "amens" to his remarks.

DIVIDING chrysanthemums is one of the early chores of the gardener's year. Although in April the well-grown crowns appear entirely too lusty to disturb, it is well to remember that much finer blossoms result from yearly division.

PHILADELPHIA, April 27. -- Development of musical knowledge among children of rural districts through the appointment of a State music director in every State was urged by the National Federation of Music Clubs in its biennial convention here today.

THE author of the "Blackshirt" thrillers is not at his best in this crime tale, which, though it belongs to the crook species, seems to have been written without any regard for the customary or original ingredients generally to be associated with that type of popular fiction.

As the number of cases of food poisoning reported to the Westchester County Health Department mounted to 745 when its offices closed for the week-end yesterday, the germ which caused the epidemic was identified by a chemist of the Yonkers City Health Department. He said it was staphylococcus pyogenes aureaus.

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday it had filed recommendations with the United States Army Engineers here for the improvement of Buttermilk Channel. The proposals contemplate a complete utilization of the Bay Ridge section of the harbor. The engineers already have under consideration a proposal to increase the width of the channel from 500 to 1,200 feet with a depth of 40 feet.

Virtual completion of the Treasury's plans for refunding at lower rates the Government's war indebtedness will have brought the average interest rate on the public debt from 4.339 per cent in 1921 to something less than 3 per cent this year. The Treasury computed it at 3.181 last June, and very large subsequent conversions of wartime 4 1/4 per cents into 3 1/4s and 2 1/2s will have fixed a still lower average.

The American flag will have a forty-ninth star if a committee representing the majority of the Puerto Rican Legislature has its way. The committee is expected to arrive in the United States very shortly to urge the granting of Statehood to the island, which now ranks technically as an American possession.

The Wanamaker drawing competition for school children has attracted 12,500 entries this year from 595 public, private and parochial schools in the city. The judging will take place tomorrow and after the presentation of medals on May 11 the drawings will be on exhibition in the Wanamaker store until May 18.

ONE of the most persistent investigators of American first editions is Merle Johnson, author of "A Bibliography of Mark Twain" and the check-list, "American First Editions," both of which are still standard works of reference.

Resplendent in their colorful uniforms, topped by tall bearskin shakos, members of the Old Guard of New York City celebrated the 109th anniversary of their organization yesterday in traditional fashion.

NEWPORT, R.I., April 27. -- Miss Marion Mason Wilson, well-known horsewoman, daughter of Mrs. Richard T. Wilson and the late Mr. Wilson of New York and this city, this noon became the bride of Lieutenant William A.M. Morin, U.S.A., at present attached to the Second Battalion of the Thirteenth Infantry, stationed at Fort Adams here.

HEREIN we meet again our old friend Hashknife Hartley, the roaming cowboy detective, some of whose varied exploits have been recounted by W.C. Tuttle in several earlier stories. But Hashknife, accompanied as always by his inseparable Sleepy Stevens, does not appear until we reach page 103 -- and then nobody in Pineville knows who he is, or where he came from, or what his business may be.

THE hero of Alexander Duffield's first novel is something a good deal less than a heroic figure. Once Sam bucked his father's will when, after leaving college, he went to Paris to study art. But, always cynical with himself, he knew he had no tremendous urge and only a modest talent.

PHILADELPHIA, April 27. -- Stroked handsomely by Ben Chapman, the Yanks outscrambled the Athletics, 9 to 8, today, to give the McCarthymen their second straight triumph of the series before a gathering of 10,000.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 27. -- Solution of the $129,000 mail truck robbery at Fall River, Jan. 23, was announced today by postoffice inspectors after a raid on a Warwick estate had uncovered $8,000 of the missing cash and a gangsters' arsenal described by police as the most formidable ever seized in this State.

In the manner of its telling, this story is rather incoherent, but that is only because the events in it are seen solely from the viewpoint of Crane Adams, who, in the circumstances, can scarcely be expected to do any coherent thinking. Adams, who is a teacher of English in a high school, suddenly finds himself suspected of the murder of his friend, Chatterton Manley.

THIS year the public schools in New York State have received more State aid than in any of the three previous years, when the annual increases provided for by law were set aside. This was accomplished by the passage last Summer of the Porter bill, carrying additional appropriations of $13,346,000, which was sponsored by a number of civic organizations, including the League of Women Voters.

GENEVA, April 27. -- War and educational films are the movies least liked by children, according to a report, "Cinema for the Young," submitted to the League of Nations Child Welfare Committee today by the British delegate. The report covers answers from eleven countries in the committee's world-wide inquiry.

The city is extending home relief to 234,000 families at a cost of $400,000 each working day, according to a report received yesterday by Oswald W. Knauth, chairman and executive director of the Emergency Relief Bureau, from Edward Corsi, director of the Home Relief division.

RACHEL CROTHERS, whose twenty-seven years in and about Broadway have earned her the title of America's foremost woman playwright, returned last week from her first screen-writing job in Hollywood. It was an adaptation of A.E. Thomas's play, "No More Ladies," which will be turned into film by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

BERLIN, April 27. -- The National Socialist May Day festival this year, for which the program was published today, is designed to be primarily a national thanksgiving to Reichsfuehrer Hitler for restoring Germany's armament and sovereignty through conscription.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Southern Senators, fighting desperately the Costigan-Wagner anti-lynching bill, were beaten back by a vote of 37 to 28 today, when, as yesterday, they tried to adjourn the Senate and, by this parliamentary move, throw the bill into the discard for the rest of this session.

The undefeated baseball team of Seth Low Junior College rallied in the ninth and tenth innings to beat the Wagner College nine, 10 to 7, yesterday at Wagner Field, Grimes Hill, S.I. Seth Low scored four runs in the ninth.

FOR a good many Fears past, Olive Wadsley has been turning out a novel or two annually, fairly well told and entertaining love stories which have yet lacked any striking quality to distinguish them from the works of minor British feminine contemporaries.

FREEPORT, L.I., April 27. -- Launching a strong attack after being held to one try during the first half, the undefeated New York Rugby Club registered a 14-to-5 victory over the Pilgrims Rugby Club of New York in a sternly contested struggle at the Municipal Stadium today.

LIBERAL, I{an.. April 27 .'P).-Deaths of six persons this week were attributed to dust-storms by Red Cross officials tonight as headquarters here pushed relief work in the 18,000.000-acre stricken section.

WITH the flare of flash bulbs and the click of camera shutters, a new course has made its appearance on the campus of the University of Pittsburgh. What is thought to be the first formal instruction in news photography began with the present semester there.
WASHINGTON, April 27. -- The Denver "send-a-dime" chain letter which has flooded the postoffice in that city with mail was declared illegal today by the Postoffice Department.

The protest aroused by your editorials "Fewer Patents" and "Inventors Protest," based on my article in the March Journal of the Patent Office Society, ought to start a very useful controversy, but not be one; for the statements so far objected to are simple matters of fact

Governor Lehman signed many bills and vetoed others last week, but he kept silent about what the legislators who passed the measures most wanted to know -- whether they will have to return to Albany for a special session to put through the reapportionment of election districts.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 27. -- The Fireside Players of White Plains emerged the winners of the eighth Westchester County Little Theatre tournament tonight, winning a silver cup.

OSWALD W. KNAUTH, the new "czar" of relief in New York City, does not pretend to be a miracle man and does not believe in miracles. But he does contend that the relief situation is not so bad as people seem to think it is.

A FANTASTIC, almost incredible idea has been realized -- an organ without pipes! After long experimentation, the physicist A. Givelet and the organ builder E. Coupleux have created an electrical instrument which permits the interpretation of any organ music whatsoever without abandoning the established manner of playing and, in addition, offers new musical and technical possibilities.
The story of the gradual defeat of pestilence in the city during the last 130 years was told yesterday in a report by Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health.

In a closely contested event which required nearly an hour to decide, Miss Helen M. Keuneke of Weehawken captured the horsemanship championship as the three-day Brooklyn Horse Show came to a conclusion at the Riding and Driving Club before a large and representative crowd last night.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Although our foreign trade in March was seasonally higher than in February, exports for the month were $5,889,000 less than the corresponding month in 1934, while our imports were $19,174,000 higher than for the corresponding month last year, an analysis by the Department of Commerce showed today.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 27. -- Scoring seven goals in the last three periods while holding the Tigers scoreless, the Army polo team today conquered Princeton by 9 to 3 on Deveraux Field. It was the first outdoor contest of the Spring for both quartets.

IMAGINE!" the press agent exclaims with the old missionary gleam in his cinemapostolic eyes, "there are only 800 Department of Justice operatives to attend to the Federal policing affairs of the nation. And each of those operatives carries a Stillson wrench, a cold chisel, a hammer and" --

The award of twenty-one scholarships and fellowships with a total value of $11,400 in the New York University Graduate School for 1935-36 was announced yesterday by Harold O. Voorhis, secretary of the university.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 27 (AP). -- The Bermuda boat Viking, owned by Kenneth and Eldon Trimingham, today retained the Prince of Wales trophy, emblematic of the championship in the international six-meter yatching series.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 25. -- Australia is experiencing three friendly invasions by Japanese and a fourth invasion is expected later. One party of ten, which is called the Pacific Economic Inspection Party, has been sponsored by two influential Japanese newspapers.

AN ALMANAC FOR MODERNS" is the day-book of a scientist who is also a poet. Donald Culross Peattie is the author of scientific works and novels, and was formerly an economic botanist in the Department of Agriculture at Washington.

CONVERTED by his past errors in drunkenness to resolutions of sobriety, Third Mate Sweeney of the tramp steamer Fontinbras lands in a wide-open South American port determined that moderation and innocent sightseeing shall mark the limitation of his diversions.

THE Eligible Bachelor" is the third lightly humorous novel about the Warmstrys, an engaging English family. Not having read the first two makes it a bit difficult to understand at once the ramifications and relationships of the Warmstrys.

MEMPHIS, April 25. -- While the Southern landlord, particularly in the Midsouth, views with a sort of curious indifference the various schemes and programs of government aid for the tenant farmer and the share-cropper, he believes after all, that if, and when, the problem is solved it will be wholly through the individual get-up-and-go of the share-cropper himself.

Other yacht harbors -- Lloyd's, for instance, out Huntington way -- may be busier over a week-end than famous old Oyster Bay, but no boating rendezvous anywhere is more fascinating or delightful. A scant two hours up the Sound, Oyster Bay is the kind of anchorage a skipper from Manhasset or City Island wants to reach on Fridays by planning his start after his office closes and arriving before twilight settles down.

Retail trade improved in the metropolitan area last week, but gains were rather spotty and somewhat under expectations. Fair consumer response met the seasonal clearances of women's apparel and accessories in preparation for Summer merchandising, which will begin soon.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- In four steps taken on as many successive clays from Tuesday through Friday of this week, President Roosevelt mustered a staff and laid down a course of operations with the object of spending $4,000,000,000 in a single year.
CENSORSHIP is a prerogative American broadcasters assert they do not possess, yet occasionally a speaker charges his speech was suppressed.
MEXICO, D.F., April 27. -- A bank holiday, President Roosevelt's recourse against financial panic soon after his inauguration, was Mexico's answer today to the Roosevelt silver policies.

BERLIN, April 27. -- Nazi organizing talent is concentrating on next Wednesday's May Day celebration, the third since the new Reich came into existence. It is to be devoted not so much to the glorification of labor as previous anniversaries have been.

VIENNA, April 27. -- Reichsfuehrer Hitler's birthday passed without any more alarming demonstrations by Austrian Nazis than the mechanical unfolding of swastika banners and the scattering of miniature swastikas in various areas.

LONDON. WHILE the relations of the author to his publisher have been exhaustively discussed, comparatively little has been said about the no less interesting relations of the author to his printer. New light has been cast on one important phase of this question -- the correction of printers' errors -- by the researches of Percy Simpson, as embodied in "Proof-reading in the Sixteenth, Seventeenth and Eighteenth Centuries" (Oxford University Press).

GLYNDON, Md., April 27. -- The Maryland Hunt Cup went to the Genesee Valley of New York today when Mrs. W. Austin Wadsworth's handsome big chestnut Hotspur II won the forty-second running of the famous race over the stiff four miles of timber in the Worthington Valley.

A shiver ran through the earth last week. In Formosa over 3,000 were killed, about 11,000 injured and some 20,000 hovels and houses destroyed or damaged. In Iran, until lately known as Persia, some 600 met death as towns were leveled in a series of shocks.

BUDAPEST is now only seven days from New York, owing to the fact that transatlantic liners have recently been linked to an air service for the hop across Europe. Hungary's capital has long been a magnet for travelers, who find on the Danube an engaging city with famous theatres and art galleries, characteristic restaurants and outdoor cafes and relics that are a living part of the history of a proud nation.

A SPY whose life is not a series of death-defying perils is not likely to hold the attention of the divan-adventurer who takes his thrills vicariously. Unfortunately, the gentle spying in Marthe McKenna's latest story is not calculated to make the hair bristle, although quite evidently she intended to reach the nerves. She says in the introduction: "X have had al I

With dramatic suddenness Mayor La Guardia drove home yesterday one of his points in favor of making Governors Island a landing field for commercial airplanes as well as a military depot. He staged his argument before a delegation of members of the Military Affairs Committee of the House of Representatives, headed by Representative John J. McSwain, its chairman.

CRUISE ships will soon be steaming out of New York Harbor in large numbers again as the late Spring and early Summer seasons get under way. This fact seems to be arousing more interest among travelers than for several seasons.

The Manhattan College baseball team, discovering its offensive power for the first time this season, went on a batting spree at the expense of City College yesterday at Manhattan Field. With a thirteen-hit barrage the Jaspers routed the visitors, 14 to 1, for their initial triumph in four starts.

BUDAPEST is now only seven days from New York, owing to the fact that transatlantic liners have recently been linked to an air service for the hop across Europe. Hungary's capital has long been a magnet for travelers, who find on the Danube an engaging city with famous theatres and art galleries, characteristic restaurants and outdoor cafes and relics that are a living part of the history of a proud nation.

JOSEPH BING, who, upon the request of the Royal Photographic Society, organized the exhibition of work by American photographers current at the American Fine Arts Building, reports that attendance has been gratifyingly large. Several organizations have visited it in a body, and today the members of the Miniature Camera Club of Philadelphia are planning to come to New York to see the display.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 27. -- Wilmer Allison of Austin, Texas, today added the annual Mason-Dixon tennis title to his long string of championships by defeating J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange, N.J., in straight sets, 9 -- 7, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 0.

BUFFALO, April 27. -- Branding the present silver policy of the Federal administration as politics, but not economics, Dr. Edwin W. Kemmerer, Princeton professor and an authority on finance and economics, today called the silver-buying program of the government an absurdity.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 27. -- After trailing for more than half of the opening period, Princeton's varsity Rugby team made a fine comeback to hand Harvard an 8-to-6 defeat today.
WASHINGTON, April 27. -- An assertion that natural gas companies had "divided up the territory" was made today by Chairman Wheeler of the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 27 (AP). -- Although Joe Mulligan, big right-handed Boston Red Sox farmhand, allowed Rochester eleven hits, he kept them well scattered and the Chiefs won today, 9 to 3. Syracuse garnered only ten hits off four Red Wing twirlers, but most of them counted.

BERLIN. OUR diminutive Shirley Temple struck Central Europe like a full-sized meteor. Her first appearance here in "Baby Take a Bow" was sensational. The picture first came out in its original American version and now, after several months of packing the larger houses in the major cities, Fox Film brought out a German-dubbed version and is still raking it in from the five-ten-twenties.

IN this volume of memoirs, always interesting, sometimes refreshingly candid, Mr. Doran sets down the record of his fifty years in publishing. The title provokes curiosity and Mr. Doran explains that it derives from a Byronic legend.
The East Side went rural yesterday after a cow had been brought to town for the tenth annual fair of the Madison Square Boys Club, 312 East Thirtieth Street.

THREE hundred years ago last Tuesday the householders of the new settlement of Boston turning from their plows and fishnets, met in their sod-roofed dirt-floored meeting house and voted to have a schoolmaster who could teach their boys Latin and Greek.

AS you look down upon the map of New York, three grand divisions of the city approach one another about Hell Gate and two islands stand like stepping-stones in the triangle of water that separates them. There today you may see a procession of piers -- in scattered detachments, with odd intervals -- making its way across the tangle of land and water from where built-up city streets stop to where they begin again.

WHATEVER else the Relief Administration has or has not done, it should be cited on Child Health Day this week as having conducted for almost two years one of the most widespread experiments in child welfare ever undertaken by a national government.

A census of unemployment in the United States, to be taken by white-collar workers out of jobs, will be one of the new Federal work-relief projects, President Roosevelt has announced. The need for such a census has long been urged; Senator Wagner, particulary, has often emphasized the importance of setting up machinery to determine the number of jobless.

THIS afternoon the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra concluded its ninety-third year of performances. In thirty weeks 119 concerts have been given, including the ten Students' Concerts and the six Children's Concerts conducted by Ernest Schelling.

MEXICO, D.F., April 27. -- That Mexico and the United States must reach some modus vivendi regarding the silver situation was the opinion expressed to THE NEW YORK TIMES correspondent today by students of Mexico's problem.

VIENNA, April 8, 1935. AT a popular Viennese cabaret they tell a sour little joke about a toothless and decrepit old beldame who, tottering into the State Opera, demands to see the director. After prolonged but ineffectual remonstrances, the desperate porter insists she must have come to the wrong address.

The Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria will be opened for the Summer season with a gala dinner and supper dance on the night of May 14. A generous percentage of the proceeds of the entertainment will be given to the Humane Society of New York, which has its headquarters at 313 East Fifty-eighth Street.

PARIS, April 27. -- France and Russia spent another day of delicate but friendly diplomatic dueling today without being able yet to decide on exactly how they are going to word their mutual assistance pact.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- General F.M. Andrews, chief of the powerful new General Headquarters Air Force, was revealed tonight to have told a house committee that in an "emergency" the United States "must be prepared to seize" British and French islands near American shores.

SIX concerts, four evening and two afternoon, will be given in the thirty-first Nay Festival to be held in Cincinnati May 21-25, under the direction of Eugene Goossens. The soloists will include Dorothee Manski, Helen Jepson and Mary Moore, sopranos; Rose Bampton and Kathryn Meisle, contraltos; Richard Crooks and Frederick Jagel, tenors; Richard Bonelli, baritone, and Keith Falkner, bass-baritone.

The trend of credits in practically all Latin-American markets during the first quarter of this year was sharply upward, creating a promising situation for exporters planning to expand trade with South America, William Swingle, manager of the foreign department and foreign credit interchange bureau of tire National Association of Credit Men, said yesterday.

The choice of appropriate books for leisurely reading in bed is a quite personal matter. A reader naturally turns to those which he finds most entertaining and enjoyable. Yet a certain few books do make a strong and continuing appeal for quiet and restful reading.

A LIST of forty-eight American compositions, performed by orchestras of the concert division of the Emergency Relief Bureau between Jan. 1 and April 15 has been compiled by George Crandall, its director. Music by forty American composers is included in this list.

ASHLAND, Wis., April 27 (AP). -- Old battle lines were re-formed and new life injected in the controversy over the University of Wisconsin today as John B. Chapple announced his candidacy for Governor.

Disregarding the protests of more than a dozen business organizations and of hundreds of individual business men in the midtown section through which 100,000 Socialists and Communists are to hold separate parades on May Day, Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine signed permits yesterday for the parades.

With all banks closed in Mexico yesterday as a result of the rise in silver, only local quotations of the peso were available. These showed a decline conforming with the drop in the world price of silver from 81 cents an ounce to 76 3/4 cents. The Chinese currencies reacted similarly.
The Fordham baseball team -- unbeaten in intercollegiate competition this season -- fell before its metropolitan rival, New York University, yesterday, losing by 8 to 5.

Thomas F. Daly quotes Dr. Tugwell: "The people can escape the iron ring of logic." This is held to mean that Dr. Tugwell does not found his New Deal ideas on logic. If a very simple little book by a simple but profound mind is read by Mr. Daly -- "Thinking About Thinking," by Cassius J. Keyser, professor emeritus of Columbia -- he will find that logic consists of postulates and logical deductions therefrom.

ROSELAND, N.J., April 27. -- Continuing his sensational string of successes in skeet competition, Edward E. Garland of the Roseland Community Gun Club established a world's record today in winning the New Jersey State .410 gauge championship on his home field with a score of 95 out of 100.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- How to discipline Senator Huey Long, the Louisiana "Kingfish," how to check his ferocious attacks upon President Roosevelt and other outstanding administration figures, without, at the same time, breaking down the cherished right of free speech, is being discussed behind closed doors of Democratic Senatorial leaders.

The Comet, new streamlined train of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, paused here at 9 o'clock last night in the Long Island City yards, while switching over from the Pennsylvania Railroad tracks and then went on to New Haven.

In 1934 there were 4,771,675 visits to the out-patient departments of 105 general and special hospitals in New York City, in comparison with 4,276,589 in 1930, according to a report issued yesterday by the hospital information and service bureau of the United Hospital Fund.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 27. -- Yale's freshman track team scored a 68-58 victory over Andover, an old prep school rival, at Yale Field today. The meet was close throughout, the decision hanging on the final event, the 800-meter run, which was won by Congdon of Yale.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 27. -- The Princeton lacrosse team went on a rampage against the Cornell ten on University Field today and buried the Ithacans under a 20-7 score. It was the fourth straight victory of the season for the Tiger stickmen, who have not been defeated since 1932.

IN a foreword contributed to the 1934 Annual brought out by the Art Directors Club Kenneth Collins furnished a text that lends itself to widespread application. "Any man concerned with the production of advertising in this country," he observed, "has to interest himself in the constant betterment of the illustrations used in advertisements.

ASHEVILLE, N.C. -- The annual Junior League Follies, the appearance of Bill Tilden and his troupe of professional tennis players and a benefit party for the Biltmore Hospital, founded by the late George W. Vanderbilt, are features of the social calendar here for the next three weeks.

THREE picture-books of more than ordinary interest are announced for early publication by three different publishers. On May 8, William Morrow Co. will issue "Men and Ships of Steel," a story of the navy in photographs, by Wayne Francis Palmer.

PHILADELPHIA, April 27. -- Seventeen persons, including four residents of England, will receive awards for scientific achievement from the Franklin Institute at its annual Medal Day ceremony May 15, it was announced today by Dr. Howard McClenahan, the director.

A surprising reversal in the final match of the women's intercollegiate fencing championship on the strips at the East Building of New York University last night deprived Brooklyn College of its team title as Hunter College, with a determined last-minute spurt, took the honors for the first time in seven years of the tournament.

IT is not easy to say what gives this story of the Scottish Highlands its somewhat old-fashioned flavor. Perhaps it is merely a stronger emphasis on plot than on any other element in the romantic compound. T.J. Morrison is a young man -- younger than most of his colleagues in the Scotch literary renaissance.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- The great glaciers of the West, last remnants of the Ice Age on continental United States, have been retreating from their strongholds in the mountains at double time since last year. This was reported before the annual meeting of the American Geophysical Union by Francois E. Matthes of the United States Geological Survey, chairman of the union's committee on glaciers.

THE attention of the world has been attracted to the Red Army by the recent announcement of Vice Commissar of War Tukhachevsky that its strength had been increased by 56 per cent in the past year, and by the fact that Germany used this increase as a pretext for the introduction of universal military service.

IN a few months' time these pages may be listing among the openings such a phrase as "MOONLIGHT MADNESS -- Tonight at the Music Box." For now on the statute books is a note that the play may go on during the Seventh Day, a note that Governor Lehman countersigned last Tuesday.

WITHOUT wasting time or the patience of others with estimates of Paul Hindemith's place in the contemporary panorama, he may be introduced in this department as one of the notable composers of the day. Only recently there was cause to mention him in an aside as having supplied the cadenzas for the "Adelaide" concerto reconstructed by Casadesus from a Mozart manuscript.

SINCE "Kind Lady" is only a horror tale we must not speak Too solemnly about art. Art is illumination; it carries our knowledge of life beyond the boundaries of our personal experience. But when an unpretentious play of macabre sensations is neatly written and perfectly acted it gives a joy that is all out of proportion to its content.

CLAUDIUS GREGORY'S stories, "Forgotten Men." "Valerie Hathaway" and now "Solomon Levi," are simple tales of sentiment and the affections, involving religious mysticism and the ideal of human brotherhood. His latest novel is about a Jewish family of the merchant class in New York which remains orthodox in its observances and faith.

Although this story deals with murder, it is neither a mystery story nor a thriller. It falls of being a mystery because no attempt is made to conceal the identity of the murderer or to lead the reader into drawing wrong conclusions from the facts set before him.

It is interesting to read the declaration of Dr. Vilhjalmur Stefansson in THE TIMES, that Irishmen discovered America. May I recall, however, that I made a rather similar declaration in THE TIMES during the last Mayoral election and that the pros and cons of the subject are discussed by me in detail in my volume, "Ireland and the Foundations of Europe."

More large corporations revealed last week their intentions of reducing fixed charges by refunding outstanding bonds. Plans are being considered, in most instances, along lines of replacing present liens with others having lower interest coupons.

PARIS, April 26. -- In these years since the war there has been much talk of peace, security and disarmament, of pacts and covenants. Somehow, perhaps because they chatter more about these things than other peoples, the idea has been spread abroad that the French have in some measure lost their nerve.

Taxation of non-resident aliens has become an important issue to American business. The subject was brought to the front by the inauguration of an intensive campaign by the United States Treasury having for its objective the rigid enforcement of revenue laws applicable to transactions conducted by or for account of non-resident aliens and non-resident foreign corporations.

If the United States Senate fails to pass the Social Security Bill, "the movements for social security are likely to receive a setback for a decade or more," Edward F. McGrady, Assistant Secretary of Labor, said yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel Astor of the American Association for Social Security.

WHEN shrubs are in bloom it's time to sharpen the pruning shears." The writer heard an old gardener make that comment once and has never fogotten it. It's a good bit of advice, because it is double-edged. The best time to prune shrubs, almost without exception, is just after they are through flowering.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- A resolution attacking the administration's holding company bill and calling upon all members to oppose passage of the measure will be among the principal matters before the annual meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, opening here Tuesday.

LOS ANGELES, April 26. THOSE admirers of Walter Hampden and his classical repertoire who journey to the Pasadena Community Playhouse these nights have something of a shock awaiting them. For Mr. Hampden is in blackface.

RACING over Muroc Dry Lake, California, a stock Hudson sedan last week smashed thirty-five A.A.A. records, even upsetting the mark made in the same make and type of car by Sir Malcolm Campbell at Daytona Beach last February, it is announced.
THE more the merry fight program is studied, the stronger grows the belief in this corner that it should be carried out with a musical accompaniment.

WEIRD, extraordinary, hair-raising events always emblazon Talbot Mundy's romances of British India, his limitless capacity for hocus-pocus attaining its peak in this wild tale of murder. Hindu occultism, supernatural phenomena and penetration into the grisly realm of the fourth dimension.

THE fast-flowing stream of life is the "River" of Mr. Boyd's title, but it is accompanied, and at times symbolized, by that other river which flows past the Pennsylvania town of Midian. There the Rand family had lived for several generations, and there Clara and Tommy Rand, the two whose histories this novel relates, were born.

CHICAGO, April 28. -- Raisers of hogs in the middle West are watching the market closely. They withhold supplies whenever there is a drop in price, and rush them in on every sharp advance. Eleven leading markets handled 196,000 hogs last week, an increase of 7,000 over the previous week, but 250,000 less than a year ago, and 277,000 less than the corresponding week two years ago.

I have been interested in your reports of the sessions of the American Newspaper Publishers Association. I do not know what THE TIMES thinks of the actions taken there, as reported in your issue of today, but to my mind they sound much like a Republican program. Are most newspaper men still Republicans, with THE TIMES in a sad minority -- or not voting?
WASHINGTON, April 28. -- Food prices are about to stop their nervous climb and settle down to a constant level for a few months, the consumers' guide of AAA says.
CINCINNATI, April 28 (AP). -- Behind the five-hit pitching of Bill Lee, the Cubs rallied for three runs in the ninth today to defeat the Reds, 4 to 1.

ABOARD U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA, San Pedro, Calif., April 28. -- One hundred and thirty-four ships anchored here and in San Diego Harbor will commence their sortie from port shortly after midnight tonight as the United States Fleet starts the preliminary phases of one of its greatest mimic wars.

MANILA, April 28. -- Suffrage leaders foresaw tonight a hard fight to retain the ballot rights given temporarily to women in the Philippines because of the apathy of their sex and scattered outcroppings of opposition.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- Pressed by President Roosevelt for greater speed on his legislative program, administration leaders will try earnestly tomorrow to break the anti-lynching filibuster which has held the Senate at a standstill since early last week.

The Knickerbocker Greys had to battle a head wind on their parade down Fifth Avenue yesterday, but with colors furled they marched trimly to St. Thomas Church at Fifty-third Street for their annual service.

CHICAGO, April 28. -- The course of prices for corn on the Board of Trade here last week was affected at times by efforts of local professionals, with the help of a little outside buying, to advance prices for futures, based on expectations of scarcity before a new crop is available. Bulges, however, were short-lived, as realizing sales and the erratic action of wheat created nervousness, and at times sharp fluctuations.

Four hundred members of the Jesuit Mothers Guild attended mass at the Church of St. Francis Xavier in West Sixteenth Street yesterday and then had communion breakfast at the Waldorf-Astoria in honor of Mrs. Francis J. Cashman, president of the guild.

Telephonic messages from Jewish leaders in eight key cities and letters from Governor Lehman and Dr. Albert Einstein reinforced the plea of speakers here last night for adequate funds to aid in the rehabilitation of the Jews of Germany and Eastern Europe and the upbuilding of Palestine.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- Regardless of the "action or inaction" of the administration on increased taxes, the Progressives in the Senate propose, before this session of Congress adjourns, "to make the best fight of which they are capable for drastic increases in the taxes levied upon wealth and income."
NEWARK, N.J., April 28. -- The Newark Bears took a firm grip on first place in the International League today by beating Toronto in both ends of a double-header before a crowd of 12,000.

Clearances of Spring merchandise, with special emphasis on markdowns of women's coats and suits, met with an active consumer response last week in the various sections where these events were featured by stores, according to reports received in the wholesale market here.

SCHENECTADY, April 28. -- Union College officials made public today a letter written by President Fox to Governor Lehman in which Dr. Fox strongly objected to the Weisman bill which would "prevent a private school or college from determining its own character," according to the letter.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., April 28 (AP). -- Officials of the United Ribbon Workers and the Federation of Silk Workers stated today that a strike will be called in the silk ribbon industry, effective at midnight Wednesday, unless manufacturers and workers get together and settle their differences.

The Rev. R.E. Woods, preaching yesterday at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral, praised the government of the United States for "attempting to practice the highest degree of Christian charity." He defined this as "preventing the necessity for charity by enabling the poor to help themselves."

Mercedes de Velasco, screen dancer and actress who returned to this city recently from Brazil, will be seen here in public soon in a native jungle dance which she added to her repertoire after spending a year in the Matto Grosso studying the ceremonial dances of jungle tribes.
NEW ORLEANS, April 28. -- While last week in the cotton market here started with trading rather quiet, activity increased as the price of silver advanced sharply.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 28. -- Cornell athletics were cut loose from the old system today, as the university announced a new plan of athletic organization and control. The system was adopted by the board of trustees, which met yesterday, in approving a report of a special committee which has been investigating the present set-up since last January.

LONDON, April 28. -- Germany's submarine building and her reported conversion of the Island of Sylt into a secret North Sea airplane and naval base with subterranean hangars has brought the question of empire defense into the political forefront, "Defense week" is how one commentator describes the coming days.

ROSELAND, N.J., April 28. -- Yesterday, during a lull in the cannonading at the Roseland Community Gun Club, scene of the New Jersey skeet championships, we cornered Ed Garland, the man with the ten-gallon hat, in the clubhouse.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- Some experts expressed the belief today that Secretary Morgenthau had played a smart game by not boosting the price of silver in the last few days. If the Treasury is using the two billion dollar stabilization fund for speculative purposes in silver, the gamble apparently has been good, they said.

The four-masted barkentine Juan Sebastian de Elcano, training ship of the Spanish Navy, arrived yesterday from the Pacific on her sixth visit to New York. The ship, which has been on a round-the-world cruise that began at Ferrol last Aug. 15, has on board thirty-seven cadets who are in training to become officers in the Spanish Navy.

The Visitation Triangles captured the American Basketball League championship by conquering the Jewels, 26 -- 10, in the fifth and deciding clash of their play-off series at Prospect Hall last night. A crowd of 2,200 saw the battle between the Brooklyn rivals.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- The Shipping Board Bureau of the Department of Commerce in a report made public today condemned all tariffs filed by common and contract carriers in intercoastal commerce under the Intercoastal Shipping Act as failing to comply with the requirements of the statute.

CHICAGO, April 28. -- Grain future prices on the Chicago Board of Trade fluctuated within a wider range last week, and closed with moderate reactions after a good advance. Net losses on wheat futures were 2 1/8 to 2 1/4 cents a bushel. Corn was off 5/8 to 2 1/2 cents.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., April 28. -- The efforts of Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley to settle out of court the factional differences of the Hungarian Dutch Reformed Church came to naught today when the meeting called for the purpose in the church developed into bedlam.

Commodity futures declined fairly sharply last week despite the wide advance in silver, while the temporary flurries in the grain market had only a minor effect on the other staples. Gains were made in cottonseed oil, lead and silk futures, however.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $7,583,674,480. They consist of Treasury bonds, consols, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

CHICAGO, April 28. -- Oats were depressed in sympathy with other grains at times last week on the Board of Trade, but there also were sharp prices advances, with profit-taking a feature. On the breaks, processors absorbed the offerings.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- The report that the nation "is closer to breaking the back of the depression" than at any time since recovery began was made by the organized manufacturers today as hundreds of critically minded business men converged on the capital for the twenty-third annual convention of the United States Chamber of Commerce.

Father COUGHLIN now announces that he will not lead a new political party. He still thinks it desirable, and even necessary. It will attempt to embody and carry out the social and political ideas which he has so long been broadcasting. But though he may found it, he will not head it, and may not be even a prominent member of it.
WASHINGTON, April 28. -- Highlights in President Roosevelt's radio speech follow:

The end of April finds the Federal Government with a deficit of about $2,700,000,000 for the current fiscal year. This is approximately $600,000,000 less than the deficit at the same point last year. It is still further below the budget estimates submitted by the President to Congress early in the present session.

Interest in the foreign exchange market last week centred in the sharp rise in the silver currencies following the Presidential decree lifting the purchase price of domestic silver to 77.57 cents, from 71.11 previously. Silver as a commodity rose in New York to 81 cents, highest since November, 1920, and in London it touched 36 1/4d, highest since July, 1922.

The search for Mrs. Ann Booth Gordon, 25 years old, who disappeared April 10 from Farmington, Conn., shifted to the metropolitan area yesterday, after her father, Walter C. Booth, New York insurance broker, turned over to the police a letter he had received from Creedmoor, L.I.
A bright sun shining warmly through clear skies yesterday drew the largest crowds of the year to the beaches and resorts and into the parks and streets of the city.

Francis Cola-Santo announces a new series of popular-priced operas for the Manhattan Opera House beginning on Thursday evening. "Aida," with Aldo Franchetti conducting, is billed for the opening, "Rigoletto" for Friday night under Miguel Sandoval.

Mounted and exhibited in the American Museum of Natural History is a set of djahns, birds resembling the American barn-owl, the acquisition of which involved great personal danger because superstitious natives of the island of Manus, in the South Seas Admiralty group, regarded the killing of such a bird a certain sign of death.

EAST MEADOW, L.I., April 28. -Two men were fatally injured and a third was taken to Nassau Hospital with serious spinal injuries when an automobile overturned at 1 o'clock this morning on Hempstead Turnpike near Jerusalem Road.
VATICAN CITY, April 28. -- Pope Pius brought to an end this afternoon the international Jubilee Year with a religious ceremony in St. Peter's Basilica.

LONDON, April 27. -- Much quieter conditions have been restored in the Foreign Exchange market, thanks to the success of the Dutch and Swiss authorities who have temporarily succeeded in restoring something like confidence in their currencies.

The cults of force in the world are sweeping freedom away, the Rev. Dr. Raymond C. Knox asserted yesterday morning in his sermon at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University. Dr. Knox is chaplain of the university.
NEWPORT, R.I., April 28. -- Mrs. H.S. Hooker gave a dinner for a company of twelve at the Muenchinger-King tonight. Among her guests were some of the members of the Morin-Wilson wedding party.

KAUNAS, Lithuania, April 28. -- It is learned in well-informed quarters here that the reply of the Lithuanian Government to the note of the signatory powers to the Memel convention, requesting closer adhesion to the letter and spirit of the Memel statute, will be forwarded on Tuesday.

Plans for the establishment of a separate code for municipal bankers who are now operating under the general Investment Bankers Code will be discussed today at a special meeting of the code committee to be held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

SAN JUAN, P.R., April 28. -- Charged with conspiring against the life of President Rafael L. Trujillo of the Dominican Republic, Amadeo Barletta, Italian consul, has been held incomunicado in a military prison at Santo Domingo since Wednesday, relatives of the Italian official revealed here today.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- The so-called company union is not an adequate agency for genuine collective bargaining, according to a report on this form of organization, part of a study of the government in labor relations, made public today by the Twentieth Century Fund.

MOSCOW, April 28. -- France and the Soviet Union from the beginning of negotiations on their projected pact have been agreed that mutual assistance should be subject to a decision of the Council of the League of Nations, it was authoritatively announced tonight through Tass, the Soviet official news agency.

Following an old tradition of their regiment, the three troops known as Squadron A, which comprise the Manhattan unit of the 101st Cavalry, attended the annual memorial service and vespers yesterday afternoon at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at Ninetieth Street.

John Wicklun, senior metropolitan champion, captured the fifty-yard back-stroke final which featured the weekly A.A.U. swimming meet at the Park Central pool yesterday. The St. George Dragon Club star's time for the distance was 0:29.2 He finished ahead of Everett Martin of the Ninety-second Street Y.M.H.A and Henry Pferr of the Brooklyn Central Y.M.C.A.

Brooklyn bats swung with extraordinary inaptitude yesterday against the slow-ball pitching of Bobby Smith, with the unhappy result that the Braves took the final game at Ebbets Field, 5 to 3, and the series, two games to one.

Commissioner Valentine told more than 3,500 members of the Police Department yesterday that if they reacted properly to the new order in the department "the chiselers, who enable former bootlegging thugs, murderers and assassins to insinuate that they bought your good name, won't dare to stench your midst."

Of late little has been heard about the war, at one time blazing fiercely, between the Administration and Governor DAVEY of Ohio about relief in that State. Perhaps Mr. FARLEY, that Jeffersonian genius of conciliation, has sprinkled patience upon heats that might threaten discomfort in '36.

The recent proposal of several ministers in New York to ignore war was likened to a man standing in the midst of a smallpox epidemic and saying "I'll have nothing to do with it," without taking any precautions, in a sermon yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Irving Husted Berg, pastor of the Fort Washington Collegiate Reformed Church, Fort Washington Avenue and West 181st Street.

CLEVELAND, April 28 (AP). -- The Tigers blasted four Cleveland pitchers today for twelve hits, including a home run by Hank Greenberg, to end the six-game winning streak of the Indians. The score was 5 to 3.

LONDON, April 27. -- The boom in silver is attracting widespread attention. The price here is now the highest in thirteen years. The current quotation of 36 1/4d an ounce compares with 12d, touched in 1931.

Although there is no place for even a singing bird in Beethoven's "Missa Solemnis," an ordinary sparrow injected itself into the concluding performance of the New York Philharmonic Orchestra and the Schola Cantorum yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall.

Re-employment is the main problem facing the country today and its solution can come about only through private business expansion, the Guaranty Trust Company says in the current issue of its publication, the Guaranty Survey.

BERLIN, April 27. -- The week's business sentiment was less optimistic and almost all leading stocks declined on the Boerse. Industry was disappointed by the warning of the vice president of the Reichsbank that currency considerations imposed a limit on State financing with credit and that the most immediate problem was consolidation of short-term debts already incurred for the creation of work.

LEWISBURG, Pa., April 28. -- Richard A. McGee has accepted an offer to become warden of the new $10,000,000 penitentiary on Rikers Island, New York City, it was made known today when his resignation as supervisor of education at the Northeastern Federal Penitentiary was accepted by the warden, Major Henry C. Hill.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, April 28 (AP). -- A vast national defense scheme designed to make Rumania the strongest military power in Southeastern Europe and the Balkans was approved today at a council session at which King Carol presided.

PARIS, April 27. -- The foreign exchange market is very quiet, with the guilder firm here as well as the Swiss franc. Gold continues, however, to leave both Holland and Switzerland, particularly the latter.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- The United States today is "closer to breaking the back of the depression than at any time since 1932," according to the National Association of Manufacturers, which today made public "a careful analysis" of the business outlook in the nation.

The last of Arturo Toscanini's series of farewells for the season to Philharmonic-Symphony subscribers was the occasion for protracted demonstrations of enthusiasm at yesterday afternoon's repetition of Beethoven's "Missa Solemnis" in Carnegie Hall.

Paramount has two stories under consideration for Barbara Stanwyck, who recently was engaged on a one-picture deal. She will either play opposite Gary Cooper in "Invitation to Happiness," his next film after "Peter Ibbetson," or have the leading feminine role in Ferenc Molnar's story, "The Pastry Baker's Wife."

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- Senators Hale and White, Governor Brann and the Maine delegation in the House, together with prominent representatives of the textile industry in that State will be heard tomorrow at the first of a series of conferences on the cotton textile situation.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 28. -- Three 7-year-old boys who disappeared from their homes here Friday afternoon were hunted widely today by the police, members of the American Legion, city officials and airplane observers. They were reported seen yesterday at the Newark Airport.

Eddie Tolan had just beaten Ralph Metcalfe for the Olympic 100-meter championship at Los Angeles when one commentator delivered himself of the very expressive but inelegant remark, "When Africa speaks, she talks mighty fast." Three years later the summaries of the Penn and Drake relays display for all to see the remarkable rise of the Negro as a track athlete.

Several points in Donald Richberg's recent statement regarding the Brookings Institution report on the NRA deserve comment. In my opinion, Mr. Richberg's emotional defense of his own NRA is in sharp and unfavorable contrast to the careful statements characteristic of the several Brookings Institution reports which I have read.

Daylight saving is here again, and no doubt there will be millions of seasonally furrowed brows. They belong to good citizens who have never quite mastered the alleged simple mathematics of pushing the clock forward one hour.

BOOS, Ill., April 28 (AP). -- A small army balloon, carrying delicate instruments to record upper atmospheric phenomena, landed safely on the outskirts of this small community at 1:10 o'clock this afternoon after a four-hour flight through the substratosphere.
Miriam Marmein gave her first New York recital in several seasons yesterday afternoon at the Barbizon-Plaza before a muchpleased audience that comfortably filled the hall.

Senator Robert F. Wagner of New York defended his Labor Disputes Bill, now before Congress, and Clinton L. Bardo, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, attacked the measure in a radio debate last evening over station WOR.

Exhibitions which run the gamut of variety, from work of recognized masters of other generations to painting, craft work and sculpture done by children, are on the calendar of art shows for the current week. A number of group shows of size are included.
J.B. Grier of Wilmington, Del., won all the major prizes in the annual spring shoot of the Atlantic Indians held over the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 28. -- The text of the radio address by President Roosevelt tonight follows:

A clean sweep in the running events gave the German-American Athletic Club a well-earned victory over its nearest rival, the Brooklyn St. George Dragon Club, 45 -- 24, as the first of a series of advancement meets was staged by the women's athletic committee of the Metropolitan A.A.U. yesterday at McCarren Park, Brooklyn.

BOSTON, April 28 (AP). -- Four hits by the Senators and two errors by Manager Cronin enabled Washington to tally four runs in the ninth today and defeat the Red Sox, 5 -- 3. A crowd of 23,500 fans watched the game. The Senators swept the three-game series.

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday a call for redemption on March 1, 1936, of all its series A New York-New Jersey Interstate Bridge (Arthur Kill) 4 1/2 per cent bonds, due serially from 1937 to 1946. The bonds are outstanding in the amount of $12,200,000 of the original amount of $14,000,000 issued in 1926.

MEXICO, D.F., April 28. -- The Bank of Mexico announced today it would buy and sell an unlimited quantity of dollars at 3.60 pesos beginning tomorrow, thus restoring the exchange rate which until the peso shot up Thursday has been in effect for a year and a half.

BERLIN, April 28. -- Germany's dependence upon foreign raw materials was revealed today as the most serious stumbling block in the path of Reichsfuehrer Hitler's comprehensive program to rearm the nation.
An Irish folk dance presented by twelve little girls will be a feature of the Spring fete of St. James's Church on the afternoon of May 6 at the Central Park Casino. They will be:

Two of the three justices of the Court of Special Sessions who were condemned by Mayor La Guardia Saturday for having arrested sentence on John J. Sullivan, former night watchman of the Wallabout Market, after he had been convicted of violating a regulation of the Department of Markets, issued replies yesterday.

A new novel by Willa Cather -- her first in four years -- is announced for publication on Aug. 1 by Alfred A. Knopf. The title will be "Lucy Gayheart," and the publishers say it is "romantic -- Western -- modern." There will be a limited, large-paper, signed edition, the size of which will be determined by the number of orders received before June 1, the date on which the book will go to press.

NEW HAVEN, April 27. -- Professor Irving Fishers' index number of commodity prices this week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 81.8, which compares with 81.5 the week before, 81.7 two weeks before, 81 three weeks before and 80.6 four weeks before.

" The church of the living God must set itself to create a Christian social order," Bishop Titus Lowe declared yesterday at the morning service in the First Swedish Methodist Episcopal Church, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-second Street.

American merchant ships are not adequately staffed with officers to handle emergencies at sea, according to Bert L. Todd, secretary of the United Licensed Officers Association. In a survey of the shipping situation in the current Neptune Log, official organ of the association, Mr. Todd places the blame for the Morro Castle disaster on what he maintains was a lack of licensed men qualified to direct the crew rather than on the men themselves.

Tangible evidence of his confidence in the investment value of real estate was given over the week-end by Edgar A. Levy, who announced his return to the market after an absence of five years, with the purchase of the southwest corner of Third Avenue and East Fifty-sixth Street.

EXCELSIOR SPRINGS, Mo., April 28. -- Springfield, Ill., home of Abraham Lincoln, first Republican President, was picked today for the "grass-roots" conference of Republicans from nine Midwestern States. The date, to be set next week, is expected to be during the first two weeks of June.

CHICAGO, April 28 (AP). -- The White Sox concluded their first home stand of the season today by warming 28,000 shivering fans with a 6-to-4 victory over the Browns to sweep the series and extend their string to six straight.

The Summer weather -- well, to be exact, it is Lee Shubert -- is bringing a light comedy to town this evening. The name is "Something Gay," and in it are Tallulah Bankhead and Hugh Sinclair, Percy Ames, Walter Pidgeon, Nancy Ryan, Roy Gordon and Elizabeth Dewing.

LOURDES, France, April 28 (AP). -- Cardinal Pacelli, Papal Secretary of State, served indirect notice upon Chancellor Hitler of Germany today that the church never would come to terms with him while the Nazis persist in a racial philosophy "contrary to the Christian faith."
American Jews were warned in sermons at two synagogues yesterday morning to be alert to the menace of fascism and increasing anti-semitism.

While Socialists and Communists were completing their programs yesterday for their separate May Day parades, the West Side Association of Commerce announced plans to prevent future parades in the business districts. Together with a dozen other organizations, the association had protested in vain against the granting of permits for the May Day parades.

Forest and brush fires continued yesterday on Long Island and in New Jersey, with one of the largest reported in the vicinity of Riverhead, L.I., where 400 acres of the Flanders Club game preserve were destroyed. The fire came within 100 feet of the clubhouse while 350 volunteers fought it.

New York City should be judged not by the gangster and criminal element but by its cultural and spiritual qualities, as represented in the many churches, synogogues, art galleries and theatres, the Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray said yesterday in a sermon at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration, 1 East Twenty-ninth Street.

ST. LOUIS, April 28 (AP). -- Cy Blanton, Pittsburgh rookie, engaged Dizzy Dean in a hurling duel today and came out on top as the Pirates downed the world champion Cardinals, 3 to 2, in the finale of their three-game series before a crowd of 12,000.

Louis J. Carruthers of New York has again been appointed chairman of the amateur rule committee of the United States Lawn Tennis Association and this body has been designated to formulate and administer regulations for the enforcement of the new eight weeks' playing rule.

The Bee Line, Inc., operator of several bus routes in Queens, served notice yesterday of its intention to go to the courts and to Governor Lehman, if necessary, to obtain redress against Mayor La Guardia for "destroying" its business and "traducing" its good name and that of its president, Harry B. Carter.

ALBANY, April 28. -- With more than 100 of the "thirty-day" bills disposed of Governor Lehman planned today another busy week on the big batch of measures passed in the final ten days of the legislative session. It was expected that he would announce tomorrow some measures on which he would hold public hearings.

Whenever currency-tinkering experiments are resumed at Washington, Wall Street at once indulges in confused and conflicting inference from the course of markets. On last week's stock market, the advance which has prevailed throughout April continued, with several "million-share days."

The chess championship of the United States should be contested for annually in tournaments open to the best players in the country, and not by match play as heretofore, Frank J. Marshall, champion since 1909, stated yesterday.
LONDON, Monday, April 29 (AP). -- A "powerful" naval and airplane base has been constructed on the North Sea by Germany, The Daily Herald said today.

Last week two members of the New York banking community made criticisms of the new Banking Bill which cannot fail to impress thinking persons. One of these criticisms was indirect. BENJAMIN M. ANDERSON Jr. of the Chase National Bank devoted a lengthy analysis to a recent book by LAUGHLIN CURRIE called "The Supply and Control of Money in the United States."

Today the annual gathering of books for seamen will be begun in New York by the American Merchant Marine Library Association. This opportunity to share books must make special appeal to those who cannot themselves go out upon the seas except in their imaginations.

BERLIN, April 28. -- According to present plans, German naval experts will go to London, probably this week, to hold a series of preliminary conversations with the British Admiralty on the Reich's plan for strengthening its fleet, provided Britain does not abandon the talks.

ROME, April 28. -- A somewhat cryptic warning to the Italian people that there were difficult times ahead was sounded by Premier Benito Mussolini in a speech to a large crowd of workers in the Plazza Venezia at today's celebration of the "birthday of Rome."

Joseph Droual of the French Sporting Club, who had a five-minute allowance, defeated sixty-eight rivals in the twenty-seventh annual A.A.U. six-mile handicap road race staged by the St. Anselm's A.C. in the Bronx yesterday.

MILAN, Italy, April 28. -- To enter Italy after a year's absence is to meet at once the "warlike face" described by Premier Benito Mussolini. In this respect the change in the last few months has been spectacular. Signs of military activity are more apparent than in Germany.
The recent session of the Legislature was characterized yesterday by George H. Hallett Jr., secretary of the Citizens Union, as one of "extraordinary accomplishments."

More than 1,000 members of the Holy Name Society of the Fire Department, attending the eleventh annual communion breakfast of the society yesterday morning at the Hotel Astor, heard speakers assert that religious faith was the "greatest guarantee against the spread of radicalism" in this country.

LONDON, April 28 (AP). -- In private referendum British electors are piling up a large vote in favor of peace measures -- adherence to the League of Nations and abolition of military planes and of the private manufacture of arms.

ST. LOUIS, April 28. -- Asserting that Leo Durocher, captain and shortstop of the St. Louis Cardinals National League Baseball Club, had manifested an anti-union attitude, the Central Trades and Labor Union voted unanimously today to boycott the Cardinals' games here until Durocher is removed from the team's line-up.

The city administration was reported yesterday to be planning to ask Governor Lehman to veto the bill setting up the Wendel Foundation, created to manage the vast real estate holdings left by the late Rebecca Wendel Swope and Ella V. Von E. Wendel.

LONDON, April 28. -- Lord Rutherford, director of Cavendish Laboratory at Cambridge, is making public on behalf of scientists throughout the world an appeal to the Soviet Union to allow Professor Peter Kapitza to return to Great Britain to complete vastly important researches in the new laboratory the British built for him at Cambridge.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- Monetary troubles in Mexico, born of world silver prices soaring after United States Treasury offers, today were taken directly to Secretary Morgenthau by representatives of the southern republic.

STOCKHOLM, April 28 (AP). -- New emphasis is being placed on military aviation in the small countries of Northern Europe which, including the Baltic States, now could place more than 500 planes in the air at one time.

Seventeen-hour train service between New York and Chicago was begun yesterday, when the crack trains of the New York Central and the Pennsylvania Railroads began operating under new schedules. The running time, for both the Twentieth Century on the New York Central and the Broadway Limited on the Pennsylvania, was cut one hour for the trip.

Brilliant riding by Franco Georgetti in the last five miles enabled the Italian ace and his partner, Tino Reboli, to capture the thirty-mile motor-paced professional-team race before 9,000 persons yesterday at the Coney Island Velodrome. The crowd was the largest in four years to see races at the Velodrome.
LONDON, April 27. -- The Economist's fortnightly index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood on April 24, at 66.7

PHILADELPHIA, April 28. -- Delegates to the biennial convention of the National Federation of Music, Clubs attended special choral and organ sevices in churches here this morning, arranged by the Pennsylvania Chapter of the American Guild of Organists.
Baseball's Hall of Fame beckoned to Hal Schumacher yesterday at the Polo Grounds, but the blond husky from Dolgeville, N.Y., missed the call by a margin that could not be narrower.

Mrs. Florence Sheldon Jaffrey, 37-year-old divorcee and daughter of a well-to-do Brooklyn coffee importer, leaped from a window of her studio apartment at 36 East Fifty-eighth Street just after dawn yesterday.

PROVIDENCE R.I., April 28. -- In a labyrinth of secret tunnels and subcellars beneath the Warwick "fortress" of a crime "syndicate" uncovered in a spectacular raid early Saturday, Federal officials hope to find three bodies of racketeers slain by the syndicate in a career of robbery, kidnapping and narcotics and rum smuggling.

THE TIMES, in reporting the address of an eminent industrialist before the American Chemical Society, stated: "He estimated that the accumulated demand in the durable goods industries was about $85,000,000,000."

PHILADELPHIA, April 28 (AP). -- Two American records were shattered and titles were carried off by Woonsocket, R.I.; New York City and Allentown, Pa., today in the junior national weight-lifting championships.
