The unloading of incoming foreign mail at the docks instead of transferring it to lighters at Quarantine, is urged in a report to be made to the Chamber of Commerce of New York at its monthly meeting next Thursday. The change, it is said, would expedite the delivery of mail, prevent long and unnecessary delay to passengers, and save the government the expense of double handling of mail sacks.

Details of how the "momentous influences" of the last two years have reshaped social welfare activity in this country are given in the 1935 Social Work Year Book of the Russell Sage Foundation, issued yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, April 28 (AP). -- Interest in the Federal Government's prosecution of alleged income tax law violations in Louisiana revolved around three developments yesterday, most important of which was postponement of the trial of Abe L. Shushan, a leader in Senator Long's political organization, who was scheduled to face Federal court here May 6 on ten counts charging attempted tax evasion.

Martha Graham brought her season to a close last night with a brilliant recital at the Guild Theatre, in which she was assisted, as usual, by her exemplary group and the indispensable Louis Horst. The special interest of the evening was divided between the first performance of two new compositions, called "Perspective -- No. 1 and No. 2," and the repetition of the large group work.

MOSCOW, April 28. -- The thirty-five churches which are all that remain of the thousand that once dotted Moscow were filled to overflowing last night for the celebration of the Russian Easter, the holiest anniversary of the Greek Orthodox calendar.

TRENTON, N.J., April 28 (AP). -- Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Relief Administrator, informed Governor Hoffman today that further Federal aid to New Jersey would be contingent upon the State's contributing its "fair share."

The inventions of the last 200 years have brought Western civilization nearly to a state of material perfection, Professor William B. Guthrie, head of the department of government and sociology at City College, declared yesterday morning at Montefiore Synagogue, Hewitt and Macy Places, the Bronx.

An old downtown hotel with an interesting background as the meeting place of legal and political celebrities of the city, State and nation passed to new control, it was learned yesterday when real estate brokers announced the leasing for 101 years of the Cosmopolitan, at Chambers Street and West Broadway.

Columbia's hopes of retaining its Eastern Intercollegiate League baseball title received a severe jolt on Saturday when the defending champions suffered two unexpected defeats at the hands of an underrated Cornell nine.

PITTSBURGH, April 28. -- The event of last week for the steel trade was the outline of policy on price filing released by the National Industrial Recovery Board, which was virtually altogether in favor of the Steel Code. The trade had feared that restrictions would be imposed that would decrease the code's usefulness.

The preliminary meeting of Midwestern Republicans was held in secret on Saturday at Excelsior Springs, Mo. From a trustworthy informant the press learned that there were many differences of opinion, but agreement on two points. The first was that everything must be done to defeat President ROOSEVELT next year, while the second was that no declaration of Republican principles should be adopted before June.

Settlement of the ninety-five-day strike of several thousand employes of the National Biscuit Company in New York and Philadelphia was announced last night. Striking employes in both cities are to return to work this morning.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 28. -- As Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer checked out of the Syracuse Hotel today government secret service men checked reports of jury tampering in Schultz's trial for income tax evasion.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- Indirect employment on the railroad construction and improvement program financed with Public Works funds was three and four times greater than the amount of employment afforded on the site of projects, according to a factual study made by the Bureau of Labor Statistics for Secretary Ickes made public today.

Unique among garden tours in behalf of philanthropy is the series planned for Wednesday and Thursday afternoons and the afternoons of May 15 and 22, when gardens of private homes in New York will be shown for the benefit of the Anne Brown Alumnae Free Nursery School.

ROSELAND, N.J., April 28. -- With a remarkable exhibition of steadiness under trying conditions, Dr. C.W. Scranton of East Orange, a member of the host club, scored 99 out of 100 to capture the New Jersey State all-gauge skeet championship on the field of the Roseland Community Gun Club today.

BERLIN, April 28. -- Roman Catholics throughout Germany began today an intensive campaign for the maintenance of their parochial schools as guaranteed in the Vatican concordat. The campaign is to be pursued throughout a so-called "educational week" lasting until May 5.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- Enactment of social security legislatio was linked as a "necessity" along side the new $4,000,000,000 emergency work relief program by President Roosevelt tonight, when he went on the air for another 'fireside talk" with the American people.

An assassin, seeking Dr. Angel Morales, former Minister of the Dominican Republic at Washington and now in exile from his native land, forced his way last night into the apartment at 87 Hamilton Place that Dr. Morales shares with his friend and ardent supporter, Sergio Bencosme.

The cotton futures market was more active last week than it had been in some time. After a decline, quotations recovered moderately when the higher domestic price for silver was announced. At the close on Saturday, active future contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were 7 to 32 points higher than at the close of the previous week.
Gains are shown in the earnings reports of several corporations just issued. Statements follow:

PHILADELPHIA, April 28. -- A base-clearing homer by Earl Combs gave the Yankees the necessary lift this afternoon to clear out of Shibe Park with a clean sweep of their three-game series with the Athletics.

We live in a world of new beginnings and tragic ends, the Rev. Robert Russell Wicks, Dean of the Chapel of Princeton University, said yesterday morning in a sermon at the Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive.

There are others besides the famous European sculptor now visiting this country who deplore the lack of front-yard gardens in our city and who would rejoice in the spectacle of gay, fragrant borders around the Public Library and in Bryant Park.

Among the many sidelights -- some of them conflicting -- which bear on the course of production, consumption, trade and business recovery, none is at the moment more remarkable than the motor-car reports. The Commerce Department has just published its statement of last month's automobile production in the United States.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP). -- Urging approval of sections of the Omnibus Banking Bill designed to centralize control over currency and credit in the Federal Reserve Board, Chairman Fletcher of the Senate Banking Committee tonight asserted that the "bewildered" bankers should approve of this "stabilizing" step.

CHICAGO, April 28. -- Belief that there is to be inflation of the currency and that government activities are to be enlarged and become more a factor in general business is growing among traders in grains and other commodities here. They look consequently for an expansion of speculative operations on the Board of Trade.

Mayor La Guardia, despite his recent declaration of intention to ask Governor Lehman to veto the Transit. Unification Bill recently passed by the Legislature, will accept the measure and seek to make whatever progress he can under its provisions, it was indicated yesterday.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 28. -- The brilliant performance of the Amazonian filly, Nellie Flag, and the sturdy colt, Today, in yesterday's turf wars on Western and Eastern fronts made it appear likely today they will draw heavy support from the crowd of 100,000 expected to witness the sixty-first Kentucky Derby next Saturday.

An investor bought the six-story elevator apartment house at 1,681 Forty-ninth Street, Brooklyn, in a deal involving all cash over a first mortgage of $108,500. The sale was made by the New York Mortgagees Service Corporation for a client. The same corporation leased 453 State Street, owned by the City Savings Bank.

Twenty-three romances that had budded in the Lenten season burst into simultaneous flower yesterday in the Church of Our Lady of Mount Carmel, 187th Street and Belmont Avenue, the Bronx. The pastor and five priests performed the ceremonies, which began at 11 A.M. and ended at 8:15 P.M., with thirty minutes off for lunch.

DETROIT, April 28 (AP). -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin's new series of weekly radio broadcasts opened tonight without him at the microphone. His place was taken by Louis B. Ward, an associate in his National Union for Social Justice, who explained that the priest desired to rest.

In an effort to supplement formal academic studies "by a year's direct contact with the basic material of social science not available in the classroom or library," the Social Science Research Council has instituted a new type of fellowship, it disclosed yesterday in its annual announcement of awards.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- A "camouflaged" provision for a powerful air base near the Canadian border was disclosed today to have been written into the Wilcox Air Base Bill as redrafted by the War Department.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- A "camouflaged" provision for a powerful air base near the Canadian border was disclosed today to have been written into the Wilcox Air Base Bill as redrafted by the War Department.

PHILADELPHIA, April 28. -- About 5,000 physicians from all parts of the United States, Canada, and from several foreign countries will gather here for the nineteenth annual clinical session of the American College of Physicians, which opens tomorrow and will be continued through Friday.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 28. -- The vanguard of those who will attend the running of the Kentucky Derby on Saturday already has arrived at the Greenbrier, where among those registering today were Mr. and Mrs. William Woodward and Mrs. Ogden L. Mills, who joins Mr. Mills.
Mamma Emma Walsh, the youngest woman baseball manager in Queens, opened her thirteenth season yesterday, but lost the first game through a mistake in strategy.

The Rev. Abraham L. Feinberg, who resigned as associate rabbi of Temple Israel, 202 West Ninety-first Street, in March, 1930, making a farewell sermon in which he characterized organized religion as timorous and decaying, has returned to the ministry, it became known yesterday.

DEBARKING at Southampton, Fred Perry made his weekly announcement that he wasn't going to turn pro but would be on hand to defend the Davis Cup for Merrie England this Summer. So they can dust off the seats at Wimbledon and prepare for a goodly crowd.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., April 28. -- Two boats capsized and several others narrowly missed the same fate while Bill Swan and Miss Allegra Knapp were cleaning up in the dinghy racing on Manhasset Bay today.

Oswald W. Knauth, executive director of the Emergency Relief Bureau, went to Harlem yesterday afternoon to "get acquainted" with the district in which the depression has caused some of its gravest damage.

The theft of $5,000 in jewels belonging to Mrs. Charles B. Williams of Whitestone, Queens, civic and philanthropic worker, was reported yesterday afternoon by the Ward Liner Siboney when the vessel docked at Wall Street and the East River.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA AT SEA, April 29. -- With guns manned and battle lookouts at their stations, ships of the United States Fleet were steaming slowly northward tonight in readiness for a great, far-flung game of war.

TOLEDO, Ohio, April 29 (AP). -- Striking union workers of the local Chevrolet plant voted tonight to appeal to other units of the United Automobile Workers' Federal Union in General Motors plants, asking them to join the walkout until contracts are signed for all.

ALBANY, April 29 (AP). -- Albany scored ten runs in the first inning today but Rochester tied the score at 14-all in the ninth and then won in the tenth, 15 to 14, on a walk to Moore and a two-base hit after two were out.

Lefty Gomez, the singular Castilian southpaw who will tell you without batting an eye that he is no great shakes of a pitcher even when in the very best of condition, was still complaining yesterday of an ailment of some sort in his throat.

Surrogate James A. Delehanty heard argument yesterday on the application of Hildred P. Gude, wife of Oscar Gude Jr., son of the founder of the General Outdoor Advertising Company, that she should receive the income from a trust fund set up-by Mr. Gude for his son.

THERE is some debate as to whether or not Hal Schumacher of the Giants was robbed of a no-hit game by the cruel hand and the cold heart of an official scorer, but in this corner it doesn't seem particularly important. There have been plenty of no-hit games scattered through the records, and some of them were placed there by pitchers who were no great shakes in the long run.

i A. new realty brokerage firm known as i .V.B. Altreuter, Inc., has opened offices in, the Pershing Sq. Building, 100 E. 42(1 St. i The officers are %r S. Altreuter, president: i Harold A. %Vatson, vice president, and ' Harry C. Zaun, secretary and treasurer. Mr. Altreuter formerly was with X. Vm. A. { XVhite Sons and ivor B. Clark, Inc., andI ).Ir. V'atson was with Spear Co.

More than 4,000 qualified civil service employes seeking appointments were passed over for relief jobs while the Emergency Relief Bureau filled positions from other sources, testimony before the Aldermanic Committee Investigating Relief disclosed yesterday.

Sales of reporting department stores in the metropolitan area in the first half of April showed an increase of only 1 per cent over the corresponding period last year, according to the May 1 review of credit and business conditions by the Federal Reserve Agent at New York.

CALLANDER, Ont., April 29. -- Elzire Dionne, the world's most famous mother at 25, and possibly its most discontented one, sat in the living room of her farm home today and said that reports of additions to the family were just so many guesses, and all wrong.

Eugene S. Daniell Jr., who has been a street-corner orator since he caused suspension of trading on the Stock Exchange on Aug. 4, 1933, by dropping a tear-gas bomb into its ventilating system, was arrested last night when he attempted to hold a meeting on behalf of Senator Huey P. Long and the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin in East Eighty-sixth Street in the Yorkville neighborhood.

WARSAW, Poland, April 29. -- Fear of Germany was believed here tonight to be driving Lithuania and Poland toward a settlement of differences that have kept their common frontiers closed since the World War.

Time, the inveterate ironist, must be chuckling at the concern of Senator ROBINSON and Senator HARRIS0N over the Democratic filibuster against the Wagner-Costigan Anti-Lynching Bill. In 1890 filibustering against the Force bill was a sacred Democratic duty. Application of the same method now interferes with the higher Democratic duty to dispose of the Bonus Bill and make way for the measures of the Administration.

The President "went on the air" again Sunday night, and once more showed his mastery of that medium of appeal to the people. His tone and manner were as near perfection as any one can come over the radio. He was friendly, composed, ingratiating. The whole address was like that of a man quietly sitting down with his neighbors to talk over matters of deep concern to them as well as to himself.
LONDON, April 29. -- Britain's Ministers began considering today what, if anything, they should do to answer Germany's resumption of submarine building.

Captain Harold Driseoll, well known fishing guide, who was engaged last Winter by the Bermuda Development Company to explore the island waters and report on the big-game fishing possibilities there, returned to New York on Sunday. He was enthusiastic over the results of the survey, which covered a period of almost two months.
ALBANY, April 29. -- Two bills designed to put the State in a position to participate in the $4,800,000,000 works program of the Federal Government were signed today by Governor Lehman.

CHICAGO, April 29 (AP). -- Police guards were posted at Chicago relief stations today and most of the 9,800 employes of the Illinois Emergency Relief Commission were cut off the payroll as a result of the agency's financial collapse.

Mayor La Guardia said yesterday that he approved of a plan submitted by William Stanley Miller, president of the Department of Taxes and Assessments, for a three-year moratorium on taxes on building improvements to stimulate the remodeling of slum areas.

Thirteen pastors signified yesterday afternoon that they would refuse to sign a declaration that has been circularized by twenty-nine Jewish and Protestant clergymen among 1,200 clergymen asking them for an unqualified renunciation of war.
Foreclosure auction sales made up most of the Manhattan activity in the real estate field yesterday. Seventeen parcels were bid in by plaintiffs.
The Broadway theatre -- speaking in general -- will make what will probably be its last gesture of abundance this season with the premieres of two new plays this evening. They will be:

Mayor La Guardia, commenting yesterday on the charges made against him by former Police Commissioner John F. O'Ryan, as counsel to the Bee Line Bus Company, declared that the charges should be considered in the light of their source.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt entertained at a dinner tonight in the White House seventy-four guests, headed by Major Gen. Blanton Winship, Governor of Puerto Rico, and including Senator Russell, Patrick J. Hurley, former Secretary of War, and Mrs. Hurley; former Representative and Mrs. Swager Sherley and Mr. and Mrs. Richard Crane.

Making its first appearance on a Brooklyn diamond this season, the City College nine turned back Brooklyn College at Manhattan Beach yesterday, 9 to 5, in a game marred by eight errors. The losing team was the chief offender, with five misplays, which helped the Beavers to triumph.
Sailing in a fresh south by west breeze in a rough sea, the Class J yacht Yankee, bound for regattas in England, was 760 miles from Boston Lightship yesterday, the fourth day of her voyage.

BUENOS AIRES, April 29. -- The government has appointed a national cotton board to establish a I strict government control of all phases of the cotton industry from selection of the seed to sale of the ginned fibre. The board was hurriedly appointed two days after it was announced American capitalists would invest $10,000,00 in the installation of gins and mills in Argentina.
BALTIMORE, April 29 (AP). -- Two circuit blows in the eleventh inning today gave Buffalo three runs and a 7-to-4 victory over Baltimore.

The friends of Pennsylvania rowing have been going around this Spring with their fingers crossed and mumbling charms to themselves. Not in several years has there been a more promising start in Red and Blue crew work than this year, and they are taking no chances with luck.

CHICAGO, April 29. -- Conflicting news developments resulted in erratic price changes today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade. Wheat had a range of nearly 2 cents a bushel, with all deliveries selling above $1 at the top, but liquidation by scattered longs developed in the May delivery and it reacted quickly to close at the same price as the July contract, compared with a 3/4-cent premium at the finish on Saturday.

Charles Williamson, metropolitan champion from the Police Athletic League, registered a brilliant triumph over Bradley Lewis of the Salem-Crescent Athletic Club in the 160-pound special bout which featured the A. A. U. boxing show held at the New York Athletic Club last night.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Riding roughshod over rank-and-file delegates from Toledo who demanded "direct action" in the form of strikes and argued that "the only answer big business knows is force," a special conference of national and international unions, State federations of labor and central labor bodies decided today to press organized labor's legislative program for immediate action in Congress.

ALBANY, April 29. -- Governor Lehman vetoed the Burke bill today which would have eliminated civil service requirements for inspectors of the State Liquor Authority and for executive officers and inspectors of local liquor control hoards.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:
Mrs. Albert Keller gave a luncheon yesterday in the Pall Mall Room of the Ritz-Carlton. Her guests included:

What more appropriate place could there be for advertising treasure trove than a literary magazine? In THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Review last Sunday a display notice announced the sale of 3,558 gold coins at public auction in Baltimore day after tomorrow under court auspices and in behalf of THEODORE JONES and HENRY GROB, minors.

Universal Notre Dame Night, observed last night by more than 8,000 Notre Dame alumni in all parts of the world, was featured by radio addresses over a nation-wide N.B.C. hook-up. The principal speakers were the Rev. John F. O'Hara, president of the university, and Frank C. Walker, '09, director of the National Emergency Council.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Secretary Ickes said today that dirt would begin to fly soon on low-cost housing construction in New York, Chicago and twenty-six other cities, under public works plans approved prior to the enactment of the $4,000,000,000 work relief program.

CHICAGO, April 29. -- Six home runs, two fist fights, banishment of four players, a ten-run Chicago rally in the eighth and a parade of ten pitchers marked riotous proceedings today as the Cubs and Pittsburgh Pirates, meeting for the first time this season, battled figuratively and literally through 2 hours and 41 minutes before the Cubs gained a 12-to-11 decision.

TOKYO, April 29. -- High quarters in the Japanese Army have issued a series of statements designed to dispel illusions that perfect peace broods over the Manchukuoan-Siberian border as the result of Russia's sale of the Chinese Eastern Railway and Moscow's preoccupation with European war clouds.
New week in money brought no change in the credit market. Turnover was small and quotations unchanged for all classifications.

A tablet marking the spot where Jersey City "had its beginning" with the landing at Henderson and Fourteenth Streets, near the Holland Tunnel entrance, of Hendrick Hudson in 1609, was placed yesterday, under direction of the Historic Sites Commission.

Jonas Lie, president of the National Academy of Design, presented awards last night at the 109th annual commencement exercises of the free school of the academy in the school's auditorium at Amsterdam Avenue and 109th Street.

Settlement of the strike of cleaners and dyers as it affects wholesale plants employing about 7,000 workers was announced yesterday by Mayor La Guardia at City Hall after a conference with representatives of the employers and of the two unions directing the strike.

Experiments that have been under way for a number of years at the Stevens Institute of Technology to develop a technique known as "controlled sound" have reached a point where the practical applications of the technique promise a tremendous gain in effectiveness in the theatre and opera.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 29. -- The establishment of a third unit of the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton, to be known as the School of Humanistic Studies, was fannounced today, together with the appointment of two professors to the staff of the new school.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- The Supreme Court ruled today that the government could not stop the State of Arizona from interfering with construction of Parker Dam on the Colorado River, and as a result Elwood Mead, Commissioner of Reclamation, ordered work on the dam halted, pending a conference tomorrow with Secretary Ickes.

Miss Bankhead is a plucky lassie. For the past two seasons she has been hovering around the neighborhood in quest of a play that might suit her buoyant temperament. If "Something Gay," which was produced at the Morosco last evening, is legitimate evidence, her luck is steadily growing worse.

Comedy is not entirely divorced from the grim actualities of monetary and trade dislocations and confusions that are pestering the economy of the world in general and of various countries in particular, as the result of the Congress subsidizing the silver industry of our argentiferous States.

In announcing the forthcoming publication of "The Story of Civilization -Our Oriental Heritage," by Will Durant, Simon Schuster say that this work, of which "Our Oriental Heritage" is the first of five volumes, was planned by Will Durant in 1914.

The Cooperative Committee of the Big Sisters will hold a fashion show during the luncheon hour next Monday to mark the opening of Chatham Walk at the Chatham. Mrs. Fair Vanderbilt and Lady Armstrong are honorary chairmen of the committee arranging the showing and Mrs. Sidney C. Borg is the active head.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- The average wage-earner family in Manchester, N.H., spends 37 cents of every dollar of its income for food, 12.7 cents for clothing and 0.4 cents for education. If its income is less than $1,500 annually it is "in the red" at the end of a year from $47 to $93.

When the utilities took it upon themselves to argue that the pending Wheeler-Rayburn bill would destroy the effectiveness of State regulation they were told that it would do nothing of the kind. Commissioner SEAVEY of the Federal Power Commission took the stand before the House committee to testify that it was "conceived entirely "as a supplement to, and not a sub"stitute for, State regulation."

The reorganized board of trustees of the Police Relief Fund, Inc., met for the first time yesterday at police headquarters and elected Commissioner Valentine as its president. Legislation to vest control solely in the hands of the police was signed on Feb. 12 by Governor Lehman, after extensive criticism of investments made for the fund under former boards.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- The Southland since its birth has placed moral and spiritual values above mere economics and is still unwilling to sacrifice them, John E. Edgerton, president of the Southern States Industrial Council, told an audience of Southern Congress members and their guests here tonight at the council's annual dinner.
Housing properties made up the bulk of the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday:

Morris Hillquit, lawyer and Socialist leader, left a net taxable estate of $28,981 and $30,000 in non-taxable insurance, according to the transfer tax appraisal filed here yesterday. The gross estate, before deduction of debts and expenses, was valued at $54,062, exclusive of the insurance.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Indicating that another Treasury refunding had been successful. Secretary Morgenthau announced tonight that no further subscriptions would be received after the close of business Thursday for exchange of First Liberty bonds into the Treasury's 1 5/8 per cent five-year notes.

BERLIN, April 29. -- In the present flurry over the alleged construction of submarines by the Reich, Germany takes the position, it was declared today, that as she no longer considers herself bound by the military clauses of the Versailles treaty her rearming program would take cognizance of the requirements of all branches of the nation's defense services.

The National Orchestral Association will close its season tonight. Leon Barzin will conduct and Albert Spalding will be violin soloist in the Tchaikovsky concerto. Habokoff's "Les Danses de Polichinelle" will receive its first performance.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 29. -- Making his second start of the Eastern racing season and his first since suffering defeat in the Harford Handicap at Havre De Grace, Wise Prince carried the colors of Felix Spatola to victory in the Baltimore Spring Handicap, six-furlong feature of the opening day program at Pimlico today.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- The chiefs of the diplomatic missions in Rio de Janeiro of Argentina Chile, Peru and the United States today urged Brazil to reconsider her previous refusal and join them in projected negotiations to bring about peace between Bolivia and Paraguay in the Chaco.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 29. -- The Paraguayans have been completely defeated in the Battle of Gambeti, begun ten days ago, it is announced here. The Bolivians report the capture of 500 prisoners, including fifteen officers, and have seized machine guns, rifles, ammunition, horses, mortars and important documents.

Coincident with the issuance of a survey by the National Shoe Retaliers Association, indicating a steady rise in business, several hundred merchants, manufacturers and tanners convening yesterday for the Fall style forecast of the organization at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, expressed confidence in the outlook for the remainder of the year.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- President Roosevelt conferred with Secretary Ickes and Colonel Horatio B. Hackett, head of the PWA Housing Division, on low-cost housing under the work relief program, and with State representatives on other projects.

NEWARK, N.J., April 29. -- The Bears were unable to hit young Junie Barnes, Toronto's left-handed submarine ball hurler, in the pinches today and dropped the third game of their series to the Maple Leafs by a score of 10 to 4.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 29. -- The United States and Bermuda six-meter yacht teams, which concluded the series for the Prince of Wales Cup last Saturday, competed today for a trophy offered by the Governor of Bermuda, Sir Thomas Astley Cubitt.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Two injunction suits in the District of Columbia Supreme Court against the National Industrial Recovery Board were dropped by petitioning companies today without a hearing when the board withdrew action to take the Blue Eagle from them.

Mrs. Payne Whitney's Black Buddy, which failed in his first effort at Jamaica last week, came back in his best form yesterday and captured the featured St. Albans Class A Handicap at six furlongs. The 4-year-old son of Bud Lerner caught Sgt. Byrne a sixteenth from home and gained the verdict by a head.

Irregularly distributed gains appeared yesterday in all the important speculative markets. There were signs of hesitancy early in the day, followed by more positive price movements later. Generally, the final quotations indicated a drift toward higher price levels, although there were few important net changes.

In the slowest trading since Feb. 13 the bond market moved in irregular fashion yesterday. United States Government long-term issues showed the best strength, closing up 5-32 to off 2-32 point, with the Treasury 4 1/4s due in 1952, the highest-priced issue of the group, establishing a new high record at 116 9-32.

ST. LOUIS, April 29 (AP). -- The Tigers opened a four-game series today by giving the Browns their worst drubbing of the season, 18 to 0, behind Tommy Bridges, before a crowd numbering less than a thousand. It was the seventh consecutive defeat for the losers.

The reorganization committee of the Celotex Company announced yesterday that an order for a hearing on July 1 on the plan of reorganization of the company had been entered in the Federal court in Wilmington, Del., by Judge John P. Nields.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, April 29. -- The Academic Carelia League (the association of Finnish students and teachers) announced today there have been mass deportations of more than 2,000 Ingrian Finnish families from their homes near Leningrad to the Turkestan-Mongolian frontier of Siberia. (Ingria is a Russian district south of Finland.)

Sir Josiah Stamp, president of the London, Midland and Scottish Railway and a director of the Bank of England, explained industrial control in Great Britain as it corresponds to the New Deal in this country at a luncheon yesterday of the British Empire Chamber of Commerce at the Hotel Commodore.

Trading was highly mixed on the local commodity futures markets here yesterday. Sugar was strong, reflecting an advance in refined sugar. Cocoa and copper were weak. On the cash markets, where refined sugar went to 5.25 cents a pound, the highest price since Nov. 18, 1929, wheat, corn and silk also advanced, while rye, oats, cotton, lard and rubber sagged and butter sold at its low price for the year.

MIAMI, April 29. -- America's words whisper peace and her actions thunder war, Representative Lee of Oklahoma declared tonight in an address before 900 women gathered here for the annual convention of the National Congress of the Parent-Teachers Association.

LONDON, April 29. -- With a brilliance unequaled since the days of Melba, the Royal Opera jubilee season opened in Covent Garden tonight with an uncut presentation of "Lohengrin" that lasted five hours.
PARIS, April 29. -- The Franco-Soviet negotiations for a mutual assistance pact made what is officially described as "very appreciable progress" today.

LONDON, April 29. -- The stock markets here were generally firm today, with business expanding. Outstanding was strong demand for aircrafts, in expectation of increased orders by the government in speeding up its construction program in view of German activity.

LONDON, April 29. -- Prancing thoroughbreds from the Royal mews thrilled thousands of spectators on Park Lane today with an old-fashioned two-reel runaway. It served as an unofficial prelude to the great jubilee procession in which "the King's horses and the King's men will march down the street and march back again."

CHICAGO, April 29. -- In the first action of its kind taken under the amended Bankruptcy Law, Federal Judge William H. Holly today appointed committees to represent stockholders and creditors of the Rosenbaum Grain Corporation, which is seeking reorganization under Section 77b.

Resolutions urging revival of private business, a city-wide 2-cent postage rate, a veto by Governor Lehman of bills restoring pay cuts to city employes and development of the Delaware River water supply for the city will be offered at the annual meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- The only man who ever rode to baseball immortality on a strike-out -- the "mighty Casey" of "Casey at the Bat" -- smiled today as he sat in his little suburban home here and reminisced over that fateful day a half century ago.
CINCINNATI, April 29 (AP). -- Paul Dean scored his third victory of the season today, holding the Reds to six scattered hits while his St. Louis teammates made timely safeties to win, 7 to 2.

BERLIN, April 29. -- The secret political police have resumed their campaign for the suppression of all sources through which the series of nation-wide arrests of Protestant clergymen could be reported either here or abroad.

Business and industrial activity in the territory served by the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation improved slightly in 1934, according to S.J. Magee, chairman, and C.L. Cadle, president, in the annual report, issued yesterday. Operating revenues were $13,205,606, a gain of $334,120 over 1933, or 2.6 per cent, including a gain of $202,244 in sales of electricity.

Rosie, the Central Park hippopotamus, stood with her cavernous mouth expectantly open most of the day yesterday, but the results were disappointing, and Rosie was puzzled. She could see only the back of the brand-new sign on her pen that reads: "Do not feed or annoy the animals, $25 fine."

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Compensation of $365,358 was paid in 1934 by the International Business Machines Corporation to Thomas J. Watson, president, a registration statement filed with the SEC disclosed today. Of this amount, $264,432 came from a bonus contract, $100,000 was salary and $926 was in director fees.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- President Roosevelt's legislative speed order enunciated in his radio "fireside talk" last night to the people had a gloomy reaction in Congress today. The most important measures of the President's program are still blocked behind a Senate filibuster over the Costigan-Wagner Anti-Lynching Bill.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 (AP). -- Bing Miller's pinch single with three men on base and two out in the eleventh inning gave the Red Sox a 10-to-8 victory over the Athletics today. The defeat was the fourth straight for the Mackmen.

A reproduction of one of the weird megaliths of Easter Island in the South Pacific, which have inspired many scientific explorations, will be placed on public view here for the first time this Summer by the American Museum of Natural History.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP). -- The Supreme Court today reversed a Treasury ruling holding that when shares of stock are sold from margin purchases made at different dates and at different prices, the gain or loss for taxing purposes must be computed -- when the shares sold cannot be identified -- on the basis that the stock sold was that which was earliest purchased.

have read with deep interest the report in THE TIMES of the testimony of Edward Corsi before the aldermanic investigating committee. While I have not liked the temper of this particular investigation, it has been worth while to get before the public eye the two schools of thought concerning the control of emergency relief policies.

Silvio Giolito of Stuyvesant, 16- year-old star who has been fencing only six months, captured the P. S. A. L. individual foils championship in the Washington Irving High School auditorium last night. Of the six finalists who had survived two previous eliminations, which cut down the starting field of thirty- six, Giolito was the lone contestant to win foul bouts, losing only one.

Eugene F. Bryant, chief of detectives of Miami Beach, testified yesterday before a Federal grand jury which is investigating the activities of Noel C. Scaffa, private detective, and the part he played in the return of $185,000 worth of jewels stolen last January from Mrs. Margaret Hawksworth Bell in the Miami Biltmore Hotel.
WASHINGTON, April 29. -- The NIRB approved today a revised schedule of budget expenditures, totaling $2,037.89, for the beauty and barber equipment manufacturing industry, effective May 16.

The screen rights to Sean O'Casey's play "The Plough and the Stars" have been purchased by RKO Radio Pictures. It will be brought to the screen under the direction of John Ford, with Cliff Reid acting as associate producer and Dudley Nichols caring for the film adaptation.

WASHINGTON. April 29. -- Senator Harrison, chairman of the Finance Committee, is expected to tell that committee tomorrow that the White House program calls for passage of a new NRA law with a minimum of delay.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 29. -- The trail of the three young boys who have been missing from their homes here since Friday while local agencies and hundreds of volunteers have hunted for them, led today to Pond Creek, in a swampy area about a mile from Newark Bay.

Senator LA FOLLETTE is twitting the "conservatives" who want a balanced budget. They can get it, he says, simply by submitting to a Spartan taxation, but they "inconsistently" object to that. So let them not cite the balanced budget of Great Britain as an example for us to follow.

PITTSBURGH, April 29 (AP). -- Robert H. Jackson, government counsel, moved today to withdraw from prosecution of the government's $3,089,000 income-tax case against Andrew W. Mellon after the Board of Tax Appeals rejected a 4,500-word brief which he had filed in arguments over eligibility of certain letters he was seeking for the records.

Consolidated net earnings of the Cities Service Company and subsidiaries in 1934 amounted to $61,593,921, an increase of $1,808,989, compared with 1933. The figures are before deductions for depletion and depreciation.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP). -- The United States' first naval limitation pact, the Rush-Bagot agreement, proclaimed 118 years ago by President Monroe, was credited today by William Phillips, Under-Secretary of State and first American Minister to Canada, as having set before the world an ideal of "good neighborship."

MARGATE, England, April 29. -- Administering the first defeat to Jose R. Capablanca of Cuba, former world champion, and winning also from W.A. Fairhurst. Scottish champion, Samuel Reshevsky of New York gained the lead today in the international masters tournament of the Kent County Chess Association.

Vice Chancellor Vivian M. Lewis in Jersey City announced yesterday he would take under advisement an application for an injunction to restrain the Jersey Law Publications Society of Newark from selling a publication advertised as the official record of the trial of Bruno Richard Hauptmann, convicted of slaying and kidnapping the Lindbergh baby.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- The controversy over the old Manhattan Elevated Railway spur in East Forty-second Street was settled today by a Supreme Court opinion upholding awards to transit interests of $539,117 for the easements, $235 for the scrap value of the structure and no money at all for the franchise.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Attacks on the administration's banking bill, the passage of which President Roosevelt urged in his radio address last night, started in the House today when consideration of the bill began.

Substantial savings can be made in the management and operating expenses of the eighty-four moving picture theatres comprising the Fox Metropolitan Playhouses. Inc., it was testifies yesterday before Federal Judge Julian W. Mack in the County Lawyers Association Building, 14 Vesey Street.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., April 29. -- Upsala College overwhelmed the St. Francis nine today, 13 -- 5, in a game previously postponed by rain. All but one of the Upsala players tallied in the sixth inning. Gaul got four hits, including a triple. N. Spinelli pitched the entire game for the victors.

In an unobtrusive fashion quite at variance with his usual custom, Max Baer spent a day in New York yesterday keeping out of sight. He reached town late Sunday night without any fanfare or announcement. Although the heavyweight champion of the world was not willing to admit it, perhaps his recently acquired black eye had something to do with his new-found shyness.
After almost four months of arduous campaigning across the country and back, William Tilden still had enough left in reserve to come within a stroke of defeating Ellsworth Vines last night.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29. -- A new operation for angina pectoris and congestive heart failure, diseases of the heart which constitute one of the major causes of death after the age of 50, was reported here tonight before the nineteenth annual session of the American College of Physicians.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP). -- With the life of the wheat control program after this year dependent on a formal referendum May 25, George E. Farrell, Director of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration's Grains Division, will carry the campaign direct to the farmers tomorrow in a speech at Enid, Okla.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 29. -- The first electoral mass meeting of the Yugoslav Opposition was held here today and 15,000 persons turned out for it.

TRENTON, N.J., April 29. -- Soon after the Assembly had passed tonight the Senate bill to substitute a single highway commissioner for the four-member road board, Governor Hoffman signed the measure and sent to the Senate the nomination of his Secretary, E. Donald Sterner of Belmar, for appointment to the new $15,000 position for a six-year term.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 29 (AP). -- The famous "Protocols of the Elders of Zion," which Nazis have claimed reveal plans for control of the world by Jews, were branded as out-and-out fakes by a Jewish expert today at the resumption of the protocols trial here.

MONTE CARLO, April 29 (AP). -- Wilmer Hines, former University of North Carolina star, and Henry Culley, an American student at Cambridge, today combined to win the men's doubles final of the Easter Week tennis tournament.

Not often does Washington witness an incident so extraordinary as the week-end visit of the Mexican official who sped there by airplane to discover, if possible, the meaning of our Government's silver policy. His country had benefited greatly from the earlier phases of this policy.
Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday that the city's plans for a municipal power plant would be the basis for reducing the cost of current to consumers, even if no plant were built at present.

If there was more patriotism and less partisanship in the country the major political parties would unanimously agree on Franklin D. Roosevelt for another four years and stop their bickerings right now. Our history will place President Roosevelt beside Washington, Jefferson and Jackson for the results he has accomplished, despite all the scalawag vituperations from barnyard orators.

The campaign for the collection of $250,000 by the United Republican Finance Committee for New York County started yesterday under the direction of Robert H. Thayer, chairman; Mrs. Roger W. Straus, co-chairman, and. Thomas Hitchcock Jr., treasurer.

Charges of NRA violations brought against seventy defendants under the Schackno State Enabling Law, which was declared invalid last Friday by the Court of Appeals, were abrogated yesterday by Justices Gresser, Walling and Caldwell in Special Sessions.

BOSTON, April 29. -- Shattering railroad speed records for New England, the Comet, new lightweight, streamlined train of the New Haven Railroad, streaked over the rails today from New Haven to Boston with an official inspection party aboard.

In the midst of back-breaking labor yesterday afternoon in the garden of his home in Roslyn, L.I., Christopher Morley, writer and critic, was called to the telephone and informed that he had been appointed Honorary Night Watchman of the Columbia University Press.

Forest fires that have swept thousands of acres of woodland in Long Island and New Jersey in the last few days appeared yesterday to be under the control of volunteer armies of men who sought to prevent the blazes from advancing to villages, towns, Summer homes and camps.
The six old paddle-wheel riverboats of the defunct Iron Steamboat Company were sold at their piers in Edgewater, N.J., yesterday for a total of $23,350 in a United States Marshal's sale.

Waddill Catchings, former partner in the Goldman Sachs Company, investment brokers, filed suit yesterday in Federal Court against the Collector of Internal Revenue to recover $334,885.80, representing, he said, an overpayment of his income tax for 1929 and interest.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 29. -- Today, C.V. Whitney's winner of the Wood Memorial and future-book favorite for the Kentucky Derby next Saturday, arrived at Churchill Downs in fine shape this afternoon after an uneventful trip from New York.

A Federal grand jury that has been investigating sales methods used by so-called guaranteed mortgage companies before they were taken over for rehabilitation in 1933 returned an indictment yesterday against the Westchester Title and Trust Company and four of its former officers and directors.
Several leases in the downtown area Of Manhattan, in addition to various midtown rentals, were reported by brokers yesterday, as follows:

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP). -- The Interstate Commerce Committee ended today the last of three important hearings and prepared to press for action by this Congress on a group of public utility and transportation measures urged by President Roosevelt in his fireside chat to the country.

The public schools of Rhode Island are commemorating this week its Independence Day. The historical reason for this is that on the fourth of May in 1776 the General Assembly enacted a statute "declaring Rhode Island Independence." This is asserted to be the first authoritative measure by a legally constituted governmental agency exercising a constitutional function which gave a legal status to a civil war already in progress.

KIEL, Germany, April 29 (AP). -- Navy lads were walking about the streets today with arm bands bearing the inscription "Submarine School, Kiel," giving evidence that at least theoretical education in the use of submarines has been resumed at the famous Kiel training school.

No interest will be paid on new time deposit accounts by member banks of the New York Clearing House Association made on and after tomorrow, according to an announcement last night by Albert A. Tilney, chairman of the Clearing House Committee.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP). -Republicans and Democrats alike conceded today that in his twenty years' experience in the House, Clyde Kelly of Pennsylvania probably had as much to do with the building up of the air mail as any one man.
WASHINGTON, April 29. -- There will be "no compromise" in the "Dutch" Schultz case, the Department of Justice said tonight in announcing that it had asked a retrial.

GENEVA, April 29. -- The immediate problem facing the development of commercial aviation in Europe is not technical but political, according to a report entitled "The Economics of Air Transport in Europe,'' drawn up by Henri Bouche, editor of Aeronautique, for the League of Nations transit organization, which published it today.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 29 (AP). -- Senators, Representatives and veteran politicians .will not be welcome at the "grass roots" convention of Midwest Republicans to be held here the second week of June, Justus L. Johnson, State chairman, warned today.

London Films will produce thirty- six pictures during the new season, according to an announcement yesterday by its production head. Alexander Korda. It is the largest schedule in the company's two and a half years' history.

Shortly after she was struck yesterday morning by an automobile at Jefferson Place and Boston Road, the Bronx, Mrs. Ethel Bopp, 45 years old, of 655 Jefferson Place, the Bronx, died in Bronx Hospital at 11 A. M. The automobile that struck her was operated by Nathan Rosen of 2,088 Mohegan Avenue.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 29. -- Both staphylococcus and streptococcus germs have been found in samples of the cream-filling believed to have caused the epidemic of food poisoning here last week, according to a preliminary report made today to Dr. Matthias Nicoll Jr., Westchester County Health Commissioner.

BOSTON, April 29. -- Eugenio Camalani, 42, of Roxbury, whose right hand in his coat pocket grasped a jackknife with a spring holding its 3 1/4-inch blade rigid, was arrested by an alert police guard today outside the Hall of Flags in the State House, averting a possible attack on Augusto Rosso, the Italian Ambassador.

Work on the first section of the project for replacing the old bridle and bicycle paths along Riverside Drive with a promenade, lawns and small play areas has been completed except for planting, officials of the Park Department disclosed yesterday.

Directors of the United States Steel Corporation will meet today to receive the report of first-quarter earnings and to take dividend action. The chairman, Myron C. Taylor, is in Europe. It seems to be the guess that the board will order another payment of 50 cents a share on the preferred stock, thus increasing the accumulations.
BOSTON, April 29. -- Amateur fighters from Ireland and New England divided honors in the international amateur boxing tournament before 11,000 spectators in the Boston Garden tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States moved today toward an open break with President Roosevelt on major administration policies when it issued a report condemning proposed changes in the Federal Reserve Act on the heels of the President's "fireside chat" in their behalf.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29. -''Speed and greed" were described today as the misfortune of "too many young artists" by Edward Johnson, tenor and assistant general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Company of New York. He told the National Federation of Music Clubs that "greater harm is done to a promising young artist by presenting him before he is ready than by holding him back ten years."

Prices on the Cotton Exchange were set back 3 to 9 points yesterday after having risen last week. Uncertainty over the developments in silver and rainfall over many western sections of the Cotton Belt brought some selling, but around 11 3/4 (rents a pound for the July, trade price-fixing created resistance.
The Woman's Roosevelt Memorial Association gave a reception yesterday in honor of Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt, widow of the former President, at Roosevelt House, East Twentieth Street.
ST. LOUIS. April 29 (AP). -- Sam Breadon sighed deeply tonight at the latest in the baseball magnate's woes, a union labor boycott directed primarily at Leo Durocher, his peppery shortstop.

Acts or scenes from five Russian operas were presented at the Hippodrome last night at what was designated as "a Gala Performance in Honor of Dr. Walter Damrosch." The event was for the benefit of the Musicians Emergency Fund, and was given by the Art of Musical Russia, Inc., which earlier in the season sponsored a series of opera production at Mecca Temple.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Before the President faces the microphone in a nation-wide radio hook-up, there are many conferences with advisers, the question being whether there shall be a speech at all. This settled in the affirmative, another and more protracted series of conferences is held to determine what shall be said, and how it shall be uttered.

" AMERICA is not Europe," say those who contemptuously deny that we can learn anything about our own future from what has happened in Italy or Germany. "Economic depression can have the same, or at least similar, results in any advanced capitalist industrial country," say the opponents of the sui generis theory. Who is right?

Jeno Swislowski, pianist, made his New York debut in a recital at the Town Hall last night. His program was ambitious and varied. It began with transcriptions by Joaquin Nin of three short sonatas by Cantallos and Soler and continued with Schubert's sonata in A, Op. 120, and with three intermezzos and the Rhapsody, Op. 119, No. 4, by Brahms.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Test of the New York State Schackno Act, brought by the Spielman Motor Sales Company, Inc., was ordered dismissed by the Supreme Court today on technical grounds. It had already been stated by the NRA that cases like the Spielman one, instituted under the Shackno Act, would have to be dropped, that law having been declared unconstitutional.

WASHINGTON, April 29. - Colonel Charles R. Reynolds, surgeon of the Army's Second Corps Area, at Governors Island, N.Y., was nominated by President Roosevelt today for surgeon general of the army, with the rank of major general.

NEWARK, N.J., April 29. -- The seventy-eighth Newark annual conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church came to a close at St. Luke's M.E. Church here today with the reading of pastoral appointments by the presiding Bishop, the Rev. Francis J. McConnell of New York.

Spring "moving day" in the business world arrives officially tomorrow, May 1, but it will be just another Wednesday for most of the van owners. They tucked away their great tracks last night at the usual hour, after an easy day, and it looked as if they would follow the same routine today and tomorrow.

Lack of coordination among the numerous interests concerned with promotion of home building, and improper methods of merchandising are largely responsible for the continued delay in reviving construction industries, H.M. Shackleford, advertising and sales promotion manager for the Johns-Manville Corp., said in an address to the Sales Executives' Club of New York., Inc., at the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday.

A meeting was held yesterday at the home of Mrs. Albert L. Hoffman, 58 East Seventy-ninth Street, of the committee arranging the bridge party and bazaar to be held at her residence on Thursday for the benefit of the Save-a-Life Farm, a fresh-air home for undernourished children at Nyack, N.Y.
LONDON, April 29. -- John Masefield, poet laureate of Britain, has composed a special prayer "for the King's Majesty" as part of the official jubilee program. It follows:

Again the local art world finds its calendar for the week well provided with group shows. Two of them, containing new work by members of An American Group at the Jacques Seligmann Galleries and work by "fifty outstanding American artists" at the Sixtieth Street Gallery, do not open until tomorrow.
Among the passengers due today from Southampton via Cherbourg on the Cunard White Star liner Majestic are:

A decision to make public the complete record of the VanderbiltWhitney case of 1934 was reached yesterday by Nathan Burkan, counsel for Mrs. Gloria Vanderbilt. It was immediately abandoned, however, when Mr. Burkan learned that such publication would not be countenanced by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, where Mrs. Vanderbilt's appeal is now pending.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, April 29. -- A new Nazi kidnapping of a German refugee, this time from Czechoslovakia into Germany, was causing great excitement here today.

The Investment Bankers Code Committee voted yesterday to take steps to transfer administration of the code from the NRA to the Securities and Exchange Commission, following an all-day meeting at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. The committee likewise went on record as recommending that the Presidential order authorizing the change give consideration to a plan for the establishment of a fair practice code or regulations to meet the specific needs of municipal bond dealers.

Seven traffic towers, circa 1922, whose bronze surfaces, inset clocks and polished marble bases once decorated the centre of Fifth Avenue, are among the 172 lots that the Police Department will dispose of at its coming 276th auction sale of unclaimed articles.

Reorganization of both home relief and work relief in this city, in accordance with expected budget readjustments and the Federal Government's new work-relief program, was foreshadowed yesterday as a result of a conference between Oswald W. Knauth, chairman and executive director of the Emergency Relief Bureau, and representatives of welfare and charity organizations.

The directors of the Edison Electric Illuminating Company of Boston voted yesterday to recommend to the stockholders that an application be made to the Massachusetts Department of Public Utilities for authority to issue first-mortgage bonds for $53,000,000.

BERLIN, April 29. -- The Boerse continued weak today and activity was limited. Heavy industrials were almost inactive, with widespread signs of weakness. Machines were weak, Orenstein and Koppel losing 2/2 point. Electricals were mixed and unsteady, and Schuckert lost 1/2 point, while Siemens Halske gained 3/4.

How mounting expenses affected the railroads in 1934 is shown in figures for the period contained in the report of the Norfolk Southern Railroad Company. Unlike many other railroads, the company was able to retain most of the increase in gross revenues.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Declaring that "deplorable conditions faced the textile industry as a result of the Federal processing tax but cautioning against development of "sectional bitterness" between the North and South, a delegation of mill operators headed by Governor Brann of Maine recommended today to a special Cabinet committee that a general sales tax or payments from the $4,000,000,000 work- relief fund be substituted for the processing tax to supply aid to cotton producers.
BOSTON, April 29 (AP). -- The Phillies outhit the Braves, 13 to 9, today but suffered their eighth consecutive defeat as they lost the game, 7 to 5.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- The Treasury and the Mexican Government came to a "mutually satisfactory" understanding today on Washington's silver-purchasing program, with Mexico favoring a policy, it is understood, which would increase the price, but asking that it receive a breathing spell to complete a readjustment of its internal monetary affairs.

The Port of New York Authority recommended yesterday to the army district engineers that the channels of the Raritan River be deepened to suit the needs of industrial plants that line its banks and depend upon the river for entry to New York Harbor.

Increased interest in new Summer merchandise was reflected in the heavier volume of mail orders received here yesterday. The gain over the previous week was interpreted as indicating retailers in many sections last week made considerable headway in the reduction of seasonal stocks of apparel and accessories.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., April 29 (AP). -- A bold and ruthless gang of bandits was believed to have been smashed, and two daring mail truck robberies, which netted $179,000, solved with the arrest tonight by Federal agents of five persons.

The National Cash Register Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the quarter ended on March 31 a net profit of $196,775, after depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges. This was equal to 12 cents a share on 1,628,000 shares of capital stock, against $280,817, or 17 cents a share in the same quarter last year.

CHICAGO, April 29. -- Receipts of hogs today were the heaviest since March and caused a decline of 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight in prices in the early trading. An active demand was influenced later by reports of a much better demand for fresh pork at some Eastern markets at sharply higher prices and the close was about steady.

Only eleven children of a capacity crowd of 15,000 turned up in the lost and found division of the circus yesterday morning in Madison Square Garden. Ten of them, regaled with free cones of spun sugar, were happy and seemed to enjoy being lost. The other one cried.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Thomas J. Watson, disclosed in Security Commission reports today as the recipient of a thousand-dollar-a-day income as president of the International Business Machines Company, described himself tonight as an "optimist."

Advancement of the cause of peace through meetings, classes and affiliation with peace groups was urged upon the New York State Federation of Temple Sisterhoods yesterday at its annual meeting in the Community House of the Central Synagogue, 35 East Sixty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-one leading cities on April 24 shows increases for the week of $106,000.000 in net demand deposits and $193,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and a decrease of $27, 000,000 in total loans and investments.

The biweekly dances on the Central Park Mall; probably last Summer's most popular recreational innovation, will begin again on Tuesday, June 4, according to a schedule made public yesterday by the Concert Division of the Emergency Relief Bureau. In the succeeding seven days dancing will get under way at seven other locations in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP). -- Canada, both interested and concerned at proposals to establish a "camouflaged" military air base near her border, today asked the State Department for any public data on such army plans.

NEWARK, N.J., April 29. -- Mayor La Guardia of New York was challenged today by Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein of this city to a public debate on the relative merits of Newark Airport and Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn. In a telegram to the New York Mayor, Mayor Ellenstein requested the debate at any time and at any place in New York City designated by Mayor La Guardia.

New York City will pay off tomorrow $52,000,000 of its rapid transit corporate stock issued four years ago. The stock due tomorrow bears interest at 3 per cent and was originally bought through competitive bidding by a syndicate headed by the former National City Company.
LONDON, April 29. -- Japan was branded as a treaty breaker today in a new note from Britain protesting against the creation of the Manchukuoan oil monopoly.

New York began its observance of Better Homes Week yesterday with ceremonies that centred in "America's Little House," at Park Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street, and had as their keynote the furtherance, of home ownership as a safeguard of national security.
More than 60,000 merchants who failed to make sales tax payments to the city are being checked up by a staff of 200 investigators which took the field in Manhattan and Brooklyn yesterday.

The weights for the Excelsior Handicap with $5,000 added at a mile and a sixteenth, which will be the feature at Jamaica Saturday, were announced yesterday by Handicapper John B. Campbell. Mrs. Dodge Sloane's Cavalcade tops the list with 129 pounds, a pound more than is allotted to C.V. Whitney's Equipoise, but neither of these is expected to start.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Assistant Secretary Sayre of the State Department told a group meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States today that "without an increased international trade it is difficult to see how to meet the problems of international finance which press in on every side."

The Warner Brothers will present this morning their glorification of the Department of Justice Agents, "G Men," at the Strand. On the side of the law are James Cagney, Robert Armstrong, Margaret Lindsay and Regis Toomey.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares mm follows (quotations are tnl cents):

In all this discussion of security legislation, whether for old age, unemployment or industrial accident, as pointed out in your today's editorial, a question is involved as to the extent of the insurance coverage. The usual proposal would limit benefits to those working for employers who hire ten or more men and exempt certain classifications altogether.

ALBANY, April 30. -- The Court of Appeals today unanimously affirmed the sentence of Mrs. Eva Coo, convicted of slaying Harry Wright, her handy man at her roadhouse in Otsego County. Unless Governor Lehman should intervene and commute the sentence, it will be carried out at Sing Sing at a date to be determined by the court, which will sign the death warrant tomorrow.

A pledge to protect the interests of all certificate holders in mortgage rehabilitations to be carried out by the new State Mortgage Commission was made yesterday by Wendell P. Barker, its chairman, at a luncheon given by the Real Estate Board of New York in the Hotel Commodore in honor of the commission.

Because of the large number of entries received for the national open championship, the United States Golf Association has increased the number of qualifying places for the tourney to 162, it was announced yesterday.

Announcement of the racing schedule of the Interclub sloops of Long Island Sound was made last night at the annual Spring dinner and meeting of the Interclub Class Association, in Midston House. The yachts will start their competition on May 24 at the Larchmont Yacht Club, which is a late date for them, but will continue their events through September.

LONDON, April 30 (AP). -- Attorneys for the plaintiffs told a British court today that threats and misrepresentations had forced Arnold De La Poer and Major Gerald C. Maxwell to sell their interests in an English automobile sales organization, Chrysler Motors, Ltd., to the Chrysler Export Corporation.
ALBANY, April 30. -- The power of New York City to levy emergency taxes for unemployment relief was extended for six months when the Dunnigan act was signed today by Governor Lehman.

Four young men, training for a forthcoming canoe regatta in a 22-foot racing canoe on the Harlem River about 8 o'clock last night, were thrown into the water and drifted half a mile when their craft capsized near the Washington Bridge at 181st Street.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia, announced yesterday the appointment of a committee to study "a joint curriculum of liberal arts and sciences and the theory and practice of education in preparation for high school and college teaching."

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Although the exchange offering was made only nine days ago $1,297,000,000 of the $1,933,000,000 of First Liberty Bonds called for redemption on June 15 had been turned in by holders in exchange for new 2 7/8 per cent bonds or 1 7/8 per cent five-year notes, Treasury compilations showed tonight.

The fog that settled over the harbor yesterday morning was responsible for a collision at 8:30 A.M. of the municipal ferryboat Brooklyn and the army ferryboat Hook Mountain between Bedloes and Governors Islands.

CINCINNATI, April 30 (AP). -- Young Gene Schott, only home-town lad with the Cincinnati Reds, pitched his first full game as a major-leaguer today and led his mates to a crushing 12-to-2 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

This is the night -- finally -- for W.D. Bristol's four-character play "Reprise" to arrive at the Vanderbilt Theatre. The "finally" refers to tryouts last July and January, at Dobbs Ferry and Cedarhurst respectively, but those were under other ownership.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., April 30 (AP). -- A 120-mile-an-hour locomotive, the answer of the steam-engine builders to Diesel competition, tore through a red, white and blue veil at a locomotive works here today and was officially made ready for service on the Chicago, Milwaukee St. Paul Railroad.

A new issue of $40,000,000 New York State revenue-anticipation notes, dated May 2, 1935, and due on Feb. 25, 1936, was allotted yesterday by Controller Morris S. Tremaine to sixty-three banks and banking houses at the lowest interest cost to the State in its financial history.

Registration of visiting buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday showed an increase over the preceding week and the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES. The total for the week, which was the highest since the week of March 20, was 839 as against 584 in the previous week and 633 in the same period last year.

The late Irving Babbitt used to say that some one ought to write a history of the gentleman, before it was too late. This has now been done by Henry Dwight Sedgwick. His book, "In Praise of Gentlemen," will be published by Little, Brown on Aug. 1.
NEWARK, N.J., April 30. -- Jim Pattison, young left-hander, weakened in the sixth inning today and the Toronto Maple Leafs lost the final game of their road trip to the Newark Bears by 8 to 1.

The Hobby Round-Up, a ten-day exposition of all manner of hobbies from taming alligators to collecting speakeasy cards, will open at 8 o'clock tonight in the auditorium of the Port Authority Building, Fifteenth Street and Eighth Avenue.

In today's issue of THE TIMES I note a letter concerning parades on Fifth Avenue, signed R.S.K., objecting to your editorial of April 26 protesting the May Day parades being routed through the midtown Manhattan business district.
WASHINGTON, April 30. -- "United States patent No. 2,000,000" was entered on Uncle Sam's patent register today, testifying to the prolific inventive genius of Americans.

The United States Steel Corporation reported yesterday a net loss for the first quarter of $2,173,801 after all charges. This was the smallest loss for any first quarter since 1931 and compared with a net loss of $10,234,413 in the final quarter of 1934 and a net loss of $6,989,965 in the first quarter of last year.

MOSCOW, April 30. -- From its headquarters hard by the Kremlin the executive committee of the Communist International sent out a call today to workers and sympathizers in all capitalist countries to demonstrate tomorrow, by means of strikes and May Day meetings, their readiness to struggle unitedly under the banner of proletarian internationalism.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 30. -- Whiskolo, from the Milky Way Farm of Mrs. Ethel V. Mars, won the Preparation Purse at Churchill Downs today in a field of twelve which included ten eligibles for Saturday's $40,000 added mile-and-a-quarter Kentucky Derby. The performance made certain that the bay son of Diavolo will be a starter.

Socialists and Communists were busy yesterday preparing for what both predicted would be the biggest celebration of May Day in the city's history today. The Socialists said they would have at least 125,000 persons in their parade and demonstration, while the Communists asserted that their parade would number from 60,000 to 75,000 marchers.

The organization committee for the Southern Natural Gas Corporation announced yesterday that it had prepared a plan for the company, in receivership since Oct. 1, 1931, and that application would be made to the United States District Court in Delaware for approval. Pending court approval, no deposits will be accepted by the committee.

BALTIMORE, April 30. -- Jockey Johnny Gilbert was in the spotlight on the second day of the Maryland Jockey Club Spring meeting when he accounted for three victories at the historic Pimlico track today. He completed the triple by piloting Breckinridge Long's home-bred Legume to victory in the mile and a sixteenth of the featured Woodberry Purse for 3-year-olds.

COLUMBUS, Miss., April 30. -- Sylvester Harris, Negro farmer, whose telephone call to President Roosevelt last year to "save my farm" brought quick results, is working these warm days and doing no talking about politics.

Among the Manhattan properties which changed hands yesterday was the large six-story apartment house at 87 West 169th Street, near Nelson Avenue, which was purchased by Samuel Reznick and Frank Locker, operators, from the Irving Savings Bank.
TOKYO, April 30. -- A move to test the strength of the British Empire's Ottawa trade agreements is seen in Japan's selection of Canadian trade adjustment for special examination.

Signs of improved business conditions were outlined yesterday by J.J. Byrne, who will assume office today as vice president of traffic of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad. Mr. Byrne, who has been general freight traffic manager, will succeed Nat Duke.

One person was killed, a second critically injured and a dozen others less seriously hurt just before midnight last night when a private automobile and a bus crashed in a head-on collision on the Cross Bay Boulevard, just north of Broad Channel, Queens.
PHILADELPHIA, April 30. -- Fifty girl students at the University of Pennsylvania reported today for rowing, this being the first time in history the Red and Blue coeds have tried the sport.

Most of the markets were quiet and colorless yesterday. Except for United States Government bonds, thirteen of which sold at the highest prices since they were issued, the general results were inconclusive. The day's news budget contained little that was stimulating from the viewpoint of the markets.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange held within a narrow range yesterday and ended a point higher to a point lower than on Monday. Foreign and domestic cotton markets appeared to be in a waiting attitude, with operations curtailed pending the outcome of protests against the processing tax, the next move in silver and some announcement regarding next season's loan to producers.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- An agreement to begin negotiation of a reciprocal tariff agreement with France and its colonies, dependencies and protectorates, other than Morocco was announced today by the State Department.

The Sedalia Singers of North Carolina stirred a social audience at the Town Hall last evening with authentic and heartfelt singing of Negro spirituals, dramatized with the weird intensity of their native tobacco roads and green pastures in the South.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- A registration statement by Central Aguirre Associates showed today that Charles Francis Adams, a trustee, held 2,520 shares of common stock, while 37,227 shares were owned by Charles G. Meyer, vice president, the largest holding among trustees and officers, as of April 1.

One third of the fortune amassed by the late Prince George Matchabelli in his perfume business in this country, which under the intestacy laws of this State becomes the property of his brother, Ito Matchabelli of Leningrad, may be claimed by the Soviet Government.

The Gdynia America Line announced yesterday that its new ship, the Pilsudski, which is under construction in Trieste for operation between New York and the Polish port of Gdynia, would be a tourist-class ship with accommodations for about 800 passengers.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- The NRA today extended until June 16 the emergency order establishing minimum mark-ups in the sale of cigarettes at wholesale, but at the same time amended rates to give to the sub-jobbers a larger margin.

The fourteenth annual Rainbow Ball in behalf of the Association for the Aid of Crippled Children was held in a new setting last night -- the Cloisters on the sixty-seventh floor of the RCA Building of Rockefeller Center. The event since its inception has been one of the most popular benefits of each Spring season here, and for years it was held in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Challenging the views of Governor Brann of Maine and also of his own delegation, Governor Green of Rhode Island today told a special Cabinet committee studying the textile situation that poor financial structures and obsolescent machinery comprised the principal cause of the present "deplorable" condition of the industry.
The final dinner dance for this season in the series of Yorkville dinner dances in behalf of the Yorkville Community Association was held last night in the ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton.

CHICAGO, April 30. -- Larger receipts of hogs here today brought more buyers into the market and a quick clearance was made with prices steady to 10 cents a hundred weight higher than yesterday, butcher stocks showing the most strength. The top price was 5 cents above yesterday's at $9.15, while the day's average was up 10 cents at $8.95.

It is surprising and sometimes amusing to contemplate the many curious ways that have developed in the shaving, training and general manipulation of the mustache, whereby the decorative characteristics of that appendage are made to conform to the wearer's idea of facial improvement.

Commemorating the 146th anniversary of the inauguration of George Washington as the first President, distinguished citizens and military leaders declared yesterday that peace and respect for the United States can be assured only by building up a strong, well-trained citizen reserve force.

BOSTON, April 30. -- Republicans of the six New England States, where the depression in the textile industry has become a political issue, met today in the first of five regional party conferences. The meeting suggested constructive policies for the 1936 campaign and pledged revitalization of the party.

Backed by city detectives, Dean Hannah M. Egan of Hunter College halted a meeting of the Peace Council there yesterday afternoon.
