The meeting, at which Joseph Cadden, a representative of the National Student Federation and editor of the National Student Mirror was scheduled to speak, was being held in contravention to a college rule providing that anyone speaking before a student organization must have the permission of the dean.

Henry Abbott Jr., the former Coney Island barker and burlesque comedian who organized his own "Reporters Press Association" to defraud prominent persons of money under pretext it was to be used for "indigent" newspaper men and their families, was convicted in General Sessions yesterday of the theft of $150 from a broker.

Seeking restoration of $18,000,000 in pay cuts to city employes, Alderman Frank A. Cunningham introduced a resolution in the Board of Aldermen yesterday asking modification of the city's agreement with its bankers to permit release of that amount for the restorations.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 30 (AP). -- Samuel S. Leibowitz, Scottsboro defense counsel, sent a request today to Governor Bibb Graves asking for a full pardon for all of the defendants in the "Scottsboro case."

PITTSBURGH, April 30. -- Andrew W. Mellon tonight charged Secretary Morgenthau with making a "crude effort to interfere with the administration of justice," upon learning that a telegram from the Secretary of the Treasury concerning the $3,089,000 Mellon income-tax case now before the Board of Tax Appeals had been made public.

MEXICO, D.F., April 30. -- Although 800,000,000 pesos in new copper coins have been put in circulation by the Bank of Mexico, the shortage of small change for business transactions became more acute today as silver money was retired from circulation.

Proposals to build hidden bases for aircraft along the Canadian border were included in the plans of our military experts argued for before the Congressional committee. It is not clear whether a formal or informal inquiry about this came from Ottawa to Washington.

The busiest final day in years for payment of the first half of the annual real estate levy was reported yesterday by the Finance Department. City Collector's offices in the five boroughs were thronged all day and, in addition, thousands of payments were received by mail.

Jay E. Crane, deputy governor of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, who has been local manager of the Treasury's $2,000,000,000 Exchange Stabilization Fund, resigned yesterday from the bank to become assistant treasurer of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey.

Gertler Co., bidding alone, won yesterday the award of a new issue of $4,200,000 State of South Carolina refunding bonds dated June 1, 1935, and due from 1940 to 1955. The bankers topped four other bidders by naming a price of 101.136 for the bonds as 3 1/4s.

For fulfilling "the highest tradition of the brotherhood of the sea," Captain Sadi Gonthier of the Jean Jadot of the Lloyd Royal Belge line, and eight members of the crew who took part in the rescue of two men from the British freighter Us-worth at sea on Dec. 14, received medals yesterday from Herbert L. Satterlee, president of the Life-Saving Benevolent Association of New York.

The office force of The American Mercury, 730 Fifth Avenue, went on strike yesterday. The strikers declared that they walked out when the management discharged two of their fellow employes because of their union activities. The management maintained that the employes went on strike when the publication refused to be run by a shop committee.

Efforts begun through the mediation of Mayor La Guardia and Bernard S. Deutsch, President of the Board of Aldermen, for settling the strike of the cleaners and dyers, ended in failure yesterday at a conference between employers representing wholesale plants and the unions conducting the strike.

HAVANA, April 30. -- The holding of general elections Nov. 1, next, under a modified form of the 1901 Constitution has been agreed upon by four of the most prominent political organizations of Cuba, according to an official announcement from the Presidential Palace today.

NEWTON, N.J., April 30. -- Wallace Ayres, 85 years old, a member of the Sussex County Octogenarian Club, drove 100 miles from Hazleton, Pa., today to attend the sixth annual meeting of the club and to tell the members that life begins at 60.
PARIS, April 30. -- A new hitch developed in the Franco-Russian mutual assistance pact today as the Cabinet suggested certain changes in the text which Russia must approve.

LONDON, April 30. -- The stock markets here continued their activity today. Aircraft and oil shares were again outstanding features, the former on expectations of increased orders and the latter in anticipation of an early rise in fuel prices.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Assurances that business revival was under way, coupled with sharp criticism of New Deal measures and demands that President Roosevelt assume leadership to restore business confidence, were voiced at the annual meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, which opened its three-day session here today.
Frank Shannon of New York announeed a revised list of Kentucky! Derby odds last night. Mrs. Walteri M. Jeffords's Comro_onwealth is now I quoted at 5 to I.
Meat trade condilions and wholesale prices in New York:

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that he had decided to replace Magistrate Benjamin Greenspan with former Representative Nathan D. Perlman and to reappoint Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio. Both officials will be sworn in at City Hall today.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- President Roosevelt censured the House Military Affairs Committee today for publishing secret testimony of army officers on the Wilcox Air Base Bill involving the United States' relations with Canada, repudiated the views of the officers as not in line with administration policies, and gave assurances that this government would observe in letter and spirit its treaties with Canada that have meant unfortified frontiers for a century.
Sixteen Manhattan parcels were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday.

A cabled confirmation of discussed plans, received yesterday by the United States Polo Association from the Hurlingham Club of England, assured foreign competition for our most important polo tournaments during the coming Summer.
Mrs. William Robinson Simonds gave a luncheon yesterday at the Ritz-Carlton. Her guests were Mr. and Mrs. Harold H. Will, Mrs. James Watt, Mrs. Simonds Duryea and Mrs. David Shea.

PARIS, April 30. -- Once more the proposed Franco-Russian pact of mutual assistance was sent back today by the French Cabinet for further amendment and once more Vladimir Potemkin, Soviet Ambassador here, has telegraphed his government for new instructions.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 30. -- A search by police, Boy Scouts and volunteers along the Elizabeth River here, a check-up on a bloodhound trail picked up late yesterday by two dogs from Glen Ridge and another bloodhound search of the Newark meadows this afternoon failed to turn up a clew to the fate of three Elizabeth boys missing since last Friday.

A TWA "mystery" plane roared into Floyd Bennett Field last evening with a new transcontinental flight record for transport planes, having crossed the continent nonstop from Los Angeles in 11 hours and 5 minutes, with a robot at the controls virtually all the way.

The appeal by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, that further experiments in Federal legislation be deferred until the next Congressional session in order to give a chance for unimpeded business recovery, is unfortunately not likely to bring favorable response from the Capitol.

The Shell Union Oil Corporation reported yesterday for 1934 a net loss of $949,111 from operations after all charges and reserves, including intangible drilling expenses. In 1933 the net operating loss was $5,250,290. A net charge against income of $404,789 in connection with the 5 per cent sinking fund twenty-year debentures retired in November brought the net loss for last year to $1,353,900.

Samuel Untermyer, president of the Non-Sectarian Anti-Nazi League to Champion Human Rights, criticized the League of Nations last night for failure to invoke an international boycott against Germany. Mr. Untermyer delivered an address at an "all-star variety benefit show" which the Anti-Nazi League gave at the Hippodrome.

CHICAGO, April 30. -- Liquidation was under way in the May deliveries of grains today on the Board of Trade, and the selling, with spreading and back-spreading between various futures and between the different pits and markets, furnished a liberal percentage of the trade.

A gale-like wind blew the Yankees into an early lead over the Senators at the Stadium yesterday, brushed this advantage aside with a threat of defeat and finally wafted victory into the laps of the leaderless McCarthymen, 9 to 8. A crowd of about 3,000 saw the skirmish end in the ninth inning with none out when the mighty bat of Bill Dickey crashed home the winning tally.

A derailment at Stamford, Conn., which piled up seven cars, plunged two others from a viaduct to the street and sent a badly injured conductor to the hospital, disrupted yesterday morning the service of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad.
CHICAGO, April 30. -- The Illinois Emergency Relief Commission, impoverished by the suspension of Federal aid, closed the doors of all its State stations to 1,200,000 persons tonight.

A sharp advance in prices of long-term United States Government bonds featured dealings on the Stock Exchange yesterday. The government issues were bid up 1-32 to 9-32 point, thirteen of the issues mounting to new record highs since issuance, reflecting the success of the Treasury's First Liberty Loan conversion.

The first case of tampering to occur during the local racing season was revealed at Jamaica yesterday when the stewards ordered the withdrawal of Mrs. W.T. Anderson's Jadaan from the six-furlong dash which featured the program and was won by George H. Bostwick's Ariel Cross, the 4-5 choice.

JEFFERSON CITY, Tuesday, May 1 (AP). -- Missouri went off the Federal relief rolls at midnight because the Legislature failed to provide for financing the State's "fair share" of relief costs, as demanded by the Federal Emergency Relief Administration.

DETROIT, April 30 (AP). -- Facing the dangers of a spreading strike in the automobile labor field, the Federal Government started a quick opening thrust against rapidly-shaping developments tonight, with Edward F. McGrady, Assistant Secretary of Labor, en route to try to cope with the Toledo key strike affecting four General Motors Corporation plants.
ALBANY, April 30. -- Governor Lehman signed today two bills, one designed to curb ambulance-chasing lawyers and the other to end fee-splitting between lawyers and laymen.
SOMERVILLE, N.J., April 30. -- A strange tale of a burglar whose arrest resulted from his falling asleep on the job, was unfolded this morning before Police Recorder Anthony P. Kearns.

The program with which Leon Barzin and his training orchestra of the National Orchestral Association ended their season at Carnegie Hall last night had the elements of balance, substance and novelty that have marked most of their concerts.

Reuben Nakian, the sculptor, has returned from Washington with several gray hairs, but also, triumphantly, with his busts of New Deal leaders, upon which he has been working for about a year. It was a formidable task. The sitters did not come to Mr. Nakian's studio to have their portraits made.

LINDENHURST, L.I., April 30. -- The welfare relief office here had a noisy few hours this afternoon after a disgruntled father who sought a larger relief check for his family had deposited his two small children on a desk and said, "Here, you take care of them."

How soon the Nazi pagans will succeed in eradicating Christianity in Germany it is hard to say. Perhaps we may get a hint from Soviet Russia, where an atheistic regime has been in power for eighteen years. On Easter Sunday at least 75,000 worshipers thronged the thirty-five Moscow churches that have been allowed to remain open.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- House Democrats today sang a paean of praise to Secretary Ickes, who has just been put in charge of allotments out of the $4,000,000,000 work relief fund, and voted to let him have a new $10,000-a-year Under-Secretary.

Miss Alice E. Mertz, social case work director of the Home Relief Bureau, told the Aldermanic Committee Investigating Relief yesterday that she and her husband earned a combined income of $99 a week from the State TERA as members of what she called "a privileged class."

CHICAGO, April 30. -- The Federal grand jury indicted thirty-nine men and four women today on charges of using the mails to defraud some 270,000 persons through the old Sir Francis Drake estate swindle scheme. The defendants are accused of selling shares in the mythical estate and obtaining more than $1,000,000, most of which was mailed to offices in Chicago and Sioux City, Iowa.

Favorable changes outnumbered the unfavorable in the business situation in the latter part of March and the first half of April, according to Banking, the publication of the American Bankers Association. The magazine says, however, that the changes which occurred could hardly be said to have modified the fundamental situation materially.
Child artists are much in evidence just now, and no doubt will continue to be for some little time, since the Spring is their season.

Merger of the New York Stock Exchange firms of J.R. Williston Co. and McClure, Jones Co., under the former's name, will become effective today. Partners in the latter firm, which was dissolved yesterday, who will join the new organization are Henry R. Rudkin, Charles I. De Bevoise, W. Strother Jones Jr., Perry D. Bogue, Arthur S. Russell, Walter F. Seeholzer and William T. Genth, special partner.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 30. -- The Bolivian Army reports a new victory in the northern sector of the Gran Chaco.
Various leases by wholesalers and retail firms in the midtown and downtown section of Manhattan were reported by brokers yesterday, the eve of moving day, as follows:

It is hard to keep pace with the Republican revival. One of the Republican State chairmen who are preparing for that Springfield convention in June, where the Republicans of nine Midwestern States are to put up the greatest show since the Chicago Wigwam of 1860, says that the revival movement "should come from the 'grass roots' "of the Middle West and should not be "dominated by professional politicians," State chairmen are only amateurs.

VIENNA, April 30 -- Colonel Walter Adam, Government Commissar for Propaganda, announced tonight a limited amnesty for certain ordinary criminals and political prisoners in connection with May Day. Four hundred criminals and 195 political prisoners will be released tomorrow, all having served more than half their sentences.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- President Roosevelt censured the House Military Affairs Committee for making public testimony regarding air bases taken at an executive session. He backed Harry L. Hopkins, Relief Administrator, in insisting that Illinois raise its share of relief money before getting further Federal funds and conferred with Congress members and others on NRA extension.

ALBANY, April 30. -- Three advocates of nudism won their case in the Court of Appeals today when the court upheld the Appellate Division reversal of their conviction in New York on charges of "outraging public decency, maintaining a public nuisance and indecent exposure."

ST. LOUIS, April 30 (AP). -- Rogers Hornsby's revamped line-up today failed to shake the persistent St. Louis jinx, and the Browns dropped an 11-to-3 decision to the Detroit Tigers before a crowd of fewer than a thousand.

ALBANY, April 30. -- The method of making decisions in boxing bouts in New York State was changed officially today as Governor Lehman signed the Mangano bill recommended by the State Athletic Commission.

Class I railroads of the United States spent $600,224,000 for fuel, material and supplies in 1934 against $465,850,000 in 1933 and $1,329,535,000 in 1929, according to the Association of American Railroads. Such purchases were not reported in 1930, 1931 and 1932.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 30. -- A Nazi expert, testifying in the suit brought by Jews to brand the notorious "protocols of Zion" as fakes, declared today that "the program of the World League of Jewry is identical with the program of the protocols" in seeking secret control of all governments.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30. -- Columbia drew the No. 5, or east shore lane, in the Blackwell Cup regatta varsity race with Yale and Pennsylvania here Saturday, according to an announcement today. In the draw, conducted by C. Louis Borie 3d, Yale is in the favored middle lane and Penn on the west side.
" I drove up-State for a bit of trout fishing over the week-end and for an early season visit the results were more than satisfying," reports Kenneth B. Spencer of this city.

Four well-dressed young men, two of them armed, held up the manager, four employes and a visitor in an optician's shop at 80 West Fortieth Street a few minutes before 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon and escaped unnoticed among the rush-hour crowds in Sixth Avenue, Fortieth Street and the southwestern corner of Bryant Park.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- The Senate leadership was subjected to a good-natured but none the less painful "spanking" today at the bands of President Roosevelt for the slow progress of that body on New Deal measures since Congress convened Jan. 3.

Jimmy and Johnny Woods, the 3-year-old identical twins who became famous for their experiences in the Normal Child Development Clinic of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Centre, made their radio debut at 6:15 last night over WHN.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Application of the Square D Company for registration on the New York Curb Exchange of 103,831 shares of Class A preferred, issued, and 71,668 Class B, issued, both no par, was ordered effective today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- President Roosevelt stood solidly behind Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Relief Administrator, today in insisting that the Illinois Legislature must pass a bill to raise $3,300,000 a month for relief before the State can receive another cent of Federal relief funds.

It might be misleading to describe Mrs. E.M. Delafield as a wit. In our theatre a wit is a master of the instantaneous rejoinder. And her "To See Ourselves," which was capitally acted at the Ethel Barrymore last evening, is obviously a comedy of character about the stuffiness that creeps into married life after the romantic glamour has begun to show tarnish.

Commodity futures fluctuated within a narrow range on the markets here yesterday. Activity was generally at a low ebb. On the cash markets corn, rye, tin and rubber advanced and wheat and lard declined.
About a year ago a campaign was launched to produce better and cleaner moving pictures. Outstanding and interested leaders of educational and religious groups took active part in it.

Two bickering bandits, who gave their victim several uneasy moments before they agreed whether he should put up his hands or keep them down, robbed yesterday the jewelry store of George W. Rainess at 1,194 Madison Avenue, just north of Eighty-seventh Street, of merchandise valued at $10,000 to $15,000.

The NRA can become an important factor in our economic life, or it can destroy itself by mistakes, W. Averell Harriman, administrative officer of the NRA, told the Trade and Commerce Bar Association, at its annual dinner at the Hotel Ritz-Carlton last night.

Thousands of dollars worth of imported merchandise including steel, linen cloth, plate glass and other products which have been accumulating in bonded warehouses for the last six weeks, will be withdrawn by importers starting today when the lower rates of duty provided under this country's trade treaty with Belgium go into effect.

MARGATE, England, April 30. -- Winning a game apiece today in the sixth round, Samuel Reshevsky of New York and Jose R. Capablanca of Havana remained first and second, respectively, in the international masters tournament of the Kent County Chess Association in progress at the Grand Hotel. The two favorites are still half a point apart, with three rounds to go.

An indictment charging five individuals and two corporations with conspiracy to supply manufacturers of bootleg whisky with sugar and molasses was handed yesterday by the Federal grand jury to Judge Robert A. Inch in the United States District Court in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- With plans already made for a tremendous expansion and spending program, the Civilian Conservation Corps received from the Treasury today an assignment of $190,000,000 in connection with the $4,000,000,000 work relief program.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- As a one-man filibuster delayed House progress on the administration banking bill, Representative Goldsborough of Maryland served notice today that he would seek to attach a "commodity dollar" amendment.

LONDON, April 30. -- Four hundred British members of the Pilgrims Society, assembled under the chairmanship of the Earl of Derby to honor the Duke of Kent and celebrate King George's silver Jubilee, were joined by United States members of the Pilgrims tonight in sending the King a message of tribute.

Socialists and Communists will parade today in the larger cities, but few smaller communities will witness their demonstrations. The Marxian movement in this country remains essentially what it has always been: a hothouse product of the metropolitan areas.

The Morris H.S. and James Monroe H.S. baseball teams were victorious over their respective rivals yesterday in the Bronx-Upper Manhattan Division of the Public Schools Athletic League. Port Richmond defeated Curtis, 5 to 4, in a Lower Manhattan-Richmond engagement.

A public offering of $19,371,800 of $100 par 5 1/2 per cent convertible preferred stock of the Commercial Credit Company is being made at 102, to yield 5.39 per cent, by a group headed by Kidder, Peabody Co., and the First Boston Corporation.

Hisashi Fujimura, wealthy Japanese who was one of the largest silk importers in this country, left no taxable New York estate when he disappeared on Aug. 14, 1931, from the Red Star liner Belgenland, it was disclosed yesterday when a non-resident "absentee" transfer tax appraisal was filed here.
HARRISBURG, Pa., April 30. -- Governor Earle tonight suspended Mayor Eddie McCloskey of Johnstown from the chairmanship of the State Athletic Commission for one month without pay.

MEXICO, D.F., April 30. -- After having been held up for twenty-four hours because of unfavorable weather reports, Amelia Earhart found it necessary today to postpone the take-off of her non-stop flight to New York for another day for the same reason.

CHICAGO, April 30 (AP). -- With everything calm and orderly after yesterday's pugilistic encounters that caused the suspension of two players, the Cubs shut out Pittsburgh, 3 to 0, today for their sixth victory in seven starts.

The American Society of Orthodontists opened its annual convention at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday, with 600 delegates registered for the four-day meeting. It was the first meeting of the society here in twenty-nine years.

Drama enlivened the homeward trip of 3,000 commuters on the municipal ferryboat Manhattan en route from Whitehall Street to St. George, S.I., just before 6 o'clock last night when members of the crew rescued a passenger who had leaped into the water.
Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that he had written to Governor Lehman urging the latter to sign the Transit Unification Bill passed at the last session of the Legislature.

Two Manhattan posts of the American Legion have been suspended for permitting uniformed members to picket a Brooklyn theatre, it was disclosed yesterday by Maurice Stember, State adjutant of the Legion. The suspension, which went into effect on Saturday, marks the first time such action has been taken against a post in the State.

A net income of $1,770,297 in the first quarter of 1935 was reported yesterday by the Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore after all deductions. This was equivalent, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.27 a share earned on 1,167,397 no-par common shares.

QUEBEC, April 30. -- Quebec's newsprint bill, redrafted in radical fashion, made its reappearance this afternoon, minus the most contentious clauses of all, but with a couple of new paragraphs designed to put teeth in it.

Edwina Booth, motion picture actress, who has been suffering from a complication of diseases contracted in Africa during the filming of "Trader Horn" in 1929, has accepted a settlement of her $1,000,000 damage suit against the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Pictures Corporation, her attorney, Emil K. Ellis of 1270 Sixth Avenue, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- With administration control of the Senate Finance Committee wavering, Senators representing all elements in the tangled NRA legislative situation were called to the White House today by President Roosevelt in the hope that a formula might be found for early action to extend the National Industrial Recovery Act.

The versatility of Benjamin Eisenstadt, a young attorney, became known in the Tombs Court yesterday when it was related that only a few hours before he had doffed his white linen coat as a counterman in a Flatbush cafeteria to become counsel for a man accused of forgery.

MUKDEN, Manchukuo, April 30. -- Apparently convinced that the Manchukuoan Government does not intend weakening its stand on the petroleum monopoly, the British, American and Netherlands companies are preparing to close their offices and retire from the Manchurian field.

Declaring that he was more optimistic than at any time in the last five years, Percival E. Foerderer, chairman of the board of the Tanners Council of America, yesterday called for an organized drive on the part of the shoe and allied industries to broaden shoe consumption.

The Nazi Government has many stupidities, injustices and crimes to answer for, but one important achievement, reported in a recent dispatch to THE TIMES by Mr. BIRCHALL, must be set down on the asset side of its balance sheet. This is the "super-orderliness" of the country, "its thorough "cultivation, the trimness and spruce-"ness of its settlements, the absence "everywhere of anything pertaining to "the litter of waste."
Business in the credit market was small, chiefly replacements. Quotations were unchanged in all departments.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30. -- Helium, the gas discovered in the sun before its existence on earth was known, has been found to be a new "breath of life" for sufferers from severe attacks of asthma who no longer respond to the usual treatment.
Bill Terry's Giants came to Ebbets Field yesterday for the first time this year, and left it with the same sort of headache they carried out of the Polo Grounds last September.

THE boxing office on the fourth floor of Madison Square Garden was occupied by Herr Joe Jacobs, manager of Max Schmeling, and a couple of innocent bystanders. James Joy Johnston was in the chair. Max Baer was not among those present. That was the item that seemed to be putting Mr. Johnston in something of a dither.

Our flight across the country in the first of our Douglas air liners, equipped now as a flying laboratory, indicated to me at least that the time is not far distant when we will be making the whole trip at 20,000 feet with passengers and mail.

BERLIN, April 30. -- The Jewish Review, organ of the Zionist Society of Germany, carried today a plea for some sort of definition of the position of Jews in Germany inasmuch as Dr. Wilhelm Frick, Minister of the Interior, announced that Jews were to lose their citizenship in the near future.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Spring, when the earth is putting on brave new garments and the fancy of youth turns believingly to fairy-tale endings of all romances, is the gloomy season for American legislators. Now that short sessions of Congress are abolished and the body is almost certain to be in session throughout every May, Spring pessimism will be annual instead of frequently biennial.

This is the day on which, under their agreement with the unions, the railway managements may make their first move for a cut in wages to offset the recent restoration of 10 per cent in payrolls. The move would take the form of a thirty-day notice of intention to the unions.

Any cash offer for the Fox Metropolitan Playhouses, Inc., must be submitted today at the closing session of the hearings on reorganization plans before Federal Judge Julian W. Mack in the County Lawyers Association Building, 14 Vesey Street.
CHICAGO, April 30. -- An investigation of the financial failure of the Rosenbaum Grain Corporation was ordered today by the Chicago Board of Trade.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 30. -- Ole Saulthe, former head of the New York City Department of Food and Drugs, is preparing a report for United States Senator Royal S. Copeland on the pastry poisonings in Westchester last week for possible use by the Senator in his inquiry into foods and drugs, County Health Commissioner Matthias Nicoll Jr. announced today.

The next General Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church will be held in May, 1936, in Columbus, Ohio, it was decided yesterday at a meeting of the book committee of the Methodist Book Concern, 150 Fifth Avenue.
Two new playgrounds -- one in Brooklyn for children, the other in Manhattan for adults -- will be opened today by the Park Department. These openings will bring the total for this year to fourteen.

Circulars purporting to emanate from the Actors Equity Association urging its members to march in the May Day parade today were disavowed by the Equity Council at its weekly meeting yesterday. The circulars, signed "May Day Committee of Equity Members," had been posted on theatrical call boards and otherwise distributed among players.

ROME, April 30 (AP). -- The authoritative newspaper, Giornale d'Italia, crediting its information to its Paris office, says that Germany's naval plans for 1935-36 embrace construction of thirty-one naval units, including two 20,000-ton cruisers, in addition to the twelve submarines reported in Berlin and London dispatches.

After, it is said, he had confessed to murdering a 6-year-old girl in his apartment yesterday and dropping her body down the dumbwaiter shaft, Frank Flynn, 39, of 29-07 Thirty-first Avenue, Astoria Queens, was taken to the office of the Queens County District Attorney for further questioning.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 30. -- Of the people who live in New York City, only 5 per cent actually, have to live there and the others would be better off if they lived elsewhere, according to Dr. Lyman Bryson, specialist in adult education at Columbia University.

LONDON, April 30. -- The news that a British polo team will visit Meadow Brook next Summer to compete in various tournaments, including the United States open championship, was hailed with great satisfaction when circulated at the British sporting clubs tonight.

BERLIN, April 30. -- The BoerseI continued today its downward i course, although activity was limited. Heavy industrial stocks showed slight losses, Vereinigte Stahl losing point. Electrical, chemical and machinery shares showed the same tendency toward stagnation, coupled with scattered small losses. Shipping stocks were firmer.
ALBANY, April 30. -- Three bills which would have removed some of the present restrictions in the Civil Service Law were vetoed today by Governor Lehman.

S.L. Hoffman, who has served as executive vice president of the National Association of House Dress Manufacturers, Inc., was elected president of the organization at its annual meeting yesterday in the Hotel Pennsylvania. Mr. Hoffman was the guest of honor at a testimonial dinner given at the hotel last night, which was attended by about 350 of his associates in the house dress industry.

NEWARK, N.J., April 30. -- Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein appealed to President Roosevelt today to cause the appointment of a Congressional committee, employing engineers and aeronautical experts, to determine the relative merits of Eastern sites for air mail terminal purposes.

The ban which some European governments have placed on the export of certain of their art treasures has been extended recently by France to autographs of two of her noted aviators, it became known here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Amendments to the Agricultural Adjustment Act, aiming to provide farm price and production control through operation of the "ever-normal granary" plan, were reported favorably to the House today by its Agriculture Committee.

At the annual meeting of stockholders of R.H. Macy Co. at its store yesterday, Percy S. Straus, president, said the officers had discussed unofficially the refinancing of the preferred stock issue of L. Bamberger Co. of Newark, which is controlled by Macy's. This issue, totaling $7,882,700 at the end of last year, bears an annual dividend rate of $6.50 a share.

BELGRADE, April 30. -- The situation in Yugoslavia grows more critical every day as the elections draw nearer. Opposition circles report, although official confirmation is lacking, that already 150 oppositional candidates have been arrested and interned pending the elections next Sunday.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 30. -- The American team of three six-meter yachts defeated the Bermuda group today in the second and last race for the Sir Thomas Astley Cubitt trophy, but was unable to overcome the point lead gained by the Bermudans yesterday. The local skippers captured the series, 22 1/4 points to 20 1/4.

LONDON, April 30. -- Still in a state of utter indecision, the British Cabinet will meet tomorrow for the first time since it received the news that Germany had begun to build twelve submarines in defiance of the Treaty of Versailles.

MOSCOW, April 30. -- The ejection from a theatre recently of 100 Russians who had bought tickets only to find that their seats had been given afterward to foreign diplomats resulted in a demand today for an investigation by the public prosecutor of this and similar injustices.
Victor Powell, pianist, will assist Elena Marisa, soprano, among the Madrigal Society's sponsored artists at the Town Hall tonight.

Let this morning's second note be chiding. Let it dwell, mournfully and with true sentiment, on the melodrama that used to be. Let it remember "The Bat," "The Gorilla" and the distinguished corpses that in the old days were most at home on the side streets off Broadway.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Treasury officials took a day off today so far as silver was concerned, and the price for the domestic mined metal, fixed at 77.57 cents an ounce on April 24, remained unchanged again tonight.

MIAMI, Fla., April 30. -- Closer cooperation of social agencies to improve character education methods for the youth of America was suggested by Dr. Joseph Artman of Chicago, national chairman of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers at a meeting today in connection with the organization's thirty-ninth annual convention.

MEXICO, D.F., April 30. -- Mexico, on the heels of its quick action to reform its monetary system, looks confidently into the future and views serenely any further rise in the price of silver, which is so important a factor in its economic fabric.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 30. -- Governor Merriam took under advisement today a recommendation of the Assembly, voted last week and reaffirmed today, that the "terms of Tom Mooney and Warren K. Billings be commuted to time served," without expression as to their guilt or innocence.
Victor Powell, pianist, will assist Elena Marisa, soprano, among the Madrigal Society's sponsored artists at the Town Hall tonight.
Although trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month was the heaviest in any month since last December, the volume was the lowest for any April since 1924.

For seasonal reasons, if for no other, the trend of industrial production over the next two or three months is likely to be downward, the National City Bank says in the current issue of its monthly bulletin, published yesterday.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 1. -A twenty-nine-word will, written on the back of an invitation to a dance, has been filed for probate in Middlesex Court.

Work by two famous nineteenth century French artists, Edgar Degas and Jean-Louis Forain, is currently on view in local galleries -- small bronzes and drawings by the former at the Jacques Seligmann Galleries 3 East Fifty-first Street; etchings and lithographs by the latter at Knoedler's, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street.

M.H. Lamston, Inc., operating a chain of 5-cent to $1 stores, will open on Sept. 1 an additional link in 1,393-97 Sixth Avenue, south of the southwest corner of Fifty-seventh Street. The building is being modernized by Klein Jackson to include offices on the second floor and studio apartments above.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- The largest stockholder among officers and directors of the Liggett Myers Tobacco Company was C.W. Toms, president, as of Feb. 15, with 17,500 common and 1,000 preferred, according to the company's registration statement, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Engineering construction awards last month totaled $116,972,000, a 15 per cent increase over the $101,192,000 aggregate a year ago, The Engineering News-Record reported yesterday. The rise was attributed to a private construction increase to $42,439,000 last month from $17,737,000 in April, 1934.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- G.H. Dorr, president of the Cotton Textile Institute, told members of the United States Chamber of Commerce round-table on the NRA today that ultimately "we must work out a technique for handling the workings of the competitive system if that system is to be preserved."
The Maemere Stable's Somebody, a 4-year-old son of Chance Shot, proved himself much the best of a small but good field in the Forest Handicap, which featured the racing at Jamaica yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, May 1. -- The keels of four Coast Guard cutters, to cost about $600,000 each, were laid today at the Philadelphia Navy Yard.
PHILADELPHIA, May 1 (AP). -The Red Sex won a close game with the Athletics, 8 to 6, today. The defeat was the fifth straight for the Mackmen.

MONTREAL, May 1 (Canadian Press). -- Announcement was made today at the annual meeting here of shareholders of the Canadian Pacific Railway by E.W. Beatty, president, that the company had contracted for the transfer of the Eastern section of its irrigation project in Alberta to trustees of an irrigation district.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 1. -- The Paraguayans have failed to accomplish all three of their objectives in the Chaco War, according to Enrique Baldivieso, Bolivian Minister of War. Senor Baldivieso declared today these objectives were the capture of Villa Montes, in the southern sector; the seizure of the oil fields of the central sector and the capture of Santa Cruz, in the northern sector.

CHICAGO, May 1. -- The market here for hogs was somewhat unsettled today and while early prices were steady to 5 cents a hundredweight higher than yesterday an easier undertone developed and some late sales were around 10 cents lower. The top was unchanged at $9.15 and the average was steady at $8.95.

Since the NRA has been declared unconstitutional by the Federal District Court in Newark, agents of Code Authorities who try to collect assessments for code administration from retail businesses in Jersey City will be arrested as disorderly persons, Police Chief Daniel Casey of Jersey City warned yesterday.
BERLIN, May 1 (London Times Dispatch). -- The twin problems of financial stringency and scarcity of raw materials are the object of an increasing preoccupation in competent German quarters.
GLEN COVE, L.I., May 1. -- The members of the Women's Long Island Golf Association officially inaugurated another golfing season in a one-day tourney at the Piping Rock Club today.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, May 1. -While President Jiminez read a message opening the Congress today, 5,000 Communists staged a demonstration denouncing Hitlerism, Facism and the high cost of living.

Coming from behind, the undefeated New York University baseball team scored four runs to down the St. John's University nine, 4 to 3, for its seventh straight triumph of the season at Dexter Park yesterday.

Reflecting the rising trend of the market, only seventy-eight stocks listed on the Stock Exchange established last month new low price levels since July 1, 1933, the date used in computing margin requirements. In March 293 issues dropped into new margin ranges.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- A continued rise in prices paid farmers for farm products, with the index standing at 111 on April 15, or 3 points above mid-March and 29 points above April 15, 1934, was reported today by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics.
The majority of the apartment rentals reported yesterday were in West Side houses, as follows:

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The Laclede Gas Light Company of St. Louis reported to the Securities Commission today that the Utilities Power Light Corporation of Chicago held 5,345 shares, or 21 per cent, of its preferred stock and 90,453 shares, or 84.5 per cent, of the common.

The English Boy Choristers, twelve British youths representing ten Church of England churches, who have been making a "goodwill" tour of Episcopal churches in the United States, will make one of their most important appearances on Sunday at St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- Mrs. Roosevelt received more than 3,000 guests this afternoon, entertaining them on the south lawn of the White House at the last of the season's series of teas, which also, due to the pleasant weather, was the first of this year's garden parties.
Floyd B. Odlum, president of the Atlas Corporation, the largest investment company in the United States, has been elected chairman of the board of the Neurological Institute of New York.

A rise of $254,920 in operating expenses in 1934 of the Kansas City Southern Railway was attributed by C.E. Johnston, president, in his report for that year, to $71,896 charges for liabilities under the railway pension law, $55,000 for wage restorations and $75,000 estimated costs of the company's negotiations for new rules and working conditions with the four train service unions.

Pig iron production in April, according to The Iron Age, aggregated 1,664,000 tons, as compared with 1,770,028 tons in March. The daily rate in April, at 55,470 tons, represented a decline of 2.8 per cent from the March average of 57,098 tons a day. Ninety-seven furnaces were in blast on May 1, as against ninety-eight on April 1, a net loss of one.

The focal point of the New York University women's athletic season was reached last night as thirtythree varsity letters and six special awards were given to the members of the basketball, field hockey, swimming, fencing and tennis teams at the eleventh annual dinner of the Women's Athletic Association at the Fifth Avenue Hotel.

ALBANY, May 1. -- Governor Lehman will sound the keynote of the Democratic campaign to retain control of the Assembly in a radio address over a State-wide hook-up on Sunday night, it was announced today.

New York City 3 per cent bonds with a par value of $197,630 were sold yesterday by Controller Frank J. Taylor to local financial institutions. They were part of a block of $2,282,000 held by various city retirement funds. Bids for the balance of the bonds were not accepted.
Fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange held to about 7 points yesterday, and prices ended 1 to 5 points lower in one of the most quiet trading sessions of the year.

Complete revision of the terms under which the city has always bought electric current from the Consolidated Gas system was announced yesterday by Maurice P. Davidson, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity. He made public the specifications under which the company, next Monday, will submit to the city bids expected to run between 25 per cent and 35 per cent lower than in previous years.

In an annual celebration of "Youths Day in Industry," the management of the New York Stock Exchange will be entrusted today to six junior employes of the Exchange and its subsidiaries who have been chosen from the ranks because of their employment records and scholastic work.

H.L. Mencken, former editor of The American Mercury and at one time the enfant terrible of conservative America, visited the office of the magazine yesterday. Outside he met a group of the magazine's former employes, now on strike, and lectured them on what he termed the futility and foolishness of strikes.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- Conditions under which cash transactions may be carried on in registered and unregistered securities, and some other phases of the margin requirements were set forth today by the Federal Reserve Board in formal amendments to the rules now in effect.

Unmarred by the slightest sign of trouble, and with a carnival spirit prevailing, rival parades and mass meetings were staged here yesterday by Socialists and Communists for what both said was "the biggest observance of May Day ever held in a capitalistic country."

Katharine Cornell's production of "Flowers of the Forest," the John van Druten play at the Beck, will close a week from Saturday night after an engagement of five weeks. And with its closing, Miss Cornell will end her season. She will not revive "Candida," either for special performances or for a regular run, although all but two members of the cast had been selected.
Business in money lacked feature. Replacing expiring obligations made up the day's turnover, little new money being engaged. Quotations were unchanged.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 1. -- Classification of medical patients into four income groups, with appropriate fees for each group, as a means of meeting the economic problems of medical care, was proposed at the 169th annual meeting of the New Jersey Medical Society here today by Dr. Francis H. Glazebrook of Morristown, medical director of the New York Stock Exchange.

CHICAGO, May 1. -- Liquidation of wheat futures on the Board of Trade by houses with Eastern connections was too large today to be absorbed by the relatively limited buying power, and the market closed at the lowest point of the day, with net losses of 1 to 1 3/8 cents a bushel, the May leading.

Manager Joseph V. McCarthy of the Yankees, who is seriously ill at his home at the Hotel Croydon, 12 East Eighty-sixth Street, with influenza complicated by an old gallbladder condition, was reported improved last night.

PATERSON, N.J., May 1. -Charged with sending two letters threatening to kill Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, Philip Martin of Clifton, 46-year-old night watchman in a silk mill here, was arrested today. The letters were written on March 19 and were identical. One was received by the Paterson police, the other by Warden Lewis E. Lawes of Sing Sing.

Angelo Saullo, one of nine defendants on trial in Federal Court for the kidnapping and torturing last August of Guillaume Rozen, a French seaman, testified yesterday that agents of the Department of Justice had made him stand in a corner with his face to a wall for five days.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- Congressional resentment against big financial interests was very marked today during House debate on the Banking Bill, the advocates of the measure asserting that its principal aim was to take control of the country's banking system away from "three or four men in New York" and vest it in a government body in Washington.
CINCINNATI, May 1 (AP). -- Dizzy Dean held down the Reds until it was too late for them to catch up, and the Cardinals made it two out of three in the series by defeating Cincinnati, 5 to 2, today.
That Dodger dash for first place ran against a tremendous obstacle yesterday in the person of Roy (Tarzan) Parmelee and 18,000 Flat-bush fans left Ebbets Field more than a little chagrined.

Secretary ICKES must be one of the most overworked officials at Washington. His jobs are multiple. His duties are multifarious. The Secretary of the Interior had quite enough to administer before the NIRA added immensely to his labors. He was fully entitled to have an Under-Secretary.

The Department of Commerce gave its approval yesterday to a pooling agreement between the American Diamond Lines, Inc., and the Lloyd Royal Belge Line, whereby the incomes of the two from traffic between the United States and Belgium will be divided equally.

HAVANA, May 1. -- Six alleged Spanish anarchists were detained today by the police on a charge of having been members of a group that was responsible or the burning of the Ward liner Morro Castle and other recent marine disasters.

May I suggest that Mayor La Guardia and Commissioner Blanshard extend the Complaint Bureau into all five boroughs? Last year this branch of the Commissioner of Accounts' office handled 6,500 cases, ranging from changes in contracts involving millions of dollars down to a demand for return of false teeth from a court case.

Strength in United States Government bonds again featured the markets, whose actions yesterday were largely a repetition of the dull and colorless movements of the day before. Stocks and commodities drifted lower, following early steadiness as speculators elected to remain aloof in the absence of anything in the day's news grist to prompt much action.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- A resolution barring all former employes of the Federal Communications Commission from appearing before that body until two years after they leave its employ was adopted today by the commission.
WEST POINT, N.Y., May 1. -- Army won from Lehigh on the baseball diamond today in a free-hitting contest, 10 to 7.

Louis S. Posner, member of the State Mortgage Commission, announced last night that the new commission would take over within a few days the underlying mortgages of two of the largest mortgage guarantee companies in the metropolitan district.

Samuel Seabury is sailing tonight on the Cunard White Star liner Majestic for Europe, accompanied by Mrs. Seabury. Also sailing are Arturo Toscanini, the conductor, with his wife; Francis Peabody of Boston, the Countess of Warwick and:

Holders of the 4 1/2 per cent first and refunding mortgage bonds of the Portland (Ore.) General Electric Company, due in 1960, met here yesterday and approved a proposal to modify the mortgage and deed of trust. They would eliminate provisions requiring payment when due of all indebtedness secured by any underlying mortgage or prior lien and prohibit the extension of time of payment of principal or interest of such debt.

The first of the monthly index numbers, published yesterday by Dun's Review, shows an advance during April of 2 1/8 per cent in the price average, but the index number is still slightly below that of March 1. Compared with Jan. 1 the advance has been 1 3/4 per cent; compared with a year ago the rise has been 9 1/4 per cent.

DETROIT, May 1. -- Three more plants closed today, bringing the total number of employes affected by the strike of Chevrolet Motor Company employes at Toledo to about 19,000. At Janesville, Wis., a shortage of transmissions formerly manufactured at Toledo caused the shut-down of the Chevrolet and Fisher body plants, employing about 2,600 persons.
BERLIN, May 1. -- Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler told the world again today that Germany wanted only peace.

United States Government bonds were bid up briskly yesterday on the Stock Exchange as domestic corporation issues and foreign loans moved irregularly. In the heaviest trading since March 7 most issues of the government group closed at net gains of 1-32 to 10-32 point, which lifted eleven issues to new high levels.

Following an attack on various legislative proposals now before Congress by Percival E. Foerderer, chairman of the board, members of the Tanners Council of America, meeting at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday, registered their opposition `to the Wagner Labor Disputes Bill, the Thirty-Hour Week Act and the three pending amendments to the Agricultural Adjustment Act.

MOSCOW, May 1. -- Red Russia turned her May Day celebration today into one great military preparedness demonstration. The old theme of world revolution was drowned out in a clatter of tanks and a roaring of fighting planes in Moscow's Red Square -- and not only in Red Square but in important centres in the Soviet Union's Western and Northern departments, which are regarded as the most threatened in the present European unsettlement.

WOODBURY, N.J., May 1. -- Although local backers of the project are reluctant to discuss the probabilities of construction of a vehicular tunnel beneath the Delaware River, linking South Jersey with Philadelphia, it became known here today that a real estate group, of which some members are associated with the tunnel-planning syndicate, are purchasing options on farms in the neighborhood of the proposed Jersey outlet.

PIMLICO, May 1 (AP). -- Racing in the silks of Mrs. C. Crane of Detroit and capably handled by the veteran, R. Workman, Ladfield, 6-year-old sprinter, accounted for the best offering on the program at Pimlico today. He achieved a hard-earned victory in the Class A Pimlico Graded Handicap.

MARGATE, England, May 1. -Results recorded in the seventh round of the international masters tournament of the Kent County Chess Association today left the three leaders -- Samuel Reshevsky of New York, Jose R. Capablanca of Havana and Sir George Thomas of London -- in the same respective positions they occupied at the close of the sixth.
The New English Dictionary defines a special use of the word "deal ":

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 1. -Guarded approval of the Danish attitude at Geneva when Dr. Peter S. Munch, Danish Foreign Minister, abstained from voting on the League Council's resolution on the German conscription decree was expressed by Rickard J. Sandler, Swedish Foreign Minister, in answering interpellations on Swedish foreign policy in the Riksdag yesterday.

Loew's, Inc., had a net profit of $4,345,337 after expenses, depreciation, taxes and other deductions, according to the statement covering the twenty-eight weeks ended on March 14, which will be released today. This is equivalent, after dividend requirements on the preferred shares, to $2.64 a share on the outstanding common stock.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- Urging the operative agencies of the nation-wide work relief program to make the greatest possible haste with their plans. President Roosevelt today took two steps aimed at making quick use of the $4,000,000,000 fund.

DETROIT, May 1. -- Strikes and shut-downs in eleven automobile parts manufacturing plants in seven cities have affected 19,280 workers, a survey of the situation disclosed tonight. The figures follow:
PHILADELPHIA, May 1. - For the second time this season Columbia defeated Pennsylvania in baseball, the Lions winning on Franklin Field, 6 to 2, today before a chilled crowd of 500 fans.

Joseph W. Wear of Philadelphia will captain the American Davis Cup tennis forces in Europe this year, if the United States succeeds in winning the American zone matches, which are to begin at Mexico City this week-end.

The following table gives the amount of the dealings in the stocks from which the averages are computed, as well as the total dealings in the rails and industrials, and the combined trading in both classes of issues and the number of the latter appearing in the daily and weekly transactions:

The "send-a-dime" chain letter scheme, which flooded the Denver Postoffice with mail last month, has reached New York, it was learned yesterday. The letters have been received by many persons here, and seventy in one big advertising agency are known to have done their bit to keep the chain going by sending out dimes and writing additional letters.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, May 1. -- A case of political kidnapping by German authorities similar to incidents recently occurring in Switzerland and Czechoslovakia took place in the Netherlands a few weeks ago, according to a memorandum to Dr. J.R. deB. Slotemaker, Minister of Foreign Affairs, and Dr. R.J.M. van Schaik, Minister of Justice, today by Mr. Boon, a Liberal member of the lower house.

Most of the city's 36,000 school teachers accepted their April pay check "under protest" yesterday. The move was taken to leave the way open for possible legal action to force restoration of salary cuts under the legislative resolution declaring the financial emergency at an end here.

PARIS, May 1. -- Finance Minister Louis Germain-Martin's report yesterday to the finance commission of the Senate, in which he showed that the budgetary difficulties of France were far from being solved, had an immediate effect today on the Bourse.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- Of the "pre-filibuster" -- it never actually became a real one -- against the Costigan-Wagner bill to federalize all legal action against mob violence it can accurately be said that the debate was conducted on a high plane. Not for years has a Senate discussion been so thoughtful and informing.

ALBANY, May 1. -- Twenty-three bills were vetoed today by Governor Lehman, including one which would have authorized the State Motor Vehicle Commissioner to offer rewards for the apprehension and conviction of hit-and-run drivers.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 1. - Working effectively behind the capable pitching of Ted Horton, Yale's varsity nine defeated Brown, 10 -- 0, today. Brown collected four scattered hits, and only two Bruins reached second base.

The flow of investment money into housing property in this city continued yesterday, several sales of this type being announced. The upper west side provided an outstanding deal, while the bulk of the apartment housing buying centred in the Yorkville area.

In building the jaw and other features of the human face nature knows no such thing as the ideal normal type, Dr. Ales Hrdlicka, curator of physical anthropology of the Smithsonian Institution, told the American Society of Orthodontists yesterday.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):
VATICAN CITY, May 1 (AP). -Prelates said tonight the Vatican might protest to Germany against the alleged treatment of 2,000 young German Catholics as "political suspects."

In the April and May issues of The Forum there are two remarkably interesting articles on science and the "supernatural" by ALDOUS HUXLEY. Whatever may be their scientific value, they are arresting if only because they revealed to how great an extent Mr. HUXLEY, whose name has been used for a decade almost as a symbol of the supposed cynicism of his generation, accepts the authenticity of various psychic phenomena.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- An embittered attack upon the administration's agricultural policy, with spokesmen for the grain, cotton and livestock trades leading the general condemnation, stood out noticeably today in the proceedings of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

Observance of Child Health Week, arranged by the Children's Aid Society, opened yesterday in seven of the centres maintained by the organization. There were lectures, movies, demonstrations, group weighings and a vegetable parade.

Andre L. Simon, president of the British Wine and Food Society and wine editor of the Encyclopaedia Britannica, arrived yesterday from London on the French liner Champlain to spend four weeks in the United States. At the invitation of the newly founded Wine and Food Society in America he will preach the gospel of a more abundant and pleasanter life, of which he is the chief exponent in Europe.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (;P) .Three House Den]oerats announced amendments to the Banking Bill today, Representatives Hancock of North Carolina and Cross and Patman of Texas. Mr. Cross was preparing to call a special meeting of interested members for organization behind his amendment, which would give the Federal Government complete ownership o{ the twelve Federal Reserve Banks now owned by the member banks.

BERLIN, May 1. -- Germany, although swept by intermittent and wholly unseasonable blizzards that at times destroyed all visibility, turned out in countless millions today to celebrate May Day as the day of German labor was converted into the Festival of the Nation.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 1. -- All of the big six among the Kentucky Derby eligibles, except Nellie Flag, had their last heavy work-outs this morning in preparation for the $40,000 added mile and a quarter test to be run Saturday. The filly, which continues to command wide support among Westerners, will be given her final heavy trial tomorrow.

The dollar wisely spent for newspaper advertising is probably the most valuable dollar in American business today, Kenneth M. Goode, advertising counselor of the Biow Company, told THE NEW YORK TIMES advertising class in the Times Annex last evening.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- An agreement to continue in force the provisions of the American commercial treaty of 1925 with Germany, other than those guaranteeing unconditional most-favored-nation tariff treatment, has been offered by Secretary Hull in a note to Hans Luther, German Ambassador.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 1 (AP). -- Mrs. Helen Wills Moody still is noncommittal about her tennis future, but friends of the former world's champion believe she is nearly convinced she will be able to start her comeback in the big Eastern tournaments this Summer.
WASHINGTON, May 1. -- The executive order creating the Resettlement Administration follows:
Sixteen additional companies applied yesterday to the New York Stock Exchange for permanent registration under the Securities Act of 1934. They were:

The British Premiers' meeting in London got around yesterday to certain questions having to do with possible war. The chief object, in fact, of summoning representatives of the dominions to London was to study the problems of the defense of the empire. A note of warning came from Canada and South Africa.

Satisfactory mortgage arrangements were made in connection with the sale yesterday of the twelve-story store and loft building at 208-12 West Thirtieth Street, about 125 feet west of Seventh Avenue. The property was sold by the 212 West Thirtieth Street Corporation to an investing client of Isidore S. Weitzner.
MIAMI, Fla., May 1. -- Assemblies and departmental conferences marked observance of Child Health Day by the national Congress of Parents and Teachers today.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 1. -- Sixty airplanes swooped down at the Municipal Airport here today, bringing more than 50,000 signed American Legion membership cards in the annual aerial round-up of the organization.

Six charitable and public institutions will share the residuary estate of Miss Mary Gardiner Thompson, philanthropist and a member of one of this country's oldest families. This was learned yesterday when her will was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court.

Steel production eased one point to 46 per cent of capacity last week, despite a rise of seven points to 95 per cent at Detroit, according to The Iron Age's review, given out today. Operations declined at Chicago, Youngstown, Cleveland and Buffalo, while elsewhere the rate was substantially unchanged.

Messages were exchanged between the Empire State Building and the highest structures in England and France yesterday at the opening of a telegraph office on the Empire State observation tower by former Governor Alfred E. Smith.

The Chrysler Corporation reported yesterday for the first quarter of 1935 a net profit of $9,163,182 after charges, taxes, depreciation charges and a non-recurring charge of $1,507,525 in connection with the retirement on May 1 of the $30,150,500 debentures of Dodge Brothers, Inc.
A lot of master-minding was introduced by Acting Skipper Art Fletcher of the Yankees yesterday at the stadium in an effort to stretch the winning streak of the Ruppert forces to seven games.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1. -- A discovery that the bodies of mothers contain powerful substances which protect children against such diseases as infantile paralysis, diphtheria, scarlet fever and measles was described here today before the annual session of the American College of Physicians.

James Atwater Trowbridge, retired banker, whose estate tax was disputed by New York and Connecticut, left a gross estate of $9,665,415 and a net of $9,240,521, according to the non-resident transfer tax appraisal filed here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- A new requirement that prospectuses issued in connection with the registration of securities under the Securities Act of 1933, which omit information contained in the registration statement must carry an announcement of that fact, was included in a consolidation of rules and regulations for prospectuses issued by the Securities and Exchange Commission today.

LONDON, May 1. -- The Stock Exchange here was open today for the first time on a May Day in 134 years. Originally the stock brokers used the rotunda of the Bank of England for trading, but this was needed by the bank on May 1 and Nov. 1 when the transfer lists for securities were closed.

Because there were five Sundays in April last year against four last month, the April advertising linage used by New York and Brooklyn department stores declined 1.5 per cent in comparison with 1934. A total of 3,144,997 lines was used last month, against 3,193,930 lines for the same month a year ago.

Your editorial "The Chief Blame" places upon Congress, where it indubitably belongs, the responsibility for the past and threatened future raids on the National Treasury which have disgraced this country in recent years and now threaten its financial stability, but you do not say why nor how the mischief has occurred or could be avoided.

Hearings on the reorganization of Fox Metropolitan Playhouses, Inc., will be delayed at least another week for the presentation of three last-minute offers, two involving cash bids, which were disclosed yesterday before Federal Judge Julian W. Mack in the County Lawyers Association Building, 14 Vesey Street.

One of the largest scores ever compiled by a metropolitan district schoolboy baseball team was recorded as the undefeated Poly Prep nine blanked Trinity School, 26 to 0, yesterday at Poly Prep Field in Brooklyn for its sixth triumph of the season and its second Eastern Private Schools League victory.
Several flats and business buildings were included in the New Jersey realty conveyances reported yesterday.

Acting for the first time in accordance with a recent amendment to its constitution providing for the selection of a nominating committee by the double primary system, the New York Curb Exchange yesterday named thirteen nominees for the first election on May 15.

NEWARK, N.J., May 1. -- Relief given the destitute in New Jersey is not adequate to the very minimum needs," Chester I. Barnard, State director of the Emergency Relief Administration, declared today in a statement made public here.

The four-story brick and granite continuation and vocational high school in St. George, S.I., which was completed at a cost of $1,135,000 more than two years ago, was opened yesterday to 200 girl students. The school was built to care for between 1,600 and 1,800 pupils.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 1. -- Government officials tonight were pressing the investigation of reports linking the New England gang syndicate, uncovered in the raiding of an estate at Warwick, R.I., with outstanding crimes of recent years in the East, and also were investigating a story that the gang had been involved in the disappearance of Joseph F. Crater, Supreme Court Justice of New York, several years ago.

ALBANY, May 1 (AP). -- Mrs. Eva Coo, 46-year-old roadhouse keeper under sentence of death for the insurance slaying of her crippled handyman, Harry Wright, will go to the electric chair in Sing Sing on the night of Thursday, June 27.

With leaders in the city's cultural life urging wider art appreciation as a bulwark of democracy and good citizenship, the National Music League marked its tenth anniversary yesterday at a luncheon at the Hotel Biltmore. The event ushered in a festival week of "Youth in Art and Music" under the auspices of the Municipal Art Committee.

Arturo Toscanini and Otto Klemperer will be the leading conductors of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra next season, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Toscanini will return for a ten-week period and Mr. Klemperer will be in charge for fourteen weeks. Mr. Toscanini remains the general musical director.

VIENNA, May 1. -- On the Ring-strasse here at 3 P.M. today crowds enjoying the May Day holiday promenade were astonished to see a huge swastika banner unrolling from one of the two 350-foot pinnacles of the Votive Church.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- President Roosevelt issued executive orders to carry out the setting up of the work-relief machinery, and conferred with Mayor La Guardia and Langdon W. Post, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, on slum clearance and other New York projects.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- An upturn in retail buying, stimulated by warmer weather, was reported today by the Commerce Department's weekly survey of domestic business, covering thirty-three cities. Wholesale lines were generally quiet, however.

The Chase National Bank, corporate trustee, and M. Ernest Greenebaum Jr., individual trustee, are notifying holders of the Fulnau Corporation first mortgage building and leasehold 6 per cent serial bonds that all the bonds will be redeemed on May 15, including interest on overdue interest and a premium of 3 per cent on the principal amount.

The Artef Players being a workers' group, one would think that when they presented a new play on the night of May Day, as they did yesterday at their Forty-eighth Street home, it would be something in the nature of a bomb. But the toppers need not tremble, for Sholom Aleichem's "Aristocrats," as dramatized by P. Atones, which is the new production in question, is only a delightful popping of firecrackers.

Noel Coward, the English playwright, will make his bow as a screen actor this morning at the Radio City Music Hall in "The Scoundrel." The film formerly bore the title, "Miracle in Forty-ninth Street." It was written, produced and directed by Ben Hecht and Charles MacArthur for release through Paramount.

Bonds called for redemption in April amounted to $38,238,000, compared with $64,150,000 in the preceding month and $91,791,000 in April, 1934. Public utility retirements of $11,040,000, the largest amount for a month since November, led the list of called bonds.

An attempt to draft a more protective measure against imports, tending to disrupt codified industry, as a substitute for the current Section 3a of the National Industrial Recovery Act will be made here this afternoon at a conference at the offices of the National Knitted Outerwear Association, it was announced yesterday.
May greeted New York yesterday morning with a chilly northwest wind that blew as high as thirty-eight miles an hour. It diminished somewhat, however, in the afternoon.

PITTSBURGH, May 1 (AP). -- With only one more day's session remaining in Pittsburgh, Robert H. Jackson, government counsel, put sheaf after sheaf of documents today into the bulging records of the Andrew W. Mellon income tax case, most of them over objections of the financier's counsel, Frank J. Hogan.

GENEVA, May 1. -- Sir Frederick Leith-Ross, chief economic adviser to the British Government, made before the economic committee of the League of Nations today what the members of the gold-bloc countries interpreted as a plea to them to devalue.
ALBANY, May 1. -- Governor Lehman signed today a group of ten bills changing legal procedure.

Fears that other gold-bloc countries might follow Belgium and devalue their currencies caused wide fluctuations in foreign exchanges in April, which resulted in the largest movement of gold to the United States since January. Gold imported here last month totaled $129,279,900, compared with $20,454,800 in March and $53,019,000 in April, 1934.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1. -- Bequests totaling slightly more than $19,000,000 have been received from nearly 23,000 persons since the opening ten years ago of the University of Pennsylvania Fund's fifteen-year campaign for $45,000,000, it was announced tonight by Dr. Thomas S. Gates, president of the university.

VIENNA, May 1. -- A Socialist attempt to sabotage the government's free goulash gesture failed in the face of widespread hunger. The Socialists circulated a slogan, "Rather die than eat [Chancellor Kurt] Schuschnigg's goulash!"

MARLBORO, N.Y., May 1. -- Tony Canzoneri, former lightweight champion of the world, started training today for the bout which he hopes will enable him to be the first boxer in modern ring history to regain the world's 135-pound championship.

The long-awaited test of NIRA in the Supreme Court of the United States is scheduled to begin today. The case is one of the Government's own choosing. It is brought on appeal from a decision of the Federal Circuit Court in New York City, and it will, in Mr. RICHBERG'S words, "test the validity of "the Recovery Act right across the "board."

Price movements of commodity futures continued mixed here yesterday and at no time was there any activity. On the cash markets rye and tin advanced while wheat, corn, oats, lard, eggs, rubber and cotton declined.

CHICAGO, May l. -- Discovery in the Amazon jungle of a colony of "forgotten" people, descendants of aristocratic families of the South, who migrated there after the Civil War, was revealed today by Dr. W.H. Haas, lecturer and Professor of Geology at Northwestern University.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

PRINCETON, N.J., May 1. -- Athletic insignia have been awarded to 159 Princeton varsity and freshman athletes and team managers for participation in Winter sports, it was announced today by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA, San Francisco, May 1. -- Ships of the United States Fleet emerged briefly early this morning from the cloud of secrecy thrown about their operations in the war games when Admiral Harris Laning's Southern detachment steamed into San Francisco Bay.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 1. -- Three hundred men, women and children, grinning, wide-eyed, tremulous, lined the rails of the old army transport St. Mihiel today and said goodbye to the land of their birth.

Frank Flynn, 39-year-old garage manager, accused of having murdered Margaret Parlato, 6 years old, in his apartment at 29-07 Thirty-first Avenue, Astoria, Tuesday afternoon, was charged with first-degree murder yesterday in an indictment handed up at 2 P.M. by the Queens grand jury.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- Despite organized labor's intensive lobbying effort on behalf of its major legislative program, developments today drew a cloud of uncertainty over the future of the Wagner Trades Disputes Bill, the Guffey Coal Stabilization Bill and the Black-Connery thirty-hour proposal.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 1. -- The University of Maryland nine, led at bat by Charley Keller, defeated the Naval Academy, 5 to 2, today. Maryland broke a 1-1 tie in the sixth and clinched the victory with one run in the seventh and two in the eighth.

The Yale Club gave its first "Carnegie Concert" before a special club night assembly last evening in the main lounge of the tall clubhouse at 50 Vanderbilt Avenue. More informal evenings of music are planned every fortnight, it was announced, by virtue of the new music collection presented by the Carnegie Corporation, which has installed similar gifts in seventy American colleges.

George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, announced yesterday that he had sent a letter to all life, fire, marine and casualty companies doing business in the State asking their attitude on the use of arbitration instead of court litigation in settling insurance controversies.

Last Friday your paper carried the story of the seizure of seventy-two copies of a book entitled "November," written by Gustave Flaubert, from The Volume Guild by John S. Sumner, secretary of the Society for the Suppression of Vice. I am the victim upon whom the humiliation was directed, and being an admirer of the genius of Flaubert would like to bring to light certain elements in the case that call for some comment.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 1. -- The Duke University nine collected eleven hits and as many walks from a trio of Princeton hurlers today to win the first game of its annual Northern trip, 13 to 0.

THE thirty-seventh chapter of Genesis, telling the story of the sale of Joseph, son of Jacob and Rachel, to the Midianites, takes up about two small columns of print. Thomas Mann, in his "Young Joseph" (Knopf, $2.50), which is the second volume in the trilogy of "Joseph and His Brothers," elaborates the spare original into a novel of some 300 pages.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- Members of the fur manufacturing industry would be required to furnish reports on wages, hours, conditions of employment and number of employes when requested by the Code Authority or the National Industrial Recovery Board, under an amendment submitted today by the Code Authority for the industry.

Real estate tax collections for the first half of the current year, not including payments received yesterday by mail, totaled $174,329,882.96, as compared with $166,069,418.99 for the corresponding date in 1934, Controller Frank J. Taylor announced.

LONDON, May 1. -- A force of 14,000 troops and 12,000 police will line the route of the King's Jubilee procession to the thanksgiving service at St. Paul's on Monday, it was announced today after King George approved the final miltary arrangements.

TOKYO, Thursday May 2. -- The thirty-three-foot ketch, Flying Dutchman was reported in a dispatch today to the Rengo News Agency from Taihoku, Formosa, to have been detained, while three members of its personnel, including an American described as a retired United States naval lieutenant, were held on suspicion of espionage.

Reports of brighter prospects for the plumbing trade and a warning against relaxing standards of work were given to members of the New York State Association of Master Plumbers at the closing sessions of their forty-seventh annual convention yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Mayor La Guardia rebuked former Police Commissioner John F. O'Ryan and former City Magistrate Benjamin Greenspan yesterday when he swore in Nathan D. Perlman at City Hall to succeed Magistrate Greenspan and reappointed Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 1. -- Governor Lehman signed today the legislation amending the racing law which was put through under an agreement among the Jockey Club, the State Racing Commission and Democratic Senate Leader John J. Dunnigan.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- "Unless a miracle intervenes" an open break between organized business and industry, as represented by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, and President Roosevelt, is expected tomorrow with the adoption of critical resolutions at the closing session of the chamber's annual convention.
