" Your readers may be interested to know that the ice is just beginning to go out of the lakes in the Southern Adirondacks, which means that lake trout fishing will now be in vogue," writes Mortimer Norton from Piseco, N.Y.

The life and career of Dr. John L. Elliott, headworker of Hudson Guild, settlement house in the Chelsea district, was praised last night by many speakers at the fortieth anniversary dinner of the guild held at the Hotel Astor.

The Hobby Round-Up formally opened at 8:35 o'clock last night at the Port Authority Building, Fifteenth Street and Eighth Avenue. Symbolizing its motif, a series of cardboard disks, with an hourglass painted in red and blue upon each, trimmed the ceiling above the two acres of hobbies.

Holding St. Francis to two singles, Joe Nahem hurled Brooklyn College to victory, 10 to 0, at Manhattan Beach yesterday. Sam Nahem, older brother of Joe, drove a homer and double that accounted for four runs.

Stirred by disclosures that many relief job-holders are non-residents of the city, the Board of Estimate met yesterday in committee of the whole and voted favorable consideration of a bill imposing a six-months' residence requirement on all relief clients and a twelve-months' requirement on those holding "non-relief" jobs.

Fordham and City College had their own May Day parade at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday. It was a parade of walking batsmen. The high total of twenty-one men reached first base on passes issued by four generous pitchers whose only common trait was an uncontrollable wildness.

In response to protests made by many artists and art organizations in the city to the National Academy of Design about the reported plan of the city to tax those who teach the fine arts, music and drama for profit, Jonas Lie, president of the academy, announced last night that he had received assurance from Mayor La Guardia that such a law would not be enacted.

ALBANY, May 1. -- Governor Lehman vetoed today the Porter bill which would authorize the Whiteface Mountain Highway Commission to issue $1,000,000 in bonds to provide additional improvements, including a new trail and a tunnel to the centre of the mountain and an elevator shaft from the centre to the top.

HACKENSACK, N.J., May 1. -Nicholas M. Schenck, motion picture executive and one of the former owners of the Palisades Amusement Park, regained control of the Fort Lee property with a bid of $150,000 at a Sheriff's sale this afternoon in the Court House.

May I again bring to public attention the repeatedly expressed and frequently published appeal of the Commissioner of Motor Vehicles for the cooperation of all applicants for licenses to operate motor vehicles in order that every possible means available may be employed in our constant effort to eliminate an alleged condition occasionally made the subject of letters to newspapers?

TRENTON, May 1. -- Governor Hoffman, Senate Majority Leader John C. Barbour and the Rev. Lester H. Clee, Speaker of the Assembly, agreed in conference today on ways by which $9,987,000 could be made available for emergency relief, but did not decide how to provide the balance of the $20,000,000 that will be needed before Dec. 31.

Perhaps some of your readers who have wondered about the War Department's great military manoeuvres and provision for a powerful air base on the Canadian frontier would find an interesting contrast in the historic comedy of the fort at Rouses Point later known as Fort Montgomery.

LONDON, May 1. -- The Cabinet approved today the statement on British policy with which Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald will open tomorrow's eagerly awaited debate on foreign affairs in the House of Commons.

Professor Jacques Brettmon, University of Paris radiologist, who has reported killing a mouse by a "death ray," arrived yesterday on the French liner Champlain. He said that use of the ray in warfare was still in the imaginary stage.
Properties in Manhattan and the Bronx offered for bidding by auctioneers yesterday were bought in by the plaintiffs in the foreclosure proceedings.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- Worn down by six days of debate, conducted almost wholly on constitutional grounds, and facing the warning that the speech-making would continue indefinitely, the Senate today surrendered to the anti-lynching-bill filibuster and proceeded to the consideration of the more pressing veterans' bonus.

Among the chief beneficiaries of economic security legislation now before the Senate will be the children of the United States, Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, said last night in an address at the Park Lane Hotel. She addressed a dinner celebrating the fortieth anniversary of the founding of Union Settlement, which is at 237 East 104th Street.

Dividends declared in April were smaller in amount than a year ago, principally because of substantial decreases in payments ordered by oil and public utility companies. The total of $139,366,332 for 705 corporations compared with $175,667,316 for 627 companies in April, 1934.

The third opera ball in behalf of the maintenance fund of the Metropolitan Opera Association will be held tonight at the Metropolitan Opera House. Society and the musical world have combined forces for several weeks preparing for the event, which is expected to be fully as glamourous and financially successful as its two predecessors, which were important factors in assuring seasons of Metropolitan opera during the last two years.

ABOARD S.S. NORTH HAVEN, Way 1 (By Wireless). -- The Pan American Airways expedition, which for the last two weeks has brought more turmoil to lonesome Midway Island than ever before in its centuries of existence, has folded up its tents like the Arabs and noisily started across the sea.

The first of May was celebrated as a "Day of National Labor" by 3,000 Germans who filled the Yorkville Casino, 210 East Eighty-sixth Street, to capacity last night. Floors and balconies were blocked by the audience and the police were forced to close the doors half an hour before the meeting began.

New security flotations here in April amounted to $465,408,100, the largest volume for a month since March, 1931. They reflected in part the widespread movement of corporations to refund bond issues. They consisted of forty-five bond issues marketed at $460,408,000, and one stock issue of a face value of $5,000,000.

Amos Kubik remained in deep seclusion all day yesterday in his room at the Hotel Commodore. Only when it was good and dark did the 66-year-old town crier of Provincetown, Mass., entrust his Pilgrim Father costume, large buckled shoes and dinner bell to the rowdy, revolutionary May Day air.

While lecturing to an audience of 150 physicians, including his two sons, Dr. Joseph Henschel, an authority on physical therapy and president of the Bronx Borough Medical Society, fell dead at 10:35 o'clock last night in the Academy of Medicine, 2 East 103d Street, at the corner of Fifth Avenue.
CLEVELAND, May 1 (AP). -- The Cleveland Indians strengthened their grasp on first place in the American League today by conquering the Chicago White Sox, 11 to 5.

ADOLF HITLER'S May Day speech was in effect an answer to a severe indictment. By the Allies at Paris and the Council of the League at Geneva he had been charged with violation of treaties and with stirring up fear and destroying confidence throughout Europe.

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 1. -- Another search of the salt meadows along the Elizabeth River and the Newark meadows, between this city and Port Newark, by police, firemen and volunteers failed today to yield any trace of the three Elizabeth boys missing since last Friday.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- The President's expressed wishes were overridden in the Senate Finance Committee today when, by the overwhelming Vote of 16 to 4, it approved a resolution continuing the National Industrial Recovery Act in an amended form from its expiration on June 16 only until April 1, 1936.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., May 1. -- A hearing on charges against society, based on an indictment drawn up by members of twenty-seven youth groups of the Oranges and Maplewood, was conducted here tonight in the Maplewood Junior High School.

LONDON, May 1. -- For the first time in British history an official tribunal sat in judgment today on the future of the privately owned armaments industry and only a handful of spectators thought it worth while to be present.

The Downtown Glee Club held its Spring concert in Carnegie Hall last evening, conducted by Channing Lefebvre and greeted by an audience of those who had followed the artistic advance of a chorus of Wall Street men for the last nine years.

A light-weight, streamlined, standard-sized, steam-driven train is about to be subjected to tests on the Alton, a subsidiary of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, Daniel Willard, president of both companies, said yesterday. This train, made of a new alloy of steel, is soon to be duplicated with one made of aluminum.

Although the Forty-second Street spur of the Manhattan elevated was demolished long ago, it keeps cropping up in the news as one court after another is asked to pass on the propriety of the award made at the time the property was condemned. It was not a simple case.

With an advance appropriation based on an expectation of a 100,000 sale, George Michael's newly announced book, "Handout," will be published next week by Putnams. It is expected that "all the elements disaffected with the present administration in Washington will seize on this book."

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 1. -- A Derby dinner dance will be given tomorrow night in the Colonnades at the Greenbrier in honor of guests of the hotel, who will depart later on the George Washington for Churchill Downs to witness the running of the Kentucky Derby.

Richard A. McGee, former educational supervisor of the Northeastern penitentiary, the Federal prison at Lewisburg, Pa., was sworn in yesterday morning as warden of the city's new penitentiary on Rikers Island. He took over his new duties directly after he took the oath before Correction Commissioner Austin H. MacCormick.
PARIS, May 1. -- Once again while pens were almost literally poised to sign the Franco-Soviet pact of mutual assistance the event has been postponed.

OTTAWA, May 1. -- No one in Canada believed that the United States Government had any intention of departing from the traditional "good neighbor" attitude maintained between the two countries for generations, Sir George Perley, the Acting Prime Minister, stated today.

Aroused by the steady increase in the sale of drugs through other than legitimate drug store channels throughout the country, members of the Drug Institute of America, Inc., meeting here yesterday at the Hotel Lincoln, decided to place the matter squarely up to manufacturers and wholesalers in an effort to stabilize distribution in the industry.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- An application for $150,000,000 of work relief funds to finance a one-year housing program in New York City was laid on President Roosevelt's desk today by Langdon W. Post, Tenement House Commissioner and chairman of the Housing Authority of New York City.

ON BOARD THE U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA, San Francisco, May 2 -- Forty warships under command of Admiral Harris Laning were ready tonight for instant departure, while another strong, fast-striking force of the United States fleet moved into Puget Sound during the night, under command of Vice Admiral Arthur J. Hepburn.

Dr. Thomas Parran Jr., Commissioner of Health of the State of New York, who delivered the 1935 Hermann M. Briggs Memorial Lecture last night in the New York Academy of Medicine, 2 East 103d Street, stressed the need for better system in State medical expenditures and services.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Within a week after President Roosevelt's unqualified insistence upon passage at this session of his program of reform legislation, organized business, through the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, came out vigorously today in opposition to his proposals.
WASHINGTON, May 2. -- A summary of the resolutions of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States follows:
As a regular reader of THE TIMES I want to express my personal appreciation for the calm, poised attitude conveyed in Mr. Noyes's Monday reviews.
ALBANY, May 2. -- Governor Lehman signed twenty-five bills today, including measures modifying the law on alimony payments and expediting court rulings on primary contests.

Frederick Brown, operator, has resold a taxpayer with fourteen stores adjoining the southeast corner of Main Street and Roosevelt Avenue, Flushing, to Joseph P. Ryan. The parcel, assessed at $452,000, fronts 145 feet on the avenue and 75 feet on the street, with an area of about 43,000 square feet.
j Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

PHILADELPHIA, May 2. -- America's primary plan of campaign for the coming Davis Cup tennis wars, as emphasized by the newly appointed pilot of the United States squad, is laid along the lines that overtraining is fatal.

PARIS, May 2. -- The Bourse continued yesterday's trend in the first half of the session today, with rentes falling and equities rising. Later, however, a complete reversal took place and rentes returned to their previous level, while industrials lost most although not quite all of their gains. Activity was reduced to a minimum with only speculators in the market.

MANILA, Friday, May 3. -- At least sixty persons have already been killed and 100 wounded in disorganized radical uprisings in five Philippine provinces today. The original plan was apparently carefully conceived, but it fell apart because of lack of leadership.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- With Democratic leaders busily studying political drifts and the President holding a series of conferences on the general situation, the party chieftains are now confident that the administration is not losing ground.

MARGATE, England, May 2. -- With one more round to be contested tomorrow, Samuel Reshevsky of New York and Jose R. Capablanca of Havana, still half a point apart, continue to show the way to the other eight competitors in the international masters tournament of the Kent County Chess Association, the eighth and semi-final round of which was contested today.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 2 (AP). -- The Buffalo Bisons defeated the Albany Senators by 7 to 5 today in the opening game at home despite two home runs by Hack Wilson and another by Frank Packard. Cold weather held the attendance to about 7,500.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 2 (AP). -- The empire of crime which investigators charge Carl Rettich ruled from his Warwick stronghold continued to crumble today as his bonds were tightened and additional plunder was brought to light.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 2. -- One of the first offerings of common stock under the Securities Exchange Act to finance an industrial concern will be made by the Glidden Company, it became known today when Adrian D. Joyce, president, confirmed reports that the company was filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission an application for registration of additional common stock.

LONDON, May 2. -- Mary Ellis is co-starred with Ivor Novello in the latter's spectacular twenty-scene musical play, "Glamorous Night," at the Drury Lane tonight. She has a colorful role affording full scope to her histrionic and musical talents.

The waters of Bimini provided the setting recently for one of the strangest episodes in the annals of big-game fishing -- a battle with a huge marlin that ended in a dramatic, almost fantastic, fashion.

Seventy-six visitors from Ireland stepped ashore into West Twentieth Street at noon yesterday when the United States liner Washington arrived from European ports. Most of the group, said to be the largest contingent of tourists from the Emerald Isle ever to visit America, drove to the Hotel Wellington.

Brown Harriman Co., Inc.; Edward B. Smith Co., the First Boston Corporation, Kidder, Peabody Co. and the Lee Higginson Corporation will offer today at par and interest to date of delivery $12,000,000 of Atlantic Coast Line Railroad ten-year collateral trust 5 per cent notes due in 1945.

A Bensonhurst building operation will be undertaken as the result of the sale of a plot 115 by 200 feet at Cropsey and Sixteenth Avenues by the Powell Real Estate Company, as broker, for Arthur W. Butz. The purchaser will improve the property with one-family houses containing six rooms and occupying a plot 40 by 100 feet.

A decline of 0.2 points to 126.7 in i The Annalist Weekly Index of Wholesale Commodity Prices in the week ended on Tuesday was attributed chiefly to a reaction in the prices for livestock, meats, hides land anthracite.

LONDON, May 2. -- Floodlighting for the King's Jubilee is to cost $1,000,000; Regent Street traders are spending nearly $50,000 for flowers and other decorations; four barrels of free beer for dancers in the streets have been provided by an anonymous donor at Bishops Waltham, Hampshire.

The State of South Dakota announced yesterday a new issue of $3,000,000 of rural credit bonds for award on May 15. The issue will be dated May 1, 1935, and will mature serially from 1943 to 1950. Bidders are asked to stipulate the rate of interest at not to exceed 4 1/2 per cent.

The Bank of the Manhattan Company sold the five-and-a-half-story apartment house at 61-73 Elwood Street through Nehring Brothers, brokers. The house is on a plot 150 by 100 feet and contains 214 rooms. It is assessed for $210,000. The buyer was represented by Curtis Johnson and Leonard J. Beck.
WARSAW, May 2. -The devaluation of the Danzig gulden and the reduction of its gold content to the zloty's are regarded here as a desperate move to save the Free City from financial ruin.
Purchase of an industrial plant in Hudson Boulevard, Bayonne, for expansion of a laundry moving from Jersey City featured the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 2 (AP). -- Fifty-eight cars were entered officially today in the 500-mile automobile race May 30. Entries closed last midnight. Mails from the East and West Coasts are expected to bring a few more nominations. The thirty-three fastest will start.

The Tide Water Associated Oil Company expects to pay off this year the dividends accumulated on its preferred stock and aims to resume common dividends as soon as practicable, William F. Humphrey, president, told stockholders yesterday.

Public offering will be made today of $6,000,000 of serial debentures and $7,500,000 of twelve-year 4 per cent convertible debentures of the Union Oil Company of California by a banking group comprising Dillon, Read Co., the William R. Staats Company, Blyth Co., Inc.; Dean Witter Co., the Pacific Company of California and the Bancamerica-Blair Corporation, which has underwritten the two issues.

Prices on the commodity futures markets here were generally easier yesterday. The volume of trading was moderately heavy. In the cash markets only rye was higher. Wheat, corn, oats, flour, cocoa, butter, tin, silk and rubber were lower.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- A strong drive for the inflationary $2,100, 000,000 Patman Bill was started in the Senate today as debate on the issue of prepayment of the soldiers' bonus was begun with this measure sharing a three-cornered front with the $2,660,000,000 Harrison compromise and the American Legion sponsored Vinson Bill, naming no specific sum.

Seventy-three Classes will be judged during the five days of the fifteenth annual Newark Horse Show, which will open this evening in the Essex Troop Armory, Roseville Avenue, Newark, to continue through Tuesday evening. The evening sessions will begin at 7:15 o'clock and a matinee has been arranged for tomorrow afternoon beginning at 1:30 o'clock.
A mass meeting of the Friends of the New Germany was held last night in the Hippodrome for the declared purpose of registering their approval of the rearmament of the Reich.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Charges that a "minority group with selfish political and business interests" were attempting to use the Chamber of Commerce of the United States as a "catspaw" to defeat administration plans for NRA extension were voiced today in a telegram to Henry I. Harriman, its outgoing president, by Peter Van Horn, head of the National Federation of Textiles, Inc.

Frank A. Vanderlip said last night that a "reign of terror exists among the bankers" and that none of them dared to speak out against the Eccles bill now pending before Congress. He spoke before more than 350 New York University School of Commerce alumni at a reunion dinner in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

LONDON, May 2. -- Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald today answered Germany's rearmament in the air by announcing that his government was "already taking steps for further and accelerated expansion of the British Air Force."
LONDON, May 2. -- Following is the text of the address of Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald on armaments before the House of Commons today:
An exhibition of home cooking, Italian style, won praise for 14-year-old Angelo Sferrazza, the Brillat-Savarin of the Madison Square Boys Club at 312 East Thirtieth Street.

The collection of rare books, manuscripts and autographs valued at $500,000 which Thomas B. Lockwood of Buffalo has given the University of Buffalo will place that institution near the leaders in the country in the ownership of rare volumes of English and American literature, according to estimates in book circles here yesterday.

The new novel by Virginia Woolf, which tentatively was announced for publication in the Fall by Harcourt, Brace, will be held over until next Spring. There is some possibility that it may be serialized in a magazine before book publication. No title has been selected.

DETROIT, May 2. -- A strike of a few hundred men in Toledo may paralyze the manufacturing and sales organization of the Chevrolet Motor Company, and even of all the other units of the General Motors Corporation, or the settlement for which Federal and other officials are working may end it all in a peaceful return to normality in the industrial Ohio city.

KARL MARX was born May 5, 1818. This is his month, though its name, derived from that of the mother of the god of merchandise, seems inauspicious. In 1889 the Paris Congress of the Second Socialist International chose May 1 as the date of international labor celebrations, with the purpose of making a holiday of it no matter upon what day of the week it came.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 2. -- There was a large attendance tonight at the Derby dance in the Colonnades at the Greenbrier, many of the guests later leaving on the George Washington for Churchill Downs to see the running of the Kentucky Derby on Saturday.

CHICAGO, May 2. -- Bearish sentiment in the wheat trade was increased today on the Board of Trade by rains over parts of the Winter wheat belt and in the northwest. Weakness in silver also induced scattered liquidation by the East, and at the inside prices were off as much as 13/4 cents from yesterday's finish.

In memory of the late William H. Brennan, the manager of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, who died last week, the orchestra will play Richard Strauss's "Also Sprach Zarathustra" today and tomorrow in the season's final program. The Strauss tone poem was one of Mr. Brennan's favorite compositions.

Four new films will be shown in the Times Square sector this morning. They are the new Marlene Dietrich picture. "The Devil is a Woman," opening at the Paramount; "Laddie," adapted from Gene Stratton-Porter's novel and featuring John Beal and Gloria Stuart, at the Roxy, and "Great God Gold," with Sidney Blackmer, and "Million Dollar Baby," with Judith Allen, the twin bill at the Criterion.
The story of relief case No. 2,796, and a battle against odds that dwarf anything James J. Braddock will face in a prize ring June 13 against Heavyweight Champion Max Baer, was revealed yesterday.

ON BOARD U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA, San Francisco, May 2. -- Sailors strolled through Chinatown and Market Street was crowded with bluejackets tonight as the men of the fleet celebrated their last liberty before the ships steam westward tomorrow to fight a far-flung mimic war.

BERLIN, May 2. -- Air Minister Hermann Wilhelm Goering in an amazingly frank address before the Foreign Press Association today mapped out the secret process by which the Reich, defying the Versailles treaty, had secretly rearmed in the air.
LONDON, May 2 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

PIMLICO, Md., May 2 (AP). -- Racing in the silks of Charles S. Bancroft, Dokas, 3-year-old chestnut son of Dozer, made a show of the opposition he encountered in the Druid Hill Purse, stellar attraction at the Pimlico course today.

ORANGE, N.J., May 2. -- "Society'' was found "guilty" of employing its workers at starvation wages and of five other less serious abuses tonight by the "jury" at the end of the three-day "trial" of accusations brought by thirty-five local youth groups against their environment.

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 2. -- The bodies of Frank Truggiano, 7 years old, of 400 Palmer Street and Charles Arnone, also 7, of 550 Fourth Avenue, two of the three Elizabeth boys who disappeared last Friday, were found this afternoon in the Elizabeth River near the Baltic Street Bridge. Police continued the search for the third boy, Mario Truggiano, 6.

In a luxurious setting reflecting the benign atmosphere of plantation days in the "deep South" of the pre-Civil War era, the third Opera Ball was held last night in the Metropolitan Opera House in behalf of the Metropolitan Opera Association.

GENEVA, May 2. -- The opening discussion of the League of Nations anti-terrorist committee have left the French with little hope for the international penal court whose establishment they proposed in their memorandum to the Council on Dec. 9, 1934, when it dealt with the assassination of King Alexander of Yugoslavia.

The danger of regarding social action as a substitute for religion instead of an expression of it was stressed by the Rev. Dr. Lynn Harold Hough, dean of Drew Theological Seminary, in an address yesterday at the opening session of the New York Annual Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church.

A study is being made of the administration, scientific and professional activities and the finances of the Neurological Institute, of which Floyd B. Odlum, president of the Atlas Corporation, has been elected president of the board of trustees, it was announced yesterday.

HANOVER, N.H., May 2. -- Dartmouth's annual Green Key Prom, the social highlight of the Spring season, will open tomorrow with more than 700 feminine guests expected in Hanover for a round of week-end festivities.

The secret of President Roosevelt's admittedly great power to sway audiences by speech, both in public and in radio appearances, lies in the fact that his jaw and his face are "built for sound," Elizabeth McDowell, Associate Professor of Speech of Columbia University, told the American Society of Orthodontists yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- The index of wholesale commodity prices remained unchanged at 80.3 in the week ending April 27, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. This compared with 73.5 for the corresponding week of 1934. Although the composite index was stationary, eight of the ten major groups which go to make it up registered fractional increases, with farm products and textiles showing the only decreases.
Former Magistrate Benjamin Greenspan asked Mayor La Guardia yesterday to "clarify further the many unfair innuendoes accredited to you concerning myself."

Barney Ross, who surrendered the lightweight championship of the world to make a second bid for the welterweight crown, will arrive in New York today. The Chicago battler will be accompanied by his managers, Sam Plan and Art Winch, and will remain in town until tomorrow.

Three abstractionists, two of them American and one French, are having exhibitions. The native painters are Arthur Dove, whose annual one-man show will continue until May 27 at Mr. Stieglitz's An American Place, 509 Madison Avenue, and Charles G. Shaw, whose work A.E. Gallatin has placed on view for the Summer at the Gallery of Living Art in New York University.

MOSCOW, May 2. -- The news that the Franco-Soviet mutual assistance pact had been signed reached Moscow late tonight. It caused considerable surprise, for only the initialing and not the actual signing had been expected so early.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- House leaders allowed members to talk as much as they wished today on the Administration Banking Bill before the amending stage is reached. So the measure was denounced from various quarters as "sugary water," as one that would "undermine the nation's credit" and "an international bankers' bill."

WASHINGTON. May 2. -- Striking at fraudulent practices in sale to the public of oil and gas royalty interests by unscrupulous dealers, the Securities and Exchange Commission promulgated new regulations today. Those seeking exemption from registration of offerings not exceeding $100.000 in the aggregate must file comprehensive information with the commission and also give it to the prospective investor prior to the conclusion of any contract of sale.

Commitments to New York State reformatories and prisons of boys and girls between the ages of 16 and 21 show a startling increase since 1928, Dr. John Slawson, executive director of the Jewish Board of Guardians, reported at the annual meeting of the board last night at the home of Adolph Lewisohn, 881 Fifth Avenue.
ConditJon in the money market >hewed no change either in the matter of business, which remained small, or quotations, which were steady.

CHICAGO, May 2. -- Hogs were as much as 10 cents a hundredweight higher in the early trading here today, but reports of a slowing up in the demand for fresh pork and a decline of as much as 1/2 cent a pound for loins in the local market resulted in an easy close.

Behind the capable pitching of Ken Weafer and a barrage of hits, the Duke University baseball team conquered Fordham by 10 to 4 yesterday at Fordham Field, successfully continuing its Northern invasion. On Wednesday the Blue Devils from Durham, N.C., beat Princeton, 13 to 0.

Many of the recent newspaper dispatches from Washington with reference to the soldiers' bonus have stated that the leaders of the veterans' organizations will not accept the compromise proposal of Senator Harrison and will insist upon the passage of either the Patman or the Vinson bill.

The Actors' Forum, the insurgent group within the Actors' Equity Association, has returned to the fight which it lost in March when it failed to elect candidates to the committee which nominates one-fifth of Equity's council.

Oparations of the Shell Union Oil Corporation and subsidiaries, including the Shell Pipe Line Corporation, in the quarter ended on March 31 resulted in a net loss of $1,121,040 after expenses, depreciation, depletion, amortization, abandonments, intangible development costs, interest and provision for Federal income tax.

Papers were filed yesterday with Public Administrator James F. Egan of New York County laying claim to the late Czar's estate here in behalf of a petitioner who signed herself "Grand Duchess Anastasia Nikolaevna of Russia." The papers, in which she proclaimed herself the Czar's daughter, were presented by Edward H. Fallows, an attorney, and bore yesterday's date.

Nothing has revealed so dramatically the extent of the reversal of public opinion on the NRA as the overwhelming vote of the Senate Finance Committee refusing to extend the life of the present Recovery Act for more than ten months, and reducing even the extended act, by the provisions eliminating price-fixing and intrastate control, to a shell of its former self.

The special contract which the New York Edison Company has with the New York Central Railroad for the supply of current would not be affected by the proposed ban on submetering, according to testimony presented yesterday before the Public Service Commission.
Three marvels of modern electrical science were demonstrated to the audience of The American Institute last night at a meeting in the auditorium of the American Museum of Natural History.

Four prominent Republicans, representatives of their party in the East, the Midwest and the Far West, launched a concerted attack last night on the Roosevelt New Deal at a meeting held by the Republican County Committee at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

Lewis W. Douglas, who resigned last September as President Roosevelt's budget director, declared here yesterday at the Bankers Club that government interference was threatening the existence of the capitalistic system.
WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Some of the major resolutions on public policy adopted today by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States were as follows; textually:

OTTAWA, Ont., May 2 (Canadian Press). -- A sharp increase in Dominion Government deposits, small increases in chartered bank and other deposits and a decrease in the volume of notes in circulation were shown in the weekly statement of the Bank of Canada, issued today.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company is considering means to reduce its interest burden of about $50,000,000 annually, it was said yesterday at the office of the company. News of the development caused an advance of nearly 2 points in the company's stock on the Stock Exchange.
HUDSON, N.Y., May 2 (AP). -- M. William Herbs, Hudson City Treasurer, who disappeared April 15, was brought back under arrest today, charged with misappropriating a small amount of city funds.

Re-elected as president of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York at the 167th annual meeting yesterday, Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, pledged himself to fight more strongly against "unsound" governmental policies affecting business, and for "sound" currency, banking and business fundamentals.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Senator Clark has struck the NRA between wind and water with his ten-month extension resolution, and only the President can save the ship from going down. To save it will require a combination of force and luck, with the time element a vital factor, for the rescue must have failed or succeeded by June 16.

At a service attended by more than 800 persons in the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street, last night, 240 clergymen, both Jewish and Christian, pledged themselves to renounce war. At the invitation of the Rev. Dr. Allan Knight Chalmers, pastor of the Broadway Tabernacle Congregational Church, the audience stood with them as a gesture of agreement as they repeated the following words of their "Covenant of Peace".

The City Park Department and the State Conservation Department have opened a drive against a serious infestation of gypsy moths in the Bronx, it became known yesterday. On some trees in the blighted area, which has been confined thus far to the eastern part of the borough, as many as 1,000 egg masses are said to have been found.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Allotments to States totaling $81,883,125 to care for the jobless during May were announced today by Harry L. Hopkins, Relief Administrator. While those allotments were $31,778,259 below the $113,661,384 granted for April, seven States, including New York, were not on today's list.

MIAMI, Fla., May 2. -- American colleges are teaching forty years behind the times instead of trying to teach at least ten years ahead," B.H. Darrow of Columbus, Ohio, chairman of radio for the National Congress of Parents and Teachers, declared in a conference at the annual convention of the body today.

Gorgeous costumes were worn last night at the Opera Ball, not only by the participants in the pageant but by many of the guests who took advantage of the opportunity to "dress up" in the habiliments -- hoop skirts, pantalettes and other furbelows -- of ante-bellum days.

OTTAWA, May 2. -- Statistics of Canadian trade for the fiscal year just ended indicate that, despite the Ottawa agreements and tariffs which are now under discussion in Washington, the United States has practically regained its old place as Canada's chief supplier and second-best customer.

VATICAN CITY, May 2. -- Eugenio Cardinal Pacelli, the Papal Secretary of State, on his return today from Lourdes, where he represented Pope Pius at the closing of the international jubilee for the nineteenth centenary of the Redemption, was immediately received by the Pontiff, with whom he discussed the recent anti-Catholic manifestations in Germany.

Governor LEHMAN'S veto of the latest Whiteface Mountain Bill is rooted in sound conservation and common sense. Last year the commission which is building a memorial highway to the top of the mountain sought legislative authority to improve on nature by erecting a tall tower on the summit.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 2. -- James (Little Caesar) Lyons, rookie southpaw, pitched the Rochester Red Wings to a 5-to-0 victory over the Newark Bears in the local inaugural today. It was the Bears' first shut-out defeat of the season.

The New Bedford Gas and Edison Light Company, which is part of the Associated Gas and Electric system, reduced bank loans from $1,035,000 to $930,000 in 1934 and to $755,000 on April 10, according to the report for 1934 issued yesterday by Oliver Prescott, chairman, and David W. Beaman, president.

Before the aldermanic committee yesterday the Commissioner of Purchases, Mr. FORBES, testified that in the city's relief work the overhead about equaled the cost of supplies bought and distributed. He said that "paper work" was the chief cause of the high incidental expense. He blamed no one.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- A pledge of House leaders to stand by President Roosevelt in his planning for the future of the NRA followed quickly today the action of the Senate Finance Committee yesterday in overriding his wishes by reporting the Clark Resolution, extending the Recovery Act until April 1, 1936.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- The largest new money bond financing registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission since the new form for seasoned corporations was adopted in January was filed today by the National Distillers Products Corporation, seeking to issue $15,000,000 of ten-year 4 1/2 per cent debentures.
Yesterday's statement for the twelve reserve banks again raised the system's gold holdings above all previous records.

MANILA, Friday, May 3. -- Captain Jose Guido of the Constabulary Intelligence reported to the Governor General's office today that the revolt situation was "very grave." He suggested that Acting Governor General Joseph R. Hayden dash back to Manila at once by airplane from Mountain Province, in Northern Luzon, where he has been on an inspection tour.

CHICAGO, May 2 (AP). -- A young writer who termed himself a "fiend" and confessed to authorities that he was the phantom firebug responsible for a series of incendiary fires faced possible murder charges tonight.

The applied and clinical phases of dietetics and their importance to the welfare of the nation generally were discussed by authorities in this field yesterday at the opening session of the annual convention of the New York State Dietetic Association at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Dean Virginia C. Gildcrsleeve of Barnard College declared yesterday that "women are being forced back to the kitchen," not only as a result of the depression but because public sentiment is opposed to the idea of women working in men's jobs.

Resolutions adopted yesterday by the United States Chamber of Commerce are interpreted by some as a definite "break" with the President. Not necessarily. The Chamber does break with some of the policies and measures which he is supposed to favor. It is against the bills dealing with utilities and banks and labor and soldiers' pensions.

RYE, N.Y., May 2. -- Following their golfing colleagues of Long Island by a day, the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Association inaugurated the tournament season today at the Westchester Country Club.

The strike of seven employes of The American Mercury continued yesterday after Lawrence A. Spivak, the publisher, had agreed to receive a committee of the strikers, but later changed his mind when the committee appeared together with a representative of the Office Workers Union, with which the strikers are affiliated.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 2. -- The development of Atlantic City into a spa on a par with others internationally known was visioned here today with the announced discovery of a stratum of mud which is believed to possess highly curative powers.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Tribute to the "vision and courage" of Miss Jane Addams, founder of Hull House, Nobel Prize winner and "crusader for public welfare and world peace," was paid tonight by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, Secretary Ickes and others at an "anniversary dinner" held in the social worker's honor and attended by more than 1,200 men and women, including diplomats, high officials and others from all parts of the country.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- By adopting a modified rule dealing with the information which must be included in advertisements in newspapers and periodicals by issuers using the new form A2 in registering securities, the Securities and Exchange Commission today sought to open the way for resumption of this type of financial advertising.

A claim to the estate of Georgiana G.R. Wendel, sister of the late Ella V. Von E. Wendel, was filed yesterday in Surrogate's Court by Mrs. Meta Wendel Strauch of 29 Vahrenstrasse, Bremen, Germany, who asserts that she is the child of Georgians Wendel and an unnamed German naval officer.

The trading pace in the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange was greatly diminished yesterday, chiefly because of the lighter dealings in United States Government bonds. Prices, for the most part, showed minor irregularities. Government issues closed 4-32 point lower to 1-32 higher, with business light in the First Liberty Loan bonds, as the time for exchanging them for 1 5/8 per cent notes expired yesterday.

Coincident with the taking up of the pastorate of the Broadway Presbyterian Church, at 114th Street, by the Rev. John H. McComb, it was disclosed yesterday that James Frank Shrader, Philadelphia attorney, has been appointed a legal custodian of the orthodoxy of the sermons preached in the church.

Abraham J. Hammer, who, according to Lyon Boston, Assistant District Attorney, defrauded six or more savings banks of hundreds of thousands of dollars on bogus real estate tax receipts, was found guilty in General Sessions yesterday of obtaining the signatures of a bank official under false pretenses.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- While the Treasury was making public figures today showing that at the end of the tenth month of the Treasury's fiscal year, April, expenditures had exceeded receipts by $2,768,461,126, as compared with a deficit of $3,334,444,123 on the same date a year ago, it was indicated that there was unlikely to be any "new money" borrowing by the Treasury before June 15.

Mayor La Guardia assailed his critics yesterday for attacking his administration while he was in Washington getting assurances that $125,000,000 would be advanced to the city for housing and sewage disposal.

After an early decline yesterday had carried prices on the Cotton Exchange to low levels of the week and a quarter cent from recent tops, active buying of the October delivery lifted new-crop positions about 15 points to close the list at the best figures of the session with a loss of 1 to a gain of 7 points.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended May 1, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,468,000,000, a decrease of $9,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $22,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1934.

The four proprietors of the Pacific Parlor Furniture Company and five delegates of the Furniture Workers Industrial Union were arrested yesterday afternoon on charges of assault and battery after police had stopped a brawl among them outside the factory, at 180 Whiton Street, Jersey City.

PARIS, May 2. -- What is being described here enthusiastically by some as the most important diplomatic event in the organization of peace that has taken place for many years was concluded this evening when Pierre Laval, the French Foreign Minister, and Vladimir Potemkin, the Soviet Ambassador, signed at the Quai d'Orsay the Franco-Russian mutual assistance pact that has been elaborated with so much difficulty and so many delays.

Taking the position that the Feld-Crawford bill, giving manufacturers the right to fix the resale price of trade-marked merchandise, is "faulty and badly drawn," the Retail Dry Goods Association of New York is opposing the bill, it was stated yesterday by Neil Petree, president of the association and head of James McCreery Co. Mr. Petree said Frank L. Weil of Weil, Gotshal Manges, attorneys for the association, will present the organization's views.

The share market was unable to make much progress yesterday in shaking off the lethargy that has persisted this week, although the volume did have a modest increase and by a little close calculation prices could be shown to be a shade higher
Howard Froelick of DeCoppet Doremus will transfer his membership to Howard C. Smith, who, if elected, will become an associate broker for the same firm, the Exchange announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 2. -- After deliberating four hours, a jury in Federal court late tonight acquitted both Frank P. Parish and Samuel J. Maddin of charges of using the mails to defraud stock investors of $35,000,000 in the collapse of the Missouri-Kansas Pipe Line Company.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 2. -- Ulrich Fleischauer, chief Nazi expert, charged today that the "Protocols of the Elders of Zion" were adopted by a Jewish "secret order," the B'nai B'rith, the headquarters of which, he said, is in Chicago.

AURORA, Ill., May 2 (AP). -- Woodlander, a long-striding son of Rolled Stockings -- Rosewood, from the stable of B. Hernandez of New Orleans, staged a brisk finish today to win the feature even of an all-claiming program at Aurora.

Describing his plan for bringing grand opera to the "real people" at a luncheon of the Advertising Club yesterday, Herbert Witherspoon, new manager of the Metropolitan, interpreted opera as a powerful, uplifting force in relation to social morals and economic conditions.

At the age of 66 and with nearly thirty years of service in the school system behind him. William B. Hayward, principal of the Theodore Roosevelt High School of the Bronx, went on trial for his job yesterday before a committee of the Board of Education.
WILMINGTON, Del., May 2 (AP). -- A distinguished roster of friends today joined relatives of Alfred Irenee du Pont at the funeral for the former official of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co.

Renewed efforts are now under way to keep us out of war by proving that Mr. HEARST made us go to war with Spain in 1898 and Mr. MORGAN made us declare war on Germany in 1917. This is the Manipulationist or Personal Devil interpretation of history.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2. -- Two detecting devices, developed by application of radio principles, were demonstrated before the Institute of Radio Engineers here today by Charles J. Young and Dr. David Luck and Maurice Artzt of the RCA-Victor research laboratories.

Just how far can Mayor La Guardia and his administration go in assuming rights and privileges that are not rightfully theirs? The recent announcement of the Mayor's intention to tax all private teachers of any description whatever is the last straw in the campaign to cull funds from sources not properly open to a city government.

BERLIN, May 2. -- An outline of German rearmament and its ostensible purpose, in so far as either of these can be revealed without exposing military secrets, was given today by Air Minister Hermann Wilhelm Goering at a luncheon tendered to him and his wife by the Foreign Correspondents Association of Berlin.

H. Hobert Porter, president of the American Water Works and Electric Company, Inc., made public yesterday a letter which he has sent to Senator Burton K. Wheeler, in which he asserted that utility holding companies provided junior capital and skilled managements necessary to all but the largest of these organizations.

MOSCOW, May 2. -- While Moscow's youths were dancing in the streets this evening in a carnival following the May Day celebration, foreign attaches exchanged impressions of yesterday's military demonstration and debated the war potentialities of the new airplanes and tanks disclosed by the Soviet Government.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- A public hearing on amendments to the Silk Textile Code, some of which propose major changes in labor provisions, was set for May 21 today by the National Industrial Recovery Board. The amendments are proposed by both the Code Authority for the industry and by the Labor Advisory Board of the National Recovery Administration.

Renewed weakness in the gold-bloc currencies yesterday swept the Netherlands guilder and the Swiss franc once more below the prices at which it becomes profitable to ship gold here from abroad. The French franc dropped to within 1\4 point of its gold import point. Sterling and its followers, on the other hand, rose in dollar value.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2. -- Two vaccines giving immunity against athlete's foot, a type of ringworm estimated to attack 80 per cent of the population, was announced here today before the American College of Physicians by Dr. Herbert Thomas Kelly of the University of Pennsylvania Graduate School of Medicine.
HALIFAX, May 2 (Canadian Press). -- Mariners counted fresh toll today as the twin perils of the North Atlantic, ice and weather, reared their yearly menace to shipping along the seaboard.

MEXICO, D.F., May 2. -- Amelia Earhart again deferred her proposed non-stop flight to New York this afternoon on account of unfavorable weather. She now plans to start between 5 and 6 o'clock (between 7 and 8 A.M. New York time) tomorrow morning, if reports are satisfactory.

The piercing shrieks in the bird sanctuaries in the Bronx Zoo are not wails of mourning for Dillinger, the whooping swan that died recently, it was explained yesterday evening by Lee Crandall, curator of birds.
Five races have been scheduled by the Virginia Gold Cup Association for tomorrow afternoon at Broadview, the estate of Alexander B. Hagner, at Warrenton, Va.

Interference by the weather man yesterday forced fans of Manhattan and Flatbush to be content with a two-round draw between the Giants and the Dodgers. The third and fourth battles of the interborough strife will be fought at the Polo Grounds on Memorial Day.

CHURCHILL, Man., May 2. -- Swinging along with the easy hip motion typical of a man who rates that highest of all praise in this North Country, "a traveler," Dave Irwin arrived in Churchill today just as the sun was painting the ice of Hudson Bay a deep crimson.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- F.P. Small, president of the American Express Comany, received in 1934 compensation of $68,665, and Theodore Roosevelt, chairman of the board, $12,101, the company's registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today. J.K. Livingston and R.T. Reed, vice presidents, received $19,087 and $19,531 respectively.

The new police eligible list, grading 5,503 young men, including graduates of Harvard, Fordham, Columbia and the Naval Academy, from whose number new members of the police force will be appointed in the next four years, was made public yesterday by the Municipal Civil Service Commission.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 2. -- Yale and New York University tried a football innovation today, playing a practice game on Anthony Thompson Field. Rain fell and this laboratory test of the plays the teams have been taught in their Spring practice during the past three weeks was held under as rigidly secret conditions as the traditional final workout before the climax game of the season.

GENEVA, May 2. -- James H. Rogers of the United States gave mild, support in the League of Nations Economio Committee today to the view advanced yesterday by Sir Frederick Leith-Ross that devaluation by the gold-bloc countries would improve world trade conditions.

Mrs. Grover Cleveland Bergdoll, the 28-year-old wife of "the millionaire draft dodger," arrived yesterday on the United States liner Washington to seek clemency for her husband from President Roosevelt. As the slender, attractive young woman was landing here with her four children, indications from Washington were that she would get little sympathy, at least from the Department of Justice.

A speedy agreement for the city's purchase of the rapid transit properties of the I.R.T. and the Manhattan Railway elevated lines is being blocked only by the refusal of stockholders to abandon their demands for exorbitant prices, Samuel Seabury, special counsel for the city, declared last night in a statement given out as he was sailing for Europe on board the Cunard liner Majestic.

Out-of-town entrants in the 325-mile seventeen-day hike that Bernarr Macfadden, veteran physical culturist and publisher, will lead out of New York City tomorrow morning for Dansville, N.Y., began to arrive here yesterday.

Four former officers and directors of the Westchester Title and Trust Company who were indicted last Monday for mail fraud and conspiracy leading up to the failure of that concern in 1933, entered pleas of not guilty yesterday before Federal Judge Murray Hulbert and were released in bail of $3,500 each.

Thirteen regions instead of ten will be proposed in the mapping of this country and Canada for the reorganization plan of the American Power Boat Association. That was decided upon by the committee in charge of the proposed changes, which met last night in the Hotel Lexington.

Mifflinburg Body Co., store and second floor in 549 ~.V. 39th St. from Port of New York Authority; Aldrich Co. The lessee an auto body firm, is combining its Brooklyn. Newark and Manhattan warehouse and office space in the quarters rented.

KAUNAS, Lithuania, May 2. -- A reply to the Easter note of the signatory powers of the Memel Convention was communicated today by Lithuania to the Ministers of Great Britain, France and Italy. It was learned on good authority that the Lithuanian Government in its reply renewed its contention that it was employing every effort to obtain satisfactory collaboration between President Bruwelaitis of the Memel Directorate and the Landtag.
Richard Rohman, newspaper man and labor reporter, has completed "The Power of the Press," a play suggested by the strike recently conducted by the American Newspaper Guild against The Newark Ledger.

Anticipating that social legislative measures will be adopted by the present Congress, the stockholders of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey at their annual meeting on June 4 will be asked to vote to terminate the fifth stock purchase plan for employes as of Dec. 31, 1935.

A memorial resolution in honor of Adolph S. Ochs, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, who died last month, was unanimously adopted by a rising vote at the annual meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York yesterday.

District Attorney William C. Dodge received a letter yesterday from Samuel Marcus, counsel for the Society for the Prevention of Crime, in which the lawyer intimated that the prosecutor was allowing the grand jury investigations of the vice and policy rackets to die of inanition.
BERLIN, May 2. -- The Boerse was strong today, although activity still was limited. At the close the market was quieter, with some realization selling appearing.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):

A proposed modification of the Henry Hudson Parkway project to permit its future incorporation into a broader traffic scheme was suggested yesterday in a statement issued by the Regional Plan Association.

NORTH CALDWELL, N.J., May 2. -- Although the Federal Government is supposed to be in the mortgage business only temporarily, there is danger that it will become permanent, said Major Fred M. Oliver, counsel for the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks, at a meeting of the New Jersey Savings Banks Association here today in the Greenbrook Country Club.

DETROIT, May 2. -- A survey showed that fifteen units are closed today, as a result of strikes or shutdowns necessitated by shortage of parts and materials. On a basis of estimates from various sources, about 26,000 workers are affected.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 2. -- Without any help from Dizzy Dean, who came to college today, the Cardinals won an 11-to-3 exhibition game from Cornell. The world champions reached four of the Red hurlers for sixteen hits, one of which was a home run by Jack Rothrock with the bases full.
PARIS, May 2 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

The Board of Estimate voted $20,002,000 for home and work relief this month at a special meeting yesterday, while the aldermanic relief investigation developed testimony showing substantial waste in the purchase of materials because of red tape.

John McAuliffe, president of the Isthmian Steamship Company, resigned yesterday as chairman of the American Steamship Owners Association because of a difference of opinion among the association's member lines as to Federal merchant marine legislation.

CLEVELAND, May 2. -- A plan for extending the $15,000,000 of Van Sweringen Corporation five-year 6 per cent gold notes due on May 1, of which the Vaness Company owns $18,787,000, was announced here today.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- President Roosevelt received a delegation from the Business Advisory and Planning Council of the Commerce Department, who pledged him their support despite the anti-administration resolutions adopted at the final meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

Bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday rose to the highest level for the year, with a total of $6,011,214,000 for the twenty-two principal cities, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. This compares with $5,615,558,000 reported for the corresponding week of 1934 and represents an increase of 7.0 per cent
BRYN MAWR, Pa., May 2. -- Despite gloomy skies, intermittent rain and breezes that were anything but springlike, the traditional May Day exercises were observed today at Bryn Mawr College.

Bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday rose to the highest level for the year, with a total of $6,011,214,000 for the twenty-two principal cities, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. This compares with $5,615,558,000 reported for the corresponding week of 1934 and represents an increase of 7.0 per cent
BRYN MAWR, Pa., May 2. -- Despite gloomy skies, intermittent rain and breezes that were anything but springlike, the traditional May Day exercises were observed today at Bryn Mawr College.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Industrial leaders on the Business Advisory and Planning Council of the Department of Commerce rallied to the support of President Roosevelt's program this afternoon within a few hours after the convention of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States had ridden rough-shod over it.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- The battle before the Supreme Court which the government views as a "right-across-the-board" test of the constitutionality of the National Industrial Recovery Act began today when arguments in the Schechter poultry case from New York opened in an atmosphere of tenseness reminiscent of the hearings on the gold clause abrogation a few months ago.

Many reservations have been made for the Japanese dinner dance to be given tomorrow night at the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the New York Section, National Council of Jewish Women. The ballroom will be decorated to resemble a cherry orchard in bloom, with brightly colored Japanese lanterns illuminating the scene.

Forty years have passed since JOHN LOVEJOY-ELLIOTT with a group of friends started the Hudson Guild, in the Chelsea section of Manhattan Island. Children of that neighborhood who knew his kindly interest in them are now in middle life; adults still living who knew his brotherly counsel in their troubles and his sympathy in their sorrows and joys are now in age.

MONTREAL. May 2. -- The redrafted newsprint bill as now pending in the Quebec Legislature is regarded here as of particular interest because of the omission of features which appeared in the original draft. This development, it is felt in interested circles, may effectively dispose of the contention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association that the legislation constituted governmental interference with bona fide contracts between producer and consumer.

In his address yesterday at the annual convention of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, Secretary HULL recalled that precisely two years ago, speaking before a very similar audience, he had urged this country to adopt "a sane, practical middle course" to revive world trade.

Yesterday's moderate upturn in stocks was encouraging to those who were predicting that the advance would be resumed soon. It also was disconcerting to the experts who have been pointing to the stock average charts to prove that the market recently has been "topping off."

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- A defense of his view on the need of rebuilding the international economic structure by a sensible adjustment of high tariff walls and modifying other restrictions to trade was delivered by Secretary Hull today to the convention of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

An "open letter to the people of Japan," opposing the American fleet manoeuvres in the Pacific and signed by 301 American religious leaders, was made public yesterday by Harold E. Fey, secretary of the Fellowship of Reconciliation. The message, Mr. Fey said, was signed by, among others, fourteen Bishops and many college presidents, ministers, rabbis and editors of religious publications.

With Sylvester Carlton, 21-year old ticker transmitter operator, in the chair of Richard Whitney, president, operation of the New York Stock Exchange was entrusted yesterday to six junior employes in the Exchange's sixth annual celebration of Youths' Day in Industry.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Present accommodations for the Naval Reserve Aviation Base at Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn are inadequate and scattered, Secretary Swanson wrote to Representative Delaney of New York today. The Secretary said the navy would welcome the use of 472 additional acres, an offer of which New York City is understood to be considering.

Vagaries of the weather have once more interfered with the expansion of trade counted on at this time in the metropolitan area. Reports here yesterday indicated the situation was very spotty, with the average volume running well below expectations.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2. -- The annual problem of mud, and how it will affect the Kentucky Derby candidates, arose today as a heavy thunderstorm broke over the track in the morning hours and left the strip very sloppy. Rain also fell in the afternoon and more is forecast for tomorrow.

The market value of all shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $2,612,247,946 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. The average price a share on May 1 was $25.77, compared with $23.73 at the beginning of April.

PITTSBURGH, May 2 (AP). -- The government's investigation of Andrew W. Mellon's tax affairs is "well started, but nowhere near finished," Robert H. Jackson, government attorney, asserted tonight after the income-tax hearing was adjourned here.

The "most thorough, scientific and impartial investigation" ever undertaken on the effects of alcohol on the human system will be made by the Council for Moderation, an organization engaging in a ten-year campaign of education to develop an attitude of moderation in this country in the use of alcoholic beverages.

A further increase of $20,579,000 in gold-certificate reserves to a new high mark of $5,750,844,000 was reported for the week ended on Wednesday in the statement of the Federal Reserve System, published yesterday. The rise was about equal to the week's gain of $20,000,000 in monetary gold stocks, which lifted them also to a new high record of $8,721,000,000.
TAIHOKU, Formosa, May 2 (AP). -- Three adventurers, one a former American naval officer, were still held in a Formosa jail cell today for investigation on suspicion of espionage.

BALTIMORE, May 2. -- United States gold coins, of a face value of $11,425, which were dug up in an old Baltimore cellar by two poor boys, brought $22,500 at an auction sale today, attended by coin collectors from many parts of the country.

Some of the more attenuated hobbies, like boomerang throwing and cog-wheeling the carrots for a vegetable salad, were still getting their booths organized yesterday at the Hobby Round-Up of the Leisure League of America. The established pastimes, meanwhile, like that shown in the Bay Ridge Tropical Fish Society's exhibit, were functioning like well-oiled machines.

The nominating committee of the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday nominated John H. McFadden Jr. for re-election as president for the ensuing year. John C. Botts and Clayton B. Jones were nominated for re-election as vice president and treasurer, respectively.

John S. Schulte, In 941 Park Av., through Brown, Wheelock, Harris Co.; Mrs. Frank M. Leavltt, in 33 E. 70th St., through William B. May Co.; Ranald H. MacDonald, in 911 Park Av., through Stockwell Marling; Tishman Realty Construction Co., lessor.

Complying with suggestions of the Securities and Exchange Commission, the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday a 50 per cent reduction in its arbitration charges, urged members to make better use of arbitration agreements and revised the procedure of the business conduct committee in disputes between members and their customers.
Manuel Quezon, President of the Philippine Senate, who is in New York City, was inclined last night to discount reports of the number killed in the uprising.
DANZIG, May 2. -- The Free City's gulden today joined the long series of currencies that have been forced off gold parity by the decline of the pound and the dollar.

For practical purposes the United States is very much in the situation of a suzerainty occupied and governed by a foreign power. As a collection of citizens we no longer have the right of self-determination. We must do what we are told or it will be just too bad for us.

STANFORD UNIVERSITY, Calif., May 3. -- How the "dishonesty" of his book, "Revolt in the Desert," annoyed its author was disclosed today when the Hoover War Memorial Library made public the text of a letter written by "Colonel T.E. Lawrence of Arabia."

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Appeals for continued and increasing activity in the cause of world peace, to meet and conquer the growing menace of competition in preparations for war, were broadcast today By high officials of Great Britain, Japan, France, and Soviet Russia.
ROME, May 3. -- The debate in the British House of Commons yesterday was read today with very mixed feelings in Italy.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Code provisions attempting to eliminate "loss leaders," or selling at retail below the cost to the seller, should be continued for "at least another trial period," the National Industrial Recovery Board found today in the second of a series of statements on administration policy.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 3. -- Five persons were trapped and burned to death this afternoon in a fire which destroyed a three-story building at 411 Main Street.

An explanation of the "weekly payment" amendment to the Labor Law recentlq signed by Governor Lehman was issued yesterday by Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, as a result of inquiries from employers who feared a drastic reorganization of their bookkeeping methods.

PARIS, May 3. -- Nothing short of close cooperation between France and the United States can bring about world recovery. Jacques Rueff, financial expert and Inspector of Finance of the French Finance Ministry, told the American Club here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- A bill proposing an automatic wartime tax of 100 per cent on personal net incomes in excess of $10,000 a year, and 99 per cent on corporate returns of above 6 per cent, was introduced in the Senate today by Senator Nye as the first of a series of measures to be proposed by his Munitions Investigating Committee to take the profits out of war.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in the State, now offered by dealers:

The three-game series between the Giants and the Reds, marking the first Western invasion of the Polo Grounds this season, yesterday started in a demoralizing bombardment of base hits and closed in a drenching downpour.
LOS ANGELES, May 3 (AP). -- Southern California's greatest track and field team will be represented, at least in part, in the I.C.A.A.A.A. championships at Cambridge, Mass., May 31 to June 1.

CARLISLE, Pa., May 3. -- Declaring that our educational system must not surrender to the socialistic trend and, further, insisting that the national educational system will be destroyed if it continues to be centralized in bureaucratic control in Washington, United States Senator Lester J. Dickinson of Iowa addressed the opening ceremonies in connection with the inauguration of Dr. Fred P. Corson as the twentieth president of Dickinson College here tonight.
PARIS, May 3. -- The text of the Franco-Russian mutual assistance treaty, signed yesterday, was published this evening, and won a good if not enthusiastic, reception in Paris.

The gentleman who is here from England to teach the American people how to spend two hours at lunch has set himself a hard task. As a hobby the two-hour luncheon might receive the sympathetic attention of the Leisure League.

OTTAWA, May 3. -- W.D. Herridge, Canadian Minister at Washington, will soon resign from that post to take a leading part in the forthcoming general election campaign. Mr. Herridge, who is Prime Minister Bennett's brother-in-law and has more influence with him than any one else, was a considerable figure behind the scenes in the 1930 campaign, which elected the present government to office.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Organization of a bloc of industrial unions into a separate national labor federation, led by the United Mine Workers of America, leaving the remaining craft unions within the present American Federation of Labor, was regarded as an eventual possibility in labor circles today.

An exhibition entitled "Design in Local Industry" is current until May 19 at the Addison Gallery of American Art, Andover, Mass. The exhibition is made up of products from Lowell, Lawrence, Haverhill, Andover and North Andover, and a primary aim has been to call attention to possibilities of good design in industry.

Vincent McGarrett's letter favoring restoration of city employes' pay cuts, displays indifference to many of the important factors affecting this problem. I would like to point out some oft-repeated facts for the benefit of others.

Federal Judge William H. Holly of the United States District Court in Chicago, has issued restraining orders in the case of the Public Utilities Securities Corporation, for which an application for receivership and reorganization under Section 77b of the National Bankruptcy Act is pending, thus taking the case out of the hands of the Chancery Court in Wilmington, Del.

The first of two programs under the title of "Men in the Dance" was given last night at the Park Theatre in Columbus Circle under the joint auspices of New Theatre Magazine and the New Dance League. The evening was of great interest, if one makes allowance for certain managerial shortcomings which included chiefly a delay of half an hour in raising the curtain and quite the dirtiest floor on record.
LONDON, May 3. -- American visitors were plentiful among the jostling crowds today that reduced traffic to a three-mile-an-hour crawl along the route of the King's jubilee procession.

A somewhat more cheerful tone pervaded the markets yesterday. Share prices made their best showing in a little more than a week, with the volume edging close to the now coveted million-share mark. Mining and steel shares were among the leaders, the former responding to a recovery in silver and the latter influenced by court approval of the Republic and Corrigan, McKinney Steel merger plans.

LONDON, May 3. -- The private view of the annual Royal Academy show today was an even more gala occasion than usual, coinciding as it did with King George's silver jubilee festivities. All day the famous Burlington House galleries were thronged with celebrities, many of whom came to see their portraits by Britain's leading artists.

CHICAGO, May 3. -- Hogs weighing 210 to 260 pounds were in fairly active demand from smaller packers today and advanced as much as 10 cents a hundredweight over the prices on Thursday. Packers are finding that these weights cut out to better advantage than others.

In view of the large amount of refinancing in recent months through loans from banks and other institutions instead of by public offering of securities, there has been a large demand for preferred stocks, and many of these issues now are selling at the highest levels in history.

PIMLICO, Md., May 3. -- Showing his noted mud-running ability, Star Porter atoned for his defeat in the Baltimore Spring Handicap when he soundly trounced four other sprinters to account for the six furlongs of the Eutaw Purse, the principal attraction today at Pimlico.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- In a move to speed up the final stages of the conversion of First Liberty bonds, the Treasury announced today that after midnight Tuesday a premium of 50 cents a $100 would be charged on the new 2 7/8 per cent bonds for which holders may still exchange their Liberties.

MOSCOW, May 3. -- The pact of mutual assistance between the Soviet Union and France, made public here tonight, is far from being the pact that Foreign Minister Maxim Litvinoff originally conceived to protect the peace of Eastern Europe.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Payments of $55,000 compensation to A.E. Duncan, chairman of the Commercial Credit Company, and of $50,717 to Daniel E. Woodhull, president of the American Banknote Company, were disclosed today in registration statements filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

LONDON, May 3. -- In a bitter attack on President Roosevelt's silver-buying policy, the London weekly, The Economist, today hints that other nations may be forced to take retaliatory measures for their own protection.

This column, like Miss Otis, feels compelled to preface its remarks this morning with regrets -- regrets, that is, for the abrupt closing of the Casino de Paree last Sunday night. With the expiration of Jimmy Durante's engagement on that particular evening, the management saw fit, for reasons of financial expediency, to put up the shutters -- and Broadway is thereby left with but one large theatre-restaurant to excite the wondering visitors, the French Casino.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):

Bernard J. Dubos, member of the Meteorological Society of France, disclosed yesterday in an interview here that he was in this country to study weather conditions and to seek aid in experimenting with a "meteorological tube" about 2,000 feet high, which he would construct to force water vapor into the upper air to create, rainfall over large areas.

The Cleaners and Dyers Board of Trade moved yesterday to have its members close plants crippled by the strike of 9,000 employes. At the same time Aldermanic President Bernard S. Deutsch offered the services of the city administration in an effort to effect a settlement.

PHILADELPHIA, May 3. -- Pennsylvania's oarsmen make their debut tomorrow when the Blackwell Cup race is staged over the Henley distance on the Fairmount Park course. The Quakers will face the Yale and Columbia varsity eights in this feature event of the regatta.

Check exchanges at the principal clearing houses of the country in April amounted to $24,755,597,629. This was a decline of 6 per cent from the preceding month, but a gain of 1.7 per cent over April, 1934.
PARIS, May 3. -- Following are the texts of the Franco-Russian mutual assistance acoord and the protocol of signature:

BERNE, Switzerland, May 3 (AP). -- A Nazi, Ulrich Fleischauer, told the "Protocols of Zion" trial court today that the League of Nations was a Jewish institution and that it was part of a plan by Jews for attaining world domination.
Seven Manhattan properties and six in the Bronx were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday. One scheduled Bronx sale was adjourned. The Manhattan results were as follows:

Cardinal HAYES -- the "Cardinal of Charity," as he has been called -- has made it most emphatic in his annual appeal for Catholic Charities that taxation should never excuse us from exercising the virtue of charity toward our fellow-men. "It is inconceivable," His Eminence says, "that our Christ"like charity could be expressed only "through the increased burden of taxes "which we are bound to meet as a civic "obligation."

GALLUP, N.M., May 3. -- An amazing narrative of kidnapping and beating by hooded gunmen was laid before authorities tonight by Robert Minor and David Levinson, who are in New Mexico on behalf of ten Gallup riot murder defendante.

NEWARK, N.J., May 3. -- Lieutenant J.W. Wofford of the West Point horse show team, mounted on the black gelding Prince, carried off first money in the open jumping class, one of the leading events of the first session of the fifteenth annual Newark horse show tonight in the Essex Troop Armory.

BERLIN, May 3. -- The Boerse continued firm today. Gains ranged up to 3 per cent and despite fluctuations the market closed steady. Heavy industrials ended with an upward movement, Harpener gaining 2 3/4 points, Kloeckner 2 1/4 and Rheinstahl 2 1/2.

DANZIG, May 3. -- The Rev. Herr Eichel, Protestant clergyman, and Herr Mendelsohn, a Jewish merchant, were among the first victims of the Danzig gulden's devaluation of 42.37 per cent, announced here yesterday. Both were arrested today, the first man on a charge of street agitation against the government and the second on a charge of raising prices.

The grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria was thronged last night for the Lace Ball, one of the largest events of the Spring season, which was given for the benefit of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association. Lace in many styles, colors and textures was the dominating motif of the occasion and an elaborate fashion revue of this material was presented in floral settings of marked beauty.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 3 (AP). -- Thousands of Kentucky Derby hound fans crowded the air, land and water travel lanes toward Louisville tonight. The vanguard arriving today found the city perking up after a severe wind and electrical storm.
