CHICAGO, May 3. -- Additional rains over part of the Winter wheat belt, including Central Kansas, where they were much needed, combined with dry weather in the Northwest, which is necessary for completion of Spring wheat seeding, more than offset today on the Board of Trade here the effect of an advance in silver.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Friendly notice that the American Bankers Association would carry to Congress its fight to assure to the Federal Reserve System freedom from "political control" was given to President Roosevelt today during a White House call by the members of the executive committee of the association.

Net profit of the Childs Company and all subsidiaries for the first quarter of this year was $15,586 after interest, depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges, according to the report issued yesterday. This was equivalent to 41 cents a share on 37,321 shares of $100-par 7 per cent preferred stock.
Villanova snapped the Long Island University baseball team's string of nine straight victories by winning, 7 -- 3, at Manhattan Beach yesterday. Rain halted the proceedings after seven innings.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 3. -- Professor Albert Einstein will attack science's important theory of quantum mechanics, a theory of which he was a sort of grandfather. He concludes that while it is "correct" it is not "complete."

DETROIT, May 3 (AP). -- The shutdown of Tarrytown plants today brought the total number of auto workers made idle by the Toledo strike to 31,215 in eighteen factories. This does not include several hundred laid off by independent concerns which manufacture supplies for Chevrolet and Fisher.

Bonds of domestic corporations moved higher as United States Government issues and foreign loans gave ground yesterday on the Stock Exchange. Trading was moderately active, totaling $12,061,700, compared with $10,520,200 on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- The Senate Committee on Education and Labor, in its report on the Wagner Labor Disputes Bill, made public today, declared that "the time has come for a clean decision" to withdraw the governmental guarantee of collective bargaining contained in Section 7a of the Recovery Act "or implement it by effective legislation."

Elias Orenstein in a letter to THE TIMES disagrees with my letter dealing with Polish problems which was printed in your issue of April 5. Mr. Orenstein asks, Who started the war with the Ukrainians of Galicia in 1918?

A vigorous campaign by our local relief agencies to urge home modernization as authorized by the Federal Housing Administration easy-loan plan would result in the creation of thousands of jobs for the unemployed of Greater New York this Spring and Summer.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

The network of corridors, pedestrian tunnels and trucking ramps under the two upper blocks of Rockefeller Center between Forty- ninth and Fifty-first Streets, Fifth and Sixth Avenues, has been completed, officials of the development announced yesterday.

One would-be bandit was killed and another escaped yesterday after a pistol fight on the fourth floor of the Seamen's Church Institute, 25 South Street, where they had attempted to take a $5,000 payroll from a woman cashier.

ALBANY, May 3. -- Earl Harkness of Kew Gardens, L.I., has been reinstated as principal bank examiner in the State Banking Department, it was announced today in the department's weekly bulletin. From Jan. 1 to May 1 he was deputy superintendent of banking.

MADRID, May 3. -- The stop-gap government that Alejandro Lerroux formed just a month ago today had to resign twice this afternoon before President Niceto Alcala Zamora, whose Leftist sympathies and dislike for the Conservative Catholic Action majority in the Spanish Parliament are well known, would accede to the wishes of the elderly republican Premier.

Some commentators have discovered that a portion of the pending Banking Act seems to give the national government, rather than some bankers, control of our national monetary policies. A committee of the United States Chamber of Commerce is likewise disturbed. So no doubt will be many others who want the Old Deal redealt.

It is one thing to be brave when you are a keeper at the zoo and know positively that a snake is not venomous, but it is quite another thing when you are only a banana man trying to get along and you see two cold eyes gleaming at you through the dark of your cellar.

" Pressure politics" at its worst is now on display in the Senate. Every member of that body knows that payment of the soldiers' bonus is not due until 1945. Every member knows that the plan to advance the date of payment by ten years cannot be described as a "relief" measure, since ex-soldiers already have precisely the same recourse to Federal assistance which is available to every other citizen.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 3. -- Sixteen persons were left dead and upward of 100 injured today in the wake of furious wind and electrical storms which spread destruction over seven States.

The first low-rate "fishermen's special" to Montauk will be operated tomorrow by the Long Island Railroad. Thus will be inaugurated another season of sport on the famous fishing grounds at the eastern tip of the island, where the waters of Gardiner's Bay, Fort Pond Bay, Block Island Sound and Long Island Sound merge with the Atlantic.
LIMA, May 3 (AP). -- Peru prohibited today the exportation of silver bars and coins and the hoarding, buying or selling of silver, under pain of severe penalties.

The Excelsior Handicap, with $5,000 added, at a mile and a sixteenth and the last of the handicap stake events of the meeting, is down for decision as the feature at Jamaica today. The race has drawn eight of the top-notch performers of the East out of a total of forty-three nominations, with the promise of a keen contest.

The Misses Elizabeth Chew and Peggy Sykes gave a dinner last night in the roof garden of the St. Regis for Miss Audrey Jaeckel and John Hamilton Baker, who will be married May 17, and for Miss Doris Merrill and Robert Anderson Magowan, whose marriage will take place in June.

Our Young Republicans may be interested in the talk and work of their English brethren and sisters, the National League of Young Liberals. A community of misfortunes and hopes, the common aim of rehabilitating the party, are a bond of sympathy between the two phalanxes of rejuvenation.
" Aida" will be sung at the Hippodrome tonight, with the Misses Jarboro and Caselotti and Messrs. De Muro, Pandiscio, Miller and Ruisi.

Operating expenses of the Western Pacific Railroad increased 10.9 per cent in 1934, according to the annual report of Charles Elsey, president. He attributed this advance to greater train mileage, wage restorations, higher costs of supplies and an addition of $97,682 to expenses for liabilities under the Railway Pension Law.
TOKYO, May 3. -- American sailors were strolling tonight along Yokohama's streets, where the public, especially the shopkeeping section, was giving them an interested welcome.

BERLIN, May 3. -- It was announced today that a number of Catholic Church newspapers, including the Berlin bishopric's official organ, had been confiscated for publishing a pastoral letter from the German Bishops which, according to the announcement, "contains intolerable criticism" of governmental institutions.

Impetus given by extensively advertised sales during the last week-end, together with the added volume of business resulting from the late Easter, raised the level of April retail sales for the country as a whole 4 to 12 per cent above that of a year ago, according to a preliminary estimate announced yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- President Roosevelt turned aside criticisms by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States with the remark that many business organizations misrepresented business men. He received officers of the American Bankers Association, who served notice, in connection with the banking bill, that they would urge that the Federal Reserve System be kept free from political control.

ON BOARD U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA, San Francisco, May 3. -- The most powerful fleet the United States ever has possessed was "somewhere in the Pacific" tonight in the first stages of one of the most ambitious strategical manoeuvres ever planned.
NANKING, May. 3. -- A revival of efforts to end extraterritoriality in China was presaged today following the organization of a special committee "for the retrocession of judicial rights."
BUENOS AIRES, May 3. -- Seventeen steamers left Argentine ports this week carrying 65,511 metric tons of corn to the United States.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Amid hilarity seldom seen in the Supreme Court, occasioned by a graphic description of the technique of chicken slaughter by counsel for the A.L.A. Schechter Live Poultry. Corporation of Brooklyn, argument in the test of the NRA was concluded today and the court prepared to render a decision.

MEXICO, D.F., May 3. -- Mexico's Davis Cup team practically clinched the right to meet the winner of next week's United States-China series by taking two singles matches from Cuba today. Two more encounters in singles and one in doubles remain to be played, but little doubt is held that the Mexican players will score at least one more victory.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 3. -- Twenty-two thoroughbreds, a number equal to the record field which went to the post in 1928, were named today for the sixty-first running of the $40,000 added Kentucky Derby tomorrow. The size of the entry surprised every one. including officials, but the starting field is expected to be smaller, since several of those named are listed as doubtful and others as sentimental starters.
Money market was quiet. While funds were in good supply not a great deal of new funds were employed, the day's business being taken up in replacements. Quotations were unchanged.

PARIS, May 3. -- Official quarters disclosed today that France stood ready to help the Soviet build railways and strategic roads along her western frontier so as to facilitate movements of the Red Army in that area.

The tempo of growth and development is more rapid among young girls than among young boys and is basically influenced by the two factors of heredity and environment, Professor Franz Boas of the Department of Anthropology of Columbia University told the American Society of Orthodontists yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Sharp criticism of his policies by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States was waved aside today by President Roosevelt because of his firm conviction, based on previous experience, that often organizations do not really voice the opinion of the majority of the individuals for whom they speak.

Exports and imports from and into the United States by classified groups of merchandise during March, given out by the Department of Commerce, compare as follows with a month ago and the corresponding period of 1934. Exports as given in the subjoined tables cover only domestic exports, not foreign goods re-exported.

A Te Deum of thanksgiving "for the life and leadership of the King and Queen of England will be offered tomorrow at the 11 P.M. service in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fiftieth Street, because of the silver jubilee celebration of the reign of King George V, to be held on Monday.
DETROIT, May 3. -- Automobile executives and factory workers in Detroit and vicinity were more or less marking time today, so far as strike and strike threat activities were concerned.

It was with great interest that I read the report by the Manufacturers Association that business could re-employ 4,000,000 people if Congress would only cease threatening legitimate business interests with unsound legislation like Wagner's Labor Bill, the Thirty-Hour Week Bill and more such pernicious short-sighted proposals.

The Japanese Economic Mission to Brazil is sailing for Rio de Janeiro on the Northern Prince today. One of its purposes will be to investigate the possibilities of buying in that country a larger part of the Japanese cotton supply, virtually all of which now is bought from the United States.
CLEVELAND, May 3. -- The government today lost its suit for an injunction under the anti-trust laws to halt the merger of the Republic Steel Corporation and the Corrigan-McKinney Steel Company.

Joseph Heistand of Hillsboro, Ohio, was outstanding in both the amateur championship of America at double-clay targets and in the preliminary shoot at sixteen yards yesterday at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. He took the doubles championship by breaking 190 out of a possible 200 targets and won the preliminary event after a tie in which he and two others had broken 100 straight apiece.

PHILADELPHIA, May 3. -- Classifying our civilization as Stone Age in economic thought in the face of a golden age of scientific discovery, Sir Josiah Stamp tonight called for a "new international standard of value" as one of the greatest solvents of present economic problems.

The Railroad Credit Corporation has repaid nearly one-third of the contributions to the loan pool that it managed until the pool was terminated on June 1, 1933, according to a report filed yesterday with the Interstate Commerce Commission. The corporation collected $75,422,410 for the pool from freight surcharges which ended on that date and lent the proceeds to needy railroads.
Sharply opposing views on the desirability of continuance of NRA codes were expressed here yesterday by representatives of outstanding apparel and accessory groups.
Sales of multi-family buildings in the West Bronx featured realty trading yesterday.

Under a scientifically devised program of low-cost diets it is now possible properly to feed and nourish a family of five persons in this city on $8 a week, it was indicated in a report presented yesterday to the New York State Dietetic Association.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- The government will attempt to spend $5,550,000,000 instead of $4,000,000,000 for work relief before July 1, 1936, it became known today when it was revealed that the Public Works Administration had not yet spent $1,550,000,000 of its works funds.

New State and municipal financing will continue next week to be comparatively light, with issues aggregating only $18,528,180 scheduled for award, and more than half of this amount consisting of a single issue. The figure compares with this week's revised total of $29,786,125, which does not include the $40,000,000 New York State notes which were allotted after the fashion of bank loans.
ALBANY, May 3. -- The Burchill Transit Unification Bill was signed by Governor Lehman today at the request of Mayor La Guardia, although the Mayor declared it was not fully satisfactory to him.

CHICAGO, May 3. -- Asking a minimum of government regulation and criticizing government intervention in private business, a long petition to Congress was adopted tonight by the directors of the National Petroleum Institute after an eight-hour special session.

A report of progress on the construction of the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary, which is being finished at Clydeside, near Glasgow, was made yesterday by officials of the line in New York. The occasion was the formal opening of the line's new offices in the International Building, Rockefeller Center, attended by several hundred passenger agents and shipping officials.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- As a result of investigations into complaints of monopoly, price-fixing and restraint of trade against manufacturers of fire hose and the Code Authority for the mechanical rubber division of the Rubber Manufacturing Code, the National Industrial Recovery Board stayed indefinitely today all the price sections of the code.

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 3. -- Miss Charlotte Glutting, New Jersey State women's golf champion, made her season's debut in a New Jersey Women's Golf Association one-day tournament today by winning the event with four strokes to spare.
BERLIN, May 3 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of April 30 shows the following changes in reichsmark:

Discussion of the Residence Bill now before the Board of Aldermen and provisions for home relief aroused the delegates to the Spring convention of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs yesterday and brought prompt action before the close of the session, which was held in the Hotel Astor.

Elimination of red tape and delay in relief administration was recommended in a new plan announced yesterday by Controller Frank J. Taylor, who suggested that the city buy its own work relief materials and get reimbursement of 75 per cent from Federal and State agencies in the form of increased home relief allowances.

Adoption of the Goldsborough amendment to the Banking Bill was urged yesterday by Frank A. Vanderlip in letters to members of Congress. He declared that passage of the bill without this amendment would be both dangerous and unconstitutional.

Two hundred and forty boys of Riverdale Country School united their voices in the choruses of Handel's oratorio, "Saul," given in abridged form at the Town Hall last night as part of a Bach-Handel celebration program undertaken by the school.

To expedite the registration of the securities listed on the New York Stock Exchange, the committee on stock list of the Exchange sent a letter yesterday to issuers of listed securities explaining the use of the provisional registration form known as Form 7.

BERLIN, May 3. -- George Sosnowski, the Polish Baron, termed by secret police "one of the most dangerous spies in Europe," has been traded for three German spies held in Poland, it was disclosed today.
ALBANY, May 3 (AP). -- Capitol observers pointed tonight to Louis H. Pink of New York City as New York State's future Superintendent of Insurance.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations, including processing tax, on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

MARGATE, England, May 3. -- Defeating Brian Reilly of Ireland in the ninth and final round, Samuel Reshevsky of the Marshall Chess Club of New York won the international masters' tournament of the Kent County Chess Association, which was concluded at the Grand Hotel today.

MIAMI, Fla., May 3. -- After a six-hour session, climaxed by the passing of twenty-one resolutions, notably one on academic freedom, the National Congress of Parents and Teachers ended its convention here today.

WINNIPEG, Man., May 3. -- Sir Hubert Wilkins, bearded traveler in the cold places of the earth, has revealed further details of his plan for establishment of a submarine meteorological station beneath the Arctic ice, 400 miles from the North Pole.

EINSTEIN expresses his dissatisfaction with the quantum theory, for the development of which he is in part responsible. It is a theory which asserts that the atom, and hence a universe composed of atoms, lacks unity. Ultimate particles jump about for no apparent reason. Order, continuity -- these are human inventions, the quantum theorists tell us.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Amended to include a direct appropriation of $2,263,545,684 for immediate cash payment to World War veterans, the Vinson Bonus Bill gained such great support in the Senate today that its passage was averted only when Democratic leaders forced a recess until Monday.

NEWARK, N.J., May 3. -- The schedule of reduced rates of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company was announced today by the New Jersey Board of Public Utility Commissioners, who ordered the new rates effective on bills sent out on and after June 1.

Plans for maintaining two retail establishments in close proximity to each other were announced yesterday in connection with the leasing of space in the building at the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street, opposite the old Wendel home site.

BERLIN, May 3. -- In the first official public declaration of any kind made by a member of the German Government on the important question of the rate at which Germany is building military airplanes and adding to her newly created air force, General Hermann Wilhelm Goering said to me:

A bronze memorial tablet to mark the site of the James Beekman House, a historic mansion of Revolutionary days which was demolished in 1874, was unveiled yesterday in Public School 135, at First Avenue and Fifty-first Street. The school occupies the place where the old house stood.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 3. -- Brazil's first Congress elected under the new Constitution was formally inaugurated today.
GREAT NECK, L.I., May 3. -- Lakeville, represented by a strong team and having the added advantage of playing over its home course, swamped Nassau in the opening series of women's team matches today.

PHILADELPHIA, May 3. -- A mysterious new extract from the animal body, which has shown itself in preliminary experiments to act as a substitute for insulin in relieving diabetes, was described here today before the closing sessions of the annual meeting of the American College of Physicians.

After eight years in business, Random House will publish its first new novel in the Fall. The book will be Morley Callaghan's sixth novel, "They Shall Inherit the Earth." Other novels on the Random House list include James Joyce's "Ulysses" and Marcel Proust's "Remembrance of Things Past," but these were known all over the world before they were published by Random House.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 3. -- The Rumanian Minister, Charles A. Davila, was among the luncheon guests of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick H. Prince of Newport at the Greenbrier Casino today. Mr. and Mrs. Prince arrived at the Greenbrier Hotel this morning.

William R. Hayward, principal of the Theodore Roosevelt High School in the Bronx, made out his own time card to show that he had been at work for a full week when he had put in only a total of about eight hours, according to testimony given at his departmental trial before a committee of the Board of Education yesterday.

I was much interested in the article in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine of April 21, entitled "Great and Growing Problem of Leisure." The author inquires what we are "to do about the large amount of leisure that lies ahead." It is also stated that "workdays have been shortened and are likely to be still more shortened in the future."

Reorders for shoes improved slightly this week, but continued disappointing, according to manufacturers here yesterday. While the last few days of the week before Easter saw many shoe stores breaking former records for sales, this activity, failed to make up for the previously disappointing business.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission amended today its instruction book for Form A-2 registration so as to provide for its use by gas, oil and water companies whose service is confined solely to stockholders and which meet certain conditions.

Although new bond financing this week fell far short of last week's total, it amounted to $48,546,000. Corporate financing was again larger than State and municipal -$27,500,000 against $21,046,000. Last week new bonds in the amount of 112,310,000 were marketed.

A get-rich-quick scheme in which 150 men and women, many of them nationally known, were to have been threatened with injury unless they paid large sums, has been frustrated, the Department of Justice announced here yesterday, with the arrest in Bridgeport, Conn., of a $10-a-week butcher's boy.

BERLIN, May 3. -- The conclusion of the Franco-Russian mutual assistance pact, which is considered here as nothing less than the old-fashioned military alliance under a new name, and the increasingly definite stand by Great Britain against Germany's "arbitrary rearmament" have produced such a grave impression in German quarters that anxiety is beginning to seep into the carefully guarded newspaper comment.

PARIS, May 3. -- The tendency which had manifested itself in the last few days on the Bourse continued today, with rentes again declining and equities rising. The movement, in fact, was particularly marked today as the volume of trading showed a distinct increase.
The women's fencing team of the Salle d'Armes Vince retained the national senior championship last night in the competition staged at the Fencers Club.

Principally through the efforts of Van Lingle Mungo, their ace right-hander, the Dodgers got off to a successful start against Western opposition by downing the Pittsburgh Pirates, 2 to 1, at Ebbets Field yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 3. -- The first Beaux Arts ball of Westchester County was held here tonight at the County Centre, under the auspices of the Westchester Arts and Crafts Guild and the Artists and Writers Dinner Club of New York.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 3. -- Charles River Basin tomorrow will be a busy place for the college oarsmen. Seventeen crews from Harvard, Cornell, Syracuse and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology will hold a three-hour regatta in which there will be 153 competitors.

The list of the French liner Champlain, leaving today for Havre, via Plymouth, includes John Van Druten, English playwright; Charles Wakefield Cadman, composer; Gertrude Stein the writer, with her secretary, Alice B. Toklas, and:

The testimony of Dr. John F. Condon before a Bronx grand jury in May, 1932, was made public yesterday to show that he said at that time he was positive that he could identify the mysterious "John" to whom he had paid $50,000 ransom on behalf of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh in St. Raymond's Cemetery on the night of April 2, 1932.

A leading item of next season flashed twice on separate horizons yesterday, to wit: it was made known here that Max Gordon will be co-producer with Sam H. Harris of the musical comedy which Moss Hart and Cole Porter have been writing on their round-the-world cruise.

An entertainment entitled the "Tip-Top Ball" was given last night in the Pierre Roof Garden under the auspices of Auxiliary 5 of Stony Wold Sanatorium. The proceeds will aid the maintenance of the institution at Lake Kushaqua, N.Y., which provides care and treatment for working girls and women afflicted with tuberculosis.

The H.W. Perlman Corporation, which conducts a furniture business in 345-347 Grand Street under a lease, has purchased the building from Celia Schwarz, Rose Hahn and Jessie David, it was learned yesterday. A little more than $56,000 was paid for the property, which is assessed for $78,000, according to Leon Forst, attorney for the sellers.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange hardened again yesterday, the October going to 11 1/2 cents a pound and old-crop positions to within a few points of the high marks made last week. Final gains were l0 to 13 points.

HAMBURG, Germany, May 3. -- American and other yachts that are to race from Newport to Bergen, Norway, will have a German competitor, the Stortebeker, with Captain L. Schlimbach at the helm, it became known today.
ALBANY, May 3. -- Governor Lehman signed two bills today to expedite acceptance by the State of Federal funds for old-age relief and the care of dependent children.

Barney Ross, former lightweight and welterweight champion of the world, arrived in New York yesterday from his home in Chicago, and after spending several hours in town traveled to Ferndale, N.Y., where he will set up training headquarters for his welterweight title fight with Jimmy McLarnin at the Polo Grounds on May 28.

Price movements on the commodity futures markets here were mixed again yesterday. The trading continued light. Coffee was an exception both as to price and volume of trading done. Copper, hides, gasoline and cottonseed oil were higher and other staples lower or irregular.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Imports of silver dropped to $1,350,377 in the week ended April 26, compared with $2,619,195 in the preceding week, showing a restriction of buying abroad by the Treasury during the period of rising prices.

An uncompromising stand against war, included in the social service committee's report to the New York annual conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, provoked a lively controversy in the Eighteenth Street church, 305 West Eighteenth Street, near Ninth Avenue, yesterday afternoon during the second day of the conference.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP). -- A statement by Charlton Ogburn, counsel for the United Automobile Workers, that settlement of the Toledo Chevrolet strike must provide a new auto labor board apparently conflicted tonight with a White House view.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Basic minimum wages for reporters and other editorial department employes of newspapers, ranging from $12.50 to $25 a week according to the population of the city of publication, are provided by an amendment to the Newspaper Code proposed by the Code Authority and approved today by the National Industrial Recovery Board.

CHICAGO, May 3. -- With sixty-nine Illinois counties lacking relief tonight and no assurance of fresh funds from Washington or Springfield, the State capital, drastic steps were taken here for permanent reduction of the number of families on relief.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Conditions incident to the Sakdalista revolt in the Philippines were reported under control, although still uncertain, in a report received by Secretary Dern today from the office of the Governor General in Manila.

A four-run rally in the ninth inning gave Horace Mann's baseball team a 9-to-8 decision over Irving School of Tarrytown on the victor's diamond yesterday. It was the second triumph in as many Eastern Private School Baseball League starts for Horace Mann.

MANILA, Saturday, May 4. -- The arrest of several leaders and the issuance of a warrant for a woman insurgent credited with directing the seizure of weapons from six American sailors to help the rebel cause apparently broke a revolt today in which at least fifty-nine persons were killed.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., May 3. -- Both the plants of the Chevrolet Motor and Fisher Bodies Companies shut down for an indefinite period, due to the strike at Toledo, which stayed the supply of transmissions being shipped to Tarrytown.

While picketing shortly after noon yesterday with striking employes of The American Mercury in front of the Heckscher Building, 730 Fifth Avenue, twenty-one pickets, including seven women, were arrested on charges of disorderly conduct.

Winning eleven of the thirteen events, Columbia's powerful freshman track team defeated the New York University first-year men, 89 -- 28, yesterday at Baker Field. It was the first time in many years that the Lions have toppled the Violet.

The Controller's annual report reveals the largest payments on account of current expenses in the city's history -- $706,000,000, as compared with $645,000,000 a year ago and $517,000,000 in 1929. But $157,000,000 of that was for unemployment relief, an item unheard of in 1929.

The article in THE TIMES of April 24 concerning the taking of intelligence tests by legislators is an excellent idea, in the light of the demands made upon the teachers of this country to take oaths, allegiances and all sorts of test to determine fitness.

There seems to be a sudden efflux of speculation among the Democratic leaders at Washington with regard to next year's Presidential campaign. It might be thought that they had enough troubles on their hands in 1935 without anticipating those of 1936. But it is the nature of man the political animal to look before and after, especially in the United States.
THE Strand is resting up. The London cable, though it would like to offer more, reports only three attractions opening there this week. To get at them quickly:

TO the casual reader the country over Greenwich Village must connote a Bohemia inhabited by writers and artists, living picturesquely though sometimes sinfully, loaded to the Plimsoll mark with gin and genius. This book, "prepared under the auspices of the Columbia University Council for Research in the Social Sciences, in collaboration with Greenwich House," goes far beyond this conception Greenwich Village is far more than an American Left Bank.

WHEN Gertrude Stein became a national institution she incidentally gave readers courage to say they could not understand what they were reading. The custom has spread. Time was when thousands of people claimed "Ulysses" and "The Waste Land" were perfectly clear to them.

The "two-thirds" clause in the section of the Bankruptcy Law applicable to railroads has made difficult for an indefinite period any progress in reorganizing the Missouri Pacific Railroad, according to Eugene J. Conroy, secretary to counsel for the committee representing $224,000,000 of the company's first and refunding-mortgage bondholders.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., May 4. -- Union College students from thirteen fraternities are escorting feminine guests from many States to the various festivities packed into the crowded calendar of the junior prom week-end, which got under way yesterday with the annual "moving-up-day" exercises in the morning, athletic events, picnics and tea dances in the afternoon and the Junior promenade in the evening.

ROCK ISLAND, Ill., May 4. -- Thirty days ago twin daughters were born to Mr. and Mrs. Richard Klinkerman of Los Angeles. Mrs. Klinkerman, the former Miss Elda Parkin of Davenport, Iowa, died a short time after their birth.

PHOENIX, Ariz., May 4. -- Arizona is jubilant over its victory in the Colorado River-Parker Dam dispute because the United States Supreme Court by unanimous vote ruled that the dam could not be constructed on the Arizona side of the river without permission of this State.

TOKYO, May 4. -- A Filipino who said he was "president and envoy of the Sakdalista party of the Philippines" was apparently busy seeking Japanese support for his cause today, but Japanese leaders said flatly he had had no contacts with the Tokyo Government.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- The rather incongruous partnership between certain conservative business and banking groups and the New Deal was publicly dissolved this week, the mists of fear in which it was formed having been absorbed by the sunlight of recovery. A majority of the delegates of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States decided to go back to their economic home.

FOR another week the reports on retail trade were of a disappointing sort. Since Easter, sales have failed to meet expectations even when weather conditions were favorable. Clearances have not brought the response desired.

In three of the five murders recorded in this story, a method is used which defies detection. Even a post mortem fails to reveal the cause of death. Whether this method is feasible is a question for medical experts to determine. All that matters for the moment is that the author has succeeded in making it appear quite possible and that she has built up around it a story calculated to keep the reader guessing.

PANAMA, R.P. -- The lack of enthusiasm in Central America for the Inter-American Highway, which is to make possible an automobile drive from Texas to the Panama Canal, cannot be explained entirely on the basis of a natural apathy of the people or of fear of an imperialistic invasion by the Colossus of the North.

Children at the age of seven should have completely disavowed not only Santa Claus but the entire spirit world, including Easter bunnies and fairies, according to a new "social maturity" scale demonstrated yesterday at the sixth annual meeting of the Association of Consulting Psychologists, held at Teachers College, Columbia University.

Federal Judge Julian W. Mack reserved decision yesterday after hearing argument on an application for the payment of about $250,000 in counsel fees and other charges in conjunction with the receivership of the Manhattan Railway Company.
HANOVER, N.H., May 4. -- The Army track team conquered Dartmouth today, 72 -- 54.

Behind the steady pitching of Ken Norton, the Long Island University baseball team turned back Seth Low at Manhattan Beach yesterday, 8 to 2. Seth Low scored its two runs in the first inning, but was held safely by Norton in the remaining chapters.
One of New York's best known yacht clubs, organized forty-nine years ago, in 1886, last week began the erection of a new and modern clubhouse on a brand new location.

THE old idea that private schools educational country clubs for sons of the rich is becoming out of date. The recent announcement of the Taft School that next year's pupils will have household tasks assigned them only adds to the growing number of private secondary institutions with self-help programs.

A NEW Sultan of the Two Thousand Isles -- the Maldives, a group of coral islets in the Indian Ocean 400 miles southwest of Ceylon, and a British protectorate -- has just been elected. He succeeds Muhammed Shams-ud-Din, who was deposed last October.

THE acid girl in the row behind me, when I saw "The Scoundrel" (Radio City Music Hall), assumed the responsibility for representing the American film public and applied the scalpel of sarcasm to almost every line of the work. In a deafening stage whisper she disliked Noel Coward, Ben Hecht, Charles MacArthur and the picture.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 4. -- Keen rivals for Middle Atlantic States collegiate honors in the championship track events to be held here next week-end, Lehigh and Rutgers today met in a dual meet, which was won by the Scarlet-clad athletes by 77 to 54.

The gardens and grounds of Planting Fields, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. William Robertson Coe in Oyster Bay, will be opened to the public next Saturday afternoon in behalf of the Girl Scouts of Nassau County.
BOSTON, May 4. -- Sixteen students from New York State, New Jersey and Connecticut have been elected to offices in organizations of Simmons College.

TROY, N.Y., May 4. -- Russell Sage College has completed plans for the inauguration of a four-year college degree course in nursing designed to place nursing on a professional basis in line with the recommendations of recent State and national studies.

IF you had to name one show which looms a bit larger than any other on next season's horizon, it might easily be the musical version of "Porgy." Planned by the Theatre Guild for this season and then postponed until next Fall, it has kept off the Broadway rumor circuit. Nevertheless, it has been assembling itself slowly, with results to date as follows:

WHEN the three Emerson brothers, following a lead given to the eldest by a dying Indian who had said there was gold in Thunder Mountain and evil spirits guarding it, actually found great nuggets lying above the ground in that Idaho mountain fastness, they hoped to clean up at least a modest fortune for themselves before news of their discovery leaked out and a stampede set in.

The annual report of the Tennessee Electric Power Company for 1934 refers to the Chattanooga power, referendum, where citizens voted nearly 2 1/2 to 1 for an $8,000,000 bond issue to buy or erect a municipal electric distributing system, as having been directly attributable to the presence and activities of the Tennessee Valley Authority in that section.

ALICE FOOTE MacDOUGALL says that she has ventured to add another to the already numerous cook books already known to the public, because "this is no cook book in the usual sense of the word" and because there was in her heart a great desire to send it forth to the public.

SWEET BRIAR, Va., May 4. -- Sweet Briar College celebrated its twenty-ninth annual May Day Festival on Thursday, and the times of Robin Hood and his Merry Men were re-enacted on the college campus when, for the entertainment of the May Queen and her court, the students staged an outdoor play based on the old English folk stories of Robin Hood in Sherwood Forest.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., May 4. -- The 22-year-old high school graduate and butcher boy who hoped to accumulate a fortune quickly by extorting funds from 150 wealthy men and women said today in jail that he had been aware a week ago that "the jig was up."

SOME two years ago, Dr. H.L. Blumgart of Boston startled the medical world by boldly advocating the complete removal of the over-active thyroid gland in desperate cases of angina pectoris. A few operations were performed under his direction after some very fine studies had been made which revealed much that was new about the velocity of the blood stream and the relation of that velocity to high tension or blood pressure.

THERE is something primarily mural in the work of Paul Meltsner, current one-man exhibitor at the Midtown Galleries. His subject-matter is man against an industrial background -- man, whether employed or idle, become a part of the mechanization he has effected in the world. Sincerity of purpose, directness of approach, a certain obviousness of rhythms and balance in design and clear bright color distinguish this artist's work.
LONDON. TWO food campaigns have been launched in London simultaneously -- "Eat More Fish" and "Eat More Bread."
In your issue of April 21 there appeared an account of a speech by Professor Albert Einstein which contained charges against the Zionist-Revisionists. The professor said, in part:

AMOY, China, May 4 (AP). -- China's women pirates, seldom seen, but famous in song and story along the South China coast, were a grim reality today to 300 terror-stricken Chinese travelers who arrived here aboard the coastal steamer Lokiang.

Although the week's activity on the whole was slightly disappointing and spotty in some departments, other divisions of the wholesale markets here, particularly popular-price dresses and beach apparel, enjoyed increased activity, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by the McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 4. -- G.H. (Pete) Bostwick and his brother, Dunbar W. Bostwick, today registered an upset as match play started in the annual four-ball invitation golf tournament at the Meadow Brook club today.
Uncle Robert came forward yesterday with a reminder to the public that his annual Parents' Day celebration would take place as scheduled next Sunday on the Mall in Central Park.
FLORENCE, Italy, May 4. -- In addition to military preparations visible on all sides, the further an observer penetrates Italy the clearer he sees the people's mind being readied for war.

A series of disorganized uprisings in five Philippine Provinces occurred last week in which about sixty Filipinos were killed. The fighting was instigated by a group of extremists called Sakdalistas, who constitute the only organized opposition to the Quezon-Osmena coalition.

AN American Group -- Stuart Edie (still-life with masks and portrait heads in gouache), Frederic Knight (drawings and a gracious study for a tempera panel), Isami Doi (drypoints and one amusing block print) and Hobson Pittman (some of the best watercolors he has done) are well and typically represented at the Jacques Seligmann Galleries through May 18. Mr. Pittman's work especially displays steadily gathering strength and effectiveness.

THIS book will add strength to the timid contention of some that the technical study of money is a fascinating subject, woefully neglected by the educators. Because of this neglect, it is still the mystery that it is professed to be.

SYDNEY. AT times a huge lake, fourteen miles long, seven miles wide and many feet deep, at others a great sunken oval meadow of luscious grass, surrounded by blue hills, Lake George, New South Wales, was for many years regarded as "Australia's chief mystery."

KAY FRANCIS, having completed her two latest assignments for Warner Brothers in "Stranded" and "The Goose and the Gander," was going away. She had booked passage on the Aquitania for France. The newspapers were notified of the epochal event such a departure would be.

The new treaty between France and Soviet Russia, the text of which was published yesterday in THE TIMES, reflects the growing concern of nations living on the frontiers of HITLER'S Germany. At least for the time being, efforts to assure peace in Europe either through a general or a regional treaty of security have failed.

The annual appeal for funds for the Catholic Charities in the Archdiocese of New York will begin today and will continue for one week. After the formal appeal in all the Roman Catholic churches today, 20,000 men and women workers will make a house-to-house, floor-to-floor canvass among the more than 1,250,000 Catholics of the archdiocese.
CARDINAL MAZARIN had seven nieces and three nephews ripening in the sun of Rome while he was consolidating his position in France. They were part of his scheme to be used when ready."

PARIS, May 4. -- Premier Pierre-Etienne Flandin was severely injured today near Auxerre when the automobile in which he was riding with his family was in collision with an automobile owned by Deputy Jean-Michel Renaitour, who represents the Department of Yonne.

MADRID, May 4. -- Under the leadership of her veteran republican statesman, Alejandro Lerroux, Spain's new regime apparently is working out its salvation by the slow but sure process of trial and error. The Premier's efforts during the past month to reorganize the majority coalition of the Centre and Right parties in Parliament seem on the threshold of success.
BOSTON, May 2. -- The all-day regional Republican rehabilitation conference in Boston on Tuesday probably is taken more seriously outside, than within, New England.

An extension of the service of the speech improvement department in the city's public school system has been outlined in a budgetary memorandum that will be submitted to the Board of Education next week.

The painting and sculpture awards in the twenty-second annual exhibition of the Allied Artists of America were announced yesterday by George Elmer Browne, president of the organization. The exhibition will open with a private showing at 215 West Fifty-seventh Street tomorrow at 8 P.M. It will open to the public Tuesday.
Joe McCarthy, manager of the Yankees, continued to gain ground yesterday in his fight back to health at his home in the Hotel Croydon, where he has been seriously ill for the past week.

RICHMOND, May 3. -- The phenomenon of leading Negro citizens standing at the polls and challenging scores, if not hundreds, of other Negroes who had been herded to the ballot box by white ward heelers was seen in Raleigh, N.C., the other day, when the municipal primary was held.

JACK CONROY'S first novel, "The Disinherited," won him a place among the growing number of realistic novelists who are writing of American life on the proletarian level. This second book, a more closely knit novel, strikes furthest left. Its two distinguishing characteristics are its raw naturalism on the physical plane and its frank message of straight communism.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., May 4. -- Skidmore College will celebrate its annual May Day Saturday afternoon, May 18, with an outdoor pageant which is a dramatization of Dayton Newton's "A Lament of Pan." Dr. Dixon Ryan Fox, president of Union University, will be the speaker Saturday morning at the May Day chapel service, which is an annual tribute to the memory of Mrs. Lucy Skidmore Scribner, the founder of the college.
KENT, Conn., May 4 (AP). -- Princeton's third varsity and second freshman crews made a clean sweep over the Kent first and second boatloads on the upper Housatonic River today.
Completion of the new Fordham greenhouse marks the beginning of plans for the beautification of the campus, which will eventually be converted into an extensive arboretum.

Two ex-convicts, one of whom said he had received commutations twice while serving sentences for life in Sing Sing, were arrested at Broome Street and the Bowery last night on charges of grand larceny in connection with the swindling of a woman out of $1,500 March 2, she alleged, by selling her imitation diamonds as real ones.
WASHINGTON, May 4. -- The United States Government pays 989 salaries of $10,000 a year or more and 7,223 of $5,000 to $10,000.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- A warning that enactment of Title II of the administration Banking Bill would have adverse effects on banks, bankers and depositors, without any compensating advantages, was placed before the House today by Representative Wolcott of Michigan in summing up conservative objections to the measure.

BALTIMORE, May 4. -- Accorded mild consideration but favored by his light impost of 108 pounds, Only One, bearing the silks of Mrs. W. Deering Howe, galloped off with the thirty-first running of the historic Dixie Handicap that had its renewal at Pimlico today before a throng of 15,000.

PARIS, May 4. -- Very little if any of that popular enthusiasm which greeted the Franco-Russian treaty alliance of 1894 accompanied the signature Thursday evening of this new treaty of mutual assistance between the two countries.

THERE is a King who rules the lives of millions of citizens within this Commonwealth of free and independent States. His domain extends from the Carolinas to the Gulf and from Texas eastward to the sea; a land sun-kissed and fertile but often marred with the blight of poverty The name of the King is Cotton.

A strict pacifist program as originally drafted by the Social Service Committee of the New York Methodist Episcopal Conference, was voted down, 86 to 73, yesterday when 500 pastors, their wives and laymen assembled for the third day of the annual conference sessions.

SHANGHAI. -- General Chiang Kai-shek, in orders telegraphed from his new headquarters in Chung-king, in distant Szechuan Province, is again demonstrating his growing authority and his determination to bring the army into good repute.
ALBANY, May 4. -- Governor Lehman vetoed today the Gillen Bill which would have required illuminated automobile license plates.

UTICA, N.Y., May 4. -- A panel of 100 talesmen was drawn today by John W. Hahn, clerk to the Federal court, for the second trial of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer. Jurors will be ordered to report at 10 A.M. May 14 in the Federal courthouse in Syracuse.

THE bewildering list of new annuals offered each year often leaves the gardener who has room for but a few of them at a loss as to which varieties to try. The more limited the number he can use the more anxious is he that those which he does plant shall prove satisfactory. The new things described in this article have all been grown by the writer under ordinary conditions.
Two armed hold-up men staged a daring daylight robbery shortly before noon yesterday in the crowded Times Square station of the B.M.T. subway and escaped with an envelope containing a $1,600 payroll.

The Cleaners and Dyers Board of Trade voted unanimously yesterday at a meeting in its headquarters, 223 Second Avenue to keep the plants of members open and resist the strike of 9,000 men called by the Cleaners, Dyers and Pressers Union.

The New York University rifle team captured the Metropolitan Intercollegiate League championship yesterday by defeating City College and Brooklyn Poly (Day Division) in the shoot-off at the Fordham University range. The victors, composed of Jacobowitz, Lipsius, Metlicka, Parker and Hlavac, tallied 1,366 points.

WASHINGTON, Nay 4. -- Lawyers in half a dozen government divisions sought today to loosen legal knots said to be delaying President Roosevelt's four billion dollar works program. Complications were disclosed to have arisen in the formulation of policies and plans to pursue the course charted by the works bill.

VENICE, May 4. -- Hungary today complicated the preliminaries to the proposed nine-power Danubian conference. Meeting with representatives of Italy and Austria to discuss in advance problems expected to come up in Rome in June, Koloman de Kanya, her Foreign Minister, indicated Hungary would be willing to participate in the later conference only on four conditions that are anathema to the Little Entente.

OPPOSITION is growing apace to the proposal of the Board of Aldermen to license teachers and schools of the arts. The movement began to gain impetus as soon as the matter was brought to the attention of the dancers and there is a more strongly organized sentiment among them than at any previous time.

The recent change in athletic administration at Boston University, in which Dean Frederick Rand Rogers was relieved of all connection with competitive sport and Dr. John Harmon made director of athletics, is interesting. Dean Rogers remains as director of the physical education course.

VIENNA, April 22, 1935. FURTWAENGLER is back in harness once more. The Viennese received him like something heaven-descended, trailing clouds of glory and likewise encompassed with an aura of martyrdom. He was almost unnerved by the tidal wave of popular affection that engulfed him.

Cricketers in New Jersey will open their season next Saturday at Warinanco Park, Elizabeth. The New Jersey State Cricket League, with which the Newark, Paterson, Plainfield, Passaic, St. George of Orange and Union County Cricket Clubs are affiliated, has prepared a schedule of matches lasting from May 30 to Sept. 15.

THIS is the first novel we have had from Miss Bagnold since her delightful "Serena Blandish" was published anonymously about ten years ago. It is a book that is rich with life that has been lived amply and with gracious easiness and that has eventually spilled over irresistibly into art.

SYDNEY. BECAUSE few white people are settled in Northern Australia, several aborigine tribes still roam there under primitive conditions. The tribes move from hunting ground to hunting ground; tribal law is rigidly upheld.

ALBANY, May 4. -- Cooperation among the States for mutual benefit was indorsed today by Governor Lehman in a telegram to John G. Winant in Chicago, president of the Council of State Governments. Mr. Winant was formerly Governor of New Hampshire.

THE beginnings of the Music Box's "Ceiling Zero" date back to the days just after the armistice when Commander Wead, then a plain lieutenant who had graduated from Annapolis in 1916 and who had served on a mine layer in the North Sea during the last year of the World War, went in for naval aviation as a career.

Since the automobile industry is dependent on the continued supply of a large number of different parts, industrial executives were greatly interested in the action taken by the General Motors Corporation last week when a strike at its Chevrolet transmission factory at Toledo threatened to affect the assembly lines.

SIR JAMES BARRIE will be 75 on Thursday. Bernard Shaw is some four years his senior. The other veterans of contemporary English literature are all his juniors. His empire of fame is perhaps not as world-wide as Shaw's, for outside the English-speaking countries he has not always exported well.

The Manhattan freshman track team opened its dual meet season with a 59-31 victory over Gorton High School of Yonkers yesterday on the losers' field. The Jasper cubs captured nine of the ten first places in the meet, failing only to win the high jump.

THESE notes from Napoleon to a bride half his age carry the absorbing interest private mail sometimes assumes when our curious code of sanctions makes it honorable for every one to read it. Their discovery is an event of far more biographical than historical importance.

IN reporting for 1934 the first increase in the State's motor accidents since 1929, Connecticut's Department of Motor Vehicles emphasizes what safety authorities are realizing more forcefully every day: that the worst among the causes of automobile mishaps is the demon speed.

The heroes of sports at Fordham University whose names have been associated with football, baseball, basketball, track and other forms of athletics on Old Rose Hill during the past year, received their due last night.

Applications for home relief, which have consistently declined since the first of the year, dropped from 33,146 in January to 23,777 in April, Edward Corsi, director of the Home Relief Division, reported yesterday to the Emergency Relief Bureau, of which Oswald W. Knauth is chairman and executive director.

ALMOST any week of the season offers those who care for such often-rewarding lucubrations an opportunity to run through the fascinating gamut that stretches between literal and abstract treatment of subject -- this without carrying one's search beyond the immediate panorama of current shows.

With both retailers and manufacturers keenly alert to what will happen to the NRA, both groups are giving serious attention to changes in wholesale buying practices which may develop once the situation is clarified, according to spokesmen for both groups.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 4. -- The Princeton varsity rugby team today overcame the Yale fifteen, 3 -- 0, in a closely contested game on the soggy turf of Bedford Field.

TOKYO, April 20. -- The agitation against holding the American naval manoeuvres in the North Pacific has been 100 per cent American. It has had no counterpart here, because there is no counterpart in Japan to the agencies which haw evoked it in America or the pacifist sentiment from which it springs.

Members of the Executive Committee of the Actors' Fund Matinee Club headed by Mrs. Preble Tucker are active in the sale of boxes and seats for the special performance of "The Old Maid," to be given on Tuesday afternoon at the Empire Theatre for the benefit of the welfare work of the Actors' Fund of America.

IT should be made perfectly clear at the beginning that this is a holiday book. "At least one purpose of these notes," Mr. Morley says, "is to teach myself a little Spanish." And again: "These notes perhaps be useful in showing how little the tourist is likely to learn."

THE Metropolitan Opera is emerging out of the red, if not yet safely in the black, according to those charged with the new deal on musical Broadway. Again a deficit, less than was feared, has been paid by the association.

Three local and near-by units of the United States Power Squadrons reported yesterday to National Secretary William M. Finkenaur that their free instruction courses in piloting and small boat navigation had been completed for the year and that new batches of motor yacht skippers had received certificates.

TORONTO, May 4 (Canadian Press). -- The Toronto Maple Leafs defeated Syracuse, 4 -- 3, today in a twelve-inning game that was ended by Wes Schulmerich's long fly to the outfield after Mulligan weakened on the mound for the Chiefs. Oliver walked in the twelfth and was sacrificed by Morrissey, Chapman and Boone drew walks and Schulmerich then lifted a fly to left, Oliver coming in after the catch.

Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Emergency Relief Administrator, attacked "a small minority of business interests" in an address here yesterday on the ground that they were trying to scuttle President Roosevelt's program for social security and economic democracy.

As the Hamburg-American liner Deutschland came up the bay Friday afternoon to her North River pier a ruddy-faced man in his sixties stood on the deck and expressed amazement at the skyline. It was the first time he had been to New York in almost twenty-five years and the prospect was so different he wondered whether he was approaching the right port.

Details of the affairs of the Public Utilities Securities Corporation, finance company in which virtual control of the Utilities Power and Light Company was vested, have been set forth in an affidavit filed in Wilmington, Del., by Norman C. Norman, holder of 100 preferred shares of the company.

BLIND flying is not blind navigation. Our Federal airways system, while unquestionably the best in the world, does not and cannot serve every hamlet and town. There are only ninety-four airway radio range beacons from coast to coast, serving 18,655 miles of principal air routes.

TORONTO, Ont., May 4. -- The Hudson Bay Mining and Smelting Company has reported for 1934 a net profit of $1,549,612 after charges but before depletion. This was equivalent to 58.4 cents a share. In 1933 the earnings were 31 cents a share.

A box turtle that had been in the family of its proud owner for ten years sedately played the part of tortoise at the pet show of the Home Thrift Association's playground at Eighty-ninth Street and York Avenue yesterday. There was no rabbit to play the hare, but a white rat, shown in harness and on a lead, scampered along swiftly enough to be an acceptable substitute.

Giving effect to the purposes of recent successful refinancing, several corporations last week called large blocks of their bonds for redemption before their dates of maturity. These announcements, in which redemption dates were set for later months, made up the principal calls of the week.

At the quarterly meeting of delegates to the American Kennel Club to be held at headquarters on Tuesday, May 14, the most important business will be consideration of the new rule regarding entries that has been approved by the board of directors.

THOSE of us who hurriedly run through the monumental indexes handed to us by librarians and who suddenly find on opening them all the information we had sought there, on one little square on the page, rarely stop to think of the labor involved in the planning of one of these huge tomes and of the people who have compiled these most useful tools of reference.

After being held scoreless for five innings and losing a 7 -- 0 lead in that time, the Wagner College nine punched over three runs in the ninth to beat Pratt Institute, 10 to 9, yesterday at Wagner Field, Grymes Hill, S.I. Caddy Wasmund doubled to drive in Rocco Zasa with the winning run after Zasa had singled to score Joe O'Reilly and Walton Kibat.

C.H. Knebelkamp's 4-year-old King Saxon proved himself one of the best handicap performers in this country and probably the best at this time when he romped away with the twenty-eighth renewal of the $5,000 added Excelsior Handicap at a mile and a sixteenth at Jamaica yesterday before a crowd of 10,000 racing enthusiasts.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 4. -- Reynolds May of Duke pitched a great game against the Naval Academy today, allowing only four hits -- all singles and in separate innings -- to blank the Middies by 3 to 0.

BECAUSE one of his horses, shot dead, had been found behind the Reyes National Bank and the gang that robbed that bank and killed the sheriff had made free with his name, young Whip Ryder, so called by reason of the whiplike swiftness of his draw, decided in haste that it would be best for him to disappear.

" I was very interested in your recent comments on the swordfish and marlin," writes G.F. Coope from Tocopilla, Chile. "In this part of the world the broadbill or swordfish is quite common and there is a good opportunity to get an opinion based on the experience of the local fishermen, who have captured many thousands of these mighty specimens.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., May 4. -- The Bryn Mawr College glee club will present next Friday and Saturday evening at Goodhart Hall the Gilbert and Sullivan operetta "The Pirates of Penzance." The proceeds will go toward the $1,000,000 fund sought by alumnae to mark the fiftieth anniversary of the college's founding.

VIENNA, May 4. -- When Mrs. Grundy first came to Vienna in February, 1934, coincident with clericalism's political triumph she was extremely busy, not even churchyards escaping her eagle eye. She soon discovered that the tombstone of the Viennese opera singer, Selma Kurz, who died a year ago, bore the marble figure of a semi-clad recumbent woman.

A ninth-inning home run by Arky Vaughan was all that young Cy Blanton needed to break up a pitching duel with old Tom Zachary and give Pie Traynor's Pirates the second game of the series with the Dodgers, 1 to 0, at Ebbets Field yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 3. -- Retail trade in this Federal Reserve District this week was again better than weather conditions warranted, running ahead of last year in spite of cold rains. A special sale, which began on May 1, drew crowds of shoppers to one store in this city, while a furniture sale was unusually successful in another.

DOROTHY McCLEARY attracted a modest amount of attention about six months ago with a short story called "Winter," which appeared simultaneously in two anthologies. It was a fine, full-bodied story, remarkable for its characterization and prophetic, it would now seem, of Miss McCleary's particular gifts.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 4 (AP). -- M. Baumgartner, the prosecution expert in the Jewish effort to convict Swiss Nazis for slandering the Jewish race in connection with the "Protocols of the Elders of Zion," today branded the protocols as "false."
TOKYO, May 4. -- When plans that the Foreign Office is supporting materialize, Japanese newspapers will receive their foreign news entirely through Japanese sources.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- A detailed plan of the low-cost housing and slum-clearance program designed for New York City at a cost of $150,000,000 was handed to the Division of Applications and Information today by Langdon Post, Tenement House Commissioner of New York, as applications for public works projects from all over the country poured into work-relief headquarters.

The establishment of a permanent government agency to supervise a national housing program to be put into effect after the emergency housing measures have fulfilled their aims was urged by Mrs. Mary K. Simkhovitch, president of the National Public Housing Conference, in an interview at the Greenwich House, 29 Barrow Street.

A 30 per cent increase in European travel this month compared with last May is the prospect indicated by the monthly travel survey published yesterday by the American Express Company. Basing its estimates on advance bookings, the company predicts the most active travel movement by motor car, ship and airplane since the peak years of 1929-30.

CARLISLE, Pa., May 4. -- The traditional "Rah-Rah" boy, who goes to college for everything except an education, has passed, and in his place has appeared the student with a more serious mind who is willing to invest his talents in the service of society, Dr. Fred P. Corson declared today in his inaugural address as the twentieth president of Dickinson College.

SPEED, and more speed, seems to be the present-day demand in transportation, and the railroads are answering it. Almost every week they report that some old passenger schedule, formerly thought fast, had been shortened by hours.

PREPARATIONS are going forward for the 500-mile International Sweepstakes at the Indianapolis Speedway on May 30. According to officials of the Speedway, indications point to the largest entry list in many years, with one of the Big Three manufacturers in the industry participating with a fleet of ten cars.

The Maternity Centre Association will give a large buffet supper next Sunday in the Appleton Memorial Mess Hall of the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street. The occasion will be the association's fifth annual Mother's Day' meeting and the speakers will be Alfred E. Smith, Dr. Thomas Parran Jr. and Dr. S.S. Goldwater.

HARVEST," even if somewhat heterogeneous in the matter of contents, is animated throughout by the same unquenchable ardor, infused with the same high spirit of human and literary adventure, which have made the books of Selma Lagerlof respected and loved in many lands besides her native Sweden.

BERLIN, May 4. -- German authorities have taken cognizance of the Czechoslovak charges that Joseph Langsberger, a German emigre, was kidnapped by German agents from Czechoslovak territory near Zelesna Rude and dragged across the German border on April 27.

A STRIKING addition to any group of flowering house plants is the red fuchsia, properly known as fuchsia triphylla. It is not so common or well known as the ordinary purple and red fuchsias, but its clear red flowers are infinitely lovelier.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP). -- With a compromise virtually worked out, Senator Copeland predicted today that his hotly contested food and drug bill would be called up soon before the Senate for final passage.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP). -- Seventy-five "Left Wingers" from eleven States agreed today in secret conference that the time was ripe for the organization of a national liberal third party to drive a wedge between the Democrats and Republicans in 1936.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 4. -- The showing of Greystone, the estate of Samuel Untermyer on North Broadway, Yonkers, next Saturday afternoon will inaugurate the annual garden visits of the Westchester County Children's Association.

LONDON. SOMETHING like a sensation has been produced in literary circles by the prosecution and conviction of a leading London publishing firm for issuing an indecent novel. The defendants pleaded guilty and were fined 100, plus 105 costs.

MRS. Parmenter's latest and most pretentious novel is the story of two Boston families, the aristocratic Kings of Beacon Hill and the workaday Bowens of Roxbury. When Robert King bought some licorice candy from Sandra Bowen, serving behind the counter in a small confectionery shop, he promptly fell in love with her and in a short time married her.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 4. -- Yale easily outscored Pennsylvania, 86 1-3 to 48 2-3, in a dual track meet today. The visitors, however, provided the highlight of the meet by the double victory of Gene Venzke.

LONDON. ENGLAND is always England when it comes to what her daughters wear for the London season. Give them a royal jubilee and they will add extra glamour to the usual tulle, crystal sequins, organdie, mousseline frills and trailing flounces.

A SOMEWHAT protracted American auction season will come to a close in a few days and the scene shifters will be making their annual transfer of the stage machinery from New York to London. Two sales of a highly unusual character to be held at Sotheby's give an advance indication of the possibilities for this Summer's program.

In this picture book Marjorie Flack has added another engaging character to her gallery of lovable canine rascals. This is the chronicle of Topsy, the cocker spaniel puppy, who lived in a store window, waiting wistfully for some one to take her to a real home, hoping especially that it might be little Judy who passed by every day.

ROME, May 4. -- The claims made by some German scientists in pursuit of a theory of the supremacy of the northern races that the origins of Mediterranean civilization are to be found in the migration toward the sunny South of blond Celtic German giants are vigorously refuted by the well-known archaeologist, Luigi Ugolini.

A CHARACTER study rather than a story, Mr. Maxwell's new novel presents a type comparatively little known on this side of the Atlantic. For, while Mr. Wyke Bond was most certainly a snob, he was a snob of a kind which can exist only in an old and well-established social order.

Silver traders were interested last week in following the price of silver around the clock, especially after the Metal Exchange in London began trading in .999 fine silver, the unit in use in this country, as contrasted with silver .925 fine, known as standard silver, which is traded on the spot market in London.
DENVER, May 1. -- Rising silver prices have not brought unmixed joy to the people of the silver States.

ADMONISHING his readers that his modest volume is not a metaphysical treatise, and that it will not trouble itself with the problem of how to be nobler or more spiritual than we are, that it merely will be "concerned with the technique of human happiness," John Cowper Powys chats familiarly out of his own experiences and disciplines on this very difficult subject.

ONE of the prizes every antique collector hopes some day to acquire is a piece of furniture with the label of the maker still affixed, or one linked authentically with a definite cabinetmaker by a bill, inventory or other document. When a table or a chair can be thus connected with a known craftsman, the lore of Colonial cabinet work is enriched and the piece itself acquires higher rating and value.

In the belief that limitations on the installation and use of machinery should be dropped from codes of fair competition as soon as possible, leaders of the steel industry probably will not seek to continue the Steel Code's ban on the construction of ingot capacity, it was said yesterday.
Among the corporations that issued reports of earnings yesterday was the American Zinc, Lead and Smelting Company. The statement covered also the operations of subsidiaries.

ST. THOMAS, Virgin Islands, May 4 (AP). -- Hundreds of excited islanders, including clergymen and local legislators, stormed the United States District Court today for the first public hearing of the Congressional inquiry into Governor Paul M. Pearson's administration of the Virgin Islands.

LONDON, May 4. -- With London like a gigantic mardi gras or a Mediterranean town en fete, the stage is set for the greatest cavalcade of pageantry seen in more than a quarter of a century in honoring on Monday the twenty-fifth anniversary of King George's accession.
VIRGINIA CITY, Nev., May 4 (AP). -- The once slumbering Comstock Lode, from whose depths the bonanza kings took an estimated $500,000,000, is coming to life again to the tune of 77-cent silver.

" My FRIENDS": The reason for President Roosevelt's effectiveness as a speaker, before either visible or radio audiences, was explained last week by Elizabeth McDowell, Associate Professor of Speech at Columbia University. It's his jaw. The professor told a meeting of scientists in New York that the President's long face and wide jaw indicate an exceptional breathing mechanism; they constitute the ideal gear for the production of effective, melodious speech.

Representative John E. Rankin of Mississippi fails to present all the facts about the little city of Tupelo, especially when he says that the citizens paid a "power rate" of 10 cents a kilowatt-hour for their electric service. There never was a "power rate" in that city for the simple reason that there never was any private ownership in Tupelo.

One of the patients in a private sanitarium for the insane complains that she has been robbed of a box containing bonds to the value of $400,000. How it happens that those who had her committed to the institution have permitted her to carry such valuable luggage is not explained, probably because no explanation would make sense.

Yacht racing on Long Island Sound will start on Saturday, instead of on May 24 as had been planned. The American Yacht Club of Rye, through its race chairman, E.A. Hodge, offered the Interclub sloops a chance to show their new rigs with triangular mainsails and loose-footed jibs and will hold contests for them on Saturday and next Sunday.

ON BOARD THE U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA, May 4. -- The United States fleet, which left San Francisco yesterday for extensive manoeuvres, is considerably stronger in ships and planes and fighting strength than the fleet of a year ago.

With a wave of a toy pistol Mayor La Guardia started forty-eight men and women, including two reporters, on a 325-mile seventeen-day hike to Dansville, N.Y., from Broadway and Sixty-fourth Street yesterday morning. The purpose of the jaunt is to strengthen the young and "prevent premature old age" in the older folk, it was announced.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 4. -- An English May Day with a court of twelve members and a queen is the theme of the annual pageant which will be presented as part of Parents Day festivities at the New Jersey College for Women Saturday, May 11, it was announced yesterday by Miss Emily May Phelps, '35, of Montclair, chairman of the festivities.

LONDON, May 4. -- Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler is a marvelous matchmaker. This idea irresistibly comes to the mind of the observer who has the rare opportunity of inspecting the military situation on both sides of the frontier of Italy and France.
TOKYO, May 4 (AP). -- Japan has threatened "drastic action" in North China, alleging Chinese violations of a demilitarized zone, the Rengo News Agency reported today from Hsinking, Manchukuo.

The Society of Stoopnocracy, which was incorporated two years ago to aid the destitute and unemployed, will give a Black Ball on Thursday night in the ballroom of the Delmonico. Although the party is of philanthropic intent, it has been arranged in the facetious vein that has characterized the entertainments given by the society in the past.

City College will mark the eighty-eighth anniversary of the granting of its charter with special exercises on Thursday at the main centre and in the School of Business, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of the college.

ATLANTA, May 1. -- Much of Georgia believes Governor Talmadge is inviting political suicide because of his outbursts against the President and his attacks on administration policies. That he has abandoned any intention of opposing Senator Richard Russell next year seems certain; and this decision, if accurately reported, is considered a wise one, for the Governor's once overwhelming certainty of defeating the present incumbent has passed.

IN the last few years, gardeners in the Northern States have learned to appreciate several relatively new plants from South Africa. Still these flowers are not so well known as they deserve. Many gardeners hesitate to try new things, fearing they will prove difficult.

Palestine today is a country of achievement and not a land of promise, Norman Bentwich, Associate of the High Commissioner for German Refugees and Professor of International Relations at the University of Jerusalem, said last week at a tea given in his honor by the English Speaking Union at 19 West Forty-fourth Street.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 4. -- With two dual meet and Crimson records broken, the Harvard varsity track and field team defeated Princeton, 75 2-3 to 59 1-3, in the Harvard Stadium today.
The Department of Markets made good yesterday the Mayor's recent promise that it would take care of cases or alleged racketeering.

GALLUP, N.M., May 4 (AP). -- Shouts of "liar" and accusations of "frame-ups" on both sides broke up a hospital conference today of Robert Minor and David Levinson with one of the principal investigators of their asserted abduction and abandonment in the desert.

Dr. Abraham M. Russak, a dentist of 135 West 116th Street, was startled when he entered a cafeteria at 116th Street and Lenox Avenue yesterday noon to find lunching there three young men who he said had held him up in his office late Friday afternoon.

Three men, who said they were striking former employes of the James Butler Grocery Company, were arrested last night after windows of four of the chain's stores in midtown Manhattan had been smashed, resulting in minor injuries to three persons.

THE visitor to China is never too busy with his observations of life in the crowded cities to note the junk, China's favorite means of transportation. Whether he halts at Hoosung, the terminal at the junction of the Yangtze and Shanghai Rivers, or continues to Hongkong or Canton, the Chinese boat will remain an important part of what he sees on river and in bay.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 4. -- The electoral campaign reached its climax today with a Belgrade mass meeting of the governmental party. Premier Bogolyub Yeftitch, the chief speaker, dealt with Yugoslavia's foreign and home policies.

SEATTLE, Wash., May 4. -- Frank Dorbandt, noted Alaskan aviator, who died today at Fairbanks, was reborn in Waco, Texas, forty-one years ago and began to fly in 1913 as a pupil of the late Silas Christofferson, pioneer California aviator.
