He had been flying almost continuously since, with the exception of three years spent in the automobile business in Detroit.

BOSTON, May 4 (AP). -- Investigators tonight continued to dismantle the outlaw stronghold used, they charged, by Carl Rettich and his gang as a base for many crimes, including the $129,000 robbery of a Fall River postal truck.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 4. -- The 169th annual commencement of Rutgers University will be held in the Rutgers Gymnasium on Saturday, June 8, it was announced today by Robert C. Clothier, president of the university.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., May 4. -- A three-day celebration of the "Virginia Court Season" at Old Williamsburg, the first of its kind since the restoration of the ancient capital of the State, will begin on May 11 with the arrival of the Governor by coach from Richmond, accompanied by a retinue of mounted "Red Coats."

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 4. -- The raw weather and the early drizzle dimmed in only small degree the gayety of the brilliant box parties, included in which were many of the best known public figures and society folk in America. Brightly colored raincoats, red, green, and even yellow umbrellas, made splashes of color from end to end of the long stretch.

A TRAVELER from New York may reach Teheran in two weeks. The capital of Persia -- now Iran -- is but a four-day trip from Jerusalem, and only eight days by Taurus Express from London or Paris. If one is willing to fly, these times may be cut in half, and there is a first-class air service all the way to Baghdad.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 4. -- Taking firsts in twelve of the fourteen events, the Navy track and field team overwhelmed Virginia in a dual meet today, 90 to 36. The Middies lost only in the 100 and the high hurdles. Joe Patterson stood out for the victors.

The New York University track and field team defeated the alumni aggregation, 78 to 57, at Ohio Field yesterday. The graduates, featuring such former Violet stars as George Spitz, Pete Zaremba and Milton Sandler, compiled nine first places in the fifteen events.

CANTON, N.Y., May 4. -- Laurens Hickok Seelye was elected president of St. Lawrence University today at the annual May meeting of the board of trustees at which Owen D. Young, an alumnus, was present. Mr. Seelye will fill the vacancy to be left by Dr. Richard Eddy Sykes, who is retiring at the end of the present school term after sixteen years as president of the seventy-nine-year-old institution.

WELLESLEY, Mass., May 4. -- Twenty-three hundred years were as nothing at Wellesley College this afternoon when students of Greek presented the "Elektra" of Sophocles in a manner as nearly approximating the original production as research, imagination and hard work could achieve.

In times not greatly remote as geological times are measured, the Yellow Sea of the Asian coast curved into the mainland of China a distance of nearly 300 miles beyond its present shore line. At that time the inland adjacent sea was not much unlike the Gulf of Mexico in shape.

Colonel McTaggart, who has written many books on horsemanship for adults, has here organized his knowledge for the benefit of children, explaining the essential points of riding simply but thoroughly, so that there is little room for confusion in the mind of the young rider.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., May 4 (AP). -- Four persons were killed and Jackie Coogan, famous film juvenile, was injured late today in the sudden plunge of the Coogan car down a roadside embankment in the mountains, fifty-five miles east of San Diego.

HANOVER, N.H., May 4. -- With the retirement of Dr. John W. Bowler from the faculty of Dartmouth after thirty-six years of service, the college loses a man whose biography might well be the history of Dartmouth athletics.

BASLE, Switzerland, May 4. -- The monthly statement of the Bank for International Settlements, issued tonight, shows a rise of 4,000,000 Swiss francs in its gold bar assets, which now total 15,000,000 [the Swiss franc is currently quoted at 32.37 cents].
ST. LOUIS, May 4. -- For the second successive day the frost-bound Yankees were held in idleness today, continuing cold causing another postponement in the series with Roger Hornsby's Browns.

PARIS, April 23. -- Many of the former characteristic Spring activities, and some new ones, are to figure in the great program of entertainment that is being arranged in Paris for the big season. Already the program of racing and other events, from May 25 to July 7, is coming along according to schedule.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- A charge that President Roosevelt was "absolutely unfair" in his criticism of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States was made today by Representative Snell. House Republican leader, who issued a statement asserting that the chamber "tried to follow the President for nearly two years, and during that time he certainly did not find fault with their position."
PHILADELPHIA, May 4. -- Playing in a steady rain, Penn's baseball team broke a two-game losing streak today, beating its traditional rival, Penn State, 9 to 7, on Franklin Field.

HANOVER, N.H., May 4. -- Ted Olson, veteran right-hander of the Dartmouth pitching staff, scored his third successive Eastern Intercollegiate League victory today by turning back Yale, 4 -- 3, in ten innings.

ONE of the most important books on the Fall list of the Bobbs-Merrill Company will be the autobiography of General Giuseppe Garibaldi, grandson and namesake of the great Italian liberator. The book will be called "A Toast to Rebellion," and it will recount the author's adventures in following the Garibaldi tradition in many parts of the world.

THE average port of call welcomes the cruise ship, whose coming means money. Expenditures of the passengers range from large sums invested by the collector of antiques to pennies scattered among street lads who sing and dance and do their best to make the visitors recall the place as "so interesting."

BOSTON, May 4. -- James Roosevelt, the President's eldest son, is going to Washington to work with his father and, incidentally, take another training course in the subject in which he is most interested, politics.

The interest of many younger members of society is attached to preparations for the Spring Ball to be held on Friday night at the Ritz-Carlton. Decorations characteristic of the season will add a colorful note to the main ballroom for the occasion.
WASHINGTON, May 4. -- Increasing power welled up behind the Vinson immediate cash payment bonus bill today as the Senate prepared for a vote on it Monday.

SEATTLE, Wash., May 4. -- Washington State yesterday began the circulation of its own "money," tax tokens worth one-fifth of a cent, as the new retail sales tax of 2 per cent went into effect amid widespread confusion.

PITTSBURGH, May 2. -- With the bill of Senator Guffey of Pennsylvania for Federal regulation of the soft-coal industry now on the calendar, supported by a favorable report from the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee, general interest in the subject is growing.

Scoring four runs in the second inning, Villanova continued its successful invasion of metropolitan diamonds by defeating Fordham, 5 to 2, yesterday on the Ram's field. This one spurt proved decisive in the interesting and keenly-fought contest.

YOUTH would not be denied in the climbing of Minya Konka, that elusive mountain almost 25,000 feet high in the Alps of Western China. From the time of Marco Polo a giant peak had been reported "between the great red basin of Szechwan and the high Tibetan grasslands."

NEW LONDON, Conn. May 4. -- Students of science at Connecticut College held an exhibit of their individual and group projects this week in New London Hall, the science building. Among other things, they showed maps and charts indicating the result of research in several lines, interesting plant and animal specimens collected for study in the botany and zoology courses, and some results of experimentation in chemistry and with foods in the home economics department.

AN engineering student who alternates actual factory or field work with classroom study progresses as far in five years as does the regular theoretical-course student in eight. So the University of Cincinnati announces in its bulletin celebrating thirty years' trial of the cooperative system, which it was first to introduce in this country.

Criticism of the administration for carrying its "good neighbor" policy to the point where foreign nations could take advantage of this country died out in export trade circles last week with announcement that negotiations for a reciprocal trade treaty with France will be opened shortly.
ROME, May 4 (AP). -- The World Cotton Congress decided today the United States would have to modify her cotton program or European buyers would increase their cotton dealing elsewhere.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 4. -- Charging into the lead at the far turn, and never thereafter leaving the result in doubt, William Woodward's Omaha today won the sixty-first Kentucky Derby in far easier fashion than his famous sire, Gallant Fox, also owned by Mr. Woodward. It was the third time the father and son double was completed in this classic mile and a quarter test, which was run in the rain before 50,000 persons.

DELAWARE'S capital has set next Saturday for the annual celebration of "Dover Day," under the auspices of the Garden Club of Dover, when the old mansions and old-fashioned flower gardens of the little Colonial city will be thrown open to general public inspection.

Much antagonistic oratory, plus a set of denunciatory resolutions, demonstrated last week that a large section of business and industry -- that represented by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States -- had come to the parting of the ways with President Roosevelt.

There was a little excitement yesterday at Pier 48, North River, foot of West Forty-fourth Street, when two women and a 5-year-old boy arrived with their baggage to board the North German Lloyd liner Stuttgart, which had just moved out into the river.

AN African Spring in the galleries of New York -- three exhibitions of Negro sculpture and other works going on at once-argues a considerable and increasing public interest in a contribution to the world's store of art which, until recently, had been relegated principally to museums of anthropology and archaeology.

APPROACH of Summer, which engineers forecast as ideal for short-wave communication, is enhancing long-distance reception. During the past week VK3ME and VK3LR in Australia were heard strongly every morning. The channels, respectively, are 9,510 and 9,580 kilocycles.

KING GEORGE V will have reigned twenty-five years tomorrow, and throughout the British Empire his jubilee will be celebrated with public rejoicings. For, in this age of social revolution when so many kings and crowns have been thrust on one side, George V reigns still in the hearts of his peoples -- of many races and colors and creeds.

A composite picture of this year's "typical" graduate of the Columbia School of Engineering reveals a man who is 24 years old, growing bald, is "one-twelfth married" and expects to have an annual income of $3,330 by 1940.

HAMBURG, Germany, May 4. -- The 49-foot entry in the Newport-to-Norway international sailing yacht race starting June 8 was loaded aboard the North German Lloyd steamer Haimon today just before she sailed for Boston. She will be one of the smallest entries ever making the Atlantic voyage, for her beam is only 11 1/2 feet and her tonnage between twenty-two and twenty-four.

In a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES Edward C. Johnson wrote that he had prepared a comparative table which showed that based on total enrolment a greater percentage of R.O.T.C. students entered the advanced course from elective units than from units at colleges where basic military training is a requirement.

AN all-time high was reached in the total of special taxes imposed on motor vehicle owners in the form of Federal, State and local taxes during 1934, according to a survey made recently by the American Automobile Association.
DETROIT, May 4 (AP). -- The Tigers came back today to annex a 5-to-2 decision over the Red Sox for their fourth straight triumph.

DOVER, Del., May 4 (AP). -- Dover housewives trim their gardens, dust their highboys, polish their doorknockers and dress up in stiff skirts and bodices for company next week as this historic capital celebrates its 252d anniversary.

A FAR-FLUNG line of scientists is engaged in what is probably archaeology's most absorbing task. With pick and shovel this army is endeavoring to wrest from the earth evidence that confirms Holy Writ. The archaeologists are seeking to prove that the Bible is not only a book of divine inspiration but is also a contemporary record of history.

THE part of the grounds that is subject to shade, or even to partial shade, always presents a problem. Often, however, it is quite possible to find a satisfactory solution. Sometimes the solution may be such a happy one that the section of the garden which seemed "impossible" becomes one of its most attractive features.
AMARILLO, Texas, May 4 (AP). -- Farmers whistled today and housewives sang while they swept as snow and rain broke the grip of dust storms on thousands of Southwestern acres.

OSLO. IN his new, monumental Life of Edvard Grieg, David Monrad Johansen paradoxically stresses the "thing in music that is not music." And therewith he takes sharp issue with those earlier commentators who have claimed that Grieg began and ended a school in Norway, for this biographer views his fellow-composer of an earlier generation as one of the pioneers in a movement that has not yet found its momentum.

Well-known women of society have entered specimens of their handicraft in the exhibition of "Needlework of Today," which opens tomorrow at the Vernay Galleries, 19 East Fifty-fourth Street, to continue throughout this week. Proceeds will be divided between the Adopt-a-Family Committee and the New York Association for the Blind.

ALBANY, May 4. -- The Assembly of Debaters of the New York State colleges and universities will have its third annual meeting here next Friday and Saturday. It is sponsored by the New York State Conference of Coaches of Debate. The host college is the New York State College for Teachers.

UNDER the auspices of the Federal Government, lakes and streams throughout the country are being surveyed, improved and restocked with game fish. The purpose of this program is primarily to improve fishing facilities so that the American people, with their increased leisure, may be roused to a greater interest in healthful outdoor recreation, and that the resources of streams and lakes may be utilized to the best advantage and aquatic life conserved.

The high cost of living is beginning to worry the trout. Commissioner OSBORNE, as their legal guardian in this State, is sitting up nights trying to figure out how he can meet the increasing expense of providing his special wards at the State hatcheries with a diet that will keep them healthy and content.

FOR the first time in history, buses are running between Baghdad and Mecca. Southward over the Arabian Desert which the old-fashioned caravan took a month to cross, the faithful are now whirled in three days' time with their beards and keffiyehs flying in the wind.

A new technique in fighting Japanese competition was evolved here last week by domestic manufacturers of book matches and furniture upholstery fabrics, who prepared to forestall competition by getting imports restricted before they become a serious factor.

HORICON, Wis. -- Five hundred pairs of ducks with clipped wings -- teal, mallard and canvasbacks -- are exploring their new wild-life refuge here following their liberation at the recent dedication ceremony, which ended thirty years of litigation over the question whether this 40,000-acre area should be a refuge or a farm district.

MONTREAL, May 4 (AP). -- The Royals swept their abbreviated two-game series with the Baltimore Orioles and took a firmer hold on second place in the International League standing today as they triumphed, 4 to 1, behind Chad Kimsey.

PARIS, May 2. -- Fashions in this Summer's shoe styles are following closely in the footsteps of the latest dress fashions. Tiny frills, encircling the throat line or falling over the vamp in a frilled tab, and apron fronts trim shoes which are especially designed to wear with full ruched or smocked skirts.

One of those intergovernmental "incidents" -- which in Europe would have resulted in a flurry of excitement and hasty Cabinet meetings -- took place last week between Canada and the United States. It was disposed of most calmly.

ROCKVIEW, Pa., May 4 (AP). -- In his death house cell, a few steps from the electric chair in which he will die early Monday morning, Robert Allen Edwards, slayer of Freda McKechnie, spent hours today writing a letter to his mother.

Frequent assertions in recent weeks that shelving of a number of controversial bills now before Congress would remove all uncertainty affecting business and release a flood of orders running into billions of dollars for durable goods were scouted here yesterday by industrial and management engineers and other advisers to industry.

THERE is much need for a biography of the eighth President, and any biography of him is welcome. The minor reason is that there are hardly any lives of him. The major one is that to posterity he is the most interesting of the second run of Presidents.

THE 1935 European travel season will see the renewal of the struggle for transatlantic blue ribbon honors with the entrance of the French Line flagship Normandie into service in June. She will be a new member of the rapidly changing passenger fleet of the North Atlantic, in which old familiar "faces" are vanishing.

ALL the principal characters in this novel live in a small Chicago apartment house consisting of three stories and a penthouse. The tenant of the penthouse is Mary Monroe, a former opera singer, and it is she who is shot dead while singing the Massenet Elegie to a piano accompaniment played by Deborah Cavert, a second-floor tenant.

WITH THE UNITED STATES FLEET IN THE PACIFIC, May 4 (AP). -- Somewhere in the Pacific, in the manoeuvres of 153 fighting ships of the United States fleet, distinguished men of colorful careers are playing leading roles.

HIGHLIGHTS of King George's a Silver Jubilee celebration, including two broadcasts by the British monarch, will be short-waved around the globe during the coming week. American networks will intercept the waves from London and rebroadcast.

Victory in the final women's event, the flying rings contest, gave Mrs. There Steppich of Long Island City the women's national A.A.U. all-around gymnastic championship in the fifty-first annual title competition concluded last night at the Twenty-third Street Y.M.C.A.

NORTHPORT, L.I., May 4. -- Mr. and Mrs. Edward Carll of Huntington, L.I., narrowly escaped with their lives today when their thirty-five-foot cabin cruiser, Desire, burned and sank three miles east-northeast of Easton's Neck, near here.
TOLEDO, May 4 (AP). -- Independently organized employes of the Toledo Chevrolet plant tonight expressed their desire to return to work, in a mass meeting attended by 1,600.

POUGHKEEPSIE. N.Y., May 4. -- A musical comedy of revised patterns was presented at Vassar College in the Experimental Theatre tonight. "My Country, Right or Left," a two-act satire of economic implications, was the play. It was written by four students, Muriel Fox, Marie Reed, Suzette Telenga, and Jane Whitbread. and presented -with a special musical score that closely followed the atiric content.
I am reminded, by the many current speeches and writings about the tax situation, of the sheep-shearing on the old farm.
A GENTLE reminder to all -- Mother's Day is just one week off and it is high time for every devoted son and daughter to be thinking of some remembrance to give "her" on that day.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- The Old White art colony opens its 1935 season in the galleries in Paradise Row at the Greenbrier on Friday, showing a group of canvases from the biennial exhibition at the Corcoran Gallery in Washington.

IN this, the second volume of a series to be known by the general title of "The Mirror in Darkness," we can begin to glimpse something of the magnitude of Storm Jameson's latest undertaking. The temper of the times seems favorable to large literary enterprises, and this one bids fair to be among the most spacious of the decade.

PASSENGER lines on regular schedules have studied the methods of cruise operators in an attempt to diversify their routes. Whenever feasible they add a port of call, thus providing a tour flavor. Grace Line ships in inter-coastal service now put in at Central American ports; and new experiences are offered to the transatlantic passenger.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- An order staying the maximum hours provisions of the Shipbuilding and Ship Repair Code has been extended to June 16, the date on which the National Industrial Recovery Act expires, the National Industrial Recovery Board announced today.

GREEN BAY, Wis. -- One hundred years of history and the weight of a score of nationalities moving in to settle Wisconsin have obliterated the State's old military road in some places, but many of the original stretches may still be viewed as its centenary is celebrated this year.

ON a whole vast floor of the great Port Authority Commerce Building almost everything that America has thought of as a spare-time pursuit is now on view. The first annual hobby round-up is being held until Saturday.

Earl Carroll dismissed the company of his second "Sketch Book" at 8:40 o'clock last night at the Winter Garden Theatre, where it has been rehearsing for four weeks. It was the climax of a three-year feud with Local 829 of the United Scenic Artists Union, which contends that Mr. Carroll owes its members approximately $6,000 for services in connection with the tenth edition of his "Vanities" in 1932.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 1. -- Upton Sinclair, like Huey Long, is scanning national horizons. Defeated, after a bitter fight, for the Governorship last Fall, Mr. Sinclair has spent much of his time since then in seclusion, writing and distributing to the nation the hurriedly compiled account of that campaign -- "I, Candidate for Governor, and How I Got Licked."

A RECAPITULATION of aeronautics in the United States for 1934 with something of a forecast of probabilities for this year is a feature of the current issue of Aviation. Edward P. Warner, editor of the magazine and former Assistant Secretary of the Navy for Aeronautics, and his associates are optimistic for the year and the coming years.
In your editorial "Inventors Protest" there is a remark that "In Soviet Russia, for example, there are no patents in our sense."

BRUNSWICK, Me., May 4. -- Forty-eight schools and about 400 students took part in the 1935 Bowdoin College interscholastic one-act play tournament which was recently ended with the presentations of eleven finalists in Memorial Hall here.
Manuel Quezon, president of the Philippine senate, said yesterday that Benigno Ramos, the leader of the Sakdalistas, was "political racketeer" who was taking advantage of economic distress.

SOONER or later, says Henry McBride in the Reuben Nakian catalogue at the Downtown Gallery, "the right statesman meets the right artist, and a step forward into history is made; for however much the written word may be founded on surmise and hearsay evidence, the artist's portrait is a matter of direct observation.

While the United States is restricting the production of cotton, the governments in all other cotton-producing countries are making efforts to increase output. This is revealed by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, the fact-finding body of the Department of Agriculture, in a survey of the world cotton situation.

PHILADELPHIA, May 4. -- The only portrait of George Washington painted from life by Rembrandt Peale has just been received by the Historical Society of Pennsylvania as a bequest from the painter's great-granddaughter, Mrs. Clara Reeves Henry of San Mateo, Calif.

SARABAND FOR DEAD LOVERS" is not history, and Helen Simpson herself is the first to deny it. For as she says, "every one knows, who has tried it, that history will not fit into fiction without some little adjustment here and there, a tampering with the letter in order that the spirit may have a better chance."

Edward J. Reilly, former defense counsel for Bruno Richard Hauptmann, took steps in Brooklyn Supreme Court yesterday to collect $22,398.82 from Mrs. Anna Hauptmann as his fee and expenses for services during the trial of Hauptmann in Flemington, N.J.
TRANSPORTATION of either freight or passengers has always been a difficult problem in the northland. Modern science has eased the burdens somewhat, but the problem remains difficult.

KATE CHASE -- a name of magic for any one who knows, either by memory, tradition or reading, the social and political world wherein she shone for so many years, a resplendent figure, beautiful, regal, famous.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 4. -- The Syracuse varsity eight, hitherto considered an unknown quantity, scored an important triumph in its first test of the season by winning the quadrangular regatta on the Charles today, defeating the crews of Cornell, Harvard and M.I.T.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP). -- Growing sentiment to require foreign nations indebted to the United States to furnish new security which could be sold on world money markets was evidenced today on the Senate side of the Capitol.

When it comes to grueling sports events with sheer thrills and real dangers the motor boat world points to a marathon outboard race as its idea of something awesome. A week from today about a hundred contestants will come skimming down the Hudson in frail hydroplanes.

ISTANBUL, May 4. -- Violent earthquakes spreading death and destruction over Turkey today were reported to have caused Mount Ararat, the 17,000-foot Armenian peak where tradition says Noah's Ark landed, to rumble with volcanic activity.

Francis McHugh, 20 years old, of 1,338 Bergen Street, Brooklyn, who has been receiving treatment for a mental disorder, confessed to the Brooklyn police yesterday that he had set more than twenty fires in his own borough and three in Manhattan in the last few months.

With National Cotton Week scheduled to get under way tomorrow, a last-minute rush for display material was experienced at the offices of the Cotton-Textile Institute last week, C.K. Everett, in charge of the New Uses Section, reported yesterday.

STOCKHOLM. WITH one year of endeavor behind it, the Swedish State Theatre, described at greater length in these columns last July, is now taking stock. Also some plans for the Summer have been announced, and for the first time companies from the State Theatre will tour the road and give performances in the parks during the luminous silvery nights that give Scandinavia its specific atmospheric brand of "White Theatre."

THE Interborough Parkway is scheduled to open for traffic on June 1 between Queens Boulevard and Metropolitan Avenue, it is reported. From this point into Brooklyn a temporary detour will be necessary for the rest of the Summer.

ACEL STECKER, unemployed musician, turned hobo, tramp, train rustler, member of America's vast army of hungry men, emerges from Mr. Anderson's pages as a man whom you know better than your best friend.

Senator LA FOLLETTE, Speaking over the radio a week ago, made a number of statements, regarding British taxation and our own which must certainly have given a false impression to the majority of his hearers. He accused the advocates of a balanced budget of inconsistency, holding that such people opposed drastic increases in taxes on the rich.

With Eulace Peacock, national pentathlon champion and recent dash and broad jump victor at the Penn relays, showing the way, Temple University's track and field team defeated City College, 85 -- 41, yesterday in their annual dual meet at the Lewisohn Stadium. The triumph gave the Owls a 5 to 4 edge in the nine-year series.

A unified, statewide employment service to select workers for relief projects according to occupational fitness was recommended to Governor Lehman yesterday by his Commission on Unemployment Relief, of which Allen Wardwell, attorney, is chairman.

THE question "What makes a good movie title" has never been completely answered. In the opinion of most producers, apparently, readers of books and playgoers are susceptible to a wholly different kind of appeal from screen fans.

NEWARK, N.J., May 4. -- Making three faultless rounds to score a signal triumph, the Second Corps Area team tonight won the military team jumping competition, feature of the day's double program of the fifteenth annual Newark Horse Show in the Essex Troop Armory.

Holders of $13,398,432 of F-1 guaranteed mortgage certificates issued by the New York Title and Mortgage Company authorized Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler to name Francis Martin, Robert McC. March and James I. Clare, trustees of the issue, it was announced yesterday.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., May 4. -- Notified today of his election as new president of St. Lawrence University, Laurens Hickok Seelye, at his present home here at 45 Elm Street, lauded the liberal policies in St. Lawrence University and said it was with regret and anticipation that he was accepting his new appointment.

The net was tightened around New York's public enemies, the gangsters, last week when Governor Lehman signed the bill which gives New York City the right to approve pistol permits issued elsewhere in the State before they are recognized as valid within the boundaries of the city.

WARRENTON, Va., May 4. -- Indigo, a blue gray gelding, by Stefan the Great -- Malachite, carried the purple and white silks of the Northwood Stables to triumph in the fourteenth running of the Virginia Gold Cup today.

LONDON, April 28 (By mail) -- Mrs. Violet Van Der Elst, the London widow who does not believe in hanging murderers and who has started a campaign to abolish the death penalty in Great Britain, is spending $20,000 a week trying to alter this law.

LOS ANGELES, May 4. -- Japanese electric light bulbs were barred from this country in a decision rendered by Judge Paul McCormick in Federal court here today in favor of the General Electric Company in an action against a group of Japanese distributers.

The reasons that impelled Congress to set up the Civilized Trade Practice Administration in the early Summer of 1936 are easy to grasp. Something had to be done to cope with the ravages of cut-throat competition among opponents of the competitive system.

A Spencer Felz and Christopher G. McGrath, chairmen of the Education Committees of the New York State Senate and Assembly, were guests of honor at a luncheon celebrating the third anniversary of the Hunter College Instructors Association held at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday afternoon.

To THE TIMES and its correspondent, F. Raymond Daniell, must go the thanks of all thoughtful Americans for an excellent series of articles on the plight of the Arkansas share-croppers. Mr. Daniell has given a true and faithful account of the peonage of the plantation, of night-riding and other acts of terrorism employed by the planters to maintain their hold, and the attitude of supposedly respectable elements of the community toward these things.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 4 (AP). -- Carrying banners declaring "relief stations must not be closed," unemployed groups today picketed dispensaries still open here as a skeleton State organization attempted to supply minimum food and medical needs for the 1,200,000 persons on its rolls.
A further improvement in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday ended with gains of 3 to 10 points after the July had sold within a few points of 12 cents a pound and October above 11 1/2 cents.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 4. -- Business in the Sixth Federal Reserve District this week continued its steady climb. The recession in buying demands which followed the heavy Easter season apparently was brief, as retail and department stores in the area reported substantial gains in sales as compared with a year ago.

THE trend toward important and serious elements of literature and history, that current phenomenon of the screen, will not abate, but is destined to expand with the raising of the mental ceiling of audiences and eventually will embrace the more remote phases of fact and writing.

ANY woman who is fed up with housekeeping, taking care of the children, or an office job, will find enjoyable wish-fulfillment fiction in "But For Her Garden." Its heroine, Judith, is beautiful, magnetic, and talented, but the willing reader will find this no impossible handicap in identifying herself with that resourceful lady and her eventful career.

Adverse weather again affected retail trade in the metropolitan area last week. While sales increases over a year ago were achieved, the gains were under expectations for this period. Revised estimates on April trade indicate a gain for that month of from 4 to 7 per cent.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- In a revolutionary departure from all previous custom, American clubwomen are preparing to stand up and be counted next month on such highly controversial issues as birth control, lynching, universal finger-printing and dictatorships, including fascism, as well as communism vs. democracy.

LOWELL, Mass., May 4 (AP). -- The 139th New England Methodist Episcopal Conference today adopted a resolution warning of the "approaching menace" of fascism and charging the American Legion and other patriotic organizations with "sponsoring" it through State and local channels.

CHICAGO, May 4. -- Intense dislike for the sales tax, dissatisfaction with the administration of relief by the Illinois Emergency Relief Administration and a strong belief that Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Relief Administrator, is trying to make Illinois pay for the deficit in relief contributions of other States are the factors chiefly responsible for the deadlock of the State and Federal Governments that threatens hunger for 900,000 dependent unemployed in Illinois.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 4. -- The Maxwell School of Citizenship and Public Affairs, Syracuse University, will eliminate the senior thesis from its graduation requirements, becoming the second unit in the institution to adopt the comprehensive examination.

Trends of bonds on the Stock Exchange were mixed yesterday. In the two-hour trading period United States Government bonds finished generally easier, domestic corporation liens were steady, foreign loans showed minor price fluctuations. Trading was active for a Saturday, amounting to $6,535,000, of which transactions in Government bonds accounted for $1,246,500.

Miss Alice E. Mertz is director of social case work of the Home Relief Bureau, a job paying $70 a week. In that capacity she signed an order directing that only one person in a family might receive work relief. When she signed the order, she admitted last week before the aldermanic committee which is investigating the administration of relief, her husband, Henry Miller, was on the public bounty payroll at $29 a week.

THE provinces of France enter objection to the popular idea that the possessions of the galleries of Paris constitute the nation's treasury of fine arts. The visitor to France whose interest centres in painting and sculpture is in serious error if he considers the storehouses of the Louvre the end of his path, say the provincials.

Many dinners were given last night at the opening of the Summer garden of the Pierre. George Ehret and his brother, Louis J. Ehret, gave a dinner for Mr. and Mrs. F. Bartholomay Jelke, Mr. and Mrs. George S. Steele, Mr. and Mrs. Sigourney Thayer, Miss Alice Andre, Miss Frances Munn, Miss Mary Munn, Frank Rediker, Robert D.L. Gardiner and Alexander Tarsaidze.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- Debits to individual accounts, as ported to the Federal Reserve Board by banks in leading cities for the week ended May 1, aggregated $9,277,000,000, or 33 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week, which included five business days in some of the reporting cities, and 9 per cent above the total for the corresponding week of last year.

The cosmopolitan character of New York City's population creates definite health problems here, it is said in the Quarterly Bulletin of the Health Department, made public yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health. It is not generally realized, the bulletin says, that the city's population is exceeded by but three States -- New York, of which it is a part, Pennsylvania and Illinois.

BEHIND a table of statistics kept by Lloyd's Register of Shipping, Karl Baarslag saw a good story. In 1904 the percentage of American tonnage lost at sea was 1.20, foreign tonnage lost 1.54. In 1933 the American percentage had dropped to .21, the foreign to .50.

The strange doings recorded in this story begin with the hearing of the will of Horatio Walters, known because of his scientific attainments, as the "Wizard." The will is not read by the family lawyer as is customary, but its provisions are made known to the heirs by the deceased himself through the medium of a sound picture which he has caused to be prepared some time before his death.

Competition on out-of-town cinder paths will lure many of New York City's schoolboy track athletes on Saturday. A large proportion of them will travel to Troy to see action in the fourteenth annual Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute interscholastic meet, while others will visit White Plains to participate in the Westchester relays or will go to Garden City for the St. Paul's School invitation games.

During the brief trading period yesterday the share market followed up the advantage gained on the day before, with trading interest shifting a bit to include new groups. For example, a rather marked demand appeared for sugar and oil stocks.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP). -- Congressional leaders, split widely over the NRA's future looked definitely today toward the nine justices of the Supreme Court for guidance in determining how long and how powerfully the new Blue Eagle will reign.

Because of the major influence it will have upon trade during the second half of the year, and upon retail buying plans for Fall, which will be formulated soon, the $4,800,000,000 work-relief program of the President is being intently watched by retail executives.
LONDON, May 3. -- It has been an exhausting week for any one who has had to push through the crowds that have streamed to London from all parts of the Empire for King George's silver jubilee.

VATICAN CITY, May 4(AP). -- For the first time the Holy See and Japan are to enter into diplomatic relations, prelates reported today. They said the establishment of a Nuncio in Tokyo to replace the Apostolic Delegate and the establishment of a Japanese Embassy or Legation to the Vatican were imminent.

WHAT an opportunity the King's jubilee is going to give the women of England to indulge their fancy for fashion! "The Colonel's Lady and Judy O'Grady" cannot fail to don some sort of finery in celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of their rule of King George and Queen Mary.

IT seems that Chief Little Wolf, the Redskin wrestler, who plans to scalp, tomahawk or otherwise distort Dick Shikat on the mat at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night, couldn't keep his mind on his work yesterday. He said his spirit was not in the stuffy gym but was roaming in the happy horse country of Kentucky on Derby Day.

BERLIN, May 4. -- The upward movement on the Boerse continued today, aided by favorable industrial reports. Gains of one to two points were frequent, in some instances reaching three. Heavy industrials were strong, rising up to two points.

IN her apartment in the Avenue d'Iena. Paris, Elsie de Wolfe has a bathroom which has achieved fame and is the joy of her heart. Ambassadors, statesmen, famous artists and authors, even royalty, have admired it and have enjoyed tea parties and after-dinner coffee surrounded by its beauties.

LONDON, May 4 (AP). -- The Bolton Wanderers' late drive to regain their first-division status proved successful today as they qualified, together with Brentford, to play in the major English Soccer League next season.

Fear that the food industry is headed into a period of "profitless prosperity," with steadily rising sales volume offset by contracting profit margins, was expressed here yesterday by manufacturers and distributers who despair of finding a means to check the wave of price-cutting in various divisions of the industry.

IN his book of memoirs, "My Life and Art," Constantine Stanislavsky of the Moscow Art Theatre fame relates the following episode: On one of their tours in the provinces some members of Stanislavsky's company happened to be walking in a park.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- The tense debate over the proposed Banking Act of 1935 is drawing toward a close in the House, but a stiffer test is expected when the bill emerges from committee into the Senate. The fight centres chiefly around Title II of the bill, which would constitute the Federal Reserve Board upon a new basis and state in new phraseology the purposes for which it should work.

OMAHA, Neb., May 2. -- Secretary Wallace and Agricultural Administrator Davis are again asking Middle Western farmers, "Do you still love us?" They will get their answer May 25 in the referendum on the question, "Are you in favor of a wheat production adjustment program to follow the present one, which expires with the 1935 crop year?"

ATLANTIC CITY -- An unprecedented attendance of early vacationers are enjoying the ideal weather month of the year here and are in the midst of a busy round of social and sporting events, exhibits and conventions.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 4. -- Hun School and Manhattan College crews divided honors in two one-mile races on Lake Carnegie today. The Hun varsity beat the Jasper freshmen by five lengths after the collegians' third varsity gained a close victory over Hun's seconds.

GARISHLY retitled for American consumption -- in England it was published as "Dark Encounter" -- Miss Craig's second book is far more earnest than it sounds. Like its predecessor. "When Adam Wept." it is a curious blend of romance and problem novel, brightly up to date in many respects but in others old-fashioned and almost naive.

ALBANY, May 4. -- Leading physicians of New York State will gather in this city for the three-day session of the Medical Society of the State of New York, convening on Monday, May 13. This will be the 129th annual meeting of the society.

For two hundred and ninety years seafarers in all manner of strange craft have been scooting into Saugatuck River and Westport Harbor when the prevailing southerly winds on the Sound blew too vigorously. A Summer like the one ahead will find hundreds of yachtsmen on holiday week-ends investigating the anchorage in this famous Connecticut territory that was settled in 1645.

TURNING from her psychological study and interpretation of the modern woman, as set forth in her "Way of All Women," which attracted favorable attention last year, Dr. Harding takes up in this new book a theme that has demanded much research in worldwide myths and legends concerning the moon.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., May 4. -- A last-period drive which netted four goals enabled the Baltimore A.C. lacrosse team to break a 4-all tie and turn back the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club ten, 8 to 4, today. The setback was the first for the Crescents in four starts this season.

Young women headed by Miss Virginia McGuire are aiding in the sale of scats for the performance of "Ceiling Zero" tomorrow night at the Music Box which has been taken over to raise funds for the Catholic Centre for the Blind. Serving with her are the Misses Angela Morgan, Jane Ryan, Matilde Mittendorf, Emma McGuire, Nancy White, Rosalie Kennedy, Greta Stafford and Carmel White.

THE iris is almost as universal a favorite as the rose, and there are few gardens in which, in one form or another, it is not represented. Many gardeners realize, however, that irises may readily be had in bloom for weeks on end, instead of for the usual all too short season.
WASHINGTON, May 4. -- Statistically speaking, says Paul Popenoe of the Los Angeles Institute of Family Relations, there are "very few" bachelors over 35 "who are yet worth marrying."

One of the cases affected by an erroneous ruling of the Bureau of Internal Revenue in connection with the 5 per cent excise tax upon dividends, enacted in the National Industrial Recovery Act, came to light within the last week in an obvious attempt by the Commissioner of Internal Revenue to collect the tax directly from the stockholders of the Consolidated Gas Company of New York.

DR. HARBAGE has admirably succeeded in his purpose of presenting "as an individual" one of the most woefully "neglected or misunderstood" figures in English literature. His biography of Sir William Davenant is soberly luminous and humanly interesting, as it is solidly grounded on research.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 4. -- The Hill School today won the Class A division of the thirty-ninth Princeton interscholastic track and field meet in Palmer Stadium with a total of 43 points. Twenty-five of these were registered in field events as Hill retired the Princeton interscholastic trophy.

PARIS, May 4. -- Eleven and a half million voters will elect 450,000 municipal councilors tomorrow in 38,014 communes in France. As their vote is believed to represent the political tendency in the country, a great deal of interest is attached to it.
ALBANY, May 4. -- Governor Lehman signed bills today creating a State "Scotland Yard" and the Queens-Midtown Tunnel Authority.

BELIEVING that the achievements of Catholics during the Colonial period of America have not received their due of attention, the author, who has been for many years Professor of Ancient, Modern and Ecclesiastical History at the Catholic Foreign Mission Seminary. at Maryknoll, New York, has prepared this book to remedy what seems to him to have been an injustice.

RICHMOND, Va., May 3. -- Such barometers as month-end reports of revenue receipts, customs collections and bank clearings indicate that the Fifth Federal Reserve District in April had exceptionally good business conditions in comparison with those a year ago.

THE heights of the Himalayas, always a challenge to man, are soon to be attacked on four fronts. The British Mount Everest expedition is already on its way, and the Government of India has granted authority to Dutch, German and French explorers to conduct assaults on peaks of the Himalayas and the Hindukush.
SHANGHAI, May 4 (AP). -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, determined to make China an air power of the first magnitude, is stepping up activity along all fronts of aviation development.

The lightweight championship of the world will be the stake when Tony Canzoneri opposes Lou Ambers at Madison Square Garden on Friday night. The pair will meet over the fifteen-round route, and the winner will receive the recognition of the New York State Athletic Commission and the N.B.A. as the 135-pound titleholder.

It was a very lonely but plucky young American girl who stood in the Strasbourg station one early Winter's evening, waiting for her relatives to welcome her to Alsace. Sixteen-year-old Christian Ford, left alone in America by the death of her father, had made arrangements to live with the elderly Alsatian cousin who had brought up her long-dead mother.

MOSCOW, May 4. -- The Red Army paraded 3,000 planes and nearly 3,000 tanks before the Russian public in May Day celebrations in various parts of the Soviet Union, according to official figures made public today.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP). -- The recent international flurry over a proposal to establish an American air base near the Great Lakes was described today by a leading congressional student of military affairs as "much ado about nothing."

Gertrude Stein, American novelist who lives in Paris, sailed yesterday for Havre on the French liner Champlain after a six months' visit to her native land -- the first in thirty-one years -- during which she traveled all over the United States and lectured in thirty-five universities.

Sharp differences between buyers and manufacturers over schedules of price increases put into effect ten days ago precipitated threats of a buying strike in the wholesale chinaware markets last week. Buyers, as yet unorganized, are awaiting the return from Europe of several leading retail representatives before presenting demands that the producers modify the price increases and reduce the volume spread set up in the new schedules.

Plans for the Sixth Avenue subway are being rushed, in view of Mayor La Guardia's recent announcement that the city would find a way to finance it, whether the $57,000,000 PWA loan for the project were forthcoming or not. His statement, Mr. La Guardia let it be known, should not be construed as showing any lack of faith that Federal aid for this important link would be available.

The announcement last week that Germany is planning the construction of submarines opens a new chapter in the European armaments race. Great Britain has already voiced her alarm, and throughout the world naval officers and civilians are watching with interest the development of the Third Reich's new undersea craft and carefully scrutinizing their own submarine forces.

GENEVA, May 4. -- Steps toward important talks and possibly preliminary negotiations in September among the great democracies about their economic and monetary difficulties have been very quietly taken among some influential members of the League of Nations Economic Committee, the regular session of which has just ended.

GASTRONOMIC experts are usually pretty gloomy about the easy-going indifference of Americans to their food, so it must have heartened them to hear recently that apple pie had been made an issue in Congress by Representatives of rival States.

BOSTON, May 4. -- Bill Walker, slim left-hander of the world champion St. Louis Cardinals, pitched a fine three-hit game today and let the way to a 3-to-0 victory over the Braves in the delayed series opener.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 4. -- Creation at Harvard University of a new Doctor of Philosophy degree in the "History of Science and Learning," designed to meet the increasing demand for teachers in this field, is announced by President Conant.

Since March 11, when the Treasury announced its plans for retiring national bank notes from circulation through the redemption on Aug. 1 of the bonds bearing the circulation privilege, national banks have made marked progress in transferring to the government liability for this form of currency. Only a relatively small number of the notes have actually been retired, however.
The following table shows some of the important dividend meetings scheduled for this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange and the last distributions ordered by the directors:

In the address that he delivered before the American Geophysical Union, Mr. F.E. MATTHES of the Geological Survey presented evidence that the glaciers of the United States are melting away faster than ever, and this because of last year's abnormally hot Summer.

SHUNYO YANGAWA'S delightful and distinguished story of a modern Japanese family can dispense with the modest apologies set forth on the jacket. The "seemingly redundant material" and the "peculiar idioms" retained, as the publishers tell us, "to preserve the true flavor of the original," contain nothing that could be wished away.

Because tomorrow there will be celebrated in London and throughout the British Empire the silver jubilee of the reign of George V. King of England, clergymen here will pay tribute to the King in their sermons. Many will dwell upon the good feeling between Great Britain and the United States.

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, May 4. -- "We are certain the vast majority will vote my Opposition list tomorrow," said Dr. Vladko Matchek, leader of the Croat Peasant party and president of the Opposition bloc, in his simple office at the Zagreb party headquarters today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 4. -- Navy today defeated Yale, 24 -- 6, in the first lacrosse game ever played here by the two institutions. Ward, Schact, Parham and Nibbs totaled eighteen of the visitors' goals. John Warner registered two goals for Yale, to lead his team.

GENEVA, N.Y., May 4. -- Hobart's commencement exercises, which will be held this year on the weekend of May 25-27, mark the close of the first year of the new "Hobart plan." The graduation exercises this year will be two to three weeks earlier than in most other colleges.

ESSEX, Conn., May 4. -- Mrs. Helen Hill of Larchmont, N.Y.; W.L. Inslee of Montclair, N.J.; George E. Ratsey of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and H.M. Baker of Huntington, L.I., all western Long Island Sound sailors, led in the class racing today in the opening session of the Essex Yacht Club's annual Spring dinghy regatta.

TO those who believe, as this writer does, that the fewer conductors a great symphony orchestra plays under, the better the chances for finished and authoritative performance, the announcement of the Philharmonic-Symphony's plans for next season is heartening.

PHILADELPHIA, May 3. -- Business has been well sustained for the last three months in the Third Federal Reserve District, according to the Federal Reserve Bank. There is such a great variety of industries in the section that the report has encouraged both manufacturers and distributers.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 4. -- The P.M.C. polo team today counted twice in the final chukker to beat the Princeton riders by 7 -- 5 on Devereux Field.

IT is indeed a privilege to have outspread before us so ample a selection of etchings and lithographs by Jean-Louis Forain. This show is being held, until May 24, at Knoedler's and should prove an event of peculiar interest. Many of have long been conversant with the graphic work of this admirable French artist.

LISTED first among President Roosevelt's work relief projects, the Federal program for highway construction and grade-crossing elimination is considered the greatest plan of its kind ever launched by any nation. Combined with Federal and State funds already authorized, the program involves an outlay of over $1,500,000, 000 during the next two years.

The theory that persons past 45 cannot assimilate knowledge with the same facility that younger persons do was discounted by Professor Edward L. Thorndike of Teachers College, Columbia University, in a survey on "Adult Interests," just made public.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 4. The New York Rugby Club scored a 10-6 victory over the Harvard fifteen at Soldiers Field today.

THE route of Britain's royal couple, to the formal ceremonies at St. Paul's Cathedral tomorrow, opening the jubilee year, is like that of the traveler on his first visit to London. What tourist has not marked as "must" Piccadilly, Pall Mall, Trafalgar Square, the Strand, Fleet Street and Ludgate Hill?

With sulky skies overhead and a cold rain threatening momentarily, officials of the Giants and the Cincinnati Reds yesterday postponed the scheduled second game of the Western invasion at the Polo Grounds. The game will be played as part of a double-header on June 11.

FOUR Balkan nations-Greece, Turkey, Rumania and Yugoslavia signed a non-aggression pact on Feb. 9, 1934, a loose bond, to be sure, but one that seemed likely to promote peace among the polyglot peoples of Europe's unsettled peninsula Yet before the pact was a year old the war trumpets had sounded, and two months ago they were heard again.

A card party and dance for the benefit of old St. Andrews Church, in Duane Street, opposite City Hall, the pastor of which is Mgr. William E. Cashin, former Sing Sing chaplain, will be held on May 24 in the Hotel Commodore. Arrangements for the affair will be completed at a meeting of the committee in the hotel next Tuesday evening.

WASHINGTON May 3. -- The United States Chamber of Commerce, which went on record this week as opposed to certain measures put forward by the New Deal, is no more interested in the brawling aspects of politics than it is in lobbying.

BOTH the group exhibition at the Rehn Gallery and that at the Montross (current until May 31 and May 11 respectively) were referred to in a glancing way earlier in today's survey of the week. Work by third-three artists is included in the Rehn exhibition.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- The United States is committed to, and is carrying out, a silver policy that stops short only of free and unlimited coinage. Unless silver is forced to $1.29 an ounce first, the program calls for the acquisition of the metal until, valued at that figure, it is equal to one-third the nation's gold stock.

With sulky skies overhead and a cold rain threatening momentarily, officials of the Giants and the Cincinnati Reds yesterday postponed the scheduled second game of the Western invasion at the Polo Grounds. The game will be played as part of a double-header on June 11.

A card party and dance for the benefit of old St. Andrews Church, in Duane Street, opposite City Hall, the pastor of which is Mgr. William E. Cashin, former Sing Sing chaplain, will be held on May 24 in the Hotel Commodore. Arrangements for the affair will be completed at a meeting of the committee in the hotel next Tuesday evening.

FERA allotted $82,000,000 last week to the States for relief of unemployment during May. This compares with $114,000,000 in April and with $133,000,000 in March. The trend is downward, but a precise comparison cannot be made for the reason that funds for May have not yet been allotted in the case of seven States.

LONDON, April 12. TO playgoer who looks back over the theatre's recent past it is clear that among its most conspicuous changes has been the substitution of revue for musical comedy. Musical comedy is not altogether clone with; there are revivals now and then and even now pieces that may claim the title; but the day of "The Merry Widow" and "The Dollar Princess" is over.

A NEW type of double-frame construction, which is said to provide additional strength and rigidity, is the main feature of the newly introduced Dodge and De Soto convertible coupes. It consists of the regular chassis frame six inches high, and a subframe, four inches high, built inside the body.

THE Soviet customs authorities permit foreigners to bring in certain personal possessions, such as typewriters and cameras, duty free on condition they take them out when they leave. Such items are simply entered on the traveler's passport.

ON a basis of six parts take two of biography, two of history, one of tradition and one of author's comment and garnish with a spice of fictionesque narration and you have about the formula on which Mr. Finger's unique book is constructed.

BERLIN, May 3. -- For still another week nothing seems to have happened to arrest what has been characterized as the "galloping deterioration" that has recently afflicted European relations. Yet the fact is that rarely have the European chancelleries been busier.

FERA allotted $82,000,000 last week to the States for relief of unemployment during May. This compares with $114,000,000 in April and with $133,000,000 in March. The trend is downward, but a precise comparison cannot be made for the reason that funds for May have not yet been allotted in the case of seven States.

LONDON, April 12. TO playgoer who looks back over the theatre's recent past it is clear that among its most conspicuous changes has been the substitution of revue for musical comedy. Musical comedy is not altogether clone with; there are revivals now and then and even now pieces that may claim the title; but the day of "The Merry Widow" and "The Dollar Princess" is over.

A NEW type of double-frame construction, which is said to provide additional strength and rigidity, is the main feature of the newly introduced Dodge and De Soto convertible coupes. It consists of the regular chassis frame six inches high, and a subframe, four inches high, built inside the body.

THE Soviet customs authorities permit foreigners to bring in certain personal possessions, such as typewriters and cameras, duty free on condition they take them out when they leave. Such items are simply entered on the traveler's passport.

ON a basis of six parts take two of biography, two of history, one of tradition and one of author's comment and garnish with a spice of fictionesque narration and you have about the formula on which Mr. Finger's unique book is constructed.

HE REALLY DOESN'T: A filling station attendant who is looking into the muzzle of a hold-up man's gun is much too nervous to sound convincing when he says he does not know the combination of the safe. That fact has been proved, by unpleasant experience, to officials of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey.

THIS book, says Mr. Sperry, who is dean of the Theological School, Harvard University, is the result of a request made to him two years ago by a member of the Junior League, New York, that he would talk over with the league the puzzling problem of the religious instruction of their children.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 4. -- The purchase by a wife for her husband of a second wife is one of the curious customs of the Babylon of 4,000 years ago revealed by translations of tablet inscriptions made by John B. Alexander of Kezar Falls, Me., at Yale University.

IT was a pleasant evening and it promised to be a pleasant supper party one recent Sunday night at Great Neck, where friends assembled at the home of the star of a current Broadway comedy. Call him Mr. X. The supper began affably, but after a while the guests couldn't help observing the impatience of their host.

COMEDIES, one hears, are not as funny as they used to be. A generation is growing up that has never experienced the esthetic tingle that follows a glimpse of a rotund comedian being struck wetly by a custard pie. The two-reelers as often as not are miniature musical comedies, mostly without the comedy.

CHICAGO, May 4. -- Scattered liquidation by longs and evening-up operations furnished most of the trading in grains today on the Board of Trade. Local sentiment was bearish because new outside buying failed to develop, and wheat never showed a pronounced disposition to rally.

A sure sign of Spring is the enthusiasm for rowing registered at the colleges that are fortunate enough to have suitable bodies of water near by. At Smith and Wellesley, rowing has been one of the favorite sports for some seasons, and this year more Wellesley girls than ever have taken to exercise and racing on Lake Waban.

Much criticism has developed in recent years of the activity of lobbies in Congress. The development of lobbies as a sort of super Legislature is a natural result of the American system of choosing legislators, which practically excludes the real leaders of great movements from nomination for public office unless they are willing to bow to local political bosses.

Limitations on leaves of absence to improve teaching in the public schools through continuity of service were recommended yesterday by Jacob Greenberg, Associate Superintendent of Schools, at a meeting of the High School Teachers Association in the Hotel Astor.

DETROIT, May 3. -- The strikes in the automobile industry in the last week are more than sporadic indications of a labor situation; they mark the divergence in methods and objectives between two types of union. One organizes by groups and international bodies and is easily split; the other binds itself into a representative shop system that can act as a unit.

DEBATE over changes in the banking system, long discussed and long postponed, has reached the floor of Congress. "The revolutionary Eccles proposal," as some describe the Banking Bill of 1935, has split the members of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee; it has stirred up argument in the House, and it has disturbed old-line economists and bankers the country over.

The Engineers Public Service Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday consolidated gross earnings of $44,118,512 for the twelve months ended on March 31, comparing with $41,990,228 for the preceding year, while net earnings after expenses and taxes were $18,020,754, against $18,164,312.

LIMA, Peru, May 4. -- As a result of President Roosevelt's decree fixing the price of silver at 77.57 cents per ounce, the silver market here is in a state of disorder. For the past three days there has been a wild scramble to reach the banks to get change for 5 and 10 sol notes, and there is an increasing dearth of small coins.
TUCSON, Ariz., May 4 (AP). -- The government obtained one indictment today in the kidnapping case of little June Robles and quickly pressed on in its year-long investigation.

TWO years ago a group of jobless men were hanging on to life in West Virginia mining camps. They owned nothing; home to them meant a shack on a scarred hillside. They had been on relief for months. There was no money with which to move away, and no job to move to, anyway.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- The place, if any, of the spoils system in public service will be discussed by Senators O'Mahoney, Democrat, and Vandenberg, Republican, Wednesday night, and by members of the League of Women Voters from thirty-five States in executive council meetings beginning here on Tuesday and continuing through Friday.

THIS is a better than aventure adventure story. In plain words and accents, Upton Terrell sets down the life of old Adam Cargo, a renegade Confederate cavalryman who became a Southwestern frontier outlaw in the reckless days after the Civil War. The result is a very brisk yarn.
BATON ROUGE, La., May 4. -- Great athletes battered at the doors of world-record fame today in the Southern Amateur Athletic Union's annual track and field meet.

TARRYTOWN, May 4. -- Construction work is scheduled to start soon on the main structure of a group of new buildings for Marymount College, which will be erected on the hills above Tarrytown, commanding a wide view of the Hudson River to the west and the Tarrytown lakes to the east.

BERLIN, May 4. -- The discovery today of a wrecked airplane and seven bodies in a lonely spot in the Fichtel Mountain Range in Northeastern Bavaria terminated a five-day search for a Junkers W34 passenger plane that left Stuttgart for Breslau last Tuesday at noon.

LONG BEACH, L.I., May 4. -- Jewelry valued at about $14,000 and $110 in cash were stolen last night from the home of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Jacobs at 19 East Beech Street here by a thief who forced open a rear window, the police reported today.

A FRENCH playwright -- I think it was Dumas fils -- was instructing a novice in dramatic technique, and above all in the importance of making himself understood. "First," he said, "tell your audience what is going to happen.

What the Iowans call good corn weather is something worth going hundreds of miles to avoid, and the author of this book writes of it as one who knows. She must have spent at least one Summer in that Midwestern State where the tall corn grows.

PITTSBURGH, May 4. -- Charges that the Republican party was turning to radicals for support were voiced in a speech here tonight by Senator Robinson of Arkansas as he defended the New Deal against a Republican onslaught by Senator Dickinson of Iowa.

Women interested in the work of the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery have arranged a garden festival to he held for the benefit of the nursery at the opening of the Park Lane Gardens on May 21. Young women of society will act as manikins in the showing of the latest fashions for Summer wear, which will be a feature of the entertainment.

PHILADELPHIA, May 4. -- The sun shone on Pennsylvania rowing today despite a lead-colored sky and a drizzle of rain. For the first time in the history of the regatta the Red and Blue varsity boat took the Blackwell Cup from Yale and Columbia in the finest start Penn rowing has had in years.

ALASKA is staging a comeback as a tourist centre, according to ship lines and travel agents. Entirely apart from the trek of homesteaders and prospectors, this season's movement of visitors to the land that seethed thirty-five years ago with seekers after its golden treasure is unprecedented.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 4. -- Torrential rains, accompanied by howling gales, which have lashed the city of Bahia and its vicinity for the last five days, have taken at least 400 lives and caused injuries to several hundred persons, according to advices received here tonight.

TRANSPORT airplanes continue to cut substantial slices from their previous records between the coasts and to press ever more closely on the time of racing planes. Last week twenty-eight and a half minutes was lopped from the transport type mark by TWA's flying laboratory, the Douglas DC-1, in the hands of D.W. (Tommy) Tomlinson, Harold Snead and Peter Redpath.

A "Masque of Light and Color," in which two departments and several student organizations are participating, will be presented in the Little Theatre of Hunter College, Bronx Buildings, Navy Avenue and Bedford Park Boulevard, next Thursday and Friday evenings at 8:30 o'clock.
The European armaments race took on new speed last week. From Berlin to London and from Moscow to Rome statesmen talked about peace and in the next breath admitted preparations for defense -- or war.

Recent labor difficulties and the possibility of more as the warmer season progresses have led to numerous estimates of organized labor's strength throughout the country. The statement was recently made, in a survey by the Twentieth Century Fund, that "union organization in the United States today has penetrated more extensively into every industry and geographic area than at any time in its history and is being further extended."

PALO ALTO, Calif., May 4. -- Construction of a cosmic ray plant designed to kill bacteria and cancer cells by concentration of the rays with a 150-foot copper "collector tower" has been started at Stanford University by John K. Kalsey, British X-ray technician and laboratory expert.

MANILA. FOR the time being at least both Spanish and English will be retained as official languages in the Philippine Islands. That was decided by the recent constitutional convention, but the action does not alter the fact that the matter of a permanent language will be settled as language problems are always settled, by usage and not by legislation.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 4. -- Columbia had an easy time defeating Brown in a dual track meet today, 86 to 49. The Lions took ten first places, split with Brown in another and swept all three places in the 100-yard dash and high jump. The invaders allowed Brown only one first place in the track events.

HERE is another of those accounts of privately managed yachting trips around the world calculated to make all the sea-loving wander-tribe sore with envy. This one, made some three or four years ago in the trim and handsome Camargo, seems to have been a particularly happy and successful journey.

WHEN the amateur-hour vogue was at its height last Winter prophecies were heard that the popularity would diminish in the Spring as rapidly as the snow. The prophets were false. The amateur "craze" seems destined for an all-Summer run on the air.

HAVANA, May 4. -- Life imprisonment was imposed upon Eduardo Galvez, a civilian also known as Yayo, by a court martial in the city of San Diego today after he had been convicted of having planted a bomb in the home of a customs collector in the town of Puerto Padre, Oriente Province, last March.
CLEVELAND, May 4 (AP). -- The Athletics reached out of the American League basement today to administer a surprise beating to the pace-setting Indians, 12 to 1.

PANAMA, R.P. -- Two laws passed by the last National Assembly, the first designed to nationalize retail business and the second to increase employment of Panama nationals, are causing some concern to the government, but more to foreigners who have invested money here.

HARTFORD, May 3. -- Liquor control, which provided the Connecticut General Assembly with a bitter fight in the 1933 session, is threatening to play a return engagement of the same sort this year. Adjournment under the Constitution is mandatory on June 5, leaving fewer than twenty working days for the Legislature under its present schedule, and thus far the judiciary committee has not even agreed on a bill.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 4. -- Bill Grohs, Army star on the football field and hockey rink, broke up a baseball game today with a drive into right field which gave the Cadets a victory over Temple University by 5 -- 4. It was cold and 3,000 shivering spectators held their seats throughout the close and exciting play.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 4. -- "The Embarcadero," as the broad thoroughfare that carries on its surface most of San Francisco's foreign and domestic commerce is known, became the scene of more than ordinary activity as the past week closed.

OTTAWA, Ont., May 4. -- That the difference between America and Europe is even greater than the 2,500 miles of ocean which separates them was demonstrated this week when the attempt to make an international sensation out of the projected establishment of a United States air base near the Canadian border fizzled out like a damp squib.

IN the preface to "Wheels and Butterflies," a collection of one-act plays, William Butler Yeats says: "We poets and artists may be called, so small our share in life, 'separated spirits,' words applied by the old philosophers to the dead."

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- Unless the Democratic bellwethers of the United States are able soon to rally their straying flock for a final, supreme push for the New Deal program, the first session of the Seventy-fourth Congress stands every chance of becoming an anti-climax to the legislative record of President Roosevelt's "first" administration.

PARIS.-- It is scarcely necessary to tell the public of America that Europe, and more especially France, is under an oppressive strain and expecting great calamities. Everywhere people are asking each other:

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- Recording a decline in industrial output in the latter half of April, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly survey of domestic business conditions that the production index for the entire month would be lower than that for March.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 4 (AP). -- Incorporation papers for the National Union for Social Justice, founded by the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin of Royal Oaks, Mich., were filed today with Secretary of State George S. Myers.
I read with interest, in THE TIMES, the statements of Dr. Vilhjalmur Stefansson relative to the discovery of America by an Irishman.

Why is it that the British delight to honor King GEORGE on the completion of his twenty-fifth year on the throne? It is partly because he mirrors so well the British conception of what a King should be. They do not now want a dashing and romantic figure to represent the Crown.

ALL thoughtful, forward-looking persons are beginning to recognize the necessity of putting administrative public service upon a secure basis and a higher level, making of it a profession demanding ability, character and training comparable with the careers offered in professional and business life.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):

PARIS, May 4. -- The midseason collections develop and amplify the Oriental and Greek trends that were launched last February. Draperies are ubiquitous for afternoon and evening. Ihran head scarfs and saris have become established fashion facts.
TOKYO. -- United States cotton producers have reason to be interested in the Japanese economic mission which left recently for Brazil.

BOSTON, May 4 (AP). -- Colonel Robert R. McCormick, editor and publisher of The Chicago Tribune, assailed administration policies, radicals and share-the-wealth advocates in an address in Faneuil Hall tonight.

THE application of lime to a soil in order to change it from a "sour" to a "sweet" condition is one of the oldest of horticultural practices, having been known to the ancients more than 2,000 years ago. Only within the present century, however, has the matter been placed on a scientific basis.

WARRENTON, Va. -- The Warrenton Garden Club is planning a local garden-visiting day for May 25 to raise money for the memorial fund in honor of Mrs. Martin, founder of the Garden Club of America. Several gardens will be open and one ticket will admit the holder to all.

Price trends continued mixed on commodity exchanges here yesterday, with sugar, copper, rubber and hides moderately higher and coffee and cocoa lower for the day. In the cash markets all grains declined, while cotton, rubber, lard and zinc were strong.

Plans for the Spring Festival of the People's Chorus of New York to be held the night of May 16 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria will be discussed at a reception to be given by Mrs. Leonard Tyson Scully Tuesday afternoon at 1,060 Park Avenue.
PARIS, May 4 (AP). -- The Anglo-American Press Association today made public a recent protest to the French Government against "censorship" imposed on cable communications during recent weeks.

Shooting in brilliant form, Joseph Heistand of Hillsboro, Ohio, won the thirtieth annual amateur singles championship of America at clay targets over the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. He took the title, the most important one in the Eastern trapshooting world, by breaking 199 out of a possible 200 targets.

AMERICAN radio industrialists have always lived in the fear that a premature announcement of some new invention might paralyze their existing markets. They confess that is one reason they hesitate to reveal how far television has progressed.

Charges of police brutality to prisoners the night of the Harlem riot of March 19 were made yesterday by witnesses at a hearing of a subcommittee of the Mayor's Commission on Conditions in Harlem. The hearing was marked by frequent disorders.

COMMACK, L.I., May 4. -- White Hall Cyclone, a white, liver and ticked pointer dog, owned by Charles L. Lawrance of East Islip, annexed first honors in the Junior All-Age Stake in today's fourteenth annual field trials of the Brookhaven Game Protective Association.

Senator ROBINSON, the Democratic leader, is not of French extraction, so far as we know, but he has one ingrained political habit of the French. When things go wrong, whether in military or civic affairs, they insist that the trouble is made by a sinister group of conspirators.
ST. NAZAIRE, France, May 5. -- The largest ship in the world, the French liner Normandie, put out to sea today for a successful commencement of ten days of trials.

COMMACK, L.I., May 5. -- Two women, Mrs. L.I. Durborow of Maplewood, N.J., and Miss Valle Ewing of Greenwich, Conn., took highest honors in today's concluding field trials of the Brookhaven Game Protective Association.

LOS ANGELES, May 5 (AP). -- Tortured by memories of the motor car accident that took the lives of his father and three friends last night, and suffering from the pain of his own injuries, Jackie Coogan returned here tonight and was taken to a hospital in Glendale for rest and observation.
