PITTSBURGH, May 5. -- National production of steel ingots last week was put here at 46 per cent of capacity, and the estimate for the previous week was revised from 48 to 47 per cent, making it the same as for several preceding weeks.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., May 5. -- A human chain, hastily formed under the direction of the Rev. James H. Killian, Roman Catholic chaplain of the Bridgeport Fire Department, saved the lives of a score of men, women and children last night when fire destroyed Elmore Hall in the near-by suburb of Trumbull.

CANTON, N.Y., May 5. -- Presentation of an oil portrait of Owen D. Young to St. Lawrence University by the board of trustees through Millard Jencks, chairman of the board, marked today the annual Charter Day exercises of the university in Gunnison Memorial Chapel.

Both home relief and work relief are on the decline in New York City, a survey of the situation revealed yesterday. Latest figures available show that on March 22, 1935, the number of families on home relief was 219,030, as compared with 217,382 for the corresponding date in April.

BERLIN, May 5. -- Chancellor Hitler is spending the week-end aboard the North German Lloyd's new 18,000-ton liner Scharnhorst, which is making a trial cruise in the North Sea preparatory to entering the company's Far Eastern service this month.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP). -- "Upper bracket" salaried men are numerous on the Federal payroll, according to a study of the Civil Service Commission's "official register of the United States" and of private department lists. Those getting $10,000 or more total 989 and those between $5,000 and $10,000 number 7,223.
A letter from President Roosevelt was read last night as the formal opening of National Music Week in a broadcast over radio station WJZ and the National Broadcasting Company network.

Socialists of New York State offered a program of harmony yesterday to the national executive committee of the party, controlled by left-wing elements headed by Norman Thomas. One of the conditions proposed for the restoration of unity is the exclusion from the party of Communists and elements advocating violence and armed insurrection.

Modern civilization was likened to existence in the jungle, where self-preservation and self-seeking is the first law of life, by the Right Rev. Arthur S. Lloyd in his sermon yesterday morning at St. Michael's Protestant Episcopal Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Ninety-ninth Street.

Mayor La Guardia and former Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick were among more than 1,200 persons who attended a mass yesterday morning in the Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church, 333 West Forty-second Street, commemorating the first anniversary of the death of Controller Arthur W. Cunningham. Mrs. La Guardia accompanied the Mayor to the mass, which was arranged by the Women's Auxiliary of the 165th (Old Sixty-ninth) Infantry.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., May 5. -- The Maidstone Club opened today. Mr. and Mrs. Ernest H. Rice had a party of eight for luncheon. Others entertaining were:

A careful reading of the text of the Transit Unification Bill, passed in the closing hours of the Legislature and now signed by Governor LEHMAN, with Mayor LA GUARDIA'S reluctant approval, reveals ample grounds for the Mayor's hesitation. The doubtful wisdom of requiring a compulsory popular referendum on any proposal to increase the fare, even if backed by a unanimous vote of the Board of Estimate, is at once apparent.

Financed by a $40,000 grant from the Carnegie Corporation of New York, a survey of the hospitals of the city is to be started at once under the auspices of the United Hospital Fund, it was announced last night by David H. McAlpin Pyle, the fund s president.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- The United States is a creditor nation only on the doubtful basis of the defaulted war debts and obsolete investment estimates, George N. Peek states in a report submitted today to President Roosevelt, to whom he is special adviser on foreign trade.

The report of the 145 Class I railroads in the United States for the first three months of this year shows virtually no change in gross revenues, compared with the same period last year, but a decline of 24.8 per cent in net railway operating income, according to the Association of American Railroads.

Students of the College of the Sacred Heart, Manhattanville, will give a tea dance on Saturday in the grand ballroom of the Pierre to aid the endowment fund of the college. Arrangements are under the direction of Miss Kathleen Dempsey, who is being assisted by the Misses Zaida Jones, Marjorie O'Connor, Betty Rafter, Marion Moran, Jane Kreag, Margaret Lambert, Ruth Tooley and Peggy McAuliffe.

The five-story loft building at 50-52 Franklin Street, near the Criminal Court Building and downtown civic centre, has been sold by Emily Christie to an investing client of Otterbourg, Steindler Houston. The structure is on a plot 50 by 100 feet and will continue under the management of Daniel Birdsall Co.

BERLIN, May 4. -- Business interest in Germany this week was concentrated on the government's plans for taxation in the form of a forced loan or levies, concerning which it is officially being attempted to impose secrecy, not only as regards the nature of the measures but also with respect to their real purpose.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., May 5. -- The St. Louis Central Brewers and the Pawtucket Rangers, sectional champions, played to an overtime 1-1 tie on Coats Field today in the second game of the final series for the national soccer championship. St. Louis won the first game, 5 -- 2, on its home field last Sunday.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 5 (AP). -- Former President Herbert Hoover declared here tonight that economic and social security should not be attained through regimentation of "the mental and spiritual health of our people."

Two hundred volunteer workers, men and women, will begin solicitation today for subscriptions in the drive for $250,000 to be divided among the Republican National, State and County Committees, Robert H. Thayer and Mrs. Roger W. Straus, chairman and co-chairman of the United Republican Finance Committee of New York County, announced yesterday.

The foreign exchange market was quiet last week. Some strength was noted in the gold bloc on the first two days, but this was attributed to "shorts" covering month-end commitments. With the advent of the new month the demand from this quarter ceased, the trend was reversed and the group developed a uniform trend downward to the week's close.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., May 5 (AP). -- Laden below the Plimsoll line with a cargo of lusty tales, the stout schooner Yankee returned to Gloucester today after an absence of eighteen months during which she leisurely circled the globe and, dropped her hook in some of the most obscure ports on any chart.
ALBANY, May 5. -- The text of the radio address made from the Executive Mansion tonight by Governor Lehman follows:
ALBANY, May 5. -- Governor Lehman announced today the veto of two bills easing bail bond requirements. In his notation he said:

May I say a word in praise of your Manila correspondent's dispatch in the paper today? The message gives to one familiar with such outbreaks a clear impression and it is free from what I have called an atmosphere of having been written from a Manila viewpoint.

Christians owe their first loyalty to the spiritual fellowship of their church rather than to the nation of which they are citizens, the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, President of the Union Theological Seminary, declared in a sermon yesterday morning. He preached at the James Memorial Chapel of the seminary, Claremont Avenue and 121st Street.

CHICAGO, May 5 (AP). -- With silent John Whitehead, freshman right-hander, turning in a four-hit shutout for his fourth victory in as many major league starts, the surprising White Sox defeated the Senators today, 4 to 0, and forged ahead of the league-leading Indians on a "won and lost" basis, although remaining in second place by percentage points.

MAUSTON, Wis., May 5. -- A babe-lost-in-the-North-Woods drama ended happily today with the finding of 21-month-old Thelma Ann Wilke, missing since Friday, playing unconcernedly in a thicket of scrub oaks three miles from her home.

Dr. William Frederick Durand, Professor Emeritus of Mechanical Engineering at Stanford University and an outstanding authority on aeronautics, will receive the 1935 Daniel Guggenheim Medal, it was announced yesterday. The award was for "notable achievement as a pioneer in laboratory research and theory of aeronautics, and for distinguished contributions to the theory and development of aircraft propellers."

The Niagara Hudson Power Corporation and subsidiaries report for the first quarter of 1935 a consolidated net income of $1,773,430, equal to 20.3 cents a share on 8,738,559 common shares, against $1,714,293 revised net income, or 19.6 cents a share on 8,738,135 common shares, in the 1934 period.

PHILADELPHIA, May 5. -- The number of cases on the rolls of the Philadelphia County Relief Board has just shown a decrease for the first time since last August. This is true also of Pennsylvania at large.

NEW ORLEANS, May 5. -- While the market for cotton futures contracts here was comparatively quiet last week, the spot market was strong, with a good demand, although the actual volume of trading was restricted by the scarcity of offerings and the extremely stiff basis demanded.

PARIS, May 5. -- Premier Pierre Etienne Flandin returned to Paris today and, although he was well enough to travel by train and joke lightly about his motor accident yesterday near Auxerre, doctors at the clinic to which he was taken to have his arm fracture treated, insisted that he remain there for a few days' rest.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 5. -- A two-game home-and-home series between the football teams of the University of Chicago and Princeton University was announced tonight in a statement issued jointly by T. Nelson Metcalf, director of athletics at Chicago, and Professor Burnham N. Dell, chairman of the Princeton council on athletics.

BERLIN, May 5. -- An announcement that 333,000 women between the ages of 16 and 33 were needed on farms immediately to become mates to "healthy, virile hereditary" farmers was made today by Germany's Estate of Nutrition, matchmaker extraordinary.

A home for unemployed girls, to be supervised by the Nuns of the Good Shepherd, will be opened here this Fall by the Women's Auxiliary of the House of the Good Shepherd, Miss Therese Heide, president of the auxiliary, announced at the annual communion breakfast held yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The New York Society of Teachers of Dancing, Inc., celebrated its twenty-first birthday with a luncheon and dance at the Hotel Astor yesterday morning, following a business and demonstration session which marked the May meeting and the beginning of the Summer recess.

How a new religion was borne to the primitive natives of the Ninigo Islands by a South Pacific tidal wave in 1927 was told yesterday by William F. Coultas, who recently returned from six years of exploration as head of the Whitney South Sea expedition of the American Museum of Natural History.

Commodity futures milled about with moderate activity last week, with some former trends upset, but there was little conclusive evidence upon which to base judgments of the future course of prices of most staples. In the cash markets, rye, coffee, refined sugar, lard, beef, zinc, tin and cotton rose for the week, while wheat, corn, oats, flour, cocoa, antimony, rubber and dairy products eased.

A tendency toward a decline in the number of families and the total number of persons requiring public relief was reported yesterday by relief administrations over the country in response to inquiries from THE NEW YORK TIMES.

LONDON, May 5. -- Tomorrow Britain begins with a solemn thanksgiving her general rejoicing to celebrate the twenty-fifth anniversary of her King's accession to the throne, a celebration that will continue in various forms for the next six months.

TOLEDO, Ohio, May 5 (AP). -- Department of Labor conciliators will conduct a poll, possibly on Tuesday, among 2,300 workers at the Toledo Chevrolet plant, to determine whether the management's offers toward settlement of the strike there will be accepted.

St. Bartholomew's and Trinity Protestant Episcopal Churches joined yesterday in the celebration of the silver jubilee of King George V and Queen Mary, which will reach its climax in a brilliant pageant in London today.

BERLIN, May 5. -- However much askance the world may look at National Socialist policies, there is no doubt that in the minds of many Germany is acquiring the reputation of a miracle land that is beginning to replace the United States as a country of unlimited possibilities.

The State Chamber of Commerce announced yesterday that it had asked Congress not to place further handicaps upon the American merchant marine in considering legislation to promote safety at sea. Frederick E. Hasler, chairman of the committee on the harbor and shipping, said the committee feared that provisions would be incorporated in some of the measures now before Congress placing the shipping industry here at a further disadvantage in meeting foreign competition.

ORANGE, N.J., May 5. -- The safety of more than 2,000 residences and other buildings in Essex County is endangered by the ravages of termites and probably 75 per cent of the owners of the properties are unaware of the danger, it was said here today by R.E. Harman, County Agricultural Agent.

LONDON, May 5. -- Stories are beginning to reach London of privations now being undergone by thousands of Italian troops quartered in Italian Somaliland and Eritrea in readiness for a possible campaign against Ethiopia.

The twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of Young Judaea, junior Zionist organization of America, was celebrated last night at a dinner at the Grand Street Boys Clubhouse, 106 West Fifty-fifth Street. The group was started by the late Professor Israel Friedlaender and Dr. Judah L. Magnes, now chancellor of the Hebrew University in Jerusalem.

DOVER, N.J., May 5. -- A group of hikers en route to Dansville, N.Y., who left Manhattan yesterday and spent the night at Paterson, arrived here today at 5:10 P.M. with a "stowaway" in their midst. The extra man was with the party from the start but his status was not determined until last night.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- Only some major political strategy, which administration leaders were unable to evolve over the week-end, can prevent a direct issue between President Roosevelt and his overwhelmingly Democratic Congress over cash payment of the veterans' bonus.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- Participation in a spectacular anti-war campaign in all the principal armed countries of the world was voted by the American section of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom at its closing session today.

Young matrons and debutantes of this and recent seasons will assist in the tea room and will have charge of several features of the entertainment at the annual Spring fete of St. James's Church to be held today at the Central Park Casino.
ATLANTA, May 5. -- Relief rolls in Georgia have gradually declined since the peak of 101,585 last September.

The Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, Inc., of which J. Reuben Clark Jr., former Under-Secretary of State and former Ambassador to Mexico, is president, will issue today its first annual report of its work in obtaining settlements for United States holders of Brazilian, Dominican Republic and German bonds.

GENEVA, May 5. -- The thing in the Franco-Soviet pact that seems to impress neutral experienced observers here is its clear-cut subordination to the Locarno treaty. This subordination, which the protocol brings out, serves to give Great Britain the whip hand but in such a manner that to exercise it she must act through the League of Nations Council.

The board of directors of the American Petroleum Institute, speaking for the $12,000,000,000 oil industry, with more than 1,000,000 employes, will present a petition to Congress today opposing enlargement of the National Industrial Recovery Act and setting forth principles regarded as essential to further recovery.

Aided by a handicap allowance of 2 minutes 15 seconds, Albert Handley, 19-year-old representative of the Irish-American Athletic Club of Newark, yesterday captured the annual four and one-half mile road run of the Swedish-American Athletic Club in the actual time of 24:21.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1935, as well as last prices for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 5. -- Nassau County detectives were investigating today the robbery of $7,000 worth of rare china, glassware and furniture from the country home of Raymond Almirall, New York architect. The large house, surrounded by five acres of grounds at East Fulton Street and Henderson Avenue, about a mile from the centre of town, apparently was entered by a second-story porch door, which the police found unlocked.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP). -- Amid widespread disputes over processing taxes, the Farm Adjustment Administration checked its financial standing today and reported $777,540,894 in revenue and $776,103,578 of expenses.

Although many dress buyers were bore to purchase Summer merchandise, buying otherwise was less active in the wholesale markets here last week, reflecting the disappointing trend of retail buying. Retailers made last-minute purchases of various types of cotton apparel, particularly dresses for day and evening wear, to be featured this week in National Cotton Week promotions.

MOSCOW, May 6. -- "Press Day," the twenty-third anniversary of the founding of Pravda, the chief organ of the Communist party, was celebrated here today with pledges by leading journals and journalists to improve themselves in the role of instructors of the Soviet public.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 5. -- Omaha will go in the Preakness on Saturday, and Today threw a shoe in the Kentucky Derby yesterday. These were the principal post-race developments as Louisville awakened today, following the sixty-first running of the race which brought 50,000 persons to Churchill Downs.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, May 5 (AP). -- Former Premier Alexander Tzankoff said today that the Bulgarian people were on "the verge of mutiny" and if the government attempted to adopt a ready-made Constitution without the people's approval it would shake the foundation of the monarchy.
A price war among North Jersey and Rockland County (N.Y.) golf courses was brought into the open yesterday.

The proposed bill for taxing private schools and teachers seems to me excellent if it would apply only to those of a commercial type and making money. But to tax so heavily the idealistic, sincere and already impoverished school or private teacher with a few pupils seems unjust and short-sighted.
BAHIA, Brazil, May 5. -- Drenching rains and powerful winds wrought their sixth straight day of havoc today in Bahia and the interior. Fatalities, unofficially placed at 400, appeared to be mounting.

Reading the well deserved national tribute and homage paid to Jane Addams as heading the list of inspired leaders with "vision and courage," one almost naturally visualizes that other list in 1917 -- also headed by the same Jane Addams -- containing the names of the "undesirables" to be shunned and disgraced.

In so far as last week's markets expressed any visible judgment on the course of events, they appeared in most instances to reflect composure. Stock market prices changed little, but their trend, on increased business, was conservatively upward.

The United States liner Washington will sail Wednesday from Pier 60, North River, starting its third year in the New York-Cobh-Plymouth-Havre-Hamburg trade. The ship sailed May 10, 1933, on her maiden voyage in the transatlantic service and has made twenty-six crossings.

The world consumption of cotton showed an increase in March over February, according to the New York Cotton Exchange Service. The increase was larger in the case of foreign cotton than in the United States product.

Canada, with its unoccupied spaces and its almost limitless wealth of virgin forests and streams, annually attracts thousands of American sportsmen. Starting this month and continuing throughout the season, fishermen will travel across the border in a steady stream.

Mr. THOMAS WOLFE, the Young Giant of American literature, is the subject of a respectful, if somewhat searching, criticism in The American Review. The critic, Mr. ROBERT PENN WARREN, himself a poet, attributes to Mr. WOLFE the "instinct" of the poet as well as "on a large scale many of the gifts of the novelist."

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- Subscriptions amounting to $1,446,000,000 had been received by the Treasury at the close of business Saturday in response to the offering of bonds and notes in exchange for First Liberty bonds called for redemption June 15, Secretary Morgenthau stated today.

The editorial in your issue of April 27, "Bronx Market, New Style," mentions the market as "that speculation from which Mayor Hylan expected so much and realized so little," and "grandiose schemes like this of Hylan's."

NEW ORLEANS, May 5. -- The Federal relief roll in Louisiana as of April 19 totaled 62,036 cases of relief and rehabilitation, these cases comprising both individuals and families, but averaging 4.3 persons to a case. The peak was 70,643 cases on Feb. 22.

DETROIT, May 5 (AP). -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, in a double-barreled address to the members of his National Union for Social Justice tonight, told them he does not seek "to establish a third party" and asked their support for the Patman bonus measure.

Two awards -- one for the best performance on the Broadway stage this season and the other to the member of the Drama League of New York attending the most shows -- will be made by the league at its annual meeting and luncheon on May 17 at the Casino in Central Park.

GALLUP, N.M., May 5 (AP). -- A keen-eyed Navajo Indian tracker read from signs on the desert's surface today a story substantiating those of Robert Minor and David Levinson that they were abducted Thursday night by a band of hooded vigilantes, beaten and thrown out of a motor car.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 5. -- Schools and colleges are becoming "bookish" and should "learn more about life and its realities," Dr. Constance Warren, president of Sarah Lawrence College, told an education conference at the Edgewood School this afternoon.

Leading Christians, headed by former Governor Alfred E. Smith, called upon all Americans yesterday to aid the United Jewish Appeal in its effort to raise $3,250,000 in the United States for the relief and rehabilitation of Jews in Germany and Eastern Europe and the settlement of Jews in Palestine.

The 120-mile-an-hour locomotive recently completed for the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad may well prove to be an outstanding milestone on the road to recovery on the part of the railroads. Some years ago when locomotives were turned out in substantial quantities a new type did not call for particular notice.

The Giants braved not only the cold but the rain of yesterday in a bid for victory over Chuck Dressen's Cincinnati Reds at the Polo Grounds, but in the end had to be content with a ten-inning deadlock at 2-all.

LONDON, May 4. -- After a period of depression, British railway receipts again are expanding. A good deal of the extra traffic at the moment arises from passengers, in connection with the recent Easter holiday and the present Jubilee celebration, but there are also signs that merchandise receipts again are expanding moderately.

PITTSBURGH, May 5. -- On direct relief in the city of Pittsburgh at the present time are 45,122 cases with a total of 129,501 persons. In Allegheny County outside of Pittsburgh are 25,975 cases with a total of 105,622 persons.

NEWARK, N.J., May 5. -- Captain Donald A. MacGrath of East Orange, N.J., riding the veteran bay mare Lindy from the Essex Troop horse show team, tonight won his second leg on the James Kerney Challenge Trophy. He triumphed in the leading event of the military night program of the fifteenth annual Newark Horse Show.

At the annual meeting of the governing council of the United States Figure Skating Association, held yesterday at the Metropolitan Club, Charles M. Rotch of Boston was elected president, replacing Sherwin C. Badger of New York. Richard L. Hapgood, also of Boston, became secretary for the next year and Bedell Harned of New York was named vice president.

The Film and Photo League will present "Taxi," its first feature-length film production, on Saturday at 7 P.M. and 9:30 P.M. at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street. The story deals with the life of the taxicab driver, and is acted by members of the Taxicab Drivers Union and Theatre Union Studio.

More than 13,000 fans sat through a drizzling rain and a chill wind at Ebbets Field yesterday to watch the Dodgers stage one of their most painful performances. The customers jeered their erstwhile heroes at the end, and it was suspected that Casey Stengel bore them no resentment for so doing.

There was recently brought to my attention a statement issued by the Federal Power Commission which purports to show an anxious utility investor that the shrinkage in market value of the bonds, debentures, preferred and common stocks of twenty-five utility holding companies since March 1, 1933, is insignificant.

James A. O'Gorman, former United States Senator, who has seen New York grow from a city of 800,000 to one of 7,000,000 inhabitants, celebrated his seventy-fifth birthday yesterday at his home, 1,148 Fifth Avenue.

Jimmy McLarnin, who will defend his world's welterweight championship against Barney Ross at the Polo Grounds on May 28, is due to arrive in New York this morning. The 147-pound titleholder is expected to arrive at the Newark Airport at 10:15 o'clock from Berkeley, Calif., where he has been engaging in light training exercises for the past two weeks.

Contracts for the authorized biographies of Sara Delano Roosevelt and Jane Addams were signed on one day last week by Appleton-Century. "Gracious Lady: The Life of Sara Delano Roosevelt," the authorized biography of the President's mother, is the work of Rita S. Halle Kleeman.
CHICAGO, May 5. -- Charles G. Dawes is standing pat on his prosperity prediction.

DETROIT, May 5 (AP). -- In a letter addressed to President Roosevelt today, Martin H. Carmody, supreme knight of the Knights of Columbus, asked that the government "exercise its good offices in behalf of persecuted Catholics in Mexico."
PARIS, May 5. -- Perfumed face powder by the boxfulls was used as ammunition by women suffragists in Paris against the police during today's municipal elections.
Eight persons were killed yesterday day in automobile accidents in and near the city.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 5. -- Abandoning the usual custom of determining only one winning team, officials in charge of the annual four-ball invitation golf tournament at the Meadow Brook Club today awarded prizes to three victorious combinations.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $7,558,744,480. They consist of Treasury bonds, consols, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 5. -- All telegraph and telephone communications between points within Yugoslavia are being requisitioned for government use, and there is only official news tonight concerning the results of the elections today.

CHICAGO, May 5. -- Trading in grain for future delivery, which is highly essential in handling all crops, has reached so small a level that many in the trade regard it as necessary to have a restoration of operations in privileges, and above all a reduction in margins.

" Christian life may be summed up in one word -- charity," the Rev. Thomas L. Graham declared yesterday morning at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral as he announced the opening of the annual Catholic Charities appeal for $1,000,000.

The Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, pastor of the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, said in a sermon broadcast yesterday from WMCA that "the cause of social reform has been set back from one to two decades by the precipitous and poorly-thought-out theories of the New Deal."

In his latest address the President made a forceful appeal to the people. He invited fair criticism, predicted prosperity, and disclosed that one of the objects of his departures from Washington is to keep in closer contact with the people, so as to obtain direct information as to their condition and welfare.

On the 117th anniversary of the birth of Karl Marx two rival radical organizations staged rallies yesterday in Madison Square Garden. In the afternoon Socialists filled the vast hall; in the evening it resounded to the cheers of nearly as many Communists.

Two thousand Bronx children swarmed yesterday to the community house of the New York section of the National Council of Jewish Women at 1,122 Forest Avenue, the Bronx, near 166th Street. There was a carnival, a bazaar and a neighborhood baby show.

LONDON, May 4. -- Silver continues to fluctuate violently here, and speculative activity remains intense. The dangerous nature the situation and its almost complete domination by the United States policy have been demonstrated by the heavy fall of the last few days, the current quotation of 33 3/8d an ounce for standard silver comparing with a recent high of 36 1/4d.

ESSEX, Conn., May 5. -- An unseasonable, stiff southeast wind swept the Connecticut River today and upset boats as well as calculations in the North American Dinghy Association's regatta at the Essex Yacht Club.

MADRID, May 5. -- Spain is closely following Washington's silver-buying program because if the American price per ounce is increased another 20 cents a situation similar to that produced in Mexico will prevail here. The silver content of Spanish coins would make them worth more than the peseta was quoted today on the foreign exchange market.

Modern man, with all his freedom, is not much happier than the stoic who drilled himself in self-repression by constant effort, Dr. Clarence A. Barbour, president of Brown University, said yesterday morning in a sermon at the Riverside Church.

CHICAGO, May 5. -- Imports of Canadian cattle into the United States since Jan. 1 have aggregated 55,000 head, while in 1934 imports were only 2,058, says The Drovers Journal of Chicago. Receipts of Canadian cattle here last week were thirty-four carloads, about 3 per cent of all arrivals.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 5. -- Governor Lehman hailed on the radio tonight the record of the Democratic-controlled Legislature and pledged himself to seek for New York State its full share of the huge Federal relief fund.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- Registration of all dealers in over-the-counter securities is required under regulations covering this class of operations issued today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 5 (AP). -- The second game of the twin bill between the Albany Senators and the Toronto Maple Leafs of the International League was called off today at the end of the fourth inning because of rain, with Toronto leading, 4 to 2.

Interesting material for study of politics has come from Washington within the past two or three days. When the Chamber of Commerce of the United States took a position hostile to most of the legislation which the President is supposed to desire, there was at first a touch of resentment reported from the Executive Offices.

DETROIT, May 5. -- Michigan's welfare burden has decreased for the fourth consecutive month and the latest deduction is more widespread than before, the State Emergency Relief Administration reported today.

A resolution denouncing the manoeuvres of the United States fleet in the Pacific and the billion-dollar appropriations for the army and navy is expected to be introduced today at one of the final sessions of the New York Annual Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church.

BOSTON, May 5. -- With a wide grin on his face, Dizzy Dean waved his outfielders back to the fence and grooved a fast third strike on Babe Ruth today when they faced each other for the second time in the St. Louis Cardinals' 7-0 shutout over the Boston Braves.

HARRISON, N.Y., May 5. -- Clearing the obstacles in excellent fashion, Sonny, agile bay gelding owned by Mrs. Gordon Wright of White Plains, captured the championship jumper sweepstake, a feature of the fifth annual Harrison Horse Show today. T. Arthur Johnson's roan mare Village Vamp was placed in reserve.

NEW HAVEN, May 4. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices this week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 82.1, which compares with 81.8 the week before, 81.5 two weeks before, 81.7 three weeks before and 81 four weeks before. It is the highest since the first week in March.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., announced tonight that it would attempt to establish eight new world speed records and that in doing so would use the DC-I Douglas robot "mystery" plane, which recently set a new transcontinental record of 11 hours 5 minutes and 45 seconds from Los Angeles to New York.

MANILA, Monday, May 6. -- Recurring rumors that the Sakdalistas are planning further attacks were circulated today as several hundreds of the extremists were reported to be gathering in the hills within thirty miles of Manila.
WASHINGTON, May 5. -- A joint resolution providing for an automatically balanced budget will be introduced in the Senate tomorrow by Senator Tydings, Democrat, of Maryland.
LONDON, May 5. -- All King George's Empire except the Irish Free State will join with the mother country tomorrow in celebrating the King's twenty-five years on the throne.

MEXICO, D.F., May 5. -- The Mexican tennis team made a clean sweep of its Davis Cup series with Cuba by taking the final two singles matches today. The triumph advanced the Mexicans to the final of the North American Zone, in which they will oppose the winner of the forthcoming engagement between the United States and China.

The decision Saturday by Judge Paul McCormick in a Los Angeles Federal court favoring the General Electric Company in an action against Japanese distributers of electric light bulbs was hailed last night by General Electric representatives here and in Cleveland and Schenectady as of major importance to the industry.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP). -- Apparently undisturbed by slow progress on Capitol Hill, President Roosevelt had word passed to Democratic leaders today that he had no objection to Congress staying in session all Summer, if necessary, to get his legislation program on the statute books.

IT would be a great story if James J. Braddock went from the relief line to the world's heavyweight championship within a year and there are some fanciful fellows who are looking ahead and seeing it happen that way. That would be a true tale of "From Rags to Riches," with ruffles and flourishes.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 5. -- Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt entertained a party at luncheon in the Colonial Room of the Homestead today. Her guests were Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Henry Prince, Mr. and Mrs. Fornes Morgan and Mr. and Mrs. Fay Ingalls.

Predicting that the election this Fall will be marked by efforts of Democrats to claim credit for much legislation originally sponsored by Republicans, Chase Mellen Jr., New York County Republican Chairman, declared last evening in a statement that Governor Lehman'e action in signing the bill designed to create a State "Scotland Yard" was a case in point.

BERLIN, May 5. -- The German press was conspicuously effusive today in its congratulatory tributes to King George on his jubilee and the unanimity that inspires its felicitations stands out in contrast to the recent acerbity over Britain's part in the proceedings at Stresa and Geneva, the debate in the House of Commons on German rearming and Prime Minister MacDonald's public rebuke of the Reich's rearming policy.

VENICE, May 5. -- Considerable progress was reported today in the consultations going on here between representatives of Italy, Austria and Hungary to prepare the ground for the Rome conference next month for elaboration of the collective system of security in Europe.

PARIS, May 5. -- Municipal elections were held all over France today, but the exact political significance of their result cannot be estimated until the second ballot is held next Sunday. On that occasion the united votes of the minority parties may easily upset many calculations.

Persecution of Catholics in Mexico was condemned by a member of Congress and denied by a representative of the Mexican Government in a radio debate last night during WOR's forum hour. The speakers were Representative Emanuel Celler of New York and Eduardo Villasenor, Mexican Consul General in New York.

CHICAGO, May 4. -- Grain futures, with the exception of rye, closed lower on Saturday, compared with a week ago. Net losses on wheat were 2 1/2 to 3 1/2 cents a bushel; corn, 5/8 to 1 5/8 cents; oats, 2 3/8 to 4 cents. Rye was 3/4 cent a bushel higher on May and 1/8 cent higher on the deferred months.

MONTREAL, May 5 (AP). -- The Montreal Royals and Syracuse Chiefs divided a double-header today before a crowd of 15,000, Montreal battering an 8-to-1 triumph in the opener and the Chiefs rallying to win the seven-inning afterpiece, 3 to 2.

LONDON, May 5. -- King George and Queen Mary received one of the most remarkable ovations of their twenty-five-year reign tonight when they appeared on a balcony of Buckingham Palace and smiled and waved their hands at the vast crowd below.

Many who are flushed with success receive their gifts and blessings in the spirit of vanity and self-pride, forgetting "the providential nature of the origin of good things," the Rev. Herbert Lockyer of London said yesterday morning in a sermon at the Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street.

A fashion show in which young women of social prominence will be manikins is scheduled to be held during the luncheon hour today at the formal opening of Chatham Walk under the auspices of the Cooperative Committee of the Big Sisters.

An unprecedented honor to King George V. occasioned by the British monarch's silver jubilee, was paid by St. Thomas Church yesterday when a verse of the British national anthem, "God Save the King," was interpolated into the regular evensong service.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 5. -- A veteran campaigner and consistent winner, Ch. Rockefeller's Ace, owned by W.C. Ely Jr. of Terre Haute, Ind., won the best in show award tonight at the first specialty show of the Boston Terrier Club of Westchester held at the White Plains County Centre.

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, May 5. -- The government arrested hundreds of youthful opponents tonight in connection with today's parliamentary election and ordered all foreign newspaper men to get out of Croatia.
This city will have its first frog-jumping contest on May 19. It will be held in Central Park under the auspices of the Mark Twain Centennial Committee.

HERE is the prettiest kettle of fish that has been cooked up in a long time! Two Washington correspondents, combining under the pseudonym of George Michael, have written a book called "Handout" (Putnam, $2) that is going to cause plenty of squirming in the citadels of the New Deal. It is a "j'accuse" document of major proportions.
CHICAGO, May 5 (AP). -- The spectacle of more than 200,000 persons without food or money to pay rent and buy clothes faced Cook County today.

Tonight's theatrical matters are all off the beaten Times Square track, to the east and to the north. Stop one: In Harlem, a Negro repertory company will revive "Sailor Beware!" at the Lafayette Theatre, Seventh Avenue at 131st Street. Stop two: UP in Boston the Theatre Guild will open its Spring, and satiric, revue called "Parade."

Trading in futures on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet last week and prices fluctuated in a narrow range. New crop contracts tended to strengthen relative to old-crop months and active future contracts closed on Saturday 2 to 21 points higher than a week earlier.

PARIS, May 4. -- While the foreign exchange market was quieter this week, the weakness of the pound and the dollar indicated a lightening of the pressure on Dutch and Swiss currencies. The discount on forward sales of guilders and Swiss francs was heavier, indicating that anxiety was still felt, particularly with respect to Switzerland.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 5. -- Mrs. Dodge Sloane, with a party of guests including Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Dow Gibson, Miss Melissa Yille, Douglas W. Paige and Harry Payne Bingham, arrived today at the Greenbrier from Churchill Downs, where her horse, Psychic Bid, ran in the Kentucky Derby.
The ancients said one man's food may be another man's poison. The new name for it is allergy. It is the idiosyncrasy which makes the most respectable proteins disagree with a particular individual.

ROCKVIEW PENITENTIARY, Bellefonte, Pa., Monday, May 6 (AP). -- Robert Edwards died in the electric chair today at 12:34.5 A.M., Eastern standard time (1:34.5 New York time) for the slaying of his sweetheart, Freda McKechnie.

CHICAGO, May 5. -- The action of the corn market on the Board of Trade last week was a disappointment to those who had expected prices to advance to materially higher levels, as liberal selling on all bulges brought sharp price recessions despite the light movement from the country and reports that a little corn seeding had been accomplished in Central Illinois.

LONDON, May 4. -- The period of calm in the foreign exchange market, which lasted a fortnight, has been broken in the last week. Goldbloc currencies again are experiencing heavy weather, and, as was the case when the Dutch bank rate was advanced, the rise in the Swiss bank rate on Thursday accelerated rather than relieved the selling pressure on Swiss, Dutch and French currencies.
Industrial buildings, a garage and a theatre in New Jersey figured in leasehold deals over the week-end.
The Rev. John H. McComb took up the ministry of the Broadway Presbyterian Church, at 114th Street, yesterday morning. There were more than 600 worshipers present.

Three thousand members of the New York Postoffice Holy Name Society, attending the fourteenth annual communion breakfast at the Hotel Astor yesterday, heard the "tyrannies" of Russia, Germany and Mexico scored as being opposed to church and peace.

The twenty-second annual exhibition of the Allied Artists of America, Inc., will hold its varnishing day reception and private view this evening at 8:30 o'clock in the galleries of the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street.

The gift of $50,000 by Mrs. JAMES PARMELEE, making possible the resumption of structural work on the Washington Cathedral, is doubly significant. It gives work immediately for a considerable number of skilled men and it gives heart to many who ar concerned about spiritual recovery.
Dartmouth and N.Y.U. continued to set the pace in intercollegiate baseball last week as activities were considerably curtailed by the unfavorable weather.

St. Stephen's Protestant Episcopal Church, 128 West Sixty-ninth Street, celebrated the 130th anniversary of the parish with commemorative services yesterday morning. The parish was founded on May 7, 1805, and moved in 1897 to Sixty-ninth Street under its present rector, the Rev. Dr. Nathan A. Seagle. The Rev. Dr. M. George Thompson preached the anniversary sermon for Dr. Seagle, who is ill.

BERLIN, May 5. -- I have now had a glimpse of Germany's preparations in the air. Through the courtesy of General Hermann Wilhelm Goering, the Air Minister, I have visited the military airdrome at Staaken, the great military camp at Doerberitz and the colossal Air City now being built at Kladow.

In October of 1933 the Secretary of State, the Secretary of the Treasury and the chairman of the Federal Trade Commission invited a number of prominent men from different parts of the country to Washington to discuss the organization of a committee for the protection of American holders of foreign bonds.

A group of almost 100 picketers demonstrating in front of the General Motors Building on Broadway, between Fifty-seventh and Fifty-eighth Streets, were routed by the police at 12:45 P.M. yesterday and twenty of them were arrested.

There were 336,135 cases on relief in this city on April 26, according to the weekly statistical statement yesterday of the Emergency Relief Bureau. This number includes families, individuals, transients and homeless.

The New Jersey State Racing Commission, in its first annual report to the Legislature yesterday, said legalized pari-mutuel betting on races in the State would put $1,500,000 a year in the State Treasury.

Twenty years ago today a torpedo from the German submarine U-20 streaked through the slate-green waters of the Atlantic Ocean ten miles off Old Head of Kinsale on the Irish coast and struck the S.S. Lusitania squarely amidships on the starboard side.

CHICAGO, May 6. -- A call for a "grass roots" conference of Republicans at Springfield, Ill., on June 10 and 11, to "Lake an inventory" of America's affairs under the Roosevelt New Deal and prepare a "constructive program" for the 1936 Presidential campaign, was issued today by a Republican committee from nine Prairie States.

The American Museum of Natural History "faces another difficult year financially," according to the annual report submitted to the trustees yesterday by F. Trubee Davison president. The report said 1,113,000 persons visited the museum in 1934, an increase of nearly 200,000 over 1933.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 6. -- The torrential rains, which, accompanied by violent winds, have buffeted the city of Bahia for the last six days, abated for a short time today, but soon recommenced with increasing fury.

" Sailor, Beware!" suits the Harlem Players. They selected the late comedy by Kenyon Nicholson and Charles Robinson for the opening bill at the Lafayette Theatre last evening, and every one who was present understood it completely. When white actors were playing it on Broadway last season, this marine "variation of a familiar theme," as it was dubbed, seemed brisk enough to be thoroughly clear.
The oldest patient ever to be cared for at the Montefiore Hospital for Chronic Diseases. Gun Hill Road near Jerome Avenue, the Bronx, died there yesterday morning.

Every few months Mr. GEORGE N. PEEK is certain to emerge excited and alarmed by some new rearrangement he has made of figures long ago published by the Department of Commerce. The lack of novelty in the figures is more than atoned for by the striking novelty of his interpretations.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- President Roosevelt completed establishment of the work relief organization today by signing an executive order officially creating the Division of Applications and Information, the Advisory Committee on Allotments and the Works Progress Administration.

Four jurors from a special panel of 150 talesmen were chosen in General Sessions yesterday for the first-degree murder trial of Joseph Lieb Steinmetz, 22 years old, in the shooting of his 17-year-old wife, Ruth, last Nov. 26, in a room in the Knights of Columbus Hotel, at Eighth Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

GREAT NECK, L.I., May 6. -- Honors in the Long Island Golf Association's opening tournament of the season, a one-day amateur-pro open event at the Lakeville Club, were shared by four teams today. Sixty pairs played.

The New York Central Railroad carried 45,495,809 passengers in 1934, an increase of 477,297, or 1.06 per cent, from 1933, according to the annual report for last year, issued by F.E. Williamson, president. Through passengers increased 6.5 and local passengers 5.6 per cent, but commuting passengers declined 1.02 per cent.
WASHINGTON, May 6. -- The text of the Supreme Court decision, holding the Railroad Retirement Act unconstitutional, was as follows:

A movement to focus "the best thinking of schools, institutions, social agencies and citizens" on the pressing problems of maladjustment, retardation, truancy and delinquency was started yesterday by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools.

Fred Banninger's letter opposing restoration of city employes' pay cuts refers to several "oft-repeated facts," most of which are not facts, and yet constitute the basis of most misconceptions of the status of civil service employes.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-one leading cities on May 1 shows increases for the week of $72,000,000 in total loans and investments, $197,000,000 in net demand deposits and $58,000,000 in time deposits, and a decrease of $67,000,000 in government deposits.

GENEVA, May 6. -- Canada, in accepting membership on the committee of thirteen named by the League of Nations Council on April 17 to consider non-military sanctions against European treaty denunciators, has notified the League she opposes any general rule to this effect.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- An interpretation of the Federal Reserve Board's margin rules as they affect the authority of the business conduct committee of a national securities exchange to grant more than one extension to creditors in margin and cash transactions was issued today by the board as follows:

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- Upon learning of the death of Senator Cutting the Senate adjourned immediately and the House took similar action a few hours later. His death saddened official Washington and brought expressions of sympathy from President Roosevelt and high officials.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 6. -- Dr. Harlow Brooks of New York, who believes he is one of the first white physicians to be allowed to witness a "Medicine Sing" among the Navajo Indian tribes, described today the sincerity and apparent helpfulness of this method used by the Indians to cure illness.

Chalmers Wood of Johnson Wood, chairman of the committee formed to effect a settlement of the controversy over the validity of dealings in certain securities of the Alleghany Corporation, which were traded on a when-issued basis, said yesterday that a majority of the replies to a letter issued by the committee favored arbitration.

TOLEDO, May 6. -- Whatever the results of the poll of sentiment of 2,450 Chevrolet workers on Wednesday, when officials of the Department of Labor will supervise a canvass to ascertain the views of the strikers on the company's wage proposal, it is clear to observers here that a signed agreement and union recognition will not result from the action of the employes.

Yesterday's airplane crash in Missouri was the first in scheduled air transport in the United States in which any passenger fatalities have occurred since Jan. 1. It was also the first in America in which pilots or passengers have been killed in a Douglas transport plane.

LONDON, March 6. -- At 4 o'clock this morning, just before the dawn of Jubilee Day, the heart of London presented a spectacle unprecedented and unforgettable. From Buckingham Palace to St. Paul's the population was awake and assembling for the spectacle of eight hours later.
Less than two hours after the announcement of the Pulitzer awards, an attack had been made on one of the selections of the advisory board.

Mayor La Guardia emerged as the victor yesterday in his battle with the Consolidated Gas system when the company formally submitted to the city bids for providing electricity for the city this year at a figure $2,354,000 less than it tried to charge the city last December.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- The political complexion of the Senate will be changed by the death of Senator Cutting, who was regarded as an uncompromising fighter for liberal principles who ignored partisan politics.

The Catholic population of the United States, including Alaska and the Hawaiian Islands, now totals 20,523 053, an increase of 200,459 over the figures of 1934, according to Official Catholic Directory for 1935, published yesterday by P.J. Kenedy Sons of New York.

While volume was not as large as was expected, orders and reorders on Summer merchandise were quite numerous here yesterday. Business in white coats showed an increase, with crepe, novel material and cotton waffle styles receiving the bulk of buying interest.

The decision of the United States Supreme Court in overturning the Railway Pension Law acted to rehabilitate Wall Street's reputation as a prognosticator for decisions by the high tribunal -- a reputation which had been affected adversely by the findings in the "gold cases."

PHILADELPHIA, May 6 (AP). -- An attack on the Wheeler-Rayburn Holding Company Bill as "one of the most destructive pieces of legislation ever presented to Congress," was delivered today by John E. Zimmermann, president of the United Gas Improvement Company.

Nine aspiring writers whose hobby is collecting rejection slips from editors were announced as finalists in a contest for a scholarship in short-story writing yesterday at the Hobby Round-Up in the Port Authority Building, Eighth Avenue and Fifteenth Street.

ALBANY, May 6. -- Irving M. Ives, Republican leader of the Assembly, will go on the air next Sunday night over a Statewide hook-up to reply to the address of Governor Lehman in which he praised the Democratic record in the 1935 Legislature.

When a fog-shrouded airplane carried to his death Senator Cutting of New Mexico yesterday it cut down in relative youth the aggressive and dramatically successful political career of a statesman born to high financial station, but always a liberal champion of social advancement for the masses.

Senator Carter Glass, Dr. George E. Vincent, Cornelius N. Bliss and Dr. Harvey Cushing will receive gold medals of the National Institute of Social Sciences Thursday night at the institute's annual dinner at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Control of the American Export Steamship Line, which has been held during the last year by the New York Shipbuilding Company, has been sold to a banking syndicate that includes Lehman Brothers and Thomas L. Chadbourne, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- Congratulations were sent by President Roosevelt today to King George on the twenty-fifth anniversary of the British ruler's accession to the throne as a thanksgiving service was held in Washington Cathedral paralleling the one held in St. Paul's Cathedral in London.

Definite plans for the Republican campaign to recapture control of the Assembly will be made at a meeting at Syracuse on Saturday, according to John R. Crews, Brooklyn leader and chairman of the campaign committee of the Republican State Committee.

The railroads of the United States now expend about $35,000,000 annually in pensions. The Employes Retirement Act which the Supreme Court yesterday held unconstitutional would have brought this expenditure by the roads themselves to about $60,000,000.

The Consolidated Gas Company has now officially submitted its new bids for serving city buildings and lighting the city streets. They show an average net reduction over the earlier bids of something like 24 per cent. This is a substantial victory for Mayor LA GUARDIA, won by resort to the threat of public competition.

Reports of relief work among destitute seamen in fourteen world ports, submitted yesterday at the 107th annual meeting of the American Seamen's Friend Society, indicated that the withdrawal of merchant tonnage from service because of lack of passengers and cargoes had affected seamen in all parts of the world.
WASHINGTON, May 6. -- The text of the Supreme Court minority opinion on the Railroad Retirement Act was as follows:

Penthouse terraces and gardens in the rear of private houses in the city will be opened the afternoon of May 14 for the benefit of the Robert E. Lee Memorial Foundation, an organization devoted to the restoration and preservation of Stratford Hall, the home of the Lee family in Virginia.

PHILADELPHIA, May 6. -- William Clarke Mason, representing the Baldwin Locomotive Works, filed exceptions today to Federal and State tax claims amounting to $95,168 against the company. Argument on the claims will be heard by Howard Benton Lewis, special master appointed by the Federal court looking to the company's proposed financial reorganization.

" Hot dogs," known also as wieners, Coney Islands, half smokes, red hots and, on occasion, frankfurters, are New York City's favorite sausages. This information was released to the public yesterday by George A. Schmidt, chairman of the governing committee of the National Organization of Sausage Manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- A thorough re-examination of the New Deal social security legislative program in the light of the Supreme Court's decision on the Railroad Retirement Act was ordered today by President Roosevelt's leaders in the Senate.

Another unexpected plea of guilty to maintaining an objectionable apartment at 30 East Fifty-fifth Street blocked in Special Sessions yesterday the trial of Polly Adler on that and another charge that she kept an obscene motion picture film in the suite last March when it was raided.

Joe Rossi, East Side welterweight, outpointed Ray Napolitano of Williamsburg last night in the eight-round feature bout at the St. Nicholas Palace before a crowd of 5,000. Rossi weighed 147 1/4 pounds and the loser 147.

Senator CUTTING'S tragic death yesterday takes from the Senate an able and independent member. Going to New Mexico years ago for reasons of health, he soon established himself in newspaper work there. From this he seemed to gain a flair for politics, for which he soon displayed a marked talent.

ATLANTA, Mo., May 6. -- Out of fuel and desperately groping through a dense fog for a landing place, a twin-motored Transcontinental Western Air liner crashed early today at the edge of a pasture here and killed United States Senator Bronson M. Cutting, the two pilots and a woman passenger.
Methods of obtaining contact with the "spirit world" were argued yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Isidor Wasservogel at a hearing on a dispute between two groups of spiritualists.

CLEVELAND, May 6 (AP). -- Executives of three national organizations of railway employes interpreted the Supreme Court's decision today holding the Railway Retirement Law invalid as a direct blow to the administration's proposed social legislation program.

With the London market closed, dealings in foreign exchange were somewhat restricted yesterday, but they disclosed continued weakness of the gold-bloc currencies, contrasted with strength in the sterling group. The French franc dropped below its gold import point and, with the Netherlands guilder already below its gold point, an early resumption of the influx of gold to this country seemed assured.

Endorsement by the "great majority of consumers goods manufacturing industries" of the recommendations submitted to President Roosevelt last week by the Business Planning and Advisory Committee of the Department of Commerce was recorded with the President in a telegram, made public yesterday, from George A. Sloan, chairman of the Consumers' Goods Industries Committee.

The United Light and Power Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for 1934 a consolidated net income of $986,719, equal to $1.64 a share on 600,000 shares of $6 first preferred stock, compared with $1,510,925, or $2.52 a share on the same stock, for 1933.
The theft of jewelry valued at $10,000 on Friday from J. Starr Anderson, a broker, became known yesterday when two men, one of whom described himself as an archaeologist, were arrested.

HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., May 6. -- With a few more blisters, and most of their 325-mile ramble still ahead of them, the forty-eight hikers who hope to reach Danaville, N.Y., by May 20, at the latest, halted here at 5 o'clock this afternoon, sixty miles from their New York City starting point on the third day of the walk.

An appeal to help raise a fund of $30,000 to enable the Welfare Council of New York City to complete its program on the study of welfare and relief problems has been sent to 10,000 persons in the city.

CHICAGO, May 6. -- A much better demand for fresh pork today, with Eastern markets quoted as much as 3 cents a pound higher, brought all classes of buyers into the hog market here and, while early sales were 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight lower than on Friday, the close found medium and weighty butcher hogs about even with that day's prices.

LONDON, May 6. -- So tremendously exuberant was today's jubilee celebration of London's millions, swelled by tens and hundreds of thousands of visitors, that thirty-seven persons were taken to hospitals with injuries received in the big crush and the ambulance corps estimated at 1:30 P.M. it had treated 7,139 cases of fainting, sprained ankles and broken bones.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- Groves A. Whalen, chairman of the Board of Schenley Distillers Corporation, received $78,196 compensation in 1934, the company's registration statement to the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today. Lewis S. Rosensteil, chairman of the executive committee, got $50,280; Harold Jacobi, president, $35,300, and Lester E. Jacobi, vice president, $30,240.

PHILADELPHIA, May 6. -- Shareholders of the United Gas Improvement Company at the annual meeting today by a vote of 119 to 41 defeated a resolution to compel the company to throw open for inspection the minutes of meetings of the directors and the executive committee five days before an annual or a special meeting.

ALBANY, May 6. -- Governor Lehman signed today a bill requiring that all employes of the New York City Board of Transportation receive vacations with pay. Workers on the city subway system are under supervision of the Board of Transportation.

In an editorial, "Politics and Banking," you took occasion to inform your readers concerning the nature of the views expressed in my book, "The Supply and Control of Money." Instead of reading the book you chose to derive your information solely from a speech by Dr. Anderson, economist of the Chase National Bank, whose references to the book abounded in misquotations and distortions of its contents.

The seven-game winning streak of New York University came to a very unexpected and abrupt termination yesterday, splintering against the strong right arm of Xavier Rescigno. In the moist setting of Manhattan Field a Jasper nine that had won only one game all season not only toppled the vaunted Violets but shut them out in the bargain, 5 to 0.

CLEVELAND, May 6. -- The Cleveland Indians yielded first place in the American League to the idle Chicago White Sox today when they dropped the first game of their series with the Boston Red Sox, 2 to 1, as Fritz Ostermueller out-pointed Oral Hildebrand in a mound duel.

Although it has the fastest and most efficient airplanes in the world, with even more striking technical development under way, the United States, at the beginning of 1935, still lacked a comprehensive national aviation program, according to "The Aircraft Year Book for 1935," published today by the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America.
WASHINGTON, May 6. -- The chief points presented in the majority opinion of the Supreme Court on the Railway Pension Act follow:
Money market failed to move out of the narrow groove within which it has rested for weeks. Turnover was small, chiefly in replacements while quotations were unchanged for all classifications.

After the Big Parade, which terminated on Nov. 11, 1918, we were assured that there would be in the world no more parades. Books were writen with titles to that effect. Plays were produced which proved up to the hilt how sick the world must henceforth be of parading.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange early yesterday reached the highest quotations since the break in March but fell again and ended the day with losses of 7 to 15 points. The market was unsettled by persistent rumors that the manager of the government's cotton pool would make some announcement regarding government policies because of difficulties of consumers in obtaining raw material.

The State Liquor Authority at its meeting in Albany today will consider the question: Are bitters a beverage or are they a flavoring and possibly a medicine and stomachic? If they are a beverage, then they can be sold in liquor stores and presumably not in grocery and delicatessen stores.

On a motion by Prosecutor Daniel T. O'Regan, Judge Thomas F. Meaney in Hudson County Special Sessions, Jersey City, granted a nolle prosse yesterday in the case of Dr. Albert Rosenberg of 1,921 Hudson Boulevard, Jersey City, indicted on a charge of perjury.

NEWARK, N.J., May 6. -- Lieutenant John W. Wofford of the West Point team captured the individual military jumping championship of the fifteenth annual Newark Horse Show in the Essex Troop Armory tonight. Riding the 8-year-old black gelding Prince, Lieutenant Wofford made a faultless round the first time and then won the jump-off after a two-horse tie.

LONDON, May 6. -- Rudyard Kipling, favorite poet of the British Empire in its safer and more spacious days, made one of his increasingly rare public appearances tonight to warn of the dangers threatening the empire at the present time.

The opinion announced yesterday by the Supreme Court, holding the Railway Pension Act unconstitutional, is a decision of very large importance. This law was approved by the President about a year ago, but not without certain reservations. It was "crudely drawn," he said at the time -- so crudely that the decision whether to sign or to veto it had been "difficult" for him to make.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- By the narrow margin of a single vote, the Supreme Court today declared the Railroad Retirement Act to be unconstitutional, and in so doing raised serious doubts in the administration and Congress as to the validity of the pending Social and Economic Security Bill in its present form.

So many words have been written about the NRA that one more seems a sacrilege. The fact is, however, that a system of controlling the worst evils in industry today is in imminent danger of being wrecked largely because those for the system are tired of shouting its praises, while the relatively small minority against it are denouncing its continuance with increased vigor.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- Higher standards of wages in New England textile mills, propaganda which is helping to destroy American markets and a consequent piling up of surplus of finished goods, were blamed today by Governor Curley of Massachusetts for the present plight of the industry.

The annual announcement of the Pulitzer prize winners in journalism and letters, made last night in the Hotel Commodore at a dinner of the Columbia University School of Journalism alumni, had the added fillip of being surrounded by mystery which was dispelled only at the last minute.
WASHINGTON, May 6. -- The chief points presented in the minority opinion of the Supreme Court on the Railway Pension Act follow:
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 6 (AP). -- Flood struck at the Midsouth again today, taking ten lives in four States and inundating thousands of acres of farm and range lands.

Simon Schuster have just signed a contract, they say, with "The Unofficial Observer," who wrote "The New Dealers," for a book entitled "American Messiahs." It is a book about General Hugh S. Johnson, Huey Long, the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, Dr. Townsend, Upton Sinclair and others.

The committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it had received applications for permanent registration under the Securities Exchange Act from forty-four listed companies. This is in addition to those received in recent weeks.

TOMS RIVER, N.J., May 6. -- Testimony that indictments charging William H. Fischer, Toms River editor, with libeling officials of the county, were drawn by State Senator Percy Camp, a Republican leader, was taken today at a hearing before Supreme Court Commissioner David A. Veeder.
LONDON, May 6 (AP). -- "The old man -- God bless 'im!"

London was the centre of worldwide broadcasting yesterday as the far-flung British Empire joined by radio to celebrate King George's silver jubilee. From 6 o'clock in the morning until late afternoon American radio networks participated in the international pageant, heralded by the New York program directors as one of the most extensive and impressive broadcasts ever held.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 6 (AP). -- The most drastic shake-up in Harvard's long rowing history was made by Coach Charlie Whiteside today when he selected those he regards as the best oarsmen in his squad to form a new varsity eight.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- The aid of American military experts would be extended to the Commonwealth government of the Philippine Islands, which goes into effect shortly, under a bill passed today by the House. On a recommendation by Harry H. Woodring, Assistant Secretary of War, Manuel Quezon, President of the Philippine Senate, had asked that the action be taken.

" Famous Women of French History," it is called -- the exhibition that, with a reception and private view from 9 to 12 o'clock this evening, will serve to open the new permanent Gallery for French Art Inc., in Maison Francaise, Rockefeller Center.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 6. -- The annual Spring flower show of the Larchmont Garden Club was held this afternoon at the Larchmont Avenue Church House here. The staging committee included Miss Dorothea E. Axelstrom, chairman; Mrs. Johan Olson, Mrs. Edward Hedman and Mrs. Edward MacLoughlin.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 6. -- The Westchester Board of Supervisors voted unanimously today to restore one of two 10 per cent pay cuts to county employes receiving less than $3,000 a year.

The city of Portland, Ore., has announced formally its long-awaited refunding program which calls for the sale on May 22 of a new issue of $4,185,000 of bonds. The issue will be dated May 15 and will mature serially from 1936 to 1945. Bidders are asked to name the rate of interest at not to exceed 3 1/2 per cent.

Henry Seligman, member of the private banking firm of J. Seligman Co., left an estate of $1,277,970 gross and $1,203,254 net when he died on Dec. 23, 1933, according to the non-resident transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. His interest in the banking firm was appraised at $899,174.

Production of steel ingots in the United States in April amounted to 2,606,311 tons, compared with 2,830,700 in March and 2,897,529 in April, last year, American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday. Operations in the month averaged 45.28 per cent of capacity, against 49.18 per cent in March and 52.64 per cent in April, last year.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., May 6. -- Wesleyan and Amherst battled to a 6-6 tie in eleven innings today. The game was called because of darkness.

In the belief that the nation is ready for a mass movement for "constructive social action," the People's League for Economic Security began last night a national drive for the enactment of a seven-point program.

BERLIN, May 6. -- Dr. Wilhelm Frick, Reich Minister of the Interior, has finally received permission from Chancellor Adolf Hitler to call a halt on the wholesale arrests of Protestant confessional pastors. These have been made in recent weeks by the secret political police under the orders of Heinrich Himmler, chief of the black coated Hitler guardsmen.

S. Theodore Hodgman, assignee of the Royal Amplitone Company, manufacturer of movie sound equipment, filed notice yesterday in Federal court of a suit for $15,000,000 in treble damages that it will institute against alleged monopolists in the industry.

ALBANY, May 6. -- Governor Lehman today announced the appointment of Louis H. Pink of New York City as the new State Superintendent of Insurance. He will succeed George S. Van Sehaick of Rochester, who is retiring.

BALTIMORE, May 6 (AP). -- Walter M. Jeffords's brown colt Firstborn stepped into the front rank of Preakness hopefuls today by gaining a decisive victory in The Prep, generally regarded as a good pointer for Saturday's big race at Pimlico.

MOSCOW, May 6. -- Joseph Stalin, Soviet dictator, has at last explained why the Bolshevist regime has driven the Russian people into industrialization and collectivized agriculture regardless of privation and hardship and despite protests within the country against the punishing pace.
LONDON, Tuesday, May 7. -- Last night was one of the gayest London has ever known. It will go down in history with Mafeking Night and Armistice Night, the only previous comparable occasions.

A compromise resolution condemning war was unanimously adopted yesterday afternoon by 500 persons at the final session of the 136th New York Annual Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church at the Eighteenth Street Church, 305 West Eighteenth Street.

About 1,000 persons attended a meeting last night to celebrate the Silver Jubilee of King George. The session was arranged by the World Fellowship of Faiths at Christ Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.
The annual Negro festival will take place tonight at the Westchester County Centre in White Plains, with Alston Burleigh as conductor.

Outside of cocoa, which advanced because of the storm at Bahia, Brazil, commodity futures were irregular and dull on the local markets yesterday. On the cash markets all the grains, cocoa, gasoline and wool tops were higher. Cotton and silk declined and butter made a new low.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- President Roosevelt was asked, under a House resolution passed today, to transmit for information of that body a transcript of his press conference of Friday, in which he commented unfavorably on the anti-administration resolutions adopted by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

A moderate advance occurred last month in the average bond values listed on the New York Stock Exchange, with the average price for all listed bonds standing at $90.69 on May 1, comparing with $89.49 on April 1.

MADRID, May 6. -- A new Cabinet was formed today by Alejandro Lerroux, elderly Republican statesman, but it is unlike the three previous governments he has headed since the monarchy fell in 1931. His own Centre Radical party has fewer portfolios in the new Ministry than the Catholic Popular Actionists, whose youthful leader, Jose Maria Gil Robles, finally makes his Ministerial debut by taking over the War Office.

Mrs. Clarence S. Rose gave a luncheon yesterday at the Park Lane. Her guests were Prince and Princess Vladimir Koudacheff, Princess Francesco Rospigliosi, Mrs. James R. Deering, Mrs. Turnbull Oelrichs, Mrs. Chauncey Olcott, William B. Robertson, Samuel Bourchard.

Anatol Rapoport, young Russian-American pianist, made his first appearance at the Town Hall last night. His program included Bach-Busoni's Organ Prelude and Fugue in D and the Chaconne, Scarlatti's Sonata in A, Rameau's Gavotte Variee, a group by Brahms and Schubert, Debussy's "Hommage Rameau," Godowsky's "Moods from Triakontameron," Prokofieff's Toccata, Liszt's "Funerailles" and the "Campanella."

The news item "Roosevelt's Jaw Built for Sound," in THE NEW YORK TIMES, offers some rather astonishing conclusions. To assert that the jaw is a determining factor in the production of the voice is both unscientific and misleading.

FRANKFURT-AM-MAIN, May 6. -- Robert Rohne, an Austrian whose home is in London, was sentenced today to eighteen months in jail for "gravely insulting remarks" about Chancellor Hitler, Germany and German women.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 6 (AP). -- Finding a track which just suited his aging legs, the veteran Mr. Sponge, owned by J. Emery and trained by the former jockey, Frank Chiavetta, today splashed through the Churchill Downs mud to capture the feature Eastern Parkway Purse.

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will produce forty-nine feature films and seventy-three shorts during the 1935-36 season, according to an announcement made here yesterday coincident with the opening of the company's sales convention in Detroit.

DUBLIN, May 6. -- A solitary Union Jack flying with the Irish tricolor flag over Trinity College was the only public evidence of Dublin's association with King George's jubilee celebrations today. Officially the Irish Free State took no part in the celebration although the government was represented at the London ceremonials by High Commissioner John W. Dulanty.

Universal will display two of its horror films on Broadway this week. On Thursday night "The Werewolf of London," with Henry Hull, Warner Oland and Valerie Hobson, will open with a preview showing at the Rialto. A change in plans brings "The Bride of Frankenstein," with Boris Karloff, Colin Clive and Elsa Lanchester, into the Roxy on Friday instead of "Mr. Dynamite," as previously announced.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP). -- Representative Cannon, Democrat, of Wisconsin, after part of a night in jail, forfeited a bond today and failed to appear in police court to answer a taxicab driver's charge of drunk and disorderly conduct.

It is sometimes the case that when a long-awaited court decision affecting the markets for securities finally comes in the course of trading hours, the result, marketwise, falls considerably short of expectations. This is what happened yesterday when the United States Supreme Court's ruling invalidating the Railway Pension Law became known soon after 1 P.M.
An all-steel piano of rust-proof metal soon may be offered to the musical world as the joint experimental product of piano, steel and typewriter manufacturers.

BOSTON, May 6. -- A three-run drive in the ninth inning plus fine relief hurling by Waite Hoyt and Cy Blanton gave the Pirates an 8-to-6 decision over the Braves in the first game of their series today.
An imposing array of golf events appears on the schedule of the Metropolitan Golf Association, which has just made its appearance at the clubs in the district.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 6. -- Another important advance in the Bolivian offensive was reported from headquarters in the field tonight.
VATICAN CITY, May 6. -- Pope Pius, in an address today to 130 German pilgrims protested against Nazi Germany's alleged ill-treatment of 2,000 young Germans who made a pilgrimage here on Easter Day.

NEW ORLEANS, May6 (AP). -- An appeal for complete freedom of the press was coupled by Kenneth F. Baldridge of Bloomfield, Iowa, President of the National Editorial Association, with a statement today that since the newspaper code was put in effect "conditions are better than they were."

Mrs. Payne Whitney's Black Buddy, which appears to have reached his best form, scored his second straight victory by gaining a close decision in the featured Melville Handicap at six furlongs at Jamaica yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- Early passage by the Senate of full cash payment of the veterans' bonus was freely conceded today by administration leaders as they prepared to make a desperate stand to sustain a "certain" veto at the hands of President Roosevelt.

CHICAGO, May 6. -- A coalition committee of the Chicago Curb Exchange's membership approved today a resolution recommending that the governors of the Exchange establish a book value on seats as of June 1, next, as a basis for liquidating memberships of a group seeking dissolution of the organization.
