HERR KARL JOHANN GRIMM, painter, composer, wood carver and banjo player, came to town yesterday to see what could be done about moving the Giants out of the first place in the National League and moving his Chicago Cubs into that spot. Among other activities, Karl Johann is the manager of the Cubs.

Some of the thirty occupants of the upper two floors of the Hotel Alvin, Fifty-second Street and Broadway, probably owe their lives today to Ragatag and Dodo, pet dogs whose worried barking revealed a fire that swept the top floor of the six-story building at 5 o'clock yesterday morning.

The bond market on the Stock Exchange moved irregularly higher yesterday in fairly active trading. Railroad issues, particularly the more speculative liens, responded to the United States Supreme Court's decision nullifying the Railroad Pension Law, with gains of a point or more in many instances, most of which were retained through to the close.

Even the Weather Bureau, always ready to prove by statistics that matters "might be worse," was compelled last night to concede that the "merry month of May" had failed thus far to live up to its reputation. More than that, it was predicted that New York, which already had experienced seven successive days of rainy or overcast weather, may look forward to some more rain today.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

MAYFIELD, Ky., May 6 (AP). -- Terming the Coughlin-Long-Townsend economic plans bogey-men scaring the nation's business, General Hugh S. Johnson tonight advised a "forthright repudiation" of them by the Roosevelt administration.

ALBANY, May 6. -- Representatives of leading New York City merchants today joined forces with organized labor, consumers' and farm organizations in urging Governor Lehman in a four-hour public hearing to veto the Field-Crawford Price-Fixing Bill.

The second annual exhibition of "Needlework of Today," including about 1,000 pieces of amateur needlework, was opened for the benefit of charity yesterday at the Vernay Galleries, 19 East Fifty-fourth Street, and will be continued through Saturday.

CHICAGO, May 6. -- Corn became today the market leader in grains on the Board of Trade. The May delivery acted extremely tight and sold 1 3/4 cents a bushel higher than at Saturday's finish, closing at the top, while the distant months gained 1 cent.

Stealing credit for legislation is one of the meanest things a party can do. Yet Mr. MELLEN, of the New York County Republicans charges that the Democrats at Albany, aided and abetted by Governor LEHMAN, have done that very thing. The method is simplicity itself.
Chief Little Wolf, Navajo Indian wrestler, took another step toward a bout for the heavyweight title by defeating Dick Shikat, former champion of the world, at Madison Square Garden last night.

If you've got to have an operation, the sooner it's over the better. That is, from the business point of view. Our Canadian friends haven't long to wait. The Montreal Gazette says that preparations are being made for a Federal election "in Summer or early Autumn." Senator RAINVILLE, the Federal Conservative manager in Quebec, has sounded "a clarion call" to the party in his Province.

LONDON, May 6. -- George V. "by the Grace of God, of Great Britain, Ireland, and the British Dominions beyond the Seas King, Defender of the Faith, Emperor of India," completed today, on the anniversary of his accession, twenty-five years of a reign containing much tribulation, yet accounted glorious.

LONDON, May 6. -- Natives of these islands -- save for the conspicuous abstention of the Irish Free State -- underwent many hours of discomfort today to indulge in what to the uninitiated might have seemed one of the strangest of rites.

AMONG writers Eric Linklater, the laughing Scot, is a gay guerrilla who refuses to fight any one's wars but his own. A year ago, in the heart satire of "Magnus Merriman," he polished off the Scottish nationalist movement, which has had the modern Caledonians marching about in kilts and talking about the necessity of separating from England.

Entries for the eighth annual Albany-to-New York outboard motor boat race, which will be held on Sunday, have reached a total of seventy-three, one of the largest in years, it was announced last night at the final meeting of the racing committee of the Middle Atlantic Outboard Association at the Hotel Lexington.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- Constant reports that James Roosevelt, eldest son of the President, would become a member of the White House secretariat, were disposed of today with an announcement at the White House that he would go to Hyde Park to manage the dairy and forestry interests which the President maintains on the family estate.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- A review of the administration's monetary policy will be presented to the nation Monday night by Secretary Morgenthau in a radio talk, and it was indicated that he would then supply the answer to many inquiries about steles already taken and the goal sought.
Spring rains that have caused double-headers to burgeon like dandelions on the baseball turf brought more of the twin bills to view yesterday, including one each for the Giants and Dodgers.

PARIS, May 6. -- As was the case last week, the tendency on the Bourse today was toward firmness, with improvement in industrials and weakness in public funds. Electrical, chemical, holding, bank and some international equities, such as Suez Canal, were especially strong.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- A finding that "foreign influences were attempting to carve in this country a foothold for anti-Semitism," was made today by Sigmund Livingston of Chicago, chairman of the Anti-Defamation League, in presenting the league's report to the second day session of the fourteenth quinquinnial convention of the B'nai B'rith here today.

KLAGENFURT, Austria, May 6. -- The Yugoslav Government is announcing a great victory at yesterday's elections. Yet this correspondent found in Croatia evidence that in this part of the country, at least, there was apparently no reason for such claims.

HELSINGFORS, May 6. -- International sports relations in Northern Europe are likely to be considerably improved by the Finnish Athletic Congress's decision last night to lift immediately the strict boycott on Sweden started in 1932.

Some 125 undernourished school boys and girls of the Chelsea district on the lower West Side feasted at noon yesterday on a mammoth birthday cake, studded with raisins and coated with a half-inch vanilla icing.

Warned that long unemployment was building "a permanent army of misfits and unemployables" in the ranks of single women, representatives of thirty women's groups moved yesterday to draft a work relief program to aid women in industry.
VENICE, May 6. -- The way was tentatively opened today for Hungary to take part in the Rome conference next month that will discuss a system of collective security for Central Europe.

OWEN D. YOUNG, standing beside his portrait, which is to be placed in the great central room of the men's dormitory of St. Lawrence University, said that in this semblance he would through the years, even beyond the period of his own life, "anxiously watch" not only his own university but the "world as a whole."

ALBANY, May 6. -- Governor Lehman vetoed today the Byrnes bill which provided that civil service workers could be removed for cause only after public hearings, at which they could be represented by counsel.

Eighteen young women and twenty-two men, employes of the Lewis chain of department stores in Great Britain, arrived yesterday on the Scythia of the Cunard White Star Line to pass five days studying the methods of New York department stores.
BOSTON, May 6. -- Like most innocent pawns on financial chess boards, the one and only Babe Ruth, head cold and all, today was placed right in the "middle" of the Boston Braves' muddled affairs.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses will be called before the aldermanic committee investigating relief tomorrow or Thursday to explain why nine relief employes drawing pay from the Works Division received additional salaries from the management corporation of Jacob Riis Park, in Queens, it was announced yesterday by Lloyd Paul Stryker, committee counsel.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 6. -- The government today rested its case against Arthur (Doc) Barker and nine others charged with the Edward G. Bremer kidnapping after Byron Bolton, machine gunner for the Barker-Karpis gang, nervously told the story of the conspiracy to extort $200,000 from the St. Paul banker.

Value of Dollar in Exchange. The value of the dotlar on the local foreign exchange market based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):

Although fifty chorus girls appeared in court as "exhibits for the plaintiff," Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag refused yesterday to grant a temporary injunction sought by Earl Carroll, theatrical producer, against the United Scenic Artists Union Local 829.

Frank Greges donned his sandwich boards again yesterday and, a little wearily, resumed life just where he had been when fame touched him for a day. He plodded up and down the same stretch of Broad Street where, on Feb. 5, he had picked up $45,000 in negotiable securities and returned them to the owners.
BALTIMORE, May 6. -- The arrival at Pimlico today of Omaha, Kentucky Derby winner, gave impetus to racing interest here as preparations were speeded for running the Preakness on Saturday.
LONDON, May 6. -- The text of the address of King George V, broadcast to the empire today, follows:
TORONTO, May 6 (AP). -- Toronto and Albany broke even in an International League double-header today that attracted a crowd of 6,000 despite cold and rainy weather.

Net earnings of the Coco-Cola Company for the quarter ended on March 31 amounted to $2,106,332 after Federal taxes, dividend requirements on Class A stock and other deductions. This was equivalent to $2.13 a share on 985,900 no-par common shares, excluding 14,000 shares of stock in the treasury.

SANTA FE, N.M., May 6 (AP). -- An irreparable loss and a political earthquake were the two phrases that sprang to the lips of most New Mexicans today as they read of the death of Senator Cutting in an airplane accident while on his way to Washington to vote for the veterans' bonus payments he long had advocated.

There was not a sign of a pollack, the codfish taken reached the grand total of one, and even the lowly flounders turned exclusive. Nevertheless, some 300 optimists who journeyed to Montauk on the first "fishermen's special" of the Long Island Railroad last Sunday had a good time.

TRENTON, N.J., May 6. -- When the Legislature reconvened tonight Governor Hoffman and Speaker Lester H. Clee of the Assembly were still disagreed as to financing of emergency relief during the remainder of the year. As a result of conferences previously held, it has been determined that nearly $10,000,000 can be made available by economies and fund diversions, but only enough of this sum is left to last until July.
Former Governor Alfred E. Smith came to the aid last night of James W. Blake, the composer who wrote the lyric for "Sidewalks of New York."

LONDON, May 6. -- The monotony of waiting outside St. Paul's Cathedral for the arrival of the royal procession today was relieved for the crowd in the churchyard by watching some of the notables who walked out on the terrace to chat and to survey the less fortunate persons who had to stay outside.
ALBANY, May 7. -- Governor Lehman conferred today with Postmaster General Farley on a proposal to call an extraordinary session of the Legislature to seek to put through reapportionment.

The Park Department made public yesterday its schedule of concerts to be given in various parks this Summer. The Goldman Band series will continue on the Mall in Central Park as in past years, playing Wednesday, Friday and Sunday evenings from June 19 through Aug. 18.

More bargain-day attractions were added to the rapidly mounting list by the rain which prevented all of yesterday's scheduled games in the National League and one in the American League. The doubleheader between the Giants and the Cubs at the Polo Grounds was washed out, as was the meeting of the Dodgers and Cardinals at Ebbets Field.

Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase announced yesterday that a collection of 3,500 books and 2,000 pamphlets on economics, including many early and important works, had been presented to New York University by Felix M. Warburg.

Although the action of other markets and less rain west of the Mississippi River tended to ease prices on the Cotton Exchange several times yesterday, the market stiffened after each recession and ended at a gain of 2 to a loss of 6 points.

The Woman's Auxiliary of the National Council of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York held its annual meeting and corporate communion yesterday morning in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.
ALBANY, May 7. -- Governor Lehman signed the McNaboe bill today tightening the law on the issuance of degrees by professional schools.

Arthur Hays Sulzberger, son-in-law of the late Adolph S. Ochs and for several years vice president of The New York Times Company, was elected president of the company and publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday at a meeting of the board of directors, filling the vacancy caused by the death of Mr. Ochs last month.

Selection of the East's representative soccer team to oppose the Scottish internationalists, champions of Great Britain, when they make their metropolitan debut at the Polo Grounds on May 19, was announced yesterday by Secretary Jim Armstrong of the U.S.F.A.

Three of the four officers of the Cunard-White Star Line who were aboard the Lusitania when she was sunk by German torpedoes twenty years ago kept an engagement to meet yesterday morning aboard the Scythia to commemorate the anniversary.

AURORA, Ill., May 7 (AP). -- Tadcaster, racing in the colors of William Hinphy, former jockey, galloped to a surprise victory in the feature event at Aurora today. In his last start Tadcaster trailed by eighteen lengths.

The Columbia Yacht Club, homeless since Park Commissioner Robert Moses ousted it last Spring from the clubhouse at Eighty-sixth Street and the Hudson River, which it had occupied for sixty years, will establish new quarters further up the Hudson in the old Percy R. Pyne mansion in Riverdale at 247th Street.

The limestone balustrades on either side of the gilded statue of General Sherman at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street may be removed soon in order to make the Grand Army Plaza harmonize with the corresponding island on the south side of Fifty-ninth Street on which stands the Pulitzer Memorial Fountain.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- The Patman bill authorizing payment of the soldiers' bonus immediately with $2,201,000,000 of printing-press currency was passed in the Senate today by a vote 55 to 33 and headed straight for a White House veto, which administration leaders say will be sustained by a margin of about half a dozen votes.

Large-brimmed straws with shallow crowns tipped smartly to the right were the feature of the Summer millinery show that the Trade Development Committee of the Millinery Industry held last night at the Waldorf-Astoria. A thousand persons, including buyers, designers and manufacturers, attended the showing of town, country and formal hats and imported French creations.

The New York Civic Orchestra, Jacques Gordon conducting, will perform Beethoven's "Eroica," the Overture and Bacchanale from "Tannhaeuser," and John Powell's "Naehez on the Hill" at the Museum of Natural History this afternoon at 2 o'clock.

Commissioner of Accounts BLANSHARD bluntly told the aldermanic committee investigating the handling of relief funds that the members were wasting their time. They were simply giving the city a free "circus." What is really needed is a comprehensive survey, without prejudice or passion, so as to devise better plans for supervising all this spending by the city.
PHILADELPHIA, May 7. -- Claimants to the $17,000,000 estate of Mrs. Henrietta E. Garrett, numbering more than 5,000, were reduced by about 500 today by an Orphans' Court decision.

The board of directors of the Metropolitan Opera and Real Estate Company, owner of the Metropolitan Opera House and its site, will hold its annual meeting today at the offices of the Guaranty Trust Company.

Jimmy McLarnin, welterweight champion of the world, arrived here yesterday morning to launch his training campaign for the fifteen-round title bout with Barney Ross at the Polo Grounds on May 28. McLarnin, who completed his trip by train from Chicago, after flying to the Windy City from the Coast, gave a graphic account of the flight, a flight which held more than a few uneasy moments for him.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- An application for the registration of $50,000,000 of 4 per cent first collateral mortgage sinking fund bonds, the largest single issue filed under the Securities Act of 1933 by an industrial corporation not in reorganization, was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the National Steel Corporation of Pittsburgh.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- The Patman Bonus Bill, as passed today by the Senate and previously by the House, provides for immediate cash payment of the face value of adjusted service certificates in their full 1945 value.

LONDON, May 7. -- Jubilee Day is over, but the remarkable Jubilee spirit, a striking demonstration of the nation's deep affection and loyalty toward its monarch, continued unabated today and well into the night.
PITTSBURGH, May 7. -- Chuckling at his desk today is the diminutive "admiral" of the Pirates, William (Bill) Benswanger, son-in-law of the late Barney Dreyfuss.

Wall Street spent some time yesterday in seeking out "marginal cases" among the railroads which might be affected at this time by the decision of the United States Supreme Court invalidating the Railway Pension Law. The decision proved as ineffective a market factor as it did on Monday, when it was delivered, railway stocks easing in a listless market.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP). -- President Roosevelt today reminded the country that next Sunday is Mother's Day and said that it was unnecessary to issue a proclamation to call attention to such a day.

Despite the plea of Assistant Corporation Counsel Sherman S. Rogers that the city had "no money on hand" to pay a trust fund of $26,000 "illegally invested in mortgage securities" by a previous City Chamberlain from funds of the late Elizabeth D. Kingsland, Surrogate James A. Delehanty ordered yesterday that the money be paid to the legatees.

Bond prices moved irregularly lower on the Stock Exchange yesterday in somewhat heavier trading than on Monday, due mainly to a larger volume of business in United States Government long-term issues. The turnover was $13,401,300, of which government issues accounted for $4,267,300.

Two unfeeling but efficient robbers held up the wine and liquor store of Mele, Inc., at 25 East Fifty-sixth Street, just west of Madison Avenue, at 12:45 P.M. yesterday and escaped with $399 after locking four victims, two of them women, in the washroom.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 7. -- Heavy fighting continues on virtually all fronts from D'Orbigny to Vitiones. According to General Enrique Penaranda, the action is favoring the Bolivians. The opposing forces are drawn up in a great crescent nearly 250 miles long.
ST. LOUIS, May 7 (AP). -- Rogers Hornsby sent five pitchers against the Senators today, but the St. Louis jinx remained unshaken and the Browns dropped their ninth straight game, 7 to 3.

Reporting for the first three months of this year a net income for the sixth consecutive quarter, David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America, devoted his prepared remarks yesterday to the status of television, in which he said the United States had surpassed Europe and that television would not supplant sound broadcasting.

MANILA, Wednesday, May 8 (AP). -- Arrests as a result of the Sakdalista uprising mounted to 500 today as the constabulary was kept busy tracing rumors, including one from Cavite, that a plot to assassinate Manuel Quezon, President of the Philippine Senate, and other Filipino leaders had been uncovered.

After deliberating for an hour and five minutes yesterday, a jury in the Queens County Court in Long Island City found Mrs. Anna Kurzenhauser not guilty of a charge of felonious assault made by her husband, Edwin, a railroad engineer.

Relations between the United States and the Latin-American republics have improved greatly during the administration of President Roosevelt, Leo R. Sack. Minister to Costa Rica, declared yesterday in an interview at the Biltmore Hotel. Mr. and Mrs. Sack returned on the Santa Elena on the first vacation the Minister has had since he took office nineteen months ago.

" Handout," the new book in which the New Deal administration is berated, is getting away to a quick sale. Published on Monday by Putnams, it has already sold about 13,000 copies and re-orders started coming to the publishers yesterday, making necessary an order for a new printing of 5,000 copies.

A jury of thirteen was accepted in General Sessions late yesterday afternoon for the first-degree murder trial of Joseph Lieb Steinmetz, 22 years old, in the shooting last Nov. 26 of his bride of a few weeks, Ruth, 17, in the Knights of Columbus Hotel, Eighth Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Thrown into an uproar by the demands of Representative Dirksen, Republican of Illinois, for an investigation and impeachment of Judge Samuel Alschuler of the Federal Circuit Court in Chicago, the House listened today to the severest verbal chastisement of one of its members by another that has been heard this session.

NEWARK, N.J., May 7. -- The Federal Grand Jury handed to Judge Guy L. Fake today eight indictments against Reo Distillers, Inc., of 27 Jelliff Avenue, this city, one of the largest distilleries established here since prohibition, and three of its officers, on liquor tax fraud charges.

Earl Sande, hero of Flying Ebony's Kentucky Derby victory when he rode that fellow through deep mud, was the recipient of congratulations at Jamaica yesterday when he saddled his first winner of the year in Maxwell Howard's Polycletus, which made a show of his field in the Sands Point Handicap through the sloppy going which prevailed.

P.D. Hursh, treasurer of Durkee's Famous Foods, Inc., Elmhurst, L.I., was elected chairman of the Spice Grinders' Section of the American Spice Trade Association at a meeting of the division held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday in connection with the twenty-ninth annual convention of the association.

The directors of the Woodrow Wilson Foundation, 8 West Fortieth Street, voted yesterday to award the foundation's medal to President Thomas G. Masaryk of Czechoslovakia in recognition of his steadfast support of the Wilsonian principles of democracy, self-determination and personal freedom.

TOLEDO, Ohio, May 7 (AP). -- On the eve of a poll to be taken among employes of the Toledo Chevrolet plant closed by a strike since April 23, Francis J. Dillon, American Federation of Labor organizer, urged union strikers to reject the company's offers of a wage increase and other concessions.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Scheduled airlines operating in the United States established a new record in March, when 24,134,055 passenger miles were flown, the monthly survey of the Bureau of Air Commerce showed today. In March last year the passenger miles flown totaled 8,717,404.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- President Roosevelt's Advisory Committee on Allotments in its first meeting today at the White House segregated $2,000,000,000 for the eight types of projects designated in the Works Relief Act, and made several decisions on policy required to put the vast works program into immediate operation.
PARIS, May 7. -- The program for Foreign Minister Pierre Laval's trip to Warsaw and Moscow was settled in a Cabinet meeting this morning.

Oswald W. Knauth, director of the Emergency Relief Bureau, said yesterday that reports of his split with Mayor La Ouardia on the .Lyons compulsory residence bill for relief employes were "imaginary !and ridiculous."

PARIS, May 7. -- Reversal in the trend of rentes, which rose sharply, was a distinguishing feature of today's session of the Bourse. The rest of the market did not suffer, as equities also rose considerably in animated trading. Most rentes gained sixty to eighty-five centimes, closing at the best levels of the day.

The new State Mortgage Commission began operating yesterday by serving notice upon George S. Van Schaick, retiring State Superintendent of Insurance, to turn ever to the commission the defaulted certificated mortgages guaranteed by the Bond and Mortgage Guarantee and the New York Title and Mortgage Companies, together with the underlying real estate.

ST. PAUL, May 7 (AP). -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals in a decision handed down here today reversed the conviction of William Langer, former Governor of North Dakota, and four others charged with conspiracy to misuse Federal relief funds.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 7 (AP). -- Governor Lehman, at a dinner of Democratic women leaders of nine States here tonight, praised the accomplishments of President Roosevelt and denounced the criticism that he said he has heard in recent weeks.

BOSTON, May 7 (AP). -- Four persons perished today in a fire which swept the four-story Back Bay mansion of John Lavalle, portrait artist, World War bombing pilot and grandson of a former dictator of the Argentine Republic.

CHICAGO, May 7. -- Brisk competition was reported for hogs ere today, with the lighter weights selling to better advantage, some showing gains of as much as 25 cents a hundredweight over Monday's prices. The general market was up 10 to 15 cents, with the top lifted 10 cents to $9.30 and the average was 10 cents higher at $9.10, the highest since the middle of March.
ROME, May 7. -- A considerable extension of military preparations was announced today as a result of the Italo-Ethiopian situation.

Of your numerous British readers many are doubtless anticipating attending the Jubilee service for King George to be held at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine on May 12. I am afraid some of them may be sadly disappointed.

PHILADELPHIA, May 7. -- The Phillies, believing that to string along with their young hurlers is the club's best chance -- for 1936 if not for this season -- today cut the first veteran from their mound staff.

GENEVA, May 7. -- There were 48,300,000 radio receiving sets in the world at the end of 1934, according to an annual chart issued today by the International Broadcasting Office in Geneva. A. R. Burrows, director of the office, estimates this to represent 193,000,000 listeners.

The proposed ramps to connect the three new Hudson River piers, now under construction between Fifty-fourth and Forty-eighth Streets, with the West Side elevated express highway will be eliminated on an amended engineers' map to be considered by the Board of Estimate on Friday.

Dr. Thomas C. Poulter, senior scientist of the Byrd expedition and second in command, returned to New York yesterday on the Grace liner Santa Maria from Balboa, where he landed from the Byrd flagship Jacob Ruppert. He was accompanied by his wife and their three children, who had been living in New Zealand during his absence in Little America.

Miss Penelope Borden gave a din-J ner last night at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lewis M. Borden, 40 West Seventy-fourth Street, for her cousin, Miss Audrey Jaeckel, and John Hamilton Baker, who will be married May 17. Later the hostess took her guests to the Persian Room of the Plaza for supper and dancing.

From the conference of New England Republican Rejuvenators, called by State committees, came no healing word. What could be expected of cool and calculating Yankees? Their brethren of the Midwest are of a nobler temper. The Grass Roots are murmuring sweetly.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Dr. John D. Brock of Kansas City, a sportsman pilot, established a unique world air record here today when, piloting his little cabin plane over the capital, he marked his 2,000th consecutive daily flight. He began on November 15, 1929, and since then he has flown every day.

CHICAGO, May 7. -- Blinking like so many owls, the Yankees today got their first glimpse of the sun in many days and so contrived finally to start operations on their first Western expedition of the campaign.

I believe the following will furnish at least a partial solution of the problems discussed in your editorials "The Inevitable Plot" and "Meeting Criticism." It may also help to reassure the correspondent writing under the caption "Something Held Lacking" in the same issue.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 7. -- The Federal Bureau of investigation disclosed today that James M. Kemper, a friend of Attorney General Cummings, had been the target of a $250,000 kidnap extortion plea.
PHILADELPHIA, May 7. -- University of Pennsylvania girls had their first experience rowing in gigs today when Coach Rusty Callow put four crews on the Schuylkill. They were promoted from a big barge.

NEWARK, N.J., May 7. -- Newark's fifteenth annual horse show came to a colorful close tonight in the Essex Troop Armory, with a sparkling program that included the judging of the rich sweepstakes and championships in the several divisions.
WASHINGTON, May 7. -- A new form for the registration of fire and casualty insurance company securities on national exchanges was promulgated today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Bids were sought yesterday by the Board of Transportation on 500 new subway cars to be paid for with an issue of forty-year 4 per cent corporate stock. The cars are expected to cost somewhere between $19,000,000 and $20,000,000. Bids will be opened May 28.

ABSECON, N.J., May 7. -- Mrs. Leo Federman, member of the Lakeville Country Club, carded 82 to top the field at the end of the first round in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association tournament today at the Seaview golf links. Her net score was 81.

An application for an $800,000 public works loan for a building at Sea View Hospital, Staten Island has been submitted to the budget director by the Department of Hospitals, it became known yesterday.

TRENTON, May 7. -- Although the Senate bills authorizing New Jersey to enter into agreements with New York and Connecticut to check pollution of New York Harbor and adjacent waterways were on its calendar for the third reading, the Assembly adjourned for the week today without acting upon them.

WARSAW, May 7. -- The new electoral law with its peculiar blend of democratic principles and fascist tendencies was submitted today by the Premier, Colonel Walery Slawek, before the group of government and political leaders sponsoring it in the Sejm, or Chamber of Deputies.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 7. -- While her owner, Colonel E.R. Bradley, hung over the grandstand rail, Bazaar, a daughter of imported Tetratema, made a show of her opposition in today's Churchill Downs feature, the Wilderness Trail Handicap.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- In anticipation of the "home-coming" Friday of Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd and members of his second Antarctic expedition, both houses of Congress adopted a concurrent resolution today expressing the nation's gratitude for the "successful and heroic exploration" of the party.

BALTIMORE, May 7. -- High-spirited Preakness candidates pranced impatiently behind their stable bars at Pimlico today waiting for better weather to begin their workouts for Saturday's classic test for 3-year-olds.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- A resolution providing for American entry into the League of Nations was introduced in the Senate today by Senator Pope. It brought immediately from Senator Johnson, California Republican and arch foe of the league, this retort:

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Government acceptance of a compromise agreement on the Illinois relief situation was regarded as likely tonight, despite official reiteration that the State will not "get a thin dime" unless it begins to pay $3,000,000 a month at once as its share of relief costs.

OMAHA, May 7 (AP). -- Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. of New York told a Republican Founders' Day banquet here tonight that a swing away from the New Deal, which, he asserted, was now under way, would sweep the "New Dealers into political oblivion."

Architecture and the arts that accompany it now stand higher in the United States than anywhere else in the world, Dr. Ralph Adams Cram of Boston, chief architect of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, told members of the North American Conference on Church Architecture at their annual session yesterday at the cathedral.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 7. -- Discovery of a mysterious "torch murder" in Hudson last night resulted tonight in a purported confession by Anthony di Stasio, 23, that he and his father, Frank di Stasio, 48, had plotted the death of the unidentified victim in order to swindle insurance companies of $12,500.

BERLIN, May 7. -- Having temporarily conceded King George's silver jubilee the right of way as the day's outstanding news event, German official and editorial opinion is indulging in more serious contemplation of the Franco-Russian mutual assistance pact than was accorded that instrument on the occasion of its announcement last week.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market. based on quotations for the French i franc on the days indicated, com- pares as foIlows (quotations are in I cents):

Transfer of the American agency of the Anchor Line from the Cunard Company to the Waterman Steamship Company, an American line with its main office at Mobile, Ala., announced yesterday. Arrangements are being made at the New York offices of the Waterman company, 89 Broad Street, to accommodate the Anchor Line staff, which now occupies space in the Cunard offices at 25 Broadway.

DETROIT, May 7 (AP). -- Swinging into action again after a three-day enforced layoff due to rain, the Tigers let loose with a barrage of twelve hits today and defeated the Athletics, 5 to 3. It was the fifth straight victory for the American League champions.

Six Coast Guard craft and two airplanes searched the foggy waters off the New Jersey coast yesterday for a mysterious vessel in distress. Since an amateur radio operator in Manhattan accidentally heard a call for help early yesterday morning the vessels have maintained a patrol about twenty miles off Seabright, N.J., the position of the vessel, apparently a fishing schooner.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Approval of an amendment to the code for the commercial stationery and office outfitting trade, providing that members of the trade may enter into an agreement among themselves for the payment of liquidated damages for violation of code provisions was announced today by the National Industrial Recovery Board.

To the Masonic organization of this State politics must remain a "forbidden field," Grand Master Robert Elliott Owens declared in his address yesterday at the 154th annual meeting of the New York State Grand Lodge of Masons. The three-day convention opened at 71 West Twenty-third Street with more than 1,500 delegates and other officers of the order throughout the State in attendance.

When the Federal Works program under the recently enacted $4,000,000,000 measure is set into motion, there will be at least 215,000 employables now on the relief rolls of the Emergency Relief Bureau ready and qualified for employment on Federal projects, Oswald W. Knauth, executive director of the Emergency Relief Bureau, said yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 7. -- The identification of the influenza virus through observation of its effects on eight generations of ferrets was described today by Dr. I.J. Brightman of Yale University at the seventh annual meeting of the Society for Pediatric Research in the Chalfonte-Haddon Hall Hotel, here.

The city of Boston, Mass., announced yesterday that it will offer tomorrow at noon a new issue of $4,000,000 of revenue anticipation notes. The issue will be dated May 13 and will mature on Nov. 8. Interest will be payable at maturity, with the rate to be named by the bidders.

TRENTON, May 7. -- Ground-breaking ceremonies for the new Trinity Cathedral on West State Street, adjoining All Saints Chapel, featured the opening of the two-day meeting of the Episcopal Diocese of New Jersey here this afternoon. The convention, commemorating 150 years of diocesan life and the 250th anniversary of the First Church of England services sung in this State, is being attended by clergy from all parts of the diocese at the synod hall.

Rapidly mounting support for the textile industry export plan; by which the government would grant cotton goods exporters a 7-cent tolerance on each pound of the staple going into cloth for foreign shipment, was reported here yesterday by Samuel C. Lamport, chairman of the committee, sponsoring the proposal.

Reports were current yesterday in the financial community that prices of crude oil in the greater mid-continent area would be raised within a few days. For more than eighteen months prices in that section have held steady around $1 a barrel for the grade produced in the East Texas field.

ATHENS, May 7. -- The newspaper Vradene, Premier Panayoti Tsaldaris's chief organ, today underlined the probability of former King George's return, which is regarded as certain by many here. The government is certainly in constant contact with the exiled monarch through normal official channels.

The new three-cents-a-day hospital plan went into operation yesterday with an enrolment of 640 members and a large number of applications waiting for acceptance, it was announced by Frank Van Dyk, executive director of the Associated Hospital Service of New York, with offices at 370 Lexington Avenue.

The possibility of "a Berlin agreement" to settle the relations of Germany with the other nations of the world was predicted yesterday by Guillaume Fatio, Swiss banker visiting this country as a representative of the Central European Committee of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

Walt Disney's Silly Symphony, "Midnight in the Toy Shop," leads the new program at the Bijou Theatre. Among the other cartoons are Mickey Mouse in "Castaway," an MGM Technicolor short called "Toy Broadcast"; "On Trial," "Scrappy's Party," "Black Sheep" and "Wooden Shoes."

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- As Congress approaches its end when members must face their constituents and patronage hunters, the patronage revolt among some House Democrats has flared up anew. Led by Representative Sabath, chairman of the House Steering Committee, this group plans to lodge another protest with the President and seek more jobs for "deserving Democrats."
DETROIT, May 7. -- Vern R. Drum was elected president and general manager of the Hupp Motor Car Corporation today. He has been in charge of production at the plant.
The annual dispute concerning the best play of the season gathered force yesterday following the publication of the Pulitzer award.

Sugar, coffee and cocoa futures were more active and strong in yesterday's market here, but the balance of the commodity futures continued dull and irregular. On the cash markets all the grains, silk and lard declined, while dairy products advanced.

Your correspondent Charles H. Seaver does not view with alarm the entrusting to the government of the control of bank credit. In a way, his apathy, shared probably by most of our citizens, is not unjustifiable. Aside from the earlier inevitability of malpractice and inefficiency under political control (if history is any criterion), what difference does it make, as Mr. Seaver intimates?

Lewis W. Douglas, former director of the budget in President Roosevelt's administration, and Millard E. Tydings, Democratic Senator from Maryland, declared last night that continued government spending in the face of an unbalanced budget would lead to national disaster.

In the presence of the entire Board of Estimate except Mayor La Guardia, who spoke by telephone from Washington, Bernard S. Deutsch, President of the Board of Aldermen, was honored last night as a public leader and a Jewish champion by 1,000 friends at a dinner at the Hotel Commodore.

DEARBORN, Mich., May 7. -- In the presence of several hundred representatives of agriculture, science and industry, meeting beneath the tower of the reproduction of Independence Hall in Greenfield Village, there was proclaimed today a "declaration of dependence upon the soil and of the right of self maintenance."

NEWARK, N.J., May 7. -- An application by the Newark Morning Ledger Company for discharge of the trusteeship under which it has operated since January was taken under advisement today by Vice Chancellor M.L. Berry at the close of a hearing.
BERLIN, May 7. -- The Voelkischer Beobachter, leading Nazi organ, printed today a vigorous defense of the sinking of the Lusitania by the German submarine U-20 just twenty years ago.
DETROIT, May 7. -- Nearly 6,000 operagoers crowded into the Masonic Auditorium tonight to hear the world premiere of Puccini's "La Rondine" as sung in English.

The Consolidated Oil Corporation has arranged for a loan of $40,000,000 from a group of banks to retire two bond issues outstanding in the amount of $48,000,000, including about $3,000,000 now in its treasury. The bank loans, which will run from two to five years, may be repaid any time.

IN recent years announcement of the Pulitzer awards has been the signal for the more atrabilious columnists and critics to get out their knives and blowguns for a general slaughter. And in justice to the instincts of these contrarious fellows, it must be said that the choices in the immediate past have not been invariably distinguished for either acumen or sensibility.
WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Members of Admiral Byrd's expedition began assembling today for the "homecoming" celebration.

The New York State Association of Manufacturing Retail Bakers, meeting yesterday at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, for its fortieth annual convention, adopted unanimously a resolution threatening to withdraw from the code of fair competition for the baking industry unless the industry was allowed to regulate itself through a State body "without interference from other agencies."

Daily average gross production of crude oil in the United States last week was 2,494,100 barrels, compared with 2,561,400 in the previous week, a decline of 67,300 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A drop of 64,150 barrels was recorded in Oklahoma.

A FEW more days of rain and some of the teams will have to start the training season all over again. But the Chicago White Sox prefer to go right on from where they are now. The suspicion is that they will go off instead of on, however. In the meanwhile, Manager James J. Dykes must be strutting around smoking two cigars at a time.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Plans for a campaign to arouse public opinion to what were described as the dangers of the spoils system in government were revealed before the general council of the National League of Women Voters today in a committee report by Mrs. George Gellhorn of St. Louis.
BRONSON CUTTING went to New Mexico in search of health and found in addition a career. ISABELLA GREENWAY went to Arizona in search of health for a young husband and struck her roots in the soil.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Charging the present administration with breaking its campaign pledges and political spending of relief funds with consequent waste, Governor Talmadge of Georgia appealed tonight for a "return to the Constitution" and abolition of the National Industrial Recovery Act, the Agricultural Adjustment Act, all processing taxes and immediate payment of the bonus.
In the magazine section of your issue of May 5 there appeared an article by G.E.R. Gedye entitled "Slowly Peace Advances in the Balkans."
The "Adonis of the police force," Patrolman George Sylvester Vincent Wandling, has resigned from the department, Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday.

The need for better housing and the importance of Federal action in making it a reality on a national scale were stressed by President Roosevelt and Secretary Harold L. Ickes in messages read last night at the annual dinner of the National Public Housing Conference.

DUBLIN, May 7. -- Thousands from all parts of Ireland thronged the Royal Dublin Society's show grounds in Ballsbridge today for the opening of the Irish Free State's first big industrial fair. The place where Dublin's famous horse show is held was today a microcosm of the new industrial Ireland which has sprung into being during the past three years.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 7. -- Hunger demonstrators appeared at the State Capitol today as Governor Homer awaited word from Relief Administrator Hopkins on the immediate enactment of the Governor's tax program, which would assure help for the 1,200,000 persons on relief.

Little enthusiasm was manifested by the markets yesterday. Stocks showed a little wider decline than on the day before in diminished trading, although the list was not without a few strong spots. Bonds were lower, notably United States Government issues as bonus legislation claimed an important place in the day's news.

A decrease in the number of buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was noted in comparison with the figures for the preceding week. However, the total was above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.

An attack on demagogues was made and the question of whether American democracy shall be supplanted by despotism was raised last night by Dr. Robert A. Millikan, internationally known scientist and director of the California Institute of Technology in an address from Hollywood, Calif., over a coast-to-coast network of the National Broadcasting Company.

Before it reached the Supreme Court the Railway Pension Act was held by a lower court to be unconstitutional primarily for the reason that it attempted to establish a Federal pension plan for all employes of the transportation companies, "making no dis-"tinction between those engaged in in-"terstate commerce and those not so "engaged."

STROUDSBURG, Pa., May 7. -- Bernarr Macfadden and thirty-nine of the forty-eight who started from New York on the "bunion derby" to Dansville, N.Y., rested here tonight after having covered the longest day's hike of the trip, making 28 miles since 7:15 this morning.

The thirteenth annual Spring Salon, put on by Salons of America, Inc., opened with a reception for the artists and their friends last evening at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, where, beginning today, the work will be shown to the public until May 25.

POINT BARROW, Alaska, May 7. -- Fourteen deaths had been counted at Point Barrow and Wainwright today as the toll of an influenza epidemic, and others were expected to die. All but one of the victims were natives.

BERLIN, May 7. -- The Boerse resumed today the steady downward course which was interrupted by a rally a week ago after an announcement that wages would not be raised as threatened. Widespread evidence of weakness yesterday is said to have hurried speculators into realization selling this morning.

Another metropolitan polo centre announced plans for its season yesterday when Captain C.E. Davis, leader of the Governors Island team which recently won the national junior indoor championship, released plane for Morris Memorial Field this Summer.

With Park Commissioner Robert Moses scheduled to take the stand before the Aldermanic Committee Investigating Relief at 10 o'clock this morning, the inquiry uncovered yesterday the case of a thrice-bankrupt iron works proprietor who obtained park work to the value of $58,000 after getting a $45 relief job for himself and a $33 job for his son.

A statement that the New York County grand jury investigating vice conditions, bail bond practices and the policy racket has had little success was presented yesterday by Lee Thompson Smith, the foreman, to Judge Morris Koenig of General Sessions.
Custom among newspapers requires a new publisher to announce his policies and to them pledge adherence.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Father Coughlin and the bonus inflationists won the battle in Congress today when the Senate followed the House in the passage of the Patman bill, which directs an issue of greenbacks to pay immediately veterans' adjusted service certificates, due in 1945.

Net profit of the Standard Oil Company of California in the first quarter of this year was $4,891,021 after expenses, depreciation, depletion, amortization, estimated income tax, dividends paid on outstanding preferred stock of a subsidiary and other charges. This was equivalent to 37 cents a share of Standard Oil Stock. It compared with a net profit of $3,318,590, or 25 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter of 1934.

Captain Charles Beckwith, Montauk skipper who fishes commercially in the early Spring, made a sizable haul of pollack and codfish in his set lines off Block Island yesterday morning, according to word received by Captain Walter Willis of the Long Island Railroad. It was said to be the first good catch of pollack by a commercial man this year.

Savings bankers of the country will open today in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria the three-day annual convention of their organization, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks. Representatives from institutions in all of the eighteen States in which mutual savings banks operate will be present.

Detailed scores of games played by Jose R. Capablanca of Havana, former world chess champion, in the early part of the international tournament recently concluded at Margate, show that the famous Cuban master had a close call with W.A. Fairhurst, Scottish champion, and may be regarded as having been fortunate in escaping with a draw.

The American Bankers Association sent yesterday to the 12,000 banks composing its membership a letter revising its position on the proposed Banking Act of 1935 so as to assume a much stronger stand against certain portions of the measure than it had previously expressed.
BAHIA, Brazil, May 7 (AP). -- Six homes rolled from a hillside under an avalanche today in storm-stricken Bahia and thirty persons were estimated to have been killed in the wreckage.

PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, May 8. -- The Rev. Dr. George Cadwalader Foley, theologian, preacher, educator and writer, who had been active in the Protestant Episcopal priesthood for nearly sixty years, died at 1:15 o'clock this morning at his home here.

ABOARD S.S. NORTH HAVEN, May 7 (by Wireless). -- The navy transport Henderson, carrying officers and men to various Asiatic stations, and the steamship North Haven, with the Pan American Airways expedition now colonizing Pacific islands as airports for the projected United States-Orient air line, are converging to meet in mid-Pacific on one of those errands of mercy that make the epics of the sea.

SAN JUAN, P.R., May 7. -- Chief Justice Emilio del Toro of the Supreme Court will not prosecute Luis F. Velazquez, Nationalist, for having slapped him on June 15, 1932, he advised United States District Attorney Cecil Snyder today. He asserted that he wanted neither to persecute nor to make a martyr of his assailant.

Gravely ill, but cheerful because former Governor Alfred E. Smith had befriended him, James William Blake, 72-year-old author of "Sidewalks of New York," was resting comfortably last night in St. Vincent's Hospital.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Payment by United Drug, Inc., of $62,255 compensation to Louis K. Liggett, president, in 1934, was reported in a registration statement filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The report, which included remuneration from subsidiaries, also disclosed payment of $26,057 to George M. Gales, president of Liggett Drug Company, Inc.

So far as it is possible to acquire a play that has not yet been written, Sam H. Harris has accepted "God's in His Heaven," by George Jessel and Mark Hellinger, the columnist. It is about the home life of a West Coast film producer and, though no one is saying so definitely, it seems reasonable to think that Mr. Jessel will be in it.

ALBANY, May 7. -- Governor Lehman vetoed today two bills which would have cut the working day of employes of many State institutions to eight hours. He said that the State could not at the present time bear the extra financial burden the program would impose.
Percy L. Gassaway, Oklahoma's new and picturesque "Cowboy Congressman," came to New York yesterday to fire away at his arch enemies, Senator Huey Long and Father Charles E. Coughlin.

ALBANY, May 7. -- Major John A. Warner, Superintendent of State Police, tonight completed plans for the creation of an independent criminal investigation unit in each of the seven State police troops under the "Scotland Yard" law just approved by Governor Lehman.

This is the name given to the emigration of juvenile groups from other countries to Palestine; but it has come to be applied especially to the groups of youth going from Germany. It is the largest rehabilitation activity for children that has ever been undertaken in modern times except during the World War period.
CHICAGO, May 7. -- Increased selling pressure developed today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade and disclosed a lack of support after a steady opening. Closing trades were about the bottom.

Television will be taken out of the laboratory for field tests, David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America, announced yesterday at the annual meeting of the corporation's stockholders.

BALTIMORE, May 7. -- Grand Slam, developed during the Winter racing season, today carried the banner of the Bomar Stable, owned by the Detroit sportsmen, Bohn and Markey, to victory in the twenty-seventh running of the Pimlico Nursery Stakes.
BISMARCK, N.D., May 7 (AP). -- William Langer today hailed the ruling granting him a new trial as proof "I am an honest Governor."

The opening of. Chautauqua Institution, sixty-one-year-old educational centre on Lake Chautauqua, N.Y., for another Summer season on July 7 was announced last night by Dr. Arthur E. Bestor, president of Chautauqua, at a dinner at the Town Hall Club.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Definite Senate opposition appeared today to President Roosevelt's proposal to abolish all except "necessary" public utility holding companies, with the prospect growing that that chamber would enact legislation calling for regulation, without abolition.

Another regatta was added to the list of college rowing events for this season yesterday when it was officially announced that Marietta College of Ohio would be host for the Mid-America Intercollegiate Rowing Regatta on the Ohio River at Marietta on Saturday, June 1.
I wish to commend and endorse the letter from Ernest Flagg published recently under the title "Glorified Mob Rule."

LONDON, May 7. -- Diplomatic circles in London were greatly pleased today by confidential information that has been filtering in throughout the day from Continental sources. It is all to the effect that Adolf Hitler in a notable speech he is preparing on the European situation, to be delivered before the Reichstag ten days hence, will strike a conciliatory note.

HARRISBURG, Pa., May 7. -- Shortly before a joint legislative committee began an investigation into the methods of the State Emergency Relief Administration, the Senate voted today to rip out the State Relief Board and place relief distribution in the hands of assistance boards in each of the sixty-seven counties.

The scramble for the thirteen places in the national open golf championship allotted to the metropolitan sector will take place on Monday with the qualifying tests at the Baltusrol Golf Club, Short Hills, N.J.
ALBANY, May 7. -- New York State will receive about $500,000,000 as its share of the $4,880,000,000 Federal relief program, it is expected by State officials.

MACON, Mo., May 7 (AP). -- A crippled radio set, blinding fog before dawn and a dwindling gasoline supply were points presented today to a coroner's jury seeking to explain the death plunge early yesterday of TWA's "luxury" night liner, the Sky Chief.
WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Large corporations reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission today the following salaries and large stockholdings:

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Convinced that the Social Security Bill, keystone of President Roosevelt's social reform program, does not fall within the general prohibitions laid down by the Supreme Court yesterday in its invalidation of the Railroad Retirement Act, Administration leaders today nevertheless began an intensive study of the measure in the light of the court's decision to make it "bullet-proof" before it is permitted to come up for vote in the Senate.
The suit to test the recent custody ruling in the case of' 10-year-old Constance Brock of Mamaroneck, N.Y., Was heard yesterday by the Appellate Division in Brooklyn. Decision was reserved.

Hollywood is the intellectual centre of the world, in the minds of the Syrians and their neighbors in Asia Minor, Dr. Bayard Dodge, president of Beirut University in Syria, declared yesterday at a tea given in honor of him and Mrs. Dodge by Dean Virginia Gildersleeve of Bernard College.

John W. Hanes, one of the ten official nominees for the governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange, clarified his position on the question of commissions yesterday in a statement answering attacks which, he said, had been made on him by supporters of the four independent nominees for the governing board.

Twelve hundred prospective buyers crowded into the Property Clerk's office at the foot of Thirty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, when the Police Department's 276th public auction of unclaimed articles opened yesterday at 10 A.M. Most of the bargain hunters were men, but there was a scattering of women and young boys also.

Since the beginning of the first Five-Year Plan many outside observers have been puzzled by the almost frantic pace at which the industrialization of Soviet Russia was proceeding. Was so much haste, inevitably resulting in heavy waste, really necessary? They marveled at the sacrifices that the Soviet masses were called upon to endure.

ST. THOMAS, Virgin Islands, May 7. -- Ignoring the opposition against his administration, Governor Paul M. Pearson had just held conferences with representatives of leading New York financiers and with Arnold Golden, president of the St. Croix Chamber of Commerce and chairman of the Colonial Council of that island.

Mayor La Guardia and former Governor Alfred E. Smith will appear together in blackface on May 26 for the first time in their public careers, it was revealed yesterday. Their debut as a blackface comedy team will be made at an amateur minstrel show to be given at the St. James Theatre by New York Lodge 1 of the Elks, of which Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora is Exalted Ruler.

What union circles yesterday characterized as a possible signal for a strike of 50,000 cloakmakers after June 1, when existing agreements in the garment industry expire, came yesterday in the form of a statement from the Merchants Ladies Garment Association announcing its determination to obtain revision of its present contract with the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

The Municipal Art Commission, it was learned yesterday, has rejected designs for mural paintings to decorate the corridors outside the chapel in the new Rikers Island penitentiary but has given its tentative approval to a design for a mural in the recreation room of the Women's House of Detention in Greenwich Village.

THE NEW YORK TIMES editorial "British Taxes and Ours" is in the right direction, but fails to emphasize one glaring reason why Senator La Follette's statement that we do not tax wealth as highly as does Great Britain is fallacious. You say, "Even income tax comparisons must be read with the warning that the two countries define income differently for taxation purposes: the British, for example, do not tax capital gains as we do."

CHICAGO, May 8. -- For nearly a week several leading commission houses have been expressing a belief that July wheat probably would be a good purchase at 94 to 95 cents a bushel. An early dip today on the Board of Trade carried the market into that zone, with the result that commission-house buying increased and absorbed the surplus in the pit.

Yesterday Mr. MOSES gave the aldermanic committee a graphic account of some of the difficulties encountered in the administration of "work relief." Describing it as "infinitely preferable" to the straight cash dole, he nevertheless found the whole present system essentially a makeshift -- "a very poor "substitute for ordinary business, ordi-"nary private enterprise."
ALBANY, May 8. -- Governor Lehman signed today a group of five bills recommended by the Law Revision Commission which he said brought State law into harmony with modem social and economic conditions.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 8. -- Seniors of Princeton University voted 278 to 86 that they would rather win a Phi Beta Kappa key than a varsity letter in college, it was announced tonight at the annual class dinner in Madison Hall on the campus here.

Casualty and surety insurance corporations cut their underwriting loss from $15,337,396, or 3.2 per cent, in 1933 to $8,551,013, or 1.7 per cent, last year, according to the annual statistical analysis of the industry, made public yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 8 (AP). -- After losing the first game of a double-header today to Cincinnati, 15 to 4, and running their losing streak to nine straight, the Phillies turned on the Reds and gained a 5-to-4 victory in the nightcap.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:
CHICAGO, May 8. -- For a brief interval today the Yankees flashed back to the days of their former triumphs. They walloped three homers and the one-time steamroller appeared to be in action again.

Strength and activity returned to several staples in the local commodity futures markets yesterday. Coffee and cocoa, which were strong features on previous days, reacted in light trading, and sugar continued its forward movement with a large turnover.

An effort is being made to inject "anti-social propaganda" into paintings paid for as relief work by the government, according to Jonas Lie, president of the National Academy of Design and painter member of the Municipal Art Commission.

Harold W. Garton, store manager of Lord Taylor, has been re-elected president of the Stores Mutual Protective Association, it was announced yesterday following a meeting of the organization at the Empire State Club. Sheridan Gorton of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., was named vice president to succeed Royal S. Evans of Oppenheim, Collins Co. Van B. Sims of Lord Taylor was elected treasurer and H. Nelson Street, secretary.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP). -- Oscar Johnston, manager of the 1933 cotton producers' pool, announced today that, effective at once, limited amounts of government pool cotton will be sold for immediate consumption or export.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- Payments made to Archie M. Andrews, former chairman of the board of the Hupp Motor Car Corporation, after a letter had gone forth to stockholders last August, stating that "one officer" was serving without salary, were the centre of questioning today at the Securities and Exchange Commission's hearing on the New York Stock Exchange's application for permission to drop Hupp shares from its list.

Former Magistrate Charles A. Oberwager announced yesterday that he had been retained by Mrs. Anna Hauptmann to defend a suit for attorney's fees brought by Edward J. Reilly, former chief counsel for Bruno Richard Hauptmann.

In the second accusation made by a Federal grand jury investigating the sale of mortgages and mortgage certificates, the State Title and Mortgage Company and four of its former officials were indicted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- An upward trend in building in many sections, with operations ranging from minor house repairs prompted by Federal Housing Administration aid, to major engineering projects, was reported today by the Department of Commerce in its weekly survey of business in thirty-three cities.

One of two Negro hold-up men chopped the tips of two fingers off the left hand of Henry Ohlandt, 34 years old, manager of a chain store at 132 Buffalo Avenue, near Bergen Street, Brooklyn, shortly after noon yesterday when Ohlandt demurred at the robbers' command to open the safe.

BALTIMORE, May 8. -- Carrying the crushing impost of 120 pounds and perfectly ridden by Jockey R. Workman, Collateral, in the livery of C.V. Whitney, triumphed today in the best offering at the Pimlico course. He accounted for the mile and one-sixteenth Class B graded handicap.
WASHINGTON, May 8. -- The Senate apparently was headed into another deadlock today, soon after the Democratic steering committee mapped a program on which quick action was to be sought.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- The government controlled corporation, wholly or partially owned by the government, is no longer a transitory device for speedy action, Louis B. Wehle of New York told members of the American Bar Association here today.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- A general denial of all allegations made in the gold clause suit brought in the Court of Claims on March 11 by Robert A. Taft, son of the late President and Chief Justice, was filed today by the Department of Justice, which asked that the suit be dismissed.
ALBANY, May 8. -- Objections to State NRA codes must be filed with Edward J. Flynn, Secretary of State, before May 24, his office announced today.

ROME, May 8 (AP). -- The possibility of conciliation of the boundary dispute between Italy and Ethiopia was seen tonight by authoritative circles, but Premier Mussolini continued to push his huge military preparedness program.

LONDON, May 8. -- It is understood here that, subject to the Home Office's permission, a bout between Max Baer, world's heavyweight champion, and Max Schmeling has been arranged for Aug. 17 at Wembley Stadium. It was learned that at today's meeting of the Wembley Board of Control approval for the match was given.

To conform to a Federal policy giving first consideration on public works to unemployment relief, the Board of Education, at its meeting last night, upset its priority list of new school buildings which had been arranged in order of necessity and thus delayed, against its wishes, efforts to relieve congestion in classrooms.
I was much interested in a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES under the caption "Defending the NRA," and signed by Ernest G. Draper.

ALBANY, May 8 (AP) -- Vigorous denial that the Roosevelt "New Deal" was heading the nation toward bankruptcy, fascism and communism was made today by two Democratic women members of Congress, Caroline O'Day of New York and Mary T. Norton of New Jersey, at a conference of several hundred Democratic women leaders from nine Northeastern States.

As a result of strikes in the automobile industry, the rate of steel ingot output has declined from 46 to 45 1/2 per cent of capacity, according to The Iron Age's weekly review, issued yesterday. Increased activity in Chicago and Buffalo failed to offset a recession of three points in the Cleveland-Lorain area, the magazine stated.

The city of St. Louis, Mo., will offer for public sale $1,800,000 of relief bonds, dated June 1, next; due from June 1, 1941 to 1945, and callable in 1940. Call for bids is expected about June 1. Two issues of St. Louis bonds are selling at prices to yield 2.35 per cent for 2 3/4s maturing in 1951 and 2.50 per cent for 3s maturing in 1954 and 1955.

Attempts to interpret yesterday's market movements in terms of response to the passage of the Patman Bonus Bill were peculiarly difficult. The government bond market was strong, whereat it was remarked that this reflected a belief that passage of the Patman bill in the face of assurances of a Presidential veto meant that there would be no bonus legislation in this Congress.
Realty trading yesterday was featured by leasehold deals in Manhattan and sales of apartment houses in the Bronx.

Vincent Astor will obtain possession of the Hotel St. Regis and the present receivership will be ended under the terms of an agreement yesterday between attorneys for Mr. Astor and for corporations controlled by the heirs of Benjamin N. Duke.

Outboard marathon drivers, those intrepid seafarers whose idea of cruising is to go forty-odd miles an hour in a watch-charm of a boat, now total an entry of eighty-five for the Albany-to-New York classic, which will start Sunday morning at 7 o'clock.

Pitching magnificently for twelve innings while the Dodgers gave one of their poorest batting exhibitions at Ebbets Field in a long time, Van Lingle Mungo finally was rewarded with a sundown triumph yesterday.

Manhattan Island, with its wooded upper regions, is not so different today from what it was in 1626, when Peter Minuit bought it from the Indians for about $24. Game, though no longer plentiful, is still to be found, and the wild fox can be seen, pursued by equally ferocious dogs -- if one gets up early enough.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- President Roosevelt indicated today a veto message on the Patman Bonus Bill would be sent to Congress within a short title. At his regular press conference, while he declined formal comment on passage of the immediate cash payment measure, inasmuch as he had not received it from Congress, he observed that he might not take advantage of the ten days allowed by the Constitution for action on the bill.
HARRISBURG, May 8 (AP). -- Two Binghamton men were convicted today of two charges of kidnapping under the Federal "Lindbergh Law" and sentenced to serve twenty years each in prison.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- A movement to induce former President Hoover to renounce any Presidential ambitions and take the leadership in the reorganization of the Republican party has been started here by members of the Republican Campaign Committee of the House.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- The Eastman Kodak Company paid $90,903 in 1934 to its president, Frank W. Lovejoy; $61,230 to William G. Stuber, chairman, and $45,000 each to Thomas J. Hargrave and C.E. Kenneth Mees, vice presidents.

Tony Canzoneri and Lew Ambers concluded training yesterday for their fifteen-round lightweight championship bout tomorrow night in Madison Square Garden. A capacity crowd of 20,000 is expected to witness the contest.
The St. John's University baseball team trounced the Wagner College nine, 14 to 3, at Dexter Park yesterday.

IRVINGTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., May 8. -- Dr. Paul Kyle, friend of the late President Theodore Roosevelt and tutor for many years of the children of New York's wealthiest families, killed himself this morning on the lawn of the Kyle School for Boys, which he founded almost half a century ago.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- The principle that political parties could and should survive without the use of patronage was endorsed by Senators O'Mahoney, Democrat, and Vandenberg, Republican, in addresses tonight at a general council dinner of the League of Women Voters.

ALBANY, May 8. -- The Appellate Division, Third Department, today unanimously annulled the orders of the Public Service Commission in the rate case of the New York Edison Company and other public utility corporations and remitted the proceeding to the commission for a further hearing.

PARIS, May 8. -- On the eve of Foreign Minister Pierre Laval's visit to Warsaw and Moscow, official opinion in France is much perturbed by a growing belief that very soon the German Government will seek to complete the process of liberation from the restrictions of the Treaty of Versailles by demanding revision of the status of the demilitarized Rhineland zone.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- Definite word from the White House that the President would veto the Patman bonus bill and signs that the veto would be sustained in the Senate caused leaders of the veterans' organizations and their supporters today to bring massed pressure to bear on the White House and Congress to save the $2,000,000,000 cash payment measure from final defeat.

The body of United States Senator Bronson M. Cutting, who was killed Monday in the wreck of a Transcontinental plane in Missouri, was brought to New York last night and was taken to the home of his mother, Mrs. W. Bayard Cutting, at 24 East Seventy-second Street.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP). -- Far down the Potomac River Rear Admiral Richard Evelyn Byrd tonight held the two ships that bore his expedition to the Antarctic, endeavoring to time his arrival in the capital city to the day and hour set for an official reception.

GEORGE S. VAN SCHAICK had had little experience in the insurance field when he took office as State Superintendent of Insurance, by appointment of Governor ROOSEVELT, in 1931. He soon had plenty. To the pressing demands on his office resulting from the depression as it affected the great life and fire insurance companies were later added the troubles of the mortgage guarantee companies and their clients.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 8 (AP). -- After five days of idleness the Buffalo Bisons proved sprightly enough to halve a double-header with the league leading Newark Bears today, winning the opener, 6 to 2, and suffering a 3-to-0 setback in the second.

VALHALLA, N.Y., May 8. -- Threats of a school strike were made tonight by Mrs. Nathaniel Pousette-Dart in behalf of 300 parents whose demands for resignation of the local school board members were rebuffed at the annual meeting of the board here last night.

Edwin Markham, dean of American poets, who celebrated his eighty-third birthday last month, received an ovation from more than 1,500 persons yesterday at the 154th annual convention of the New York State Grand Lodge of Masons.

World "trouble spots," from the standpoint of remittances for merchandise shipped, were lised as Argentina, Brazil, Germany, Rumania, Italy, Costa Rica, Spain, Nicaragua and Uruguay, at the monthly round-table conference on credit and collection conditions abroad, sponsored at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday by the foreign credit interchange bureau of the National Association of Credit Men.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- The offer of the Consolidated Gas Company and its subsidiaries for a reduction ranging up to 35 per cent in municipal and Federal power rates in New York City was accepted today by the government and the city.

I was waiting for the elevator on the main floor of Rockefeller Center when my attention was attracted to a little group of people who were talking subduedly and rather excitedly. "Where shall we go to hear him best?" "It would be nice if we could find some quiet place, not too many people."
Eugene J. Shields, a former deputy fire marshal, was acquitted of a charge of arson, second degree, by a jury last night before County Judge John J. Fitzgerald in Brooklyn.

ST. LOUIS, May 8 (AP). -- Despite two home runs by Sammy West and a desperate ninth-inning rally, the Browns dropped their tenth consecutive game today, losing to the Senators, 10 to 9. Washington won the game in the fifth, scoring five runs on three walks, an error and a single.

CHICAGO, May 8. -- Hogs continued in good demand here today with prices about steady with the average on Tuesday. Little change was shown in fresh pork prices in the leading markets. A top price of $9.25 was paid for hogs, 5 cents a hundredweight under hte best figure of the previous day, while the day's average was unchanged at $9.10.
PHILADELPHIA, May 8. -- Miss Edith Quier of Reading and Huntingdon Valley won the Clarence H. Geist Cup by turning in a card of 82 to lead the field at the Overbrook Golf Club today.

Additional provision for the care of large numbers of patients suffering from chronic diseases was advocated yesterday by Dr. S.S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals, in an address at a luncheon of the Kiwanis Club at the Hotel McAlpin.

HUNTINGTON, Ind., May 8. -- Mayor Clare W.H. Bangs's battle with the Northern Indiana Power Company brought him a jail term today. Judge David Smith ordered the Mayor and five fellow citizens locked up until $2,100 is paid to the company for damages alleged to have been caused by the Mayor's attempt to extend the municipal electrical plant's lines to the utility company's patrons.

LONDON, May 8. -- Renewed operations of the unofficial tin pool today caused such an acute shortage of tin for immediate delivery that dealers on the Metal Exchange gave up trying to buy and walked off the floor in protest.

Miss Amelia Earhart, who in private life is Mrs. George Palmer Putnam, made good yesterday her statement after her successful solo flight across the Pacific from Honolulu to Oakland, Calif., in Jan- uary, that she would not abandon distance flying "while there's life in the old horse left."

" November," which in recent years was translated from the French and published in this country, does not transgress the State law against objectionable literature, Magistrate Jonah J. Goldstein ruled in the Tombs Court yesterday. His decision was handed down in the summons proceeding started by John S. Summer of the Society for the Prevention of Vice against Herman Miller of the Volume Guild, a book distributing concern.

HARRISBURG, Pa., May 8. -- The legislative battle over providing $60,000,000 in new taxes for one-year relief needs in Pennsylvania was settled tonight when Senate Republicans agreed with Governor Earle on a ten-point tax plan.

Awards totaling 223 sets of major letters, minor insignia and class numerals will be made today at City College's eighty-eighth charter day exercises at the Great Hall of the college, according to an announcement yesterday by Professor Walter Williamson, college manager of athletics.

The subcommittee on education of the Mayor's commission on conditions in Harlem at a hearing yesterday afternoon heard Miss Louise E. Tucker, principal of P.S. 90, the largest elementary school in Harlem, deny charges of maladministration and discrimination against Negroes in her school that had been made by witnesses at former hearings.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 8. -- Princeton's baseball team moved up in the Eastern Intercollegiate League race today as it took its second extra-inning battle of the year from Columbia by a count of 5 to 4.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 8. -- After meting out a five-day suspension to Don Meade, contract rider for Colonel E.R. Bradley, for rough tactics astride Glitter Glow, winner of the second race at Churchill Downs today, the stewards wired officials at the Pimlico track that they had no objections to Meade's riding Colonel Bradley's Boxthorn in the Preakness Saturday.
Doris Reed, a young Brooklyn soprano, is to make her debut tonight as Micaela in "Carmen" at the Hippodrome.

More than 1,000 savings bankers responsible for more than $10,000,000,000 in deposits gathered yesterday in annual conference at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria to discuss the security of the public utilities and the railroads in which they had placed the savings of 14,000,000 depositors throughout the country.

Earnings of the Crown Cork and Seal Company in the first quarter of this year were the largest in the, history of the organization, according to the report for this period issued yesterday. Net profit for the company and its domestic subsidiaries was $323,167 after depreciation, interest, Federal taxes and other charges.
