Resolutions in praise of Richard Whitney, who will retire on next Monday from the presidency of the New York Stock Exchange after five terms of office, were adopted yesterday by the board of governors of the Exchange at their final meeting before the annual election, also on Monday.

Back on the production schedule of the Theatre Guild is George O'Neil's 'Something to Live For,' which the guild first acquired in the Fall of, 1932 and later released. This time, since the three Summer months are not included in option agreements, the guild's control of the play will extend well into next season.

BERWYN, Pa., May 8. -- Charles C. Harrison 3d's Feu D' Esprit won the featured Devon Horse Show Plate Steeplechase at the Spring meet of the Radnor Hunt Club near here today. Six horses started the grueling journey over a three and a half mile hunting course at the Chesterbrook Farms and only three finished.
The strike or lockout of seven employes of The American Mercury was the subject of a hearing yesterday before the Regional Labor Board as the board sought an adjustment of the dispute.

TOLEDO, Ohio, May 8. -- By a vote of 1,251 to 605, employes of the Chevrolet Motor Company's Toledo plant today rejected the offer of a 5 per cent wage increase and other concessions, and decided to remain on strike for union recognition, a written agreement and more favorable terms.

LONDON, May 8. -- "Unless we rise above patriotism there will be no peace," Salvador de Madariaga, Spain's delegate to the League of Nations, told a distinguished audience at the Royal Society of Arts today, where he delivered the annual Richard Cobden Memorial Lecture.

HAVANA, May 8. -- Dr. Antonio Guiteras, who was Secretary of Interior, War and Navy during the Grau San Martin administration, was killed today in a fight between army and navy forces and a group of rebels headed by the former Cabinet member.

Sales of General Motors cars in April and also for the first four months of this year were the largest for these periods since 1929, it was announced yesterday. Sales to consumers in this country were 143,909 cars in April, against 106,349 in April, 1934.

The Hotel and Restaurant Wage Board named by Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews to recommend minimum wage schedules for women and minors in the industry was formally sworn in by the commissioner yesterday at his offices in the State Building, 80 Centre Street.

TOKYO, May 8. -- M.A. Pierce, former Police Commissioner of Los Angeles, has just been released by the police in Kobe after eleven days of detention on suspicion of espionage and the payment of a fine of thirty yen ($8.55).

Released at last from the enforced idleness that the recent bad weather visited upon them, the Giants stepped out into the sunshine that flooded the Polo Grounds yesterday, took both ends of a double-header from Charlie Grimm's Cubs, and sent the Chicagoans down to third place in the National League standing.
High points in the testimony yesterday of Park Commissioner Robert Moses before the Alderrnanic Committee Investigating Relief follow:

The colors of C.V. Whitney, which are becoming more prominent as the meeting progresses, were brought down in front again at Jamaica yesterday when his 3-year-old filly Song won the featured Dahlia Purse at six furlongs and paid 6 to 1.

DEARBORN, Mich., May 8. -- Creation of a coordinating forum for American agriculture, industry and science for the purpose of developing new industrial markets for farm products by the application of organic chemistry was decided upon today at the closing session of the joint convention of spokesmen for these major groupings in American life.

The management of the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation is giving careful consideration to what action should be taken because of its failure to earn interest charges on the debentures for more than four years, particularly with reference to the next interest payment, which is due on July 1, according to the annual report for 1934, made public yesterday.

Dean K. Worcester, assistant secretary of the New York Stock Exchange since 1929, will become its executive vice president if a constitutional amendment creating the new position is ratified, it was stated yesterday by Charles R. Gay, who .is to be the next president of the Exchange.
CLEVELAND, May 8 (AP). -- Monte Pearson pitched the Indians to a 2-to-0 victory over the Red Sox today. Pearson, a right-hander, allowed only four hits.

The old Williamsbridge Reservoir site in the Bronx is to be developed as one of the most unusual playground centres in the city, according to plans prepared by the Park Department. A feature of the project will be a wide promenade, laid out on the reservoir embankment, which will be comparable with the broad walks that many European cities have built along the tops of their abandoned fortifications.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 8. -- Offensively and defensively, Orlin Rogers, brilliant moundsman, was the star today as the University of Virginia nine won from Navy by 1 to 0.

Nathan L. Miller and Joseph M. Proskauer argued before General Sessions Judge Collins yesterday for the dismissal of indictments returned last November against six former officers of two title and mortgage companies in the general grand jury investigation of alleged irregularities.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- A. move to rush the administration's Utility Holding Company Bill to the Senate floor for a preferred position and early consideration was started by Democratic members of the Interstate Commerce Committee today, following defeat in committee of an attempt to delete the "death sentence" from the measure.

The Dictaphone Corporation's directors declared yesterday a dividend of 50 cents a share, payable on June 1 to holders of record of May 17. On March 1 a dividend of 25 cents a share was paid on the common stock. The regular quarterly dividend of $2 a share was declared on the preferred stock, likewise payable on June 1 to holders of record of May 17.

The North American Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on March 31 a consolidated net income of $11,056,325 after all deductions, equal after preferred dividend requirements to $1.07 a share on 8,602,991 common shares, comparing with $11,498,865, or $1.16 a share on 8,351,363 common shares, for the preceding year.

A letter from one of your readers regarding the Silver Jubilee service to be held at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine on May 12 prompts me to explain the arrangements for seating on that occasion.

BERLIN, May 8. -- The Boerse was quiet at the opening today, with signs of weakness, but the market showed some firmness at the close. Speculators have withdrawn and the investing public is waiting for further information on Dr. Schacht's projected export subsidy tax.
HARTFORD, Conn., May 8. -- The body of Mrs. Anne Booth Gordon, young Farmington matron who had been missing from her home since April 10, was found this afternoon in the Farmington River at Simsbury.
WORCESTER, Mass., May 8. -- The Holy Cross nine made it five straight victories today by defeating Yale, 11 to 1.

Young women headed by Miss Alicia Ludlow will act as ushers at the garden party and entertainment to be held this afternoon at the Wanamaker Motohome exhibition in the auditorium of Wanamaker's for the benefit of the Child Placing and Adoption Committee of the State Charities Aid Association.

Registering seventeen strike-outs, Marius Russo, Long Island University southpaw, subdued the Manhattan College nine, 4 -- 3, at Manhattan Beach yesterday. It was the second time this season Russo had set back Manhattan by a lone run, winning, 7 -- 6, previously.

Mrs. Josephine C. Herrick, mother of Walter R. Herrick, of Herrick Berg Co., 40 Wall Street, who died on May 2, left her estate, valued at $1,200,000, to her six children and a grandson, it was learned yesterday when her will was offered for probate in Surrogate's Court.
Money market remained dull, turnover being limited to replacements. No change in quotations was reported.
WARSAW, May 8. -- The Kaunas conference has been followed with more than usual interest here, as it is likely to show whose influence will prevail in the Baltic countries -- Poland's or Russia's.

LONDON, May 8. -- The text of King George's address today to members of the diplomatic corps, and representatives of the dominions who congratulated him at St. James's Palace on his silver jubilee follows:

BUENOS AIRES, May 8. -- Plans for a preliminary peace conference at Rio de Janeiro have been definitely dropped. Diplomatic representatives of the mediating republics will meet here tomorrow to arrange for the organization of a definite peace conference as proposed by the League of Nations.

Recapitalization of the Hahn Department Stores, Inc., moved nearer completion yesterday with the listing on the New York Stock Exchange of new securities of the Allied Stores Corporation which was organized to take over the assets of the Hahn chain.

A strong opening attack enabled Manual Training High School to defeat Columbia's freshman nine, 4 to 3, yesterday at Baker Field. One of the game's features was a triple by John Moller that scored two runs for the Lion cubs in the first frame.

Mrs. Emily Ringling, wife of John Ringling, circus man, was on the stand all day yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Peter Schmuck in the trial of her suit to collect $50,000 lent by her to Mr. Ringling four days before their marriage, and to set aside an agreement relinquishing her dower rights.

Felix M. Warburg has been elected a member of the board of the Metropolitan Opera Association, Inc., it was announced yesterday. The three other directors previously selected -- John Erskine, Ernest Hutcheson and John M. Perry -- who will represent the Juilliard Musical Foundation, with Mr. Warburg, were also officially named in accordance with the agreement made between the foundation and the association.

Audrey Wurdemann, who received the Pulitzer Prize in poetry on Monday night for her book, "Bright Ambush," is assembling and revising a second collection of her work for publication this Fall by John Day and Reynal Hitchcock.
Combining effective pitching with hard hitting, City College's varsity baseball team had little difficulty in defeating Upsala College of East Orange, N.J., 9 to 0, at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday.

BOSTON, May 8. -- A "clean-cut" alternative to the New Deal needs to be proclaimed by the Republican party, Ogden L. Mills, former Secretary of the Treasury, declared here tonight in an address before the Women's Republican Club of Massachusetts.

Much of the restraint under which the share market has been operating for some time was thrown off abruptly yesterday as industrial issues made their widest advance of the year, some eighty-five attaining new high levels. Final prices were at or near the day's best.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- Perhaps a stranger request was never made of a President by Congress than that contained in the House resolution asking for the transcript of Mr. Roosevelt's discussion at his press conference last Friday of the historic attitude of business toward reform legislation.

ROME, May 8. -- Several direct contacts between members of the Italian Government and statesmen of the countries most interested in the Central European situation are scheduled to take place in the next few weeks.

ALBANY, May 8. -- The New York and Richmond Gas Company offended the spirit and intent of the Public Service Commission Law in 1931 when it reclassified 150,000 shares of its stock without obtaining consent of the commission, the Appellate Division, Third Department, ruled today.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- A greater income from sales of principal products and governmental rental and benefit payments was received by farmers in thirty-two States in the first quarter of this year than for the same period in 1934, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics said in a survey today. The gain for all States combined was put at 12 per cent.

Interest in the New York Cotton Exchange was centred again yesterday in the possibilities of the producers' pool liberating spot cotton Reports from Washington that the manager of the pool had said that the AAA would release limited amounts of the staple, seemed to relieve tension regarding the old-crop months, whose premiums widened materially over the new crop.
The cotton control program of the New Deal was attacked and defended last night in a debate on "Our National Trade Policy" at the 113th dinner of the Economic Club of New York at the Hotel Astor.

FLOWER HILL, L.I., May 8. -- Gloria Vanderbilt, 11-year-old daughter of Mrs. Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt and the late Reginald Vanderbilt, received her first communion this morning at St. Francis Convent in this village. The child, over whose custody a legal contest has been waging for several months, arrived at the convent in a sedan, accompanied by her governess, Mrs. Mary Carney Hill.

President ROOSEVELT is certain to veto the Patman bill if it is laid before him for signature. He could do no other. Self-respect as well as official duty demands it. He cannot decline to meet this challenge to his authority -- the most direct that has yet been made.

Mayor La Guardia has asked Governor Lehman to veto a bill that would pave the way for granting civil service status and pension rights to the 25,000 employees of the Interborough and the B.M.T. if the rapid transit properties of those companies should be taken over by the city as part of a unification plan.

MEXICO, D.F., May 8. -- Amelia Earhart began here today another trail-blazing venture of the air -- the hitherto unflown non-stop trip from this capital to New York -- when she forced her heavily loaded plane into the air after a mile and half of take-off run at 6:10 A.M. (8:10 A.M. New York daylight tearing time).

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP). -- Backed by a Justice Department assertion of its constitutionality, Senate administration leaders pressed today for quick committee approval of President Roosevelt's social security program.

Mrs. Robert Ashton Macready gave a luncheon yesterday in the roof garden of the St. Regis. Her guests were Mrs. Edward C. Meats Kemp, Mrs. David C. Hanrahan, Mrs. William Woodward Phelps, Mrs. Thomas D. Webb, Mrs. Van Dyke Hill, Mrs. Henry A. Clinkunbroomer, Mrs. Edward Hart, Mrs. Francis Mason, Mrs. George Breed, Mrs. Elihu Washburn and the Misses M. Augusta Macready, Julia Beale and Lucy Howe.

Among the numerous apartment leases reported yesterday was a rental of the sixteenth floor, containing sixteen rooms and five baths, in 903 Park Avenue to Mrs. Paul D. Cravath. The house, at the northeast corner of Seventy-ninth Street, is owned by Vincent Astor.

Describing this country as a cultural extension of Europe, James Marshall, appointed recently by Mayor La Guardia to the Board of Education, denounced last night the attitude of prejudice against minority groups, which he said existed in some quarters among "the older Americans."

In the first trial ever held in this district under the so-called Lindbergh law, which carries a death penalty for offenders, three men and a woman, four of nine defendants accused of kidnapping, were convicted late yesterday.

License Commissioner Paul Moss has denied an application submitted to him for a license for a proposed motion-picture theatre to be built at the southeast corner of Seventy-ninth Street and Madison Avenue, it was announced yesterday.
DETROIT, May 8 (AP). -- Connie Mack's Athletics pounded two Tiger pitchers for sixteen hits and a 7-to-6 victory today.

Have New York legislative and law-enforcement agencies nothing better to do than to interfere with faddists' enthusiasms for airing, sunning and bathing their entire integuments in company with others like-minded? Is it all a hoax, the daily news of thefts, hold-ups, swindles, business and professional malpractice, corruption, and various crimes of violence?
The new film opening this morning at the Radio City Music Hall, "The Informer," adapted by RKO Radio from the novel by Liam O'Flaherty, features Victor McLaglen, Heather Angel and Preston Foster.

KAUNAS, Lithuania, May 8. -- The second Baltic conference with the Foreign Ministers of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia as participants closed today after three days of deliberations. Although no concrete decisions were taken, it was agreed that the Baltic States should continue close collaboration in a spirit of solidarity and mutually cooperate toward the realization of security in Eastern Europe.
HAMILTON, N.Y., May 8. -- Colgate turned back the St. Lawrence nine today, 4 to 3.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- Senator Austin, in attacking the TVA today as "one of the most dangerous ventures a government ever catered upon," said it had "exceeded its authority to such an extent it had to be enjoined" by the courts. He said the Norris bill undertook to "patch upon these defects, these violations of the law."

CLEVELAND, May 8. -- Speaking tonight before the largest crowd that ever assembled in the Public Auditorium, the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin of Detroit made a vigorous attack on President Roosevelt's bank bill, assailed Senator Bulkley of Ohio for his vote against the Patman Soldiers' Bonus Bill, and proclaimed his National Union for Social Justice as a great lobby of the middle class in Washington.

The shippers conference of Greater New York went on record opposed to the Copeland-Bland merchant marine bills, considered the most important maritime legislation before Congress, at its monthly meeting yesterday at the offices of the Merchants Association.

The program for the Parents' Day celebration to be held Sunday on the Mall in Central Park was made public yesterday by Uncle Robert, who insists that Mother's Day should be observed in honor of both parents.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- President Roosevelt declined today to send to the House a transcript of his interview Friday with newspaper men in which he assailed the attitude of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States. The refusal was on the ground that compliance would mean an end to "the free and informal fashion" in which he is accustomed to holding his press conferences.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 8. -- Rebirth of the days of '49, this time under a planned economy with thousands of unemployed men recruited from relief rolls to search for California's yet untapped billions in gold, is pictured in a bill now pending before the State Assembly.

Despite the inauspicious opening of consumer demand for Summer merchandise, retail executives here feel that there still remains sufficient opportunity for the sale of most apparel and accessory lines at regular prices. The active retail Summer season, it was pointed out yesterday, will continue through June.
Representative Wright Patman of Texas, author of the bonus bill that bears his name, refused to concede last night that a Presidential veto would kill the measure.

POINT BARROW, Alaska, May 8. -- The church in Point Barrow holds thirteen dead Eskimos, victims of the influenza epidemic that has been raging here for more than two weeks, and Eskimo boys are now digging graves for them in the near-by cemetery.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 8. -- Harvard conquered the Providence College nine, 6 to 2, in a twilight game today.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP). -- Veterans have already borrowed on a large part of the bonus for which the Patman bill would direct cash payment.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- A new test of the administration's gold clause abrogation, intended to compel Treasury acceptance at their old gold value of government securities offered in payment of taxes, was disclosed today to be in preparation here.
BOSTON, May 8 (AP). -- The Braves ended a batting slump with a mighty burst today as they whaled three Pittsburgh pitchers for a dozen hits and a 12 -- 3 victory.

Value of Dollar in Exchange. The value of the dollar on the local iorelgn exchange market, Based on quotations for the French frano on the days indicated, compares am follows (quotations are in cents):

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- The expressed willingness of Representative Fish of New York to run for the Presidency in 1936 on the Republican ticket was approved today by Speaker Byrns, a Democratic leader of the House, who seized, with apparent delight, an opportunity to say:

After two days of drooping prices, United States Government bonds rallied yesterday in fairly spirited trading. They gained 1-32 to 12-32 point on sales on the Stock Exchange of $5,698,000, against $4,267,300 on Tuesday, the turnover each day approximating one-third the total for the entire bond division on that market.

A patient-looking horse named Frank, who for years has clumped about the City Hall area hauling copies of The Sun to newsdealers, made a violent protest at noon yesterday against forty-four-page newspapers.

LONDON, May 8. -- Two notable additions to the ceremonies of Jubilee Week today provided the occasion for new demonstrations of loyalty to the British throne and of affection for its present occupants.

LONDON, May 8. -- The black republic of Liberia, with its yellow fever, its forced labor and its untapped forest resources, will be given to Germany as a mandate under the guardianship of the League of Nations if the leaders of the present government of the Union of South Africa can have their way.

The North German Lloyd liner Bremen will arrive today from Bremen and Channel ports. Among her passengers are Ambrose Clark, international sportsman, with Mrs. Clark; Joseph Larkin, vice president of the Chase National Bank, and Mrs. Larkin; Poultney Bigelow, author and traveler, and Princess Louise Mdivani of New York and Newport.

After a glimpse of "The Hook-Up," which was put on at .the Cort last evening, any one can see that the theatre and the radio have not buried the hatchet. Being both fantastic the two mediums do not get along. Jack Lait and Stephen Gross are the authors of this feat of horseplay that brings Ernest Truex back for a late Spring engagement.
The New Jersey Fish and Game Commission announces that it has forwarded to Federal authorities a recommendation for a continued open season on waterfowl this year.

MACON, Mo., May 8 (AP). -- Thorough investigation by the Department of Commerce of the TWA air liner disaster in which Senator Bronson Cutting and four others lost their lives was recommended tonight by a coroner's jury.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- The right of the Business Advisory and Planning Council to make public its own reports was established to- day during a conference between President Roosevelt and Harry Kendall, chairman of the council.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- With the aid of nearly all Republicans present, administration leaders in the House today obtained rejection of the Goldsborough "commodity dollar" amendment to the Omnibus Banking Bill.

LONDON, May 8. -- The Gaumont British Picture Corporation, Ltd., paid $5,000 today in settlement of an unusual libel action brought by Arthur Upham Pope, director of the American Institute of Persian Art and Archaeology.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses recommended that the city's entire work-relief program be financed with Federal funds and operated here by the State TERA when he testified yesterday before the Aldermanic Committee Investigating Relief at City Hall.
BOSTON, May 8. -- A flood of formal statements poured out of Braves Field today when Emil Fuchs, the club president, returned to his desk after a business trip.
Amelia Earhart added another mark to her list of air records yesterday when she flew non-stop from Mexico, D.F., to Newark Metropolitan Airport.
SPRINGFIELD, Mo., May 8. -- Chain - letter "factories," with $18,000 changing hands at three of them within five hours, turned this Southwestern Missouri city into a money-mad maelstrom today.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 8. -- A medal presented annually by the American Association of Physicians to a physician for "outstanding achievement" in medical science was awarded today to Dr. Frank Burr Mallory of Brookline, Mass.

BALTIMORE, May 8. -- stern Preakness battle, despite the heavy backing for Omaha, was heralded today as candidates for Saturday's classic began pounding Pimlico's turf in workouts for the mile-and-three-sixteenths test of $25,000 added value.

NEWARK, N.J., May 8. -- Eleven men and one woman received prison terms ranging from ten days to three months from Common Pleas Judge Daniel J. Brennan today on charge of obtaining relief by making false statements of their financial conditions.
Leases to manufacturers and retailers in large number were reported by brokers yesterday.

Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey assailed the New Deal administration as a trend toward collectivism and denounced the NRA as a debt-building, industry-destroying machine in a speech before the New York Board of Trade yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- A "diving ball," the commercial counterpart of the Barton Bathysphere used by Dr. William Beebe in his undersea explorations off Bermuda, will be demonstrated in Washington next month, according to Science Service.

Seriously hit by a decline in sales and profits and mounting costs, members of the American Spice Trade Association, at the closing session of their twenty-ninth annual convention in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday, decided to formulate plans for a nation-wide campaign designed to increase the consumption of all forms of spices.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- President Roosevelt again expressed determination to veto the Soldier's Bonus Bill, he affirmed the right of the Business Advisory and Planning Council to make public its own reports, and refused the House's request for a transcript of his remarks about the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, made at a press conference last Friday.

CLEVELAND, May 8. -- In this age of severe technological unemployment, when millions of sturdy young men are denied the opportunity to work, while old men and children are required to waste their lives in socially unnecessary endeavor, the overwhelming majority of the American people has arrived at the conviction that old-age pensions are absolutely indispensable to the social welfare.
HONOLULU, May 8. -- Forty-eight flying boats in Pearl Harbor tuned up today for a take-off, probably tomorrow, for Midway Island, with possible stops at Pearl Hermes and other isles.

Mike DeVito, New York University righthander, pitched the Violets to a 12-0 victory over Stevens Tech yesterday at Castle Point Field, Hoboken. He gave only two hits and struck out thirteen batters. He also showed remarkable control in not issuing a base on balls. So effective was he that Ray Moser and Ed Verdee, who found his offerings for a triple and single, respectively, were the only Stevens men getting on the bags.

Never before have there been so many Federal jobs for deserving Democrats; and a little thing like civil service reform hasn't been allowed to interfere with the proper distribution of rewards in the new world of offices created. Yet multitudes of the faithful are still unprovided for.

ST. ALBANS, L.I., May 8. -Solving golf problems that had no particular political aspect, fiftyfour members of the National Democratic Club of New York launched their opening tourney of the season at the St. Albans Golf Club today.

Net income of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company and subsidiaries amounted to $2,350,721 after interest, depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges, according to the preliminary report for the quarter ended on March 31. This is equivalent to 27 cents a share on 8,674,342 shares of $50 par capital stock.

A good demand for apartments in houses on the East Side was indicated in brokers' reports yesterday. Several leases of suites in buildings on Park Avenue were announced. Brokers also reported rentals of apartments on the West Side.

The doors of the Paramount will swing open at 9:30 o'clock this morning to usher in the new Mae West picture "Goin' to Town." Appearing with Miss West are Paul Cavanagh, Ivan Lebedeff and Marjorie Gateson.
Certain regulations governing the entry of foreign vintages into this country need to be clarified, according to Major H.R. Rudd, an authority on wines and spirits.

DETROIT, Mich., May 9. -- On the heels of the Chevrolet automobile workers' union victory in the poll last night, the General Motors Corporation today agreed to a collective bargaining conference with American Federation of Labor representatives, meeting at Toledo on Saturday.

BERLIN, May 9. -- The Boerse was firmer today, authough with a few exceptions it remained virtually stagnant. Heavy industrials were quiet and slightly firmer. Chemicals were slightly stronger. Machines were firm, Orenstein Koppel gaining 1/2 point and Schubert Salzer 1.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):
WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Among reports on salaries to the Securities and Exchange Commission today were the following:

ALBANY, May 9. -- The number of persons employed in New York State factories increased 0.6 per cent and payrolls increased 0.3 per cent between the middle of March and the middle of April, Industrial Commissioner Andrews reported today.

The American Jewish Olympic team and an Italian amateur boxing squad arrived yesterday on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia. The United States athletes returned from the second World Maccabiah staged at Tel-Aviv, Palestine, while the Italians are headed for Chicago, where they will meet that city's Golden Gloves team of amateur boxers.

Mr. ROOSEVELT has decided not to issue a Mother's Day proclamation. He thinks such a formal reminder no longer necessary. The first Mother's Day was proclaimed in May, 1914, by WOOROW WILSON in response to a joint resolution of Congress.

Max Krauss, president of the Morro Castle Safety at Sea Association asked Attorney General Cummings yesterday to designate one of his aides or appoint a special assistant to replace United states Attorney Martin Conboy in the investigation of the sinking of the Ward liner Mohawk.

Richard Gimbel, vice president in charge of Gimbel Brothers, Philadelphia, and secretary of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., has been suspended as an officer and employe of the corporation by Bernard Gimbel, president of the company. The suspension was ordered in a telegram sent to Mr. Gimbel, after he had discharged Arthur C. Kaufmann as merchandise manager of the store.
With a fate-defying designation and a rather alluring company of singers and dancers, the Permanent Italian Theatre gave its initial production last evening at the Majestic Theatre.

Robert F. Hunter, 52 years old, of 33 Third Avenue, Brooklyn, who used unemployed girls as unwitting dupes in a check swindle, according to the police, was arrested in a midtown hotel yesterday on a charge of grand larceny.

Politics vied powerfully with business yesterday for the attention of floor members of the New York Stock Exchange as the contest over the Exchange's annual election on Monday entered the final stage. Four developments marked the race that is being made by ten regular and four independent nominees for places on the Exchange's governing committee.
BOSTON, May 9 (AP). -- Tex Carleton, six-foot right-hander, who turned back the Braves six times last season, held them to five hits today to pitch the Cubs to a 5-1 victory in the series opener

Mrs. Bartow S. Weeks gave a dinner followed by bridge last night at the Park Lane to celebrate the birthday of Mrs. John Charles Turner. Other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Leonard L. Hill, Mr. and Mrs. Henry McSweeney, Mr. and Mrs. Raymond D. Hackett, Mr. and Mrs. Z.A. Cushman, Mr. and Mrs. Ary Lamme, Mr. and Mrs. Irving Schmelzel, and John J. Murphy.

Current assets of the General Motors Corporation on March 31 last were $398,409,978, against $865,844,370 at the end of 1934, according to the pamphlet report issued yesterday. Current liabilities on March 31 were $101,256,535, against $90,198,504 on Dec. 31.

MONTREAL, May 9 (AP). -- Pete Appleton pitched a smart seven-hit game, allowing only one extra base blow and fanning six, as the Royals snapped a three-game losing streak by defeating the Albany Senators, 9 to 2, today. It was Appleton's third straight triumph.

PARIS, May 9. -- Pierre Laval, French Foreign Minister and diplomatic traveler, left Paris tonight on the North express to pass through Berlin en route to Warsaw and Moscow. The purpose of this trip is to attempt to clarify the relations of Poland, France, Germany and Russia, in view of the newly concluded Franco-Russian treaty and the older Polish-German agreement.

The weights for the Toboggan Handicap, with $3,000 added, at six furlongs for 3-year-olds and upward, which will be run as the feature for the opening of the Belmont Park meeting next Wednesday, were announced yesterday by John B. Campbell, handicapper.

An ebony motif prevailed at a large dinner, dance and entertainment -- designated as the Black Ball -- given by the Society of Stoopnocracy last night in the Lorenzo ballroom of the Delmonico. Several hundred members of the society, or "Stoopnocrats," attended the party which was one of several given each year to further the philanthropic work of the organization among the destitute and unemployed.

CHICAGO, May 9 (AP). -- The White Sox fell from first place today as Wes Ferrell shut them out until the ninth inning and his Boston mates battered two of their younger pitchers, Les Tietje and Vernon Kennedy, for fifteen hits and a 10-to-1 triumph.

Apparently the Giants don't read the newspapers. They showed scant respect yesterday for the awesome reputation that Cy Blanton brought to the Polo Grounds and handed the most sensational young pitcher to come up in the National League this year an unceremonious welcome.

HANOVER, N.H., May 9. -- Dartmouth overcame a four-run lead piled up by Pennsylvania in the first inning today to weather the storm and beat the Philadelphians, 6 -- 5. Ted Olson went all the way for the Green to annex his fourth Eastern Intercollegiate League victory.
HAVANA, May 9. -- Police late this afternoon raided the Honduran Consulate here and searched it thoroughly, but they reported finding no compromising documents or arms.
With a Bach-Handel program, the eleventh Westchester festival will open tonight at the County Centre in White Plains. A star at the second concert tomorrow evening will be Giovanni Martinelli.

CHICAGO, May 9. -- The market for hogs made a strong start and a weak finish today. Early sales were steady to as much as 10 cents a hundredweight higher with underweights showing the most strength, but butcher hogs, weighing 250 to 300 pounds, weakened as much as 10 to 15 cents and closed at the bottom.

The motion picture industry will show the first of a series of films on character training to Manhattan and Bronx pupils today, as a visual instruction project. The program was arranged through the cooperation of Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, and Will H. Hays, president of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributers of America, Mr. Hays's office announced yesterday.

Mrs. Payne Whitney's Cheshire, which appears to have reached his top form, proved his right to be classed among the top flight 3-year-olds when he scored an easy victory in the Moriches Purse, feature of the racing at Jamaica yesterday.
The night superintendent of the Central Park Zoo -- one Alfred E. Smith -- received a new job yesterday from Park Commissioner Robert Moses -- that of renting agent for the Prospect Park Zoo.

PHILADELPHIA, May 9 (AP). -Bucky Walters, whom Jimmy Wilson imported from third base to do mound duty, turned in a fine job of stopping the champion Cardinals today and behind his four-hit pitching the Phillies won the series opener, 2 to 1.

OTTAWA, May 9. -- A cabled intimation that Prime Minister Bennett will, sail for Canada tomorrow to disclose the facts about his physical condition to his supporters and discuss with them a possible successor to the leadership, caused a stir in Canadian political circles today.
ALBANY, N.Y., May 9. -- Governor Lehman disapproved today the Feld-Devany bill which would have put hairdressers and cosmetologists under State license.

The insured mortgage program set up by the National Housing Act was criticized as impractical last night by Louis H. Pink, who is to be sworn in at Albany today as Superintendent of Insurance, succeeding George S. Van Schaick. Mr. Pink's first public address since he was named by Governor Lehman on Monday was broadcast by WNYC.

ALBANY, May 9. -- Governor Lehman listened for nearly three hours this evening to arguments for and against the bill dividing the Eighth Judicial District in Western New York and creating a new Tenth district, but gave no indication of what action he will take.

The establishment of a municipal airport and the rehabilitation of shipping facilities in the harbor were urged yesterday afternoon by Mayor La Guardia as the two essential factors in restoring business prosperity to New York City.

PARIS, May 9. -- With the fiscal situation fast approaching a crisis and the franc's future becoming more and more debatable, Paris today was alive with all sorts of sensational rumors, which created a feeling of great nervousness on the Bourse and in financial and banking circles.
LONDON, May 9 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

Although trading in United States Government obligations diminished yesterday to the smallest volume for any day this week, business in the bond market on the Stock Exchange continued fairly active with comparatively little price change in the main body of corporate issues.

I read with much regret that James W. Blake is ill, but THE TIMES article reads that Mr. Blake is the author of the song "The Sidewalks of New York" and makes no mention of my father, Charles B. Lawlor, who went to Mr. Blake with the title "Sidewalks of New York" and the idea of the song.

Federal expenditures for the current fiscal year have passed the six billion dollar mark and set a new high record for a peacetime year. This will not faze those members of Congress who would willingly add another two billion to pay the soldiers' bonus. Many of them belong to the school which believes that the more rapidly the Government spends money the more certain is business to recover.

The attack on the New Deal by business leaders at the annual session of the United States Chamber of Commerce in Washington last week was explained here last night by Henry I. Harriman, who presided at the sessions of the chamber as its outgoing president.

The French liner Paris, which has been displaced in the transatlantic service by the new express liner Normandie, arrived here yesterday from Havre on her last regular trip in the service. She was in command of Captain Luc de Malglaive and carried 204 passengers.

The share market absorbed without much difficulty the profit-taking at the outset yesterday that had been induced by the disappointment over the lack of progress in settling labor difficulties in the automotive industry and the confusion resulting from the jockeying over the bonus legislation, and moved forward to new high ground.
An error helped the Seward Park High baseball team to defeat Curtis, 5 to 4, yesterday in the Lower Manhattan-Richmond P.S.A.L. tournament. The game went eight innings.

The Board of Estimate will have before it today an amended engineers' plan doing away with the "aprons" in front of the new Hudson River piers which were to connect their second stories with the West Side elevated express highway. The steamship companies favored these links as an aid to the embarkation and debarkation of passengers.

Mayor La Guardia and Police Commissioner Valentine were surprise witnesses yesterday before the holdover March grand jury in its investigation of the policy racket in New York County. In calling the two officials, the grand jury apparently acted over the head of District Attorney Dodge.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 9. -- In an address before several hundred Harvard students and faculty members today Lewis W. Douglas, former Director of the Budget, strongly criticized President Roosevelt's New Deal, declaring that its only "effect will be to delay the day of reckoning."
ATLANTIC CITY, May 9. -- The New Jersey Federation of Women's Clubs in convention in Chalfonte-Haddon Hall joined the fingerprinting movement this afternoon.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 9. -- Tap day exercises at Yale took place at 5 o'clock this afternoon in the court of Branford College when ninety members of the junior class were pledged to membership in the senior societies.
ROME, May 9. -- Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg of Austria arrived in Florence this afternoon and was received with a complete lack of cere

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Fear that American abandonment of the Philippine Islands might "bring Britain and Japan face to face" there and disturb the whole Far Eastern situation was expressed today by Senator Gibson, Vermont Republican, in recommending that Filipinos ask Congress to withdraw its grant of sovereignty to them.

CHICAGO, May 9. -- Congestion in the May deliveries of wheat and corn is becoming more apparent, and while the markets on the Board of Trade here were little affected today, the nearby delivery of wheat in Kansas City and Minneapolis ran up sharply again.

LONDON, May 9. -- Although its team for the most part is an unknown quantity -- except, of course, Lawson Little, holder of the title -- the United States challenge in the British amateur golf championship again is regarded as a strong one. In the draw issued today are eleven from the United States and a team sent on tour by the Canadian G.A.

Three coups, the first emanating from information from the police of Hoboken, N.J., ended yesterday in the arrest of six persons said by the New York police to be connected with the printing and marketing of bogus sweepstake and lottery tickets in this city.

Doubleday, Doran have contracted with Grant Wood, the Iowa painter, for a book on modern American art to be published next Autumn. It will be an informal account of contemporary painters who are "expressing America."

Count Court Haugwitz Reventlow of Denmark, whose visit to the United States has been connected with rumors that he is to wed the Princess Barbara Hutton Mdivani, arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen considerably upset by it all.

HUNTINGTON, Ind., May 9. -With feeling running high, authorities took precautions tonight to prevent a second attempt to deliver Mayor C.W.H. Bangs from the county jail, where he is held on a contempt of court citation.

Bank clearings established a new peak for the year in the week ended on Wednesday. They were also the largest for any week since the first one in January, 1932. The total for twenty-two leading cities in the country in the last week, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., was $6,242,917,000, compared with $5,157,101,000 in the corresponding week last year.

The report of the Buffalo, Niagara and Eastern Power Corporation and subsidiaries for 1934, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $7,243,553 after all deductions, equal to $20.69 a share earned on 350,000 shares of $5 cumulative first preferred stock.

Deliveries made for 260 stores in the metropolitan area by the United Parcel Service during the week ended May 4 showed an increase of 2 per cent over a year ago, the comparison being with identical units. The gain compares with a decrease of 11 per cent in the preceding week, which was the week immediately after Easter.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 9. -- E.D. Shaffer's St. Bernard, which disappointed in the Kentucky Derby after showing early speed, returned to his true form to account for the Perryville Purse, chief attraction on today's card at Churchill Downs.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., May 9. -- The golfing members of the New York Athletic Club, some 152 strong, opened their season at the Winged Foot Golf Club today and then held a special dinner at the clubhouse later.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- The Utilities Control Bill was hastened to completion today by the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee after further modifications, calculated to make the measure somewhat less objectionable to State regulatory bodies and operating companies.

Behind the sterling relief pitching of Ray Benge after they had scored all their runs in the third inning, the Dodgers downed the Cincinnati Reds, 5 to 4, at Ebbets Field yesterday in the Opener of a four-game series.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 9. -- The Manufacturers Association of New Jersey at its twentieth annual convention here today condemned all phases of governmental activity in industry in a resolution marked by the bluntness of its phraseology.

HONOLULU, May 9. -- The American Navy's secret move across a trackless stretch of the mid-Pacific with an unprecedented forty-six-plane flight from Honolulu to Midway Island got under way here today and almost immediately faced the prospect of battling storm conditions at sea.
Yesterday's statement for the twelve reserve banks showed total holdings to be at the highest point of the year to date.

BALTIMORE, May 9. -- Apparently not satisfied that Omaha is the better horse following his decisive victory in the Kentucky Derby, five 3-year-olds, each of which finished far back of William Woodward's chestnut flash at Churchill Downs, will be given another chance Saturday when they face the son of Gallant Fox in the $25,000 added Preakness at Pimlico.
PARIS, May 9 (AP). -- France brought private air organizations and reserve units into its national defense plan against German rearmament today and moved for closer ties with Italy and Russia.

Fifteen members of the Cincinnati baseball team, led by their manager, Charles Dressen, visited the police line-up at headquarters yesterday morning and witnessed an exhibition of shoplifting technique.

Some months ago in an editorial, "No Hat Upon His Read," you quoted from The Times of London a letter recounting a story about a Mr. Damer, who later became the Earl of Dorchester. Mr. Damer was talking with a friend on the street corner one very cold day when Lady Melbourne passed in her carriage.

ST. LOUIS, May 9. -- A bronze tablet was dedicated this afternoon to mark the place where the American Legion was born in St. Louis at the first caucus in May, 1919. President Roosevelt sent a greeting to Jules R. Field, executive secretary of the 1935 American Legion convention.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Disbursements by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation since its establishment on Feb. 2, 1932, to April 30, 1935, totaled $7,146,163,946.81, and repayments over that period on loans and other advances were $2,751,749,019.78, the corporation reported today.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Rear Admiral Richard Evelyn Byrd will end his long voyage from the Antarctic here tomorrow, to be honored by President Roosevelt as the third successive incumbent of the White House to greet him on the completion of a hazardous exploration.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Worried by a two-day filibuster, Democratic Senate leaders were apparently laying plans tonight to put aside the contested Tennessee Valley Authority legislation and proceed with the bill to prolong the life of the National Industrial Recovery Act.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- President Roosevelt in a message to the American Bar Association urged revision of the criminal code. He conferred with advisers on his bonus veto message, and received George Foster Peabody to talk about charity matters.

Edwin S. Friendly, business manager of The Sun, has been re-elected chairman of the committee in charge of the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, it was announced yesterday.

" Seven Keys to Baldpate," the Players' revival which is due to brighten the last week of this month, will find the president of that distinguished club participating in the show. Mr. Bentley, the owner of Baldpate Inn, is the role that Walter Hampden will play, and a small part it is, too -- only a few lines in the last act.

Yesterday was the first anniversary of the signing of the Jones-Costigan Act, which made sugar cane and sugar beets "basic commodities" and provided for quotas not only for domestic crops but also for shipments from Cuba, Puerto Rico, Hawaii, the Philippines and other sources.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Walter P. Chrysler's stock interest in the Chrysler Corporation, of which he is president, was placed at 149,972 shares in a registration statement filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company stated that it would disclose salaries before June 30.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP). -- Postal inspectors are being concentrated in cities where the chain-letter craze is at its height in search of evidence on which to arrest those who are writing letters so that "the chain will not be broken."

Faced with conditions that are considered worse than those that preceded the ambulance-chasing investigation of 1929, the casualty and liability insurance companies of New York have undertaken private investigations of accident claimants and attorneys suspected of fraud, it was revealed yesterday.
Several flats were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

Medals to 1,288 child artist winners in the twenty-third annual Wanamaker Drawing Competition for Children of Greater New York for 1935 will be awarded tomorrow morning at 11 o'clock in the Washington Irving High School Auditorium, Irving Place and Sixteenth Street.

At a hearing before Judge Mortimer W. Byers in the United States District Court in Brooklyn yesterday, Herman F. Forman, an attorney for a stockholders' committee of the Lehrenkraus Corporation, presented a plan of reorganization embracing the following points:...

Showing no effects from the strain of her 2,100-mile flight from Mexico, D.F., to Newark on Wednesday, Amelia Earhart "rested" only theoretically yesterday at her rooms in the Hotel Seymour. Telegrams, telephone calls and letters of congratulation poured in upon her.

Mr. H.G. WELLS begins in Collier's today publication of his studies of the American scene. In his hands observation is always an "extensive view." In his first article he starts out, as usual, with conclusions to be drawn from the history of mankind for "the past thirty centuries."

WOODBRIDGE, N.J., May 9. -- Miss Dorothy Petite, 24 years old, of 1,342 Corlies Avenue, Neptune, N.J., a waitress, was shot dead tonight in a saloon at Fords near here. Edgar H. Crockett, 45, a salesman, who had been with Miss Petite at the table, was arrested charged with murder.
I cannot permit to go unchallenged certain statements regarding the work of the late Carl Akeley made by Russell Owen in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine article, "Africa Recreated in New York."

Now that the Municipal Art Commission has unexpectedly turned down the designs for the proposed Rikers Island penitentiary murals that had been prepared by Ben Shahn and Lou Bloch, it may be of interest to discuss the work as projected and the designs as carried almost to a point of completion.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 9. -- The Czechoslovak Minister to Germany, Vojtech Mastny, was instructed today by the Foreign Office to present a protest to Wilhelmstrasse against the recent Nazi kidnapping on the Czech frontier of a German citizen named Joseph Lampersberger.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended May 8, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,471,000,000 an increase of $3,000,000 compared with the preceding week and a decrease of $13,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1934.

Poultney Bigelow, veteran traveler and writer, returned on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen yesterday en route to his home, which he calls his "cowyard up the Hudson," after a visit with his old friend, the former Kaiser, at Doorn.
Cotton sold within 2 points of the 12-cent mark yesterday on the Cotton Exchange, when the July was quoted at 11.98 cents a pound. The March sold up to 11.94.

A claim that city taxes were paid with $34,794 that should have gone to bondholders was presented yesterday in a bankruptcy hearing before Harry A. Gordon, sitting as referee in the affairs of S.W. Straus Co. at 9 East Forty-sixth Street. After hearing attorneys for the bondholders and the receiver, the referee ordered both sides to present briefs.

R. Elliott Owens of Cortland, N.Y., was re-elected Grand Master of the Grand Lodge of Free and Accepted Masons of the State of New York at the closing sessions yesterday the 154th annual convention at the Masonic Temple, Twenty-third Street and Sixth Avenue.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., May 9. -- Although opened to the general golfing public late in April, the new "blue" course, first of the three new units in Bethpage State Park, had its baptism of fire today when it was under the surveillance of experts.

Appointment of Francis Boardman to succeed Colonel William J. Wilgus as director of the works division of the Emergency Relief Bureau was announced last night by Oswald W. Knauth, chairman and executive director of the bureau.

PHILADELPHIA, May 9. -- Supervision of all important agencies of transportation by a single Federal body, "fair and impartial," was declared today by Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Transportation, to be the solution for present problems.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., May 9. -- An exhibit of bird portraiture in natural colors, executed by Rex Brasher, was opened today in the old White Art Galleries at the Greenbrier. The paintings shown are part of a collection of 900 studies, recently completed by the artist, after forty-four years of labor.

Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens charged yesterday before the Aldermanic Committee Investigating Relief that relief materials had been stolen and sold by employes of the Works Division in Queens.

The eighty-eighth anniversary of the founding of City College was marked yesterday by tributes to Alexander Stewart Webb, Civil War hero and second president of the college, at ceremonies in the Great Hall of the institution.
CLEVELAND, May 9. -- Events continued to break very badly for the Yankees today. So badly, in fact, that the very heavens wept.

When the president of a college in the Middle West conferred upon FRIDTJOF NANSEN, after his return from what was then farthest north, the honorary degree represented by the letters LL.D., some editor in the East facetiously asked whether they stood for "Doctor of Latitude and Longitude."

I have read Dr. Lauchlin Currie's letter in THE TIMES of May 7 protesting against the editorial appearing on April 29 which commented on his book "The Supply and Control of Money in the United States." Dr. Currie characterized a speech in which Dr. Anderson, economist of the Chase National Bank, subjected the work to a critical analysis as abounding "in misquotations and distortions of its contents."

LONDON, May 9. -- Aroused by the speed of Germany's rearmament in the air, the British Government let it be known today that it had taken two important steps to prepare the country against air attack.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 9. -- The major social event of the Spring at Princeton University will take place this week-end as 627 feminine guests arrive for the annual Spring house parties of the eighteen upper-class eating clubs.

New York City no longer can finance the purchase of supplies and materials for relief projects and wait for reimbursement from the State and Federal Governments, Controller Frank J. Taylor informed Mayor La Guardia yesterday.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, May 9. -Vladimir Matchek's Opposition bloc is accumulating evidence showing that government terrorization of electors on Sunday, especially in the Lika district, was worse than that previously revealed.
WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Alston, a hardy hunter, occupied the spotlight as the National Capital horse show opened at the Bradley Farms today.
BERLIN, May 9 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of May 7 shows the following changes in reichsmark:

NEWBURGH, N.Y., May 9 (AP). -- Five "polite bandits" who held up fifteen persons and robbed a branch bank of $15,000 today, had vanished tonight, in spite of a heavy concentration of police on all Southern New York roads.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 9. -- Miss Anna Schmid, 32 years old, servant in the house of Max Kade at 2 Edge-cliff Road here, was stabbed fatally by an unidentified assailant while she was walking home alone at 11 o'clock last night.

BERLIN, May 9. -- Reichs Bishop Ludwig Mueller, who has refused to join the confessional Protestant leaders in attacking the new pagan movement as a threat to Christianity, has issued a statement calling on all Protestants to adopt toward the Nordic religious movement a "worthy attitude expressing the particular character of the Evangelical church."

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Government officials insisted today that, contrary to assertions of Robert Moses, New York Park Commissioner, it would be possible to put a substantial number of persons on jobs quickly under procedure planned for the $4,000,000,000 work relief program.

BALTIMORE, May 9. -- Mrs. T.H. Somerville, Virginia sportswoman, furnished the winner of the Billy Barton Steeplechase, a testing gallop of three miles over nineteen fences, which served as the principal event today at the Pimlico course.

The plan for reorganizing Fox Metropolitan Playhouses, Inc., containing several last-moment amendments submitted by Milton C. Weisman, receiver in equity for the Fox Theatres Corporation, was approved yesterday by Federal Judge Julian W. Mack at a hearing in the County Lawyers Association Building, 14 Vesey Street.

After a prolonged questioning as to whether he would be loyal to the official boards and agencies of the Presbyterian Church, the Rev. John H. McComb, a Fundamentalist, was received into the membership of the Presbytery of New York at a special meeting of that body yesterday afternoon.

TOKYO, May 9. -- An interesting political experiment was launched today when Premier Keisuke Okada invited a number of prominent persons to join the National Policy Council, which has been formed under imperial ordinance.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., May 9. -- Max Baer, in training here for the defense of his world's heavyweight championship against James J. Braddock, received a painful powder burn today while rehearsing a radio skit in the Berkeley Carteret Hotel.

Chanting anti-Nazi slogans and bearing banners and signs against war, Hitler and the decline of culture in the Reich, more than 500 persons marched through the German quarter in Yorkville last night in a torchlight procession staged by the American League Against War and Fascism.

MADRID, May 9. -- A comprehensive legislative program for his new government has been announced by Premier Alejandro Lerroux, to whose Cabinet the Cortes yesterday gave a confidence vote of 181 to 22. The problems scheduled to receive first attention are unemployment, national defense, agricultural reform and press and municipal electoral laws.

Continued cooperation between government and privately operated institutions is essential to any progressive plan of hospitalization, Dr. Haven Emerson, public health authority, declared yesterday in discussing the current survey of hospital facilities in the metropolitan area, to be conducted under the auspices of the United Hospital Fund.

BERLIN, May 9. -- The outlines of a new German penal code, now being completed by a special commission as the National Socialist substitute for the Roman Law still in force, have just been placed before the German public by Dr. Fran Guertner, Reich Minister of Justice, and other authorized spokesmen.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 9. -- Breaking a long losing streak, Lehigh's baseball team defeated Muhlenberg at Taylor Stadium today, 12 to 9.
PARIS, May 9 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 9. -- Taking sixteen fences without a fault, the towering chestnut gelding Will Gallop, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Carver of Westport, Conn., won the open jumping class at the first evening session of the eleventh annual New Haven horse show, which opened today in the Arena.

Strange-looking contraptions will roll along auto roads from many directions today, all converging on Albany for Sunday's classic of the motor-boat racing world -- the annual Hudson marathon. Some few of the frail, shallow, shiny outboards will be lashed to sedan tops, but the orthodox method used by most of the skippers will be to attach a trailer to carry the boats.
MOSCOW, May 9. -- A new stage in the Soviet production of iron and steel will be formally ushered in at a conference of the heads of the Commissariat for Heavy Industry starting here tomorrow.

ST. LOUIS, May 9 (AP). -- Aided by errors and the tight pitching of Dick Coffman, the Browns finally ended the season's most persistent losing streak by registering a 4-to-2 victory over the Athletics today.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- The thirteen-point program laid down by Ogden L. Mills in Boston as the course which the party might properly take in the campaign next year was generally approved here today by Republicans. He called for a return to a gold standard, abolition of the NRA, a balanced budget and an international conference to stabilize currencies.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Backers of the Patman inflationary bonus bill rejected today all attempts at compromise, and staked their hopes of passing the measure at this session on the chances of the Senate overriding a certain Presidential veto.
SPRINGFIELD, Mo., May 9. -- Sad-faced men and women walked around in a daze tonight, seeking vainly for some one to buy their chain letters.
CAMDEN, N.J., May 9. -- A strike call was issued today to all employes of the New York Shipbuilding Company, effective at midnight Saturday. About 3,000 men will be affected.

PHILADELPHIA, May 9. -- The fourth annual Wissahickon Junior Horse Show, which will be held at Wissahickon Farms on Saturday, has attracted an impressive entry list. Those who have reserved parking space include:

HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 9. -- Two vessels laden with fresh vegetables for the relief of suffering inhabitants of Turks Island, British West Indies, sailed from here this week. One finished the 700-mile voyage today, according to a message received here.

I have selected a pilot, H. Hollick-Kenyon of Winnipeg, for the Ellsworth Transantarctic Flight Expedition's third attempt to solve two major geographical puzzles of the relatively unknown continent at the end of the world, a continent as large as Europe and Australia combined.

Miguel A. Garcia Mencez, Speaker of the Puerto Rican House of Representatives, and Bolivar Pagan, Vice President of the Puerto Rican Senate, in a joint statement issued from Washington, characterize the relief administration in the island as "an affront to our people" and charge that, because of the way relief is being administered there, the people of Puerto Rico are "on the verge of popular revolt."

HELSINGFORS, May 9. -- Reports were widely welcomed here that leading American sports authorities, including Daniel J. Ferris, secretary-treasurer of the Amateur Athletic Union, had expressed genuine satisfaction at the Finnish Athletic Congress's decision to lift the boycott on Sweden.

OTTAWA, Ont., May 9 (Canadian Press). -- A substantial increase in Dominion Government deposits was shown in the weekly statement of the Bank of Canada issued today. Deposits from the chartered banks declined, while notes in circulation remained virtually the same as last week.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Preparation of a complete code of criminal law, including the administration of criminal justice, "more nearly suited to modern social and economic conditions," will be undertaken by the American Law Institute.

MARGARET MEAD, author of "Coming of Age in Samoa," has in "Sex and Temperament" (Morrow, $3) written the book to end all books that dogmatize about men, women and the human nature in which they both allegedly participate. But before summarizing Dr. Mead's findings, I feel it incumbent upon me to set forth the dream I had last night after reading this disturbing book.

While Department of Justice agents waited to arrest him on a charge of embezzlement, Herman Goelz, 64 years old, former cashier and vice president of the First National Bank of Hoboken, attempted suicide at 10 A.M. yesterday by shooting himself in the head and inhaling gas in his room at a boarding house at 261 Sherman Avenue, Jersey City.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- The latest plan to test the abrogation by Congress of the gold clause in government securities by demanding that Treasury gold clause notes falling due on June 15 be received at the rate of $1.69 in the payment of taxes is sponsored by Robert Jackson, an attorney here.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- The Administration Banking Bill, setting up permanent Federal insurance of bank deposits and concentrating in the hands of the Federal Reserve Board control of Reserve bank open market operations and discount rates as well as reserve requirements for member banks, was passed by the House today by a vote of 271 to 110.
Nothing happened to disturb the even tenor of the credit market, which still runs to small-size trades at prevailing quotations.

Mayor La Guardia made his third appointment to the Board of Education yesterday when he named Dr. Alberto C. Bonaschi, secretary of the Italian Chamber of Commerce, to succeed William J. Weber as one of the seven members of the board.

ALBANY, May 9. -- Governor Lehman signed today the bill creating a Bureau of State Publicity in the Conservation Department to launch an advertising and publicity campaign to attract tourists. The measure appropriated $100,000 for the campaign.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- On an assumption that Congress will pass an act extending the NIRA in so far as code regulation of those industries engaged in interstate commerce is concerned, the recovery administration is rapidly reorganizing and deciding upon the new policies it will pursue, Donald R. Richberg, acting chairman of the NIRB, said today.

In recognition of "distinguished services rendered to humanity," the National Institute of Social Sciences conferred its gold medal on four well-known Americans at its annual dinner last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Those honored were Senator Carter Glass, Cornelius N. Bliss, Dr. Harvey Cushing and Dr. George E. Vincent.

Offering will be made today of an issue of $4,000,000 City of Boston 0.99 per cent tax anticipation notes, dated May 13 and due on Nov. 8. 1935. They are priced to yield 0.75 per cent. Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., Hemphill, Noyes Co. and G.M.-P. Murphy Co. have underwritten the issue, following their successful bid of yesterday of 0.99 per cent plus $26 premium.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 9. -- Seventy-six players competed at the Woodway Country Club today as the second one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association was completed. A high wind proved troublesome and partly accounted for the return of only thirty-one cards.
Nothing happened to disturb the even tenor of the credit market, which still runs to small-size trades at prevailing quotations.

Mayor La Guardia made his third appointment to the Board of Education yesterday when he named Dr. Alberto C. Bonaschi, secretary of the Italian Chamber of Commerce, to succeed William J. Weber as one of the seven members of the board.

ALBANY, May 9. -- Governor Lehman signed today the bill creating a Bureau of State Publicity in the Conservation Department to launch an advertising and publicity campaign to attract tourists. The measure appropriated $100,000 for the campaign.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- On an assumption that Congress will pass an act extending the NIRA in so far as code regulation of those industries engaged in interstate commerce is concerned, the recovery administration is rapidly reorganizing and deciding upon the new policies it will pursue, Donald R. Richberg, acting chairman of the NIRB, said today.

In recognition of "distinguished services rendered to humanity," the National Institute of Social Sciences conferred its gold medal on four well-known Americans at its annual dinner last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Those honored were Senator Carter Glass, Cornelius N. Bliss, Dr. Harvey Cushing and Dr. George E. Vincent.
Several sales of apartment houses in the Bronx yesterday indicated a demand for multi-family buildings in that borough.

TRENTON, N.J., May 9. -- Activities of the public, the press and the radio outside the court room during the trial of Bruno R. Hauptmann at Flemington for the murder of the Lindbergh baby are being studied by a special committee named by the American Bar Association.
HONOLULU, May 9. -- Forty-six Navy flying boats took off from Pearl Harbor this morning on a secret non-stop flight with tiny Midway Island, 1,323 miles away, their destination.
The upper West Side and Washington Heights sections furnished the outstanding deals in yesterday's realty activity, which was marked by sales of housing properties.
CHICAGO, May 9. -- The Illinois relief crisis, in which most of the 1,200,000 persons on the State's rolls soon will be without any financial aid, became more acute today.

The possibility that the wage and hour provisions in the NRA codes may soon be invalidated directs attention again to the minimum wage laws of individual States. Most of these are drawn in a far more cautious spirit than the NRA labor codes. Instead of attempting to fix a blanket minimum wage, they commonly provide that minimum wages shall be fixed in particular industries only after special investigation.

LONDON, May 9. -- In the great bare hall at Westminster, whereto Simon de Montfort summoned the knights of shire, burgesses and barons and prelates to form England's first Parliament six centuries ago, King George V met his Lords and faithful House of Commons today and received their congratulations upon twenty-five years of glorious reign in which British freedom has been preserved and enhanced and democracy made safer and more enduring.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP). -- President Roosevelt sent word to the National Committee for Religion and Welfare Recovery, formulating its 1935-36 program here today, that "if permanent economic prosperity is given proper safeguards, the business, social and religious life of our people must be coordinated."
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., May 9 (AP). -- A six-ton bronze memorial to John Brown, depicting him with his arms about the shoulders of a Negro boy, was unveiled at ceremonies here today.

Most commodity futures continued to advance here yesterday. The volume of trading also increased. Coffee and cocoa failed to share in the advance because of decline in Brazilian exchange. On the cash markets gains were scored by all the grains, cotton, lard, silk, rubber, hides and wooltops.
ROME, May 9. -- Ominous words regarding the Italo-Abyssinian crisis are contained in a report on the budget of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, distributed in the Chamber of Deputies today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 9. -- Sport awards to seventy-five Yale undergraduates, recommended by the Undergraduate Athletic Association, were announced today by the Board of Control of the Yale Athletic Association.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Old masters of art paraded like phantoms across the stage today as the bitterly contested Mellon tax trial was brought here from Pittsburgh for its final sessions, which may last three weeks.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., May 9. -- Dr. and Mrs. Tyler W. Dennett will entertain the Williams College trustees at luncheon on Saturday. There will be eighteen in the party. They are having as weekend guests William Pratt Sidley of Chicago, Professor James Phinney Baxter 3d of Cambridge and Herbert J. Brown of Portland, Me., members of the board.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Old masters of art paraded like phantoms across the stage today as the bitterly contested Mellon tax trial was brought here from Pittsburgh for its final sessions, which may last three weeks.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., May 9. -- Dr. and Mrs. Tyler W. Dennett will entertain the Williams College trustees at luncheon on Saturday. There will be eighteen in the party. They are having as weekend guests William Pratt Sidley of Chicago, Professor James Phinney Baxter 3d of Cambridge and Herbert J. Brown of Portland, Me., members of the board.

The five-story building at 139 West Ninety-sixth Street was put up at foreclosure yesterday in the Vesey Street Exchange by James J. Dooling, auctioneer, who struck it down to George Gernsback, said to be an outsider, for $15,300. The acquisition of a property at auction by an outside bidder is an unusual occurrence in the present market.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- The National Commander of the American Legion has wired "148 key-men in the organization" to organize a bombardment against a veto by the President of the Patman greenbacks Bonus Bill, and, when vetoed, a cannonade of Congress against sustaining the veto.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 10. -- The eleventh annual Westchester Music Festival opened tonight at the County Centre with a choral and orchestral program of Bach and Handel music in honor of the 250th anniversaries of the famous composers.
When recently the Board of Aldermen passed a resolution requesting the Mayor to effect proper inspection of tenement houses, he was quoted as saying that inspection would not prevent fires.

The four-story brownstone residence of Dr. Charles H. May at 698 Madison Avenue has been sold to Charles Hubrecht, owner of the adjoining building at 700 Madison Avenue, it was learned yesterday. The high-stoop house with one-story extension in the rear occupies a lot 20 by 70 feet, between Sixty-second and Sixty-third Streets.

The second annual drama tournament of the Carroll Club at 120 Madison Avenue closed last night with the judging of seven plays presented by units of the Catholic girls' organization. The Athletic Association, which gave "The Happy Journey," by Thornton Wilder, received first prize, a silver cup donated by Mrs. Nicholas F. Brady.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP). -- The strict censorship that blanketed the flight of forty-six navy patrol planes from Honolulu communicated itself to the Navy Department tonight and only silence met inquiries as to the mass manoeuvres.
ADDIS ABABA, May 10. -- The Ethiopian Government has handed a note to the Italian Minister protesting statements by the Under-Secretary for Colonies at Rome Tuesday.

CHICAGO, May 10. -- State headquarters of the Illinois Emergency Relief Commission, which has handled the distribution of $274,000,000 to the needy since it was organized more than three years ago, voted today to close tomorrow noon.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- Setting foot on soil of the United States mainland for the first time in nineteen months, Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd received an enthusiastic national welcome when he landed with his crew late this afternoon on his return from his second Antarctic Expedition.
Properties in Manhattan offered at foreclosure auctions yesterday were bought in by the plaintiffs. One sale was adjourned. The results follow:

WARSAW, May 10. -- Only a very small top-hatted group and a few reporters met Pierre Laval, French Foreign Minister, when he left his train in Warsaw this evening. The train had been side-tracked across the river to the Eastern station, and special passes were issued to a few diplomats and newspaper men, who had great difficulty in gaining admission.
KANSAS CITY, May 10 (AP). -- The chain letter "road to fortune" tonight had attracted gamblers and burglars.

There is an "unprecedented accumulation of money today seeking investment," according to a report made yesterday at the closing session of the annual conference of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks by its committee on government obligations.

Because the Eighth Avenue Coach Corporation objected to the inclusion of a collective bargaining clause in a proposed franchise for bus operation on Eighth and Ninth Avenues, Mayor La Guardia yesterday struck the proposal from the calendar of the Board of Estimate.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- S. H. Kress, chairman of S. H. Kress Co., was disclosed today as holding 58.8 per cent of the corporation's common stock and 55.1 of the preferred. A registration statement to the Securities and Exchange Commission also reported that C. W. Kress, president, held 17.9 and 20.8 per cent, respectively, of the two classes.

WESTFIELD, N.J., May 10. -- Rainbow's End, chestnut mare, owned by Miss Jeanne Nehrbas of Huntington, L.I., carried off the blue ribbon in the saddle horse class for mounts over 15.2, a feature of the opening session of the annual two-day Westfield Horse Show tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- Administration leaders of the Senate, already hard pressed but apparently making headway in gaining support for a Presidential veto of the Patman Bonus Bill, were thrown into confusion late today by reports of a speech by Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, at Pinehurst, N.C., which was interpreted as virtually favoring cashing the veterans adjusted service certificates.

CLEVELAND, May 10. -- Inspired by Captain Lou Gehrig's second homer of the campaign and some vigorous left-handed pitching by the doughty Vito Tamulis, the Yankees bounced out of their losing streak today and laid the Indians by the heels all in the one sweep.

The referee for the Canzoneri-Ambers fight last night was Arthur Donovan. The judges were Charlie Lynch and Marty Monroe. Canzoneri weighed 133 pounds and Ambers 133 3/4. The round-by-round description follows:

BERLIN, May 10. -- The Boerse was quiet but firm today. Heavy industrials were slightly stronger. Vereinigtestahl gaining 1/2 point. Potashes were mixed. Machines were slightly stronger, Schwarzkopf gaining l 1/2 points. Chemicals were firm, I.G. Farben gaining 7/8 point.

Trade results here during the week proved a sharp disappointment to merchants. Sales volume fell below last year by 5 per cent or more, with an increased number of stores participating in the decline. While merchants were primarily disposed to blame adverse weather there was an increasing tendency to ascribe the poor showing in considerable measure to the effect of the sales tax here.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in the State, now offered by dealers:
WASHINGTON, May 10. -- Money in circulation on April 30 amounted to $5,477,736,103 as compared with $5,493,137,741 a month earlier and $5,367,572,469 a year ago, the Treasury reported today.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., May 10. -- An award of $125,000 was granted today to F. Brandon Smith Jr., 29-year-old Charlotte real estate man, in his alienation of affections suit against his former father-in-law, Joseph F. Cannon, wealthy Concord business man.

The recognition of the theory of the "gradation of responsibility" in international organization would make it possible for the United States to become actively associated with the League of Nations in the preservation of peace without joining it, Professor James T.
