Shotwell of Columbia University told a gathering of the American branch of the International Law Association, at its annual dinner at the Hotel Plaza last night.

ALBANY, May 10. -- Governor Lehman heard Mayor La Guardia accused today of breaking faith with the residents of the Bronx because of his opposition to the bill providing for four additional Municipal Court justices for that county.

The Marine Midland Trust Company of New York, named as successor trustee under an agreement dated March 1, 1929, for the $47,596,500 of 5 per cent sinking fund gold debentures of the Kreuger Toll Company, has issued an interim report in which it states, in effect, that progress is being made in untangling the affairs of the late Ivar Kreuger and his companies.

Twenty-five night club and cafe proprietors have been ordered to appear at the State Department of Labor, 80 Centre Street, Monday morning to explain why some of their waitresses and cigarette and hat check girls work after 10 P.M.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- The Claire Knitting Mills, Inc., which moved its plant from New York City to Shelton, Conn., was ordered today by the National Labor Relations Board to employ at former rates of pay as many of its New York workers as might want to work in Shelton.

Although a pause in the forward movement of business was revealed this week by reports from manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers in various parts of the country, the recession appears to be of only trifling proportions, according to the weekly trade review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Captain Alfred W. Peterson, master of the Ward liner Havana that went aground on Mantanilla reef, in the Bahamas, on Jan. 6, was held to have been negligent in his navigation of the ship in a report filed yesterday by the local steamboat inspectors after a hearing.

BALTIMORE, May 10. -- "Beat Omaha and win the Preakness," was the word at Pimlico today as eleven 3-year-olds, including the Kentucky Derby winner, were named for the $25,000 added test which is Maryland's most famous horse race.

HONOLULU, May 10. -- Censorship and radio silence today completely cloaked the operations of the forty-six navy flying boats that took off from Pearl Harbor yesterday morning with Midway Island, 1,323 miles away, their apparent destination.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- Mrs. John Hay Whitney was established as one of the most successful exhibitors in the National Capital Horse Show at the Bradley Farms today as her entries carried off a succession of ribbons.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., May 10. -- With more than 200 students and adults stricken with a mild form of food poisoning, State and local authorities were investigating its causes tonight.

The possibility of new financing for the public-utility industry became somewhat less remote yesterday as a result of improved investor attitude toward the industry, and utility issues in the open market furnished a bright spot in the trading on the Stock Exchange with a rally which raised THE NEW YORK TIMES average for that classification 0.77 point.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- A saving of $14,000,000 to farmers indebted to the Federal Land Bank System was voted by the House today in the form of lower interest rates on an estimated $1,500,000,000 of loans through the Farm Credit Administration for farm-mortgage refinancing.
" Gigolette," a Select production released through RKO Radio and numbering among its players Adrienne Ames, Ralph Bellamy and Robert Armstrong, opens this morning at the Globe.

LONDON, May 10. -- Wholly unannounced and without pomp or ceremony, King George and Queen Mary paid a surprise visit today to some of the poor relations of their "big family," including those living in the Communist centre, Battersea.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- Provisional budgets for Lumber and Timber Products Code administrative agencies, for May 2 to June 16, have been approved conditionally by the National Industrial Recovery Board. They are pro rata extensions of the budgets for 1934.

Tomorrow will be Mother's Day. It will be widely observed publicly and privately throughout the United States. There will be meetings, radio broadcasts, church services, family gatherings and countless messages and gifts to mothers.

The International Cement Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday, in the annual statement for 1934, a net profit of $666,730 after interest, depreciation, depletion, Federal taxes and other charges. This is equivalent to $1.04 a share on 636,978, no par, shares of capital stock, including 10,800 shares held in the treasury. In the previous year the company had a net loss of $102,266.

ALBANY, May 10. -- Outboard drivers, ready for the 129-mile marathon from here to Dyckman Street, Manhattan, on Sunday, began reporting today at the Albany Yacht Club. They grinned with delight when they found the Hudson nearly two feet higher than normal and carrying an extra current that swirled around the bridge piers.

PHILADELPHIA, May 10. -- Employes of the Pennsylvania Railroad soon will receive $2,500,000, representing 2 per cent of the salaries paid them between Aug. 1, 1934, and May 1 last. The sum was set aside by the company under the terms of the Federal Railway Retirement Act, which the United States Supreme Court has declared unconstitutional.

The Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Corporation, Richard A. Brennan, president, has sold to the Macberth Realty Company, Inc., S. Schwartz, president, a twenty- seven-family apartment house at 2,080 Seventy-seventh Street, Brooklyn.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 10. -- The Now Jersey Federation of Women's Clubs went on record today condemning "communism, fascism or any other political system which tends to curtail Ireo expression of thought and set up dictatorships, group or individual."
The "forgotten men," thousands of unemployed professional musicians, victims of sound pictures, years of unemployment, depression and poverty, are getting attention again.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- A retried criminal statute covering double jeopardy, or the conditions under which a new trial may be granted, was adopted today by the American Law Institute for submission to State Legislatures as a model law.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations, including processing tax, on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:
PARIS, May 10. -- Due Maurice de Broglie, eminent French scientist, in an address to the American Club yesterday, paid a high compliment to American scientists, especially physicists.

If the Banking Bill which has just passed the House by the heavy majority of 271 to 110 were to become law in its present form, some of its provisions might cause grave concern. Fortunately, it seems probable that it will be subjected to close scrutiny and extensive amendment in the Senate.

John Ringling, president of Ringling Brothers circus, testified for nearly two hours yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Peter Schmuck, declaring that he had put up five paintings worth more than $500,000 as security for the $50,000 note which his wife, Mrs. Emily Haag Buck Ringling, is trying to collect by a lawsuit.

The Federal Grand Jury Association for the Southern District of New York charged yesterday in a letter to the Senate Appropriations Committee that Federal relief funds were being used to teach subversive doctrines to 20,000 adult students in more than twenty schools for workers throughout the country.

Edward J. Murphy, 39 years old, for fifteen years an investigator for the Treasury Department, was held without bail yesterday in Bronx magistrate's court for the fatal shooting of his wife in their home at 4,333 Kepler Avenue, the Bronx. The shooting occurred shortly before 6 A.M. yesterday, after Murphy had returned from a dinner at an inn in Riverdale.

Sugar, coffee and the metals were firmer on the local commodity futures markets yesterday and were generally active. Light profit-taking shaded the prices in other staples, which had advanced earlier in the week. On the cash markets, oats, lard and tin rose and wheat, corn, rye, flour and rubber declined.
WASHINGTON, May 10. -- Applications for the registration of 1,016 security issues, aggregating $1,720,000,000, have become effective since the Securities Act of 1933 became operative in July, 1933.

Track and field will present a new fixture today when the Heptagonal Games bring together the seven colleges of the East's old guard in a championship meet that will enable them to settle the question of supremacy among themselves without being bothered by the powerhouses from California.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., May 10. -- Dinners were given last night at the Greenbrier by John F. Fahey, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board and the Home Owners Loan Corporation; Mr. and Mrs. Isaac H. Clothier 3d of Philadelphia and their son, Isaac, and Mr. and Mrs. Richard Bowditch of Boston.

OSSINING, N.Y., May 10. -- An automobile containing six members of the Jamaica High School track team crashed into a signpost this afternoon on Route 404, killing one of the youths and injuring the others. One of the injured is in a critical condition at Ossining Hospital.

Cubans of Left sympathies will not be alone in discerning a touch of the heroic in the death of ANTONIO GUITARAS at Matanzas in battle against the government forces. He was the iron man of the late Grau San Martin regime.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, May 10. -- At impressive ceremonies last night President Juan B. Sacasa presented to Dr. Daniel M. Molloy of the Rockefeller Foundation a letter of gratitude from Nicaragua for his twenty years of service in connection with the public health service of Nicaragua.

CHICAGO, May 10. -- The Red Sox, who yesterday tumbled the White Sox from the American League lead by handing them their first home defeat in ten games, scored another runaway victory today, winning 12 to 2.
WASHINGTON, May 10. -- Admiral Byrd's most vivid recollection of the four solitary months he spent in a snow-heaped Antarctic hut is of the silence that surrounded him.

Gross earnings of the Continental Gas and Electric Corporation and subsidiaries for 1934 were $1,262,202. or 4.28 per cent higher than in 1933, amounting to $30,769,951. Sales of electricity were 8.30 per cent better and sales of gas rose 3.81 per cent.

Victor Aloysius Meyers, debonair 36-year-old Lieutenant Governor of Washington, relaxed in his suite at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday noon and said that he would like to go Senator Huey Long one better by running for the Presidency on a "Share-the-Debts" program.

Many expressions of reset were received last night from persons prominent in the music life of New York and Chicago, who had known Mr. Witherspoon as a singer, teacher and opera executive. They included the following:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 10. -- Clearing twenty-four fences without the semblance of an error, the brown mare Lady Biff, exhibited by the West Point Horse Show team, tonight won the knock down-and-out jumping competition, the most spectacular number on the card of the second evening performance of the eleventh annual New Haven Horse Show.
ALBANY, May 10. -- Governor Lehman signed today the Pack bill designed to facilitate collection by instalments of judgments obtained in the New York City Municipal Court.

Judge Robert A. Inch issued yesterday in the United States District Court in Brooklyn an order directing three financial institutions to distribute $1,173,000 to holders of five series of bonds issued by the Prudence Bonds Corporation, which is undergoing reorganization, under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Law.

Dr. GEORGE VINCENT'S account of the advance in the heroic attempt to drive yellow fever off the face of the earth deals with one of the most dramatic and inspiriting stories of human achievement. The deaths of STOKES and NOGUCHI added new names to the roll of martyrs to science in this world warfare

The board of directors of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., yesterday dismissed Richard Gimbel, vice president in charge of the company's store in Philadelphia because of his action in discharging. Arthur C. Kaufmann as merchandise manager. Mr. Kaufmann was appointed to succeed him as manager.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- Mr. Eccles surprised his conservative critics at the hearing today with a statement that there was "no urgent demand for new currency" and that it could not be kept in circulation if issued.

CHICAGO, May 10. -- Grain traders on the Board of Trade placed a moderately bullish construction today on the government estimate of a Winter wheat crop of 432,000,000 bushels, issued after the close of the market. While it was only 3,000,000 bushels under the returns of a month ago, the forecast was 18,000,000 bushels below the average of the recent private guesses, and only 27,000,000 bushels above the abnormally small crop of 1934.

A young man who posed as a prospective purchaser of treasures from imperial Russia held up the manager of a gallery at 36 West Fiftieth Street in the RCA Building at 6:30 o'clock last night and escaped with jewelry valued at $10,000.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):

Tonight's departures from Broadway are three, including the pair already announced. "To See Ourselves," the E.M. Delafield comedy at the Ethel Barrymore, decided yesterday to be content with an engagement of slightly less than two weeks.

HUNTSVILLE, Texas, May 10 (AP). -- Two convicts and a guard were slain and half a dozen men were wounded in Texas penitentiary system disturbances today within eighteen hours after the death in the electric chair of Raymond Hamilton and Joe Palmer for killing a prison officer to escape.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., May 10. -- Protests of preparations for war were contained in four resolutions adopted here today at the concluding session of the fifth annual meeting of the Middle Atlantic Conference of Congregational and Christian Churches.

Senator AUSTIN of Vermont, who made a fine impression as a debater during his first term in the Senate and was re-elected last November, made a stir on Thursday by some pungent criticism of the Tennessee Valley Authority. He attacked both its methods and its work.

A police alarm was broadcast throughout eight States yesterday for Eleanor Schmaus, 13 years old, of 218 Eckford Street, Brooklyn, who disappeared Monday after writing a letter to her father hinting that she intended to "seek my own happiness" with Henry J. Simpson, twenty-two years her senior, who was formerly organist at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Ascension, 129 Kent Street, Brooklyn.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 10. -- In the second of the inter-club team matches of the Westchester division of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association, held at the Century Country Club, the five players from the Westchester Country Club today went into the A division lead by winning 8 points in a session of double match play with Gedney Farm and Quaker Ridge.

When Francis Boardman assumed his duties yesterday as director of the Works Division of the Emergency Relief Bureau, succeeding Colonel William J. Wilgus, he announced that his "immediate job" was to inform himself of what was being done so that he could "plan intelligently to carry on the admirable work of Colonel Wilgus in the efficient and practical operation of the Works Division."

The directors of the Metropolitan could throw no light last night on what direction the Metropolitan would now take. Paul D. Cravath, chairman of the board, had no comment to make. Allen Wardwell, a member of the board and a classmate of Mr. Witherspoon at Yale, observed that something would have to be done soon.
BUCHAREST, May 10. -- The fifth Balkan Entente conference opened this afternoon, with Foreign Minister Nicolas Titulescu of Rumania presiding.

With the arraignment yesterday of two alleged counterfeiters who were receiving relief from the city, Treasury Secret Service men, under Agent Robert L. Godby, believed they had cut off a flow of fake half-dollars, quarters, dimes and nickels that have had a widespread circulation in Yorkville for a month and a half.

MEXICO, D.F., May 10. -- By winning the first two singles matches, the United States today virtually eliminated China from the Davis Cup competition this year. One doubles match is scheduled to be played tomorrow and the last two singles on Sunday.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., May 10. -- Lakeville's team, impressive as it was in the opening series of women's golf matches a week ago, made an even more impressive showing today at the North Hempstead Country Club.

Herbert Witherspoon, the new general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, died suddenly yesterday afternoon in the executive offices at the opera house that he had occupied for only two weeks, since the departure of Giulio Gatti-Casazza.

Ingeborg Torrup, after an absence of several seasons, gave a recital of dances last night at the Barbizon-Plaza. In her own field of work, Miss Torrup is a charming dancer who adds to her graciousness of personality an evident knowledge of what she is about. Her field is that of musical interpretation, and its dimensions are small; it is, indeed, chamber dancing, rather than theatre dancing, but excellent of its kind.

More than 1,000 persons, many of them prominent in the public, social and business life of the nation, attended funeral services yesterday afternoon for United States Senator Bronson M. Cutting in St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street.
PURCHASE, N.Y., May 10. -- About 1,250 persons visited the palatial Whitelaw Reid mansion today on the occasion of its opening to the public before its furnishings are sold beginning Tuesday.

Polly Adler, 32 years old, who gave the name Joan Martin when she was arrested March 5, was sentenced to thirty days in the workhouse yesterday by Justices McInerny, Murphy and Rayfiel in Special Sessions for maintaining a disreputable apartment in East Fifty-fifth Street near Madison Avenue.

Activity in the market for new State and municipal financing will continue comparatively small next week, the total scheduled Being $9,591,672, compared with $23,794,180 this week. Only two issues will exceed $1,000,000. They are offerings of $3,000,000 of State of South Dakota and $2,840,000 of State of Delaware bonds.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 10. -- Princeton's baseball team today defeated Fordham, 2 -- 1, on University Field. Johnny Morris, starting his first game on the mound for the Tigers, pitched superb ball, fanning four while letting the Ram batters down with five scattered hits.

ALBANY, May 10. -- Governor Lehman signed today the Byrne bill, establishing the Albany Regional Light, Heat and Power Authority. The measure permits Albany and its environs to go beyond the provisions of the municipal ownership law in creating or taking over present power facilities.
ST. LOUIS, May 10 (AP). -- Vernon Wilshere, former Indiana University southpaw, limited the Browns to seven hits today while his teammates mistreated four hurlers and the Athletics won, 7 to 4.

A prize of $10,000 for first place in a radio contest conducted to select a title for a previously unnamed fragment of music by Richard Wagner was awarded to Miss Majorie B. Pettee, a school teacher of Birmingham, Ala., it was announced last night by the pharmaceutical concern which was sponsor for last season's broadcasts from the Metropolitan Opera House.

The Board of Transportation awarded yesterday to Emerson-Hines, Inc., of 370 Lexington Avenue a $158,125 contract for installation of cables for the signal system of the Houston-Essex-Rutgers Street line of the city's independent subway system.
To see a child on the roof, in Spring sunlight, one arm on mother's knee the other on father's, means joy.

Men and women cooks, meeting in a debate yesterday at the Port of New York Authority Building, Eighth Avenue and Fifteenth Street, where the Hobby Round-Up will end its session today, failed intrinsically to prove which sex is the better cook, but the decision went to the women.

The Dun-Bradstreet preliminary report on this week's exchange of bank checks throughout the United States gives a figure not only 21 1/2 per cent above the same week in 1934 (when trade was described as active), but the largest of any week since the beginning of 1932.
Mothers' Day will be observed tomorrow in churches of every communion. Commemoration services also will be held in Salvation Army centres throughout the city.

PINEHURST, N.C., May 10. -- Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, returned late tonight to his hotel from a fishing trip to learn to his surprise that his address before the North Carolina State Bankers Association had created a stir in Washington.

President Roosevelt was assailed yesterday afternoon by the New York East Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, holding the eighty-seventh annual session in Brooklyn, for preparing the United States for war. His government policies were termed "extraordinary" and should be "without the sanction and support of the church."

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- A sharp clash of ideas over banking legislation developed today when Marriner S. Eccles, governor of the Federal Reserve Board, faced Senator Glass at a hearing before the Glass subcommittee on a banking reform bill very similar to that passed in the House yesterday by a vote of 271 to 110.
LONDON, May 10 (AP). -- Letters oozing with endearment enlivened the opening today of the breach of promise suit of Angela Joyce, "Miss England" of 1930, against wealthy young Lord Revelstoke.

SHREVEPORT, La., May 10 (AP). -- Mounting the Parish Court House steps here today, State Representative Rupert Peyton of Caddo Parish defied the State PWA Funds Control Law dictated by Senator Long and announced before a crowd that he had violated it at 12:01 o'clock, one minute after the act went into effect.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., May 10. -- Virginia's first "court season" since the State was a crown colony will be officially opened tomorrow morning by Lieut. Gov. James H. Price. On Monday night Governor George C. Peery will hold in the restored Capitol building a reception that will be the brilliant finale of old Williamsburg's three-day celebration.

Aldermanic President Bernard S. Deutsch criticized Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens yesterday for making "wholesale charges without specific facts to substantiate them" before the Aldermanic Committee Investigating Relief last Thursday.

TOLEDO, May 10. -- Unless the conference which opens here tomorrow succeeds within a "reasonable" time in settling a pattern for union recognition, local unions of the American Federation of Labor will call additional strikes in key plants of the General Motors Corporation in the hope of crippling production for the remainder of the season, it was indicated here tonight following the arrival of union leaders from Detroit.

The recent series of poisonings from eclairs in Westchester County very closely resembled similar outbreaks which, from time to time, have been recorded in medical literature. The ingredients used, the nature of the toxin and symptoms produced were practically identical.

ROME, May lO. -- Feverish war I preparations by Ethiopia are I charged by the Giornale d'Itali to-I night in an article obviously in-I spired. A strong profest is made[ against the supplying of arms to/ Ethiopia by European armament / firms, which are acaused of encourJ aging Ethiopia in assuming an aggressive attitude agains Italy.

Persons sailing today for Mediterranean ports on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia include Fin Lund, Danish Minister to Mexico, and Mrs. Lund; Luciano Lopez Ferrer, Spanish Ambassador to Cuba; Joseph Schenck, president of United Artists; Myrna Loy, film actress, and:

Magistrate Jonah J. Goldstein, accepting the statement of James J. Wilson, Assistant District Attorney assigned to Special Sessions, that the District Attorney's office is opposed to arrests and convictions of policy players, discharged four defendants in the Tombs Court yesterday on such charges.

Ducking under his opponent as he tried a flying tackle and slamming him to the floor with a body hold, Dan Levin of Jamaica threw Maurice La Chappelle of France in the main bout to a finish at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory last night.

Many younger members of society attended the Spring Ball last night in the main-ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton, which was organized for the benefit of the Summer camp maintained by the Masters School Day Nursery of this city.

The two Canadian airplane pilots who have been helping to open the mining country of the North by air and who will fly the Northrop monoplane Polar Star for Lincoln Ellsworth on his third attempt to span the Antarctic Continent from the Weddell Sea to the Ross Sea next Autumn visited New York yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- A Winter wheat crop of 431,637,000 bushels, about 81.2 per cent of the 1923-32 average, and 26,603,000 bushels more than was expected on April 10, was predicted today by the Crop Reporting Board of the Department of Agriculture.

To a country that has just seen the Senate pass the Patman Bonus Bill and hears the insolent clamor that threatens the opponents of that measure, the speech of Senator GLASS accepting the medal of the National Institute of Social Sciences is as salutary as it is timely. Senator GLASS will not even accept the common phrase "public servant" in its contemporary meaning:

BALTIMORE, Md., May 10. -- The long expected plan of reorganization of the Consolidation Coal Company which has been in receivership since June, 1932, was announced today by a committee composed of Howard Bruce, John J. Nelligan and Acosta Nichols.

The March holdover grand jury has arranged for the appearance of two more prominent city officials before it Monday to testify in its investigation of the policy racket, it became known yesterday at the Criminal Courts Building.
In the two days following its selection as the Pulitzer prize-winning novel, "Now in November," by Josephine Johnson, sold more than 9,000 copies, Simon Schuster report.

Announcement by the Stock Exchange yesterday that it had suspended dealings in capital stock of the United States Express Company because the process of liquidation had reduced the company's remaining assets to a negligible amount set something of a precedent.

LONDON, May 10. -- The portly Duke of Manchester, as he gloomily paced a jail cell tonight after being sentenced to nine months' imprisonment for fraud in pawning the jewels of his late American-born mother, admitted ruefully:

Salvatore Mancuso, leader of a ring of narcotic smugglers, who kidnapped and tortured two French sailors last Summer in the belief that they had found and sold a small package of morphine, was sentenced yesterday to serve forty years in jail.
WASHINGTON, May 10. -- President Roosevelt and the Democratic leadership of the Senate came to an open break today over the subject of extending the National Industrial Recovery Act.

Charges that "Jim Crowism" is practiced against Negro doctors and nurses on the staff of the Harlem Hospital, a city institution, were made yesterday by witnesses at the first hearing of a subcommittee on health and sanitation of the Mayor's Commission on Conditions in Harlem.

Episodes characteristic of the development of the Kips Bay neighborhood in the last 300 years were among the colorful features of "The Pageant of the Good Neighbor," produced last night in St. Gabriel's Park, which extends from Thirty- fifth to Thirty-sixth Street between First and Second Avenues.

CHICAGO, May 10. -- Stockholders of Swift Co. approved today the issuance of $50,000,000 first mortgage 3 3/4 per cent bonds to replace a similar amount of 5 per cent bonds of 1944 and 5 per cent gold notes of 1940.
Frederick E. Bickford, on Rtdgewood Drive, Rye, from Mrs. Rene P. larshall; Robert J. Lewis, on Forest Av., Rye, from William Rand estate; Edward V. Siedle, broker.

Election of fifty-four student candidates to membership in the Columbia University cheer of Sigma XI, honorary scientific research society, was announced yesterday by Professor Marston T. Bogert, president of the chapter.

MOSCOW, May 10. -- The principal mission of Pierre Laval, French Foreign Minister, on his visit to Moscow, beginning Monday, will be a discussion with Soviet authorities of how to bring Germany and Poland into a general Eastern European security system, of which the Franco-Soviet pact is avowedly only a beginning, it was said today in informed Soviet circles.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., May 10. -- Dedicated to the memory of Adolph S. Ochs and avowedly intending, in so far as its field will permit, to model itself on the standards and character of THE NEW YORK TIMES, a new weekly newspaper, The Port Washington Times, made its appearance here today.

ALBANY, May 10. -- A plan for cutting down ruinous interstate milk price wars through a licensing program in cooperation with the Federal Government was announced tonight by Peter G. Ten Eyck, Commissioner of Agriculture.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 10. -- Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin is charged in a Supreme Court suit disclosed here today with conspiring, when he was District Attorney of the Bronx, to convict Paul Orzel, New York engineer, of manslaughter in connection with a coal pocket collapse in 1930 in which three men were killed.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 10 (AP). -- Wilho Winika, Rutgers football player, set a new record for the javelin throw today as about 150 athletes from thirteen colleges opened the twenty-third annual Middle Atlantic track and field championships at Lehigh University.
Along with the trouble brought on by the weather and its attendant accumulation of double-headers, Manager Bill Terry and his Giants suffered a new blow yesterday.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., May 10 (AP). -- Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin S. Orcutt, parents of Miss Maureen Orcutt, expressed surprise today when they were informed that their daughter had already been married to Mr. Crews.

HONOLULU, May 10. -- The unprecedented manoeuvres of the American Navy's great mid-Pacific air armada went forward today behind an impenetrable wall of secrecy thrown about the operations by Admiral Joseph M. Reeves, the commander of the fleet.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd reported on the scientific achievements of his second Antarctic expedition tonight at a reception in Constitution Hall held in his honor by the board of trustees of the National Geographic Society.

A tiny line upon a photograph furnished yesterday the evidence by which Frederick Gross, 49-year-old bookkeeper in a chemical importing house, was faced with a charge of murdering his wife and four children with thallium sulphate, a seldom-used poison.

Four one-story taxpayers on a plot 100 by 105 feet at the northwest corner of Castle Hill and Houghton Avenues were sold by the Henthel Realty Corporation to Richard M. Lederer for investment. The stores are near the Bronx approach to the Triborough Bridge.

Levy Brothers, Manhattan operators and builders, have leased for thirty-one years from the city of Newark a triangular plot for improvement with a two-story store and office building. The plot fronts 122 feet in Raymond Boulevard, 13 feet in Washington Avenue and 104 feet in Academy Street.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 10. -- Florida made another bid for tourists today as Governor Dave Sholtz approved a measure for ninety-day divorces.

TRENTON, N.J., May 10. -- Supporting the assignments of error recently filed with the Court of Errors and Appeals, counsel far Bruno Richard Hauptmann, who is under sentence of death for the murder of the Lindbergh baby, filed today 193 specifications of causes for asking a reversal of the verdict returned by the jury at the recent trial at Flemington.

BOSTON, May 10 (AP). -- The Walworth Company of Boston, manufacturers of valves, tools, pipe fittings and wrenches, with 4,200 employes, and plants also in Illinois and Pennsylvania, today filed a petition in Federal District Court to reorganize under Section 77B of the Bankruptcy Act.

OUT of an inner room came Pie Traynor, manager of the Pittsburgh Pirates. It was a few minutes past noon and Pie was only a few minutes out of bed. Fine example for a manager to be setting for his brisk athletes. He should be up and around at dawn, singing like a lark.

The first dead heat on a New York track in almost three years occurred in the second race at Jamaica yesterday. At the finish G. W. Ogle's Tractable, the 8-5 favorite, and Mrs. Ida Katz's Little Argo, a 40-1 outsider, were on such even-terms that the judges could not separate them.

HELSINGFORS, May 10. -- Werner Janssen, the young American guest conductor this last season of the New York Philharmonic Symphony Society, conducted tonight with outstanding success the Helsingsfors Municipal Orchestra in his second Sibelius concert here in the large University Hall, where he captivated last year the Finnish critics and music-lovers with his notable interpretations of the Fourth and Fifth Symphonies of Finland's great composer, Jean Sibelius.

The old ring maxim, "They never come back," went by the boards last night in Madison Square Garden, where Tony Canzoneri carved himself a niche in the ring's hall of fame by regaining his world's lightweight title.

The Board of Estimate showed good judgment yesterday in rejecting the Lyons bill, which would have excluded out-of-town residents from positions in the Relief Administration. It is true that New York City seems a large enough field in which to find capable officials and employes for most work of this sort

Shares of the Discount Corporation of New York, which hitherto have been held exclusively by a group of leading banks and by a few officers of the corporation, are being offered to the public in connection with the disposal of a part of its holdings by the Amerex Holding Corporation, successor to the Chase Corporation.

If the lustrous audience which greeted him at his premiere on Thursday evening was any indication, Harry Richman should prove the biggest "draw" the Versailles Restaurant has had this season -- and certainly the most popular current attraction in intimate nightlife circles.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- Plans for putting 10,000 men to work this Summer on a soil-erosion program designed principally to offset drought damage in the Middle West were announced today by the government.

POUGHKEEPSIE, May 10. -- The younger generation tonight made its bid for recognition as a social and intellectual force at the start of a conference of students, faculty land parents at Vassar College. The conference was arranged in an effort to reconcile home influences and home understanding with college life and the new points of view gained from academic pursuits.

A further increase in traffic was forecast for this year in the report of Hale Holden, chairman of the Southern Pacific Company, for 1934. Mr. Holden described unregulated highway competition as a continued threat to railway prosperity.

It is through the experience of private welfare agencies over a long period of time that we have gained much light on many of our larger social questions -- unemployment, housing, delinquency and crime, mental suffering, broken homes and child guidance. These agencies have become, in a very real sense, human welfare lighthouses, constantly revealing to the public the underlying causes of our social ills.
WORCESTER, Mass., May 10. -- After trailing for seven innings, the Holy Cross nine put on an eighth-inning rally to push over six runs and defeat Pennsylvania today, 9 to 6.

The Consolidated Gas System is making substantial progress in the preparation of its plan to establish lower electric rates under a system whereby general consumers will obtain the advantage of increased company profits or lowered operating costs, it was indicated yesterday.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange gained further yesterday and futures got nearest to the 12-cent level since the big break on March 11. The July sold at 11.99 cents a pound and the March at virtually an even basis, advancing to 11,98 cents.

Intermittent waves of profit-taking failed to swerve the share markets yesterday from the forward movement begun two days before, with the industrial section closing substantially higher and the railway group holding its ground satisfactorily.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., May 10.- Mrs. William Hockenjos of Lake Hopatcong paced a field of 102 starters, the largest in several years, in a Women's New Jersey Golf Association one-day tournament today at the Baltusrol Golf Club.

Thirteen horses have been entered entered in the Cedarhurst Grand National Steeplechase, the feature event of the Spring meeting of the Rockaway Steeplechase Association, which will be held today on the course facing the Rockaway Hunting Club at Cedarhurst, L.I.

TORONTO, Ont., May 10. -- A southpaw pitching duel between Frank Coleman of the Toronto Maple Leafs and Marvin Duke of the Newark Bears was interrupted today when the home hitters drove Duke from the box in the fifth inning with a fusillade of six hits good for six runs and triumphed, 7 to 2.
DETROIT, May 10 (AP). -- Joe Sullivan, Detroit's rookie hurler, brought the Tigers back to the winning trail today when he pitched an 8-4 victory over the Senators.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 10. -- Yale University today announced the award of 154 fellowships and scholarships in the Graduate School for 1935-36. Twenty are Sterling Fellowships, the leading awards offered by the university, which are granted to students who hold the degree of Doctor of Philosophy or its equivalent.
ALBANY, May 10. -- Governor Lehman today vetoed two more bills which would have struck at maintenance of the civil service in the regulation of the liquor traffic.

PARIS, May l0. -- The Bourse was irregular today. At the opening, it resumed the general trend of weakening rentes and rising industrials, but later rentes recovered and lost only slight fractions. The perpetual 3 per cents actually mad a small gain.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 10. -- Characterizing as "dangerous" many changes in the Federal Reserve System as provided in the Federal Banking Bill, the Hartford Chamber of Commerce today telegraphed to Washington a denunciation of the pending measure.

For the first time in the twenty-six years of its existence the New York County Lawyers Association will elect a woman as an officer, it became known yesterday, when the committee on nominations announced its choice of Miss Ruth Lewinson for the post of treasurer.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 10. -- Carnegie Lake today was alive with a flotilla of crews that tomorrow will compete in a regatta climaxed by the renewal of the ancient Childs Cup race for the varsity eights of Columbia, Pennsylvania and Princeton.

The annual dinner of the Barnard College Athletic Association, at which awards of pins, letters and class numerals were presented to participants in the college's intramural athletic program, was held last night in Barnard Hall, Broadway and 117th Street.

New bond offerings this week declined to $9,461,000, of which $4,000,000 was public utility and $5,416,000 State and municipal obligations. This compared with $48,546,000 in the previous week and $54,500,000 a year ago, of which $32,500,000 was for Federal Intermediate Credit Bank and $20,000,000 was in a single issue of soldier bonus bonds of Pennsylvania.

Two big innings enabled the New York University baseball team to record its ninth victory in ten starts yesterday as it defeated Rutgers University, 10 to 6, at Ohio Field. This was the second decision for the Violet over the New Brunswick nine this season.

Incidents in the theatrical life of fifty years ago in this city were recalled yesterday by Daniel Frohman, the veteran producer, who was re-elected head of the Actors Fund of America at the fifty-third annual meeting of that organization at the Lyceum Theatre in West Forty-fifth Street.

The home bureau of the Hebrew Sheltering Guardian Society is an organization for the care of dependent children. At present 1,300 children are being cared for in boarding homes of the highest standards. The home bureau pays board for the care of its children. It provides them with medical care and clothing.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:
Visitors to the Catskill streams this week-end probably will find conditions for fly fishing more favorable than at any stage of the season to date, judging from reports received yesterday.
lay Rickey gave to Sally L. Draisin a tgage for $9,800, payable March 18. at 6 per cent, on the parcel on the north side of 12th St., 395 feet west of Av. B, 25x103.3 feet.

By a vote of eight to five, the compulsory city residence bill sponsored by Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx which affects relief workers was defeated yesterday in the Board of Estimate branch of the Municipal Assembly.

The Horace Mann School baseball team scored an 11-to-4 triumph over Princeton Prep in an Eastern Private Schools League contest at the victor's field yesterday. It was the third consecutive victory in league competition for Horace Mann.

Fair weather today, with cloudiness and showers tomorrow afternoon or evening, was forecast last night by officials at the local Weather Bureau. The temperatures today, according to the prediction, will be about the same as those which prevailed yesterday.

CARDIFF, Wales, May 10 (AP). -- Five hundred women, many with babies in their arms, tonight marched singing over the rugged mountains of Wales en route here to stage a protest demonstration before the Prince of Wales tomorrow.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., May 10. -- The annual junior promenade of Smith College will take place tomorrow. The festivities began tonight with a dinner dance, and will continue tomorrow with a garden party and the formal promenade. The dinner dance was held at the Springfield Country Club.

QUEBEC, May 10. -- Premier L.A. Taschereau told the Privincial Parliament today that while the newsprint bill would be a "weapon" for enforcing the present law, it might not have to be used because an amicable settlement might be reached from pourparlers now in progress with the industry.

LONDON, May 10. -- Every day as Italy's mobilization makes further headway the British Government becomes more and more worried over the possibility of a war against Ethiopia. There is a steadily growing belief here that Premier Mussolini is bent on destroying Ethiopia in much the same way that pre-war Austria-Hungary was determined to crush Serbia, and that nothing, not even the threatening situation in Europe, will deter him.

Anxiety over reports of the spread of radical propaganda on the campus of Columbia University was expressed in a memorandum sent by Clarence E. Lovejoy, secretary of Alumni Federation, to university officials and the executive committee of the federation, it was learned yesterday.

In a week of mixed trends. The Annalist reported yesterday, advances canceled declines, and its weekly index of wholesale commodity prices was unchanged for the week ended on Tuesday at 126.6 (revised).

The peace and well-being of the world depend on the continued friendly relations of the United States, Great Britain and France, speakers declared last night at a dinner of the New York State Society of the Cincinnati in the Hotel Plaza.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 11 (AP). -- Coldstream, which races for C.D. Shaffer of Chicago, established himself as an outstanding 2-year-old prospect of the Midwest when he made a show of his opposition to win the thirty-fourth running of the Bashford Manor Stakes before 15,000 racing fans at Churchill Downs today.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- When the year for his re-election begins, will the President have disposed of all controversial legislation, abandoned crippled emergency experiments -- such as NRA and AAA -- and completed a revised form of the New Deal for submission at the polls?

THE attention of the world is focused on London, the capital of the King's Jubilee, which, with recurring pageantry, will continue for several months. Those who have come from far-off places -- many of the Jubilee visitors are Londoners in exile -- will find a host of old landmarks; but they will look in vain for landmarks that have gone the way of things that stand in the path of progress.

UNFAVORABLE weather conditions over a large part of the country continued to restrict retail trade in the week. Clearance sales failed to draw their usual response and the introduction of new Summer lines was hampered.

PARIS, May 9. -- Schiaparelli treats her new hats as good jokes. Mickey Mouse models, looking like plaited straw pancakes with a pinfeather standing straight up in the air, are worn way over the forehead.

Impending advances in the men's wear division of the woolen and worsted field will probably not materialize until the Spring 1936 lines are opened, which will be some time in July, according to opinions expressed here yesterday by local mill agents.

" Can the parties live without patronage?" was the timely topic of discussion at last week's council meeting in Washington of the National League of Women Voters. Machine politicians have been accustomed to answer, "No." Senator O'MAHONEY of Wyoming and Senator VANDENBURG of Michigan, however, one a Democrat and the other a Republican, told the earnest members of the league what they wanted to hear, that the answer should be "Yes."

The Prosperity Shop will be the beneficiary of a luncheon and fashion show to be held on May 28 in the Renaissance Room of the Ambassador. Guests have been requested to bring packages of useful articles suitable for resale later in the shop.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., May 11. -- Virginians looked back into their Colonial past today and in its memory gathered here to celebrate a revival of the "court season," as it was officially known, or "public times," as the people of the colony generally referred to the Spring assemblies in their capital city.
BALTIMORE, May 11. -- Once the mention of dust storms at sea was a standard joke of mariners, to be followed by gales of laughter. But the Naval Hydrographic Office here has received reports of such.

Ten City College fraternities have chosen sixty-three students as pledgees, according to an announcement yesterday by Gilbert Kleine, secretary of the Interfraternity Council. The greatest number of students were pledged by Theta Kappa Phi and Phi Gamma Kappa, each of which selected nine.

LOOKING over the men's clothing sources for Spring, one notes that prices as a whole are unchanged from those of a year ago. A few special foreign fabrics are a trifle more costly because of the recent acrobatics of the pound sterling, but the average ready-to-wear suits sell for about what they did in 1932.

WHILE a number of automotive measures passed at the recent regular session of the New York Legislature are still to be approved or disapproved by Governor Lehman, the sifting process has advanced far enough for review of the changes made in motor laws.

MADISON, N.J., May 11. -- Wally Manion and Dominick Morano of Branch Brook, winners of the qualifying medal, were upset today in the second round of the Braidburn invitation best-ball golf tournament by two clubmates, Joe De Stefano and Pat Mucci.

The implications of the railroad pension decision are very disquieting. More than the nullification of the Retirement Act is the portent of an adverse decision in the pending Schechter ease. Should the court rule that the regulation of hours and wages is beyond the purview of Federal control, the legal underpinning of the New Deal will be badly shattered.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 11. -- The Golden Gate admitted into the harbor this week the steamship Resolute, pride of the Hamburg-American Line, second round-the-world cruiser to visit the city within the last week.

Despite the Clark resolution, which provides for a ten-month extension of the NRA and limits codes to those industries engaged in interstate commerce, predictions were made last week in leading retail quarters that the retail code will be continued and will apply to retailers regardless of whether they might be classed as doing an interstate business or not.
CALLANDER, Ont., May 11. -- A deluge of Mother's Day cards and greetings has descended upon the Dionne farmhouse in honor of the world's only mother of quintuplets.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP). -- Senator Steiwer, Republican, of Oregon said today that the administration had refrained from making public unfavorable portions of a recent report of its Business Advisory Council on the New Deal program and had given out only parts considered favorable.

CHICAGO, May 11 (AP). -- The White Sox, checked for two days by Boston, went on the warpath again today, and behind a two-hit pitching job by John Whitehead, who racked up his fifth straight victory of the season, pounded three Red Sox hurlers for a 13-to-3 triumph.
It was demonstrated at Ebbets Field yesterday that the batting in of runs is not a lost art with the Dodgers, as both Casey Stengel and the fans have feared for the past week.

These lines are inspired by your sympathetic criticism of "Les Miserables," which is now on view in New York. The producers have once more departed from authenticity and ended the story of Jean Valjean contrary to Victor Hugo. Other episodes have also been mutilated.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 11. -- Three individual champions were toppled and a meet record smashed today as the powerful Rutgers squad won the Middle Atlantic Collegiate A.A. track and field title for the third straight year.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- The question of Japanese imports has become one of the administration's most troublesome problems. Although many experts feel that the high tide of Japanese importation into this country has passed, the effects of the remarkable increase of the past few months are just making themselves felt politically.

PARIS, May 11. -- Municipal elections were held last Sunday all over France with inconclusive results in half of the 800 major constituencies. In consequence, second ballots will be held tomorrow in all districts where no party polled a clear majority.

Summer day-camps for girls 8 to 16 years old will be opened July 8 in three public parks in Manhattan and will continue until Aug. 30, according to an announcement yesterday by Mrs. Richard E. Forrest, commissioner of the Manhattan Girl Scout Council, under whose direction the programs will be conducted.

Most of the published descriptions of King GEORGE'S "Silver Jubilee" have stressed first the continuing loyalty, throughout the twenty-five past years, of the British people to their sovereign, then the period's great changes in the world's history and in the British Empire.

Camp Greycourt, the Department of Public Welfare's rehabilitation camp for homeless men in Orange County, celebrated its first anniversary yesterday with a field day and a visit from Mayor Frederick S. Mansfield of Boston, who is eager to establish a similar farm camp for Boston.

MILITARY and political information regarding affairs in France and England was sent to the Colonies in the early days of the American Revolution by means of letters written in invisible ink, according to a letter recently obtained by the New York Public Library from David Wagstaff of Tuxedo.

Arrangements have been completed for three obedience tests in connection with all-breed dog shows during the Summer season. The first of these will be held at the exhibition of the North Westchester Kennel Club at Mount Kisco, N.Y., on June 8. On Aug. 17 another test will be held at the Lenox Kennel Club show at Lenox, Mass. Somerset Hills Kennel Club will hold the third event on Sept. 21 at Far Hills, N.J.

GENEVA, May 11. -- A prediction that Italy's Ethiopian policy will almost fatally lead her within this year to withdraw from the League of Nations was made in private conversations today by an official who is among the best informed, most impartial and most prudent in the League.

Students of French at Hunter College and their instructors have prepared for production two three-act plays, which will be presented by Le Cercle Francais next Saturday, at 2:30 P.M. and 8:30 P.M. The plays are "Les Caprices de Marianne," a tragi-comedy by Alfred de Musset, and "L'Amour Medicin," a comedy by Moliere.
WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Plans for the establishment here of a National Crime Institute and a central radio station for broadcasting police news are rapidly nearing completion.

THE Summer flower show is about to begin, and so far as we can see there will be no special favorites this season; every entrant will receive attention. All sorts of blossoms have burst into print, from gaudy field flowers to modest violets. Big blossoms and little ones have their places.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 11. -- Social, not academic, aspects of college life are too exhausting, it was indicated by Dr. Jane N. Baldwin of Vassar College at the student-parent conference on educational purpose ending here today.

RADIO has become so closely allied with entertainment, information and education, that whenever educators go into meeting the behavior of the microphone and those behind it are usually a main topic of conversation.

WITH the publication of "The Unknown Quantity," a simple character study amid the current flood of novels aspiring to vast social significance, Hermann Broch confirms the impression of his first book, "The Sleepwalkers," that this Austrian is one of Central Europe's most sensitive and most profound writers.

PARIS. COMPARISONS are no doubt always odious, but the temptation to make them is irresistible. Paris has had the opportunity, this past month, of seeing two films whose aim and atmosphere are curiously alike in their general outlines: "Lives of a Bengal Lancer," and "Itto."
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 11. -- The Navy finished strongly to win from Georgetown today by 5 to 3, one of the few local victories in a series that has lasted over half a century.

A distribution of 7,517,548 Bibles, Testaments and parts of the Bible in 1934, in 148 languages and dialects, and in more than forty countries, was reported last week at the 119th annual dinner of the American Bible Society at the George Washington Hotel, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue.
DES MOINES, Iowa, May 11 (AP). -- By car, bus and train groups of Midwestern and Southwestern farmers moved today toward Washington to urge Congress to continue and strengthen the Crop Control Law.

DELAYS at takeoff cost a lot of money, the airlines find. Tardy passengers sometimes telephone in and ask that a plane be held for a few moments. A study of the cost of this procedure on its lines has been made by Eddie Allen, chief engineer of Eastern Air.

WIDER opportunity for self-support and industrial craftsmanship among the blind has been developed by a philanthropic undertaking at 1,554 Third Avenue. There the Community Craft Weavers, Inc., with sightless persons manning the looms, are turning out hand-woven fabrics that are admitted to be equal in quality and beauty to any tweed weaves in the world.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 11 (AP). -- The Syracuse Chiefs closed their three-game series with the Rochester Red Wings today by winning 14 to 8. The victory gave the visitors the edge, two games to one.

CEDARHURST, L.I., May 11. -- Setting the pace all the way, Mrs. Frank M. Gould's Daniel Soot captured the sixth running of the Cedarhurst Grand National over the three-mile brush course at the Rockaway Hunting Club today.

WHETHER on the first trip or on the twentieth, Americans are constantly searching for the real flavor of England. Some find it in the roast beef at Simpson's, some in the pageantry of London, some in cathedrals and some in gardens.

PROTECTION for one of the outstanding historical ruins in the United States, Chaco Canyon National Monument, N.M., has been assured by the recent PWA allotment of $30,000 to build fifty miles of strong wire fence to keep cattle and sheep from the area
WEST POINT, N.Y., May 11. -- Williams defeated Army at baseball today, 5 to 2.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 11. -- Harvard held second place in the Eastern Intercollegiate League today by crushing the University of Pennsylvania nine, 17 to 6.

Declaring that Mother's Day will have added significance when maternity deaths are decreased, the advisory obstetric council to the Commissioner of Health made public yesterday four subcommittee reports through Commissioner John L. Rice. The reports were the first by the council since its appointment last Fall.

RENO, Nev., May 11. -- Franklyn Hutton, father of Princess Barbara Hutton Mdivani, tonight virtually confirmed that she would be married to the Danish Count Kurt von Haugwitz-Reventlow as soon as she obtained her divorce from Prince Alexis Mdivani, on Monday or Tuesday.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 11. -- Brown University's social season reached its climax last night with the annual Junior Promenade in the ballroom of the Providence Biltmore Hotel. Among the 250 couples attending were guests from cities and colleges throughout the East.

WARSAW, May 11. -- The damage done to the Franco-Polish alliance by the Polish-German non-aggression declaration of January, 1934, and more recently by the Franco-Russian mutual assistance pact seems to have been repaired today by the common effort of Pierre Laval, the French Foreign Minister, and Colonel Joseph Beck, Foreign Minister of Poland, in the course of two conversations lasting for more than four hours.

DENVER. -- Although the relief load is reported as generally slightly lower now than it was several months ago, there seems to be increasing fear in the Mountain States that the system will have grave political consequences.

The annual report of Bellevue Hospital, submitted yesterday to Mayor La Guardia by Hospital Commissioner S.S. Goldwater, lists substantial improvements made during the year in the city's largest hospital, but at the same time stresses many unfilled needs.

Regarded as the opening gun in a campaign to end the fixing of prices paid by manufacturers for their raw materials, a movement to collect some $25,000 will start tomorrow in the waste paper trade for financing an anti-trust law suit against Eastern paperboard mills.

SANDWICH, England, May 11. -- W. Lawson Little, the American holder of the British amateur golf championship, made his first competitive appearance in England this season when he took part in the thirty-six-hole medal competition for the St. George's Challenge Cup on the Royal St. George's course today.
As a practical pacifist, I feel thankful that Washington has given the answer of silence to the pleas against the manoeuvres of the United States Navy in the Pacific.

BOSTON, May 10. BOSTON, or that part of it which still goes to the theatre, has been divided into two camps by the Theatre Guild's revue, "Parade." The difference in opinion was amusingly apparent at the first performance in the Colonial Monday evening, when the galleries and standees were enthusiastic in approval of the satirical sketches, and the lower part of the house took it gamely but quietly.
WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The State Department's withdrawal of courtesies as citizens from Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Switz, confessed members of an international spy ring, became known here today.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS -- The Summer program of the Greenbrier Skeet and Trap Club will open during the coming week under the direction of Carl Bradsher, former manager of the Palm Springs Trap and Skeet Club, Palm Springs, Calif.
PATRIOTS all, the London managers are hurrying to the support of the King's Jubilee. The result, says the wireless, is a crowded week ahead, in substance as follows:
ST. LOUIS, May 11 (AP). -- Jack Knott, who usually appears in a relief role, made his second start of the season today and pitched the Browns to a 4-to-1 victory over the Athletics.

MOSCOW, May 11. -- Emphasis in Soviet Russia's struggle to prepare herself against the threat of war has now been definitely shifted from the dramatically swift building of airplanes, tanks, guns and fortresses to a more prosaic but not less vital phase -- the reorganization and upbuilding of the transportation system.

BERLIN, May 11. -- Orders were issued by the chief of police today that before any new building could be erected or old one altered the owner must consult the Air Protection League on the possibility of constructing a bomb and gas proof cellar.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., May 11. -- With the return of Spring, step-sings are once more held at Smith College on Tuesday and Friday evenings. On these nights the four classes gather in front of Students' Building, the traditional scene of step-sings, and form in a hollow square, one class on each side.

AT the time of his death Henry Kitchell Webster had begun this novel and had written enough of it to establish the principal characters and to indicate the nature of the problem confronting some of them, and a very pretty problem it is.

By adhering to its basic principle of stressing volume of business, the automobile industry has restored its output this year to pre-depression levels, according to leaders of the industry. The aim of the automobile companies, in giving competition free play, has been to keep the unit of profit down, and to increase their profits by expanding the total volume, rather than by making a larger profit on each car sold.

THIS year, if the contract between the Agricultural Adjustment Administration and the beet-growers is enforced, there will be no children less them 14 years of age working in the beet fields of this country. No longer will youngsters of 6 rise at dawn to take their place between rows of growing roots, hoeing, weeding, topping and thinning, and return to their shacks only when the last glimmer of daylight passes.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, May 11. -- Ethiopia called upon Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy today to show his hand in the border quarrel between the two countries.

DETROIT, May 11 (AP). -- Jo Jo White's steal of home in the ninth for the tying run only delayed defeat for the Tigers, as the Senators came through in the twelfth inning today to win, 10 to 7. Russell, who succeeded Burke on the mound with two on base and none out in the ninth, received credit for the victory.
A home-run by Shortstop Zeale in the twelfth inning enabled the Pratt Institute baseball team to turn back the Stevens Institute nine on the former's diamond in Brooklyn yesterday, 9 to 8.

THE contrast between Mr. Pritchett's "Elopement Into Exile," published here in 1932, and his latest novel is by no means to be accounted for by the change of locality, although the substitution of the grayness of industrial England for the rich coloring of Spain is, necessarily, the first obvious difference that leaps to the eye.
ALBANY, May 11. -- The training ship Empire State of the State Merchant Marine Academy will leave its New York base June 4 for a European trip.

A FEARLESS mind and a slashing pen characterize this endeavor to set forth the conviction that the world of today demands -- or, at least ought to demand -- a new viewpoint from which to appraise them moral values which will shape its course and the ethical quality of some of the ideas, gods and creeds that have dominated mankind for centuries.

An effort to get at the roots of pupil maladjustment, retardation, truancy and delinquency and to capitalize the best thinking of the community in a new attack on these problems has been outlined by school officials.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 11. -- Scoring in every period, the Yale polo team overcame Princeton, 9 to 3, on Devereux Memorial Field today.

Charges of a "general practice" of discrimination against Negroes by officials of the city's relief agencies were made yesterday by witnesses at a hearing of a subcommittee on relief of the Mayor's commission on conditions in Harlem.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Approval of a code of fair competition for the Northwest and Alaska fish and shellfish preparing and wholesale industry, to become effective May 20, was announced today by the National Industrial Recovery Board. It was explained that the industry is a branch of the fishery industry.

Frank N. Belgrano Jr., national commander of the American Legion, left the ranks of those fighting for the bonus in Washington and came to New York yesterday long enough to declare at a dinner in his honor that the battle over the payment of adjusted compensation had obscured the essential significance of the Legion in the eyes of a great many Americans.

AN army of wander-footed people who must do their traveling by armchair have reason to be grateful to Carveth Wells for the many volumes of lighthearted and picturesque travel books he has written for their information and entertainment.

An action to determine "the marital status" of Mae West, motion picture celebrity, and Frank Wallace, resident of this city, was begun yesterday in the Supreme Court here, when Wallace applied for a declaratory judgment.

Mother's Day as it flourishes among the North Americans, says the good Professor Wotan von Dunkel, illustrates the bankruptcy of the democratic idea. Professor von Dunkel, it will be recalled, holds the chair of Eccentric Ethnology at Berlin and is the author of "The Natural History of the North Americans From Pocahontas to Father COUGHLIN."
More than 4,000 children attended a May party given by Deputy Attorney General Charles A. Schneider, executive member of the Wigwam Democratic Club, in Tompkins Square Park yesterday afternoon.

The art treasures and furnishings of Ophir Hall at Purchase, New York, residence of the late Mrs. Whitelaw Reid, ranging from Gobelin tapestries to garden furniture, will be offered at auction this week, under the direction of the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., May 11 (AP). -- Judge W.F. Harding today set aside the $125,000 verdict returned for F. Brandon Smith Jr., in his alienation of affections suit against his former wife's father, Joseph F. Cannon, textile man of Concord, and ordered a new trial.

LOS ANGELES, May 11. -- Leaders in Upton Sinclair's Epic (End Poverty in California) movement assert despite the defeat in Tuesday's municipal and school district election that they will continue to go ahead.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 11. -- Republican State leaders mapped plans at a conference here today for a high-pressure campaign starting at once to recapture the Assembly this Fall.

ON the field where a hundred years ago Philander Chase cut the trees for the founding of Kenyon College and pastured the cows that gave the college its first funds, Robert Lawless, Kenyon senior, recently landed an airplane as the first student of the new Wilbur L. Cummings School of Aeronautics of the college to complete a long-distance, cross-country solo flight.

GOVERNORS of American States seldom become known outside of their own bailiwicks. Ask any average citizen for the names of a few and he might mention offhand only two or three. They would be the Executive of his own State; Huey Long, the Louisiana Kingfish, now an ex-Governor, and Eugene Talmadge of Georgia.

Henry Smurthwaite assumed his duties last week as director of Furness, Withy Co., Ltd., in the United States and Canada. He succeeds H.C. Blackiston, who has retired after being with the company for forty-five years. Mr. Smurthwaite will be in charge of the shipping interests of the Furness group, as well as its hotel and terminal properties in Bermuda.

In aid of Jewish artisans in Poland, a joint recital was given by Mila Wellerson, 'cellist, and Thalia Sabanieeva, soprano, in the Town Hall last night under the auspices of Women's American Ort, an organization that maintains schools and agricultural training facilities in Europe.

Fifty years ago this week the movement for the conservation of the forests of this State took form in the passage of a law creating the Forest Commission, now the State Conservation Department. It is to this law that we owe that ringing declaration, since incorporated in the Constitution, that "the lands now or hereafter constitut- "ing the forest preserve shall be forever "kept as wild forest lands."

PAPPY: Al Jolson, singer of mammy songs and star of stage, screen and radio, and his wife, Ruby Keeler, screen actress, met in Chicago Tuesday and adopted an ophan boy seven weeks old. A few hours later the mother was on her way back to Hollywood and the father was headed for New York to fill an engagement.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 10. -- Fair weather after additional rains caused business to spurt again this week in the Northwest. The most encouraging note was the report from farm-machinery factories that they were unable to fill their orders for tractors and implements.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP). -- Leading soft coal producers from nine States today joined in a new appeal for special Federal regulatory legislation to avert "ultimate bankruptcy" of their industry.

BERLIN, May 10. -- In about three weeks, after having strengthened himself with a vacation, Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Germany's economic dictator, is scheduled to announce her new plan for "export promotion,'' which is to mobilize her entire industry and envisages export subsidies on a scale hitherto unprecedented.

GOSPORT, England, May 11. -- Gerard B. Lambert's America's Cup sloop Yankee, after a very good Atlantic crossing, arrived in English waters today. She expected to reach Gosport tonight but met head winds coming up the Channel which delayed her arrival so she will not come in until tomorrow.

TO raise the level of radio programs educators now realize they must do two things: They must learn the tricks of the broadcaster's trade and they must organize listener clubs for the better offerings. So in effect professors and parents from various parts of the country agreed at the joint parley of the Institute for Education by Radio and the National Advisory Council on Radio in Education held at Columbus, Ohio, last week.

The American Society for Psychical Research of this city has come out in support of the view of its rival, the Boston Society for Psychic Research, that "ectoplasmic fingerprints" purporting to be those of Walter, dead brother of the Boston medium, Margery, were really thumb prints of a Back Bay dentist named Dr. Kerwin.

TEN thousand miles of travel, with performances in sixty cities, is the record of Fortune Gallo's San Carlo Opera Company, which last night closed its tour of eight and a half months and completed its twenty-fifth season.

Home runs on successive pitched balls in the second featured the victory of the Wagner nine, 17 to 11, over St. Francis College of Brooklyn yesterday at Wagner Field, Grymes Hill, S.I. Joe O'Reilly got his four-bagger with the bases loaded and was followed with another, almost to the same spot in centre field, by Walton Kibat.

OKLAHOMA City, May 11(AP). -- A civil suit asking $35,840 damages from seven purveyors of chain letters was filed here late today as the "chainomania" reached its breaking point and disappointed investors sought to "get even with somebody."

Holders of junior railroad bonds are playing an important part in the agitation for government ownership of railroads, according to assertions made last week by Sam Rayburn, chairman of the House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce before the Associated Traffic Clubs of America at Virginia Beach, Va.

FAY WRAY, whose eyes are blue, whose hair is brown and whose husband is John Monk Saunders, returned last week from a six months' working holiday in England where she appeared in two Gaumont-British films, "Alias Bulldog Drummond," with Jack Hulbert, and "The Clairvoyant," with Claude Rains.

A single by Ed Skeuse with none out in the ninth inning deprived Pete Blumette of no-hit distinction yesterday, but the big left-hander's brilliant hurling enabled the Manhattan baseball team to overwhelm Seton Hall, 11 to 2, before a crowd of 1,000 at Manhattan Field.

PHILADELPHIA, May 11. -- From the United States Mint here pennies, nickels, dimes, quarters and half dollars have been pouring out into circulation at the fastest seasonal rate since the black days of 1929.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Two thousand farmers will gather here Tuesday to express their approval of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration and the "sound farm policy now being pursued," according to Clifford H. Day, leader of the movement, who reached the capital today.

COLLECTORS generally agree that antique furnishings are best viewed in settings similar to those for which they were created. Simple Colonial pieces are, of course, at home in the old houses of that type which survive, especially along our Eastern coast, but it is often more difficult to study in appropriate architectural surroundings the finer British and French antiques.

PRESUMABLY the local art season approaches its wind-up, so far as major activity is concerned -- though this item of finis has become, like the weather, entirely unpredictable. At any rate, the season, lively and interesting from the start, reserved for May one of its most congested weeks.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, May 11 (AP). -- The Little Entente and Greece, acknowledging that Bulgaria and Hungary already were rearming clandestinely and that they were powerless to stop it, decided today to try to bring them within a new non-aggression pact to safeguard peace in Southeastern Europe.
CHICAGO, May 11. -- Mme. Ernestine Schumann-Heink sent this Mother's Day message to the nation today:

BRUSSELS, May 11. -- For the first three days next week Belgian State securities will not be quoted on the Bourse here during the operation for conversion of rentes, it was announced today by Premier Van Zeeland. The conversion will affect various types of State, city and communal loans involving a total of 24,000,000,000 francs.
WORCESTER, Mass., May 11. -- Holy Cross staged a rally with one out in the ninth today, tallying three times to defeat Dartmouth, 6 to 5.
OUT of the general reports received from the midseason Paris openings a few points loom.

Confused by the different interpretations in all parts of the country of Section 77b, the "reorganization" provision of the National Bankruptcy Act, leading credit executives are planning an organized movement to seek a revision of the law in order to bring about more uniform procedure and regulation by the courts.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 11. -- Nearly 100 fragile miniature ships of the sea, none longer than sixteen feet and one actually only eight feet from stem to stern, will get under way beginning at 7 o'clock tomorrow morning on a day that probably will have showers and a west wind for the longest outboard race in America and by far the most punishing to drivers.

LONDON, May 11. -- The Stock Exchange was closed today. Silver rose further to 33 1/4d an ounce for spot and 33 7/16d for forward delivery on Eastern buying. Gold was lower at 143s 4d an ounce. About 170,000 of the metal was sold.

SEVERAL strikingly contrasted types of work by the Spanish artist Eduardo Benito make up a lively exhibition at the Wildenstein Galleries. There are Paris vistas, seemingly somewhat thin, in light fresh palette, with the buoyancy of Spring in them; there are vigorously brushed, deep-toned portraits, rich in color, of Spanish types; there are flower paintings, with a goodly share of bold palette knife work, dashingly decorative; and there are crayon half-figure studies, smart and vivacious.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Sales in department stores increased from March to April by considerably less than the estimated seasonal amount, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. The increase over April, 1934, was 12 per cent. The report was based on 513 stores in 238 leading cities.

TO the Virgin Islands, where royal palms stand sentinel above gleaming beaches and blue sea and tangled lianas weave across the forgotten ruins of old estates, a Senate committee is journeying this month to investigate the administration of Governor Paul Martin Pearson.

CHICAGO, May 11. -- With "hunger marchers" in Springfield the Illinois General Assembly adjourned last Thursday without action to provide relief money. The emergency sales tax bills, designed to raise the $3,000,000 monthly revenue needed to meet the demands of the FERA, had, on a new attempt of administration forces, fallen 13 votes short of the 102 required for passage.

FLORENCE, Italy, May 11. -- A two-hour conversation today between Premier Benito Mussolini and Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg of Austria ended with the issuance of the usual stereotyped communique to the effect that the two statesmen had met, discussed all the principal problems of mutual interest and found themselves in complete agreement.

Over this week-end President Roosevelt is feeling the force of the nation's strongest lobby. By the sheer weight of telegraphed words, the American Legion and the Veterans of Foreign Wars are trying to make him sign the Patman Bonus Bill. Telegraph company officials estimate that the mass lobbying by wire will run up a bill of $600,000 -- and the White House has indicated unmistakably that the $600,000 will be wasted.

A further advance in sterling and a further decline in the franc in the foreign exchange market yesterday marked the progress of doubts about the position of the currency of France. Sterling rose to $4.86 5/8, its old parity rate with the dollar, and the best price since Feb. 26, and closed at $4.86 1/4, up 3/4 cent.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- Battered by a number of lower court decisions, expecting momentarily a Supreme Court decision which may or may not confirm its powers, and harassed by a variety of legislative proposals for change and extension of the act by which it lives, the National Recovery Administration today moves in an atmosphere of uncertainty.

THIS is an ultra-romantic biography, whose heroes and heroines speak a language compounded of fairy-tale and American slang. The principal character of the drama, Elizabeth, Empress of Austria and Queen of Hungary, is a "super-woman" who is adept in "super-horsemanship."

BOSTON, May 11 (AP). -- The Cubs battered a Boston pitching quintet for 18 hits today to give Larry French, who failed to go the distance, his first victory of the season by the one-sided margin of 14 -7.

NEWTON, Mass., May 11. -- Fordham won the first game in the home-and-home series with Boston College today, the Ram nine registering a 10-to-7 triumph before 1,500 Fathers' Day spectators at Alumni Field.

PARIS. THIS is the season of short trips, when smart women satisfy their Spring wanderlust with week-ends in the country, or fortnights of touring, savoring the wines and regional dishes of picturesque provinces, and revisiting their favorite beauty spots, within "dashing distance" of Paris.

I read with a great deal of interest the article in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine by Clair Price about Sir James Barrie. In speaking of "Peter Pan" it is said: "Heaven knows where "Peter Pan" stems from. Certainly it has nothing to do with Auld Lichts."

AS New York City, always a Summer capital for sightseers, prepares for its annual influx of visitors, it is making intensive plans to reduce the onslaughts of one of its minor menaces -- the mosquito.
