Under the direction of the Mosquito Control Board of the Department of Health, which is hoping for substantial funds from the nation's $4,880,000,000 work relief appropriation, the work is already under way.

BERLIN, May 11. -- The Boerse was firm and fairly active today. Heavy industrials were quiet, Vereinigtestahl gaining 1/2 point, while potashes were firm in a limited market, Aschesleben gaining one point. Machines were irregular, with a tendency toward strength, Berlin Karlsruhe advancing one-half point.

The difference between actual prison conditions and the glorified treatment of criminals as portrayed in movies and detective stories was revealed to twenty-four boys from the lower East Side who for an hour yesterday morning assumed the role of real prisoners.

OMAHA, Neb., May 9. -- While Middle Western Republicans were laying plans to hear from the "grass roots" at their Springfield (Ill.) conference in June two movements were springing out of the "grass roots" in Nebraska, one of which at least has interesting possibilities.

Women in New York who have been active in behalf of the Robert E. Lee Memorial Foundation have arranged a showing of penthouse terraces and back-yard city gardens for Tuesday afternoon to raise funds for the restoration and upkeep of Stratford Hall, the historic home of the Lee family of Virginia in Westmoreland County.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., May 11. -- A contingent of sixty-five members of the Knickerbocker Greys, New York City boys' cadet corps, staged a parade and review at Hackley School here this morning as the guests of Dr. Walter B. Gage, headmaster.

Although the golf season started more than a week ago, the first important event of the year will be the sectional qualifying rounds for the United States open championship tomorrow. These will be held throughout the country in twenty-five districts, the local scene of action being the Baltusrol Golf Club at Short Hills, N.J.

The problem of meeting interest charges of about $1,270,000 on the $44,630,530 of 5 per cent bonds and the 1,244,174 of debenture stock of the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation on July 1 is being considered actively by the management and directors of the company in view of the failure of the company to earn these charges since 1930.

NEW LONDON, May 11. -- A two-day conference on Education for Public Affairs, designed to improve college procedure along these lines, will be held at Connecticut College Thursday and Friday. Participating in the conference will be representatives of fifteen women's colleges, members of the Connecticut College faculty and board of trustees, and a large group of men and women active in public affairs either professionally or as volunteers.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 11. -- The New Rochelle High School track team emerged the victor today over ten other schools in the first annual Westchester invitation interscholastic relay carnival at the White Plains High School stadium.

On Thursday the last shot was fired on the aldermanic front of the complex relief situation. A final report, if funds are granted, will sum up the four-week battle during which Lloyd P. Stryker, counsel for the municipal body's relief investigating committee, tried to blast New York's gigantic relief edifice into bits of boondoggles and slash it into ribbons of red tape.

CARDIFF, Wales, May 11 (AP). -- Wales gave homage to its Prince in celebrating the King's jubilee today after 500 women who marched over the mountains to protest armaments to the heir to the throne were turned back by police before they reached the city.

SUMMER-FLOWERING bulbs have only recently begun to receive a measure of the use their outstanding qualities merit. Among the reasons for this steadily increasing popularity is the fact that no other occupants of the Summer garden give quicker results with a maximum of certainty and a minimum of care.

DENVER, May 11 (AP). -- The "guaranteed" chain letter business blossomed into sizable profits for letter "factories" today as they served crowds of customers seeking to promote chains before the Federal Government mashes the game.

A special program of entertainment has been arranged to feature the gala dinner and supper dance to be given on Tuesday night in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Humane Society of New York. The event will mark the opening of the roof garden for the season.

New York University's two-year reign as the metropolitan intercollegiate track and field champion was halted on its own Ohio Field yesterday as the well-balanced Manhattan College squad scored in all fifteen events to dethrone the Violet.

SANTA FE, N.M., May 11. -- Dennis Chavez, long a political figure in this State, was appointed by Governor Clyde Tingley today to succeed to the Senate seat of Bronson Cutting, who was killed in an airplane crash Monday.

SWIFT, easy travel by ear through one of the most traffic-harassed sections in the world is promised to metropolitan motorists when the Triborough Bridge opens some time in the Summer or Fall of 1936.

While I was seeing "Black Pit" at the Civic Repertory Theatre, I felt, I knew, it was a good play by that nearly infallible test, that nothing sounded false, that my feelings were aroused strongly. The emotional reaction I felt was strong enough to carry over the two sizable intermissions, to last after the curtain was down, after all the greetings in the aisle on the way out, and the pulling away of irrelevant conversation.

AMID all the talk of the political future of Ireland, there is surprisingly little talk of the political future of Irishmen. The Free State is presumably engaged in designing and cutting republican garment in which to array itself. At present writing, the garment is still in the hands of the Free State's political tailors, and nobody quite knows what it is going to be like.

A conference of the Mayors and business representatives of all the larger seaport cities of the nation will be held here on June 10, 11 and 12 to discuss ways and means of reviving international trade, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday.
MEMPHIS, May 11 (AP). -- A blazing shotgun halted an eighty-mile-an-hour attempt by two bandits to escape today less than five minutes after they had made a spectacular robbery of a $4,000 payroll.

I read with great interest the story of the "trial" held by the Orange youth groups ha which "society" was found guilty of a number of things. Back of the apparently farcical nature of the proceedings was a very evident seriousness. I was rather saddened by the spectacle of well-meaning and ideal-loving youth parading in the guise of all-wisdom and, though possessing only small stock of knowledge and experience, passing judgment on the world.

In connection with the triennial general meeting here of the Society of the Cincinnati, the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, has placed on exhibition manuscripts, pamphlets, portraits and memorabilia dealing with the early history of the order.
LE MARS, Iowa, May 11. -- Four masked robbers armed with a machine gun held up the Le Mars Savings Bank today and escaped with about $5,000 in currency.

PHILADELPHIA, May 10. -- The Chamber of Commerce featured this week a pageant portraying business progress for 247 years, placing emphasis on the number of ancient enterprises which still are functioning profitably.

WORLD renown among scientists of medicine and sociology has been won by Magnus Hirschfeld, whose Institute of Sexology in Berlin has long been famous. He was also one of the founders of the Medical Society of Sociology and with August Forel and Havelock Ellis he founded the World League of Sex Reform, of which he is president.

THIS book might also have been called "The Revolt of Science," for it fairly bristles with the indignation of scientists that men do not pay more attention to their teachings and flames with warnings as to what will happen to them if they do not mend their ways.

CHORUSES, music clubs and national groups in Michigan and Detroit are to participate in a popular festival to be held in Detroit from May 24 to June 2. The event, which is expected to be the largest of its kind ever held in Michigan, is called the International Music Festival, and is to be held annually in the future.

CHICAGO, May 11. -- Wheat made a strong start and a weak finish today on the Board of Trade, general liquidation following an advance of around a cent a bushel made at the start when shorts covered as a result of the bullish construction placed on the government report on Winter wheat issued late yesterday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 11. -- Scoring in eleven of the fourteen events, Phillips Andover Academy swept to an easy victory in Class A of the fiftieth annual Harvard interscholastic track meet at the Harvard Stadium today with 565/14 points.

TROY, N.Y., May 11. -- New Utrecht High School of Brooklyn won the fourteenth annual Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute scholastic track meet today after capturing second place for the past two years. It was the first victory for the New Yorkers since 1931.

THIS year marks the golden jubilee of the School Savings Banks of New York City. The banks started with a single unit in the Spring of 1885, and a few pennies and nickels gathered by the boys and girls of a district school; today they have deposits of more than $20,000,000.

THE American railroads this week will start their campaign to "sell" the scenic attractions of the country to vacationists with a series of combination trips that extend from the Atlantic to the Pacific Coast and from Mexico to Canada.

LONDON. -- Since unemployment and old-age pensions are being established in the United States, partly at least under the influence of British experience, it is appropriate to examine the scope, the growth and the cost of these and other public social services in Great Britain, as revealed by recent Treasury reports and by the estimates for the current year embodied in the new budget.

When the question of whether the Department of Parks or the Borough President of Manhattan should supervise the further development of the West Side express highway comes before the Board of Estimate again on May 24, representatives of many civic associations will be present to take part in the discussion, it was learned yesterday.

Five thousand persons watched 500 diminutive vessels compete for prizes yesterday afternoon in the Conservatory Lake in Central Park at the eleventh annual model boat regatta, of which Bloomingdale's and the city Park Department were sponsors.

The recovery in prices on the Cotton Exchange to around the 12-cent level created a more two-sided market yesterday, so that strengthening influences were neutralized by Southern selling and week-end realizing, the list ending with losses of 1 to 5 points.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 11 (AP). -- With Dutch Schultz demanding possession of his big black ledger -- the keystone of the evidence the prosecution used against him in his first trial for alleged income tax evasion -- the line of battle was drawn today for the second trial, to open in Federal court Tuesday.

GENEVA, May 10. -- The League's regular routine brings the mandates problem in its general terms before the Council at the session next week for the first time since two important developments -- Japan's departure from the League and Hitler's talk with Sir John Simon and Anthony Eden of the British Cabinet.

DUBLIN, May 10. -- To people abroad the refusal of the Irish Free State government either to send a message of congratulation or participate in King George's jubilee celebrations may naturally be construed as implying strained or unfriendly relations with Britain.
Mothers all over the nation will receive today the honors incidental to Mother's Day.

The Spring festival of song and dance of the People's Chorus on Thursday will be preceded by many dinner parties. Members of the junior committee will meet at the home of the chairman, Mrs. Leonard J. Scully, 51 East Ninetieth Street, and from there will go to the dinners and thence to the Waldorf-Astoria for the festival, which will aid the maintenance fund of the organization.

MANILA, Sunday, May 12 (AP). -- More alarmist reports, more cutting of communication lines and further preparations against violence today marked the approach of the Commonwealth Constitution plebiscite Tuesday. Police, armed with rifles, guarded newspaper plants in Manila against rumored violence plots.

Because today is "Mother's Day," pastors of all faiths will preach sermons on "Mother," the music will he on the same theme and there will be banks of flowers built by Sunday school pupils in honor of mother. Some churches will include fathers in the celebration and make it an observance of Parents' Day.

NEW LONDON, Conn., May 11. -- Junior Promenade week-end at Connecticut College for Women reached its height with the formal promenade in Knowlton House tonight. The week-end festivities began with a dance open to all classes last night.

THE occasion which inspired the writing of this book was the celebration of the hundredth anniversary of Wheaton College, at Norton, Mass., which opened in 1835 as Wheaton Female Seminary. Although the volume is a part of that celebration, neither the college nor its history holds more than a duly proportionate share of the author's attention.
ALBANY, May 11. -- Governor Lehman signed today the FitzGerald bill appropriating $300,000 for a revolving fund to meet expenses of the Public Service Commission in handling rate cases.

HONOLULU, May 11. -- It was unofficially learned today that a mass attack on Hawaii by 450 planes was being planned on the tactical theory that an enemy had suddenly overpowered American defenders of Midway Island and was advancing from the west toward Honolulu and the important Pearl Harbor naval base with an enormous air fleet.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 11. -- Dangerous Lady, 4-year-old bay mare, owned by the Terre Haute Farm of Louis Kaiser of Bethel Conn., and ridden by Earl Testers, tonight won the championship sweepstakes for three-gaited saddle horses at the concluding session of the eleventh annual New Haven Horse Show.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Delegation of authority to the President to aid the administration of the laws through rules and regulations was severely condemned and warmly praised respectively by former Governor Ely of Massachusetts and John Dickinson, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, in addresses before the American Law Institute tonight.

FROM first to last, Washington directs the attention to the unfortunate circumstances that man cannot succeed in everything that he attempts. Think how often citizens of the United States try to tell a stranger why he must visit Washington. They always fail.

MISS ISH-KISHOR'S biography of the Emperor Hadrian is no literary bombshell. It will set no new style in the writing of private lives. In fact, it is pretty pedestrian, although Theodore Dreiser is moved to say of it: "It sets forth in detail, and with patience -- with beauty of words and beauty of understanding and sympathy -- a story that the whole world should know and treasure."

RICHMOND, Va., May 9. -- Although North Carolina voted in favor of the Eighteenth Amendment in 1933 by the tremendous majority of 185,000, there has been such a shift in sentiment that the drys barely were able to block a proposal for a referendum on a system of liquor control at the current session of the State Legislature.

STRANGE and remote places are coming within the field of the traveler as new air routes are established. Wake Island is an example. A dot on the chart of the Pacific, it has been known only to seamen, naturalists, collectors of bird feathers, fishermen; soon it is to be a way-station on the route of the Pan American Airways from San Francisco to Manila and China.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Sunday, May 12. -- After all-day conferences which concluded early this morning, tentative proposals for an early settlement of the strike in the Chevrolet Motor Company's plant here were placed before the union committee subject to approval by a mass meeting of the strikers.

NO one can fairly complain that the Pulitzer Prize has gone to an unworthy play. In both the playwriting and the acting "The Old Maid" is distinguished by fine workmanship. Out of Edith Wharton's novel of the same title Zoe Akins has written a nicely mannered period piece about life in New York a century ago.

OTTAWA, Ont., May 10. -- The eighty-one-odd pounds of almost perfectly matched femininity known to the world as the Dionne quintuplets will reach their first birthday anniversary on May 28 with a prosperous future "under government ownership" seemingly assured them.

ROME, May 11. -- The projected air pact between France and Italy was fully discussed by General Victor Denain, the French Air Minister, and General Giuseppe Valle, Italian Under-Secretary for Air, in a series of conferences today. Experts assisted the two generals.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 11. -- The Harvard Faculty of Arts and Sciences has voted that for students entering Harvard College after the present academic year the distribution requirements for the bachelor's degree shall consist of at least four courses chosen from any of the subjects not related to the field of concentration.

IN "Gay Family" Ethel Boileau showed herself mistress of a graceful, intimate style in telling the story of an interesting but not extraordinary English family. In "When Yellow Leaves" she veered off toward the melodramatic and sensational and was not nearly so successful.

IF to Mr. Gibbons's title is given an answer as categorical as its question seems to be, there can be only one, and that is a simple and explicit "No." For he saw only a very small section of America and that the part which, mainly, is least illustrative of the country as a whole.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., May 11. -- Americans, it seems to me, are attempting to combine simultaneously reform with recovery, and the result has been something of an economic jam.

STYLE has been called "the immortal thing in literature" and a classic has been defined as a book that "maintains itself by virtue of a happy coalescence of matter and style, an innate and exquisite sympathy between the thought that gives life and the form that consents to every grace and dignity."

George W. Sutton Jr., president of the American Power Boat Association, accepted last week a new trophy, the gift of Stanley W. Ferguson of Boston and Waban, Mass., sponsor of last season's intercollegiate outboard regatta at Worcester, Mass.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., May 11 (AP). -- Chase Mellen Jr., chairman of the New York County Republican Committee, tonight called upon President Roosevelt to abandon his "sophomore experimentation and Barnum and Bailey press agentry" and return to the 1932 Democratic platform upon which he was elected.

LAWRENCEVILLE SCHOOL, at Lawrenceville, N.J., celebrates on Friday and Saturday the 125th anniversary of its founding, in conjunction with its annual alumni festivities. Opened as a private school by the Rev. Isaac V. Brown in 1810, when the democratic movement was sweeping over American education and replacing the old aristocratic form of Latin grammar school with the academy, it has become one of the leading institutions for the primary and secondary training of boys.
