NOW things are beginning to pop in the garden. There is no season of the year when the grower so much needs to keep his wits about him and both eyes and fingers busy. A few warm days, after a long spell of moist, cool weather, will bring the need of immediate attention in so many different directions that it is difficult to tell which way to turn first.

LONDON, April 18. A WEEK in which there have been no first nights -- partly because the week includes Good Friday and partly because the rush of playgoing that will precede the King's Jubilee is yet to come -- provides me with an opportunity, which I have long desired, to discuss certain general subjects arising from the theatre that are ordinarily thrust aside by urgent theatrical routine.

ATLANTIC CITY -- Belmont Park is being reproduced in the municipal convention hall here in preparation for the fourth annual Atlantic City Horse Show opening on Wednesday and continuing through Saturday.

New York University's baseball team reached two City College pitchers for ten hits and took advantage of seven Lavender misplays in the field to score an 8-3 victory yesterday when the two local rivals met for the second time at Lewisohn Stadium.

The Patman Bonus Bill, if it were to become law, would not permanently increase the volume of money in circulation, but would greatly enlarge bank deposits and would lay the basis for a huge expansion of credit on top of the already heavy foundation, according to bankers and economists who discussed the measure last week.

ALEXANDRIA, La., May 11 (AP). -- Secretary Wallace today struck a blow for the New Deal agricultural policies in Senator Huey Long's home State of Louisiana and said the administration of his chief, President Roosevelt, had been "strengthened by sniping politicians."

PRINCETON, N.J., May 11. -- Following the custom begun in 1929 when the problems of the economic depression led many college students to study "practical things," the sophomores of Princeton University have, in the main chosen to do the greater part of their upper-class work in the field of social science, it was revealed today by a survey made here.

STONES OF RIMINI" is a remarkable -- we are almost tempted to say a unique -- book, as, indeed, in many ways it is. It is not just another foray on some phase of Italian art or culture. It is an extremely sensitive, clear-visioned interpretation of Mediterranean art forms and civilization, as distinct from other forms and cultures.

AUGUSTA, Ga. -- Augusta will turn back the pages of history 200 years and crowd the outstanding events of two centuries into five days of pageantry when the city holds its bicentennial celebration, beginning today.

THE prefabricated house so long expected and discussed has finally arrived. After the rather dispiriting examples at the Chicago Fair eighteen months ago, one was inclined to expect a longer delay in its working out, and even to temper one's expectations of what it would be when it did arrive.

The film version of Shakespeare's "A Midsummer Night's Dream," which has been completed recently under Max Reinhardt's direction at the Warner Brothers studios in Hollywood, will run for two hours and twenty minutes, of which one hour and twenty minutes are dedicated to the music, Professor Erich Wolfgang Korngold said in an interview here last week.

Columbia University made public yesterday a reprint of a discussion of "Where Does Academic Freedom Begin?" from the 1934 report of President Nicholas Murray Butler. The reprint was taken as the university's response to the memorandum of Clarence E. Lovejoy, secretary of the Alumni Federation, charging that radical activities on the campus were alienating alumni support.

Will Rogers made a suggestion yesterday that King George and Queen Mary come to the United States and "we maybe could make some arrangements with them satisfactory to them that we could get back with 'era." Mr. Rogers spoke over an NBC network in an international broadcast to England in honor of the King's jubilee.

ON April 14 the organizers of Theatre Alliance presented its plan to an invited audience at the Belasco Theatre. Several days later a statement was issued to the press summarizing the principles and the program of the newly formed organization.
Twenty-nine additional listed companies applied yesterday to the New York Stock Exchange for permanent registration under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. They were:

PHILADELPHIA, May 11. -- Charles E. Starr, investment broker and one of the administrators of the $17,000,000 estate of Mrs. Henrietta E. Garrett, will "at the proper time" claim the estate for himself, it was disclosed today. More than 5,000 alleged heirs of the Garrett family, living in this country and Europe, are claiming shares of the fortune.

The Junior Group of the American Woman's Association will present a performance of the musical comedy, "The Gingham Girl," tomorrow night at the clubhouse, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street, as the fourth annual entertainment for members and friends of the association.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The $100,000,000 rural electrification program, designed to open "a new era for American agriculture," was put into operation today when President Roosevelt signed an executive order establishing a Rural Electrification Administration and making $75,000 available for its immediate administrative needs.

DALLAS, May 9. -- Denouncement of a veritable orgy of waste, undergone so relentlessly that it became perhaps the most prodigal dissipation of a natural resource in the history of the world, has been written with the signature of Governor Allred to a legislative bill.

The city is prepared to modify its construction of the Sixth Avenue subway line to meet the conditions laid down by the Federal authorities in connection with the allocation of work project funds to municipalities, it was indicated yesterday.

Drastic action against drunken drivers was ordered yesterday by Mayor La Guardia as part of the city's campaign to reduce traffic accidents. The Mayor said the safety drive must be continued "indefinitely and without interruption."
Eight persons died yesterday as the result of automobile accidents in and near the city.

The trend of prices in the commodity futures markets was generally upward in quiet trading yesterday. Coffee, rubber, copper and rawhide futures gained moderately and December sugar sold at the highest level since July, 1928. In the cash market, lard, tin and rubber were higher, while all grains and cotton were lower.

QUESTIONS regarding the safety factor in flying and measures taken to make air travel safer naturally arise whenever a major accident occurs to cast a shadow over aviation. Conversely, a brilliant and successful flight lends confidence to those who travel the airways.

BUENOS AIRES, May 10. -- A suggestion by Secretary of State Cordell Hull this week put an end to the long-drawn-out Chaco peace imbroglio and started proceedings which, it is hoped, will terminate the three-year war between Bolivia and Paraguay by the end of this month.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- The greater part of the ground which had to be traversed in the march toward the balance of prices between products sold and products bought by farmers specified in the Agricultural Adjustment Act has been covered.

ONE might not expect to find charm of style in a book on modern scientific research. But charm is an outstanding characteristic of this volume, which is an interesting, useful and practically important addition to the slender stock of literature on research.

A MOST admirable spirit infuses the three lectures which comprise this book. The addresses were delivered by Mr. Dafoe, a Canadian journalist who is editor-in-chief of The Winnipeg Free Press and has been all his life a student of the relations between Canada and the United States, last year, under the Julius Beer Foundation, at Columbia University.

DEARBORN, Mich., May 10. -- Columbus, dreaming of a New World in the West, was a simple sailor of limited faith, compared with the exponents of the "chemurgic" movement who presented the articles of their faith this week to a gathering here of some 300 scientists, agriculturists and industrialists.

SYRACUSE, May 11. -- The administration banking bill was condemned as "putting our monetary affairs in the hands of politicians" by George C. Cutler, president of the State Trust Companies Association in an address before a meeting of Group IV of the New York State Bankers Association here tonight.

DESPITE a long career of facile novel writing, Ben Ames Williams seems to be remarkably uninformed about the ways of modern youth. When one contrasts this new book of his with the work of such newer arrivals as Katharine Brush, Nancy Hale or Virginia Faulkner, it is evident that his bright young people are sadly out of date.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- An amendment to Federal Housing Administration regulations to facilitate cooperation of building and loan associations in the home modernization program was announced today. Loans conforming in other respects to FHA regulations now will be insured for the first five years of their duration, even if granted for longer periods.

ROME, May 11. -- No effort is being spared by Italian diplomacy to reconcile the divergent views of the countries that will send delegates to Rome next month to discuss collective security for Central Europe.

TO the question "How can one have color in one's garden all Summer long and cut flowers for the house without robbing the garden of its bloom?' there is one answer: "Grow annuals." A garden without annuals has, necessarily, a drab and uninteresting period after the first glorious burst of Spring and early Summer flowering is past and before the late Summer flowers arrive.

PHILADELPHIA, May 11. -- The senior class at the University of Pennsylvania will bequeath its position on the campus to the juniors next Friday at the traditional Hey Dey exercises, symbolic of a moving up of all the classes. Combined with them will be the class day exercises of the seniors, presided over by William R. Robinson of Abington as committee chairman.

AT the close of one of the tamest musical seasons the city has known of late years, it is pertinent to inquire into the causes of this condition. Is the fault with the nature of the musical offerings, or with the public? Or shall we lay it all on "the depression," which has borne the blame for so many human failings?

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 11. -- Miss Phyllis Reed of Rahway, May Queen at the New Jersey College for Women, presided over her court of twelve attendants today for the college's annual pageant, a feature in the Parents' Day celebration.
ITHACA, N.Y., May 11. -- The top of a swinging steel boom on a steam crane owned by the Cornell University heating plant is "home sweet home" to one Mrs. Robin Redbreast.

TORONTO, May 11. -- Toronto and Newark broke even in a doubleheader today which closed the series and gave the Leafs two victories in the three games. However, they failed to dislodge the Bears from the league leadership.
PARIS, May 1 (By Mail). -- Paris bids fair to have a brisk social season, not in spite of the big jubilee doings in London but in part because of them.

Reviving a custom which was dropped in this city eight years ago, the New York Furniture Exchange will open a mid-season market for the showing of late Summer and early Fall merchandise tomorrow. The market, which will run for a week, is expected to attract more than 3,000 retailers to view new lines of merchandise offered by 525 manufacturers represented in the showing.

IT is upon occasions such as this that one is most likely to be caught unprepared; caught with a realization that history, like seaside sand, has a disastrous way of slipping out through one's fingers.

Stimulated by the success of its first meeting last Sunday, another is to be called by the new Hudson River Yachting Association which has returned to service after fifteen years of dormancy. It will take place this month, according to James A. Cruikshank, secretary.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, May 11 (AP). -- Former King George of Greece, confident of restoration, it was learned upon high authority tonight, has made overtures to former Queen Elizabeth, from whom he recently obtained a secret divorce, to return to the throne with him.

Publication in Paris of the first of twenty volumes of a general Jewish Encyclopedia, an enterprise never before attempted, will be marked at a dinner to be held here Friday in Beethoven Hall. The dinner will be under the auspices of the American committee cooperating in the publication, the Yiddish Pen Club, Y.L. Peretz Writers' Union and the editorial staffs of the daily Jewish newspapers in this city.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- The five-to-four decision of the Supreme Court of the United States holding unconstitutional the Railroad Retirement Act has materially intensified the feeling of uneasiness and uncertainty, even in administration circles, as to the probable attitude and decision of the high court on the question of the constitutionality of other measures, both those recently enacted and those now pending in Congress, which are more vital to the New Deal.

The use of light-weight equipment, which has received wide attention through its application to passenger service, has been extended by the Baltimore Ohio Railroad to freight equipment through the construction of thirteen freight cars of advanced design.

Many phases of aviation, from squadrons of military planes flying in formation to big transports of the modern air line schedules ranged alongside old-time "Jenny" planes, will mark Air Transport Day at Newark Airport Wednesday. The day has been set by Mayor Ellenstein in celebration of the nineteenth anniversary of the first commercial air mail flown by Lieutenant Torrey Webb of the army between Hadley Field, N.J., and Washington.

A MEMORIAL exhibition of work by R. Sloan Bredin, who died in 1933, was held in October of that year at the Grand Central Galleries. Now (current until May 20) a second memorial showing is in progress at the Ferargil.

Bonds called last week for redemption before their dates of maturity were more diversified than in recent weeks and included a greater number of foreign loans. Most of the larger redemptions continue to be scheduled for distant months.

RYE, N.Y., May 11. -- Three interclub boats, rushing the yachting season by a fortnight, afforded something of a comparison between the new rig and the old in a race conducted by the American Yacht Club today.

MATANUSKA VALLEY, Alaska, May 11. -- Weary, but well content, after their long journey by land and sea from Minnesota, the first of the Alaska colonists are settling down happily in their new and strange surroundings.

Refusing to be stampeded by threats of inflation, industrial purchasing agents are disregarding passage of bonus legislation in making commitments for both raw and finished materials, a canvass of leading purchasers disclosed yesterday.

Since the Red Widow is a pet name for the guillotine, one may reasonably expect in this story something extra special in the horror line. Nor is one disappointed, for although the scene is London of the present day, the story harks back to Paris in the days of the Terror.

DURING the last several years, the Air Corps materiel division at Wright Field has been active in the study of crankshaft torsional vibration in both in-line and radial engines. The ill effects of resonant vibrations are well known when they affect instrument readings, vibrate fuel lines and cause fatigue failures of engine mounts.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 11. -- The outdoor tennis season in the metropolitan area got under way today with the appearance of the professional players headed by William Tilden in a series of matches at the Montclair A.C.

In SHAKESPEARE'S "Timon of Athens" there was a finance steward named Flavius, who made as desperate an effort to prevent a budget deficit as did LEWIS DOUGLAS and with as little success. "At many times," said Flavius when blamed as if he had been remiss in acquainting his "loved lord" with the state of his budget, "I brought "in my accounts * * * prayed you to "hold your hands more close."

The teaching of conservation of nature in school gardens was seen as one of the most important functions of education and an outstanding achievement of the schools by speakers yesterday at the twenty-fifth annual luncheon of the School Garden Association of New York, in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

MOST of Elizabeth Jordan's recent books have been mystery stories. Her latest, "Daddy and I," is in a very different vein -- the first crack at authorship of a high school girl, June Drew, told in her own words. June's mother died when June was two days old, so June and her father .are very close friends, even though he is an old man of 38.

BALTIMORE, May 11. -- Coming through the stretch by himself, William Woodward's Omaha today won the historic Preakness Stakes, scoring the easiest victory in this famous test since Man o' War won in 1920. A cheering, surging throng of 45,000, the biggest ever to see a race at old Pimlico, yelled itself hoarse as Jockey Willie Saunders clucked to his mount on the far turn and put his opposition away.

Displaying all the qualities of a high-class colt, Ogden Phipps's White Cockade easily led home a field of six 2-year-olds to capture the $2,500 added Youthful Stakes at five furlongs before a crowd of 15,000 at Jamaica yesterday.

WESTFIELD, N.J., May 11. -- Pamela, attractive gray mare owned by Robert Nehrbas of Huntington, L.I., and shown by James Thompson, topped a strong field to carry off the $250 saddle horse championship stake as the two-day Westfield Horse Show was brought to a successful conclusion in the Westfield Armory tonight.

New Jersey's Inland Waterway, already a boon to small-boat skippers who want to cruise to Chesapeake Bay or even to Florida but who don't want to risk the outside run from Manasquan to Cape May, is to be improved still further this season.

RAWALPINDI, India, April 15. -- Although our expedition has been in the field only a month we have made a rich collection of vertebrate fossil remains from the late Tertiary formations of the Salt Range area.

Operating under the Minimum Wage Law enacted by the State of New York in 1933, the Wage Board of the Hotel and Restaurant Industries, consisting of representatives of employers, labor and the public, opened its sessions last week. Its purpose is to regulate and standardize the hours, wages and conditions of labor for the 60,000 women and minors employed in these industries.

MANILA. -- The possibility of the flight of capital from the Philippines under a commonwealth government or the proposed independent regime has been broached here. This is a sore subject for politicians and, although it has been much discussed behind closed doors, it has seldom received press comment.

VISITORS at Radio City studios never know who may be sitting next to them. Like the unseen audience, the studio guests represent a cross-section of American life. For example, in the studio last Tuesday night Mrs. Calvin Coolidge was present and not many seats away sat Mr. and Mrs. "Dizzy" Dean and other members of the Cardinals; in the front row, former Governor Joseph B. Ely of Massachusetts and his wife watched the show.

THE exhibition of African Negro art at the Musuem of Modern Art has had an attendance of 45,000 to date, according to announcement by the museum. The exhibition will close at the end of the present week.

Following a police investigation of reports that candidates for the civil service eligibility lists for the police and other city departments had been induced to pay from $500 to $700 for places on the lists, a man was arrested yesterday and held in $5,000 bail on a grand larceny charge.

IN various localities at certain periods of time some books have suddenly become rare, by virtue of no other reason than summary action on the part of the authorities. Books have been persecuted, proscribed, seized, impounded, burned, destroyed -- in a word, suppressed.

Those who enjoyed Carol Brink's promising first book, "Anything Can Happen on the River," will not be surprised to find that in "Caddie Woodlawn" she has written an even better story. There is again an abundance of lively incidents, while the characterization is deeper and the background filled in with a surer hand.

LIKE the world itself and everything on the face of it, the West changes. The "Old West" of the open range, of range wars, two-gun desperadoes, wholesale cattle rustling, has gone for good -- except in the numerous stories that continue to be written about it.
MONTREAL, May 11 (AP). -- Leo Dandurand's threat to take Les Canadiens out of Montreal turned out to be a threat and nothing more today.

Becoming alarmed at the trend of legislation in Washington, the oil industry will launch within a few days a nation-wide educational campaign with the purpose of defeating certain legislation now pending in Congress.

FIRST aid for parents in the important matter, often long mooted and sometimes disagreed over, of the baby's name is offered in this interesting volume, which, the publishers feel sure, is the first to deal authoritatively with the subject at a popular price.

The question of what is good and what is bad in radio seems to be agitating the minds of many professional busybodies these days. Our system of broadcasting -- admittedly the finest in the world -- is being subjected to a clinical analysis on the part of various groups and individuals who are happiest when they are shedding crocodile tears about the great American home.

I was correct in claiming that the tendency to take patents on invention is markedly declining, as your editorials have told people. William I. Wyman, whose letter of protest you published, is a higher official in the Patent Office, but does not seem to know that statistics must be taken straight or doctored scientifically, but not so as to twist them to one's thesis.

ALBANY, May 11. -- Governor Lehman vetoed today the two Holley Bills designed to make provision for naming of illegitimate children. His disapproval was based on what he regarded as technical defects in the measures.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 11. -- With delegates on hand from Canada, Mexico and Hawaii, as well as from 131 cities in this country, the fifteenth annual conference of the Association of the Junior Leagues of America, Inc., will open here Monday night.

FARGO, N.D., May 10. -- North Dakota's political future, now that William Langer's conviction has been reversed by the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals, may depend more on what will happen in Washington than on anything that may happen in the State.

FLORIDA now has what Professor Boyd H. Bode of Ohio State University has termed "the most wonderful school building of its type." It is the P.K. Yonge Laboratory School, recently dedicated by the University of Florida for its Department of Education.

Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. and Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan, wartime commander of the Twenty-seventh Division, joined last night, as some 150 veterans cheered, in a denunciation of Communists in this country. They addressed the semi-annual dinner of the Fourth Division Association in the Hotel Pennsylvania, at which Mr. Fish was elected its president.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The educational program being carried on by the Relief Administration was defended today by Harry L. Hopkins, administrator, in a statement taking sharp exception to charges by the Federal Grand Jury Association of New York City that relief money was being used to teach overthrow of the government.

Terminating an unprecedentedly keen contest for official positions, members of the New York Stock Exchange will go to the polls tomorrow to elect a new president, treasurer, two trustees of the gratuity fund, eleven regular governors and eight governing members, the last-named being a new class of officers created at the suggestion of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

BERLIN, May 11 (AP). -- Germany's observance of Mother's Day tomorrow gives the Nazi "educators" ample opportunity to give their view about women's place in the Third Reich -- in the home as the mother of a large and healthy family.

RICHMOND, Va., May 11. -- Chief Justice John Marshall's decisions owed much to the watchful vigilance of Thomas Jefferson and James Madison, said James M. Beck of Philadelphia, former solicitor general, at exercises here today commemorating the 100th anniversary of Marshall's death.

A resolution urging Mayor La Guardia to do all in his power to provide an increased allowance for unattached women on home relief was adopted yesterday by the Women's Democratic Club at its luncheon at the Commodore Hotel. The text of the resolution was telegraphed to the Mayor and a motion was adopted asking members to write to him to the same effect.

THE perennials of Mr. Cohen's Birmingham Negro quarter -- Epic Peters, Florian Slappey, Jasper De Void, Spasm Johnson and the rest of the weirdly named lot -- augmented by sundry newcomers, thrive again in these ten genially humorous short stories.

WHERE once the oaths of swashbuckling adventurers and the clash of broadswords resounded beneath gnarled oaks there are picnic parties, and motor cars from many States now roll along nine miles of curving white beach that, until a month or so ago, knew only the patter of bare feet and the occasional grating keel of a fishing lugger.

The Bergen Beach Gun (Club held its fortieth anniversary shoot over its traps on the shores of Jamaica Bay yesterday. The major trophy was taken by C.G. Allers, who won the High-Over-All Cup by breaking 95 out of 100 targets. G.C. Schwalb, who triumphed last year, finished second with a card of 94.

As Huey Long, Father Coughlin and William Randolph Hearst danced hand-in-hand around the stage of the Men's Faculty Club at Columbia University last night in the eighth annual "Guidance Follies," they were welcomed by a chorus of lusty voices singing:

The murder which is at the bottom of all the devilment in this book has been done before the story opens. John Haswell has been shot down in cold blood on a New York street, and the police are inclined to think that he got in the way at a bullet intended for some one else.
The folowing table shows some of the important dividend meetings scheduled for this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange and the last distributions ordered by the directors:

IT is hard to believe that there is still a country whose name is unknown to most of the world. But there is -- a country that probably not more than five Americans had ever heard of before 1934. Until 1930 it had been visited by only the most intrepid of hunters and mountain climbers.

HUNTSVILLE, Texas, May 11 (AP). -- One of three fugitives from the Eastham State prison farm was captured today and the others were closely pursued by a posse and bloodhounds in the Trinity River bottoms. The three escaped last night after a guard and a convict were killed in a gunfight.

ANY one who enjoys collecting queer specimens of humanity, in real life or in books, should consider Mr. Norris a find. William Bradshaw, who tells the story of a two-year acquaintance with Arthur Norris, found the gentleman irresistibly entertaining.
SPRING travel fever -- the urge to go somewhere -- a malady that attacks almost every one at this season, may be brought be a crisis by the stunning new luggage being shown.

Again we are invited to compare the respective efficiency of the House of Representatives and the Senate as lawmaking machines. For speed in the dispatch of business the House seems superior. This is partly because it has rules which permit the closing of debate.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., May 11. -- Probate Judge Bacon Wakeman today denied a petition brought by Mrs. Flora Martin Warner, widow of Dever H. Warner, utilities leader and corset manufacturer, seeking a $3,000 monthly allowance from her husband's estate and an order on executors of the estate to pay her $20,000 a year.

A GERMAN psychologist once said that when the heart says one thing and the mind another, the heart usually wins the argument. This, in brief, is the theme of Dr. Jastrow's book. Throughout the whole course of history, he says, men have been willing to reject cold facts in favor of some glamourous theory which made the world seem a more wonderful and satisfying place.
In THE TIMES last Sunday it was recorded that Harry F. Hopkins "Predicts a New Order."
PITTSBURGH, May 11. -- Dedication services for the new East Liberty Presbyterian Church will be held tomorrow, which happens also to be Mother's Day.

NOT so long ago Drs. W. Baade and F. Zwicky of the California Institute of Technology suggested that the mysterious cosmic rays may well have their origin in novae -- stars which explode, become tremendously active for a few weeks or months and then subside again into humdrum orbs.

SINCE Professor Harper discovered Annette, Wordsworth's French mistress, the mother of the poet's illegitimate daughter, we have had innumerable biographies and revaluations of Wordsworth's poetry. "The Prelude" and "The Excursion," his two long autobiographical poems, have been re-examined and re-edited.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 11. -- Princeton's rugby team had little difficulty in trouncing the Pilgrim Club fifteen, 51 -- 0, on University Field today. The score was one of the highest ever totaled in this country.
CHICAGO, May 10. -- Conflict of authority, with musical-comedy possibilities, is entertaining residents of Cicero and Villa Park.

The personnel of the general committee for the survey of the hospital situation in the New York metropolitan area under the auspices of the United Hospital Fund was announced yesterday by Dr. George E. Vincent, chairman of the survey, and David McAlpin Pyle, vice chairman and president of the fund.

LONDON. THERE is a town in England where, punctually at 7 o'clock on a May morning every year the doors of the houses are thrown open. And thereafter, until 6 in the evening, the people of the town, Helston, in Cornwall, high and low alike, dance through every house in the place and through the streets, all to a single tune, played by the village band.

PUERTO RICO'S drive for Statehood calls attention to a colorful little island whose leaders are busy telling the people by radio how to obtain admission to the Union. Its geographical separation from the United States has no bearing on the question, they say, for ocean and air travel and wireless have annihilated this barrier, and racial difference should mean little to a nation that has assimilated millions of immigrants.
ALBANY, May 11. -- Governor Lehman today signed the FitzGerald bill extending until September, 1938, the time in which the New York City subway can operate without being self-sustaining.

Thirty of the 130 gifted children who are the special concern of the New York University Clinic for the Social Adjustment of Gifted Children were guests at a party given at 30 Washington Square East yesterday by Professor H.W. Zorbaugh, director of the clinic.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- President Roosevelt was believed to have been urged today by Congressional leaders accompanying him on a fishing trip into near-by Maryland to use the strongest language possible in a veto of the Patman "Greenback" Bonus Bill, so that a veto might be sustained in the Senate by a decisive vote.

WHEN the Senate of New Jersey recently rejected the Kuser bill to declare the goldfinch the official bird of that State, it kept New Jersey in a small group -- with Iowa, Connecticut, Indiana, Tennessee and Massachusetts.

It now seems fairly certain that the Federal Government is going to undertake the regulation of the interstate operations of motor trucks and buses that carry freight and passengers "for hire." The President in his radio address of April 27 asked for the legislation at this session of Congress.

One of the largest salvaging projects to be undertaken by a group of private citizens acting, however, with the moral support of the United States Government, is now well under way. The Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, representing the thousands of American investors who purchased foreign dollar bonds either issued or guaranteed by foreign governments or their political subdivisions, is pushing plans to effect settlements with many debtors whose obligations have gone into default.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Mrs. John Hay Whitney displayed fine horsemanship today at the national capital horse show, held at the Bradley Farms, in garnering three blue ribbons to add to her large collection. She also carried away the Rust Memorial Trophy, one of the main prizes of the show. The Whitney horses also scored a triple yesterday.

THE full name is Darrell Elijah Blanton. Otherwise known as Bad News Blanton or Silent Cy, the Strikeout Guy. He's a mean man out there on the pitching mound in a Pirate uniform, but he looks kind add gentle in an armchair.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- Hugo Ehlenberg of New York, who refereed the various skeet tournaments at Hot Springs last year, will again act as referee for the Virginia State skeet championship, to be held in June.

Except for United States Government securities, bonds moved irregularly forward in quiet trading yesterday on the Stock Exchange. The trend of the government issues was lower, losses ranging from 1-32 to an extreme of 10-32 point. Bond dealers reported no evidence of pressure of a concerted nature, but buyers were apathetic and the day's movements in quotations were considered of no especial significance.

IN an effort to stimulate private flying the Bureau of Air Commerce has purchased sixteen "low-priced," low-powered airplanes which will be thoroughly tested and flown under various conditions. Low cost of upkeep is one of the features claimed for them as a step toward the $700 airplane.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 11. -- Mrs. Alfred R. Driscoll of Haddonfield was elected president of the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs at the closing session of its forty-first annual convention here today.
BERWYN, Pa., May 11. -- W.B. Cocks of Westbury, L.I., was seriously injured at the Spring race meet of the Radnor Hunt Club today on the estate of Mrs. J. Packard Lair.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 11. -- Vassar observed its annual sport day today, with contests in every department of sports on the college program. Tonight, for the first time, the members of the college teams were guests at a dinner, when the honors for the year were awarded by Dr. Henry N. MacCracken, president.

Former Member U.S. Board of Tax Appeals. Demands for the limitation of income, both individual and corporate, and for a redistribution of wealth, consume much printer's ink these days and ride most of the air waves. Arguments abound for this plan or the other by which to effect these claimed needs of a supposed new social order.

LONDON, May 11. -- The return of Germany's lost colonies in Africa, particularly Southwest Africa, "would be bitterly opposed by the overwhelming mass of South Africans, British and Dutch" in the opinion of Sir Abe Bailey, South African mine owner, who is on a visit to London.

IT may be that only an Irishman, remembering the Black and Tan terror, and the patriots dead in bloody ambuscades, can understand the full meaning of "The Informer." But the admirable screen version of Liam O'Flaherty's novel is a Judas drama that makes a universal emotion out of what the Irish revolutionaries felt when treachery was in their midst.
WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Passage of the Patman "greenback" bonus bill over the expected veto of President Roosevelt was urged in a radio address over a NBC hookup tonight by Senator Long.

BRUSSELS, May 11. -- Ghent authorities today asserted they had identified the person who stole two panels from van Eyck's polyptych, "The Adoration of the Lamb," from the Cathedral of St. Bavon on April 11, last year. They offered a reward of 25,000 belgas for information leading to the recovery of the missing panel depicting "the virtuous judges."

COLLINSVILLE, Ill., May 11. -- Vandalism in the utility strike was blamed today for Collinsville's water service being cut off for lack of electricity and gas service at Mount Vernon being disrupted again by a dynamite explosion.

LONDON, May 10. -- The handful of so-called Labor Peers in the House of Lords took advantage of an abnormally dull period there the other day to stage a debate upon the European peace outlook, apparently with the idea of making out a case of good intentions for Germany and saying soothing things for her benefit.

ROME, April 29, 1935. THE second novelty of the Royal opera season was Guido Guerrini's "La Vigna" (The Vine), a three-act "burlesque opera" on a book by the composer and by Alfredo Testoni after a story from the "Cene" of Anton Giulio Grazzini (surnamed "Il Lasca").

Mr. Hylander, whose "Year Round" is one of the best outdoor books for boys and girls, has written twenty-seven brief biographies of scientists, ranging from Benjamin Franklin, Count Rumford and Audubon to Burbank and David Starr Jordan, and including such contemporary figures in the scientific world as Langmuir, Millikan, Urey, Beebe and Roy Chapman Andrews.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., May 11. -- Leads announced today for "Richmond Fair," an adaptation of the opera "Martha," which students of Highland Manor School and Junior College will present on May 18 on the campus, give the role of Martha to Miss Ethel Levy of 820 Central Avenue, Far Rockaway, L.I., and that of her maid, Nancy, to Miss Ruby Rubinoff of 36 West Fifty-ninth Street, New York City.

A "typical" day in the United States Senate was dramatized yesterday at the annual luncheon of the Women's National Democratic Club. Members presented a sketch intended to ridicule man's claim to superiority over women in legislative halls.
Henry Kost asks "Why do the European nations distrust each other and arm their borders?" He suggests that European boundaries should be as unarmed as that between the United States and Canada.

THE annual series of four orchestral concerts in Central Park made possible by Walter W. Naumburg and George W. Naumburg, in continuation of the concerts given to the city for many years by their father, Elkan Naumburg, will be inaugurated on May 30 at the bandstand on the Mall, with Leon Barzin conducting.

The Giants took half a loaf at the Polo Grounds yesterday and were absolutely satisfied; so were 40,000 fans who trooped to the ball yard in the shadow of Coogan's Bluff to view the twin bill between the Terrymen and Pie Traynor's bold Pirates.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 11. -- Pennsylvania's varsity crew answered all questions on its place in the college rowing world today -- answered them fully and completely. Penn belongs with the best, for it has yet to be defeated.

CHICAGO, May 10. -- Warm weather and sunshine gave the necessary tonic to merchandising in the Seventh Federal Reserve District this week and practically all wholesale dry goods and retail store groups shared in the upturn. There were more buyers in the local field than in many weeks, while one house reported that Tuesday's sales made the best day's total in a year. Manufacturers of millinery experienced a sharp pick-up in their Summer lines.

The Century Club was gently rebuffed yesterday in its pretention to being predominantly interested in art and literature. The rebuff was administered with light ironic touch by Federal Judge Carroll C. Hincks of Connecticut, who ruled that the club's excellent kitchen, patronage of its dining room, its monthly pamphlet of social notes and its budgetary expenditures proved the club to be largely a social organization.
WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Authority to do an electric power business so broad as to appear unlimited at first study was vested by the President in the Rural Electrification Administration.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., May 11. (AP). -- Drastic action to suppress further rioting of the kind which last night swept this capital of the British Empire's easternmost Atlantic outpost was reported to have been decided upon at a meeting today of the commission government.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., May 11. -- A marked increase in the popularity of "organized bull sessions" as sponsored by the Williams College Student Forum, the Liberal Club, the Hopkins Log Society, the Garfield Club and the college Christian Association has been an outstanding phase of undergraduate activity in the past year.
ALBANY, May 11. -- New York State will create its own corps of "G men" this coming week.

Yachtsmen take too much for granted at Lloyd Harbor. Most of them haven't appreciated the historical importance of this truly remarkable anchorage which from May to October attracts more power cruisers than all the other Saturday night ports in the New York waters combined.

THIS long novel takes its time, moves slowly, building up a great deal of detail along the way. It grows somewhat monotonous; but for the patient reader who takes his time it should not prove tedious. It is thoroughly organized and well arranged.

IN her vivid biography of the Emperor Kwang Hsu, Princess Der Ling writes of a period she knows very well -- that of the years when Old Buddha was Dowager Empress of China, and the Boxer Rebellion brought misery and an indemnity of some 400,000,000 taels of silver to the Chinese.

BUILT TO LAST: Before an audience of church architects in New York last week Dr. Ralph Adams Cram discussed the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, of which he is chief architect. "Suppose it does cost $30,000,000," he said. "A superdreadnought costs an much, serves a destructive end and at the end of twenty-five years has to be scrapped.

Student honors at Manhattan College were distributed last week with the election of Student Council and class officers for next year and the tapping of fifteen members of the junior class for the Pen and Sword Society, senior honorary group.

Few times in my life have I felt more angry, more completely sold out, than on quitting the portals of Radio City after seeing the new Hecht-MacArthur picture. Inveigled within by the legend of brilliancy that has managed to attach itself to these gentlemen, I was forthwith treated to a laboriously scintillating exposition of "the futility of it all" as seen through the eyes (and presumably minds) of the authors and chief protagonist.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 11. -- In the annual ballot of the senior class of Rutgers University, the results of which were announced today, Louis Hemerda of Flemington, class president, was chosen the best all-around man, the "ideal Rutgers man," the most popular and the best looking man in the class.

Frederick Gross, 49-year-old bookkeeper, was booked and arraigned yesterday on a charge of having murdered his wife and four of his children by poison. At the same time District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Brooklyn reiterated that no motive had been found except that of poverty.

FAR the best of Diana Patrick's later novels, truer to human nature, less given to sentimentality, this story skillfully varies that romantic fiction formula which requires at the outset a rich young man's marriage to a girl in straitened circumstances.

DETROIT. GOVERNMENT buying of motor vehicle equipment in connection with the $4,880,000,000 work-relief program is to distribute millions among the automobile companies. Trucks, ambulances and station wagons ordered from General Motors will cost in excess of $9,000,000; trucks from the Reo Motor Car Company, $1,000,000; trucks from the Ford Motor Company, $867,003; motor cars from Chrysler nearly $300,000, together with bulk orders of lesser magnitude that go to smaller producers.
Long Island University's baseball team defeated Brooklyn College, 10 -- 1, at Manhattan Beach yesterday before 2,500 fans.

Retail sales volume continues to be disappointing, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. Stores therefore, the report says, are intensifying their efforts and launching into the Summer season with renewed vigor.
ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, May 10. -- This week's elections in Yugoslavia were calculated to cause anxiety in European capitals.

A 5-to-4 decision by the Supreme Court last Monday, declaring the Railroad Retirement Act unconstitutional, put New Deal supporters searching the books on constitutional law. They wanted assurance that the court would not rule out the Social Security Bill, now pending in Congress, by the same process of reasoning.

DENVER, May 9. -- Unless they can be personalized by men and localized by communities, the surging national questions that break like tidal waves on other parts of America cause scarcely a ripple from the Missouri Valley to the Pacific Slope. The Rockies seem more remote and further from the Atlantic Seaboard, the Middle West and the Pacific Coast cities than is New York from Paris.

With generally better weather throughout the country last week, retail merchants in most of the Federal Reserve Districts reported a moderate increase in sales. As a whole, the volume of business in the first four months of this year was better than in the corresponding period last year, although there were decreases in some districts.

Herbert Witherspoon's successor as general manager of the Metropolitan Opera was expected yesterday to be some one who would be in sympathy with his plans for Americanizing the opera company and is acceptable to the Juilliard Musical Foundation.

THREE major American festivals will hold the interest of many music patrons in the East, Middle West and South this week, as programs of distinctive and widely diversified character are presented at Bethlehem, Pa., Ann Arbor, Mich., and Chattanooga, Tenn.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., May 11. -- Mount Holyoke College celebrated May Day this afternoon with an outdoor pageant and the traditional crowning of the May Queen and the playing of Molnar's "Swan" indoors in the evening.

ATHENS, May 11. -- Courts-martial completed today their trials of army and navy officers implicated in the recent uprising. The Athens court, trying former officers of the rebel fleet, sentenced thirty-three to death, but only two of them faced the court. The others are fugitives.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP). -- With echoes of a thunderous welcome still in his ears, Rear Admiral Richard Evelyn Byrd turned tonight to the quiet of a Mother's Day with his family at his Virginia home.

Automobile casualties for the first four months of 1935 are reported about even with 1934, by the Baltimore Safety Council. National estimates for the first three months give about the same result, country wide. In other words, there has been no improvement.

MOSCOW, May 11. -- A generally favorable picture of the Soviet Union's manufacturing system was given today, at a conference of the recently created Council of Heavy Industry, composed of 104 persons, the chief figures of the Commissariat and directors of important plants.

THE submarine has returned to the limelight. Germany's decision to build a fleet of 250-ton under-sea boats suggests that, despite efforts to abolish this furtive naval weapon, it has seemingly come to stay.

The Regional Labor Board, in findings made public yesterday by former Supreme Court Justice Jeremiah T. Mahoney, chairman, declared that The American Mercury had discharged two employes on April 29 in violation of Section 7a as embodied in the Graphic Arts Code.

The most important question to be taken up at the Spring meeting of the board of governors of the Investment Bankers Association at White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., beginning on Wednesday, will be that of the future of the Investment Banking Code.

The Board of Superintendents of the public school system will consider applications for principalships in the Alexander Hamilton High School, the Newtown High School and Junior High School 57, Bronx (men only). Applications should be made on forms obtainable at the Board of Education and submitted not later than May 20.

THE massive iron door clicked behind me. Today was shut out by the sunlight, and I found myself in the twilight of the Middle Ages. Three or four barons in chain-mail were sauntering in a vast baronial hall hung with tapestry. Mastiffs were asleep on the hearth.
BUFFALO, N.Y., May 11 (AP). -- The Buffalo Bisons squared the series with the Baltimore Orioles by winnings the second game today, 5 to 4.

QUEBEC, May 11. -- Despite a demand by the Opposition leader, Maurice Duplessis, that the government withdraw its newsprint bill, as further unsettling the industry, the Quebec Legislature this afternoon gave first reading to resolutions constituting a prelude to the bill and giving the government sweeping powers over the industry.
COPENHAGEN, May 11. -- Fresh reports of intensive German military activity in the demilitarized Schleswig area on the North and Baltic Seas are causing considerable concern in Denmark.
The following statement is made in a communication from Benedict Fitzpatrick, published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of April 28:

THE North Cape and capitals around the Baltic Sea have loomed unusually large of late among the goals of American travelers. Now two special celebrations are focusing attention especially on Sweden: the Riksdag, or Parliament, which is said to rank next to the British Parliament in age, will observe the 500th anniversary of its founding on May 27, and the Cathedral of Upsala will also have a 500th anniversary on June 10.

BOSTON, May 9. -- Ogden L. Mills, former Secretary of the Treasury, delivered an address here last night which from one point of view was masterly and from another has been pronounced a failure. As an interpretation of American history from the traditional Republican viewpoint it was excellent.

DALLAS, May 10. -- Return of good weather after heavy rains throughout the Eleventh Federal Reserve District has brought a return of retail buying, and other indices point to continued upturn in business throughout the district.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP). -- A deadlocked House subcommittee tonight held the administration bill abolishing public utility holding companies beyond the date on which Chairman Rayburn had predicted it would be ready for action.

CLEVELAND, May 11. -- Taking the Indians over the hurdles for the second successive day, the Yankees evacuated this metropolis tonight feeling that Cleveland's 1935 pennant expectations are still a matter that should cause no great concern back home.
LONDON, Sunday, May 12. -- Jubilee week ended at midnight with one of the wildest nights London has ever known in all its history. The celebration was like the riotous scenes on Armistice night.

The need for "some form of cooperation by which purchasing power and a consumers' market can be established" was seen in a social service report adopted yesterday morning at a session of laymen and ministers of the New York East Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church at Central Church, Hanson Place and St. Felix Street, Brooklyn.

HANCOCK, Md., May 11. -- Miles removed from turbulent Washington agitation over the cash bonus and the administration's legislative program, President Roosevelt and Congressional chieftains talked tonight around a blazing wood fire high in the Blue Ridge Mountains.

Tariff barriers that limit international commerce and contribute to the world-wide depression were described yesterday as "an absurd situation which can only be rectified by an international economic agreement" by Dr. Henryk Gruber, Polish economist and president of the Postal Savings Bank of Poland.

AT the northern end of the Bay of Fundy, not far from where Maine's long-discussed Passamaquoddy power project is expected to be developed soon, are two substantially built lighthouses (range lights), that have never guided a ship, because their beacons have never been lit and probably never will be.

A UNIQUE travel opportunity lies before the American people this year. For nearly two years, the United States has been engaged in a great construction program as part of the Federal Government's drive to put the economic applecart back on its wheels.

AMHERST, Mass., May 11. -- Dedication of the Frank L. Babbott Memorial Room in the historic Octagon at Amherst College last week recalls the history of one of the most curious buildings on any American campus.

Late this month, for the sixth annual occasion, a fleet of power cruisers will come down the Hudson in formation in command of their owners who over a period of seven days will gain experience by piloting their own craft from the Richardson factory at North Tonawanda instead of receiving them as freight shipments.

Ed Balod was selling the moon's craters and dried-up ocean beds at a fairly good clip last night on the Forty-second Street curb opposite Bryant Park, but his heart was heavy with the mistrust of the native New Yorker.

BERLIN, May 11. -- A pointed speech warning that order in public finances is just as important as military prowess and requesting particularly that the Reichsbank be relieved of the steady drain on its resources caused by the government's "labor creation" and rearmament programs was delivered today before a forum of Reichsbank officials by Fritz Dreyse, vice president of that institution.

MUSIC NIGHT will be one of the events of the Bronx House Spring Festival on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday of this week. It will be held on Friday night and will follow Athletic and Recreation Night, Wednesday, and Art Night, Thursday.

SHANGHAI. CHINA is taking up athletics in a serious way. Not only is the liking for outdoor sports spreading among the people but the national government is ordering the adoption of regular training in schools and by public officials.

Ray Romersa's brilliant pitching featured Textile High School's victory over Curtis High in a Lower Manhattan-Richmond P.S.A.L. game at Curtis Field, Staten Island, yesterday. Textile triumphed by 16 to 1. Romersa allowed only two hits.

Net profit of the Briggs Manufacturing Company for the quarter ended March 31, amounted to $3,247,141 after depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges. This is equivalent to $1.64 a share on 1,979,000 no par shares of stock. In the corresponding quarter of 1934, the company earned $1,550,608 or 78 cents a share.

MONARCHY, Mr. Buchan remarks disarmingly, "in some form is universal today." And if you look around at the nations and consider the definition of monarchy, you will see that his statement has validity. The question, of course, is, in each country, who chooses the ruler?

ALTHOUGH no announcement has been made, it was learned this week that Joseph von Sternberg, whose last Paramount picture, "The Devil Is a Woman," still causes that studio to shudder at its mention, is to enter independent production, possibly tying up with the Jock Whitney interests.

MANILA. -- Agrarian unrest is again making its appearance in the Philippine Islands. It is an annual occurrence, usually beginning or culminating on May Day, but the situation has been complicated this year by the addition of sugar planters to the usually disgruntled rice farmers and sugar makers.

Secretary ICKES knows from firsthand experience that "a sound public "works program cannot be brought "into being by the pressing of a but- "ton." He points this out in THE TIMES Magazine today in an article urging the importance of careful planning and of adequate assurance that projects undertaken will actually provide "assets of permanent value."
We had to economize on food, schools and textiles to accumulate the means necessary for the establishment of industry. There was no other way to wipe out our technical poverty.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- Harking back to the principle of self-determination which Franklin D. Roosevelt enunciated in his farm relief speech at Topeka, Kan., in the early days of the 1932 campaign, the Agricultural Adjustment Administration will conduct a referendum on May 25 to determine whether the wheat producers of the country want to continue the wheat-production adjustment program, which expires with the 1935 crop year.

Several penthouse terraces and backyard city gardens will be opened to the public on Wednesday for the benefit of the School Nature League. The league, which is associated with the American Museum of Natural History, seeks to aid thousands of city children each year in increasing their knowledge of nature study.
" * * * begotten in the galley and born under a gun; every hair a rope yarn, every tooth a marline spike; every finger a fish hook and in his blood right good Stockholm tar."

After performing a series of intricate feats of memory at the closing session of the Hobby Round-Up in the Port Authority Building last night, Bernard Zufall, Forest Hills salesman, who is known as the "human encyclopedia," was unable to recall the name of a childhood neighbor who approached him from the audience.

OF all the people traveling about the countryside this Spring, none probably will see more than the two groups of men who start out in automobiles today and next Sunday -- one to traverse New Jersey, the other Long Island, to hunt birds -- not with gun or even camera but with the eye and the ear and a pad and a pencil.

The rapidly growing realization as to what termination of the processing tax would mean to buyers and distributers of cotton products created a definite broadening of sentiment in favor of retention of the levy among these groups last week.

The Aldermanic inquiry at City Hall, which told the world about "boon-doggling" and other curiosities of work relief, ran out of money last week and concluded its public hearings -- but not before staging the long-awaited face-to-face encounter between Lloyd P. Stryker, attorney to the investigating committee, and Robert Moses, Commissioner of Parks.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., May 11. -- The annual Lawridge horse show will be held here tomorrow on the estate of Mrs. Robert Law to benefit the Greenwich Free Milk Fund and the United Hospital of Port Chester.

PARIS, May 11. -- While General Victor Denain, Minister for Air, is on an official visit to Rome for the purpose of framing a Franco-Italian air convention and part of the French fleet is being welcomed at Naples, opinion in Paris is becoming seriously perturbed over the situation between Abyssinia and Italy.

NEWS that the research laboratories have supplied the basic means of lifting the curtain of space from scenes and activities at a distance is accompanied with the announcement that "television is here." But it looms as no menace to sound broadcasting, nor will the images that dance across the rooftops on tiny waves supplant or diminish the importance and usefulness of nation-wide broadcasting, according to David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America.

With moderate receipts of strawberries in the wholesale market, the prices on large, fancy size berries increased at the close of the week, it was said yesterday by George G. Royce, director of the New York office of the State Department of Agriculture and Markets.

BOSTON, May 10. -- Department store sales in the First Federal Reserve District are running at almost exactly the same level as a year ago. Weather conditions have been generally unsatisfactory for the last month, and this has handicapped the retail movement of merchandise.

The Dock Department replied to rumors yesterday with a statement that the North River pier which has been assigned the new French liner Normandie would be ready for every emergency when the ship arrives here from Havre June 3 on her maiden transatlantic crossing.
WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The fate of the Patman bill may be sealed before another week has passed, and with it may or may not be settled the bonus issue for this session of this Congress.

In this volume Mr. Mason has collected twelve stories dealing with mystery and crime and two notes on real incidents of the World War. The first of these "War Notes" tells the story of Mata Hari, minimizing her importance as a spy, but reiterating certain often denied sensational details of her death.

A declaration of policy by the national administration assuring retailers that they will receive a refund on all cotton goods purchased after June 1 in the event of termination of the processing tax was advocated here yesterday by Samuel C. Lamport of the Lamport Manufacturing Supply Company to end current uncertainty, which is holding up orders.

ST. THOMAS, V.I., May 11. -- Nathan Margold, solicitor for the Department of the Interior, said today that the department welcomed the Senate investigation into the administration of the Virgin Islands.

BERLIN. AMONG the few really important literary contributions of this year we must count "Die Grosse Fahrt," by Hans Friedrich Blunck (Langen-Mueller, Munich). It would be unjust to the author if we were to consider him a literary opportunist.

TORONTO, Ont., May 11. -- Macassa Mines, Ltd., shows net profit of $395,703, equivalent to 15 cents a share, for the year ended on March 31, in its annual report, released today. The company treated 66,534 tons of ore with recovery of $15.91 a ton, or a total value of $1,058,958.

HONOLULU, May 11. -- Preparations by the army to defend the naval base in Hawaii in connection with the fleet manoeuvres indicated today that the mass attack by 450 planes revealed by the Navy Department yesterday would be made against the defense structure here.

WHEN on Russia's Easter Eve 75,000 people flocked to the churches of Moscow, the casual visitor might well have thought that religion was holding its ground in this land of anti-Christ. Seventeen years after a revolution, based on a philosophy that abhors religion, had dispossessed the State church and scattered its congregations, religion could be seen clinging tenaciously to its traditional forms.

THERE was a Wilhelm Tell, arrow poised at apple in a Swiss crisis. There was a brave Horatius, defender of a Roman bridge. Now, to complete a trilogy of legends backed by fact, there arises one Daniel M. Casey, in a suburb of our own nation's capital, to say that he is that very "mighty Cagey" immortalized by a strike-out in baseball nearly a half century ago.

AN amusing light novel which combines romance and farce in an engaging manner, Peter Delius's "Boarding House" is concerned with one of those establishments Londoners call a private hotel. This particular and very unusual specimen of the genus was run by Kathleen Joicey of Connemara, who named it after her native place.

Philip Gordon, who will conduct his second concert with the Greenwich Sinfonietta this afternoon at the Museum of Natural History, has received from Essex County, N.J., a gift of the full scores of Beethoven's nine symphonies, following his leadership of the Newark Civic Symphony.
PHILADELPHIA, May 11 (AP). -- One of the Dean boys of St. Louis was successful today, while the other took a beating as the Cardinals and Phillies split a doubleheader.

Absorbing profit-taking without much difficulty, the share market, during the brief trading period yesterday, moved to a fractionally higher close to complete the sixth consecutive week in which prices have advanced. The comparatively modest appreciation of prices did enable about twoscore issues to enter new high around for the year, a list in which public utility stocks were well represented.

MACON, Mo., May 11 (AP). -- A weeping witness today temporarily halted the Federal Government's investigation of the fatal crash of a TWA airliner near here when he broke down while describing the crash scene.
The walls of the club room on the twelfth floor of The New York Times Annex have been decorated with the first art exhibition by members of the art department of THE TIMES.

In Europe those are weeks of diplomatic conversations and negotiations. Prime Ministers, Foreign Ministers and diplomats board trains and planes far points north, south, cast and west; every day statesmen are on the road for the announced purpose of finding peace.
PARIS, May 11. -- France is gathering her financial forces to make what will be in all likelihood her last stand against devaluation.

THE last patron to leave the Rialto Theatre in the wee sma' hours of next Thursday morning is likely to bump into the foreman of the wrecking crew which will be waiting outside for the signal to begin demolishing the theatre.

THE Spring of 1780, 155 years ago, was recently commemorated by the reproduction of a typical Revolutionary hut in Morristown National Historical Park, New Jersey, in the like of which Washington's soldiers spent one of their most difficult seasons.

Encouraged by the enthusiasm which has greeted its exhibition of "banned books," the Junior League of New York City will prolong the display at its headquarters, 221 East Seventy-first Street, until May 20. The exhibition, which includes volumes dating from the time of Confucius to the present, orginally was scheduled to end tomorrow.

LONDON. THERE is a lull just now in the production of what are popularly known as war books; that is, accounts of operations in the World War and personal memoirs of men who took either a prominent or an obscure part in it.

One of the most progressive features of the present-day college athletic programs is the introduction of the modern dance as a regular part of the undergraduate curriculum. Often part of the compulsory freshman course, it is retained as a special activity for all classes, and its popularity is steadily growing.

BUENOS AIRES, May 11. -- The Chaco peace conference was formally organized late this afternoon. Foreign Minister Carlos Saavedra Lamas of Argentina presided. Brazil, Chile, Peru and Uruguay were represented by their Ambassadors here and the United States by Charge d' Affaires Raymond Cox.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., May 11. -- About 5,000 persons visited the gardens of Planting Fields, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. William Robertson Coe, which was opened for the first pilgrimage of the season in aid of the Nassau County Council of Girl Scouts.

MISS NOURSE has ably written a short, yet admirably complete and balanced history of China. So many short and long histories of China have appeared of recent years that one is tempted to wonder what value there can be in adding one more volume to the repetitious accumulation.
CHICAGO, May 11. -- American motorists, except possibly those in Eastern States, are riding toward an all-time record of traffic accident deaths, according to the National Safety Council.
MONTREAL, May 11 (AP). -- Harry Smythe, who was chased from the mound in the first inning yesterday, came back today and pitched the Royals to a 9-to-1 victory over Albany, giving only four hits.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Declines were still in evidence in industrial indices in the week ended on May 4, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly review of the domestic business situation, but an increase in electric power output improved the general picture.

Greystone-on-Hudson, the beautiful estate of Samuel Untermyer in Yonkers, will be the scene on Saturday of a garden fete for the benefit of the Cooperative Committee of Big Sisters (Catholic, Jewish and Protestant). The gardens will be open to the public from 2 to 7 P.M. and the proceeds from the nominal admission charge will aid the work of the beneficiary in caring for neglected children.

Every trout angler lives in the hope that some day he will catch "the daddy of 'em all. Somewhere, sometime he will come to grips with a monster fish, lurking in the dark recesses of a deep pool -- a fish of noble and awesome proportions that will find its way into his creel after a titanic struggle.

At the Joint Conference of Agriculture, Industry and Science held in Dearborn last week, Drs. L.M. CHRISTENSEN and WILLIAM H. HALE read lyrics in which alcohol was glorified as a miracle-worker which would permanently place the farmer beyond the pale of distress.

THE marine intelligence announced that Donald Ogden Stewart was sailing last Wednesday on the Washington, and that was correct. The fact is, though, that Mr. Stewart is not merely taking a vacation. He is plotting a partial return to Broadway.

VALHALLA, N.Y., May 11. -- Two hundred students from the Valhalla Public School staged a torchlight parade through the streets tonight in support of Mrs. Ruby Warner and Miss Mildred Babcock, teachers whose contracts for next year have not been renewed by the Board of Education.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 11. -- Columbia and Yale each won a game in their double-header today, neither gaining in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League race. Columbia won the first, 11 -- 4, and Yale the second, 6 -- 3.

IT was the expectation of the early church that when the end of the world should be at hand there would appear before men the arch-enemy, Antichrist. But it has been the observation of Joseph Roth, in which many will concur, that, while Doomsday seems to be as remote as ever, Antichrist has by no means postponed his advent.

Sometimes gains held, to be taxable income exist only for income tax purposes. Unless a gain is actually realized by a concluded transaction, obviously its realization becomes contingent upon some eventuality. Where, in such case, the eventuality does not materialize, to the extent that it does not, the income tax will havebeen paid upon a phantom profit.

For the first time since the second quarter of 1934 the steel industry as a whole operated at a profit in the first quarter of this year, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday. Aggregate net earnings were estimated at $8,300,000 after all charges but before dividends.
SHORT-WAVE broadcasts this week in connection with King George's Silver Jubilee celebration include:

THE clubwomen of Tappahannock in Essex County, Va., have for several years been using as their clubhouse the old Debtors Prison, built in 1720. At the time the building was erected the town, which had been named Hobbs His Hole, had been rechristened New Plymouth; not until 1808 was the name changed to Tappahannock.

Varied divertissements will feature the Garden Festival in behalf of the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery on May 21 at the opening of the Park Lane Gardens. The entertainment will include a fashion showing of the latest costumes for Summer wear both for adults and children in which young women of society as well as children of well-known New York families will act as manikins.

THE older a person grows the more he must become like a child in his eating habits, according to latest investigations of members of the American Chemical Society. Housewives are told that the diet of the-grown-up requires more Grade A milk, fresh fruits, vegetables and animal oils containing the lifegiving Vitamin A, than does that of the 10-year old child -- because the child is more vitamin-conscious than his elders.

Several women of social prominence will be patronesses of a fashion show and tea to be given on Tuesday in the Italian Gardens of Le Coq Rouge, 65 East Fifty-sixth Street, for the benefit of the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 11. -- Smashing two Cornell hurlers for seventeen hits today, Syracuse won a 9-to-2 victory over their hosts before 2,000 fans, part of whom were sub-freshmen making their initial visit to the campus.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., May 11. -- Entries will close next week for the annual Tuxedo Horse Show to be held here on June 7 and 8. Mrs. David Wagstaff is again president of the show. Officers include E. Victor Loew, vice president; John E. Cowdin, secretary; George B. St. George, treasurer, and William S. Blitz, assistant secretary.

Mayor La Guardia indicated clearly yesterday that he would veto an appropriation of an additional $10,000 to complete the work of the aldermanic committee that has been investigating relief methods in the city. The committee, for which Lloyd P. Stryker is counsel, seeks the $10,000 to continue its inquiry and make up its report.
MYRNA LOY, the gay damosel from Montana who has moved through many metropolitan pictures with the gay assurance of a true cosmopolite, saw New York for the first time last week.

IN less accomplished hands than Eric Linklater's "Ripeness Is All" might have been straight farce. As it is, fitful gleams of satire brighten his most improbable situations and prevent him from degenerating into the merely absurd.

WARSAW, May 12. -Marshal I Joseph Pilsudski, Poland's man of power, died here tonight on the ninth anniversary of the 1926 ] coup that made him virtual ! dictator of the land. The news was[ [announced two hours later to ai throng gathered before Belvedere Palace.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., May 12 -- The cricketers of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club opened their season today, defeating a team representing the Brooklyn Cricket Club by a margin of 106 runs.

An increase in its international air passenger and express business last year to the largest volume in its history enabled the Pan American Airways Corporation to make a net profit of $1,064,471, or $1.68 a share, against $898,000, or $1.42 a share, in 1933, according to the annual report, issued yesterday by J.T. Trippe, president.

The cotton futures market here was more active last week and prices moved into new high ground for the current movement. At the close on Saturday, active future contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were 4 to 22 points higher than a week before.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 12. -- More than 1,500 persons attended the exercises marking the opening of the prefabricated houses built by the American Houses, Inc., near the Westchester County Center at White Plains, at 3:30 o'clock this afternoon.
LANGHORNE, Pa., May 12. -- Johnny Hannon today won the fifty-mile inaugural auto race at the Langhorne Speedway for the third straight year.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art will open to the public tomorrow a special exhibition of masterpieces of Oriental rugs and textiles, including privately owned examples that have never been exhibited before to the public.
WARSAW, April 30. -- Marshal Pilsudski, as this is written, is only 67 years old, but his life and its struggles and privations have marked him more than his years.

A department for handling loans on new building construction is being organized by the Manufacturers Trust Company, which has established an initial fund of $5,000,000 for the purpose, it was learned last night from details of the new financing program given by Harvey D. Gibson, president of the bank.

PARIS, May 12. -- By combining their forces "against fascism" the Left parties in France, ranging from the Radical Socialists to Communists, succeeded today in winning an important victory in the second day's balloting of the nation-wide municipal elections.

Barnard College alumnae are turning in increasing numbers to governmental service, according to occupational statistics in the 1935 Alumnae Register, just published by the college and the associate alumnae.

LONDON, May 11. -- Although the jubilee celebration has interrupted business in Great Britain to some extent, financial sentiment has been unostentatiously but markedly influenced by this period of national rejoicing and the demonstration of loyalty it evoked.

Plans for a $45,000,000 municipal power plant, to sell current to all classes of consumers in direct competition with the Consolidated Gas system, were outlined yesterday by Mayor La Guardia. He announced, in a statement issued from City Hall, that he would ask the Board of Estimate to give him the authority to submit the plans to the Federal government and seek a PWA loan.

The Physicians Equity Association of America, Inc., which has been in process of organization for eighteen months, announced yesterday the plans by which it hopes to place the medical profession on an economic status comparable with that of other professions.
ATLANTA, Ga., May 12. -- The fellow who originated the saying "it's Greek to me" to denote the height of unintelligibility had not heard of cakchiquel.

Dorothy Zukowski, 15 years old, of 19 Cliff Street, Jersey City, who for seven years had been treated unsuccessfully by specialists following an attack of infantile paralysis which left her partly crippled, will go to the First District Court in Jersey City tomorrow to testify for a man who has been arrested as a "hex" doctor, but whose treatments, she contends, permitted her to discard her crutches.

With an attack upon the administration- sponsored Banking Bill of 1935, the Guaranty Trust Company of New York yesterday opened the promised campaign of bankers to oppose the new legislation as it was passed last week by the House of Representatives.

Nothing but friendly relations between America and Great Britain is even conceivable to all people of good sense, Bishop William T. Manning told more than 4,000 persons of British and Canadian birth or heritage who jammed the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday afternoon at a service for the silver jubilee of George V. King of England.

The author who is picked as the United States choice in the $20,000 all-nations prize novel competition will at least be sure of an award of $4,000. If the novel chosen by the United States judges does not win the $20,000 prize, the Literary Guild will pay $3,000 for this novel's book-club rights and Farrar Rinehart will pay $1,000 in advance on royalties.

LONDON, May 12. -- Some of the poorest of King George's subjects had an opportunity today to join in the enthusiasm over his jubilee. Accompanied by Queen Mary and Princess Elizabeth, he made an unheralded journey to the East End of London, particularly to the Lime-house district, noted as one of the poorest slum areas of the city and formerly the worst haunt of crime in Britain.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 12. -- There were many arrivals today in the Greenbrier colony. Among them were Baron and Baroness Hennessy of Cognac, France, in whose party were A.R. Gillespie of Montreal and C.O. Bailey of New York.

Last week was characterized by increased hesitancy in general trade, but by strength on the Stock Exchange. On Thursday the average price of stocks went for the first time above the year's previous high level, reached in February, from which there has been a subsequent decline of 11 5/8 points and recovery of 12 3/4.

Camp La Guardia, the city's rehabilitation farm for homeless men on the old Greycourt prison site in Orange County, expects to produce a surplus of foodstuffs this year. Stanley Howe, executive secretary of the Mayor, who started the camp when he was a deputy Welfare Commissioner, has called a conference of deputy commissioners for tomorrow to arrange for the transfer of surplus crops to city departments that buy foods.

On March 21 I attended a Code Authority meeting of cigar manufacturers, at which the consensus of opinion was that the ten-cent cigar should be sold by the retailer at three for 27 cents instead of five for 48 cents, and the five-cent cigar should be sold by the retailer at five for 23 cents instead of ten for 48 cents.

BERLIN, May 11. -- Renewed talk of depreciation of the mark, with consequent active buying of foreign currencies and securities, and surmises concerning the position of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics, with Chancellor Hitler and the Nazi party were features of this week's business activities here.
