Let the final word on the Pulitzer Prize be this. It is a telegram from Miss Zoe Akins to President Butler of Columbia, acknowledging the honor given a week ago to "The Old Maid."

WESTBURY, L.I., May 12. -- For the first time since he was injured in the Eastern teams' test matches last August Tommy Hitchcock Jr. participated in a polo contest today as the Meadow Brook Club's 1935 season was officially opened with two members' games on fields at the J.S. Phipps estate.

Establishment of an Advanced School of Education that will grant degrees of doctoral level and emphasize advanced professional training and research in education was announced yesterday by Dean William F. Russell of Teachers College, Columbia University.

May was an outstanding month in 1934 for girls with the wanderlust, according to the annual report of the Missing Persons Bureau of the Police Department, submitted yesterday by Acting Captain John G. Stein.

NEW ORLEANS, La., May 12. -- The strong situation in the spot cotton market dominated all other branches of the cotton trade last week. Although trading in future contracts on the Cotton Exchange was not particularly active, the market ruled generally firm and old crop months advanced to within a few points of the 12-cent level.

As the only British-built church of Colonial times in New York, St. Paul's Episcopal Chapel of Trinity Parish, Broadway and Fulton Street, has been taking part in the King's Jubilee. In. his sermon there yesterday morning the Rev. Dr. Joseph P. McComas, the vicar, took as his text "Fear God; Honor the King."

I was immensely interested to learn from a lawyer friend that there are $600,000,000 of unpaid claims against the United States which have been verified as valid by the Court of Claims. These are for the rectification of many injustices to citizens and domestic corporations by reason of acts of the government.

Sugar was the sensation in the markets for commodity futures here last week, prices advancing to the highest level in almost seven years. The trend in other commodities generally was upward in restricted trading. In the cash markets oats, cocoa, lard, zinc, tin, sugar, cotton, wool tops, rubber, hides and gasoline advanced, while wheat, corn, rye, flour, coffee and silk declined.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP). -- Senator Long's campaign to oust Postmaster General Farley from the Cabinet tonight faced an open airing on the Senate floor with the outcome up to a heavy Democratic majority.

Controversy over the authenticity of spirit contacts claimed by Margery, famous Boston medium, reached yesterday a more bitter stage than ever when the trustees of the American Society for Psychical Research repudiated a statement in the May issue of its journal that purported to indicate the organization had changed its mind and now condemned Margery.

The Gardner residence at 12 East Sixty-third Street, a five-story brownstone structure on a plot 25 by 100 feet belonging to the Charles E. Gardner estate, is to be altered into nine apartments of one, two and three rooms each, with a six-room penthouse an d roof garden.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP). -- A bureau with functionaries throughout the country 27,000 strong has grown up to look after the American war veteran and disburse the hundreds of millions former service men are paid yearly in pensions.

IT'S hard to keep up with Madcap Max, the Big Bad Baer. Remarkable chap. When they went to look for him to tell him it was time for His Lordship, the world's heavyweight champion, to go into training to defend his title, they found him nursing a big black eye. He collected that in a casual meeting with some rough, untutored gent in the sticks. His hands were sore, too.
May one who enjoyed the friendship of Nathan Haskell Dole for more than fifty years add a word of tribute to this fine scholar's reputation?

With more than 15,000 children and their parents in attendance, Uncle Robert, with the assistance of the children who figure in his radio programs, staged his eighth annual Parents Day celebration on the Central Park Mall yesterday.
ALBANY, May 12. -- The two Feld bills designed to restore about $18,000,000 in salary cuts to New York City teachers, firemen and policemen have been vetoed, Governor Lehman announced tonight.

Casey Stengel led with his ace, Van Lingle Mungo, at Ebbets Field yesterday and the satisfying result to the Dodgers and 14,000 fans was a grand slam against the Reds, who dropped their third straight to Brooklyn by the score of 9 to 1.

Eighteen witnesses have been subpoenaed to appear today before the grand jury investigating "fixing" of the police eligible list, Assistant District Attorney Lyon Boston announced last night. The inquiry resulted Saturday in the arrest of John Flaherty, Democratic politician of 33 Fifth Avenue.

NEGORELOYE, U.S.S.R., May 12. -- Pierre Laval, French Foreign Minister, arrived tonight at this frontier station, which was lavishly decorated with French flags, and was received by a guard of honor and met by Charles Alphand, French Ambassador to Moscow, and representatives of the Soviet Foreign Office.

A group of young Communists staged an anti-war demonstration yesterday -- afternoon in Van Cortlandt Park that for a few minutes threatened to break up a parade of 10,000 military and naval cadets passing in review before 25,000 spectators.

BERLIN, May 12. -- The German Government will deal formally next Friday with the vote of censure of the Council of the League of Nations on Reich rearmament. Its pronouncement, as far as can be ascertained in advance, will include a reaffirmation of its position on all the problems raised in intergovernmental exchanges during the past three months.

Women will play a decisive role in determining the national attitude toward war and other major social problems and will thereby "shape anew the present man-made social order," the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman said yesterday at a Mother's Day service at Christ Methodist Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

When the premises at 109-115 W. 94th t. were cold by the Emigrant Bank to the One Eleven West 94th St. Corp., Irving Broff, pesident0 for an Indicated consideration of $10,000 the bank took back a mortgage for $152,825, payable on demand. The bank made a further demand loan for $120,000, or so much thereof as may be advanced, pursuant to a building loan agreement of May 10.
Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine is expected to act today on Mayor La Guardia's request that he "tighten the lines" against drunken drivers.

BANGKOK, Siam, May 12 (AP). -- Japanese influence has spread in Siam at a rate so alarming to Western powers, it was learned today, that diplomatic representatives have made many inquiries at government offices.

SHANGHAI May 12 (AP). -- The silver purchasing policy of the United States is causing a severe drain on China's silver reserves and a sharp contraction of the nation's currency and credit, the Ministry of Finance said tonight.

CHICAGO, May 12. -- The Chicago district qualifying round for the National Open golf championship tonight was postponed from tomorrow to a week hence because of the unplayable condition of the Medinah Country Club courses, due to last night's record rainfall.

PITTSBURGH, May 12. -- Steel men regard current demand for steel as satisfactory when allowance is made for the various uncertainties and attribute the demand in large part to the filling of requirements for personal and household consumption, as individuals are not concerned about the possibility that prices may decline.

PARIS, May 11. -- The exodus of gold from the Bank of France in the past few weeks appears to have been caused solely by the precautionary measures taken by all European countries against devaluation of the gold-bloc currencies, and even against further devaluation of sterling.

METZ, France, May 12 (AP). -- The arrest of a German Nazi Storm Trooper, held closely guarded in jail after the latest of the rapidly multiplying Franco-German "frontier incidents," increased uneasiness tonight in border towns.

In honoring the mothers of the nation on Mother's Day we are apt to overlook those mothers who, already overburdened physically and economically, face the prospect of another child with desperation. In thousands of families struggling through the depression, another child now will mean a shortage of the necessities of life for the children already born.

Cambridge Estate, Inc., Henry Mabel, president, sold the six-story elevator apartment house at 1,060 Ocean Avenue, northwest corner of Foster Avenue, Brooklyn. The buyer is an investing syndicate headed by Abraham Meitin. This group recently bought the apartment buildings at 9,949 Shore Road, 145 Ninety-fifth Street and 110 Lenox Road.

The Gdynia America Steamship Line, operating passenger and freight ships between New York, Gdynia and Copenhagen, has transferred its terminal operations from South Brooklyn to the Sixth Street pier, Hoboken. The change will be made tomorrow when the steamship Kosciuszko arrives.

A denunciation of American neutrality in the current European crisis as being a passive alignment with the forces of evil was voiced by the Rev. Dr. Stanley High, pastor of the First Congregational Church of Stamford, Conn., in a sermon yesterday morning at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

Controller Taylor announced yesterday that he had directed the issuance of warrants against 250 shopkeepers who have failed to pay the sales tax they collected from the public. The warrants, to be filed with the County Clerk, have the effect of court judgments and become a lien against the property of the merchant.

BOSTON, Mass., May 12. -- Rabbi Jonah B. Wise, brother-in-law of the late Adolph S. Ochs, was the principal speaker at memorial exercises for Mr. Ochs at the Burroughs Newsboys Foundation this afternoon at which a portrait of the publisher was unveiled.

MEXICO, D.F., May 12. -- The United States Davis Cup team gained a clean sweep of its American Zone semi-final matches with China today when Donald Budge of Oakland, Calif., and Bryan M. Grant of Atlanta took the final singles engagements in straight sets.

BOSTON, May 12 (AP). -- Pitcher Lon Warneke dominated the Cubs' victory, 4 to 1, over the Braves today, giving the Chicago team a clean sweep of the three-game series. Warneke held the Braves to seven hits, made four safeties in four times at bat himself and drove in two runs.

Adolph S. Ochs was eulogized as a humanitarian and a leader of mankind at memorial services held yesterday at the Jacob H. Schiff Centre, 2,510 Valentine Avenue, the Bronx. The Rev. Alexander Basel, rabbi of the centre; the Rev. Dr. Israel Goldstein of Temple B'nai Jeshurun, and Dr. John H. Finley paid tribute to the late publisher.

A smiling, good-natured Jersey commuter from North Bergen who works as an artist in an Eleventh Avenue studio painting scenery fort Broadway shows, spent the Sabbath winning America's leading and longest outboard race. For seven of the eight years this Albany-to-New York marathon, now 129 miles long, has been held, Fred Jacoby Jr. has been an also ran but never a winner.

MANILA, Monday, May 13 (AP). -- Continuing rumors of impending violence kept the Philippine constabulary on the jump today, the eve of the plebiscite in which Filipinos will go to the polls and accept or reject the American offer of independence.

Activity of cotton mills in the United States is now at about the same level as in general industrial lines, according to the New York Cotton Exchange Service. The report points out that in the greater part of the last four years cotton mills ran at a rate higher than that of most industries.

Another city garden tour in a series for the benefit of the Anne Brown Free Kindergarten at 524, West Forty-second Street will take place Wednesday afternoon when gardens in Greenwich Village will be shown.

The Philadelphia Germans, outstanding amateur eleven, clinched first honors in the American Soccer League metropolitan division yesterday by blanking the New York Americans, 1 to 0, before 4,500 at Starlight Park.

YONKERS, N.Y., May 12. -- Sid Brews, South African golf champion, and Fred Moore, professional at the Dunwoodie Golf Club, today defeated the formidable team of Paul Runyan of Metropolis and Willie Macfarlane in an exhibition match over the Dunwoodie course by 1 up.

LONDON, May 11. -- The renewed restlessness of the Foreign Exchange markets, it is believed here, indicates that the recent period of quiet and stability has done nothing to restore confidence in the ability of the gold bloc to hold out against the economic pressure to which its countries are constantly exposed, because of what is considered here the overvaluation of their currencies.

IN the true spirit of science, Professor J.T. Salter of the University of Wisconsin, author of "Boss Rule: Portraits in City Politics" (Whittlesey House, $2.50), decided that the way to learn about ward leaders and the machinations by which they keep their organizations in power is to study them on the spot. The spot chosen by Salter was the Philadelphia of the Vare machine.

CHICAGO, May 12. -- A total of 58,000 Canadian cattle have been received in the United States markets, largely in Chicago, so far this year. This is ten times the imports of Canadian cattle for the entire year of 1934.

The American Committee on Religious Rights and Minorities, 70 Fifth Avenue, yesterday made public a protest against the treatment of Jews in Germany. Not only has no basic change been made in the National Socialist "cold pogrom" decreed against the Jews there, but the support of Reichsbishop Muller, the highest official of the Evangelical Church, has been expressly given to anti-Semitism, it is declared.

With buyers here last week to cover Summer requirements, various divisions of the wholesale markets experienced greater activity than during the previous week. While dresses received the greatest amount of attention, lightweight woolen and tweed coats and suits in swagger styles, and linen and pique suits sold well.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- About 80 per cent of the outstanding First Liberty bonds have been exchanged for the Treasury's offering of 2 7/8 per cent 1955-60 bonds and Treasury notes of 1 5/8 per cent of five-year maturity.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Convinced that President Roosevelt will disapprove the Patman bill and that his veto likely will be sustained by the Senate, veterans' leaders in Congress will meet tomorrow night to devise means for keeping the bonus issue actively before this session until it is settled to the satisfaction of the ex-service men.

New York is getting back into its stride. During the depression the city's riding habit fell off sharply. Not so many husbands went downtown to work. Not so many wives took the subway to the theatres or the shopping district. Many men and women still at work were encouraged by the NRA to stay home two days a week instead of one.

A hundred jumping frogs for the big town version here next Sunday of the Calaveras County, Calif., frog-jumping contest immortalized by Mark Twain came to New York yesterday in less than a dozen hops from the bayous of Louisiana.

Our weekly contemporary, The Nation, shows enterprise in compiling an index of "labor welfare." Remarking that data on the fluctuations in business activity have been combined into indexes which show at a glance the degree of our economic health, it remarks the absence of any figure that can be said to reflect the status of labor as a group.

Two men were drowned at 1 P.M. yesterday in the Hudson River off Fort Washington Point. Strollers in Fort Washington Park near by told the police one of the men had lost his balance and toppled over, and that the other had gone to his rescue. Neither could swim.

ABOARD U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA, Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, May 12. -- Out of the silence and secrecy that have veiled their mimic war movements since May 3, some forty ships of the United States fleet steamed into Pearl Harbor a few hours after dawn this morning bearing news of three accidents that had caused the death of two men and injuries to five.

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., May 12. -- A burglar who half an hour before leaped from the second story window of the home of Clinton B. Maujer, 69 High Street, after looting it of jewelry, was shot to death by a policeman just before midnight tonight.
Donald Richberg, NRA chief, conferred here yesterday with Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of General Motors, on the strike in the Chevrolet plant in Toledo.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- The United Textile Workers of America announced tonight that it had called a "halt" in the case of its differences with the Textile Labor Relations Board in an effort to set aside an adverse decision of the Textile Board involving controversies between the union and the Callaway Cotton Mills of La Grange, Ga.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1935, as well as last prices for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:
WILMINGTON, Del., May 12 (AP). -- A young mother and her four children were burned to death in their beds early today because firemen thought the family was away from home.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 12. -- Frank Campbell piloted his new dinghy, Confusion, to 127 points in the regular Sunday regatta today at the Larchmont Yacht Club and came into possession, temporarily at least, of the Henry Plant Trophy.

TOLEDO, Ohio, May 12. -- In connection with a veiled attack on militant Left-Wing strike committee leaders who are opposed to the terms of a new proposal for a peace pact in the Chevrolet Motor Company strike here, F.J. Dillon, American Federation of Labor organizer in the Detroit area, announced tonight that he would urge acceptance of the proposal when it comes before a meeting of the union tomorrow night.

VIENNA, May 12. -- Inspired comment on yesterday's Florence interview between Chancellor Kurt Sehuschnigg of Austria and Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy, published today in the semi-official Reichspost, protests against newspaper charges that the Chancellor sought to counteract the effect of the recent visit of prince Ernst von Starhemberg, Vice Chancellor, to Premier Mussolini.

A charge that the relief inquiry of the aldermanic committee under the chairmanship of Bernard S. Deutsch, President of the Board of Aldermen, had done "more harm than good" was made yesterday by the Welfare Council and its Coordinating Committee on Unemployment.

AMSTERDAM, May 12. -- Uneasiness over the gold-bloc currencies was assuaged here this week as the French franc and the guilder showed technical firmness. Factors in their favor were the high gold reserves, the generally liquid position of banks, the reluctance of the authorities to indulge in monetary experiments and their fear of increasing monetary chaos, even if devaluation were to lead finally to stabilization.

WILLLAMSTOWN, Mass., May 12 -- The Williams College trustees have announced the appointment of seven new faculty members, the election of George A. Cluett as permanent trustee, and a more rigid policy with regard to scholarship aid.

Those of us who are awaiting eagerly the Republican Rejuvenation act to be put on at the Grass Roots Convention in Mr. LINCOLN'S Springfield in early June must be saddened by the apparent relaxation of high moral fiber on the part of National Committeeman JOHN HAMILTON of Kansas.

Coordination of sizes of manufactured building units, such as are employed in pre-fabricated homes, offers an opportunity for greater construction economies, according to Myron L. Matthews in the Dow Service Daily Building Reports. Spreading of the movement for standard-sized construction units is predicted by the Dow Service writer, who says the subject is being discussed with renewed interest in building circles.
ST. LOUIS, May 12 (AP). -- The Browns won their second straight game today, defeating the Red Sox, 3 to 2.

An encouraging picture of the realty market in suburban Westchester County is drawn by the Scarsdale Board of Realtors in its annual residential survey, completed last week. The market analysis indicates clearly that there are fewer vacant homes in the Scarsdale area than at any time in the past five years, with more building than at any time in the last four years.
PARIS, May 11. -- It is believed in Paris financial circles that Wall Street's recovery probably will gather further momentum and that the soldiers' bonus, if enacted, will be a factor in the rise.
A model of a Mayan temple built in the eighth century and now concealed in almost impenetrable jungle will be placed on view today in the main lobby of the American Museum of Natural History.

CLEVELAND, May 12 (AP). -- A new railroad retirement law, to replace the one recently held invalid by the United States Supreme Court, will be drafted as one of the major activities of the quadrennial convention of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, which opens here tomorrow morning.

HASBROUCK HEIGHTS, N.J., May 12. -- William Picune, 19 years old, of 743 Thirty-fourth Street, North Bergen, who firmly believes that flying through the air with bat-like wings will be man's future diversion, tried out his theory today over Teterboro Airport.

The condition of the world is evil, and those who say that the world is a pretty good place after all are only deceiving themselves, according to the Rev. Dr. Frederic S. Fleming, rector of Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, in his sermon yesterday morning at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.

Communism was assailed yesterday morning by former Mayor John P. O'Brien and former Corporation Counsel Arthur J.W. Hilly, who spoke before 200 members of the McGivney Council 430, K. of C., at their annual communion breakfast in the Hotel Astor. The Ladies Auxiliary of the council also was represented.
Five persons were killed and thirteen were hurt in automobile accidents in and near the city yesterday.

The scientists have had their day, and the day of the great mystics is now dawning, Sir Francis Younghusband, British national chairman of the World Fellowship of Faiths, declared yesterday in an address at the Free Synagogue, Carnegie Hall. In announcing the speaker, Rabbi Stephen S. Wise described him as an explorer, author, statesman and empire builder.

DETROIT, May 12 (AP). -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, in a radio address prepared for delivery to his National Union for Social Justice tonight, appealed directly to President Roosevelt to sign the Patman Bonus Bill "in the name of the greatest lobby the people ever established."

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today the filing of sixteen additional registration statements under the Securities Act. The financial total was $81,393,720, of which $76,418,490 represented new issues.

The middle of May still finds the local exhibition field active, with more than a score of exhibitions on the calendar for the week. While there are no group exhibitions comparable in size to those which opened last week, there are several of special interest, and the local galleries are already beginning to put on Summer shows, which will continue until Autumn.

BERLIN, May 11. -- The Reich's taxation revenue for the last fiscal year exceeded estimates by more than a billion marks, receipts amounting to 8,217,000,000 marks, compared with expectations of 7,078,000,000 marks.

BERLIN, May 12. -- Germany's first "healers' festival week" opened today with an exposition purporting to show how nature healing can and should supplant medical science, which is regarded as under Jewish domination.
In the old days of the Corn Laws the Government had decided to raise the duties on imported wheat. The Prime Minister, in conference with members of the Cabinet, said, in substance:

BASLE, May 12. -- The board and management of the Bank for International Settlements presented today to Leon Fraser, who will retire from the presidency tomorrow, a gold bar from the vaults of the Swiss National Bank.

An investigation by the United States Senate Judiciary Committee of attempts to restrict freedom of the press, speech and assembly was urged yesterday in a joint statement signed by more than 250 prominent Protestant, Catholic and Jewish clergymen from all parts of the country.
WARSAW, May 12. -- Marshal Joseph Pilsudski died here at 8:35 o'clock tonight from cancer of the stomach and liver, which had caused hemorrhages yesterday. He was 67 years old.

WARSAW, Poland, May 12. -- Pierre Laval, French Foreign Minister, left here this morning for Moscow a very happy man, and Colonel Joseph Beck, Polish Foreign Minister, who on the departure wished him good luck, was also beaming with happiness.

James E. Finegan, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, yesterday sent out requests for early favorable action on the Ordway Reclassification Plan for "correcting inequities of pay and work in city positions without either reducing salaries or increasing tax burdens."

GOSPORT, England, May 12. -- Yankee, Gerard B. Lambert's America's Cup Class sloop, continued her fight with adverse winds today as she neared completion of her voyage across the Atlantic to participate in the British regattas.
Dartmouth's continued success in the Eastern Intercollegiate League and Manhattan's unexpected victory over N.Y.U. on Monday featured last week's competition in college baseball circles.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- A trekI from the dirt roots of farm political thought began trickling into Wash-i ington today for a mass demonstra-i tion Tuesday in support of the' agricultural adjustment program.

ALBANY, May 12. -- New minimums in death rates were established during the first three months of this year, according to Dr. J.V. De Porte, Director of Vital Statistics of the State Department of Health.

Proposals for the extensive construction work required to lay out the New York approach and plaza of the new Midtown Hudson Tunnel will he received on June 6, the Port Authority announced yesterday. The tunnel will be opened for traffic in 1938. It is being built with the aid of a $37,500,000 loan from the PWA.

A possibility that the thallium sulphate that killed the wife and four children of Frederick Gross, 49-year-old crippled bookkeeper charged with their murder, had been taken by all of them about the same time, although their deaths were days apart, developed yesterday as the investigation continued.
SEATTLE, May 12 (AP). -- A "put-out-the-cat derby" was announced today by Mayor Charles L. Smith, race track philosopher, who said that "a little foolishness is a delightful thing for the citizens."

NEW HAVEN, May 11. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices this week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 82.2, which compares with 82.1 the week before, 81.8 two weeks before, 81.5 three weeks before and 81.7 four weeks before. It is the highest since the last week of February.

After declining for six consecutive months, retail prices on May 1 showed no change as compared with April 1, although showing a decrease of 3.5 per cent under May 1 a year ago, according to the Fairchild Publications Retail Price Index.

A great Polish revolutionary patriot, Joseph Pilsudski lived to see most of his dreams, conceived in the early Eighties of the last century, come to fruition. He had longed for the establishment of a Poland commensurate to the Poland of the "golden age" of the fourteenth, fifteenth and sixteenth centuries.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- A total of 789,678 individual income tax returns for the calendar year of 1933 was filed through Dec. 31, 1934, by residents of counties, cities and townships in New York State having a population of 1,000 or more, as compared with 832,486 the year before, the Internal Revenue Bureau announced today.

The total traffic on rapid transit, surface railway and bus lines within the city limits in the year ended Dec. 31, 1934, amounted to 2,913,600,000 passengers, according to a report made public yesterday by the Transit Commission.

The biggest pitcher in baseball was hammered down to midget size yesterday at the Polo Grounds as the Giants took a parting slap at the Pirates to give Roy Parmelee his fourth victory in an unbroken string. By a count of 3 to 1 the Terrymen conquered Pie Traynor's band to the undisguised joy of a gathering of 20,000.

Removal of another well-known music publishing house to Rockefeller Center has been announced. The Edward B. Marks Music Corporation, for many years at 223-225 West Forty-sixth Street, has leased half of the sixth floor in the RCA Building through Sol Stern Co., brokers.

A decided trend away from the credit system appears to be developing in secondary education, the Rev. Charles J. Deane, S.J., dean of Fordham College, asserted yesterday at the fifth annual convocation of the faculty of Fordham University. Reports by Lafayette, Hamilton and Swarthmore Colleges indicate a tendency to return to the system of general courses and prescribed subject-matter, he said.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., May 12. -- Dr. Walter H. Brundage of Pelham, N.Y., captured the championship sweepstakes for saddle horses at the fifth annual horse show on the Lawridge estate today. Mrs. Brundage was up on the greatly improved gray mare Frosty Fairy to win the title and 50 per cent of the stake, giving her mount a splendid ride to top a good field.

In its homes, churches and public places the city marked Mother's Day yesterday. Millions in every section of every borough took part in the observance which had its centre in a hotel suite where two white-haired mothers chatted smilingly over cups of tea.

MOSCOW, May 12. -- On the eve of the arrival here of Pierre Laval, French Foreign Minister, for conversations with Joseph Stalin. Premier Vyacheslaff Molotoff and Foreign Commissar Maxim Litvinoff, it is evident in Soviet circles that no, sensational developments are to be expected.

MANILA, April 12. -- When the electors of the Philippine Islands go to the polls on May 14 to vote their approval or disapproval of the Constitution of the Philippine Commonwealth, they actually will engage in four plebiscites instead of one. The combination of curious drafting in the Tydings-McDuffie law and the political circumstances in the Philippines has added other issues to the constitutional question.

Secretary ICKES said in our Magazine section yesterday that the new Public Works Relief Bill, appropriating $4,880,000,000, would pay for the construction of nine Panama Canals. This is a more cheerful thought to carry away than Senator ICKES'S other statement that the new Public Works program "reaches proportions which make such enterprises as the building of the Pyramids and the construction of the Great Wall of China seem almost petty."

Presiding Justice John Warren Hill of the Domestic Relations Court announced yesterday formation of a public relations committee of citizens to help the court render social justice with the widest effectiveness. The members of the committee are as follows:

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May12 (AP). -- The Newark Bears strengthened their hold on first place in the International League by defeating the Rochester Red Wings in both ends of a double header today, 5 to 4 and 4 to 0.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 12. -- One of the features of Mother's Day services in Westchester County was a special ceremony this mOrning of the Men's Bartholow Bible Class, which joined the day's celebration with the thirtieth anniversary of the pastorate of the Rev Otho F. Bartholow, founder of the class, at Loew's Theatre here.

A four-run drive in the fourth inning enabled the New York Athletic Club baseball team to open its season with a 5-to-3 victory over the Manhattan College nine yesterday at Travers Island. Sparkling defensive play by the clubmen, who were outhit, 7 to 6, aided them to the triumph.

A four-run drive in the fourth inning enabled the New York Athletic Club baseball team to open its season with a 5-to-3 victory over the Manhattan College nine yesterday at Travers Island. Sparkling defensive play by the clubmen, who were outhit, 7 to 6, aided them to the triumph.

Organization of a nation-wide Catholic War Veterans Association was started yesterday with the announcement of the establishment of the first post of the association at the Church of the Immaculate Conception, Astoria, Queens.

If there had been any skeptics who really believed that an Eastern team had even a slight chance of halting the Big Three of the Pacific Coast in the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. track and field championships at Cambridge three weeks hence, performances over the weekend were enough to shatter this illusion beyond repair.
A big-game fisherman from Maine invaded the waters of Bimini last week in quest of giant marlin and succeeded in making one of the outstanding catches of this or any other season.

Washington is determined to annihilate and even dismember such enterprises as utilities and holding companies, employment-giving enterprises which have conquered world markets and brought vast wealth to America.

The current trend toward "allowing too much freedom to children" is resulting in a one-sided development that emphasizes worldly success rather than moral and spiritual attainment, the Rev. Dr. Anthony H. Evans said in his sermon yesterday morning at the West-Park Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., May 12. -- Religious observances and reverent contemplation of the storied past when Virginia was a crown colony and Williamsburg its capital today succeeded the gayeties of yesterday's opening of the first "Court Season" held here since the outbreak of the Revolution in America.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Proposed Senatorial investigation of Federal relief spending, spurred by alleged irregularities in New York, would find figures to show the cost of administration running about 10 cents on the dollar.

With fast action and hard riding predominating, the Governors Island poloists began their 1935 campaign by battling to an 8-all deadlock with the New York Athletic Club quartet at Morris Memorial Field, Governors Island, yesterday. A crowd of 1,500 saw the engagement.

The suggestion that Governor Lehman should appoint a special deputy attorney general to supersede District Attorney Dodge in the grand jury inquiry of policy and vice rackets was made yesterday by the Rev. George Drew Egbert, president of the Society for the Prevention of Crime, in a sermon at the First Congregational Church, Flushing, of which he is pastor.

NEWARK, N.J., May 12. -- Although defeated by the Pawtucket Rangers, 3 to 1, in the final game of the East vs. West soccer series today, the St. Louis Centrals captured the U.S.F.A. national challenge cup with a total of seven goals to six in the three contests.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Heavy increases in purchases of household equipment in ten Southeastern States listed by statisticians for the Agricultural Adjustment Administration were interpreted in a report today as reflecting improved conditions brought about by the AAA program.

A funeral service for Herbert Witherspoon, who died of a heart attack last Friday in his offices at the Metropolitan Opera House, will be held at 10 o'clock this morning at St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church in Stuyvesant Square. The officiating clergyman will be the rector, the Rev. Dr. Karl Reiland.
ALBANY, May 12. -- Deploring "dictatorship" in State and Federal governments, Irving M. Ires, Republican leader of the Assembly, tonight assailed Governor Lehman.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $7,533,760,480. They consist of Treasury bonds, consols, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

A warning of the likelihood of a dictatorship by either the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin or Senator Huey Long, or by the two in combination, was voiced by the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, the pastor, in his sermon yesterday morning at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-Ninth Street.
LONDON, Monday, May 13. -- The death of Marshal Pilsudski is deplored here as adding one more uncertainty to the European situation at a time when there are too many uncertainties.

Volunteers for the MacDowell Club benefit at the Town Hall this evening include Rose Bampton, Charles Hackett, Harold Bauer, Edwin Hughes, Ernest Schelling, Ruggiero Ricci, Fritz Reiner, George Raudenbush, Olin Downes and Walter Golde.

BALTIMORE, May 12. -- A post-Preakness consensus among horsemen, owners and racegoers has established William Woodward's Omaha as the dominant 3-year-old of 1935 on the strength of his victories in the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness.

On May 6 The Montreal Gazette reprinted an article from THE NEW YORK TIMES in which it was stated that "It costs the British public a great deal of money to maintain the royal family, but the expenditure seems worth while, when it creates and maintains this symbol of permanence of the great factors in English public life."

HAVANA, May 12. -- A summary court-martial of the nine men and two women, captured at Fort Morrillo near the city of Matanzas last Wednesday following a gun battle with government forces, in which the rebel band's leader, Dr. Antonio Guiteras, former Secretary of Interior, War and Navy, was killed, has been set by the military authorities for Tuesday at Matanzas.

VIENNA, May 12 (AP). -- Austrian police engaged in manoeuvres over the week-end to familiarize the Federal security force with the latest weapons and tactics for suppressing revolutionary disorders. Armored cars, machine guns, artillery and airplanes were brought into play in a sham battle at Bruckneudorf, held by a "rebel" force.
PHILADELPHIA, May 12 (AP). -- The Cardinals defeated the Phillies 10 to 8, before 7,000 fans today and divided the four-game series.

The industrial stocks that seem to be bearing the brunt of the buying are those with proven investment merit, rather than the low-priced speculative and "inflation" issues that advanced spectacularly in the boomlets of 1933 and 1934. Shares selling above 100 have been the most consistent gainers, moving up a point or two daily, while the large body of stocks has done little.

Outboard men talked shop yesterday around the boat yards and the yacht clubs, convinced still more that the Albany-to-New-York Marathon continues to rank as the stiffest as well as the most unusual sports contest afloat.

A variety of excuses was offered yesterday at a hearing before Charles B. Ash. chief of the Bureau of Mercantile Inspection, State Department of Labor, by night club and restaurant proprietors accused of working cigarette, hat check and other girl employes after 10 P.M.

MANILA, Tuesday, May 14. -- Filipinos voted at heavily guarded polls today as government leaders unanimously predicted overwhelming ratification of the Constitution for the ten-year Commonwealth government to function before complete independence from the United States.

The report of the Simms Petroleum Company and its subsidiary for the quarter ended on March 31 shows net income of $58,070, after taxes, intangible development costs, interest, depreciation, depletion and other charges. This is equivalent to 12 cents a share on 462,771 shares of capital stock, excluding 37,229 shares held in the treasury.

SYRACUSE, May 13. -- The second $92,000 income tax evasion trial of Arthur "Dutch Schultz" Flegenheimer will start in Malone on July 23. His case was taken from the local court on order from Judge Frederick H. Bryant of the Federal District Court.
At noon today the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse will present "The Last Wilderness," a film record of a Western hunt with bow and arrow.
Vox-popping is not a lucrative medium of self-expression, but today I am moved to say that even a favorite jester should recognize some limits of speech.
Mrs. Anne Morrow Lindbergh is the author of a book, to be published in the Fall, about the air junket of the Lindberghs to the Far East four years ago.

The St. Louis Southwestern Railway estimated that it would have a deficit of $97,000 after charges in 1935 in statements filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission. In 1934 it had a deficit of $1,145,437. For 1936 a net income of $183,000 was forecast, the company estimating that it would receive $249,000 in 1935 and $205,000 in 1936 from emergency freight surcharges.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):

A dusty locker in the Times Square subway station, opened yesterday with a key taken from Victor (The Count) Lustig, an E. Phillips Oppenheim character in the flesh, yielded $51,000 in counterfeit banknotes and the engraved plates from which they were printed.

BERLIN, May 13.. -- Germany today officially mourned Marshal Joseph Pilsudski as a great patriot and the father of his country, but it grieved even more for the statesman who established friendly relations between Poland and Germany and was depended upon to keep them friendly despite all efforts to draw Poland into anti-German combinations.

Sir Charles Marston, British archaeologist, announced last night that fresh light had been thrown on the Lachish letters found last January at Tell Duweir, believed to be the ancient biblical city of Lachish, twenty-five miles south of Jerusalem.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- President Roosevelt was reported to have finished a message vetoing the bonus which is said to have satisfied leaders' desires for a ringing appeal. He conferred with Senators Nye, Clark and Pittman and Secretary Hull on arms embargo and neutrality questions in connection with legislation.

Aside from a fairly sharp spurt in prices for second-grade railroad bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday, investment attention turned rather clearly to the tax-exempt field. United States Government obligations rallied 3-32 to 9-32 point.

The city of St. Louis, Mo., announced yesterday that it would open bids on May 28 on a new issue of $1,800,000 relief bonds. They will be dated June 1 and will mature on June 1, 1941-45, with an optional date of June 1, 1940. Bidders were invited to suggest their own coupon rate.

CHICAGO, May 13. -- Good rains in Kansas, as much as three inches falling in sections where the Winter wheat crop could be materially benefited, and further favorable reports from the Northwest resulted in fairly general liquidation today on the part of holders of futures i in the wheat pit on the Board of Trade and prices dropped almost 2 cents a bushel from Saturday's finish before the downturn was checked.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 13. -- Eighteen Summer scholarships for eight weeks of study at the University of Heidelberg and eight for four weeks of study at the University of Munich have been awarded to Vassar students.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Drastic changes in the code for the cement industry, including the elimination of the provisions for allocation of output, for control of new plant construction and increases in capacity, for customer classification and for prohibition of sales below cost were approved today by the National Industrial Recovery Board, effective May 21.

Coming by bus, by automobile and by train, delegations of farmers are now moving on Washington to befriend or to criticize AAA. That organization, one of the first of the New Deal agencies to be set up in the feverish Spring of 1933, celebrates its second birthday this week.

MOSCOW, May 13. -- A new Eastern pact to take the place of the original "Eastern Locarno" project, which failed because of Polish and German objections, was discussed today by Pierre Laval, French Foreign Minister, and Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Foreign Commissar, in the first of a series of conversations for which M. Laval arrived here today.

Casting their heaviest vote in several decades, members of the New York Stock Exchange elected yesterday Charles R. Gay of Whitehouse Co. to succeed Richard Whitney as president and partly repudiated the New Deal in the management of the Exchange by choosing three independent candidates for places on the governing committee over three regular nominees.

Frederic G. Carnochan, ethnologist, returned yesterday from Africa with some curious reports on native customs there. He has spent fifteen years studying these customs. He arrived here from England on the American Banker.

TOKYO, May 13. -- The most ambitious social experiment Japan has yet made in the cultivation of American friendship began today with the arrival of 114 representatives of the American Garden Club, led by Mrs. Jonathan Bulkley of Ridgefield, Conn.

LONDON, May 13 (Canadian Press). -- Middlesex gained its second straight victory of the county cricket season today, defeating Worcester by four wickets at Lord's. The match was a low-scoring affair, the visitors scoring 114 and 146, Middlesex replying with 161 and 100 for six wickets.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-one leading cities on May 8 shows decreases for the week of $171,000,000 in total loans and investments, $171,000,000 in net demand deposits, $17,000,000 in time deposits and $71,000,000 in government deposits, and an increase of $24,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

Forty-six feature pictures will be produced during the new season by Republic Pictures, W. Ray Johnston, president of the new film corporation, announced yesterday. Four of the new productions will get under way this month. They are "Forbidden Heaven," with Charles Farrell and Charlotte Henry; "Westward Ho!", a John Wayne picture, which will be filmed in Utah; "Two Black Sheep," by Warwick Deeping, and "My Old Kentucky Home," suggested by the song.

GENEVA. May 13. -- "At this critical hour in its history the Ethiopian Government earnestly appeals to the Council to see that the territorial integrity and political independence of Ethiopia, a member of the League of Nations, are respected and preserved as against aggression," says a note from Addis Ababa, dated May 11, released by the League Secretariat today.

BASLE, Switzerland, May 13. -- World conditions have now become such that a general return to gold would serve to raise instead of lower prices, Leon Fraser holds in his annual report as president of the Bank for International Settlements, which he submitted to the bank's general assembly here this afternoon.
I wish to take issue with some of the statements made by Louis H. Pink, newly appointed Superintendent of Insurance of the State of New York, in an address over WNYC.

Sweeping criticisms of the New Deal were made public yesterday in the annual social service report approved at the New York East Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, which is meeting at Central Church, Hanson Place and St. Felix Street, Brooklyn.

LONDON, May 12. -- The Economist's fortnightly index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood on May 8 at 67.2. This compares with 66.7 a fortnight before, 66.4 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- The New Deal, in its first two years of operation, has been a costly and complete failure, Bertrand N. Snell, Republican floor leader, told the House today during general debate on the legislative appropriation bill, and has strained the credit of the government to the breaking point.
WASHINGTON, May 13. -- A decision to withdraw in the Senate tomorrow the Thomas motion to reconsider the Patman bonus bill was reached at a meeting of the bonus advocates tonight.

Barring prosecutors of the staff of District Attorney William C. Dodge, members of the hold-over March New York County grand jury resumed yesterday their investigation of the policy and other rackets. It heard testimony by Thomas F. Kane, a former Tammany Assistant District Attorney, and Austin H. MacCormick, Commissioner of Corrections.

MOSCOW, May 13. -- Marshal Pilsudski's death cannot fail to overshadow this week's Franco-Soviet conversations. It was already no secret that the visit to Moscow of Foreign Minister Laval of France had no immediate concrete aims, but was rather, as a high French authority said this morning, "a manifestation of friendship and of a desire to build a lasting edifice of collaboration for peace on the foundation provided by the recently signed pact."

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 13. -- Paradisical, acquired from the Wood F. Axton estate dispersal, qualified handsomely for her Kentucky Oaks engagement when she won the Crab Orchard Purse, today's feature attraction at Churchill Downs.

This, again, is a week that serves to bring forward several group exhibitions -- though nothing to compare in size with the big Allied Artists of America and Salons of America shows, already current. These two attractions, by the way, are to be found at the American Fine Arts Building and the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, remaining until, respectively, May 30 and my 25.

A 6-year-old New Jersey boy won high honors yesterday afternoon in the first audition in the metropolitan division of the annual National Piano Playing Tournament, sponsored by the National Piano Teachers Guild, at Steinway Hall.

More than 3,000 drivers and sweepers of the Department of Sanitation were informed by Louis Waldman, counsel for the Joint Council of Drivers and Sweepers, that Mayor La Guardia had approved their efforts to organize for collective bargaining.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., May 13. -- Vincent Richards's career on the lawn tennis courts is at an end.

John Marcelline, national A.A.U. champion from the Mason A.C. of Philadelphia, outpointed Joseph Wawll, Salem-Crescent A.C. star, in the 112-pound intercity special at the New York Athletic Club's final indoor amateur boxing show at its city house last night.

LONDON, Tuesday, May 14. -- Former Aircraftsman T. E. Shaw, who as Colonel Thomas E. Lawrence was known to all the world as "Lawrence of Arabia," was desperately injured in an accident on his motor cycle yesterday and is now lying at death's door in the military hospital at Bovington Camp, Dorset.
Summer has come, and with it has arrived Patsy Grazzianni, the genial hot-dog vendor of Washington Square.

An entire floor in the Times Circle Building at 333-9 West Fifty-second Street has been leased by Blancard Co., manufacturers of wedding rings, from the Adanfa Construction Company, S. L. Snyder, president, through the Herbert McLean Purdy Management Corporation.

Divisions of the dress industry began working yesterday under the provisions of the administrative or der issued last week by the NRA placing all dresses of chief content of cotton or linen up to and including the range at $22.50 per dozen under the Cotton Garment Code Authority, and those above $22.50 per dozen under the Dress Code Authority.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, May 13. -- An attempt by Germany to get an advantage in the Brazilian market through the use of blocked and compensated marks was upset today. The Federal Council on Foreign Trade issued an order calling for a free money market, intended to apply to all nations.

TRENTON, N.J., May 13. -- A resolution to submit to the voters a question of permitting pari-mutuel betting was adopted tonight by the New Jersey Assembly, 32 to 25. Twice before, the resolution had been moved, but each time failed to receive sufficient support.

ALBANY, May 13. -- The house of delegates of the Medical Society of the State of New York, representing 14,000 physicians in this State, adopted a resolution today urging the house of delegates of the American Medical Association to make a careful and thorough study of birth control and its related problems.
Restrictions in the amount of advertising permissible in radio programs is part of a three-cornered plan to be established by the Columbia Broadcasting System, effective July 30.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 13. -- More than 300 delegates of the National Association of Junior Leagues, assembled here today for their fifteenth annual conference, were told they were "at the end of the trail" by Chester H. Powell, editor of The San Francisco Chronicle.

A concert that drew a large audience was presented by a group of artists at the Town Hall last night for the benefit of the MacDowell Club, which suffered losses recently as a result of a fire in the clubhouse at 166 East Seventy-third Street. A distinguished committee sponsored the program, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt heading the list.

ST. LOUIS, May 13 (AP). -- Pelts stripped during pioneer days to build the Midwestern fur empire of Robert Campbell, explorer and Indian trader, ultimately will enrich Yale University by $1,200,000 under a decision handed down in Circuit Court here today.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Compensation of $80,000 was paid in 1934 to James H. Jourdan, president of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, while Clifford E. Paige and F.C. Weber, vice presidents, received $45,000 and $19,000 respectively, the company's registration statement to the Securities and Exchange Commission showed today.

The New York County May grand jury began an investigation yesterday into new allegations that John Flaherty, former secretary to City Court Justice Lippe and former Tammany election district captain in Greenwich Village, defrauded more than 200 aspirants for city jobs of about $200,000 in recent years.

Samples of the putty-colored dust that has been sweeping the Middle West and the Southwest will be exhibited next week at the American Museum of Natural History, it was announced last night by Dr. Chester A. Reeds, curator of the museum's Geology Department.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 13. -- Construction of seven naval vessels and an oil tanker, all valued at $50,000,000, was stopped today when more than 4,000 employes of the New York Shipbuilding Company went on strike to enforce their demands, which include a 15 per cent wage increase, a "preferential" shop and abolition of piecework.

Through its publisher, Lawrence E. Spivak, The American Mercury informed the Regional Labor Board yesterday that it could not comply with the board's order to reinstate seven of the magazine's employes who were discharged recently. Five of the seven went on strike when two were dismissed for alleged inefficiency on April 29.
Because of an interruption of about forty years in his career as an artist, Lee Lash is having his first one-man exhibition at the age of 71.

The most important purpose of society is to prepare the newly born for citizenship. We must give them ideals and a steady background. Our modern society has failed in its purpose. The child is the future citizen, but factors such as the following are detrimental to his coming behavior.

HANOVER, N.H., May 13. -- Behind the stellar pitching of Ted Olson and Joe Jayne, Dartmouth took both ends of a double-header with Princeton today, 4 to 2 and 4 to 1. Dartmouth remains undefeated at the top of the Eastern Intercollegiate League.

Louisiana swamps may harbor the biggest frogs in the country, but that is no reason why Louisiana frogs should have a virtual monopoly in honoring MARK TWAIN'S memory. One hundred animals have been brought from HUEY LONG'S State by airplane for next Sunday's all-Eastern jumping trials in Central Park.

Five young men and a young woman, accused of having staged an opposition demonstration during a parade of junior military and naval organizations Sunday in Van Cortlandt Park, were arraigned yesterday in the Bronx magistrates' court.

By way of proving that it was not done with mirrors the first time, Manhattan College again upset N.Y.U. yesterday and in slightly more emphatic fashion. The Jaspers administered to the Violets their second defeat of the year and handed Bill Gottlieb, pride of the New York pitching staff, his initial setback of the baseball campaign.

In Washington the first days of heat always start discussions of the date when Congress will adjourn. President TAFT once remarked with a chuckle that there was nothing in the Constitution about hot weather shortening a session of Congress, but that the effect was there just the same.

Hal Price Headley's Tinkling Brook, which had scored impressively earlier in the meeting, again showed her fleet heels to a field of seven other juvenile fillies when she captured the featured Coquette Purse, at five furlongs, at Jamaica yesterday.

Aldermanic President Bernard S. Deutsch said yesterday that he would oppose an additional appropriation of $10,000 for the Aldermanic Committee Investigating Relief, but would favor a $2,000 appropriation to permit preparation of its report.

ALBANY, May 13. -- Governor Lehman vetoed today the Fitzgerald bill which would have automatically put under civil service status 20,000 New York City subway employes of private companies when and if transit unification were achieved.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- For reasons best known to the President and itself, the White House secretariat told newspaper men this morning that all the members of the week-end fishing party on the Blue Ridge confined themselves to sport and human companionship and never mentioned such matters as the bonus or the legislative stalemate in the Senate.

A news item in THE TIMES was headed: "Washington Square Plan Wins," and proceeded: "Greenwich Village has all but capitulated to the plans of the Park Department for the reconstruction of Washington Square, it became known yesterday." That was not the fact "yesterday," nor will it be a fact hereafter.

The outstanding feature of the Junior Leagues of America is that they do not exist primarily or even incidentally for "society" functions or their own social enjoyments. Their purpose is to help forward good causes -- to aid their members in becoming "permanently interested and active in community service" through local welfare agencies.
The State Mortgage Commission moved yesterday to assume control of all of the $781,000,000 of certified mortgage issues of the guaranty and title companies in rehabilitation liquidation.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Secretary Morgenthau's discussion of monetary policy in his radio address tonight is expected in diplomatic circles to lead directly to a fresh study of stabilization possibilities in the countries concerned and then to tentative soundings through diplomatic and financial channels of the prospects for a concerted move along this line.

Most commodity futures were firm and fairly active yesterday despite weakness in grains and cotton. Sugar futures were the chief weak spot. On the cash markets all the grains, cotton, dairy products and cocoa declined, while silk and rubber rose and lead made a new high price.

ABOARD U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA, Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, May 13. -- Twenty ships of the base force of the United States fleet, commanded by Rear Admiral Watt Tyler Cluverius, steamed into Pearl Harbor this morning, ending the cruise that began at San Pedro, Calif., May 3.
Money market remained at a standstill so far as business and variation in rates were concerned. Turnover was light, and quotations unchanged for all classifications.

If it is true coming events cast their shadows before, the Giants have a depressing future as far as St. Louis is concerned. The Terrymen met the world champions yesterday at the Polo Grounds for the first time this season, and the Cardinals picked up where they left off in the spectacular pennant fight that closed the 1934 race.

LONDON, May 13 (AP). -- Hobbling on a stone-bruised heel, Lawson Little, American and British amateur golf champion, put on his carpet slippers again today -- and British rooters, remembering a similar prelude to last year's amateur championship, saw their hopes of bagging the title bunkered again.
WASHINGTON, May 13. -- The text of Secretary Morgenthau's radio speech was as follows:
WARSAW, May 13. -- The death of Marshal Josef Pilsudski yesterday was a personal loss for millions of Poles. The mourning is general.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- In a last-minute effort to swing the Senate into line for his proposed investigation of Postmaster General Farley, Senator Long submitted in open session today an affidavit signed by a New York woman charging the Cabinet member with criminal acts in connection with Federal building contracts, including participation in a fraud against the government on the New York Court House.
Plans of two six-story apartment houses to be built in Manhattan and Jamaica were filed with the Building Department yesterday. Each house is estimated to cost $100,000.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., May 13. -- Celestin Durand of the Garden City Golf Club and Jimmy Hines of the Garden City Country Club collaborated well in scoring a 70 to gain a tie for first honors in the amateur-pro tournament of the Long Island Golf Association today at the Rockville Country Club.
WASHINGTON, May 13. -- The affidavit submitted by Senator Long today in his demand for an investigation of Postmaster General Farley read as follows:

Transformation of the residential mortgage business of commercial banks and other large financial institutions dealing in short-term loans into a "sound and conservative method of instalment home-buying" is being brought about gradually but surely under the mutual mortgage insurance plan of the FHA, Acting Administrator Stewart McDonald reports.

Plaques of the National Safety Council in the 1934 railroad employes' safety contest, in which all Class I steam roads participated, were awarded last night to eight Class I railroads and one Pullman Company zone. They were bestowed at a dinner in the Hotel Pennsylvania "for outstanding safety achievement." About seventy officials of railroad companies were present.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP). -- The AAA allotted today the 1935 continental beet-sugar marketing quota of 1,550,000 short tons to twenty-seven processing companies after creating a reserve of 225,000 bags for further allotment.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Application for permission to extend for five years $7,783,000 in loans with the RFC which mature during the present year was filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission today by the Illinois Central Railroad Company.
Deals by operators featured the Bronx real estate activity reported yesterday.
ROME, May 13 (AP). -- A vast system of coupons -- which in effect will give Italy registered lire similar to Germany's registered marks -- will become operative shortly, it was learned today.

Mail reorders received here yesterday from stores in the West and South were quite heavy and showed an increase over the preceding week, resident buyers reported yesterday. Business from stores in the East, however, was not particularly good.

PORTSMOUTH, England, May 13. -- Gerard B. Lambert's racing sloop Yankee was anchored in the Roads at Cowes tonight, having been towed the last few miles of her voyage from the United States by T.O.M. Sopwith's motor yacht Vita.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 13. -- Arthur M. Collens was elected president of the Phoenix Mutual Life Insurance Company today by the directors. He succeeds the late Archibald A. Welch. He has been a vice president of the company.

It is a matter of congratulation for the community that it has one newspaper with the wisdom to understand the position of Colonel Wilgus in the work relief. Your editorial expression of appreciation for his efforts is a well-deserved tribute to a man who made a great personal sacrifice for the benefit of the citizens of New York and whose efforts have been either consciously or unconsciously subjected to ridicule by the aldermanic investigation.

An increase of 26 per cent in the attendance at the Polo Grounds for the first four weeks of this season as compared to an equivalent period last year is indicative of a marked improvement in business conditions, Ford Frick, president of the National League, declared yesterday at a luncheon of the Advertising Men's Post, American Legion.

The theory on which 23,000 holders of Insull debentures are attempting to recover $30,000,000 from five New York banks and the General Electric Company came into violent collision with the joint brief of the banks yesterday in the Federal court, when Judge Julian W. Mack began to hear oral argument on the seven weeks of testimony taken during March and April.

Taxicabs in New York City would be limited to 10,000 and their yearly license fees would be raised from $10 to $40 each under proposed legislation filed with the Board of Aldermen yesterday by Alderman Lester Baum, Manhattan Republican.

The Board of Education will strongly recommend reductions in the sizes of classes in all schools in submitting its 1936 budget to the Board of Estimate. This was announced last night by Colonel Walter Jeffreys Carlin, chairman of the board's committee on finance and budget, at a public meeting of the committee in the Board of Education building, Park Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street.

Upon the nomination of thirty-eight senior resident members, Actors Equity Association has forwarded to its members an "independent" ticket of nominees for its council to be voted upon at the annual election on May 27. The names listed on the independent ticket are Burgess Meredith, Sam Jaffe, Hugh Rennie, Zita Johann, Alexander Kirkland, Morris Carnovsky, Margaret Barker, J.E. Bromberg, Jack Byrne, Mary Virginia Farmer, Charles Brokaw, Edward Everett Hale and John Kline.

Police and Federal agents working in Queens, Brooklyn and New Jersey, arrested four men and a woman yesterday and announced they had solved not only a Newburgh (N.Y.) bank robbery and a resultant "ride" murder but had caught one of the participants in the spectacular $50,200 hold-up of the Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company branch at Avenue D and Tenth Street last September.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP). -- A diet rich in meat relieves headaches, the convention of the American Psychiatric Association was told here today by Dr. Eugene Foldes of New York City.

RENO, Nev., May 13. -- Barbara Hutton, Woolworth heiress, and Prince Alexis Mdivani were divorced here today and preparations were reported in progress tonight for Miss Hutton's marriage tomorrow to Count Kurt von Haugwitz-Reventlow of Denmark.

Joseph Held, a 51-year-old relief worker, got a letter from the Works Division of the Emergency Relief Bureau last Friday telling him he would be dropped from relief this week. At noon yesterday he arrived at City Hall with the letter in one pocket and stones in another.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP). -- The Supreme Court pounded home anew today its fiat that Negroes may not be excluded from juries, but failed to rule on two important laws -- NIRA and the farm mortgage moratorium.
ST. LOUIS, May 13 (AP). -- The Browns slipped into a tie with the Athletics for last place in the American League by dropping a 2-to-1 decision today to the Red Sox.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 13. -- Crippled children and the aged poor are the principal beneficiaries under the will of Alfred I. du Pont of Delaware and Florida, who died at his estate, Epping Forest, here, on April 29 after an illness of a few days.

A committee for holders of bonds of the Pressed Steel Car Company, which entered bankruptcy last June, announced that it had filed yesterday in the Federal Court in Pittsburgh a plan of reorganization based on a $2,000,000 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and the raising of $506,031 through the sale of securities.

Plans are nearing completion for a $600,000 building to house the Family Court division of Domestic Relations Court, Presiding Justice John Warren Hill disclosed yesterday. The new structure would take the place of the seventy-two-year-old Family Court building at 153 East Fifty-seventh Street, which has been repeatedly condemned as a firetrap.

THERE are five clubs with an average of better than .500 in the American League now. It's a tight fit in the first division and probably conditions will grow worse because Gordon Stanley Cochrane, the Man in the Iron Mask, has every intention of moving his Detroit Tigers up there when the weather improves.

David Irwin, the Sarcoxie, Mo., youth who went to the Far North in search of adventure and found it, arrived in New York last night for a visit before returning to his home. He stepped off a train at Grand Central Station with two of the four dogs that pulled his sled on a 2,000-mile trek alone from Alaska to Hudson Bay.

A can of cocoa from the home of Fredrick Gross has been analyzed and found to contain thallium sulphate, the little-known poison with which the 49-year-old bookkeeper is alleged to have ended the lives of his wife and four of their five children, District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Kings County disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Amended in several important ways, including the addition of a new section authorizing the Securities and Exchange Commission to waive the 1942 "death sentence" on holding companies, the Utilities Control Bill was adopted today by the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee which later filed in the Senate a dummy report.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 13. -- Trowbridge Callaway gave a dinner tonight in the Colonnades at the Greenbrier to celebrate Mrs. Callaway's birthday. Guests included Mr. and Mrs. Ralph T. Crane, Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Hornblower and Mr. and Mrs. Alden H. Little.
DETROIT, May 13. -- The Yankees' first appearance of the year on Navin Field today seemed to have a very inspiring influence on most everybody in Detroit except the Yanks.

Eighty-eight professionals and twenty amateurs qualified for the national open golf championship in country-wide sectional play on twenty-four courses yesterday, and only a scattering few prominent stars of the game failed to make the grade.

The first mid-season furniture market in this city for almost a decade got under way successfully yesterday at the New York Furniture Exchange, Inc., 206 Lexington Avenue. More than 550 buyers, most of them from stores outside the city, came in to view the new merchandise.

The circumstances of Marshal PILSUDSKI'S death may furnish at least part of the explanation for recent major developments in Poland's domestic affairs and foreign relations. The secret of his fatal illness was so well guarded that the outside world felt free to comment on the "coldness" of the French Foreign Minister's reception in Warsaw.
A few minutes devoted to simple multiplication and addition indicates that the dime chain-letter epidemic has such vast possibilities that it should not be dismissed too lightly.
If the public will make an effort to get the inner viewpoint of the New Dealers, much of the controversial criticism will disappear.
ALBANY, May 13. -- The McCall Anti-Nudism Bill, urged by former Governor Smith and assailed by various groups as too drastic, was signed today by Governor Lehman.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Cooperation with private utilities, continued regulation by utilities commissions, but not government ownership or control of power companies are provided under a tentative plan for carrying on the $100,000,000 rural electrification phase of the government's huge work relief program.

TOLEDO, Ohio, May 13. -- By a vote of 732 to 385, striking employes of the Chevrolet Motor Company agreed tonight to return to work on the terms arranged at a conference yesterday morning between officers of the General Motors Corporation and labor leaders.
PHILADELPHIA, May 13 (AP). -- Cy Blanton, young right-handed star of the Pirates, allowed the Phillies only four hits today and won his fifth game of the season, 10 to 1.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., May 13. -- After today's matches at the Briar Hills Country Club, it was fairly well assured that the Westchester Country Club will represent the Westchester division when the intersectional club winners of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association meet on July 15.

Dr. Albert Einstein was the guest of honor last night at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria arranged by a large committee of leaders in various fields, each of whom had contributed at least $25 for the relief of children of refugees from Germany.

WASHINGTON, May 13, (A.P). -- Professor Edwin W. Kemmerer of Princeton University, an international financial authority, told a Senate banking sub-committee today that payment of the bonus with new currency would be a "calamity."
SHORT HILLS, N.J., May 13. -- Big, blond-haired Craig Wood, forced to qualify for a place in the National Open by his unfortunate disqualification at Merion last year, did a grand job of it today.

CHICAGO, May 13. -- Charles R. Walgreen gave for the first time today a public explanation of the "radical influences" which caused him to withdraw his niece, Miss Lucille Norton of Seattle, from her classes at the University of Chicago.

An application for a charter was filed in Albany yesterday by Women Investors in America, Inc., as a national organization of women representing "an outgrowth of a nationally spreading interest of women in financial and social problems and representative of a new consciousness of the need of united action so that the principles upon which the United States of America was founded may be preserved."

PRINCETON, N.J., May 13. -- The 123d commencement of Princeton Theological Seminary will close tomorrow morning at 10:30 o'clock with graduation exercises in Alexander Hall on the Princeton University campus. Dr. J. Ross Stevenson, president of the seminary, will confer the degrees of Bachelor of Theology and Master of Theology on a class of seventy.

The New York Public Library will celebrate this month the fortieth anniversary of the consolidation of the Astor and Lenox Libraries and the Tilden Trust. An exhibition, "Forty Years of the Library," will be opened at the Central Building, Forty-second Street at Fifth Avenue, on May 23.
Gabby Hartnett and Freddy Lindstrom ruined the day for Casey Stengel and 7,000 fans at Ebbets Field yesterday as the Cubs subdued the Dodgers, 3 to 2.

For the decade beginning with 1925 and ending with 1934, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday, the average annual return on the investment in the steel industry in the United States was 2.5 per cent, or 37 1/2 per cent less than the funds would have earned in savings banks paying average dividends of 4 per cent. The institute's statement read in part as follows:

Patriots, doubtless by arrangement with other patriots, have been raining telegrams into the White House begging or commanding Mr. ROOSEVELT not to veto the Patman Bonus Bill. The politico-clerical charmer of Detroit diffuses the same sort of message, half-entreaty and half-threat.

Joseph Dunninger, chairman of the investigating committee of the Universal Council for Psychic Research, last night challenged Margery, Boston medium, to produce by supernatural means any spiritualistic phenomenon. Mr. Dunninger said he was ready to go to Boston at any time, attend a seance held under the medium's own conditions and pay her $10,000 if he could not, by trickery, reproduce anything she professed to have accomplished supernaturally.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- The vanguard of 3,000 farmers from the "grass roots" of the prairies and the controlled-crop cotton fields of the South slept in Washington tonight in preparation for a big day tomorrow when, with money in their pockets for the first time in years, they will join others to come in singing the praises of the New Deal farm policy and in seeing the sights of the nation's capital.

Polo is bringing one of its 1935 championships as close as polo can be brought to Manhattan Island. This year's college tournament, according to an announcement yesterday by the Intercollegiate Polo Association, will be played next month on Morris Memorial Field at Governors Island, almost within the shadows of the skyscrapers of lower Manhattan.
Allie Rowan, 133 1/2, Jersey City, gained the decision over Paolo Villa, 133 1/2, Harlem, in the feature six-round battle at the St. Nicholas Palace last night before a crowd of 3,000.

BERLIN, May 13. -- The Boerse was weaker today on various rumors regarding the tribute which industry may be forced to pay to Germany's export subsidy fund. Heavy industrials weakened throughout on reports regarding the sacrifices they will be called on to make in the foreign "dumping" program.

Following the appearance of more selling orders on the New York Cotton Exchange at the close of last week, prices showed yesterday the effects of further pressure and closed with losses of 8 to 15 points. Trading proved fairly active within a limited range of fluctuations, most operations being incidental to sales of pool cotton to the trade and necessary swapping between months.

BERLIN, May 13. -- The first exterior consequence of Marshal Josef Pilsudski's death seems likely to be the postponement of the crucial speech on Germany's international policy which Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler planned to deliver before the specially assembled Reichstag late this week.

The final concourse of the year at the Art Students League includes some 700 items -- work in oils, pencil, charcoal, pen-and-ink drawings, etchings, lithographs, woodcuts, illustrations, water-colors, plaster and bronze. So numerous are the examples shown that it has been found necessary to put up temporary screens to serve as partitions and add wall space in the league gallery, which has become a rather overwhelming spectacle for the week.

MATANUSKA VALLEY, Alaska, May 13. -- Weary after their long journey by land and sea from Minnesota, but well content, the first of the Alaska colonists are settling down happily in their new surroundings.

BOSTON, May 13 (AP). -- Silas Johnson pitched the Reds to a 3-to-1 victory over the Braves today in the opening game of their series. The triumph broke a four-game losing streak for the Reds. It was the fourth straight defeat for Boston.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 13. -- Tulips were the predominating blooms of the annual Spring flower show of the New Rochelle Garden Club held here today at the New Rochelle Public Library. The show will be continued tomorrow.
The first rod-and-reel catches of weakfish have been reported from Peconic Bay.

The Merchants Association of New York announced yesterday that it would intervene before the Interstate Commerce Commission in opposition to an action begun by the Port of Albany to obtain an increase in differentials on commercial freight to and from Albany below the rates for the Port of New York.

CHICAGO, May 13. -- The Chicago Bar Association was the scene of shouting and bitterness at a luncheon today when Thomas D. Schall, the blind Senator from Minnesota, made a severe attack on President Roosevelt.

The Park Department has been busy for the past few days creating a rural atmosphere in the form of a portable farm for the benefit of city children who have never heard a chicken cluck to her chicks or felt the velvet nose of a calf.

Lyman W. Crossman, 17-year-old captain of the Barnard School tennis team, successfully began the defense of his Athletic Association of Private Schools championship as the twentieth annual tournament got under way on the courts of the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills yesterday.

Federal and State revenues from the sale of liquor and issuance of licenses amounted to $490,574,893 in 1934, according to the most complete compilation of figures it has been possible for Dr. James M.
