Doran, administrator of the Distilled Spirits Institute and the National Distillers Products Corporation, to compile.

BALTIMORE, May 13. -- The Maryland Public Service Commission approved today the plan of a bondholders' committee for reorganization of the United Railways and Electric Company, operating street railway and bus lines in this city. However, before the reorganization can be put into effect the United States District Court here must rule on a series of objections filed by a stockholder.

GLEN COVE, L.I., May 13. -- Staging a brilliant recovery on the inward nine, after trailing by two holes at the turn, Mrs. Leo Federman, New York State champion, conquered Mrs. James McMillen of North Hempstead, 3 and 2, today to lead Lakeville to another victory in the Long Island interclub play of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- The Mellon tax case, in which the government contends that the former Secretary of the Treasury owes over $3,000,000 in taxes for 1931, entered a final phase today when the merger in that year of the McClintic-Marshall Company with the Bethlehem Steel Corporation was taken up by the Board of Tax Appeals on the question of stock valuation.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13. -- A plea for honest politics, a warless world, birth control and sterilization of the unfit was made by Mrs. Rudolph Blankenburg, widow of Philadelphia's reform Mayor, as 3,000 women paid tribute to her at a luncheon today, her ninetieth birthday anniversary.

CHICAGO, May 13. -- All interests were in the market for supplies of hogs here today. More favorable reports regarding the demand for fresh pork were a factor. Prices advanced 10 to 25 cents a hundredweight, with the top 10 cents higher than that of last Friday at $9.35, and the average 10 cents higher at $9.10.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP). -- Mayor La Guardia of New York discussed the city's relief and housing plans today with Federal officials during another of his flying visits.
Forty-six additional listed companies applied yesterday to the New York Stock Exchange for permanent registration under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.

MONTREAL, May 13 (AP). -- Pete Appleton scored his fourth straight victory today as he pitched the Montreal Royals to a 5 to 3 decision over the Newark Bears in the series' opener. Appleton's only defeat was in his first start of the International League campaign.

Now that he no longer fears competition, since the college year is drawing to an end, William Hadley, a freshman residing in the John Jay dormitory of Columbia College is willing to reveal the secrets of his career as Columbia's first professional "sitter-in," as he modestly describes himself.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- An invitation to the nations of the world to initiate a move for foreign exchange stabilization was extended tonight by Secretary Morgenthau in a country-wide radio address. He stated that if this goal was sought on some practical basis, "Washington will not be an obstacle."

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., May 13. -- With pomp and ceremony at the restored Colonial Capitol and dancing at a public ball held at the other end of Duke of Gloucester Street, Virginia's three-day celebration of the first "court season" held here since her Crown Colony days came to an end tonight.

Charity will eventually receive most of the estate Amelia A. Meyers, widow of Abraham Meyers, it was learned yesterday when her will was filed in Surrogates' Court. Mrs. Meyers died last Aug. 30. The value of her estate was not disclosed.

Displaying fairly uniform steadiness throughout the day, the share market proceeded yesterday to an irregularly higher closing, the average gain amounting to approximately 1/2 point. The trading volume on the Stock Exchange, while it exceeded 1,100,000 shares, was some 450,000 less than on Friday, due to early languor, although in the later dealings the pace quickened under the leadership of automotive stocks.

SOME twenty-five years ago Clifford W. Beers, writing with an almost intolerably vivid memory of his three years of insanity, set down the remarkable story of "A Mind That Found Itself." William James read it in manuscript and marveled at the author's prose and personality alike. A crusader who had lived to tell the tale of padded cell and straitjacket, Mr. Beers meant his book to be the "Uncle Tom's Cabin" of the insane.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- A warning that the expenditure of Code Authority funds for trade association purposes without specific code authorization would not be approved was sounded today by the National Industrial Recovery Board in a letter to all Code Authorities.

BERLIN, May 14. -- Prices on the Boerse fell further today on additional reports regarding the financing of the government's export subsidy program scheduled to go into operation this Summer. Rumors that the program will amount to confiscation of profits for the benefit of exporters continued to have a depressing effect on the market.

Mr. MORGENTHAU'S declaration that when the world "is ready to seek for"eign exchange stabilization, Washing"ton will not be an obstacle," does not carry the matter far forward. After adding that "we are not unwilling to stabilize," he coupled with the statement that, if the other nations choose to continue the present condition of international exchanges, we shall be at no disadvantage.
BATON ROUGE, La., May 14 (AP). -- Theodore S. Landry, chairman of the Louisiana Tax Commission, said today that Senator Long had been retained as attorney to collect "back taxes" owed to the State.

Numerous business leases to retailers and wholesalers in the textile field were reported by brokers yesterday. Among the other tenants were Visitours, Inc., organized late last year to cater to the "luxury" tourist trade in this city. The corporation, headed by Nelson A. Loomis, will occupy quarters in the new International Building in Rockefeller Center this month.

IDABEL, Okla., May 14 (AP). -- A cool-headed bank clerk, who argued successfully with his abductor while bullets spattered about them, told tonight of a gun battle in which a convict-bank robber was wounded and loot of $5,000 was recovered here today.

The latest musical prodigy was discovered yesterday in the person of 9-year-old Verna Mimosa, daughter of an unemployed dishwasher, in the piano tournament of the National Piano Teachers Guild at Steinway Hall.

The Grolier Club current exhibition of the graphic and literary work of Joseph Pennell and Elizabeth Robins Pennell has been extended through May 30. Admission is free and the visiting hours are from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily.

The interior of the Astor Theatre was partly wrecked on Sunday or Monday, it was disclosed yesterday, and the police and the District Attorney are investigating to fix the culpability. The damage is estimated at more than $50,000.

LOS ANGELES, May 14 (AP). -- The Richfield Oil Corporation of New York was sold today to the Sinclair Refining Company for $5,100,000 after the present company, the Richfield Oil Company of California, had settled for $5,500,500 claims of the Federal Government for oil taken under allegedly fraudulent leases from the Elk Hills Naval Petroleum Reserves in Kern County, California.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- Fifty-one officers and employes of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. received in 1934 compensation totaling $2,236,850, or an average of about $43,860 each, including bonuses, the company's registration statement to the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today.

An alarming increase in cancer, particularly cancer of the lungs, was reported by the New York City Cancer Committee yesterday at a private showing of a comprehensive exhibit on the fight against the disease.

TOKYO, Wednesday, May 15. -- Foreign Minister Koki Hirota's action in raising the legation in China to an embassy has brought into the open a quarrel with the military that in any other country would lead to an immediate showdown on the question of whether the general staff or the Foreign Office was responsible for foreign policy.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- New securities with estimated total proceeds of $154,596,548, representing thirty issues in twenty-seven statements, filed under the Securities Act of 1933, became effective during April, as compared with $130,015,787 in March. This was the largest monthly total with the exception of July, 1933.

A program of courses will be given in the next academic year by the Department of Fine Arts, Graduate School of New York University, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Pierpont Morgan Library, the Frick Art Reference Library and the Graduate and Washington Square Centres of the university, Professor Walter W.S. Cook, the chairman, announced yesterday.

A declaration that abandonment of the gold standard by this country in April, 1933, was "unnecessary and disastrous" and that we had "not begun to pay the full consequences of the step taken at that time" was made yesterday by Ogden L. Mills, former Secretary of the Treasury, in a statement answering a radio address by Secretary Morgenthau.

I noted in THE TIMES that the Mayor questioned the conduct of the internes in not testifying against drunken drivers. From my own experience, as well as that of others, the Mayor will have to do housecleaning in his courts before blaming the internes.

MOSCOW, May 14. -- Possible effects of Marshal Josef Pilsudski's death continued to form a matter of the most interested speculation for French and Soviet statesmen, and it is safe to say the subject was not neglected long in the interview today between Pierre Laval and Joseph Stalin.

MOSCOW, May 14. -- A proposal for Soviet importations from the United States was laid before the council of heavy industry today by Peter Bogdanoff, who was until recently in New York as chairman of the board of Amtorg, Soviet trading organization.

The annual showing of work submitted by artists in competition for the Prix de Rome fellowship is being held, this week only, in the Sargent Room of the Grand Central Galleries. Forty painters and twenty-four sculptors have entered material.

FREDERICIA, Denmark, May 14. -- All Denmark celebrated today as King Christian opened the gigantic new Little Belt bridge, the $8,000,000 engineering work connecting the island of Fuenen with Jutland. The occasion also marked the start of the Danish State Railway's new streamlined trains, revolutionizing Denmark's rail service and cutting traveling times by 25 to 50 per cent.
Sascha Gorodnitzki, Maxine Stellman and Sergius Kagen will play and sing at the Institute of Musical Art tonight, at a reception of the alumni association on the institute's thirtieth anniversary.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- Administration forces in the Senate were making a supreme and apparently successful effort tonight to hold in line the necessary votes to sustain a veto of the Patman "Greenback" Bonus Bill, in the face of persistent rumors that administration key men had spread the word that President Roosevelt would not seriously object to being overridden.

Mr. and Mrs. Herbert L. Satterlee gave a reception and dance last night at their home, 1 Beekman Place, for their son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Milo Sargent Gibbs. A small family dinner preceded the event. Mr. and Mrs. Satterlee and Mr. and Mrs. Gibbs will leave at the end of the week on a visit to the Satterlee plantation in St. Mary's County, Md. Later Mr. and Mrs. Gibbs will return to Europe.

Little reduction in the city's unemployment relief budget for June was indicated yesterday when Oswald W. Knauth, chairman and executive director of the Emergency Relief Bureau, made public the home relief estimate for next month.

The city is swinging so close to its constitutional debt limit that the extensive additions to its subway system that were planned some years ago are facing indefinite postponement, it was indicated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- Republicans as well as Democrats may be present when President Roosevelt addresses the convention of Young Democratic Clubs of America, Aug. 23, in Milwaukee, if he accepts the invitation proffered today.

PARIS, May 14. -- Secretary Morgenthau's statement of America's willingness, to entertain proposals for an international stabilization agreement was welcomed here with great rejoicing in the press, but with a more temperate joy in official circles.
BASLE, May 14. -- Secretary Morgenthau's speech, as reflected in the very brief summaries that reached Basle, made an unfavorable impression in central banking quarters.

Near-statesmen and politicians wisely tell us about the political situation in the United States, but it required a mountaineer in Tennessee, who was the only man in the vicinity who could read the daily newspapers, to give us the "true facts."

A meeting of stockholders of the Simms Petroleum Company has been called for June 17 to vote on a proposal to sell the oil-producing properties of its subsidiary, the Simms Oil Company, for $8,775,000, to the Tide Water Oil Company, a subsidiary of the Tide Water Associated Oil Company.

Gustave, a 6-year-old sixty-pound chimpanzee, with brown eyes and a winning smile, given to the Central Park Zoo by Aldis B. Squire, broker of 80 John Street and Llewellyn Park, West Orange, N.J., arrived at his new home bright and early yesterday morning.

TRENTON, May 14. -- The goldfinch has been nominated by the Senate to be the official bird of the State. There was considerable conjecture today, however, whether the Assembly would go along with this nomination.

The busiest corner of Times Square will be dimmed shortly after midnight tonight when the Rialto Theatre -- originally Hammerstein's Victoria -- will surrender to the wreckers. Demolition of the building, a Times Square landmark since its erection in 1898, will begin immediately after the last screening of its picture. A new building, housing a new Rialto, will rise on the site and be opened to the public by mid-October.

About 500 employes of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies and eighteen of its affiliated institutions left their jobs for two hours yesterday afternoon to protest the alleged refusal of the federation and the institutions in question to recognize the Association of Federation Employes and grant demands for wage adjustments.

PRINCETON N.J., May 14. -- The annual inspection and review of the Princeton Field Artillery unit of the R.O.T.C., with Major Gen. Dennis E. Nolan, commandant of the Second Corps Area, leading the reviewing party, was held here this afternoon.

Senator Joseph Clark Baldwin 3d made a spirited defense of Mayor La Guardia's administration yesterday afternoon at the monthly meeting of the Republican Committee of One Hundred at the Hotel Savoy-Plaza, which was attended by more than a hundred women.
SAN JOSE, Calif., May 14 (AP). -- The second jury to try Davis A. Lamson on a wife murder count was discharged late today, having been unable to reach a verdict after deliberating nearly four days.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale Prices in New York:
ALBANY, May 14. -- Governor Lehman will journey to Washington tomorrow to visit the White House, where he and Mrs. Lehman will be guests at dinner.

BINGHAMTON, May 14 (AP). -- Congressional investigation of what it termed "laxity" on the part of Secretary Perkins and Daniel W. MacCormack, Commissioner of Immigration, was demanded here today by the commandery general of the Patriotic Order Sons of America, at the closing convention of the national convention.

Seven Manhattan properties were taken over by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday, Columbia University acquired on a $350,000 bid the fifteen-story Downing Building at 106-08 Fulton Street, with an ell to 14 Dutch Street. The action was against the Eagle Development Corporation for $413,048 due, with taxes, , amounting to $14,345.

The Rabbinical Assembly of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America voted yesterday to adjust the traditional Jewish marriage law so as to allow a Beth Din (House of Law) to grant a divorce to an agunah (deserted wife) without the consent of the husband.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 14. -- The so-called "Protocols of the Elders of Zion," purporting to reveal plans for Jewish world dominion, were branded as forgeries and their circulation in the Canton of Berne was forbidden in a judgment of the cantonal court today.

BOSTON, May 14. -- The Patman Bonus Bill was described as an extremely immoral proposal today by Walter Lippmann, economist and journalist, in an address at the luncheon of the Boston Chamber of Commerce.

Inflation is still the most overworked word in Wall Street. Last week, when the Senate approved the Patman Bonus Bill, brokers were linking the stock market's rise to the possibility of currency inflation. Since then currency inflation has seemed rather unlikely, but the market has continued to go up.

GOSPORT, England, May 14. -- Amidst the shrieking of sirens and cheers from ship and shore, Gerard B. Lambert's racing sloop Yankee entered the harbor of Gosport today. She had been anchored overnight in the Roads off Cowes near the King's cutter Britannia, the only British boat now sailing that has the distinction of having defeated an American yacht in British waters, and that over forty years ago.

Mrs. Jennie E. Francis Thorley, widow of Charles Thorley, capitalist, sportsman and Fifth Avenue florist, who died last May 9, named her daughter, Countess Frances de Palen-Klar, and her granddaughter, Frances Goodwin Balding, both of 920 Fifth Avenue, principal beneficiaries in her will, which was offered for probate in Surrogates' Court yesterday.

TOLEDO, May 14. -- Preparations were under way today for reopening the Chevrolet Motor Company's plant at 6 A.M. tomorrow and for a speedy resumption of day and night operation by 2,340 employes in an effort to catch up on production of transmissions due to the three weeks' strike delay.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- A sudden revival of the Copeland Pure Food and Drug Bill under circumstances making for enactment during this session of Congress was disclosed today by Senators interested in the measure.

Mayor La Guardia told a group of housewives yesterday, according to their spokesman, that he wished he were back in Congress where he could do something to aid their campaign to reduce the cost of living.
LONDON, May 14. -- Great Britain's unwillingness to stabilize the currency at the present time has not been shaken in the slightest by Secretary Morgenthau's speech of last night.

Communicants of the Protestant Episcopal Church, marking the 150th anniversary of the organization of the diocese of New York, were warned yesterday that political and economic measures were powerless to achieve social justice and brotherhood unless backed by spiritual understanding and faith.
Directors of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., yesterday elected officers for the current year and named Arthur C. Kaufmann, vice president of the Philadelphia store, a director to fill a vacancy on the board.

The proposed rule which would require the closing of entry lists for dog shows at least ten days prior to the event was tabled until December by the delegates to the quarterly meeting of the American Kennel Club yesterday. Sixty delegates from the member clubs gathered at the organization's headquarters at 221 Fourth Avenue.

LONDON, May 14. -- Colonel Thomas E. Lawrence, "Lawrence of Arabia," is still unconscious tonight in the little military hospital in Bovington Camp, Dorset, more than thirty-six hours after having sustained grave head injuries in a motor-cycle accident yesterday morning.

Company unions for collective bargaining are increasing in the steel industry, according to a report of a survey made by the American Iron and Steel Institute. Such unions are supported by 89.1 per cent of the employes in the operating divisions of 101 companies which employ more than 90 per cent of the wage earners on the steel company payrolls, the institute stated yesterday.

Miss Edna V. O'Brien, 49 years old, who as a stock trader and women's investment adviser was so successful in 1928 that she paid an $80,000 income tax, but who lost her entire fortune in the market crash a year later, was sentenced in General Sessions yesterday to a term of fifteen months to three years in the Women's Prison at Bedford Hills.

Harry Weinberg's suggestion that our tax laws be amended so that new buildings be exempted from taxation for a period of ten years raises the question of the tax to be laid to make up for the loss that would ensue from the proposed exemptions.

With Aldermanic President Bernard S. Deutsch voting in the negative, the Board of Aldermen approved yesterday an appropriation of $4,500 to continue the Aldermanic Committee Investigating Relief until it completes its report.
WASHINGTON, May 14. -- Just reciting the Jobs that Secretary Ickes has is enough to make a man tired.

For the last few weeks the message that "the ice is out" has been circulating throughout the eastern half of the United States as one by one the 2,500 fishing lakes of Maine have freed themselves from their Winter overcoats.

Penthouse terraces and gardens hidden in the rear of private houses in the city were opened yesterday afternoon for the benefit of the Robert E. Lee Memorial Foundation. The organization is devoted to the restoration and preservation of Stratford Hall, the home of the Lee family in Virginia.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 14. -- Polo began speeding up today with contests on Phipps Field and at the Roslyn Polo Club. Several of the leading players of the game took part, including Thomas Hitchcock Jr., who played his second game since his accident of the past season, at Phipps Field.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- Amendments to the TVA Law designed to meet such objections as that in which Federal Judge Grubb of Alabama held that the Tennessee Valley Authority exceeded its rights in marketing electricity were approved by the Senate today by a vote of 56 to 19, following the collapse of a filibuster started a week ago.

HAVANA, May 14. -- Two gliders, cut loose from a sky train on arrival from Miami, Fla., circled over this city and slid down to a perfect landing in front of the capitol this afternoon. Crowds lining the Prado, decked with flags and bunting, enthusiastically cheered pilots Jack K. O'Meara of New York and E. Paul du Pont Jr., of Wilmington, Del.

LONDON, May 14. -- The Labor party's attitude toward Europe and especially toward Britain's impending rearmament in the air will be clarified at an important party meeting next Tuesday on the eve of the defense debate in the House of Commons.

Thomas D. Thacher, retiring president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, speaking last night at the annual meeting of the association at 42 West Forty-fourth Street, announced that a special fund of $34,175 has been raised.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 14 (AP). -- New processes for sterilizing foods in silver-plated vessels and insulating houses with cellular bricks were described today to the American Institute of Chemical Engineers.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP). -- The writings of some "literary artists" read like the telltale phrases of schizophrenia, the mild form of insanity known as split personality.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 14. -- In the opening amateur handicap tournament of the Long Island Golf Association today at the Hempstead Golf Club, A.W. (Laddie) Biggs of Crescent, the district amateur titleholder, and Dr. Charles J. Robinson of Wheatley Hills, tied for the lead with a card of 75 each, two over par.

The sum of $23,000 has been received by public subscription toward the guarantee fund of $50,000 required to assure the completion of the schedule of opera, symphony and ballet performances at the Lewisohn Stadium this Summer, it was announced yesterday.

The relative merits of the steam-driven and Diesel-motored electric streamlined trains will be tested in actual operation by the Baltimore Ohio Railroad. The first of these two trains, which together will cost $950,000, will be named at Springfield, Ill., by Governor Hornet, the ceremonies being broadcast at 1:30 this afternoon over a nation-wide hook-up by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, a New Deal infant approaching a seventeenth-month anniversary but with 14,000 banks and $16,000,000,000 under its wing, has had to pay off depositors on an average of less than once a month.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- With more than 80 per cent of the First Liberty Bond issue exchanged for 2 7/8 per cent bonds or 1 5/8 per cent notes, the Treasury announced today that the books on further exchange subscriptions for the new bonds would be closed at midnight May 23.

Two claims totaling $7,623 were recommended yesterday for allowance at a continuation of the fraud hearings against S.W. Straus Co. in the office of the receiver, Louis F. Schultze, 9 East Forty-sixth Street. The cases are being heard by Harry A. Gordon, referee.

Canonization ceremonies at St. Peter's, Rome, next Sunday for the English martyrs, Sir Thomas More, Lord Chancellor of England, and John Cardinal Fisher, Lord Bishop of Rochester, who were beheaded in 1535 at the order of Henry VIII of England, will be broadcast from the Vatican and carried here over the WEAF network at 7:14 A.M., Eastern daylight-saving time. Pope Plus XI will officiate.

Adams Co. report the following buildings under their management as being 100 per cent rented: 43-51 W. 36th St., 116-18 W. 29th St., 224-6 W. 29th St., 45-51 W. 25th St., 162 5th Av., 85 5th Av., 131-5 W. 35th St. and 135 W. 17th St.

Charles Mattman, captain of the Trinity School tennis team, defeated Wilson Rood of Poly Prep yesterday to gain the final of the tournament for the championship of the Athletic Association of Private Schools.
" A Nous La Liberte," a French film satire directed by Rene Clair, will be shown tonight at the Young Men's Hebrew Association, Ninety-second Street and Lexington Avenue.

A youthful band of soccer football players, the Scottish Internationals, arrived last night aboard the Cunard-White Star liner Aquitania for an extended series of exhibition contests in the United States and Canada.

The Humane Society of New York was the beneficiary of a dinner and supper dance held last night at the formal opening of the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria. A percentage of the proceeds was donated to the needs of that organization. Many dinner and supper parties were given.
ROSLYN, L.I., May 14. -- Harbor Hill, the country home which Mr. and Mrs. Clarence H. Mackay closed in June, 1932, to save money, will be reopened within a few days, it was learned here this morning.

WILLIMANTIC, Conn., May 14 (AP). -- Six persons are dead as the result of an automobile accident tonight at North Windham, a village near here. Reuben Blumenthal, 39, of 15 Taft Avenue, Providence, R.I., died at the Windham Community Memorial Hospital here just before midnight to make the sixth fatality.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- A registration statement for the issuance of $25,000,000 ten-year convertible debentures under the Securities Act of 1933 was filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today by the American Rolling Mill Company.

New policies of the Columbia Broadcasting System planned to raise radio advertising standards and to take the "blood and thunder" out of children's programs were generally applauded by other broadcasters yesterday. The majority pointed out that they were already enforcing "stricter standards" or were taking steps in that direction.

The re-election of Edwin J. Barclay as President of the Republic of Liberia and the carrying of a constitutional amendment extending the President's term from four to eight years was announced here yesterday by Walter F. Walker, Liberian Consul in New York.
WASHINGTON, May 14. -- President Roosevelt addressed 4,500 farmers gathered from all parts of the country to support the AAA.
WASHINGTON, May 14. -- The text of the address of President Roosevelt to farmers today, as given out at the White House, was as follows:

The report of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries for the first quarter, yesterday, shows consolidated net income of $4,521,223, equal after preferred dividends to 40 cents a share on 6,261,357 common shares, against $3,992,100, or 31 cents a share on the common stock in the 1934 period.

BALTIMORE, May 14 (AP). -- The backing of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company would be given the Kelly-Springfield Tire Company by a reorganization plan for the latter concern, now operating under a trusteeship, filed here today with Federal Judge W. Calvin Chesnut.

Despite opposition by Fusion members of the Board of Education Dr. George J. Ryan was re-elected president for a fourteenth term at the annual meeting of the board yesterday. The vote was 4 to 2, with a Fusion member not voting.
ROME, May 14. -- Following is the text of Premier Mussolini's address today to the Italian Senate:

A colorful and tuneful pageant, in which the importance of milk as a body-builder was demonstrated by a score of youngsters belonging to the club centres of the Children's Aid Society, started the society's celebration of Milk Week yesterday afternoon at the Schermerhorn Playground of the West Side Centre, 411 West Thirty-ninth Street.

A curious alignment of forces may confront us in the revolution which is supposed to be more or less around the corner. Over the ramparts of the capitalist system we shall see floating the battle flag of the American Federation of Labor alongside the proud standard of the United States Chamber of Commerce.

Detectives working on the murder of Edward Martin, the bank robber whose body was found in the weeds-at Hohokus, N.J., on Friday, reported yesterday that they had found the plane which they believe he piloted in getting away with his loot.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- All shades of Republicans except those who deserted the party in 1932 and have accepted Democratic appointments will be represented in the party's second regional conference to be held June 10-11 at Springfield, Ill.

Yielding but one safety and striking out nine, Harry Grant pitched Long Island University to a I2-to-0 victory over Wagoner College yesterday at Manhattan Beach. The game was called at the end of the sixth because of darkness.

ALBANY, May 14. -- A concerted attack on proposals for compulsory health insurance was made today before the annual meeting of the Medical Society of the State of New York by Dr. Arthur J. Bedell of Albany, retiring president of the society, and Dr. Frederic E. Sondern of New York, the incoming president.

James Marshall, a member of the Board of Education, in a recent speech denounced the prejudice of "older Americans" against alien minority groups. This attitude, I would remind Mr. Marshall, is somewhat reciprocal in that aliens have prejudices too, and of a nature that harm our country and make "older Americans" resentful.

We must not forget that an epithet is not necessarily fact. Indeed, it may not be intended to be so. If people have a good adjective -- good because vague -- to apply to persons whom they do not like or who adopt doctrines they think abhorrent, it will be used with great freedom and indefiniteness.

CHICAGO, May 14. -- Receipts of hogs continued light today and a good distributive demand for fresh pork brought the smaller packers into the market. Prices were lifted 5 to 15 cents a hundredweight to the highest level since the middle of March.

Stockholders of the Delaware Hudson Company took the lead in the discussion at the annual meeting of the company yesterday, showering L.F. Loree, its veteran president, with questions and protests. They raised again the question of a dividend they proposed at the previous annual meeting and sought vainly for more information on their company's investments.

Old Rose Hill rang to the echo of base hits yesterday as Fordham went on a wild batting spree at the expense of the Upsala College nine. When the heavy cannonading had subsided the Rams were found on the long end of a 22-to-1 count for their seventh triumph in eleven starts this season.

OTTAWA, May 14. -- In connection with an announcement that a new domestic issue of $60,000,000 Dominion of Canada bonds would be made tomorrow, officials of the Finance Department said today that they were considering the advisability of returning to the New York money market in the Fall.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14. -- Twelve officers and employes of contracting firms engaged in PWA projects here were indicted today by a special Federal grand jury on charges of mulcting workers of their rightful wages, either through "kick-back" methods or by wrongly classifying jobs.

The first of two performances of Johann Strauss's "Gypsy Baron" was presented last night by the New York Light Opera Guild at the Heckscher Theatre. John Hand, director of the guild conducted. A large audience was on hand and warmly received singers, conductor and performance.
Net earnings of the Columbian Carbon Company for the quarter ended on March 31 were the largest for any corresponding period since 1930.

Strength of foreign government loans was the feature of trading yesterday in the bond market on the Stock Exchange. Belgian, Japanese, Polish and some South American obligations advanced 1 to 3 points. French and British bonds were steady, with a firm undertone.
Money market was colorless. All that went on was replacements at prevailing quotations. There was virtually no inquiry for new funds.

Several leases of penthouses on the East Side were reported by brokers yesterday, indicating the continued popularity of this type of living quarters. The long list of apartment leases signed showed a renewal of activity in residential renting for Summer and Fall occupancy, now that the bulk of the Spring commercial leasing has been handled by brokers.

Trustees of The Prudence Company, Inc., announced yesterday that payment is now available on the May 1, 1934, coupon of the company's issue of collateral trust 5 1/2 per cent gold bonds, due on May 1, 1961, at the rate of $20 on each $27.50 coupon.

The ending of the strike in the General Motors plant at Toledo is to be welcomed for many reasons. The settlement was made by negotiations with the company, which offered the workers certain concessions. Then the local union voted to accept the compromise despite the strenuous efforts of radical leaders to prolong the strike.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., May 14. -- Four pickets and a miner were shot, nine State troopers and twelve other workers were injured, and scores of strikers were beaten today in a pitched battle resulting from a renewal of warfare by the United Anthracite Miners to close collieries of the Glen Alden Coal Company.

Residents of the Washington Square neighborhood met at the Hotel Brevoort last night and organized the Save Washington Square Committee to oppose the Park Department's plans to remodel Washington Square Park at a cost of $2,000,000.

William F.X. Geoghan, District Attorney of Kings County, intimated last night that he was considering the release of Frederick Gross, the 49-year-old crippled bookkeeper charged with fatally poisoning his wife and four of their five children with thallium sulphate.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- Industry has improved under the New Deal, Representative O'Connor of New York told the House today in reply to a Republican attack yesterday led by the minority leader, Representative Snell of New York. Mr. O'Connor produced statistics to show that employment has increased and that the Federal relief load is declining.

THE United States just won't accept an urban destiny. For, although most of our novel readers are at least one generation removed from ugly contact with earthworms and cutworms, they flock to the rental libraries to take out books which tend to identify all goodness and virtue with hoeing and building stone walls and raising your own food supply.

CHICAGO, May 14. -- Recent rains have removed drought as a factor in the wheat market, but the continued wet weather over a large area of Illinois, Iowa and Missouri and in parts of other States is delaying plowing for corn and also planting.
Indictments charging five more men with immigration and naturalization frauds were handed up yesterday to Federal Judge Grover M. Moscowitz by the Federal grand jury in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- Following up the invitation extended to the nations of the world last night by Secretary Morgenthau to initiate moves for foreign exchange stabilization, Senator Thomas, of Oklahoma, introduced in the Senate today a resolution "requesting" the President to suggest to the other nations the advisability of preparing for early concerted action, and asking him to call a world conference when the value of the dollar had been satisfactorily adjusted and regulated.

CLEVELAND, May 14. -- Recent increases in building construction mark the most hopeful factor in the outlook for continued national recovery, except for the high rate of automobile production, Colonel Leonard P. Ayres, the business analyst, said today.

As soon as the Chicago district golfers get around to completing their own grand jury session, some 162 knights of the niblick will have received full permission to journey to Oakmont next month and make themselves miserable.

The seventeenth anniversary of commercial air-mail carrying in the United States will be marked today by the celebration of "Air Transport Day," proclaimed by Governor Hoffman of New Jersey, at Newark Airport. The Governor and Mayor Ellenstein of Newark will attend and two squadrons of Army Air Corps will do formation flying.

Operations incidental to the releasing of government-financed cotton to ease a congested raw-material situation contributed yesterday the largest percentage of trading on the Cotton Exchange. Selling pressure appeared to be centred in the July, as purchasers of government cotton released long contracts, while houses doing government business became aggressive buyers of new-crop months.

PARIS, May 14. -- The nervousness which the Bourse experienced yesterday disappeared today and as a result rentes improved, while industrials remained firm, Le Temps ascribed the better feeling to Secretary Morgenthau's statement regarding willingness of the United States to adhere to international monetary stabilization.

ST. THOMAS, V.I., May 14. -- Governor Paul Pearson and his supporters received a jolt today in the postponement until October of further hearings in the Senatorial investigation of the island administration. The reason given was lack of time for adequate presentation of the mass of evidence gathered by the subcommittee headed by Senator Robert R. Reynolds of North Carolina.

The number of visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday showed a decrease in comparison with the figures for the preceding week. The total, however, was well above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

Corliss Lamont, the son of Thomas Lamont, reviews Cornelius Vanderbilt Jr.'s book, "Farewell to Fifth Avenue," in the current Modern Monthly. In the review Mr. Lamont comments that "capitalist Park Avenue said farewell to Fifth some time ago on the grounds that it had neither brains, culture nor taste."

The ambition of Miss Mildred (Babe) Didrikson, Texas "wonder girl" athlete, to achieve national golf championship heights was abruptly halted yesterday by an edict of the United States Golf Association, ruling her ineligible for amateur competition because of her activities as a professional in other sports.

Admitting that municipal legislation will probably support the Sunday Performance Law, the Actors Equity Association is considering three courses of action, it is revealed in the current issue of Equity Magazine, published today.

Martin Conboy, who has served as United States Attorney here for the last seventeen months, and recently has made repeated appeals to Washington for release from public office, has finally persuaded President Roosevelt to accept his resignation, he revealed yesterday.

ROME, May 14. -- In a brief and loudly applauded speech made in the Senate today at the end of a debate on the budget of the Ministry for Colonies, Premier Benito Mussolini reaffirmed Italy's intention to proceed with her military preparations in East Africa without heeding the cries of alarm that have been raised in more than one quarter abroad.

Although we say we have a capitalistic system, it seems to me it also might be called Communistic. All our large corporations are owned by hundreds of thousands of citizens, and they share the profits. Many of the workers are also owners of their corporations through stock holdings.

The March grand jury, which has been investigating the policy racket, temporarily suspended questioning of witnesses yesterday to have one of them held in contempt of court for refusing to answer questions held essential to a phase of the inquiry.

With Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Discovery scheduled to make his seasonal debut in the $3,000 added Toboggan Handicap, the Spring meeting at Belmont Park, regarded as the most important racing session in the country, is scheduled to get under way today.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- If he would escape the suspicion, even the charge, of disingenuousness on the bonus, the President must now leave no loophole in his veto of the Patman bill which would admit the slightest impression of toleration of the greenbacks issue authorized by this measure.
Andrew Ponzi, world's champion, and James Evans played four blocks of their pocket billiard match yesterday at Kreuter's Academy, and the former was triumphant in three sessions at the table.
Due to my absence from New York I could not immediately draw your attention to an error in THE TIMES concerning the murder of the late King Alexander of Yugoslavia.

The board of directors of the Metropolitan Opera Association will meet today or tomorrow to decide on a successor to Herbert Witherspoon, who died suddenly last Friday in the course of his recently assumed duties as general manager.
Robert W. Atkins has resigned as a director of the American Commercial Alcohol Company.

A generally firm tone pervaded the financial markets yesterday. The share market appeared not to be unduly taxed in withstanding the disposition to take profits, and profits there have been since the advent of the rise that began a week ago today.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 14. -- Delegates numbering 458, from every State in the Union, Hawaii and Canada, gathered here today at the opening session of the conference of the Association of the Junior Leagues of America, and heard Mrs. John Gerstle Levison, president of the San Francisco League, outline briefly the plans of their organization.

Three legal concepts which had not been applied hitherto to bank loans on negotiable securities were invoked yesterday by counsel for 23,000 Insull investors on the second day of the oral argument that is to wind up their long Federal suit to recover $30,000,000 from five New York banks and the General Electric Company.

GLEN COVE, L.I., May 14. -- J. Pierpont Morgan, exhibiting blooms grown at Matinecock Point, his East Long Island estate, won the silver plate this afternoon for a collection of tulips covering fifty square feet, at the annual tulip show of the Nassau County Horticultural Society being held in the main building on the Pratt estate today and tomorrow.
Scholarships and prizes for student art work were awarded yesterday at the annual luncheon and exhibition of the New York School of Applied Design for Women, 160 Lexington Avenue.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, May 14. -- Once the proud queen of the seas, the Mauretania embarked a strange company today before sailing shortly for her final sad voyage to the Valhalla of all outdated liners, the shipbreakers' yard.

Victor (The Count) Lustig, international swindler, will have a hearing on May 27 on charges of possessing $51,000 in counterfeit banknotes. The date for the hearing was set yesterday by United States Commissioner Garrett W. Cotter.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- Speaking to 4,500 farmers, who came here from twenty-five States to praise the administration for benefits derived from the New Deal and the AAA, President Roosevelt declared today that the government was still with them -- "you who were once forgotten men."

MANILA, Wednesday, May 15 (AP). -- Election returns flowing in early today indicated the Filipinos, with women balloting for the first time, voted by a margin of probably 25 to 1 yesterday to ratify the Constitution of the forthcoming commonwealth government.

ABOARD U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA, Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, May 14. -- Eighty-three ships of the White force were still moored behind the fortifications of Pearl Harbor at sundown tonight, although extensive "enemy" activity was reported in various parts of the Northeastern Pacific in the United States fleet's mimic war.

Merchants representing stores in all sections of the country, at a special meeting yesterday in the Hotel Pennsylvania, unanimously approved plans to push organization of the American Retail Federation as the mouthpiece for the entire field of retailing."

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- Extensions of time for filing permanent registration applications under the Securities Exchange Act have been granted by the Securities and Exchange Commission for various classes of securities on which forms have not yet been drawn up.

Declaring that under no circumstances will the house-dress industry permit itself to be placed under the jurisdiction of the Dress Code Authority, S.L. Hoffman, president of the National Association of House Dress Manufacturers, declared yesterday that his group would continue to fight the NRA ruling putting dresses priced at more than $22.50 a dozen under the Dress Code.

For the first time in many years the prospect for a reclassification of city salaries appears reasonably bright. A reform administration is in office. The Municipal Civil Service Commission is in the hands of men not afraid of the old political bugaboos. At the same time it has set about its task in what appears to be a realistic fashion.

The power of the Commissioner of Accounts to subpoena rent records in investigating applications for reduction of tax assessments and to inquire into methods and accounts of the Department of Taxes and Assessments was upheld yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo in a decision regarded as having a far-reaching effect.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- An opinion that present high prices of liquor, "resulting from a combination of short domestic stocks and the high level of the present duty in conjunction with the excise tax," are probably restricting current consumption was expressed by the Tariff Commission in a report on alcoholic beverages and the tariff made public today.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- In the face of President Roosevelt's demand for a two-year continuation of the National Industrial Recovery Act, and a declaration by Donald R. Richberg that a mere ten months' extension would be "complete folly," the Senate in a burst of speed and without a record vote approved today the Clark Joint Resolution to keep the recovery agency alive only until April 1, 1936.

City College and St. John's battled through a hard-fought baseball game at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday before C.C.N.Y. gained an 8-7 victory. The Beavers scored the winning run in the ninth inning, after the Redmen had tied the count in their half.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP). -- President Roosevelt vetoed today a bill to give an honorable army discharge to a man whose excuse for deserting after a nine-day enlistment thirty-three years ago was that he must have been under the influence of liquor and did not know until twenty-four years later that he had joined up.

Declaring that it is not surprising that there would be considerable opposition to the proposed single textile code, Peter Van Horn, president of the National Federation of Textiles, said last night that "the best evidence that constructive ideas in the industry meet opposition is found in the fact that for many years the textile business, generally speaking, has gotten steadily worse."

Shows and people: Leonard Sillman should be in Milwaukee at this moment directing Robert Henderson's revue, "Up to the Stars." Material for the show will come not only from Noel Coward's "Words and Music" (produced in London three years ago), but from a couple of former Sillman enterprises -- "New Faces" and "Fools Rush In."

MOSCOW, May 14. -- For two hours today Joseph Stalin and Foreign Minister Pierre Laval of France discussed Franco-Soviet peace efforts in a situation confused by the death of Marshal Josef pilsudski of Poland.
New York University honored its Winter and Spring sport representatives last night at a dinner in the New York Athletic Club. Members of the baseball, basketball, tennis and track squads attended.

ALBANY, May 14. -- Governor Lehman signed today the Neustein bill, making broad changes in State law regarding time off for good behavior for inmates in State penal institutions, as recommended by the Law Revision Commission.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 14. -- The Rev. Dr. Herbert H. Farmer of the Hartford Seminary Foundation gave the commencement address this morning at the 123d graduation exercises of the Princeton Theological Seminary. The exercises were held in Alexander Hall on the Princeton University campus.

BUFFALO, May 14 (AP). -- The Bisons beat the Syracuse Chiefs, 4 to 3, in eleven innings today for their second consecutive overtime victory. Opening the eleventh with a triple, Meyers scored the winning run on McFarland's fly to deep centre.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14. -- The Pirates struck a blow at Bucky Walters's pitching hopes today when they drove the former infielder from the mound with a five-run attack in the third inning and then went on to defeat the Phillies, 8 to 1.

BOSTON, May 14. -- The Ebling Brewing Company, Inc., of Brooklyn, which has an office in Massachusetts, was named in an indictment returned by the Federal grand jury today charging violations of the Brewing Industry Code.

SYDNEY, Australia, Wednesday, May 15. -- Sir Charles Kingsford-Smith, who took off from here last midnight on a special Silver Jubilee air mail flight to New Zealand, returned safely to Mascot Field this afternoon after having been in serious trouble over the Tasman Sea after motor trouble had forced him to turn back. Radio messages flashed from his plane told of two near disasters.

Heavy voting, street brawls in Bayonne and a series of upsets, three of them affecting the Democratic organization of Mayor Frank Hague in Hudson County and one the Republican organization of former United States Senator David Baird Jr. in Camden, marked the commission elections held in nineteen New Jersey municipalities yesterday.

The first day's auction sale of art treasures and furnishings of Ophir Hall, at Purchase, N.Y., residence of the late Mrs. Whitelaw Reid, under the direction of the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., amounted to $23,540.

SUMMIT, N.J., May 14. -- Mrs. T.W. Hawes, playing over her home course, today won the opening one-day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association season in New Jersey. Mrs. Hawes scored a 92 over the Canoe Brook Country Club course, which was made heavy by morning rains.

Daily average gross crude-oil production in the United States last week was 2,619,800 barrels, compared with 2,494,100 in the previous week, an increase of 125,700, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

Production of new life insurance in April was 7.6 per cent less than in April, 1934. In the first four months of this year the cumulative total was 5.2 per cent greater than in the corresponding period last year.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- (AP). -- Cottonseed crushed in the nine-month period, Aug. 1 to April 30, was reported today b the Census Bureau to have totaled 3,313,843 tons, compared with 3,854,587 tons in the same period a year ago.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt spent almost an hour yesterday afternoon inspecting the annual exhibition of the work in all departments of the Todhunter School, of which she is associate principal. Girls wearing uniform blue dresses and low-heel shoes and no jewelry or make-up conducted their parents and friends through the corridors and classrooms.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 14. -- More than 2,000 Harvard students rioted for two hours in the streets tonight as a protest against a ban on the current issue of The Harvard Lampoon. Three students were arrested.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 14. -- The Westchester Better Homes Exposition, arranged by the White Plains Committee of the Federal Housing Administration, was officially opened at the County Centre this afternoon by Julian Gerard, New York State Director of the Federal Housing Administration.

Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard College, in her annual message of advice to members of the graduating class at an assembly in Barnard Hall yesterday, urged the students to take time off from their future occupations long enough to rear families.

In the course of an article in Sunday's NEW YORK TIMES, Sir JOSIAH STAMP called attention to a long-standing British problem which has now become a problem for Americans. "In England," he writes, "we have found "men on the dole computing the dif"ference between their dole payments"and what they would get in private "work.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- New York's chance of getting $150,000,000 for a slum-clearance program hinges on whether Mayor La Guardia makes good a "dare" to Secretary Ickes that the city could buy the remaining 40 per cent of land necessary for the $12,000,000 Williamsburg low-cost housing project within ten days, it appeared today from an announcement by Mr. Ickes.

The close association in one firm of the five Morse brothers, who worked together in the municipal bond department of Lehman Brothers under the direction of Frank H. Morse, came to a close yesterday when three of the five announced that they had formed a new firm under the name Morse Bros. Co., Inc.

Relief workers present a serious threat to the morale of the civil service, according to the report of the executive committee of the Civil Service Reform Association, read by Harold W. Marsh, Deputy Commissioner of Public Welfare, at the fifty-seventh annual meeting at the Downtown Association yesterday noon.

WOOL, Dorsetshire, England, Wednesday, May 15. -- The nerves of steel that saw "Lawrence of Arabia" through revolt in the desert stood by him early today after his physicians announced that he had taken a turn for the worse.

Baseball's famous hurling duo -- Dizzy and Paul Dean -- will be seen in action at the Polo Grounds this afternoon when the Cards meet the Giants in a double-header. Paul Dean is scheduled to pitch the first game and Dizzy is booked to work in the second.

The Soldiers and Sailors Club was the beneficiary of a fashion show and tea yesterday which opened the Italian Garden of Le Coq Rouge. The event marked the launching of the Memorial Day appeal for funds to support the club house, which serves as the headquarters in New York for the United States service men.

Price movements were mixed and trading generally light on the local commodity futures markets yesterday. Rubber was a strong and active exception. In the cash markets wheat, cocoa and butter reacted to the lowest prices of the year, and oats also declined, while corn, rye, cotton, silk and rubber advanced.

Vincent Ventura, pitching star of Theodore Roosevelt High, turned in a no-hit, no-run performance yesterday as he blanked the Commerce team, 3 to 0, in a P.S.A.L. Upper Manhattan-Bronx league game at Washington Stadium.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- Senator Long's proposal to investigate Postmaster General Farley was rejected by the Senate today by a vote of 62 to 20, Democrats joining almost to the man in administering a "spanking" to their recalcitrant member.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- Faced by many requests from corporations that some data filed be held confidential, the Securities and Exchange Commission revised its rules today so that copies of such data need not be filed with Exchanges and providing for a review of the requests.

In his talk yesterday to cohorts of enthusiastic farmers, swarming into Washington to pledge their loyalty and see the sights, Secretary WALLACE made one point on which critics of the Administration's farm program cannot fairly quarrel with him. This was when he likened AAA's processing tax to the protective tariff.

BOSTON, May 14 (AP). -- Seven men and a woman were indicted today by a Federal grand jury here for the $129,000 postal robbery at Fall River in January. All are under arrest and Federal investigators expressed the conviction that they comprise all involved in the crime who are alive.

Secretary Morgenthau's declaration that the United States was willing to join with other nations in currency stabilization aroused general approval in Wall Street yesterday, although it was regarded as unlikely that any foreign country would promptly take up his invitation to initiate stabilization negotiations.

WASHINGTON, May. 14 (AP) -- The administration Omnibus Banking Bill was described today by Edward E. Brown, president of the First National Bank of Chicago, as a measure which would permit the administration to compel banks to swallow new government bond issues when the public would no longer take them.
Commercial properties in Manhattan accounted for a large part of the urban realty trading reported yesterday.
DETROIT, May 14. -- Buffeted about by a biting gale that swirled around the lake and froze the very soul of man and beast, the Yankees spent another perfectly miserable afternoon here today.

The controversy between the fundamentalists and the modernists in the Presbyterian Church broke out again yesterday. A nation-wide committee of fifty ruling elders announced that it had sent to 8,000 other elders a circular asking them to take a definite stand for fundamentalism.

An offering of $960,000 of City of Ketchikan, Territory of Alaska, 5 1/2 per cent public improvement bonds, maturing serially from 1940 to 1955, will be made today by B.J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., and James H. Causey Co., Inc. They are priced, to yield 4 to 4.50 per cent, according to maturity.
CLEVELAND, May 14. -- Three-hit pitching by Mel Harder and a home run by Hal Trosky with two men on bases were the principal factors today as Cleveland downed Washington, 4 to 2.

WARSAW, May 14. -- The mortal remains of Josef Pilsudski. Poland's only Marshal and her willingly accepted dictator, rest in a simple oak coffin in the drawing room of Belvedere Palace on the edge of Warsaw and there today all the city has made a pilgrimage.

LONDON, May 14 (AP) -- A jury that listened to the court's charge that "a man doesn't promise to marry a woman by saying, 'you're the sweetest girl I've ever met,'" today tossed out the heart balm suit of Angelia Joyce against young Lord Revelstoke.

The city's income from all sources in April was $208,393,296, not including $35,000,000 borrowed, Controller Frank J. Taylor reported yesterday. Expenditures were $68,658,880 for governmental purposes and $68,908,000 for redemption, amortization and renewal of the city's debt.

MANILA, May 15 (AP). -- Three village officials and another person were shot dead today in what authorities called an outbreak of communistic terrorism in Laguna Province, scene of the bloodiest fighting in last week's revolt.

BERLIN, May 15. -- The Boerse was firm today and showed some activity. Interest was centred on shares of domestic industrial corporations producing raw materials, which are expected to profit from the rigorous import, restrictions accompanying the export subsidy program to be announced soon.

PAGING Mr. Jim Rice, erstwhile Columbia crew coach, now the guide, philosopher and friend of Bob Pearce, the world's professional sculling champion. It is believed that this is the same Rice who was billed some years ago as Professor Rizano, world's champion water-walker. But this letter has to do with Mr. Rice as a rowing authority and is respectfully called to his attention.

Members of the Association of Federation Workers picketed Lebanon Hospital, Cauldwell and Westchester Avenues, the Bronx, yesterday in protest against the discharge by the institution of twenty-nine employes for leaving their posts to take part in the two-hour stoppage carried out by the association on Tuesday.

A remarkable peculiarity of Compton Mackenzie's "Prince Charlie and His Ladies," comments Alfred A. Knopf, who has just published this book, is that the footnotes occasionally contradict the author on matters of fact and sometimes disagree on matters of opinion.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- Support for Secretary Morgenthau's appeal looking to stabilization of currencies was voiced tonight by Secretary Hull, who declared that this movement and the one he is directing for removing artificial and unnecessary trade barriers were complementary.

About 300,000 bales of pool cotton have been sold recently, only part of which has been replaced with futures, according to official estimates, and buying in connection with these operations was active again yesterday on the Cotton Exchange.

Casey Stengel gambled once yesterday and lost. The next time he took no chances and as a result the Dodgers gained an even break with the Cubs, dropping the first game, 8 -- 4, but capturing the second, 3 -- 1.
WASHINGTON, May 15. -- A proclamation establishing Maritime Day was issued today by President Roosevelt.

U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA, Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, May 15. -- Ten battleships and the aircraft carriers of the White fleet are still here, but are ready to leave at a moment's notice to join the fleet's light forces in the climax of one of the largest war problems the navy has ever attempted.

LONDON, May 15. -- Colonel T.E. Lawrence was still unconscious tonight after sixty hours of fighting against greater odds than any he faced in his desert campaigns. He had not opened his eyes since he was hurled 100 feet from his motor cycle Monday morning, fracturing his skull in at least two places and sustaining other severe injuries.

NEWARK, N.J., May 15. -- Orders alleged to have been given by the Gillette Safety Razor Company to a subsidiary here deliberately to change a high-grade low-priced razor blade into a "very bad" blade to promote the sale of Gillette blades were described to a jury in Federal court today by James Harlow, former vice president, director and superintendent of Otto Roth, Inc., the subsidiary.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- The President and Mrs. Roosevelt entertained tonight with a dinner in honor of the Governor of New York and Mrs. Lehman. The guest list totaled almost ninety persons. Senators and Representatives from New York were among those attending.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Hall gave a dinner last night in the Rainbow Room, Rockefeller Center, for Mr. and Mrs. Dearborn Clark of San Francisco. The other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Tyler Rogers, Mr. and Mrs. William O. Davey and Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Hall.

Ted Shawn, former dance partner of Ruth St. Denis, sailed yesterday on the United States liner President Roosevelt to present in London what is said to be the first exclusively male dance organization. Eight men dancers accompanied him.

NEWARK, N.J., May 15. -- Efforts have been made to relieve the drabness of the city subway, which is scheduled for opening here May 26, by the installation of landscape murals in colored tiles in the walls of each station, it was made known here today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 15. -- A committee of Rutgers University trustees has been appointed by Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of the institution, to investigate charges that Dr. Lienhard Bergel has been dropped as an instructor in German at the New Jersey College for Women because of political differences with heads of his department on nazism, it was disclosed here today.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., May 15. -- The two Springfield morning newspapers got out their May 16 editions tonight without the help of the composing rooms, shut by a strike which spread early in the evening to all four papers in the city. The four-page photo-engraved editions included local, suburban and world news.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- A five-hour attempt by government counsel to break down the Mellon contention that $500 a share was a fair market value of the stock of the McClintic-Marshall Company, as of March 1, 1913, was a feature of today's session of the Mellon tax case before the Board of Tax Appeals.

The story of how the visible world was restored by surgery to John Seaman, 19 years old, who had been totally blind for eight years and partly blind for fourteen, was told last night by Dr. Francis X. Brophy, eye specialist at the Jersey City Medical Centre, who has been caring for the youth for fourteen months.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP). -- Commenting on the latest expression of Japanese resentment over the American Pacific fleet manoeuvres, Secretary Swanson said today that he had no personal objection to the Japanese fleet's manoeuvring "anywhere as long as they stay 2,000 miles away" from the American mainland.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- A basic framework for labor's wages under the $4,000,000,000 work program, calling for a 30 per cent slash in prevailing hourly rates on construction jobs, tonight was disclosed to have been drawn tentatively for White House approval.

DUBLIN, May 15. -- The de Valera administration's fourth budget was introduced by Sean MacEntee, Irish Free State Minister of Finance, in the Dail Eireann this afternoon. In view of the present condition of national finances nobody anticipated remissions, but few expected the host of new taxes upon essential commodities now to be imposed.

Stockholders of the Consolidated Oil Corporation approved yesterday a reduction in the number of directors from twenty-four to fifteen. H.F. Sinclair, chairman of the executive committee, who presided, said the company earned a profit in each month this year and he was hopeful that "at the end of the first six months we will be in a position to pay a dividend."

A mortgage of $129,000 was extended for five years at 4 per cent interest for two years, 4 1/2 per cent for two years and 5 per cent for the fifth year in the sale by the Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Corporation of the five-and-a-half-story walk-up apartment house at 1,018 Summit Avenue, the Bronx.

CHICAGO, May 15. -- May wheat sold off fractionally to 90 3/8 cents a bushel today at the opening of the Board of Trade, the lowest price of the season and 12 1/4 cents below the high point, reached a month ago. Early scattered liquidation resulted from further beneficial rains in the Southwest, but the dip in the new-crop months caused shorts to cover, and a rally followed.

The forces opposed to the admission of women as church wardens and vestrymen scored a victory yesterday at the closing sessions of the 152d annual convention of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York in the synod house of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 15. -- Sponsored by the Plainfield Garden Club and co-operating exhibitors, the May flower show opened today in the Plainfield Armory. The exhibit will close at 6 P.M. tomorrow.

SALEM, N.H., May 15. -- Owned and trained by the father and ridden by the son, the 4-year-old bay gelding Lynx Eye, 19-to-1 shot, assured the modest Robertson stable a season's supply of fodder today by registering a smashing upset victory in the $5,000 added Speed Handicap, the six-furlong feature of Rockingham Park's opening program.

MOSCOW, May 15. -- The visit of Pierre Laval, French Foreign Minister, to Moscow has been a success beyond all expectations. It has been such a success as almost to make one wonder whether human intelligence may not, after all, be greater than human folly and, perchance, save Europe from a catastrophe that seemed inevitable.

The proposal for a landscaped approach in Central Park to the Theodore Roosevelt Memorial at Central Park West and Seventy-ninth Street has been pigeonholed by the Park Department, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- Before galleries crowded with bronzed and interested participants in the "farmers' march" on Washington, administration leaders in the Senate and House took up today the condemnation of AAA critics where President Roosevelt left off yesterday with his indictment of those "lying" about the government's farm program.

Two aviators escaped with only minor bruises and a thorough wetting last night when their three-seat, open-cockpit biplane developed motor trouble soon after taking off from the Jersey City Airport and fell into Newark Bay 200 feet off Droyer's Point, Jersey City. The men were rescued by police, who went to their aid in a collapsible rowboat kept at the field.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- General business conditions failed to show any pronounced gain last week, although some important centres, such as Chicago, Cleveland, Pittsburgh and Cincinnati reported a better tone in the retail trade, the Commerce Department's weekly survey of business in thirty-three cities reported today.

Applications for permanent registration under the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934 were received yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange from approximately 200 listed corporations. Yesterday was the deadline set by the Exchange early in April.

PALO ALTO, Calif., May 15. -- Former President Herbert Hoover said today that complete abolition of the NRA is "the one right answer" which the House of Representatives should make to the Senate's action extending its life.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- Deciding against the creation of a new national agrarian organization, farmer delegates from thirty-four States and Puerto Rico, appointed at yesterday's mass meeting, today adopted a resolution urging continuation of the Agricultural Adjustment Act, including the processing tax and amendments now pending in Congress.
PHILADELPHIA, May 15 (AP). -- Pittsburgh swept the three-game series with the Phillies by pounding four pitchers for nineteen hits and a 20-5 triumph today.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 15 (AP). -- The life of Adolph S. Ochs was described today by The Associated Press members of Tennessee, in annual meeting here, as "an inspiration to all Tennesseans" in the following resolution adopted by the group:

The General Motors Corporation in April distributed 56,935 shares of common stock to employes under its stock-bonus plan, it was shown yesterday in the monthly reports of reacquired shares received by the New York Stock Exchange. The bonus reduced the company's treasury holdings from 677,039 to 620,104 shares.

IValUe of Dollar tu Exchange. The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):

The William Wrigley Jr. Company, chewing gum, is to centre its Eastern headquarters and distribution activities in the Port Authority Commerce Building, 111 Eighth Avenue, where 40,000 square feet have been leased. The space, which is one-fourth of the eleventh floor, is larger than the company's present quarters in Hudson Street. William A. White Sons were the brokers.

It remains to be seen whether the House of Representatives will accept the bill, so speedily put through the Senate, to prolong the life of NRA until April 1 of next year. This is not what the President wants. He prefers to continue NRA for two more years, after the present act expires on June 16, and meantime to make various amendments "to clarify the legislative "purpose and to guide the execution "of the law."

" Break of Hearts," an RKO Radio production with Katharine Hepburn and Charles Boyer, opens this morning at the Radio City Music Hall. "Scheherazade," the Rimsky-Korsakoff symphonic suite, will be produced on the stage as a spectacle in six scenes.

AUSTIN, Texas, May 15. -- The Texas Supreme Court gave title to the State today to the minerals in 3,901,000 acres of school land, some of it in productive oil territory, increasing by potential millions the wealth of the public free school fund.
Clair Omar Musser and his 100 players of the International Marimba Orchestra, back from a European tour, will give their first New York concert this evening at Carnegie Hall.

CHICAGO, May 15. -- The market for hogs was somewhat unsettled today, with prices generally steady to 5 cents a hundred weight lower than yesterday although one load of choice hogs sold 5 cents higher at $9.45, the top for the current movement.

GENEVA, May 15. -- The fate of the League of Nations' technical cooperation with China appears at stake in a report that Robert Haas, secretary of the League Council's China committee, is now bringing back to Geneva.

While there is no doubt that a certain portion of the broad social security plan must be funded from contributions levied against payrolls, it is a serious question whether it is practical to place the entire burden upon them, Frank L. Weil, counsel for the New York Retail Dry Goods Association, declared last night.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 15. -- Cornell's nine defeated Syracuse today 11 to 7. Captain Hafer started for the Orange, but was replaced in the sixth by Lundy after yielding a total of seven runs.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- Italy has informed the State Department through Ambassador Augusto Rosso that she may find it necessary to send a warship to the Dominican Republic if a satisfactory adjustment is not made of the case of Amadeo Barletta, her consul at Santo Domingo, who has been sentenced to jail and fined for an alleged conspiracy against the life of President Rafael Trujillo and for alleged evasion of taxes.

MEDIA, Pa., May 15. -- Coming through in the last mile, Ewart Johnston's Seafarin Dan won the Bayard Taylor Plate Steeplechase at the opening of the Spring Rose Tree Hunt meet near here today before a fashionable crowd.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP). -- Cotton consumed during April was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 462,844 bales of lint and 70,268 bales of linters, compared with 481,135 and 66,754 for March this year and 512,594 and 67,479 for April last year.

It was asking too much of the Giants to beat both Deans in one day. So they contented themselves yesterday at the Polo Grounds with drubbing the famed Dizzy Dean by 4 to 1 in the opening game of a twin bill. In the nightcap, Brother Paul came back to uphold the family honor, downing the Terrymen by the same score.

With an unusually favorable weather map for the attempt, D.W. Tomlinson, assistant to the president of TWA, Inc., expected late last night to take off from Floyd Bennett Field this morning about 4:30 o'clock to try to restore to the United States six world's records now held abroad.

A lone glossy ibis, a strikingly colorful member of a bird family that is found ordinarily only in semi-tropical or tropical climates, has been discovered foraging for food on the marshy bank of Tibbetts Brook in Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- Assembling to work out a plan of cooperation between commercial and educational broadcasters, radio station officials, educators and Federal officials presented their opinions today at the opening session of a conference called by the Communications Commission.

Harold J. Weisensee, who was known also as Harry Whitney, was acquitted in Special Sessions in Brooklyn yesterday of a charge of illegally operating as a private detective during the investigation preceding the trial of Bruno Richard Hauptmann, condemned kidnapper of the Lindbergh baby.

The College of the City of Charleston is celebrating this week the 150th anniversary of its founding. It has not been continuously open during the century and a half, but while its doors have been open it has maintained the liberal culture traditions of the American colleges of the Colonial period, reflecting the English influence.
WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP). -- A woman whose mind was improved by an operation that removed nearly the entire "thinking" portion of her brain was described to the American Psychiatric Association today.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 15. -- Harvard won a one-sided baseball game, 17 to 5, today from Columbia to even the series with the Lions in the Eastern Intercollegiate League.
BERLIN, May 15. -- The Ministry of Defense is rigidly adhering to its policy of declining to discuss or even listen to rumors from abroad dealing with the Reich's military, naval and aviation plans.
MOSCOW, May 15. -- The text of the Franco-Russian communique follows:

BUENOS AIRES, May 15. -- The United States delegation to the Pan-American Commercial Conference arrived today and immediately went to work on a preliminary study of projects to be debated at the conference. Spruille Braden, acting chairman of the delegation in the absence of Ambassador Alexander W. Weddell, distributed among the delegates work that they will handle in representing the United States on various committees.

Secretary Morgenthau's radio address on Monday night was gratifying in some respects and decidedly disappointing in others. It was gratifying in that it indicated a willingness to cooperate with other nations in the direction of stabilization of currency, but was disappointing in saying nothing about balancing the budget or how the "soundest currency on earth" can be maintained by a country which makes no move toward balancing its budget.

Klondike Iceberg, 1,100-pound bull, and Foremost Southern Girl, 1,200-pound cow, bovine members of the recently returned Byrd Antarctic Expedition, were wheeled from a freight elevator into the East Ballroom of the Hotel Commodore yesterday afternoon as luncheon guests at the annual meeting of the American Guernsey Cattle Club.

ATLANTA, May 15. -- Repeal forces in a referendum on Georgia's twenty-eight-year-old prohibition law held a lead late tonight of 8,117 votes, with indications that an official tabulation would be necessary to decide the question definitely.

Announcement that the city-wide campaign of the Citizens Appeal for the Salvation Army had brought $311,075.91 to date was made yesterday at a luncheon attended by business leaders and directors of the campaign at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway.

A drunkard may reel along on his feet, an unpleasant but harmless object. But when he reels on pneumatic tires behind the steering-wheel of a high-speed car he is a public menace. Arrest him and the question of his condition comes up before the court. Tests are demanded by his counsel. The police and the interne of the public hospital where he may have been taken admit that none has been made.

LONDON, May 15 (AP). -- The following are the Board of Trade figures for the month of April: Total imports, 59,840,000; exports of British products, 33,000,000; re-exports, 4,200,000; total exports, 37,200,000; excess of imports, 22,640,000.

Balked in its efforts to obtain conclusive evidence against underworld leaders, the New York County grand jury that has been investigating the policy racket, bail-bond practices and vice since March was reported yesterday to be ready to ask for its discharge.
