LIMA, Peru, May 15. -- Dr. Antonio Miro Quesada, managing director of the Comercio, and his wife were slain early this afternoon by Carlos Stiers, a 19-year-old student, while walking from their home in the Hotel Bolivar to the National Club for luncheon.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- President Roosevelt established by executive order the resettlement division under the work relief program, and conferred with Secretary Perkins and Gerard Swope on the Business Advisory and Planning Council's report on social security.

Your editorial "A Curious Superstition" says, in belittling those sending telegrams to the President regarding the Patman Bonus Bill, "that either suasion or intimidation will have any effect at this eleventh hour would seem to be believed by the practicers of this common form of direct democratic 'approach' or 'action.'"
ABILENE, Texas, May 15 (AP). -- A chorus of protest arose in Texas today against the United States Golf Association ruling that Miss Mildred (Babe) Didrikson may not compete as an amateur.

ALBANY, May 15 (AP). -- Criticism of commercial companies and institutions which "farm out" radium for cancer curative purposes to individuals inexperienced in its use was expressed before the radiology section of the Medical Society of the State of New York today by Dr. Herbert Quick of New York.

ST. ANNE'S-ON-THE-SEA. England, May 15 (AP). -- Lawson Little, American and British amateur golf champion, went out in a driving rain today to get acquainted with the Royal Lytham course, over which he will defend his British crown next week.

PARIS, May 15. -- The Bourse was irregular today. The market opened firm, particularly for rentes, although international stocks continued to be sold on the strength of Secretary Morgenthau's stabilization offer. Toward the end of the session, however, a sharp reversal took place, with rentes losing all the earlier gains and mostly ending below yesterday's levels.

A meeting of Code Authorities and representatives of all branches of busines to demand a two-year extension of "an improved, enforceable and efficiently administered NRA" has been called by the Industry and Business Committee for NRA Extension to be held in Washington next Wednesday, it was announced yesterday.

Commendations for the recently announced broadcasting policy of the Columbia Broadcasting System limiting the amount and type of advertising over the air were received yesterday by the radio organization from Anning S. Prall, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, Washington; Owen D. Young, industrialist; Leopold Stokowski, conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra, and others.

PHILADELPHIA, May 15. -- Hoping to gather material for the use of medical science in fighting further outbreaks of influenza, two members of the Department of Bacteriology at the University of Pennsylvania Medical School will start by airplane Friday morning for Seattle, on the way to Point Barrow, Alaska.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 15. -- The economic situation struck its low ebb in 1932 and all indications point to the conclusion "we are slowly emerging from the quagmire," according to Max Myers of Cleveland, president of the National-American Wholesale Lumber Association.
The Alton Railroad, a subsidiary of the Baltimore Ohio, was the first carrier to report for April. Its statement, issued yesterday, follows:

Steel production and scrap prices again have moved in opposite directions, the ingot output declining from 45 1/2 to 44 1/2 per cent of capacity and the scrap index rising from $10.58 to $10.67 a ton, according to weekly review by The Iron Age.
WASHINGTON, May 15. -- Openly chuckling at Secretary Ickes's "chagrin" over losing a bill recently passed by Congress, the Senate and the House today good-naturedly passed a like one.
MONTREAL, May 15 (AP). -- Jimmy Ripple drive his sixth home run of the season in the ninth inning today to give Montreal a 5-to-4 victory over Newark.

DETROIT, May 15 (AP). -- Thousands of General Motors employes returned to work today, ending the enforced furlough which cost them $2,000,000 in wages. About 18,000 of the 33,000 affected by closing of twenty Chevrolet and Fisher Body plants in a dozen cities had been recalled today, following settlement of a strike, and company officials were hopeful that the others could be returned to their posts within a week.

The Hudson Guild's "demonstration tenement apartment," designed to teach housewives how to obtain the maximum in utility, comfort and beauty in furnishing tenement flats on incomes of $15 to $25 weekly, was opened yesterday in an old-law tenement building at 434 West Twenty-seventh Street.
WASHINGTON, May 15. -- An RFC loan of $2,300,000 to the Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad Company was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission. The road had applied for $6,000,000.

Maintaining fairly even strength throughout the day, the markets moved yesterday to a higher closing. Largely ignoring the welter of rumors, suggestions and interpretations on divers subjects relating to finance, trading was conducted in methodical fashion.

A plan for the exchange of equipment-trust certificates of the Seaboard Air Line Railway Company for receivers' certificates and the refunding of receivers' certificates now outstanding was forwarded to owners of these securities yesterday by Legh R. Powell Jr. and Henry W. Anderson, receivers for the Seaboard Air Line, at the direction of the United States District Courts for the Eastern District of Virginia and the Southern District of Florida.

For the third consecutive afternoon young pianists played to 138 empty seats and one judge behind a three-paneled screen as the tournament of the National Piano Teaching Guild continued yesterday at Steinway Hall.

District Attorney William C. Dodge, in a luncheon address yesterday, vigorously criticized press reports concerning his administration, pointed to his disposition of many criminal cases and, as a "pupil" of former Governor Smith, asked the public to "look at the record."

DETROIT, May 15. -- Striving heroically to make the best of what already had been labeled as no great bargain, the Yankees contrived to bag the final game of their series with the Tigers today, 4 to 0.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 15. -- A late rally gave Fordham a 10-to-3 victory over the Rutgers nine in a twilight game today. Held scoreless for six innings, the Rams drove Cuno Bender from the box in the seventh and pushed six runs across the plate when Bus Lepine failed in a relief role.

Marshall Field Co. will join the American Retail Federation both as a subscribing member and also through membership in the National Retail Dry Goods Association, whose directors have just endorsed the project, it was stated yesterday by John McKinlay, president of the company.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 15 (AP). -- The Illinois relief crisis moved a step closer to what officials called "the danger line" tonight as the State House of Representatives failed for the fourth time to adopt legislation designed to end the deadlock.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- The experts and the newspaper files agree that Ogden L. Mills's account of the history of the gold position of the United States from January, 1932, until the President abandoned the gold standard in April, 1933, is more accurate than that of Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau.

The notorious "Protocols of the Elders of Zion" are now declared by a Swiss tribunal to be what honest and enlightened men have long known them to be, an impudent forgery and a libel. The case was brought before the cantonal court of Berne by Jewish citizens of Switzerland.
WEST POINT, N.Y., May 15. -- Army got back into its winning stride at baseball today, defeating New York University, 6 to 1.

How to collect realty taxes, a problem that has proved nettlesome to many municipalities in recent years, is the subject of a study just completed by a committee of the National Municipal League composed of lawyers, bankers and public officials.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- The House Interstate Commerce Subcommittee reached a deadlock today when it attempted to determine a policy on the Utilities Holding Companies Bill. The issue was whether it should favor outright dissolution or discouragement and regulation of such concerns.

NEWARK, May 15. -- In a gesture openly aimed at retaining here the air-mail terminus, which Mayor La Guardia is trying to have transferred to Floyd Bennett Field, New York, air transport day was celebrated at Newark Metropolitan Airport today.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., May 15. -- The athletic year of Penn Hall Preparatory School and junior college of Chambersburg, Pa., came to its climax tonight as the athletic dinner, attended by all undergraduates, directors, members of the faculty and several distinguished guests, was held at the Hotel Flanders.

Henry Abbott Jr., 41 years old the former Coney Island barker and burlesque show comedian who posed as a correspondent for a Detroit newspaper to swindle persons out of contributions to his "Reporters' Press Association," under the pretext that the money was for jobless newspaper men, was sentenced to six months in the workhouse yesterday.

The initial assault on the proposed ordinance, introduced in the Board of Aldermen by Alderman Lester Baum. limiting to 10,000 the number of taxicabs operating on the city's streets, was made yesterday by Abe Weisinger, president of the Associated Taxicab Industry, Inc.

LOUIS BROMFIELD has been doing some thinking about himself. And he has embodied the results of this thinking in a novelette (padded by the bookmaker to 274 pages) called "The Man Who Had Everything" (Harpers, $2). Because Mr. Bromfield's self-analysis is sharp, the sections of the novelette that read like an essay on failure and success and values in life are quite good.

BERLIN, May 15. -- The German Statistical Office published today an analysis of Germany's foreign trade for the first quarter of this year, which showed that imports from the United States had dropped 60 per cent compared with the first quarter of 1934.
